title: Within Reach of the Amateur, A Camera That Shouts 'Pro'

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: DEPRESSION RATES SURVEYED Hispanic and poor New Yorkers are more likely than other residents to suffer from "significant emotional distress," according to a survey released yesterday. In the survey of 10,000 residents by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, 6.4 percent of residents over all reported such distress, with symptoms like depression and anxiety. Among those with significant distress, 54 percent said they were also in poor or only fair physical health; among other New Yorkers, 17 percent said their health was poor or fair. Hispanics had a higher rate of emotional distress than other ethnic groups, at 11.9 percent, or nearly double the overall rate. Emotional problems were also more common among the unemployed and people with household incomes under $25,000. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)

title: Extraordinary Reactor Leak Gets the Industry's Attention
description: Reactor experts around the country hope that there is something unique about Reactor No. 1 at the South Texas Project here. If not, the little crust of white powder that technicians found at the bottom of the reactor vessel, a discovery that has brought operations here to a halt for the indefinite future, could be the beginning of a broad problem for the nuclear power industry.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Caroline Newhouse, a philanthropist and widow of a founder of the Newhouse communications company, misstated her age. She was 93, not 94.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Lawyers For Poor May Get Raise
description: State lawmakers agreed yesterday on legislation that would nearly double the top hourly rate paid to lawyers appointed to represent low-income defendants in Family Court and in criminal proceedings. Legislators also agreed to create a new financing system to help localities pay for the higher fees. Fewer and fewer lawyers have been willing to represent the poor, in large part because of low pay. Helene E. Weinstein, chairwoman of the Assembly Judiciary Committee, said that if the bill passed, the new rates would go into effect in January. The hourly rate since 1986 has been $25 for out-of-court work and $40 for time in court. The new rate would be $60 an hour for misdemeanor cases and $75 an hour for other cases. Separately, New York City is appealing a court ruling that ordered appointed lawyers' fees doubled and struck down the system for compensating them as unconstitutional. It was unclear yesterday what impact the bill would have on the lawsuit. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Frustrated Vaughn Offers No Excuses
description: Mo Vaughn took two pitches from the Cardinals' Matt Morris for strikes in the first inning on Tuesday night and later waved over a curveball, beginning what must have seemed like an endless walk back to the dugout. Vaughn felt nauseous during that at-bat, the result, he said, of taking supplements on an empty stomach before the game, and he became sick in the dugout runway. He was removed from the game.

title: All the Bids Were Diamonds, Once in Error, Once in Victory
description: The most astonishing auction ever produced went like this, around the table: one diamond, three diamonds, five diamonds, six diamonds, seven diamonds, double, redouble and all pass. This occurred in a London club 70 years ago, and when the dummy appeared, light dawned. The players were using a new deck that had two diamond suits and no heart suit. Remarkably, the deal had not produced any duplicated spot cards to alert the players that something was wrong with the deck.

title: British Muslims Are Seen Moving Into Mideast Terrorism
description: LONDON, May 1  After two suicide bombers in Israel were found to be British citizens, Britain faced suggestions today that young British Muslims, previously associated with militant Islamic groups in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Yemen and elsewhere, had shifted their focus to terrorism in the Middle East.

title: Drug Maker In Ireland May Revise Asset Sale
description: The Elan Corporation, the troubled Irish drug maker, will seek new buyers for two drugs that it agreed to sell to King Pharmaceuticals of Bristol, Tenn., in January for $850 million if litigation significantly delays the King transaction, Elan executives said today.

title: Hong Kong Partner Quits Joint Bid for Global Crossing
description: Hutchison Whampoa, a large Hong Kong conglomerate, announced yesterday that it was backing out of a deal to invest $125 million in the bankrupt American telecommunications company Global Crossing.

title: Nation's Largest Medical Prize Goes to 2 for Cholesterol Work
description: Albany Medical Center awarded the nation's largest prize in medicine, $500,000, today to researchers known primarily for their pioneering work on the function and control of cholesterol.

title: Ulster Peace Effort Stumbles Again as Blair Postpones Vote
description: LONDON, May 1  The faltering five-year-old peace effort in Northern Ireland stumbled yet again today when Prime Minister Tony Blair postponed a critical election, blaming the Irish Republican Army for avoiding a "very clear" commitment to end violence.

title: $55 MILLION TO McCORMICK SETTLES OVERPAYMENT CLAIM
description: McCormick & Company, the seasonings maker, said it had received $55 million to resolve its claim that it overpaid when it bought the Ducros spice business from Cereol S.A., a French company. Cereol's payment settled an arbitration claim stemming from the $379 million acquisition of Ducros, Europe's biggest spice maker, in August 2000. McCormick said less-than-expected profit and the reduced value of assets like inventories justified the lower price. McCormick of Sparks, Md., bought Ducros, which had about $250 million in annual sales and five plants, as part of a global expansion plan.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: BORLAND SHARES RISE ON STRONG FORECAST Shares of the Borland Software Corporation , whose products are used to customize computer programs, rose 13 percent yesterday after the company said its operating margin would improve by the end of the year. Borland shares, which had fallen 24 percent in the last year, rose $1.08, to $9.09. Borland said this month that its first-quarter results had missed its earlier forecast. The operating margin, excluding acquisition-related costs and other items, was 0.6 percent in the first quarter. Second-quarter profit, excluding acquisition-related costs and other items, will be 3 cents to 5 cents a share, Borland said late yesterday. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, analysts had expected the profit to be 3 cents a share, according to a survey by Thomson Financial. The second-quarter net loss will be 4 cents to 6 cents a share, Borland said.

description: The United States asked officials from 191 countries this week to reopen negotiations on a treaty meant to control the sale and use of tobacco and scheduled to be adopted a month from now at the World Health Assembly in Geneva.

title: SUNOCO AGREES TO PURCHASE REFINERY IN NEW JERSEY
description: Sunoco Inc., a leading oil refiner, agreed to buy the Eagle Point refinery in New Jersey from the El Paso Corporation for at least $130 million. The refinery, in Westville, has the capacity to process 150,000 barrels of crude oil a day, Sunoco said. The purchase price will rise to include crude oil and refined fuel inventories when the deal closes in the second or third quarter, Sunoco said. After the purchase, Sunoco, which is based in Philadelphia, will have a 29 percent share of the 1.71 million barrels of daily refining capacity in a 17-state region of the East Coast, government figures show.

title: Of 2,000 Treasures Stolen in Gulf War of 1991, Only 12 Have Been Recovered
description: After a rampage of looting of museums in Iraq in the wake of the Persian Gulf war of 1991, American and British archaeologists compiled a list of more than 2,000 stolen objects, a sad catalog of losses to the history of civilization. Eleven years later, experts say, no more than half a dozen of the pieces have been tracked down.

title: Corrections

The flag will include the state coat of arms, not the seal, and is not unique in using the motto ''In God We Trust''; the version in use since 2001 included those words. The referendum, in which voters are to choose between the new flag and the 2001 one, is nonbinding.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Presidential Transition
description: Domitien Ndayizeye, the new Hutu president, vowed at his swearing-in ceremony to fight ethnic violence, end the civil war that has torn the country for nearly a decade and steer Burundi through its transition to democracy. ''We will spare no effort to advance the peace process,'' said Mr. Ndayizeye, who took over from the Tutsi president, Pierre Buyoya, midway through a three-year period that is to lead to elections. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Greenspan Says Tax Cut Without Spending Reductions Could Be Damaging

Opponents of the large cut favored by President Bush took Mr. Greenspan's testimony as support for their position.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Voting Problems

In the November general election and the preceding primaries, the county clerk assigned thousands of voters in the Little Rock area to incorrect voting locations, and some precincts lacked adequate or accurate ballots and functioning voting machines. The grand jury, which returned no criminal charges, said that more than half the 200,000 registration forms maintained by County Clerk Carolyn Staley had outdated or incorrect data.

Mr. Morgan, 65, who has led the company as chief executive since 1977, will remain chairman, a position he has held since 1987. Applied Materials is based in Santa Clara, Calif. Mr. Splinter worked at Intel for almost 20 years and most recently led its sales and marketing group.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nantero Creates Device For Chip Making
description: Nantero, a start-up company based in Woburn, Mass., said yesterday that it had demonstrated a way for memory-chip makers to use standard equipment to mass-produce devices that surpass the speed of today's fastest memory while also retaining data when power is turned off. That ability is currently available only in slower devices known as flash memory. Nantero said that it had built a four-inch silicon wafer with an array of more than 10 billion junctions where groups of carbon nanotubes can be switched electrically to represent the ones and zeros needed to store digital data. Carbon nanotubes are tiny cylinders of carbon. Nantero said it created the device by depositing a single layer of nanotubes across the entire wafer, then etching away tubes that were too far from a junction to be switched. Nantero said that it had not yet tested the yield of working chips from the process, but it had begun talks with several chip makers it would not identify to develop a pilot production line. Electronics designers say carbon nanotubes are among several technologies that might offer a way to replace the current mix of memory chips in products like cellphones with a single chip.

title: World Briefing: Africa

Mr. Bockarie has been in hiding since his March 10 indictment by the Sierra Leone-based court for crimes against humanity. The investigator, Al White, called on the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, to turn him in or risk prosecution for harboring a war criminal. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

description: HONG KONG, May 1  Some SARS patients who appear to recover are actually late in suffering the worst effects of the disease, while many recovered patients may still have some of the live virus in their bodies when they are discharged from hospital, doctors said here today.

Oblivious to the standing ovation in a visiting arena, to the score, to anything other than their seats on the bench, John Stockton and Karl Malone, partners in time, sat and watched the end of a rout.

title: New Charges Are Expected In Enron Case
description: After more than a year of investigations into the collapse of Enron, the government will announce today the most significant indictments yet, charging eight new defendants with participating in frauds at the company, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Using The Right Mix, Give Or Take A Micron
description: CONNOISSEURS will argue about the proper size (in microns) of the hand-ground pigment in their custom paints, but most people just pick up the Benjamin Moore. Somewhere in between are the commercial luxury paints, like C2 Paints of Buffalo or FINE PAINTS OF EUROPE , which offers formulations from Schreuder, a Dutch company that makes paint for Martha Stewart's premium line. The high-pigment Schreuder enamels (far right) can make a door look ''like the fender on a Mercedes,'' said John Lahey, founder of the company. A kit with materials to paint that door is $75, including delivery; specialized brushes, center right, cost $24 to $80; www.finepaints.com or (800) 332-1556. The brush shaped like a hockey stick ($19.69) and the five-inch Bison brush, bottom left, ($26.79) are both from Janovic Plaza, the New York-based chain.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Rebel Leader Sought
description: Wanted for a campaign of rapes and mutilations in Sierra Leone and accused in the assassination of Felix Doh, a top rebel commander in western Ivory Coast, the warlord Sam Bockarie has found shelter in Liberia, the chief investigator for a special United Nations court said. Mr. Bockarie has been in hiding since his March 10 indictment by the Sierra Leone-based court for crimes against humanity. The investigator, Al White, called on the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, to turn him in or risk prosecution for harboring a war criminal. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: WHITBREAD'S PROFIT RISES The British hotel and leisure group Whitbread reported improved results for the fiscal year that ended on Feb. 28. The company, which owns the Marriott hotel chain, David Lloyd Leisure fitness clubs, and Pizza Hut and Beefeater restaurants, said that its pretax profit rose 14 percent, to 214 million ($342 million). Revenue slipped to 1.79 billion ($2.86 billion) from 2 billion ($3.2 billion).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, STEPHANIE
description: LEVINE-Stephanie. Beloved wife of George I. Levine, devoted mother of Cari Herskowitz, and Eric Lorberfeld, and loving grandmother. Services Friday at 10 A.M. at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: Economic Scene; Market forces press state colleges to raise tuition and give financial aid; politics presses to keep tuition low.
description: LAST week the trustees of Miami University in Ohio, the state's highly ranked public university, thought they had found a novel solution to the university's financial predicament. They voted unanimously to raise the tuition of in-state residents to the level charged to out-of-state residents and to give Ohio residents scholarships equaling or exceeding the per-student subsidy Miami receives from the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, SR. ELIZABETH, RSHM
description: GALLAGHER-Sr. Elizabeth, RSHM. 97, on April 29th, Tarrytown, NY. Religious of the Sacret Heart of Mary for 77 years. Served at Marymount School New York, NY for more than 40 years, first as teacher and then in business office. Served also at SHM Sag Harbor, NY and Marymount in Los Angeles, CA; Arlington, VA; Quebec, Canada; Surrey, England; and Rome, Italy. Visiting Thursday, May 1, 3:00-7:30 PM, Mass Friday, May 2, 10:30 AM, both at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown, NY.

title: Sunset in Saudi Arabia
description: At first glance, it may look as if the United States is capitulating to one of Osama bin Laden's central demands by pulling nearly all American military forces out of Saudi Arabia. Actually, the decision is an encouraging sign that the Bush administration has the confidence and maturity to act in the long-term interests of the United States and Saudi Arabia, even if it means taking some heat for overlapping with Mr. bin Laden's agenda.

title: Rome Journal; Holding Its Nose, the City Launches Tiber Taxis
description: It is easy to dwell in this city and never feel moved to gaze at the liquid thoroughfare that runs through it, or to walk along the water's edge.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Reprieve For Condemned Man
description: The State Supreme Court ordered the release of a death row prisoner, holding that he had established the likelihood that he was not guilty of murdering a fellow inmate. Prosecutors had contended that the prisoner, Joseph Amrine, was too late in submitting recantations from his accusers. The court disagreed, holding that in capital cases prisoners may at any time try to persuade courts that they have convincing evidence of their innocence. Prosecutors were given 30 days to decide whether to file new charges, and Mr. Amrine will remain in prison pending their decision. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: SENATE PASSES MORATORIUM The Democratic-controlled State Senate has passed a bill that would stop executions until June 1, 2005, so that legislators can examine the fairness of the legal system in capital cases. Last week, for the second time in five months, a state court threw out a death sentence because prosecutors had withheld important evidence. The bill now goes to the evenly divided House, where passage is expected to be more difficult. The moratorium would be the first passed by a Southern legislature, said Richard Dieter, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: First Amendment Argument Is Made in a Trespass Case
description: The city of Richmond, Va., put the streets and sidewalks in and around a crime-ridden public housing project off-limits to nonresidents in 1997 in an effort, duplicated elsewhere around the country, to control crime by controlling access.

They indeed include an auto company: DaimlerChrysler bought $100 million of stock in 2000, worth 7 percent of the company at the time.

title: Indian Point Reactors Restarted After Fire and Power Failure
description: The two plants that make up the Indian Point nuclear power complex were restarted today after a power failure on Monday and a fire on Tuesday had shut them down.

title: Brooklyn's Courthouse Gang
description: Anyone still needing a good argument why New York should choose its judges through a merit-based system need only look to the latest shameful episode in Brooklyn. Justice Gerald Garson of State Supreme Court has been accused of taking bribes to fix divorce and child custody cases that were steered unfairly to his courtroom.

title: Discord Over Efforts At Valuing Pensions
description: Bush administration officials said yesterday that the way pension values are now measured is flawed, to the detriment of the entire pension system, and that proposed fixes by corporations threaten to weaken the system even more.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: MARYLAND: RAISING PROPERTY TAX The state is raising its property tax by 57 percent, the first increase in more than two decades. The Board of Public Works, which consists of the governor, comptroller and treasurer, unanimously approved the increase. It will generate $165 million to help balance the budget. On July 1, the tax will increase to 13.2 cents per $100 of assessed value, from 8.4 cents, raising by $96 the state tax bill for a house assessed at $200,000. Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a Republican, said he would seek to repeal the increase next year. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: 'The Right to Anything'?
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including criticism of Senator Rick Santorum and a review of the reunited Doors.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Borland Shares Rise On Strong Forecast
description: Shares of the Borland Software Corporation, whose products are used to customize computer programs, rose 13 percent yesterday after the company said its operating margin would improve by the end of the year. Borland shares, which had fallen 24 percent in the last year, rose $1.08, to $9.09. Borland said this month that its first-quarter results had missed its earlier forecast. The operating margin, excluding acquisition-related costs and other items, was 0.6 percent in the first quarter. Second-quarter profit, excluding acquisition-related costs and other items, will be 3 cents to 5 cents a share, Borland said late yesterday. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, analysts had expected the profit to be 3 cents a share, according to a survey by Thomson Financial. The second-quarter net loss will be 4 cents to 6 cents a share, Borland said.

title: What's New Under the Elephant-Free Big Top
description: Cirque du Soleil, which has turned an original mix of performance elements into an international entertainment franchise, is back in New York with its latest show. Called ''Varekai,'' which, according to a program note, means ''Wherever'' in the Gypsy language, Romany, it has set up a literal camp under colorful circus tents at Randalls Island Park in the East River, where it will remain through June 22.

title: New Orleans Journal; Blues Giant Leaves the Stage In a Grand Old Jazz Funeral
description: Outrageously feathered dancers twirled along Canal Street today, and somber dirges alternated with jubilant Dixieland stomps as New Orleans staged an old-style jazz funeral on a grand scale.

title: New Shoes And Post 12 For Favorite
description: The colt began today walking in the trainer Bobby Frankel's shedrow, a three-quarter shoe on his right front foot to alleviate any pressure on a bothersome bruise and a full-blown mob outside straining for a look to see if he truly had a tender foot.

title: Tougher Job for a Prince Who Has No Slipper to Fill
description: Within the current European mania to update the ballet classics, Jean-Christophe Maillot, the artistic director and resident choreographer of Les Ballets de Monte-Carlo, has offered a bold mix of streamlined images and dancing of brazen allure.

The picture of Mr. Koolhaas's Seattle Public Library was by Lara Swimmer; the rendering of his design for the Astor Place Hotel was by the Office for Metropolitan Architecture/Herzog & de Meuron; and the rendering for Daniel Libeskind's Jewish Museum San Francisco was by Daniel Libeskind and Gordon H. Chong & Partners.

title: Link Seen in Abductions of 2 Girls in Bronx
description: The abduction of a 15-year-old girl in the Bronx this week is believed to be related to a similar abduction in mid-April, the police said last night. In both cases, the girls were rendered unconscious and driven around in a van for a few hours before being released, but were not sexually assaulted, the police said.

title: Gritty and Determined Stevens Is the Difference for the Devils
description: Scott Stevens's presence on the ice tonight did not have the same magnitude as Willis Reed's hobbling onto the floor at Madison Square Garden for Game 7 of the 1970 N.B.A. finals.

title: Washington Talk; Health Care Limps Up Political Ladder
description: The health care crisis is returning to American politics -- gradually, but inexorably, with a force that will most likely grow as rising costs and deepening cuts squeeze more and more voters.

title: Juror in First Crown Hts. Trial Remains Bitter About Ordeal
description: It has been more than a decade since Leslie King and 11 other jurors in Brooklyn acquitted Lemrick Nelson Jr. of murder and manslaughter charges in the fatal stabbing of Yankel Rosenbaum. But Ms. King said yesterday that she was not surprised to hear that lawyers for Mr. Nelson, who is being tried for the third time in connection with the attack on Mr. Rosenbaum in Crown Heights in 1991, are now changing course and saying that he did, in fact, participate.

description: Following is the text of a peace plan for the Middle East by the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations, as provided yesterday by the State Department:

title: Vanity Wins Back Its Good Name
description: THE dressing table (also called a vanity) is back. In any size room, a dressing table provides a touch of old-fashioned glamour and a private corner of calm in which to apply makeup, talk on the phone or write notes. ''A dressing table is one of the few luxuries any woman can have,'' said Mariette Himes Gomez, a New York decorator, who put one in the bedroom/sitting room she designed at the Kips Bay Decorator Show House (18 East 74th Street; 212 988-6991).

title: Bush Flies to Carrier to Deliver Speech on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  President Bush landed safely on the deck of an aircraft carrier this afternoon, no doubt to the great relief of his security people, and prepared to speak to the American people tonight about the future of Iraq.

title: Dollar Falls to 4-Year Low Against Euro
description: The dollar tumbled to a four-year low against the euro today, as weak economic data, low American interest rates and the growing federal budget deficit encouraged foreign-exchange traders to continue seeking higher-yielding currencies elsewhere in the world.

title: Tyco Finds $1 Billion More in Irregularities
description: Tyco International, the conglomerate trying to right itself after its top executives were charged with looting the company, was dealt another setback yesterday when it said that it had uncovered more than $1 billion of new accounting problems and would post a second-quarter loss as a result.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Concrete Falls On Car
description: A block of concrete fell and struck an automobile crossing the George Washington Bridge yesterday, frightening the driver and tying up traffic for hours, officials said. The driver was not hurt, said Tiffany Townsend, a spokeswoman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the bridge. Officials could not say why the concrete fell. About 11:30 a.m., the concrete block, about four feet wide by four feet long, fell from the roof of the lower level, striking a single car in the New York-bound lane, she said. Traffic leaving New Jersey was delayed extensively after officials closed the lower-level lanes. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., maker of the Tomahawk missile, said it won a $242 million contract from Greece's Air Force to provide F-16 fighter jets with equipment to jam the directional systems of incoming weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACGREGOR, VIRGINIA WYCKOFF
description: MACGREGOR - Virginia Wyckoff, formerly Virginia Wyckoff Gregg, a longtime resident of Darien, CT, passed away on March 28th in New Canaan, CT. She was born in New York City on November 17, 1908; she grew up there and in South Salem, New York. She graduated from the Brearley School and Bennett Junior College in Millbrook, New York. After the death of her first husband, David Gregg Jr., in 1978, she married James V. Macgregor, M.D., of Darien, in 1981. He died in November 1988. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club, and the Asia Society in New York City, the Noroton Yacht Club, and the Onteora Club in Tannersville, New York. She leaves two sons, David Gregg III, of Arlington, Virginia, and Arthur Watson Gregg of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, and four grandchildren, two great - grandchildren, four stepchildren, and eight stepgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 5th, at 11:00 AM, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Road, Noroton, CT 06820, or to the Brearley School, 610 East 83rd St., New York, New York 10028.

title: Mondesi's Slam and Rivera's Debut Frame Victory
description: On top of a cardboard box in Mariano Rivera's locker is a white sheet of paper with the script for his telephone switchboard recording. ''Your call is very important to us,'' one of the lines reads, ''and will be answered shortly.''

title: Accounts
description: * Toyota Motor Corp., Tokyo, to the Torrance, Calif., office of Saatchi & Saatchi, to handle creative duties for a worldwide campaign for the Prius hybrid car, which had been handled in the United States by Oasis, New York, part of Dentsu. Billings were estimated at $50 million. Saatchi & Saatchi is part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: To Get Broadband Cable, Install a Modem Yourself
description: Q. How can I install a cable modem for Internet broadband service with a kit supplied by the cable company?

title: Making Intelligence A Bit Less Artificial
description: WHEN Mike Kellogg of Chicago shops at Amazon.com, he can view a list of recommended products that match his taste in music with uncanny precision. The store knows he loves Wilco, a folksy rock band, and offers him CD's with a similar sound.

title: A Little Imagination Yields a Lot of Compact Living
description: The Architectural League of New York will display the work of the six winners of its Young Architects Forum. ''For economic reasons, they reduced habitation to a very personal scale -- small,'' said Anne Rieselbach, the league's program director.

title: House Republicans' Tax Plan
description: These are the main provisions of the 10-year, $550 billion tax-cut bill proposed today by Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Lakers Get in a Flow, Which Is Bad News for the Timberwolves
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 30 - The gaps in Minnesota's defense repeatedly opened in front of him, but Kobe Bryant refused to exploit them. Until delivering the signature play of Tuesday's Game 5 - a baseline drive past Kevin Garnett that resulted in a reverse dunk with 7 minutes 23 seconds left in the third quarter - Bryant was content to lay back.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about new treatments for eczema misspelled the name of one medication. It is Elidel, not Eladil.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tyco, Once More, Makes a Change In Its Accounting
description: Tyco International has decided to account for one of its most important lines of business in a conservative manner -- but made the change only after struggling for months to avoid doing so. Moreover, it has done so in a confusing way that exaggerates current expenses.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CAMDEN: DOCTOR ACCUSED OF FRAUD A doctor whose license was temporarily suspended last year has been indicted on federal charges of fraud. The doctor, Edward Andujar, is president of a clinic called Medi-One Stop. In 1998 the clinic, owing about $2.8 million, filed for bankruptcy. Dr. Andujar is accused of depositing company checks in his personal bank account and diverting $106,000 to himself through a third party, his father. Prosecutors said he failed to disclose these transactions. Last year, the state Board of Medical Examiners suspended Dr. Andujar's license for two months after reports that he operated an unsanitary office and an unregistered narcotics program. His lawyer, William DeStefano, predicted that a jury would acquit Dr. Andujar.

title: Online Piper, Payable By the Tune
description: EVERY so often some gifted thinker stares at a long-entrenched product or tradition, and with sudden inspiration redesigns it and changes the world for the better. Thanks to these little moments of brilliance, society now takes for granted such advances as self-adhesive postage stamps, seedless watermelon and waxed dental floss.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: BANK'S INCOME RISES Chohung Bank, South Korea's fifth-largest bank, reported net income of 62.4 billion won ($51 million) in the first quarter of this year, more than three times its income a year earlier, when the bank posted a one-time charge of 40 billion won to reflect the decline in the value of its investment in Hynix Semiconductor. The improved result may help the South Korean government get a higher price as it tries to sell an 80 percent stake in Chohung. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Airborne Reports a Loss
description: Airborne Inc., the shipping company, had a first-quarter loss of $5.6 million as costs rose and it handled fewer air shipments.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about charges brought by the Serbian police against the suspected assassins of prime minister Zoran Djindjic misstated the name of one of the accused. He is Milorad Lukic, not Mile Lukovic.

title: Bush Won't Declare Victory in Speech
description: Washington (CNN) -- When President Bush addresses the nation Thursday night from the deck of an aircraft carrier, he will tout the success of the U.S.- led war in Iraq and declare that major combat is over, but stop short of a formal declaration of victory, White House aides said.

title: Pippen Helps Blazers Avoid Elimination
description: Amid controversy and an injury, Scottie Pippen returned to the Portland lineup to help the Trail Blazers stave off elimination tonight in their first-round playoff series with the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Guggenheim Grows: The Next Stop Is Rio
description: At a time of budget cuts, staff reductions and sagging attendance at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York, Thomas Krens, its director, has been focusing on increasing the Guggenheim's international presence. Yesterday he and Cesar Maia, the mayor of Rio de Janeiro, signed an agreement to build a $130 million museum on Mau Pier in Guanabara Bay. Rio will be the sixth city with Guggenheim museums and exhibition spaces, joining Berlin; Venice; Las Vegas; and Bilbao, Spain, as well as New York.

title: U.S. AND PARTNERS PRESENT PROPOSAL FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: A diplomatic coalition that includes the United States formally presented Israeli and Palestinian leaders with a detailed peace plan today, opening a fresh pursuit of an end to the bitter conflict as a new Palestinian government took office.

title: Ancient Architecture in Ohio Has a 3-D Rebirth
description: SOME of these monuments were wonders of the ancient world, experts say, along with the Parthenon, the Pyramids and the Colosseum.

title: Anthrax Is Found Similar To Common Soil Bacterium
description: Scientists have decoded the genome of the anthrax bacterium and found that it closely resembles that of a common soil bacterium.

title: United Machinists' Union Approves Pay Concessions
description: The machinists' union at United Airlines said yesterday that its members had voted to give the company $794 million a year in wage and benefit concessions for six years.

title: S.E.C. Chastises Morgan Stanley's Chief for Comments
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission has chastised the chief executive of Morgan Stanley for his comments on the settlement that Wall Street firms reached with the S.E.C., and the brokerage firm executive backed away from his comments today.

title: May Day in Beijing: Not Everything Is Changed by SARS
description: BEIJING, May 1  Today, as every day, an imploring crowd milled outside the iron gates of the Communist Party's central discipline office. These 50 or 60 people, from all over the country, had journeyed to the capital in the hope of righting some heartfelt injustice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, FREDERICK HARRIS
description: GOLDIN-Frederick Harris, 85, of Palm Beach, New York City and Westhampton Beach. Survived by loving daughters, Leslie Goldin and Anne Dee Goldin, adored granddaughter, Michaela Goldin, and loving companion, Renee Meisel. Services at The Riverside, 180 W. 76th St., NYC, on Friday, May 2nd, at 11:15 AM. For information: 1-800-844-0980.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Visits 2 Cities in Iraq, Meeting Troops
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld rode through the streets of the conquered Iraqi capital today, six weeks after the United States began the war to topple Saddam Hussein, and he saw for the first time the results of the military campaign he had waged from the Pentagon.

title: Attempt to Block Higher Fare Is to Go Before Judge Today
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan will hear arguments today in a lawsuit that seeks to stop the imminent transit fare increase, on the ground that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misled the public about the true nature of its finances.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Canon Posts Profit
description: Profit at Canon more than doubled in the first three months of this year, helped by strong sales of its digital cameras and color printers. Canon, Japan's largest maker of office equipment, earned 72 billion yen ($605 million) in the quarter, which ended March 31. Sales rose to 732 billion yen from 651 billion yen. Canon said a cost-cutting program generated twice the expected 10 billion yen in savings for the period. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; High Ground Can Resemble Shifting Sand
description: The trouble with taking the moral high ground in college athletics is that its height is too adjustable.

title: After Industry Protests, South Africa Softens Mining Law
description: The South African government softened its stand today on a new mining law that had drawn howls of protest from the mining industry, the mainstay of the country's economy.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BCE Posts 54% Increase In Net Earnings
description: Citing strong demand for high-speed Internet services and a tight rein on capital spending, BCE Inc., whose Bell Canada unit dominates Canada's telecommunications market, reported a 54 percent rise in first-quarter net earnings, to 458 million Canadian dollars ($319 million). The group, based in Montreal, also benefited from the recent strength in the Canadian dollar and last year's purchase of the 20 percent of Bell Canada that it did not already own. Michael Sabia, BCE's chief executive, has focused on the telephone business and on strengthening BCE's balance sheet since he took over a year ago, stalling an earlier drive to turn the company into a multimedia conglomerate. BCE confirmed its 2003 earnings estimate of 1.85 to 1.95 Canadian dollars a share, excluding special items. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Ralph Lauren Feud Muddles Outlook for Jones Apparel
description: While the Jones Apparel Group posted solid first-quarter results this week, some analysts are wondering whether the company can sustain its performance in light of a lingering feud with Ralph Lauren.

title: Bucks' Payton Promises to Play in Pain
description: ST. FRANCIS, Wis., April 30 - Gary Payton walked gingerly along the sideline of the Milwaukee Bucks' practice court today, heading to the locker room for treatment as his teammates completed what could be their final practice of the season.

title: Russia Closes File on Three 1999 Bombings
description: The office of Russia's prosecutor general unexpectedly announced today that it had closed its investigation into three apartment bombings in September 1999 that killed 243 people and wounded 1,742 others.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: Suit On Civil Unions
description: The A.C.L.U. has filed a federal lawsuit challenging a section of the state Constitution that bans not only same-sex marriage but also civil unions and domestic partnerships. The suit says that Article I, Section 29, added in 2000, is the only one of its kind in the country and discriminates against gays by preventing them from lobbying state and local agencies for health-care benefits and, for example, the right to visit partners in the hospital. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Keeping Track; On the Trail of the Invisible Leak: Meters That Measure Power Use
description: HOMEOWNERS who want to track the energy consumed by their appliances and electronic devices can turn to a new generation of compact digital power meters. The results may be surprising.

title: A First-Quarter Profit Reported by Clear Channel
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc., the biggest owner of radio stations in the United States, said today that it reversed a loss in the first quarter as expenses fell and sales rose.

title: TIVO NAMES FORMER NBC EXECUTIVE AS PRESIDENT
description: TiVo Inc., which makes a video recorder that can pause and replay television programs, named a former NBC executive vice president, Martin Yudkovitz, as its president. Mr. Yudkovitz resigned from NBC, where he had served for about 20 years, helping create the CNBC and MSNBC cable networks and the MSNBC.com Internet site, TiVo said. He succeeds Morgan Guenther, who resigned in January after three years at the company. TiVo, which is based in Alviso, Calif., is trying to increase subscriptions to its $12.95-a-month service, which helps customers find and record favorite shows.

title: Typing With Two Hands, No Fingers
description: It was a malady known to few when typewriters ruled the office. But as computers became ubiquitous, more people learned about carpal tunnel syndrome, pain attributed at least partly to repetitive movement of the wrist and fingers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Agency To Raise Bank Stake
description: The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation plans to increase its stake in the Korea First Bank and become the majority shareholder, displacing the investment company Newbridge Capital. The Korean agency plans to exercise warrants on bonds purchased three years ago, increasing its stake to 51.4 percent from 49 percent. Weijian Shan, managing director of Newbridge Capital in Hong Kong, said Newbridge would retain managerial control. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: More 'Goldberg' Variations, D.J. and Electronics Included
description: Uri Caine, pianist

title: CANDIE'S, A SHOE COMPANY, SETTLES S.E.C. FRAUD CLAIMS
description: Candie's Inc., which makes casual shoes for young women, and its chairman, Neil Cole, settled claims by the Securities and Exchange Commission that company revenue was misstated from 1997 to 1999. Mr. Cole will pay $75,000 to settle a suit filed yesterday, the S.E.C. said. Candies, which is based in Valhalla, N.Y., agreed to an order to cease and desist violating securities laws. The company was not fined. Mr. Cole and Candie's neither admitted nor denied the allegations. The S.E.C. said in its complaint that Candie's had prematurely recognized revenue and artificially inflated revenue through illusory sales transactions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHSTIM, THEODORE S. (TED)
description: HOCHSTIM - Theodore S. (Ted). Passed away suddenly on April 29, 2003 at home in Dallas. He is survived by his wife, Iva, children, David and Michelle Hochstim, Betsy and Rick Fijolek, Nancy and Michael Goldberg and seven grandchildren. Born July 7, 1927, attended Townsend Harris, graduated from Horace Mann, Washington & Lee and Cornell Law School. He served on the boards of the AFA, NPR Foundation and Macerich Company, Brown Brothers Harriman Trust of Texas. Services Thursday, May 1 in Dallas.

title: 12 SARS PATIENTS REPORT RELAPSES
description: Local health officials said here tonight that a dozen patients who had seemed to recover from SARS became ill again after leaving the hospital.

title: Albert Hakim, Figure in Iran-Contra Affair, Dies at 66
description: Albert Hakim, a businessman who wove an intricate web of Swiss bank accounts and dummy corporations in the Iran-contra arms-for-hostages deal, died on Friday in Inchon, South Korea. He was 66.

title: 700,000 Go on Strike in Israel, Protesting Government Cuts
description: Schools closed, airports shut down, and practically all public services ground to a halt today as 700,000 workers began an open-ended strike to protest spending cuts and mass firings proposed by Israel's finance minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Energy Department to Invite Bids to Manage Los Alamos Lab
description: For the first time, the Energy Department will seek competing bids for running Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, managed since it was created in the Manhattan Project by the University of California.

title: Yippies' Answer to Smoke-Filled Rooms
description: ON a crisp spring morning in the East Village, Dana Beal could envision a future for the Yippies, and it involved coffee and real estate. Mr. Beal, 56, has long white hair and a thick white mustache that give him the look of a character from a Civil War movie. A younger woman who gave her name as War Cry listened as he spoke. Real estate has been his continuing irritation; coffee, he hoped, might be his relief.

description: These are the main provisions of the 10-year, $550 billion tax-cut bill proposed today by Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Martha Stewart Living Says Revenue Fell 14% in the Quarter
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia said yesterday that it had posted a loss in the first quarter as government investigations into a stock sale by Ms. Stewart, its chairman and chief executive, cast a shadow across its business.

title: House Backs Vast Changes In Education For Disabled
description: The House today passed major changes to the laws governing special education for some 6.6 million children, while voting down amendments that would have eased the way for disabled children to attend private school at taxpayer expense.

title: Attack Injures 7 U.S. Soldiers in Angry Iraqi City
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, May 1  Seven American soldiers were wounded when Iraqis using grenades and small arms attacked a walled compound here early today. The attack followed two incidents in the city this week in which United States forces shot and killed a total of 17 Iraqis.

title: Man With Gun Is Shot and Killed by the Police
description: The police shot and killed a 28-year-old man early yesterday morning in a housing project in Brooklyn after he fired 17 shots into the air in what apparently was celebratory gunfire to mark a friend's birthday, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said.
