description: Evgeny Kissin, pianist

title: An Index of Manufacturing Is Down Again
description: Manufacturing in the Chicago area contracted in April for a second month as employment slid and a gauge of new orders fell to the lowest level in one and a half years, according to a survey of purchasing executives that was released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVER, HAROLD M.
description: LEVER-Harold M., of Boynton Beach, FL on April 29, 2003. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of David (Lisa) and Jeffrey. Loving grandfather of Allison. Cherished son-in-law of Henrietta Margolis. He will be in our hearts & memories forever. We will miss you dearly.

title: Iraqi Says He Stalks and Kills Baath Party Men, With Toll at 12
description: ''Things have improved,'' the man said, now that Saddam Hussein is finally gone. ''I can sleep at night now.

title: Albany Spurns Plan to Rectify Adult Homes
description: The New York Legislature has unexpectedly rejected a Pataki administration plan to make short-term improvements at adult homes for the mentally ill, instead turning over most of the proposed money to the homes' operators.

title: Shadows to Fall, Literally, Over 9/11 'Wedge of Light'
description: When the architect Daniel Libeskind described his design for ground zero to New Yorkers late last year, he said one prominent feature would be an open plaza upon which ''the sun will shine without shadow'' each year on the morning of Sept. 11.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Oil Minister Reappointed
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, has been reappointed in a reshuffle of the Saudi cabinet announced today. Mr. Naimi, 67, was first named oil minister in 1995 and reappointed in 1999. He represents Saudi Arabia, which is the world's largest oil producer, at the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Iowa St. Coach Faces Firing For Behavior
description: Faced with new and more serious accusations of inappropriate behavior by the Iowa State men's basketball coach, Larry Eustachy, the university's athletic director recommended yesterday that Eustachy be fired. Eustachy, who was suspended with pay from his $1.1 million job, has five days to appeal to the university president's office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAINE, GRAHAM B. JR., M.D.
description: BLAINE-Graham B. Jr., M.D., 84, of Cambridge, MA., April 7. He leaves his wife Sandra Lovell Blaine, a sister Lorna Halper; three daughters Christine Blaine, Victoria Blaine-Wallace and Lily Outerbridge; two stepchildren, Lexy Lovell and Douglas Lovell and eight grandchildren. A memorial service is planned Saturday, May 24, 10:30AM at Story Chapel in Mt. Auburn Cemetery.

title: Turkey Quake Kills at Least 100 and Traps Children Under Dorm
description: ISTANBUL, May 1 - A powerful earthquake leveled buildings over a wide swath of southeast Turkey today, killing at least 100 people and injuring hundreds more. The early morning temblor destroyed houses, bridges and office buildings throughout the mountanous region but it was a downed boarding school near the epicenter that seemed to tear most at the residents of this quake-prone country.

title: INSIDE
description: Greenspan on a Tax Cut

title: Father Inspires a Blueprint for a Play
description: ''My father was probably a big shadow,'' said Oren Safdie, 38, who is the son of Moshe Safdie, the architect famous for Habitat in Montreal. Oren Safdie has a degree in architecture but became a playwright. His ''Private Jokes, Public Places,'' which opens today at La MaMa E.T.C., is a four-person play about an architecture student, played by Mr. Safdie's wife, M. J. Kang, far left, who is defending her thesis. She argues on behalf of her model (for a public pool where people can swim from the locker room to the pool without parading their imperfect bodies in front of others) in front of a jury that includes a famous architect, played by David Chandler, left.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: DRESS-DOWN TUESDAY South Korean politicians wear dark suits, white dress shirts and ties. Yoo Si Min, a newly elected reformist lawmaker, tried something new. For his swearing-in at the National Assembly on Tuesday, he showed up wearing beige slacks and a white T-shirt under his navy blue jacket. His fellow legislators booed him off the podium. "This is not a night club!" shouted one legislator. "Are you planning to play table tennis here?" said another. Several lawmakers walked out in protest, accusing Mr. Yoo of "defaming the Assembly." Mr. Yoo, 44, was sworn in yesterday, in a suit and tie. "I just wanted to wear comfortable clothes when I work." he said. (AP)

title: Japan to Add More Cash to Its Economy
description: Jolted by tumbling stock prices and the economic fallout from the SARS virus, the Bank of Japan's monetary policy board said today that it would flood the markets with yet more cash and expand the range of collateral that it accepts for loans.

title: The Pistons Erupt Early And Cruise Past the Magic
description: In an embarrassing if not desperate situation, the Detroit Pistons, seeded first in the Eastern Conference playoffs, entered tonight's game at home trailing by three games to one in their first-round series against the eighth-seeded Orlando Magic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, GARY
description: RUBIN-Gary. The Officers and the Board of Trustees of the Solomon Schechter School of Queens mourn the death of Gary Rubin, husband and valued partner of Sheila Rubin, longtime member of the school's Board of Trustees and Board of Education. We extend our deepest sympathy to his children Ari, Michal, Jonah, and Bracha Rubin.

title: Correction: Georgia Flag
description: An illustration on Sunday with an article about a new Georgia state flag, which will be subject to a referendum, showed an outdated draft. Here is the current version.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 17 about the Milan furniture fair misidentified an automotive component used in a lamp by the designer Achille Castiglioni, whose work was cited as a contrast to this year's offerings. It was a headlight, not a battery.

title: Witness in January Killing Of Friend Speaks to Police
description: A young advertising executive who witnessed the killing of his friend on the Lower East Side on Jan. 12 spoke with police detectives for more than an hour yesterday after refusing to do so for more than three months.

title: How to Sidestep a Two-Pronged Vampire
description: IAN WOOFENDEN and Matt Buchman, neighbors in the San Juan Islands of Washington State, share a similar quest: to avoid wasting power in a way that most Americans unwittingly do every day.

title: Wall Street Revisionism
description: Monday's press conference detailing his $1.4 billion settlement with Wall Street firms accused of peddling tainted research should have been Eliot Spitzer's triumphant moment, but he did not exude a victor's comfort. And for good reason. Having won the war -- or at least a major battle -- against Wall Street's shoddy behavior, Mr. Spitzer, New York's attorney general, already fears losing the peace.

title: A Sofa Is a Star at the TriBeCa Festival
description: Pearl Gluck spent five years making a movie about her living-room sofa. More specifically, the film is about how, as a child, she heard about a family sofa from the 1880's, and went in search of it, all the way to Hungary. The sofa had once belonged to her great-great-grandfather, a Hasidic Jew in a village near the Ukrainian border.

title: K2, NEW OWNER OF RAWLINGS, TO BUY ABC HELMET
description: K2 Inc., which last month acquired the Rawlings Sporting Goods company, agreed to buy the ABC Helmet Company, the official supplier of protective batting helmets to Major League Baseball. The price was not disclosed. As part of the transaction, ABC's contract with the league was extended to 2008, K2 said. Rawlings is the official supplier of baseballs to the league. Rob Wolfe, president of ABC Helmet, will become part of the Rawlings management team. K2 is based in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: DRUG TO TREAT RARE GENETIC DISORDER IS APPROVED
description: BioMarin Pharmaceutical Inc. won federal approval for its first drug, a treatment for a rare genetic disorder. The Genzyme Corporation helped develop the drug. The Food and Drug Administration approved the drug, Aldurazyme, for a condition called MPS 1, also known as Hurler and Hurler-Scheie disease. People with MPS 1 lack an enzyme to clean out cellular debris, leading to lung, heart, bone and joint damage. The companies estimate that about 1,000 people in the United States have MPS 1.

title: Loss Estimates Are Cut on Iraqi Artifacts
description: Even though many irreplaceable antiquities were looted from the National Museum of Iraq during the chaotic fall of Baghdad last month, museum officials and American investigators now say the losses seem to be less severe than originally thought.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Judge Accused Of Indecency
description: A State Superior Court judge, Stephen W. Thompson, was arrested on a child pornography charge yesterday and suspended without pay by the State Supreme Court. Judge Thompson, 56, was charged after Camden County detectives searched his Haddon Township home and said they found a videotape depicting a boy under age 16 in a sex act. The pornography charge carries a maximum sentence of 18 months. Judge Thompson, who pleaded not guilty, was released on his own recognizance and barred from unsupervised visits with children. Prosecutors said they had no evidence that the judge, who is unmarried, had improper contact with children. His lawyer, Leonard S. Baker, denied the allegations and called his client ''an honorable man.'' Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Call Me Puerto Rican
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamas vs. Abbas
description: The war to determine if there will be a Palestinian state has begun.

title: SUITORS PROTEST IN FIGHT FOR TAUBMAN CENTERS
description: The Simon Property Group and Westfield America Inc. yesterday accused Taubman Centers Inc. of improperly using its share repurchase program to thwart a hostile takeover bid. The board of Taubman Centers ''is breaching its fiduciary duties'' to shareholders by using the program to increase the relative voting power of the founding Taubman family, Simon Property and Westfield said. Simon and Westfield are trying to buy Taubman Centers in a transaction that values the company at about $4.25 billion. The accusations are part of an effort to amend a lawsuit they filed in connection with the takeover battle. Taubman Centers expects a repurchase program announced Feb. 7 for $103 million to add about 7 cents a share to earnings in the first full year after completion, a spokeswoman, Joele Frank, said. ''The board of Taubman Centers cannot run the company on Simon Property's timetable,'' she said. ''The board firmly believes the share buyback is the right thing to do.''

title: Soul Music Has a New Heart In Memphis
description: Tomorrow, when the Stax Museum of American Soul Music opens in Memphis, visitors will enter through a replica of the original Stax studio, right, which was in business from 1960 through 1975. Stax is where Otis Redding recorded ''(Sittin' on) the Dock of the Bay,'' Sam and Dave made ''Soul Man,'' and Isaac Hayes cut ''Theme From 'Shaft.' ''

title: Health Care Is a Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlie Tolar, 65, Fullback Known as Human Bowling Ball
description: Charlie Tolar, the star fullback for the Houston Oilers of the old American Football League who was known as the Human Bowling Ball for charging at massive linemen on his 5-foot-6 frame, died on Monday in Houston. He was 65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NURNBERG, FLORENCE
description: NURNBERG-Florence. On April 29th, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Edwin. Devoted mother of Justine and Michael Borsuk, and Hugo and Cara. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Andrew and Stacey, Douglas and Melissa, Helena and Erica. Adoring great-grandmother of Alex and Jeremy. Services Friday, 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: CALPINE SELLS STAKE IN CALIFORNIA POWER PLANT UNIT
description: The Calpine Corporation, which produces electricity in 23 states, sold a 60 percent stake in a California power plant unit to GE Structured Finance for $82 million to help complete plants under construction. The unit leases and operates the 115-megawatt King City Power Plant in California, Calpine said. The plant produces enough power for 92,000 average homes and is fueled by natural gas. Calpine, which is based in San Jose, Calif., has shed workers, delayed plant projects and sold assets to trim debt and meet expenses after its credit ratings were cut by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's. GE Structured Finance is part of the GE Commercial Finance unit of the General Electric Company.

title: Metro Matters; Resume Spreading The News
description: IN a city where little is quite as it was, and tension sits on the collective shoulder, waiting to make its move, here are two for the happy-endings file:

title: Two Former Brokers Settle S.E.C. Case
description: Two former stockbrokers agreed today to pay more than $1 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges of illegal short selling in the stocks of about 15 companies.

title: Planning Ahead to Outsmart the Ink Guzzler
description: HERE'S a riddle. Which is cheaper, a $49 inkjet printer or a $299 laser printer?

title: Cellphones Ring Out With the Help of a Steeple
description: IN June 1973, lightning struck the steeple of the United Methodist Church in the small coastal town of Ipswich, Mass. The steeple, a prominent landmark since 1860 that appears on the town's seal, was badly damaged and had to be removed. The church lacked the money for a replacement, estimated to cost more than $100,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPAZ, MURIEL
description: TOPAZ-Muriel. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Muriel Topaz, alumna of the Dance Division, member of its faculty from 1959 to 1970, and its director from 1985 to 1992. Her caring personality and dedication to the art of dance will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: Closer to Heaven, or at Least to Home
description: ''Many props in the movie 'Far From Heaven' came from my store,'' said Gerald Nixon, right, an owner of a shop called Mr. Pink. Mr. Nixon started collecting items from the 50's and 60's years ago and, when the collection outgrew his apartment, he opened the store. Now he has 3,000 to 5,000 vintage glass tumblers ($8 to $12 each); Franciscan China in the Starburst pattern, $24 a plate; Bakelite-handle flatware, $8 to $12; and martini shakers, $45 to $180. Mr. Pink is at 223 West 16th Street, (646) 486-4147, or www.mrpinkinc.com.

title: Visa Reaches Settlement in Debit Card Case
description: Visa USA, facing a trial over its debit card fees, said last night that it had agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by retailers, two days after a similar deal was reached by MasterCard.

title: Saudi Arabia Awakes to the Perils of Inbreeding
description: When she was 17, marrying age for a Saudi girl, Salha al-Hefthi was presented with a husband.

title: An Everyday Struggle for Breath; Childhood Asthma Project Reaches Out in Harlem
description: For Sadi Fofana, nights were the worst. Days were tough, too, for a child whose asthma forced him to pause for air several times on the climb to his family's sixth-floor walk-up, a cramped home plagued by dust, vermin and drafts.

title: A Top Qaeda Member, Tied to 9/11, Is Captured
description: A top operative of Al Qaeda suspected of playing crucial roles in both the bombing of the American destroyer Cole in 2000 and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was captured in Pakistan on Tuesday along with five other terrorist suspects, American officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SIDNEY S.
description: STEINBERG - Sidney S. Brother of Howard G. and the late Mildred Kopp, Max Stern, Abraham, Leon and Joseph. Services Friday, 12 Noon, Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset.

title: Powell Urges Israel and Arabs to Follow 'Road Map' to Peace
description: MADRID, May 1  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, here today on his first trip abroad since the Iraqi conflict, said international efforts to achieve a lasting Israeli-Palestinian settlement through the proposed "road map" to peace must not be derailed by violence in the region.

title: Microsoft's Antitrust Problems Remain Unresolved in Europe
description: A senior European antitrust official said today that Microsoft had yet to resolve concerns about the way it competes in the European software market.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: BCE POSTS 54% INCREASE IN NET EARNINGS Citing strong demand for high-speed Internet services and a tight rein on capital spending, BCE Inc. , whose Bell Canada unit dominates Canada's telecommunications market, reported a 54 percent rise in first-quarter net earnings, to 458 million Canadian dollars ($319 million). The group, based in Montreal, also benefited from the recent strength in the Canadian dollar and last year's purchase of the 20 percent of Bell Canada that it did not already own. Michael Sabia, BCE's chief executive, has focused on the telephone business and on strengthening BCE's balance sheet since he took over a year ago, stalling an earlier drive to turn the company into a multimedia conglomerate. BCE confirmed its 2003 earnings estimate of 1.85 to 1.95 Canadian dollars a share, excluding special items.    Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTBETTER, FALENE SIMET
description: GOTTBETTER-Falene Simet. The Yeshiva University family mourns the loss of the beloved wife of Paul Gottbetter, a long time supporter, and mother of Franklyn (and Tracy) Gottbetter, Adam (and Lori) Gottbetter, YU Guardian and vice chairman of the Men's Division of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and sister of Linda Klein. Our heartfelt condolences to all members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Neil A. Clark, Chairman AECOM Men's Division

title: Bush's Stake in Peace
description: The Middle East peace plan plunges President Bush back into the process, and into tough political choices. News analysis, Page A8.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Depression Rates Surveyed
description: Hispanic and poor New Yorkers are more likely than other residents to suffer from ''significant emotional distress,'' according to a survey released yesterday. In the survey of 10,000 residents by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, 6.4 percent of residents over all reported such distress, with symptoms like depression and anxiety. Among those with significant distress, 54 percent said they were also in poor or only fair physical health; among other New Yorkers, 17 percent said their health was poor or fair. Hispanics had a higher rate of emotional distress than other ethnic groups, at 11.9 percent, or nearly double the overall rate. Emotional problems were also more common among the unemployed and people with household incomes under $25,000. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Teaching Kids a Lesson
description: It's still chilly in northwestern Oregon, and there's a real bite to the wind in the evenings. But for the 19,000 students in the sprawling Hillsboro public school district, summer vacation is coming real soon.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about Staff Sgt. Rodney Pullen, who chased a gaggle of geese out of the way of a Humvee in Iraq, gave his unit name incompletely. It was Company C of the First Battalion (Airborne), 508th Infantry, part of the 173rd Airborne Brigade.

title: Sharing a Ride to Work (but No Talking)
description: To the Editor:

title: Thrill Rides on the Color Wheel
description: PHILLIP MABERRY'S earliest memory is of wallpaper with large green and yellow flowers heavily outlined in black in a bedroom in his parents' home in Dallas. A dubious choice, Mr. Maberry now acknowledges. But that wallpaper, along with the vividly colored 50's furniture he grew up with, led him into a garden of fantastical colors he has never entirely left.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrest In Rap Shooting
description: The police arrested a Brooklyn man yesterday and charged him with wounding a hip-hop performer and fatally shooting a member of the performer's entourage on Friday. The suspect, Chauncey Dillon, 29, was charged with shooting Eric Mangrum, 28, who died shortly afterward at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. The rap performer, Ezekiel Jiles, 27, who performs under the name Freaky Zeeky, was wounded in the chest and abdomen. The shootings took place about 3:15 a.m., the police said, after a traffic accident on 21st Street and Fifth Avenue in Chelsea escalated into a dispute. An attempt to steal a medallion from Mr. Jiles may also have prompted the shootings, the police said. The police are also seeking a second suspect, named John Mingo, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Bush's Goal: Balancing a Host of Opposing Forces
description: The long-deferred publication today of a plan to create a Palestinian state side-by-side with Israel plunges President Bush back into direct involvement in the Middle East peace effort -- and into some tough choices that his aides admit he has avoided for at least a year.

title: Xerox Alters Tack to Win Business Back
description: Xerox yesterday announced new business copier products, expanded sales channels and a change in strategy in favor of cutting prices to regain the market share it lost in recent years as it was fighting to avoid bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Now Waning, Illness Takes Political Toll In Canada
description: A day after the World Health Organization lifted its travel warning on Toronto, the Canadian dollar and stock exchanges soared and businesses began offering discounts to lure back tourists.

title: The Out-of-Towner Who's Reshaping Downtown
description: LOST amid all the talk about Daniel Libeskind's vision for the World Trade Center site has been the important role played by the head of the City Planning Commission.

title: General Manager For Power Resigns
description: Susan Marenoff, general manager of the Power since the team's founding, resigned yesterday in the wake of the team's 1-3 start this season. The Power made the playoffs in 2001, the Women's United Soccer Association's inaugural season, but finished in last place at 3-17-1 last year. The team has won only 2 of its last 18 games.

title: Indulging Mother's Sweetest Obsession
description: FOR years no one spoke of my mother's peculiar behavior toward chocolate-covered cherries.

title: Distinctive Voices Along an Ancient Trade Route
description: Filmmakers in the Soviet Union often skirted the censors by using fairy tales or simple narratives as metaphors for political realities, peppering their plots with irony or black humor, or turning to historical events.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Senate Passes Moratorium
description: The Democratic-controlled State Senate has passed a bill that would stop executions until June 1, 2005, so that legislators can examine the fairness of the legal system in capital cases. Last week, for the second time in five months, a state court threw out a death sentence because prosecutors had withheld important evidence. The bill now goes to the evenly divided House, where passage is expected to be more difficult. The moratorium would be the first passed by a Southern legislature, said Richard Dieter, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Tours of Houses and Gardens: A Foot in the Door, for a Day
description: AS spring envelops the Northeast, show houses transformed by small armies of interior and landscape designers, and apartments and row houses offering a glimpse into history, are open to visitors. There are also tours of gardens large and small, including formal beds on estates and hidden urban courtyard gardens. Unless otherwise noted, all tours are self-guided.

title: In Speech, Bush Focuses on Conflicts Beyond Iraq
description: SAN DIEGO, May 1 - President Bush declared tonight that the military phase of the war in Iraq had ended and that the battle was ``one victory in a war on terror that began on September 11th, 2001, and still goes on.''

title: Text of Bush's Speech
description: Following is the text of remarks by President George W. Bush to the nation on Thursday announcing the end of major combat operations in Iraq:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Income Rises
description: Chohung Bank, South Korea's fifth-largest bank, reported net income of 62.4 billion won ($51 million) in the first quarter of this year, more than three times its income a year earlier, when the bank posted a one-time charge of 40 billion won to reflect the decline in the value of its investment in Hynix Semiconductor. The improved result may help the South Korean government get a higher price as it tries to sell an 80 percent stake in Chohung. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The Cost of SARS
description: SARS is not just a health problem. As fear and shutdowns curtail travel, it is devastating the Asian economy. It may seem heartless to look at a terrifying disease, for which there is neither a vaccine nor a cure, through the lens of cash. But as widespread suffering has failed to persuade leaders in both poor and rich countries to finance public health, perhaps an economic argument will carry more weight.

title: Two-Inch Latino Role Models, for Good or Ill
description: Shady, as she is known in the barrio, wears black sunglasses and a gray overcoat to disguise herself. She is ashamed to let friends and neighbors know she works as a stripper to support her son.

title: Demand Is High as Brazil Sells Bonds
description: Brazil's return to the international credit markets on Tuesday was a resounding hit with investors, who offered to buy seven times the $1 billion in bonds offered, traders and analysts said today.

title: North Korea Prompts U.S. To Investigate Nuclear Boast
description: White House officials have ordered the nation's intelligence agencies to conduct a review of whether North Korea could produce bomb-grade plutonium -- as it says it has done -- without detection by the United States, according to senior administration officials.

title: Veils or No Veils, Whatever She Wants She Gets
description: There's not one veil in sight, let alone seven. But for once, Salome's mythic dance is effective in exactly the right way: sexy as all get-out and thoroughly demoralizing.

title: A Wireless Wonder Converts Squiggles and Browses the Net
description: With the Tungsten C, Palm's line of electronic organizers continues its evolution from its origins as a scrappy little palmtop with a monochrome screen and less than a megabyte of memory into a true hand-held computer. The Palm Tungsten C comes with a beefy 64 megabytes of memory under its tiny hood, a bright color screen with 320-by-320-pixel resolution and built-in wireless networking that allows it to sense and connect to Wi-Fi networks for e-mail and browsing the Web.

title: Just Follow the No. 1672 Brick Road
description: NOW, bolder colors are back. But faced with the thousands of paint colors available, 80 percent of us default to some version of white. To bail us out, the color specialist Eve Ashcraft has agreed to share some of her secrets on how to pick those colors, and how to apply them. Trained as a fine artist, Ms. Ashcraft has selected wall paints for Steve Martin and mixed luminous glazes for Rick Moranis. She also designed Martha Stewart's first paint line, based on the eggs of Ms. Stewart's Araucana chickens.

title: Call Him a Know-It-All, He Says, but Call Him
description: ARE late-night urban revelers putting the cap on their weekends, and wrecking yours, by playing kick-the-can with the garbage receptacles stacked outside your apartment window? Did the pothole down the block swallow your car? Paying too much for lousy cable reception? Has the bulb on your favorite street light blown out again?

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Raising Property Tax
description: The state is raising its property tax by 57 percent, the first increase in more than two decades. The Board of Public Works, which consists of the governor, comptroller and treasurer, unanimously approved the increase. It will generate $165 million to help balance the budget. On July 1, the tax will increase to 13.2 cents per $100 of assessed value, from 8.4 cents, raising by $96 the state tax bill for a house assessed at $200,000. Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a Republican, said he would seek to repeal the increase next year. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Taxes and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Muriel Topaz, 70, Advocate For Written Choreography
description: Muriel Topaz, the former director of the Dance Notation Bureau and the dance division of the Juilliard School, and an authority on the choreography of Antony Tudor, died on Monday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. She was 70 and lived in Milford, Conn.

title: KOHLBERG & CO. WILL ACQUIRE OWNER OF CAMPGROUNDS
description: Kohlberg & Company, a private equity firm, agreed to buy the campground owner Thousand Trails Inc. for $113 million. Thousand Trails shareholders will receive $14.50 a share in cash, or 55 percent more than the company's $9.35 closing price on Tuesday, according to a statement. Thousand Trails, based in Frisco, Tex., was started in 1969 and has 112,000 members at 59 campgrounds in 17 states and British Columbia. Jerome Kohlberg started Kohlberg & Company with his son Jim Kohlberg after leaving Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in 1987.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the use of microchip implants to identify pets referred incorrectly to two companies marketing the technology. The companies, Trovan Ltd. and its American distributor, InfoPET Identification Systems, remain in business.

title: Mayor Gets Rescue Plan, But It Isn't His Own
description: State lawmakers were cobbling together a package of bills yesterday to rescue New York City from its budget crisis, but not in the form Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had asked for.

title: From Rural Ireland, Prose Carved With Precise Simplicity; A Writer Whose Works Painstakingly Follow The Pace of the Seasons
description: In his most recent novel, ''By the Lake,'' the Irish writer John McGahern chronicles a year in a lakeside community in rural Ireland. Compared with most novels, not much happens. No single narrative drives the book forward.

title: The TV Watch; A One-Time Media Diva Tries to Find Her Way on a New Stage
description: ''I wonder when Americans will get tired of being told what to do and think,'' Tina Brown wrote in her most recent column for The Times of London.

title: Both Houses Defy Pataki, Passing Their Own Budget
description: The State Legislature continued passing a budget today that would raise income taxes for the wealthiest New Yorkers, expand gambling in the state and collect sales taxes on Indian reservations, all part of its plan to restore spending on core services.

title: Pataki Picks His Battle
description: As Gov. George E. Pataki walked away from a routine ceremony celebrating public housing this morning, his step was light and he appeared invigorated, just a day after he declared war on the Legislature and most of the lawmakers from his own party.

title: Revised View of Gambling: Bane Is Now Boon
description: Washington State is debating whether to expand its once-a-day keno drawing to once every four minutes. The governor of Delaware wants additional slot machines at racetracks.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about changing work rules in the airline industry referred incompletely to the hours worked by pilots in a month. While contracts with the airlines limit them to about 80 hours in the cockpit, they spend additional time on other duties.

title: For Baghdad's Curbside Merchants, the War Economy Is Booming
description: Shops are slowly opening along dusty Sadoun Street, Baghdad's main shopping thoroughfare. But for now most of the commercial hubbub is curbside, where opportunists and entrepreneurs are making a killing in the war economy.

title: What Price Musical Glory?
description: In todays Circuits, I reviewed the new iTunes Music Store, Apples impressive debut in the downloadable music business. No monthly fees, no minimums, and almost no restrictions to what you can do with your downloads for your own personal use. Above all, I emphasized my delight at the price: a buck a song.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I just can't picture any beef that anybody would have with any of these people. Around here, if you have a problem with someone, you walk up to them and you say, 'You made me ugly the other day.' You don't poison them.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
description: AstraZeneca, the British-Swedish drug maker, reported a decline in pretax profit for the first quarter, to $1.29 billion from $1.32 billion, largely because of increased competition from generic drugs. Sales of three of its biggest products: Prilosec, the anti-ulcer drug; Zestril, for blood pressure; and Nolvadex, a cancer treatment; were $669 million lower than in the period last year. The company, which is the second-biggest drug maker in Europe, said the decline in sales of those drugs was more than offset by a strong performance in the rest of its portfolio, where sales grew 55 percent. Sales rose to $4.74 billion from $4.35 billion. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Foster Care Caseworkers' Errors Are Detailed in New Jersey
description: It is often one of the more shocking aspects of horrific child abuse cases: the way child welfare workers ignored warning signs before catastrophe struck.

title: An established agency starts a practice to try to catch the attention of young adults.
description: MANY marketers that aim at young adults have long complained about finding that group increasingly overstimulated, hurried and hard to engage.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Britain Still Wants More
description: Gerry Adams, leader of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, Sinn Fein, reiterated that the guerrilla group would undertake no activities that would undermine the Northern Ireland peace process, but the British government said the pledge did not go far enough to meet its demand for a promise of an end to all paramilitary activity. ''The key question is, does that mean that punishment beatings, exiling, arms procurement and development, intelligence gathering and targeting are at an end,'' said a Downing Street spokeswoman. Britain and Ireland, sponsors of the accord, are seeking the far-reaching nonviolence assurances in an effort to revive the suspended Northern Ireland Assembly and hold elections to the body on May 29. The largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, has said it will not return to government with its Catholic rivals in Sinn Fein unless the I.R.A. disarms. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: The Uncolor Solution
description: GRAY has an image problem. Gray is gloomy. Dingy. Depressing. The mid-February complexion of a reclusive aunt. It consistently ranks in the bottom 5 of the 38 colors tracked for consumer preference by the Pantone Color Institute. No one likes gray. (Unless, of course, you call it titanium.)

title: Bad Plan for Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nomura Posts Loss
description: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest broker, lost 26.1 billion yen ($219 million) in the January-to-March period because of declines in stock prices. It was the first quarterly loss in six for Nomura. Stock trading commissions fell 24 percent and asset management fees fell 42 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, CEIL & IRVING
description: ROSEN-Ceil & Irving. Irving, 94, on April 25, Ceil, 90, on April 29. Married 68 years. Father & mother of Michael (Annie) and Kenneth; grandparents of Darrek (Colleen), Joshua, Caitlin, Ross, Scott and Sidney; great grandparents of Hannah, Lily, and Hunter. They will forever be remembered by those who were privileged to know them. Should friends desire, contributions to Rainbow Bridges Foundation, P.O. Box 4249, Charlottesville, VA. 22905, would be appreciated. Services were held privately.

title: Gangsters, Marijuana Smokers And Ballroom Lovelies
description: Miami City Ballet

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Doctor Accused Of Fraud
description: A doctor whose license was temporarily suspended last year has been indicted on federal charges of fraud. The doctor, Edward Andujar, is president of a clinic called Medi-One Stop. In 1998 the clinic, owing about $2.8 million, filed for bankruptcy. Dr. Andujar is accused of depositing company checks in his personal bank account and diverting $106,000 to himself through a third party, his father. Prosecutors said he failed to disclose these transactions. Last year, the state Board of Medical Examiners suspended Dr. Andujar's license for two months after reports that he operated an unsanitary office and an unregistered narcotics program. His lawyer, William DeStefano, predicted that a jury would acquit Dr. Andujar. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: A 'Top Gun' Moment
description: Even in a White House that prides itself on its mastery of political staging, President Bush's arrival on board the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln was a first of many kinds.

title: Earthquake in Turkey
description: A powerful quake hit the region, killing dozens and trapping scores of schoolchildren.

title: Fit to Be Tied (In)
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: SARS Spreading Fast in Taiwan, Which Fights to Contain It
description: HONG KONG, May 2  SARS appears to be spreading in Taiwan now as fast or faster than anywhere except mainland China, prompting a desperate effort by Taiwanese officials to contain the disease.

title: Just an Average Bland, Obsessive, Embezzling Banker
description: Losing millions of dollars doesn't seem like much of a turn-on for Dan Mahowny (Philip Seymour Hoffman), the obsessive gambler who is the protagonist of ''Owning Mahowny,'' though his losses are slightly less, since he's gambling with Canadian money.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Two Counties to Withhold Documents on Indian Point Plant
description: Two of the four counties surrounding the Indian Point nuclear power complex in Buchanan, N.Y., said today that they would not provide the Federal Emergency Management Agency with documents the agency needs to sign off on emergency plans.

title: In Full Flight Regalia, the President Enjoys a 'Top Gun' Moment
description: When the small S-3B Viking appeared on the horizon over the Pacific this afternoon, it looked for a moment like a routine flight headed for a 150 m.p.h. landing on the deck of the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln. That fiction did not last long.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I look at the members of the United States military, I see the best of our country, and I am honored to be your Commander in Chief.''

title: Alabama's New Football Coach Already Faces University Inquiry
description: When Dr. Robert E. Witt became president of the University of Alabama in March, he naturally wanted to see the football team return to its accustomed standing in the national polls. At the same time, he spoke publicly of wanting the university to drop from its perennially lofty ranking as a party school.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Threat Not Discussed
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gifted Wife Emerges From a Famous Shadow
description: Helen Torr lived to see her husband, Arthur Dove, become, posthumously, one of the most esteemed of early American Modernists, while her own paintings languished in the attic of a one-room cottage the couple shared in Centerport, N.Y. Before she died in 1967, 21 years after her husband, she told her sister, Mary Torr Rehm, to dispose of her works. ''They're no good, Mary,'' she said, ''Get rid of them.''

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The $550 Billion Question: Will Jobs Follow Tax Cuts?
description: Not wanting to be perceived as ignoring the economy in the aftermath of war, President Bush has been coaxing Congress to avoid a ''little bitty tax relief package'' and instead take drastic action. The administration's sales pitch is simple: pass at least $550 billion of the president's proposed tax cuts and fiscal initiatives, and more than one million new jobs will be added to the nation's payrolls -- virtually all of them by the next election.

title: From Olympus, Divine Dresses
description: Now this is the kind of looting we admire: old looting; remote, half-forgotten, lost-in-the-mists-of-time looting. As if the priceless rubble had been spirited away not by base temple robbers but by beauteous beings attuned to the highest spiritual calling.

title: Kyrenia Journal; Beware These Greeks? No, They're Bearing Cash
description: The people of Kyrenia, with its perfect horseshoe harbor, know something about invaders. The list reads like a Who's Who of Eastern Mediterranean history. Greeks, Romans, Saracens, Byzantines, Crusaders, Venetians and Ottomans have all held this strategic and pretty spot. The last was the army of Turkey, which landed 29 years ago and never left.

title: Monuments Recall Another Empire That Ignored Writing on the Wall
description: Saddam Hussein was hardly modest. Among the legendary Iraqi heroes whom he considered his equals were Hammurabi, Nebuchadnezzar II and Alexander the Great.

title: As U.S. Troops Quit Saudi Arabia
description: To the Editor:

title: Used Cars With Police Experience
description: IN Kansas you can find yourself a long way from anywhere, and Second Lt. John Eichkorn of the state Highway Patrol wasn't happy when his cars used to break down, stranding him far from help in freezing cold.

title: Embraces, but No Fanfare, for Jazz's Stockton
description: SACRAMENTO, May 1 — Mike Bibby waited outside the visitors' locker room so he could say goodbye to his counterpart with a bearhug. Before John Stockton, the incomparable point guard of the Utah Jazz, walked off an N.B.A. court for what appeared to be the last time, most of the Sacramento Kings embraced him, the way competitive siblings embrace at a departure gate.

title: Lessons of Anthrax Attacks Help U.S. Respond to SARS
description: The government's daily SARS briefing takes place each morning at 10:15, inside a secure high-tech command center that did not exist six months ago. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, presided on Wednesday, surrounded by 60-inch-wide plasma screens and a collection of giant maps that plot the epidemic's march around the globe.

title: Arsenic Case Is Considered Homicide, Maine Police Say
description: State investigators said today that arsenic found in coffee served on Sunday in a church just north of here had been put there deliberately and that they were treating the death of one man who drank the coffee as a homicide.

title: Incumbent Dropped From Nextel Review
description: Nextel Communications has dismissed its incumbent agency, Mullen in Wenham, Mass., by eliminating it from a review for the creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $150 million.

title: Legislators Pass Spending Bills as Pataki Whets Veto Ax
description: In another day of high drama, Gov. George E. Pataki held his third news conference in Albany in 28 hours to lambaste the Legislature for being fiscally irresponsible, even as the lawmakers continued to pass spending bills in their single-minded drive toward adopting a state budget.

title: Sally Michel
description: Katharina Rich Perlow Gallery

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: WHITE STUDENTS PLAN OWN PROM A year after their school's first integrated prom, some students at Taylor County High School have decided to hold a private event for whites. While many whites say they plan to attend next week's integrated prom, the decision to hold the whites-only prom today saddened Gerica McCrary, a senior who helped organize last year's dance. "I cried," said Ms. McCrary, who is black. After school integration, separate proms became common in the South. Taylor County, 150 miles south of Atlanta, was among the last to continue the practice.    (AP)

title: Shockey Gives Draft Pick a Passing Grade
description: Like every other draft prospect, William Joseph received the petri-dish treatment. He was measured, weighed, timed, tested, interrogated, interviewed, examined. But the Giants still did not know what they really needed to know.

title: Nassau's 'Day of Reckoning' Is Getting Closer, Leader Warns
description: Nassau County may have to cut $25 million in social service programs and lay off as many as 650 employees if other financial objectives that have so far eluded it do not materialize by the fall, according to a four-year fiscal plan released today.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: BILL ON PREDATORY LENDING SIGNED Gov. James E. McGreevey signed one of the nation's toughest bills against deceptive mortgage lending yesterday. The law prohibits predatory-lending practices like refinancing a loan to increase fees, concealing the nature of the agreement and lending without regard to the borrower's ability to repay. Predatory lenders often target low-income or elderly homeowners with poor credit histories. But critics say the provisions of the new law are so vague and onerous that they will drive risk-averse lenders from the state, drying up the market for borrowers. The leaders of AARP New Jersey, which lobbied for the bill, said it would help scrupulous lenders while protecting homeowners. (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Fire-Related Episode Withheld
description: A Providence television station has decided not to broadcast an episode of ''C.S.I.: Miami'' about a fire at a fictitious Miami nightclub caused by pyrotechnics. The CBS affiliate, WPRI, said that broadcasting the program on Monday would be disrespectful to victims of a Feb. 20 fire in West Warwick that killed 99 people and injured nearly 200. Investigators believe that fire was started by pyrotechnics. The station will instead broadcast an April 22 benefit concert. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ELLIOT
description: MILLER-Elliot. All of us at The League Treatment Center mourn our gentle, good friend Elliot Miller. An artist and sculptor himself, Elliot saw potential within each person regardless of their handicap. With his guidance and vision, he enabled each one to create stunning works of art. Elliot changed the lives of all of us who loved him. Our deepest sympathy goes to his beloved wife, Joanne and his sister Karen. Dr. Steven E. Katz, Board President and all the members of the Board of Directors, and Hannah A. Kinn, Executive Director and all of the staff of The League Treatment Center

title: Tennessee Williams's Rome, in Gritty Sepia
description: The question in ''The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone'' is whether Karen Stone knows she's ridiculous and, if so, when does she know it?

title: Players Union Accepts Change to the All-Star Game
description: Despite initial opposition to the idea, the Players Association agreed yesterday to a two-year experiment that will link the outcome of the All-Star Game to home-field advantage in the World Series.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the difficulty of tracing the more than 2,000 objects stolen from Iraqi museums after the 1991 Persian Gulf war misstated the number that have since been recovered. It is no more than six, as the article said, not a dozen.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Wylie Dufresne's first restaurant, 71 Clinton Fresh Food, was an inspired sneak attack. Working in a kitchen the size of a broom closet, Mr. Dufresne turned out disarmingly simple, elegant food that caught critics and diners by surprise. Instant stardom followed, along with breathless anticipation of his second venture, WD-50, whose name combines Mr. Dufresne's initials and the restaurant's address.

description: To the Editor:

title: Senator in Heated Exchange With Parents of Gay Children
description: Four parents of gay children had a fiery private exchange tonight with Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania. The meeting did not go well, and Mr. Santorum, who has infuriated gays by likening homosexuality to incest and bigamy, left in a hurry, tripping over a chair, the parents said.

title: Surging Rentals, Thanks to DVD
description: DVD has resuscitated video sales, and now it is reviving rentals.

title: New Alternative On Dividend Tax
description: House Republican leaders agreed to abandon President Bush's plan to eliminate all taxes on dividends, forging instead a new proposal that would reduce the taxes on both dividends and capital gains.

title: G.O.P. Fails in Bid to End Filibuster Against Texas Judge
description: The battle over judicial confirmations escalated today as Senate Republicans failed to end a filibuster by Democrats blocking a vote on President Bush's nomination of Priscilla R. Owen to a seat on a federal appeals court.

title: Charles Seliger -- 'Chaos to Complexity'
description: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery

title: Jannis Kounellis
description: Michael Werner

title: A Place for Soul Music in the American Spirit
description: The letters on the red, white and blue marquee at 926 East McLemore Avenue here spell out ''Soulsville U.S.A.,'' and they proclaim a resurrection. Thirty years ago, this was a hallowed address in American music: the former movie theater that held the studio of Stax Records. In 1989 the building was demolished, leaving a decrepit vacant lot until 2001. Now, a reproduction of the old facade is the entrance to the Stax Museum of American Soul Music, which opens officially tomorrow after a week of concerts and events.

title: Cost of Parent Coordinators Too Much for Some Parents
description: The Department of Education is moving ahead with plans to hire 1,200 parent coordinators for the New York City's public schools. But many parents remain skeptical about their impact and say the nearly $43 million cost could be better spent on classroom services.

description: Surprise in Intelligence Bill

description: CAPLOW-Alvin I. Hard to remember, harder yet to forget. Love, Mi

title: Loss Narrows For Online Ticket Seller
description: USA Interactive reported a narrower first-quarter loss yesterday based on solid revenue from its Ticketmaster, Expedia and Hotels.com businesses.

title: Aspirants For Speaker Lining Up, Just in Case
description: While the political future of the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, rests with the state's courts, several council members are already maneuvering quietly to succeed him as speaker should he not be allowed to run for re-election this year.

title: A World of Fine Art, Fashioned in Glass
description: To the Editor:

description: BosePacia Modern

title: Woods's Long Breather Is Nearing a Conclusion
description: Wearing shorts and a familiar red Nike golf shirt, Tiger Woods was at the golf course this morning at the crack of dawn, but not to work on his golf game. He was there to work on a commercial.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Court Allows Access To Ex-Leader's Files
description: Switzerland's highest court has turned down an appeal by relatives and associates of the late Nigerian dictator Gen. Sani Abacha and will allow Nigeria to have documents it seeks to track down national assets allegedly looted by General Abacha and his inner circle. General Abacha, who died in office in 1998, and his associates have been accused of siphoning $2.2 billion out of Nigeria during five years of military rule. Switzerland has frozen accounts in its banks, about $618 million, that it suspects belonged in part to Abacha family members. The government agreed last year to give Nigerian investigators details about the accounts, but opponents of the move tied up the matter in court. The court ruling will help Nigeria track down assets, but Swiss officials have said they must first receive a guarantee from Nigeria that the human rights of General Abacha's widow and two sons, who are under arrest, will be respected. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Turkish Troops Clash With Protesters at Site of Earthquake
description: BINGOL, Turkey, May 2  Security forces clashed with earthquake victims protesting the government's relief response today, but an uneasy quiet hung over a flattened boarding school on the outskirts of this regional capital as rescuers continued poring through the rubble for surviving students.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Town Bars Hong Kong Visitors
description: Citing concerns over SARS, the Town Council of Clonmel in Tipperary County has decided that the town will not be the host of the Hong Kong delegation to the Special Olympics in Dublin next month. The games, the first being held outside the United States, are expected to attract 7,000 participants and 2,000 coaches, and towns across Ireland are serving as hosts for the delegations from the competing nations. The Irish health minister, Micheal Martin, said he was disappointed by Clonmel's ''premature'' decision. Prime Minister Bertie Ahern is to meet today with Special Olympics organizers to discuss potential quarantines for some visitors to the games. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Cold Truths Behind Pomp
description: President Bush's made-for-television address tonight on the carrier Abraham Lincoln was a powerful, Reaganesque finale to a six-week war. But beneath the golden images of a president steaming home with his troops toward the California coast lay the cold political and military realities that drove Mr. Bush's advisers to create the moment.

title: City Sticks to a Strict Food Stamp Policy
description: For the second year, the city's human resources commissioner, Verna Eggleston, will refuse to accept a federal waiver that would permit single unemployed adults to receive food stamps beyond the current limit of three months in a three-year period.

title: Celtics Put On a Show To Defeat The Pacers
description: The move was so breathtaking that even the Indiana Pacers had to acknowledge its excellence. Boston's Antoine Walker, driving strong to his right while Al Harrington smothered him, lost Harrington with a behind-the-back dribble and sank a running jumper off the glass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSKOWITZ, IRA
description: HERSKOWITZ-Ira, in San Francisco at his home, on April 28, 2003, age 56, of pancreatic cancer. A Member of the National Academy of Sciences and the Academy of Medicine, he was Professor of Biochemistry and Biophysics at the University of California, San Francisco. Greatly beloved by his family, friends, and colleagues, he is survived by his parents, Reida Postrel Herskowitz and Irwin H. Herskowitz, his sister, Mara, his brothers, Joel and Alan, his nieces and nephews, Laurel Dumont, Sylvan , Alexandra, Corey and William Herskowitz, and stepnieces, Tara and Nika Makhmali. The funeral will be 11:45AM Sunday, May 4, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St (at Amsterdam Ave), NY. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Ira Herskowitz Funds, UCSF Foundation, Box 0248, San Francisco, CA. 94143.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP., Falls Church, Va., the world's third-largest maker of corporate jets, said it would close a Savannah, Ga., plant that makes Gulfstream business jets for four weeks and furlough more than 1,000 workers as it slows production to cope with a drop in demand.

title: After the Holocaust Losses, Finding Hope in Legislation
description: Fred Taucher, who lost both his parents in the Holocaust, sat down at his computer in his office in Seattle Wednesday afternoon and typed in the family name.

title: Senator Santorum And His Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: Jayson Blair, a reporter for The New York Times, resigned yesterday after the newspaper began an internal review of an article he wrote about the family of an American soldier then missing in action in Iraq and since confirmed dead. The article, published on Saturday and datelined Los Fresnos, Tex., incorporated passages from one published earlier by The San Antonio Express-News. The Times has been unable to determine what original reporting Mr. Blair did to produce it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, NANCY BULLENS
description: JOHNSON - Nancy Bullens, age 60, of Silvermine, CT. passed away unexpectedly April 29, 2003 in Richmond, VA. She was formerly of Darien, CT. Survivors include her husband Robert R. (Skip) Johnson; one daughter Wendy E. Johnson; two sons Eric S. Johnson and his wife Lisa, and Kurt A. Johnson and his wife Holly; her mother Mrs. Richard S. Bullens; one brother Richard S. Bullens, Jr.; three sisters Cindy Bullens, Debbie Bullens and Suki Meredith, and two granddaughters Madeline and Caroline Johnson. Mrs. Johnson was a tireless volunteer, an avid bridge player, a friend to all and will be deeply missed. A service and celebration of her life will be held at 1:30 PM on Tuesday, May 6, 2003 at the Congregational Church of New Canaan, Connecticut. An interment will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Jesse Fund or to the A.S.P.C.A.

title: Spotlight Is on Wedge Of Light, Symbol or Not
description: Few people who have heard Daniel Libeskind describe his ideas to rebuild the World Trade Center would dispute that his plan is largely about symbolism -- his description of his arrival as an immigrant in New York Harbor, the design of a spiral of buildings to frame ground zero and mimic the upward spiral of the Statue of Liberty, and most apparently, the 1,776-foot tower.

title: SARS Spreading Fast in Taiwan, Which Fights to Contain It
description: HONG KONG, May 2  SARS appears to be spreading in Taiwan now as fast or faster than anywhere except mainland China, prompting a desperate effort by Taiwanese officials to contain the disease.

title: Police Kill Man They Say Had Just Killed Another
description: A plainclothes narcotics detective shot and killed a Brooklyn man yesterday afternoon minutes after he saw him fatally shoot another man on a crowded Bedford-Stuyvesant street, the police said. It was the second fatal police shooting in Brooklyn in two days, and it sparked a series of tense confrontations through the afternoon between friends of the man killed by the police and officers who were guarding the crime scene.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Homeless Man Dies In Bus
description: A homeless man has been charged with murder in the asphyxiation death of another homeless man whose body was found inside a parked school bus where both had been sleeping, said an assistant prosecutor, James V. Santulli. The accused man, Domingo Morales, 29, struck Eric Morales, 23 (no relation), several times during an argument Tuesday, then sexually assaulted him, the authorities said. Afterward, he called 911 to report an unconscious man. Yesterday, Domingo Morales pleaded not guilty to charges of murder and aggravated sexual assault. If convicted, he faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Old License Plates Phased Out
description: New York drivers began facing a maximum of $200 in fines yesterday for driving with old license plates featuring the Statue of Liberty. Starting in 2001, drivers were supposed to replace the plates with new ones that have seven, rather than six, numbers and a scene of Niagara Falls, the Adirondacks or the Manhattan skyline. But some drivers of the state's almost 11 million registered vehicles did not get the notice in the mail or refused to make the change, said Joseph Picchi, a spokesman with the state's Department of Motor Vehicles. Drivers now face a fine of $50 to $200. Daisy Hernndez (NYT)

title: The Tax Food Chain; Misguided Cuts in Washington
description: The political dichotomy is breathtaking: as state and local politicians struggle with deepening deficits and rising taxes, President Bush plays the fiscal Nero, the virtuoso fiddler for ever more tax cuts. If the Washington wing of the G.O.P. is deaf to the cries of pain from the nation's statehouses, surely it must hear the measured warning from Alan Greenspan, the nation's economic guru, that new tax cuts are definitely not needed now. They will probably harm the economy, not help it, he cautions, compounding the Republicans' feckless deficit spending while pushing up the national debt along with interest rates.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 7 about financial troubles of the Mount Sinai Medical Center referred imprecisely to an accounting strategy that allowed the hospital to reduce its budget deficit in 2001. In one transaction, the hospital drew $17 million from ''capital and gift funds'' donated in earlier years. In a second transaction, $6.5 million in unrestricted gifts was transferred to the hospital from Mount Sinai's medical school, with the proviso that donors could later ask that it be returned to the school. Neither transaction involved the permanently restricted part of the institutions' joint endowment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPAZ, MURIEL
description: TOPAZ-Muriel. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Muriel Topaz, alumna of the Dance Division, member of its faculty from 1959 to 1970, and its director from 1985 to 1992. Her caring personality and dedication to the art of dance will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: U.S. Set to Name Civilian to Oversee Iraq
description: The Bush administration, seeking to resolve a bitter internal fight over the postwar governing of Iraq, plans to name a high-level civilian to direct the selection of a transitional government and take control of other functions now overseen by the military, administration officials said today.

title: What Price English Glory?
description: There is no shortage of fine dealers specializing in English antiques in New York. The list includes Florian Papp, Kentshire Galleries, Philip Colleck, Hyde Park Antiques and Clinton Howell, to name just a few. Nonetheless, yesterday's opening of a Manhattan branch of Mallett, the venerable London antiques firm, is an event in the antiques world. Mallett sells only the crme de la crme, at prices that make people faint.

title: Head Injuries Are Noted In Crash Tests Of 3 S.U.V.'s
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said yesterday that results from a side-impact crash test showed that passengers in three sport utility vehicles would have suffered a high likelihood of severe or fatal head injuries.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a debate over the Big Bang included an incorrect reference to helium by Dr. David Spergel, an astrophysicist at Princeton. In response to a letter from a reader, Dr. Spergel has informed The Times that he erred in saying the helium used in balloons today was produced in the Big Bang. That helium comes from radioactive decay of elements in the earth's crust. Most helium in the universe was made in the Big Bang, but the gas was too light to be incorporated into the earth when it formed.

description: Tina Brown's first foray into television generated more talk than ratings.

description: IN early April, just before embarking on a trip to the Bahamas, Jack and Carol Davis called Ray Lopez, who services their swimming pool in Weston, Conn. ''We told him to get it open, the sooner the better,'' Mr. Davis said.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Vote To Repeal Indian Law
description: The Boston City Council has unanimously called for the repeal of a 328-year-old law that mandates the jailing of all Indians in the city. The law remains on the books, as do all colonial laws incorporated in the state Constitution of 1780 that were not rescinded by the Legislature. The Muhheconnew National Confederacy, an Indian lobbying group, asked the City Council and the Legislature to repeal the law. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Combative Investor's New German Battle
description: Guy P. Wyser-Pratte, the tough-talking Wall Street trader and investor, likes to make life miserable for corporate executives he considers heedless of shareholder interests.

title: Powell Visits Spain to Seek More Support In Mideast
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, on his first trip abroad since the end of the Iraqi conflict, said today that international efforts to achieve a lasting Israeli-Palestinian settlement through the proposed ''road map'' to peace must not be derailed by violence in the region.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: CHURCH REVERSES BAN ON LAY GROUP Bishop Thomas V. Daily, the head of the Diocese of Brooklyn, reversed a ban yesterday on Voice of the Faithful, the lay organization formed in response to the priest sexual abuse scandals, church officials said. Voice of the Fathful groups will now be allowed to meet on church property, the diocese said. For six months, while the ban was in force, Voice of the Faithful groups in the diocese, which includes Queens, met in a college meeting room, a Baptist church and an American Legion Hall. "We are eager to get back into our parishes," said Melissa Gradel, the group's regional coordinator. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Marketers extend their holiday efforts to a Mexican celebration and even to Lent.
description: MARKETERS are rarely shy about injecting commercialism into the holidays, whether it is Christmas, Mother's Day or Valentine's Day. But a selling season based around Cinco de Mayo?

title: Park Place Returns to a Profit
description: The Park Place Entertainment Corporation, the world's biggest casino company, said yesterday that it had swung to a profit of $41 million in the first quarter, helped by a new 4,000-seat theater featuring the singer Celine Dion.

title: Ten Most Wanted Has Won the Buzz Stakes
description: Pat Day returned to Churchill Downs this morning after resting for a few days because of a minor back problem. He promptly raved about his Kentucky Derby mount, jumping aboard the Ten Most Wanted bandwagon. It's a good thing Day is small. There wasn't much room left.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Debt Review
description: Moody's Investors Service put the Sony Corporation's Aa3 long-term credit rating on review for possible downgrading, citing the company's weakened prospects to generate profits. Moody's said Sony's electronics division would continue to suffer from the effects of deflation and, despite efforts to overhaul its operations, ''Sony may take longer than expected to regain the strong profit and cash flow generation patterns seen before.'' Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPPER, DOROTHY HEALY
description: HUPPER - Dorothy Healy. Died peacefully on April 25, 2003 at her home in NYC, in her 104th year. Wife of the late Roscoe H. Hupper, a longtime leading admiralty lawyer and senior partner of the Burlingham, Hupper & Kennedy firm. Mother of John R. Hupper of NYC, Roger W. Hupper of Tampa, FL and the late Joel H. Hupper; grandmother of John R. Hupper Jr., Gail J. Hupper, Craig W. Hupper, Anne H. Gans and David R. Hupper; great grandmother of five great granddaughters and three great-grandsons. Daughter of the late Dr. Herbert H. Healy and Maud Wallace Healy of Grand Forks, ND. Graduate of the University of North Dakota; since the 1920s a resident of NYC and Martinsville, ME. Long active in and Chairman of the Music Committee of the Studio Club of the NYC YWCA. For over 50 years a member of The Blue Hill Troupe Ltd, for which she performed many of the leading contralto roles in Gilbert & Sullivan operettas. President of the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women and thereafter of the James Lenox House Association. Elder and longtime Chairman of the Public Worship and Music Committees of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. Services at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 11 A.M. on Thursday, May 8, 2003; interment thereafter at the Ridge Church Cemetery in Martinsville, ME. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the James Lenox House Association, Inc., 49 East 73rd Street, NY, NY 10021 or to the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, NY, NY 10021 would be appreciated.

title: Unemployment Rate Rose to 6% in April as 48,000 Jobs Are Cut
description: The nation's unemployment rate rose to 6 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today, as employers cut jobs for a third straight month.

title: Off-Duty Officer's Car Jumps Divider, Killing Him and Five in Crash
description: An off-duty police officer from Union County and five employees from a restaurant in Holmdel were killed early this morning when the officer's car jumped a median along Routes 1 and 9 and collided head-on with the employees' car, the authorities said.

title: Grad Students Reject Union In Yale Vote
description: The group seeking to unionize 2,100 Yale University graduate students acted as if Wednesday's poll of student sentiment would be a slam dunk. Its leaders were planning to seize on the results to pressure Yale to grant union recognition to the graduate students.

title: Judge to Hear Arguments in Suit to Stop M.T.A. Fare Increases
description: As fare increases took effect on the Metro-North and Long Island railroads, a judge said yesterday that he would hear arguments next week in a lawsuit seeking to stop the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's fare increases.

title: 36 Hours | Chicago
description: IT'S impossible to do Chicago justice in just 36 hours. So, if you have a weekend, pick one part of town to explore in depth. In the years before the post-World War II rush to the suburbs, the neighborhood around the six-corner intersection of North, Milwaukee and Damen Avenues on the city's Near Northwest Side was a classic urban retail hub. Cities and retailing both changed, though, and hubs like this began to sag. Its old buildings filled with whatever tenants would take them. Wicker Park and Bucktown, the neighborhoods south and north of North Avenue respectively, went through the familiar pattern of decay and prosperity, having been staked out by artists and other urban pioneers in the 1980's and then blossoming in the last decade into trendy and sometimes very expensive hipness. It's an area that lets you bypass the travel-guide version of the Second City and see how some of the locals might spend the weekend. DENNIS RODKIN

title: Suit Settled For Students Downloading Music Online
description: Settling lawsuits intended to strike fear in the hearts of college students who regularly download music over the Internet without paying for it, four students have agreed to pay the recording industry's trade association $12,000 to $17,000 each over the course of the next three years.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Discloses Development With Nanotubes
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had generated electrically controlled infrared light from carbon nanotubes. I.B.M. , said that output from the single-molecule devices -- which are cylinders of carbon so thin that 50,000 of them would equal the thickness of a human hair -- suggest that such nanotubes could become important materials in optical communications, sensing and other light-based applications. Until now, chip researchers have focused on nanotubes as potential replacements for silicon transistors in semiconductors as microchips shrink and, in other forms, as molecular-sized wiring. Dr. Phaedon Avouris, manager of nanoscale science for I.B.M. Research, said that one barrier to further progress was the lack of uniformity among commercially available nanotubes because the wavelength of the light emitted is tied to the precise width of the nanotube. The research by I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y., is reported in the May 2 edition of Science. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Smithsonian Is No Safe Haven for Exhibit on Arctic Wildlife Refuge
description: Things had been going along pretty well in the improbable life of Subhankar Banerjee, a native of Calcutta, India, who has become perhaps the leading photographer of one of the coldest and most uninhabited places on earth, the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Yankees' Victory Is Defined By Posada
description: There were two outs in the top of the eighth inning, and Mike Mussina looked spent. He had just gone to a 3-2 count on Ichiro Suzuki before giving up a single, and the Yankees' one-run lead was in the balance. Catcher Jorge Posada went to the mound.

title: First Rule for a Class Trip: Shuck the Chaperone
description: If you have never heard of Lizzie McGuire, you are almost certainly not a female resident of the United States between the ages of 8 and 14, and you are unlikely to be related to one. The protagonist of her own self-titled series on the Disney Channel, Lizzie, as played by the appealing Hilary Duff, is a brown-eyed, blond-haired early teenager on the brink of what will certainly be dazzling womanhood. But for the moment, she leads a life fraught with anxiety, self-consciousness and a complete lack of confidence in her ability to attract an age-appropriate member of the opposite sex.

title: Zeal for Suicide Bombing Reaches British Midlands
description: The government today identified a suicide bomber who killed three people in an attack on a Tel Aviv nightclub on Wednesday and another would-be attacker as British citizens. The acknowledgment raised suggestions that militant British Muslims, previously associated with groups in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Yemen and elsewhere, may have shifted their focus to the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANEWAY, DR. CHARLES A. JR
description: JANEWAY-Dr. Charles A. Jr, M.D. Trudeau Institute extends its sympathies for the lost of its beloved Board Member.

title: The Tax Food Chain; Painful Increases in Albany
description: New York is a textbook example of the real trickle-down effect of Bush administration policies. The president cuts taxes, sending the pain down to the state. In New York, Gov. George Pataki would himself like to avoid what he calls ''job killing'' tax increases, and to shove all the misery down the food chain to the cities and the school districts. This week the state legislators became the first politicians in the chain to behave like adults. The Assembly and Senate, in a rare show of bipartisanship, came up with a plan to fill the state's $11.5 billion budget gap partly by increasing New York's personal income tax for higher-income taxpayers.

title: Off the Blockbuster Trail, Other Angles on Matisse and Picasso
description: Visitors to the majestic Matisse Picasso exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in Queens may think that by the end of the tour they have seen both artists whole. But in Manhattan there are two much smaller exhibitions, face to face on Madison Avenue, that add something of importance to the understanding of them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Is Radio Campaign Target
description: The Municipal Labor Committee, a coalition of municipal unions, plans to begin a $100,000 radio campaign today that criticizes Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for not accepting several proposals to help cut the city's budget deficit. The ads, which will run on several all-news stations, say that the mayor is out of touch and that the proposals -- which include an early-retirement package -- would mean big savings. City Hall officials have said that most of the union proposals would save little money. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Getting Started Extra Early
description: It may feel as if spring has just sprung in New York City, but on the Hollywood calendar, today is the first day of summer -- a date defined by the first sighting of a big-budget blockbuster.

description: At least 44 people died early today when a bus filled with union members on their way to a May Day rally veered off a road and plunged into a reservoir about 150 miles south of this city.

description: GOLDIN-Frederick Harris, 85, of Palm Beach, New York City and Westhampton Beach. Husband to the late Millie and the late Alan. Survived by loving daughters, Leslie Goldin and Anne Dee Goldin, adored granddaughter, Michaela Goldin, and loving companion, Renee Meisel. He was supportive of all charities, however, donations would be appreciated to The Way Station (for mental illness), P.O. Box 3826, Frederick, MD. 21701-3826 because they lovingly cared for his son Alan. Services at The Riverside, 180 W. 76th St., NYC, on Friday, May 2nd, at 11:15 AM. For information: 1800-844-0980.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Chemical Concern Cuts Jobs
description: Imperial Chemicals, the British chemical manufacturing giant, reported a pretax profit of 52 million ($83.7 million), down 21 percent from a year ago, and said it would eliminate 700 jobs by 2005 as part of a cost-cutting plan. The company also took a 76 million one-time charge to add to its pension reserves. The chief executive, John McAdam, said he would focus on cutting costs in the paints division. Heather Timmons (NYT)
