title: House Adopts Global Plan Of $15 Billion Against AIDS
description: The House adopted a $15 billion initiative to combat AIDS worldwide today. The vote was taken after conservatives won a requirement that at least one-third of the money promote sexual abstinence before marriage.

title: Good vs. Evil, With Marvelous Muscles
description: One of the best things about the great old Marvel comic books -- aside from their graphic flair and their strenuously exaggerated ideas of human anatomy -- was the way they dramatized adolescent disaffection on an apocalyptic scale, connecting the private alienation of their heroes (and readers) with the primal struggle between good and evil. More than most film adaptations of comics, Bryan Singer's film ''X-Men'' and its new episode, ''X2,'' try to honor both the allegorical grandiosity of their source and the moods and anxieties of the superpower-endowed individuals who inhabit its universe. The mutants from whose ranks the X-Men emerge are both a persecuted minority and a tribe of lonely children, shunned and feared by the ordinary humans who surround them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Church Reverses Ban On Lay Group
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily, the head of the Diocese of Brooklyn, reversed a ban yesterday on Voice of the Faithful, the lay organization formed in response to the priest sexual abuse scandals, church officials said. Voice of the Fathful groups will now be allowed to meet on church property, the diocese said. For six months, while the ban was in force, Voice of the Faithful groups in the diocese, which includes Queens, met in a college meeting room, a Baptist church and an American Legion Hall. ''We are eager to get back into our parishes,'' said Melissa Gradel, the group's regional coordinator. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: A Heretic Amid the Hibiscus
description: I don't know that I will ever receive a formal letter of rejection from the Coral Gables Garden Club. I know of the rejection only because one of my sponsors for membership told me. description: WILKE-Viola H., beloved wife of the late Robert E. Wilke, mother of loving daughters, Karen Galvin and Pinks London, grandmother of six and great-grandmother of ten, died peacefully on April 29, 2003. A beautiful and gracious woman all of her life, she will be greatly missed by her family.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY MAY PROFIT FROM TYCO BONDS
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. bought almost $900 million of Tyco International Ltd. bonds last year when two former top executives of Tyco were charged with looting the company. Berkshire, run by the billionaire investor Warren Buffett, spent $610 million on Tyco bonds with a face value of $889 million between August and December, according to reports filed by Berkshire's insurance subsidiaries with state regulators. Mr. Buffett could earn a profit of 23 percent on about two-thirds of the bonds, convertible securities due in 2020, by selling them back to Tyco by November. Mr. Buffett's purchase was a bet that Tyco would have the cash to pay debt due this year. He took that risk even as former Tyco executives were being indicted and the company lost its investment-grade credit rating from Moody's Investors Service.

title: Lock 'Em Up
description: Right after returning from covering the war in Congo five years ago, around the time of an Ebola outbreak there, I abruptly broke into the shakes and a high fever one night. I was living in Tokyo, so a Japanese friend helpfully called the health authorities and asked what to do with a foreigner who had just emerged from the central African jungle with a high fever.

Gas Natural, Spain's biggest gas distributor, can appeal the National Energy Commission's decision to the Economy Ministry.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CORDIANT LOAN TERMS EXTENDED Cordiant Communications , the British advertising agency, reported a 12 percent decline in 2002 revenue to 533 million ($858 million) and said that it would explore strategic options for the company, which analysts said could include a sale. Still, shares rose 73 percent, to 13 pence, on the news that Cordiant's bank lenders, led by the Bank of New York and HSBC , will extend deadlines to repay loans until July 15. Cordiant has struggled under a heavy debt load and shrinking business. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: DUKE ENERGY TO SELL $700 MILLION IN CONVERTIBLE NOTES
description: The Duke Energy Corporation, a leading utility owner, plans to sell $700 million in senior notes convertible to stock and due in 2023. The proceeds from the note sale may be used to reduce short-term unsecured debt, Duke said. The announcement came one day after Duke reported a 41 percent decline in income for the first quarter, and investors feared that the issue could hurt earnings per share. Stock in Duke, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., fell 74 cents, or 4.2 percent, to $16.85 a share.

title: A Long Way From Victory
description: As presidential spectacles go, it would be hard to surpass George Bush's triumphant ''Top Gun'' visit to the U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln yesterday off the California coast. President Bush flew out to the giant aircraft carrier dressed in full fighter-pilot regalia as the ''co-pilot'' of a Navy warplane. After a dramatic landing on the compact deck -- a new standard for high-risk presidential travel -- Mr. Bush mingled with the ship's crew, then later welcomed home thousands of cheering sailors and aviators on the flight deck in a nationally televised address.

title: Melancholy Chinese Painter Is Still an Enigma After 400 Years
description: Funnily enough, although we don't know who the Chinese artist with the adopted name Bada Shanren really was, we know a lot about his life. description: Dismaying developments in three nations yesterday underscored the capriciousness of SARS, the respiratory virus that had seemed to be coming under control in many countries.

description: Among the early childhood memories of two silver-haired matriarchs of this city is a visit to Gertrude Bell, the grande dame of England in Arabia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HULTON, JANE
description: HULTON-Jane. On April 29, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Adam Hulton. Loving mother of Cam, Stephanie and Blethyn. Cherished grandmother of Colin, Rick and Philippa. She will be deeply missed by her large and loving family. Funeral private. description: President Bush declared tonight that the military phase of the battle to topple Saddam Hussein's government was ''one victory in a war on terror that began on Sept. 11th, 2001, and still goes on.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Macromedia Shares Surge On Profit News
description: Shares of Macromedia Inc., a maker of Web-design software, surged yesterday after the company reported its second straight quarter of profit. The stock climbed $4.11, or about 32 percent, to $16.81. It had fallen 43 percent in the last year. Volume of 6.31 million shares was more than six times the three-month daily average. Macromedia, which makes Dreamweaver and Flash software, has been recovering from a slump that led to sales declines for seven consecutive quarters. Revenue began rising in the three-month period that ended in December as the company, which is based in San Francisco, added new products and upgraded older programs.

title: Stores Selling Alcohol to Minors Are Named
description: The Westchester County district attorney, reacting to a series of deaths in which under-age drinking was cited, said today that she had started publicly posting the names of businesses caught providing alcohol to minors.

title: Henderson Offers Some Thrills in Opener
description: Just before the Atlantic League game between the Newark Bears and the visiting Bridgeport Bluefish last night, the New York State Lottery theme song with the refrain, ''If I had a million dollars, I'd be rich,'' played through the public-address system.

title: Judge's Ruling Does Little to Resolve Battle for Mall Empire
description: A federal judge in Michigan issued a ruling yesterday in the Simon Property Group's legal battle for Taubman Centers, but it did little to resolve the dispute.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ricoh Profit Rises
description: The Ricoh Company, the office equipment maker, said profit grew 15 percent in the January-to-March quarter, helped by strong demand for copiers and printers. Ricoh, the second-biggest office equipment maker in Japan, earned 21.1 billion yen ($178 million) in the last three months of the fiscal year, which ended March 31. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Settlement Is Seen As Changing Ways Consumers Use Debit Cards
description: The unexpected deals that Visa USA and MasterCard International made this week to settle a lawsuit over their fees are likely to restyle the robust market for debit cards, possibly reshaping where and how consumers can use them, industry experts said yesterday.

title: Gunrunners in Baghdad Take Over Open-Air Food Markets
description: In the night, there is shooting. Sharp, sudden bursts of gunfire that keep Talib Juad and his family awake and afraid. Sometimes, he said, they find bodies in the morning.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CUBA: CASTRO SAYS U.S. THREAT GROWS In a televised May Day address in front of a Havana rally of thousands of people, President Fidel Castro charged that the Bush administration was out to assassinate him or invade the country. "In Miami and Washington they are now discussing where, how and when Cuba will be attacked," he said. He also said a recent crackdown on political dissidents came about because Cuba was under threat from Washington and warned critics that their words could be used to justify an invasion. (Reuters)

title: Love Me, Love My Car
description: EVERY car buyer faces difficult questions. Should I buy the extended warranty? Do I need a DVD player? How about alpaca floor mats? But people who purchase a Pontiac Aztek face another head-scratcher: how to respond to passersby who pull up next to them and inform them -- usually in obscene terms -- that their cars are the ugliest things ever to touch asphalt?

title: Tiny Tables For Travel
description: America is, as the title of a recent book suggests, a ''Fast Food Nation.'' In some regions, the drive-through is so important that burger chains have eliminated sit-down areas altogether. But after the cashier has passed that grilled stuffed chili cheese chicken quesadilla into the car, where do you put it?

title: Iowa St. Coach Tries to Cut Damage
description: Larry Eustachy walked out his front door this morning, navigated a few dozen steps across the street, and found himself in front of an elementary school. He had been to the school before, but never under these circumstances, and never feeling such an urge to be there.

title: Nets Gain in Playoffs
description: The Nets eliminated the Milwaukee Bucks in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs last night with a 113-101 victory. Kenyon Martin scored 29 points as the Nets won the series, 4-2, and advanced to play the Boston Celtics. Boston moved on by beating the Indiana Pacers, 110-90. SportsFriday, Page D1.

title: MIRANT TO SELL NATURAL-GAS CONTRACTS TO CARGILL
description: The Mirant Corporation, a power-plant owner that is selling assets to raise cash, agreed to sell Canadian natural-gas contracts to Cargill Ltd. as part of an effort to free up $200 million in collateral. The purchase price was not disclosed. The contracts are for gas supplies, storage and transport, Mirant said. The sale is one of several that will allow Mirant to withdraw from most of its Canadian gas business, the company said. Mirant, which owns power plants in 14 states, has had to post increasing amounts of collateral with its customers since its credit rating was cut below investment grade last year by Standard & Poor's. The company said Wednesday it might go bankrupt if it cannot refinance most of its $8.9 billion in debt. Cargill Ltd. is a Canadian unit of Cargill Inc. of Wayzata, Minn. Mirant is based in Atlanta.

Within that brief span of days, the western edge of Lower Manhattan, bounded by Canal Street, Battery Park, the Hudson River, ground zero and Broadway, will be a hub of intensive -- one might go so far as to say obsessive-compulsive -- cinematic activity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Race Trial Defendant Hospitalized
description: Lemrick Nelson, the defendant in the Crown Heights racial violence trial, was rushed to a hospital yesterday afternoon when he suffered an asthma attack in the courtroom. Mr. Nelson apparently recovered quickly, however, and was back at United States District Court two hours later. Mr. Nelson, 27, has a long history of asthma -- he was hospitalized for it the night that he was arrested in the stabbing death of a Jewish scholar, Yankel Rosenbaum, in 1991. Mr. Nelson faces civil rights charges. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Australia
description: HEALTH PRODUCT BAN WIDENS Federal regulators who recalled 668 nonprescription health products this week said the final sales ban could apply to almost 1,000 items, the largest such action in the industry's history here. Pan Pharmaceuticals Ltd. of Sydney, a leading maker of medicines and supplements, has been barred from production and sales for an initial six months by the Therapeutics Goods Administration, a government monitor that has been investigating Pan's quality controls and test systems for four months. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Between War and Peace
description: Apache helicopter gunships zoomed toward a band of paramilitary fighters who were stealing crates of ammunition from an arms cache near Saddam Hussein's hometown, Tikrit. As the Iraqis tried to make their getaway, the Apaches opened fire, turning the Iraqis' truck into a hunk of twisted metal and killing 14.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pharmacy Names Executive
description: Britain's biggest pharmacy chain, the Boots Group named Richard Baker, left, chief operating officer at the Asda unit of Wal-Mart Stores, as chief executive. Boots is appointing a new chief executive five months after saying it was seeking a successor to Steve Russell, 58, amid a failed expansion. Mr. Baker, 40, will join Boots on Sept. 15, the chairman, John McGrath, said.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Priceline.com Swung To A Loss In First Quarter
description: Priceline.com Inc., an Internet seller of discount travel services, reported a first-quarter loss of $8.03 million yesterday. The company said that airline ticket sales tumbled because of the war in Iraq and consumer concerns about terrorism. Priceline.com, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., said it would ask shareholders to approve a reverse stock split. The net loss of 4 cents a share was in contrast to net income of $3.89 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 23 percent, to $200.5 million from $261.9 million, Priceline.com said. Sales of airline tickets tumbled 49 percent, for the fifth straight quarterly decline on a year-over-year basis. Shares of Priceline.com gained 15 cents, or 6.8 percent, to $2.37 during regular trading on the Nasdaq. In after-hours trading, the shares surged 42 cents, or 18 percent, to $2.70.

The landlords said one thing. The tenants said the opposite. And the gallery of ''season ticket holders,'' as the board's chairman has called the regulars in the audience, was in full-throated force, with one building owner yelling ''Continue to lie!'' at a tenant lawyer who was making a presentation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trade Surplus
description: The Commerce Ministry reported a trade surplus of slightly more than $1 billion last month on the basis of exports of $15.9 billion. The ministry said exports rose 20.3 percent from April 2002 while imports were up 18.2 percent, to $14.85 billion. The surplus, the first for a full month this year, represented a reversal from a deficit of $514 million in March. Among the export leaders were wireless handsets, motor vehicles and ships. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Bill On Predatory Lending Signed
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey signed one of the nation's toughest bills against deceptive mortgage lending yesterday. The law prohibits predatory-lending practices like refinancing a loan to increase fees, concealing the nature of the agreement and lending without regard to the borrower's ability to repay. Predatory lenders often target low-income or elderly homeowners with poor credit histories. But critics say the provisions of the new law are so vague and onerous that they will drive risk-averse lenders from the state, drying up the market for borrowers. The leaders of AARP New Jersey, which lobbied for the bill, said it would help scrupulous lenders while protecting homeowners.

title: Hunting for a Little Hope In a World Without Any
description: ''The Dancer Upstairs,'' John Malkovich's directorial debut, is a stoic tease of a movie. But it is a worthy effort because Mr. Malkovich proves his devotion to actors, lingering on them during moments of silence. The director also uses Costa-Gavras's ''State of Siege'' as both homage and reference point.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 273 Airport Screeners Laid Off
description: Newark Liberty International Airport will lose 20 percent of its 1,305 federal security screeners in a cost-reduction measure, the Transportation Security Administration announced this week. Nationally, similar cuts are estimated to save the T.S.A. $280 million, officials have said. Whenever possible, the agency will make the cuts through attrition. Poor job performance, law violations or inappropriate behavior will also result in layoffs, officials said. Qualified screeners who are let go may seek transfers, and screeners may move from full-time positions to part-time. In addition, Atlantic City International Airport will lose four screeners from its work force of 70 and the Trenton-Mercer Airport will lose 2 screeners.

But this gifted actor is no one-trick pony. The range of what is held back can extend from an aching tenderness that threatens to melt into a sobbing puddle to the violent red-eyed fury he unleashed in ''Dolores Claiborne,'' which found him delivering one of the scariest portrayals of a drunken wife-batterer ever etched on celluloid.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Music; What Defines Style in Jazz? Just Listen to the Drummer
description: As Jazz at Lincoln Center's concert seasons grow more inclusive, I've heard jazz-meets-tango, jazz-meets-flamenco, jazz-meets-samba, jazz-meets-mambo, jazz-meets-calypso. I've heard early New Orleans, hard bop, swing orchestras, Coltrane music and a tiny bit of free jazz. And through all these shows, trying to make sense of how all these kinds of music fit into jazz's lingua franca, I keep looking to the back of the stage. It's in the drumming, in the grooves, where all affinities start. It's through drumming that different cultures, and even different kinds of jazz, can become most easily cross-fertilized.

description: Kenyon Martin saw the towels printed with purple and green lettering that read ''Yes We Can'' adorning the 18,717 seats at the Bradley Center tonight. Martin, the Nets' forward, laughed, looked at the Bucks across the court, and said to himself: ''It's going to be tough.''

title: Cadet Is Accused of Running Sex Club on Government Computer
description: Reeling from a sexual assault scandal that cost its top leaders their jobs, the United States Air Force Academy is investigating accusations that a cadet ran a group sex club from his government-issued computer, academy officials said today.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: Jayson Blair, a reporter for The New York Times, resigned yesterday after the newspaper began an internal review of an article he wrote about the family of an American soldier then missing in action in Iraq and since confirmed dead. The article, published on Saturday and datelined Los Fresnos, Tex., incorporated passages from one published earlier by The San Antonio Express-News. The Times has been unable to determine what original reporting Mr. Blair did to produce it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 31 about art once owned by Nikolai Khardzhiev, a Russian critic who died in 1996, referred incorrectly to the outcome of a lawsuit brought by a gallery that had once been his dealer and had acquired some of his holdings. The suit, by Galerie Gmurzynska in Cologne, Germany, against art experts who had questioned its tactics in obtaining and selling the works, was dismissed by a United States district court. But a lawyer for the gallery, contending that the suit had not been unsuccessful, said the gallery had appealed the decision and might take up some of the claims in state courts. A letter from the lawyer brought this to the attention of The Times last month.

title: Pennsylvania Researchers Turn Stem Cells to Egg Cells
description: Scientists at the University of Pennsylvania have taken stem cell research in a novel direction, showing how the cells can be converted in the laboratory into egg cells like those produced in the ovary. The work has some theologians reconsidering their ideas about the nature of life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOLFSON, SAUL
description: WOOLFSON-Saul, 90 years. Deeply loved husband of Esther Mary (nee Beck). They had a great life together for forty-three years. He was the first public affairs specialist with the Social Security Administration. During a career that spanned 45 years, he received many awards for excellent quality of work. He defended the social security program where others feared to tread by writing letters to editors of top newspapers. He was able to obtain unprecedented free advertising such as billboard advertising in Times Square, time tables and magazines to benefit the program. He was an all around great guy.

title: Residential Real Estate; 21st Century Atop 19th In TriBeCa Restoration
description: The scaffolding that has covered the 19th-century loft building at 73 Worth Street in the TriBeCa East Historic District for the last 18 months came down on Tuesday to reveal a restored five-story Italianate building. It has been turned into 24 loft condominiums topped by a contemporary two-story addition with six penthouses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIERMAN, DR. STUART
description: FIERMAN-Dr. Stuart, on April 30th, 2003. Adored husband of Waltraud. Cherished father of Howard and fatherin-law of Joyce. Devoted brother of Dennis and Marna. Loving grandfather of Brandon. Devoted uncle of Serina and Arielle. Cherished friend to Adrianne.

title: Senator Santorum And His Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cordiant Loan Terms Extended
description: Cordiant Communications, the British advertising agency, reported a 12 percent decline in 2002 revenue to 533 million ($858 million) and said that it would explore strategic options for the company, which analysts said could include a sale. Still, shares rose 73 percent, to 13 pence, on the news that Cordiant's bank lenders, led by the Bank of New York and HSBC, will extend deadlines to repay loans until July 15. Cordiant has struggled under a heavy debt load and shrinking business. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: U.S. INVESTIGATORS SEARCH ROTECH HEALTHCARE OFFICES
description: Rotech Healthcare Inc., a provider of home respiratory products, said federal regulators searched five of its offices yesterday, looking for financial records. Federal agents served subpoenas for the United States attorney's office for the Northern District of Illinois at the company's Orlando, Fla., headquarters and four other offices in three states, Rotech said. The agents did not disclose the subject of the inquiry, the company said. Rotech said in September it would restate profit back to 1999 after discovering fake documents for medical-equipment sales by a contractor to the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: Miscellany
description: * Millward Brown, Warwick, England, owned by the WPP Group, acquired Sadek Wynberg Research, London, a market research agency. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRENDT, WILLIAM
description: BEHRENDT - William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Behrendt associated with The Times from September 1958 until retiring in December 1982.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAROONEY, JAMES J.
description: MAROONEY-James J. On April 29, age 69. Loving husband of Liane Plane for 45 years. Proud father of Lisa and Caryn, joyful grandfather of Jack and Lila, dearest father-in-law of Chris Smith and David Brunicardi. Funeral on Saturday, 2:30 PM, at St. Joseph's Church, 404 E. 87 St; memorial reception Saturday 4-7 PM, New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South.

title: The Acid Test
description: There is, alas, only one Eliot Spitzer. And while you want to stand up and cheer when Mr. Spitzer, New York's attorney general, wins another round against malefactors of great wealth, his side -- our side, unless you happen to be a corporate insider -- is losing the war.

title: Weekender | Chester, Conn.
description: CHESTER, an old mill town on the Connecticut River, used to be called Dog Town, for the abundance of stray pets said to have roamed its streets. At one point it was also proudly called the Auger Bit Capital of the World, thanks to noisy factories in and around the town center. Now, the only dog you can count on seeing downtown is Stella, the bulldog at the local liquor store, and the town has shed its industrial past and polished its rural charms to become a relaxed getaway for artists and those who like to mingle with them.

title: Peres Says New Palestinian Prime Minister 'Best Man Available'
description: WASHINGTON (CNN) -- A gun battle in Gaza occurred Thursday as hopes were rising that the "road map" peace initiative would provide an escape from the endless cycle of violence in the Middle East.

title: A World of Fine Art, Fashioned in Glass
description: To the Editor:

title: Writer of 'The West Wing' Is Resigning From the Show
description: One of television's best-known writers, Aaron Sorkin, who has led the NBC series ''The West Wing'' to three straight Emmy awards for the best drama on television, announced yesterday that he was quitting the show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Record Number Of Homeless Families
description: Despite Mayor Bloomberg's proposed $17.8 million in budget cuts, officials from the city's Department of Homeless Services said yesterday that they were prepared to handle a record number of homeless families this summer. New York City's homeless-family population has increased every summer since 1999, department officials said. This year, out of a population of 39,000 homeless individuals, the number of homeless families is expected to reach 10,000. Last year, the department's decision to convert a Bronx jail into a shelter provoked controversy. The department's commissioner, Linda Gibbs, said that the former jail on River Avenue would remain open as a shelter this year ''in the event of a prudent emergency.'' Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULLES, ALICE
description: PULLES-Alice. We mourn the death of Alice Pulles on April 24, 2003 at age 80. Born in Puerto Rico, she came to the West Side of New York in 1941. She was the first person hired as a community worker by Project FIND in 1967 to seek out and document the plight of the aged in the Clinton neighborhood. She became Supervisor of senior citizen workers and then Director of the Project FIND Coffeehouse in 1972, retiring in the 90's. Our beloved, devoted friend will be remembered always. Project FIND, FIND Aid for the Aged, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONIS, WILLIAM
description: MOONIS-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Moonis, associated with The Times from March 1977 until retiring in June 1986

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABBAY, STEPHIE
description: GABBAY-Stephie. On April 30, 2003. Devoted wife of Joseph Gabbay. Mother of three children, seven grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. She will be greatly missed.

title: Blair Delays Election in Northern Ireland, Citing Violence
description: The faltering, five-year-old peace effort in Northern Ireland stumbled again today when Prime Minister Tony Blair postponed a critical election, blaming the Irish Republican Army for avoiding a ''very clear'' commitment to end violence.

title: GUNFIGHT KILLS 12 AS ISRAELI TROOPS SEEK HAMAS MEN
description: Israeli tanks and troops charged into a densely packed neighborhood here before dawn today and killed 12 Palestinians, including wanted militants and a 2-year-old boy, according to Palestinian officials. The fierce gun battles took place hours after a major Middle East peace plan was introduced.

title: New Video Releases
description: Two Weeks Notice

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: RICOH PROFIT RISES The Ricoh Company , the office equipment maker, said profit grew 15 percent in the January-to-March quarter, helped by strong demand for copiers and printers. Ricoh, the second-biggest office equipment maker in Japan, earned 21.1 billion yen ($178 million) in the last three months of the fiscal year, which ended March 31. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: California Report Tallies Cost of 'Exit Exam'
description: One out of every five high school students in California will be denied diplomas next year if the state forges ahead with a plan to require seniors to pass an ''exit exam'' before graduating, according to a state-commissioned study released yesterday.

title: Have It Their Way
description: Today's chef whip up tomorrow's fast food.

title: Portfolio: Water's Edge
description: When the weather gets warm, one impulse transcends all cultural differences.

title: Prayers and Protests
description: Protests over the distribution of supplies after the devastating earthquake in Turkey.

title: Lincoln's Sailors Reunite With Families
description: Thousands of sailors on the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln arrived in San Diego on Friday and were reunited with loved ones after nearly 10 months in the Persian Gulf.

title: Fashion Reloaded
description: The style of "The Matrix" continues to seed popular culture, including designer fashions shown on runways for fall 2003.

title: Car Washing
description: Washing your car yourself can be fun, given the right equipment.

title: Houdon's Portraits
description: Some of Jean-Antoine Houdon's true-to-life, three-dimensional likenesses.

title: Modeling Reality
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Spring Thaw on the Subcontinent
description: People on both sides of one of the world's most volatile borders are breathing a bit easier these days. India's prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, defied bellicose politicians in his own party this week to renew diplomatic and aviation links with Pakistan. The nuclear-armed neighbors are still far from peaceful relations. But if Pakistan continues to respond constructively to Mr. Vajpayee's courageous initiative, tensions could ease, and the return of diplomats to each other's capitals could lead to productive talks over Kashmir and other issues.

title: South Carolina Takes Spotlight In Democrats' Race for 2004
description: Forget Iowa and New Hampshire. South Carolina has become the hot new early primary state for the Democratic Party. Voters here are bracing for what may be the most contested, and potentially influential, Democratic presidential primary the state has seen in years.

title: Professor, Write Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Relentless Moral Crusader Is Relentless Gambler, Too
description: William J. Bennett, author of ''The Book of Virtues'' and one of the nation's most relentless moral crusaders, is a high-rolling gambler who has lost more than $8 million at casinos in the last decade, according to online reports from two magazines.

title: U.S. Is Now in Battle for Peace After Winning the War in Iraq
description: The war in Iraq has officially ended, but the momentous task of recreating a new Iraqi nation seems hardly to have begun. Three weeks after Saddam Hussein fell from power, American troops are straining to manage the forces this war has unleashed: the anger, frustration and competing ambitions of a nation suppressed for three decades.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Scales Back
description: Acknowledging that its initial strategy of focusing on first-class and business-class travelers failed, Swiss International Air said that it would drop more routes, lay off more workers and set up a new discount short-haul subsidiary. Swiss International, cobbled together late in 2001 by the Swiss business establishment to replace the bankrupt Swissair, is losing 40 million Swiss francs a month and has been told by both its lenders and the Swiss government not to expect any fresh aid. William L. Meaney, the airline's chief financial officer, said that the airline had to direct its efforts ''not to what we think the customer wants, but what the market is telling us the customer is willing to pay for.'' Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, BERNICE
description: FISCHER-Bernice. We join the family of Bernice Fischer in mourning her passing. With the help and support of her devoted family, Bernice Fischer faced her illness with dignity and courage. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bernice's husband, Donald, their children, Jill Wallen and Mark Fischer, to Jill's husband and our esteemed partner, Daniel Wallen, to Mark's wife, Marla, and to Bernice and Donald's grandchildren, Amanda, Nicole, Michael and Amy. Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, P.C.

title: Yankees' Patience At Plate Pays Off
description: The Oakland Athletics are renowned for recognizing the importance of on-base percentage. It is a credo of the small-market A's, a team that scours the majors for bargain hitters who get on base. Those players complement a devastating pitching staff, and the Athletics win big despite a low payroll.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Prices declined as the nation's unemployment rate climbed to 6 percent, undermining prospects for an increase in fuel demand. In New York, crude oil for June delivery fell 36 cents, to $25.67 a barrel.

title: If the Yankees Are Willing, So Is Tejada
description: Miguel Tejada of the Oakland Athletics left Yankee Stadium last night with a .167 batting average and a future so uncertain that he recently voiced concerns that he might be traded.

title: Britain Arrests 6 Linked to Bombing in Israel
description: LONDON, May 3 -- Scotland Yard announced today that police from its anti-terror branch had arrested six people in England in connection with Wednesday's suicide bombing in Tel Aviv that was carried out by a Briton.

title: Half-Right on McCain-Feingold
description: A three-judge federal court in Washington issued a split decision yesterday in a lawsuit challenging McCain-Feingold, the landmark law aimed at reducing the corrupting role money plays in politics. The decision upheld important parts of the law but struck down other sections that Congress rightly considered critical to reforming the electoral process, and that fully conform to the Constitution. The Supreme Court should quickly review the case and restore the law in its entirety.

title: An American and 2 Iraqis To Assume Key Oil Posts
description: A former American oil executive, Philip J. Carroll, and two senior Iraqi oil officials are expected to be appointed on Saturday as the top leaders of the struggling Iraqi sector by American and Iraqi officials here, said people who have spoken to the Bush administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about legislation authorizing American states to require European insurance companies to make public the names of Holocaust-era customers, whose families may be eligible for benefits, misidentified the party of Representative Mark Foley of Florida, who drafted it. He is a Republican.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 20 about Ahmad Zahir, a performer known as the Afghan Elvis, referred incorrectly to a rumor surrounding his death in a car wreck 24 years ago -- that it was no accident but was set up by the family of his wife, who blamed him for her death. The rumor involved his second wife; the first one is still living. (A letter newly received by the writer from a reader in Afghanistan pointed out the error.)

title: Iowa State Suspends Eustachy Assistant
description: The problems of the Iowa State basketball program continued to grow as the university suspended its associate head coach, Steve Barnes, for making a telephone call to family members of a player asking them to support Larry Eustachy, the team's embattled head coach.

title: SARS Spreads in Taiwan; W.H.O. Plans Trip There
description: SARS appears to be spreading in Taiwan as fast or faster than anywhere except mainland China, prompting the World Health Organization to prepare to send a team there despite the risk of creating diplomatic tensions with Beijing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, BERNICE E.
description: GOODMAN-Bernice E., 75, died April 26, survived by her partner Hil Van Gogh, sister Rosemarie Tapfar, brother Harrison Goodman and many loving, grief-stricken friends.

title: In Performance
description: JAZZ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMEN, HELEN C. (NEE WHITEHORN)
description: KAMEN - Helen C. (nee Whitehorn). Born July 29th, 1917. On May 2nd she quietly died. Daughter of Liba and Leib, she departed at age 85. A loving mother, grandmother, and wife. We shall mourn her death and celebrate her life. Beloved wife of Saul. Loving mother of Paul, Michael, Leonard, and Jonathan and mother-in-law to their wives. Cherished grandmother to seven grandchildren. Devoted sister to William, Anne, and Samuel Whitehorn, and dear aunt. A brilliant teacher at the Yeshiva of Central Queens and the Birch School of Merrick, NY; she had a keen and probing intellect, and a love of the written and spoken word. She was an inspiration to her family, friends and students. She will be deeply missed. Helen was a resident of Long Island, Sarasota, Lake Luzerne, NY and Yonkers, NY. Memorial Services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St., New York City, at 1:00pm on May 4, 2003. ''Dearest wife, with heavy heart I know, that our seventy-two years of a happy marriage will persist in continuo.''

title: To the Barricades! Battles Over Spam
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq's U.S. Overseer Is Praised by Rumsfeld
description: The structure of the American administration of postwar Iraq remained unresolved today, as Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld issued a strong endorsement of Jay Garner, the retired lieutenant general whose job seemed about to be eclipsed by a former State Department official, L. Paul Bremer.

title: Psst . . . Democrats Debating Tonight
description: Political junkies may have been wondering during the Iraq war whatever became of those nine Democrats who went off to run for president? Well, they are still campaigning, even if it is 18 months until the election. What is more, they have an actual debate scheduled tonight in South Carolina that unfortunately seems to be as much a national mystery as whether Saddam Hussein is dead or alive. Sponsored by ABC News, the debate has been embargoed, with no live coverage except -- where else? -- on a cable channel inside the Washington Beltway, where the campaign ruling class regularly vets reality for the rest of us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANKINS, REEVE
description: HANKINS - Reeve. Who passed away on April 29, 2003 in Bangkok, Thailand. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 5, 2003 at 4 PM at Christ Church, Convent Road, Bangkok, Thailand. In lieu of flowers, donations to: The Reeve Hankins Scholarship Fund, Room 106 St. George's Building, Hong Kong.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a letter yesterday about homophobia and racism omitted quotation marks around a passage and thus misattributed it. It was Bayard Rustin, not the letter writer, who said: ''Twenty-five or 30 years ago, the barometer of human rights in the United States was black people. That is no longer true. The barometer for judging the character of people in regard to human rights is now those who consider themselves gay or lesbian.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Bush's flight to the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln misstated a precedent. While Mr. Bush was the first president to land in a plane on a carrier, other presidents have flown in helicopters to carriers. Mr. Bush's overnight shipboard stay was rare but not unique in the period since World War II; President John F. Kennedy, for example, spent the night aboard the Kitty Hawk.

title: Writing As a Block For Asians
description: Western theories about Chinese writing have often been tainted by ignorance and prejudice, oscillating between wide-eyed veneration and smug disdain.

title: Author and Advocate
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A New Day at the Races in Hollywood
description: The way Gary Ross tells it, instead of a bar mitzvah he was given a trip to Santa Anita. With all due respect, he makes it sound like a religious experience just the same.

title: Man Who Attended Church in Poison Case Is Shot to Death
description: A man who a fellow parishioner says attended a church in New Sweden, Me., where one person was killed and 15 others were sickened by arsenic-laced coffee died this afternoon after being shot in his home in Woodland, Me.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: AIRLINE SCALES BACK Acknowledging that its initial strategy of focusing on first-class and business-class travelers failed, Swiss International Air said that it would drop more routes, lay off more workers and set up a new discount short-haul subsidiary. Swiss International, cobbled together late in 2001 by the Swiss business establishment to replace the bankrupt Swissair, is losing 40 million Swiss francs a month and has been told by both its lenders and the Swiss government not to expect any fresh aid. William L. Meaney, the airline's chief financial officer, said that the airline had to direct its efforts "not to what we think the customer wants, but what the market is telling us the customer is willing to pay for." Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Ex-Chief of Ikea Is Named Top Executive at Royal Ahold
description: Royal Ahold, the food retailer based in the Netherlands, named Anders Moberg chief executive yesterday, filling a two-month vacuum at the top of the company and raising investors' hopes of a rebound from its recent troubles.

title: Chvez and Venezuelans
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: SARS Spreads in Taiwan

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROPES & GRAY, Boston, a law firm with about 530 lawyers, said it had acquired Reboul, MacMurray, Hewitt & Maynard, New York, a 50-lawyer firm that concentrates on private-equity work, effective May 1. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Yogurt Makers Shrink the Cup, Trying to Turn Less Into More
description: In the last few months, discerning yogurt shoppers -- of which there are quite a few -- have noticed a change. First, the single-serving size of Dannon yogurt shrank by 25 percent, to six ounces, but, in many grocers' refrigerators, the price stayed the same. Then other brands followed suit, shrinking their yogurt cups.

title: Testing for SARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Prestigious British Publisher Finds a Like-Minded Buyer
description: Peter Mayer, a founder of the Overlook Press in New York, said tonight that he had acquired Duckworth, an ailing British independent publisher that built a blue-chip reputation with authors like Virginia Woolf and D. H. Lawrence.

title: China Reports 70 Sailors Die in Submarine Accident in Yellow Sea
description: Seventy Chinese sailors have perished in an accident aboard a diesel-powered submarine on a training mission in the Yellow Sea, the official New China News Agency reported this evening without revealing when or how the disaster occurred.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage and Off column of Weekend yesterday about award nominations by the Drama Desk misstated the number received by a play this year and the number received by two musicals in previous years. ''Take Me Out'' received 8 nominations this year, not 6, and ''The Secret Garden'' and ''Ragtime'' each received 14 nominations, not 15.

title: Mixed Ruling on Constitutionality Of New Campaign Finance Law
description: In the most significant court case dealing with money and politics since 1976, a special three-judge panel today upheld several major provisions of a sweeping new law limiting political donations, but found that some of its measures were unconstitutional.

title: Alabama Fires New Football Coach
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., May 3 — Mike Price's career at the University of Alabama ended today before he ever coached a football game for the Crimson Tide, self-destructing upon a date with Destiny, a stripper, and ruined by an extravagant order of room service.

title: Knicks Cut Ties With Three Assistants
description: Every move the Knicks make involving their coaching staff seems to come as a surprise. Each of Don Chaney's three contract extensions was stunning, and yesterday the Knicks raised eyebrows by informing three assistant coaches that they would not be offered contract extensions.

title: More Detailed Reports Are Urged to Show Source And Location of Cases
description: The World Health Organization announced yesterday that it would broaden its reporting standards for SARS, calling on all countries to report not just the number of suspected or confirmed cases but also where they were occurring and from whom they were contracted.

title: A Balanchine Driven, Serene, Then Bubbling
description: The New York City Ballet opened its spring season at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night with fine dancing in three major works by George Balanchine.

title: Ruffled Feathers Make a Rough Party
description: When Pearl Jam took the stage at the Nassau Coliseum tonight, Eddie Vedder hardly looked like a guy spoiling for a fight. He slouched up to the microphone, and almost before people knew he was there he was murmuring his way through ''The Long Road,'' murmuring wistful lyrics atop a one-chord riff.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ATKINS, ROBERT C., M.D.
description: ATKINS-Robert C., M.D. The memorial service to honor Dr. Robert C. Atkins will be held on Friday, May 9th, from 11AM-12:30PM in New York City. Anyone interested in attending must call 212288-3500. Tickets will be distributed on a first come first serve basis. Details regarding the location of the service will be on your ticket.

title: Committee Likes Vancouver's Plan
description: A report released yesterday by the International Olympic Committee's evaluation commission did not grade the plans offered by three cities to play host to the 2010 Winter Games, but the bid by Vancouver, British Columbia, appeared to please the panel most.

title: BROADCOM REPORTS CHARGE RELATED TO 3 RESIGNATIONS
description: The Broadcom Corporation, a leading maker of cable-modem chips, said the former head of its ServerWorks unit and two other employees had left the company, contributing to a $129 million expense in the second quarter. Severance pay for the three -- Raju Vegesna, who was removed as head of ServerWorks in March; Ken McMaster; and Kimball Brown -- will result in an $88 million expense, a spokesman, Bill Blanning, said. Broadcom said it would also have an expense of $41 million in the quarter, which ends June 30, related to the 2001 acquisition of ServerWorks.

title: A Victory With Little That Bloomberg Wants
description: If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg viewed yesterday's legislative budget package as a victory, it is hard to imagine what he would have seen as a defeat.

title: Jets Marvel At Rookie's Rare Bulk
description: One by one, the veterans turned out to watch the rookie as the Jets opened minicamp today. First was defensive end John Abraham, who, Coach Herman Edwards joked, has a new name now that defensive tackle Dewayne Robertson has arrived: ''John Stay Outside.''

title: House G.O.P. Tax Cuts Outdo Bush Plan in Favoring Wealthy
description: The tax-cut plan offered this week by Republican leaders in the House would be even more favorable to the wealthiest taxpayers than the larger plan proposed by President Bush, and those with incomes of less than $50,000 would have smaller tax reductions than under the Bush plan, a computer analysis showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROGERS, HERMAN (PETE)
description: ROGERS-Herman (Pete). You've been gone five years ago today. We miss you dearly. Love, Your Family

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Move To Deport Neo-Nazi
description: Canada moved to deport Ernst Zundel, a German-born, internationally known neo-Nazi, calling him a national security risk. A federal court must still confirm the decision by the immigration minister before he can be deported. Canadian officials say Mr. Zundel, 64, is a risk because he has published anti-Semitic literature and run an anti-Semitic Web site. He promotes the idea that the Holocaust never happened, and he faces hate-crime charges in Germany. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Democrats All: District Attorney Takes On Judge
description: When Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, sought the nomination for governor five years ago, the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn was among his strongest supporters. And when Mr. Hynes sought re-election for district attorney two years ago, it was the organization that worked vigorously to try to get his little-known opponent removed from the ballot.

title: For Anxious Families, SARS in China Adds Uncertainty
description: As the SARS epidemic grew, one small group of Americans stubbornly kept their travel plans to China. They were adopting babies there, and nothing would stop most of them. But during the past week, complications -- from closed offices to crippled transportation systems -- have begun delaying some trips, leaving families, who have waited more than a year for this moment, in limbo.

title: Funny Cide Wins Kentucky Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3  There on the track was Empire Maker, the impeccably bred favorite with a tender foot, a cocky trainer from Brooklyn and the plurality of the public's money on his back. There was Atswhatimtalknbout, the Hollywood horse, partly owned by movie royalty, and there was Indian Express, the rhythm and bluegrass colt whose owner was a legendary record producer in the 1950's.

title: U.S. Plans to Reduce Forces In Iraq, With Help of Allies
description: The Bush administration is planning to withdraw most United States combat forces from Iraq over the next several months and wants to shrink the American military presence to less than two divisions by the fall, senior allied officials said today.

title: For $2, How About Some Snacks? Transit Riders Share Wish Lists
description: Does this train stop at Jenna Dover's house?

title: Pope Goes to Spain Today, Seemingly Less Feeble Now
description: On Saturday morning, if all goes as planned, Pope John Paul II will do something that was once a hallmark and leitmotif of his papacy but has been strangely absent from his activities for more than eight months.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on the Campaign Finance Law
description: Following are excerpts from the ruling by a three-judge federal panel on the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002, which limits political campaign donations. The full text is online at nytimes.com/washington.

title: Inconsistency: New Hobgoblin For the Airlines
description: Breaking up may be hard to do, but it appears especially tough for the government and the airline industry.

title: Field of 16 Nears the Gate
description: The field for today's 129th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs. The Churchill Downs oddsmaker, Mike Battaglia, set the morning line; Joe Drape listed the horses in order of preference.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLOSTER, RICHARD S.
description: CLOSTER-Richard S. Dear Reuven, 6 years today. We miss you and love you. Miren, Howie and Dad

title: Oil Companies Reap Rewards Of Higher Prices for Crude
description: Royal Dutch/Shell and ChevronTexaco said yesterday that their first-quarter earnings more than doubled, capping a series of strong results for the industry as the price of crude oil rose.

title: Guy Mountfort, 97, Briton Who Helped Found Wildlife Fund
description: Guy Mountfort, a British ornithologist, nature writer and advertising executive who helped to found the World Wildlife Fund, died on April 23 in Bournemouth on the southern coast of England. He was 97.

title: ALBANY DEAL LETS CITY RAISE TAXES TO LIMIT LAYOFFS
description: Legislative leaders reached an agreement today with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that would allow New York City to increase taxes on sales and income to stave off severe layoffs the mayor had threatened.

title: Lucy, a Woman Wronged
description: The next time sirens propose a made-for-TV biography of a beloved star, someone should tie Leslie Moonves, CBS's president, tightly to the mast and put wax in his ears.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bankers Strike
description: Unions representing more than 200,000 bank officers seeking higher wages held a one-day strike, disrupting financial operations across India. Government-owned banks in the bigger cities were hit particularly hard. The strike, which excluded clerical employees and senior executives, affected foreign exchange trading and money market operations, reducing the volume of trading in Bombay. The unions threatened further action if their demands were not met. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Notes From a Little Fish
description: In 1985, I was prosecuted and convicted of fraud for trading on the stock market in advance of my ''Heard on the Street'' columns in The Wall Street Journal. My share of the $675,000 in illegal profits amounted to $30,000. I admitted my role, apologized for violating the ethics of my profession, and served nine months in a federal prison in Danbury, Conn.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Andreotti Cleared Of Mafia Charge
description: An appeals court in Sicily upheld the acquittal of Giulio Andreotti, a seven-time prime minister, on charges of complicity with the Mafia. Mr. Andreotti, who dominated postwar Italian politics, has for years faced criminal charges in connection with the mafia. In this case he was cleared by a court in 1999, but prosecutors appealed. In upholding that decision, the appeals court said prosecutors could not prove their case. Last year, Mr. Andreotti, 84, was sentenced by another court to 24 years in prison for his role in the 1979 murder of an Italian journalist. He has appealed that decision. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Caviar Dealer Is Sentenced For Falsifying Sales Records
description: A Russian immigrant described by prosecutors as by far the biggest caviar dealer in the United States was sentenced yesterday to a year and nine months in prison for illegal trafficking in American and Russian caviar and violation of endangered-species laws.

title: ST. JUDE MEDICAL ACQUIRES 19 PERCENT STAKE IN EPICOR
description: St. Jude Medical Inc., one of the largest makers of implantable defibrillators in the United States, said it had taken a stake in Epicor Medical Inc. and might buy all of the company next year for $185 million, based on Epicor's progress with its experimental ultrasound device. St. Jude's chief executive, Terry Shepherd, said his company paid $15 million for 19 percent of the closely held Epicor. Other terms were not disclosed. The acquisition in 2004 is contingent on Epicor's meeting certain clinical and regulatory milestones. St. Jude is based in St. Paul, Minn.

It's not that Creamer, a 5-foot-10 point guard from Mendham, N.J., and Bucknell University, is guarding her words. It's as if she can't believe so many people want to interview her and she will deflate if all that happiness comes rushing out of her.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS SAYS AQUENT'S OFFER IS INADEQUATE
description: The Computer Horizons Corporation, a computer services provider, said yesterday that an unsolicited takeover offer of a $5 a share from Aquent L.L.C. was ''grossly inadequate.'' Aquent, an information-technology consulting company based in Boston, made the $146 million offer last month, saying the company was too small to compete on its own. In a statement, Aquent's chief executive, John Chuang, said, ''We find it unfortunate that Computer Horizons has rejected our $5 cash merger proposal.''

description: The streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant were calm yesterday, a day after a fatal police shooting spurred the friends of the man killed to threaten police officers at close range and kick their patrol cars.

title: Judge Rejects A Request To Put Off Higher Fares
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to temporarily stop a transit fare increase, meaning that the base cost of riding the subway and buses will rise to $2 from $1.50 tomorrow.

description: The chief executive of General Motors, Rick Wagoner, in his first speech since adding the title of chairman, said today that the price war his company was leading was losing effectiveness and the industry would need a strong economic stimulus package from Washington.

description: HE'S so steady, so solid, so strong, sometimes it takes something scary for Scott Stevens to be appreciated. Like a rock-hard puck to the side of the head Monday night for 15 now-crusty stitches next to his left ear. And later, like having to sleep with an ice bag perched on his temple to reduce the swelling along his jawbone. How do you do that?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about results of a federal side-impact crash test described the Daewoo Nubira incorrectly. It is a small car, not a sport utility vehicle.

title: 1,638 Pages, but Little Weight in Supreme Court
description: It was a set of interlocking and contradictory opinions so complex that two of the three federal judges who ruled in the campaign finance case tried to summarize the panel's 20 main holdings in a four-page spreadsheet. The chart itself was nearly incomprehensible.

title: India Announces Steps in Effort To End Its Conflict With Pakistan
description: Saying he was making one last effort at peace, Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee announced in Parliament today that India would restore diplomatic and air links with Pakistan.

title: Wal-Mart Agrees to Sell Food Supplier
description: In an unusual strategic disposal, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its McLane Company division to Berkshire Hathaway Inc. in a $1.45 billion deal that puts Berkshire Hathaway in position to become the dominant player in the food-distribution industry.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Funds For Growth
description: Finance Minister Kim Jin Pyo, left, said the government would pump funds into the economy beginning in June with a special budget to compensate for a decline in consumer spending, the impact of SARS on exports to other Asian countries, and concerns about North Korea's nuclear program. Mr. Kim said the budget would have a minimum of 2.3 trillion won ($1.9 billion) in surplus funds, enough to be sure the economy grows by 3 percent this year, half the growth forecast before the current slump. The Bank of Korea said foreign currency reserves at the end of April were $123.6 billion, down $205 million from the end of March, after the government paid off bonds and interest of more than $1 billion. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency did not receive all of the material today that it had requested from the counties surrounding the Indian Point nuclear power plant to sign off on emergency plans, according to county officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, THE RT. REV. PAUL, JR.
description: MOORE-The Rt. Rev. Paul, Jr. The Pilgrims of the U.S. are deeply saddened by the death of their distinguished member and vice president who was for 17 years Episcopal Bishop of New York, a diocese of 203 congregations in ten counties. Here and earlier, in Jersey City, Indianapolis and Washington, he pursued his many selfless, encompassing and supportive causes, extending to the entire Anglican Communion and beyond to the devastated island of East Timor. We express our heartfelt sympathy to his nine children and nineteen grandchildren. Henry Luce III President Laurence C. Windsor, Jr. Honorary Secretary Eben W. Pyne Honorary Treasurer

INVOLVED IN ARSENIC CASE F.B.I. agents and behavioral scientists will help construct a profile of the person or persons responsible for arsenic poisonings that killed one and sickened 15 who drank tainted coffee at a church in New Sweden. Lt. Dennis Appleton, the lead state police investigator in the case, also said the authorities would ask 40 or 50 parishioners for fingerprints and DNA samples. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

Nunn, took the pulpit and described how she was trying to instill respect and restraint among her 838-strong force.

title: Sondheim's Obsessions, Revived
description: The fascination exerted by a compelling but unbeautiful woman is something that few works of dramatic art have chosen to explore. But Stephen Sondheim enjoys marginal, even taboo subjects - cannibalism in ``Sweeney Todd,'' would-be presidential killers in ``Assassins'' - and his flawed musical ``Passion,'' revived at the Dicapo Opera on Thursday for a two-week run, takes on exactly this fascination.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE AGREES TO RAISE PAY OF NURSES
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to raises of as much as 29 percent for some nurses in California and Florida. The three-year agreement between the company and two labor groups bars the nurses from striking, according to a Tenet spokesman, Harry Anderson, and the two groups that represent employees at Tenet hospitals. The accord lets other employees vote on unionizing, Mr. Anderson and the labor groups said. The agreement covers workers represented by the Service Employees International Union and the American Federation of Federal, State, County and Municipal Employees.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Gunman Kills Mayor
description: A gunman described as a disgruntled town employee shot and killed the mayor of Aci Castello, in Sicily, and four other people. The police said the man, Giuseppe Leotta, had carried at least three firearms and gunned down Mayor Michele Toscano and three town employees at the town hall. He also killed a man sitting on a bench outside, they said. A manhunt was organized across the Catania region of the island. The police said Mr. Leotta, 32, later shot himself to death in a Catholic church near Vittoria, 60 miles south. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

Abe Fortas, a Washington lawyer who was himself later named to the Supreme Court, was appointed to represent Clarence Earl Gideon. the petitioner in the 1963 case. The court did not appoint Mr. Fortas's firm, then known as Arnold, Fortas & Porter.

Boston Private's purchase includes a 51 percent stake held by Value Asset Management Inc., Dalton Greiner's chairman, Timothy Dalton Jr., said. Managers from Dalton Greiner, which is based in New York, will retain a 20 percent stake after the purchase is completed in the third quarter. Boston Private, which is based in Boston, manages about $6.8 billion in assets.

title: Sometimes, to the Victor Belongs a Host of Problems
description: It might seem strange, just after an American military victory, to submit to the brooding brilliance of this book, ''The Culture of Defeat.'' But that sort of irony is one of the book's points. In this wide-ranging study, Wolfgang Schivelbusch, a cultural historian who has in previous books teased hidden meanings out of the origins of coffee or the onset of domestic lighting, incorporates a cautionary note. He points out that if history demonstrates anything, it is that ''what triumphs today will be defeated tomorrow.'' The arrogance of power can be tempered, he argues, by an ''empathetic philosophy of defeat.''

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Court Overturns Smoking Ban
description: The state's highest court invalidated a ban on smoking in restaurants and bars in Montgomery County. Upholding a lower court decision, the Court of Appeals ruled that the County Council lacked the authority to convene as a board of health and pass the ban in 1999, without participation of the county executive, Douglas M. Duncan. The Council's move came after Mr. Duncan threatened to veto a ban. Health regulations, unlike legislation, are not subject to veto. Restaurants and bars sued to challenge the ban, which never took effect. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: The TriBeCa Film Festival
description: ''The last thing the world needs is another film festival.'' That's what Jane Rosenthal remembers thinking. But in the chaotic vacuum of Lower Manhattan after 9/11, what the world needed changed abruptly. Ms. Rosenthal and Robert De Niro, her partner in TriBeCa Productions, realized that a film festival might be the kind of event that would bring people back to Lower Manhattan. And indeed it did. Last year's inaugural TriBeCa Film Festival lured more than 150,000 people to screening venues in the neighborhood and to its restaurants and shops. The festival was as noteworthy for the mood of the event as for the films it screened, and especially for the buoyant spirit of its family street festival, an enormous party along six blocks of Greenwich Street.

title: Iraq's Permanent Capitalist
description: Faisal loves his Belgian-made FN-FAL. It's the most balanced assault rifle in the world, he says, and he knows guns. Like many in the Iraqi elite, Faisal likes to hunt. When I dropped by for a barbecue five days after the marines pulled down the Saddam statue in Firdos Square, he showed it to me, holding up the gun by its handle like a scale. We were in the library of his home, which was modeled after a Frank Lloyd Wright design and which he had turned into a sandbagged bunker. Until the Americans arrived, Faisal's street was the safest in the city. Hussein's son Uday had a house eight doors down, and Tariq Aziz lived less than a kilometer upriver. When Faisal invited me for the barbecue, the looting had tapered off slightly but the city was still very unstable. The streets around his house resembled a Medelln comuna, with local militias manning barricades of palm trunks and rubble. Just before midnight, there were a few shots from very close by and we stopped talking to listen. Faisal ran into the library and grabbed his machine gun, and when I followed he told me to stay inside. The gunfire grew heavier. Faisal told the guards to open the gates and yelled ''saula'' -- charge -- and they ran down the street firing. After a while, I went out to the front of the house and peered down the street. I saw Faisal sticking out of the sunroof of his Grand Cherokee, holding the rifle from his waist, looking for looters.

But some lucky fan may win a one-minute date with the performer of his dreams tonight, when Nickelodeon's ''TeeNick'' programming block becomes ''TeeNick Spins the Bottle.'' Scattered about the regular 6-to-8:30 line-up, which begins with ''Kenan and Kel'' and ends with ''Clueless,'' will be a series of star-filled segments filmed at the Hard Rock Cafe Hollywood.

title: QUICK BITE/Tenafly; Ice Products With Intensity
description: Ciao Bella is the ice cream of culinary gods. No wonder business chiefs have been said to call from jets to ensure that their freezers at home are stocked with the unusually flavorful gelati and sorbetti, which are made in Irvington. The mango sorbet is like biting into the sweet perfumed fruit; the edgy espresso gelato is so intensely ''coffee'' that Leila Sumulong, owner of the Ciao Bella Gelato Cafe in Tenafly, insists that customers take a taste before they commit.

title: The Encompassing Power Of No on the Island
description: This past Sunday, an ad in the Long Island section caught my eye. It showed happy people romping in the sea with their dog. I guess this was meant to show what fun folks could have summering on Long Island. But most beaches don't allow dogs from Memorial Day through Labor Day, and there are a slew of other ''nos'' to keep an eye on. These evolved over time, thanks to growing populations, bad behavior and the orneriness of some town boards or county legislatures. This nasty two-letter word has turned our island from a land of fun, into a Land of No. No access. No ball playing. No clamming, dogs, exit, fishing, cellphones, gum chewing, sleeping on park benches, horses, jaywalking, kayaking, left turn, noise, open burning, parking, rollerblading, stopping, swimming, trespassing, U-turn, vehicles.

title: How to Find a Cellist: Play Musical Chairs
description: IN July 1992, the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood included a concert that burned its way into a listener's memory on the strength of a single, unheralded new work, played by an ensemble that was just leaving its academic cocoon and edging into the professional world. The work was Osvaldo Golijov's ''Yiddishbbuk,'' a string quartet partly inspired by a photograph of children who died at Theresienstadt. Anger and lamentation mingled in its energetic strumming and eerie, high-lying pianissimo passages, and it proved a searing calling card for an Argentine-born composer who had only recently arrived in the United States from Israel.

title: 'Masters of Doom'
description: Eleven-year-old John Romero jumped onto his dirt bike, heading for trouble again. A scrawny kid with thick glasses, he pedaled past the modest homes of Rocklin, California, to the Roundtable Pizza Parlor. He knew he wasn't supposed to be going there this summer afternoon in 1979, but he couldn't help himself. That was where the games were.

title: Saying No to 'Just Say No'
description: AS the editor of the Buzzer, the Hastings High School newspaper, a Peer Leader and a college-bound senior, I want to acknowledge the difficulty of addressing the topic of under-age drinking. This article is not meant to advocate under-age drinking, nor to recommend a lower drinking age; I am well aware of the myriad alcohol-related teenage deaths that resulted when the drinking age was 18. I am simply frustrated by the unrealistic and poorly coordinated way in which this problem has been addressed in the past, by both parents and teenagers. The issues surrounding teenage drinking are too important to be ignored, and with a little understanding, the capacity for change is endless.

It's an urge my wife does not share, and one that most travel publications ignore -- perhaps wisely so.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: MASTER OF THE sENATE: The Years of Lyndon Johnson, by Robert A. Caro. (Vintage, $19.95.) In the third volume of his mammoth life of Johnson, Caro presents a more rounded version of his subject than before, conjuring a tyrannical politician who worked his magic in the Senate from 1949 to 1961, wheedling, bullying and stroking egos while pushing through landmark civil rights legislation. This Pulitzer Prize-winning account is ''a wonderful, a glorious tale,'' Anthony Lewis wrote here in 2002. ''Not even Trollope explored the ambitions and the gullibilities of men as deliciously as . . . Caro.''

title: April 27-May 3; CAMPAIGN LAW UPHELD
description: In the most crucial court case dealing with money and politics since 1976, a special three-judge Federal panel upheld major provisions of a sweeping new law limiting political donations, though it found that some of its measures were unconstitutional. The effort was aimed at evaluating whether the law's restrictions on raising and spending large donations violated the First Amendment's prohibition against government limitations to free speech. In essence, two of the three judges said Congress was within its rights to find that the unlimited donations could not be used by national parties for advertisements that dealt directly with issues or that attacked or supported candidates. But they found it impermissible to prohibit national parties from using such donations, known as ''soft money,'' for activities like increasing party registration or getting voters to the polls.

title: Mixed Messages In Housing Market
description: The median price of a single-family house in Westchester rose by 12 percent in the first quarter of 2003 - to $525,500 from $469,100 in the first quarter of 2002. That, however, was down from the record high for the county, $570,750, which was set in the third quarter of last year.

But during the year I lived there, 2000, I kept telling people that Paris was my favorite city in the world. On this day, I was feeling particularly good because I had just had a great lunch. I got in the line for a taxi. I was dressed in a brown jacket over a brown vest. Once inside, I put on my sunglasses. I saw the cabdriver looking at me in the rearview mirror. Finally, he said: ''Excuse me for being indiscreet. May I ask where you come from?''

title: Madonna's Album: Saved by the D.J.'s?
description: LISA GERMANO; VIRGIL SHAW -- The humble waltz makes a comeback on these two very different albums: Lisa Germano's ''Lullaby for Liquid Pig'' (Ineffable/IMusic) and Virgil Shaw's ''Still Falling'' (Future Farmer). Ms. Germano's waltzes (along with her 4/4 ballads) are intensely private. She confides secrets and fears amid arrangements full of shimmering echoes and splintery distortions, wafting in like the broken illusions she contemplates. Mr. Shaw gets his extroverted waltzes and rockers from a honky-tonk somewhere in the ''wilderness of this world'' that he sings about in his cracked voice. It's a place where the mystic Americana of the Band meets Mr. Shaw's own surreal tales and hard-luck images.

title: What a Mother Wants
description: It's the shopping quandary that arises every Mother's Day: what to buy for the woman who does everything? Blenders and bonbons be hanged. From young moms like Reese Witherspoon to less-conventional ones like Rosie O'Donnell, today's mothers resist stereotyping. Yet there are a few intangibles that all mothers, whether screen stars or suburbanites, crave: say, peace and quiet, time, sleep and good manners -- or simple forbearance. Below is the classic wish list, and some gifts that can help make these wishes attainable. And for goodness' sake, don't forget to make a card.

description: Westchester's Consumer Protection Department has fined the Home Depot chain $25,500 for failing to mark items with prices. The four Westchester store locations and the fines, which have been paid, are: New Rochelle, $7,500; Port Chester, $7,500; Yonkers, $7,500, and Mohegan Lake, $3,000.

title: Frank Stella's Expressionist Phase
description: Frank Stella once remarked that no artist needs to live beyond the age of 40. He made the comment many years ago, and the implication was that he had no intention of sticking around to witness the diminution of his own talent. It is a truism to say that artists do their most innovative work when they are young. It is also patently false.

She will be deeply missed by her large and loving family. Funeral private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Tufts University School of Veterinary Medicine, 200 Westboro Rd, North Grafton, Mass. 01536, Stanley Travis Fund.

At any given performance, a constellation of actors -- Elaine Stritch, Marian Seldes, Tammy Grimes, Rosie Perez, Judd Hirsch and Christine Baranski, to name a few -- sit on a makeshift platform in the club's Grand Ballroom, scripts in hand, and bring life to the writers' words.

New York's mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, looking for a reprise, wants to hold a mammoth parade to salute veterans of the Iraq war with ticker tape and cheers.

title: Sports of The Times; Credit Liberty's Wicks With Another Assist
description: SHE used to pack up her life and jet across oceans to play her trade, to play the game. Last week, the end of the journey, she couldn't bring herself to cross the river, from northern New Jersey to New York City.

title: DONATIONS SUSPENDED
description: Commerce Bancorp said last week that it would temporarily stop giving donations through its state political action committee so as to steer clear of perceived improprieties in its bond business. The company has long given donations to both Republicans and Democrats and then successfully won bond work from state and local governments. But a recent transfer of more than $100,000 from its federal political action committee to its state political action committee may have run afoul of rules that prohibit a bond broker from donating more than $250 to a state committee. So, the company said, it will suspend donations, perhaps until the Legislature enacts a law to resolve the situation. Robert Strauss

title: Red's Sweeter Sister
description: The blush and the flush of pink are all over the urban landscape, not least on women in this spring's favorite rain cover, a short coat costing less than $100. Even that hard-edged wardrobe staple, the traditional beige trench coat, gets the pink treatment this season. The thing about pink is that women feel pretty wearing it, as the woman pausing under a magnolia in the Shakespeare Garden in Central Park clearly did (and rightly so).

title: So, Which Man Will Sell You That Drywall?
description: AT the beginning of spring, the nursery at the Home Depot in Kingston, N.Y., was barren, bordered by rows of dead or dying saplings left over from last fall. Less than a quarter-mile away, the garden center at its fierce competitor, Lowe's, was bursting with color, set off by a new line of pseudo-teak benches.

title: Editorial Observer; It's Emerson's Anniversary and He's Got 21st-Century America Nailed
description: ''Trust thyself,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson admonished, ''every heart vibrates to that iron string.'' Emerson's famous essay, ''Self-Reliance,'' goes on to regret how much ''we capitulate to badges and names, to large societies and dead institutions.'' Emerson's tribute to the individual is stirring stuff, but before long he is sneering at a request for charity. ''Are they my poor?'' he asks. ''I tell thee, thou foolish philanthropist, that I grudge the dollar, the dime, the cent I give to such men as do not belong to me and to whom I do not belong.''

title: Lisa Landau, David Carnoy
