title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE world needs another movie couple like Nick and Nora Charles to make marriage look like so much fun. In W. S. Van Dyke II's AFTER THE THIN MAN (1936), Nick (William Powell) turns to his wife at a nightclub and says, ''Did I ever tell you that you're the most fascinating woman this side of the Rockies?'' Nora (Myrna Loy) answers, ''Wait till you see me on the other side.'' Nick is just trying to change the subject, which is a missing-persons case that is about to turn into murder. This was the second time Powell and Loy played the rich, witty, well-dressed, hard-drinking, private-eye Charleses, and they're in fine form. So is Asta, their personable wire-haired fox terrier, who has his own mystery to solve: a paternity case -- Saturday at 10:35 p.m. on Channel 13.

title: Repairing a Damaged Co-op Floor
description: Q -- I live in a co-op in Manhattan that had its brickwork repointed several months ago. Our living room floor is made of herringbone wood. I noticed around the time of heavy rains last November that portions of the flooring near the window wall started coming up. There were no leaks through the closed windows. It is probable that water came through the facing of the building. Management says it will not pay for repair of the floor because its insurance company has a $5,000 deductible. Who is responsible for this damage? . . . Howard Edelberg, Manhattan.

title: CHIEF JUSTICE RENOMINATED
description: After much speculation that he would not do so, Governor McGreevey has nominated Deborah T. Poritz for reappointment as chief justice of the state Supreme Court. Mr. McGreevey was said to want his own candidate over Chief Justice Poritz, a Republican appointed by Governor Whitman. But a spokesman said he decided to support an independent judiciary over a nominee aligned with his own views. Chief Justice Poritz has been praised for upholding that independence, but critics have said that she did not do enough to stop racial profiling when she was attorney general from 1994 to 1996. Some Republicans are also angry over the court's ruling last fall that allowed Frank R. Lautenberg to replace Robert G. Torricelli as the Democratic nominee for United States Senate. Michael J. Grabell

Jones fielded Clemens's remark and hurled it back. Clemens launched a semi-fast ball, around 85 miles per hour, about a foot from Jones's ear. Jones went down, jumped up, brushed himself off and then questioned Clemens's paternity. The next pitch was about 5 m.p.h. faster and three inches closer.

Those bothersome folks on the ground, with all their historical myths and nationalist narratives, always seem to get in the way of a good plan. It's so much more efficient to go ahead without them.

title: Tarred and Weathered, Cobblestones Are in Trouble
description: Six months ago, Jo Hamilton looked out her window and noticed a pothole spreading beneath the Belgian blocks that pave Jane Street, between Greenwich and Washington Streets. She hoped the city would not discover the hole, however, because she knew the city would fix it with tar and asphalt, rather than similar stones.

title: 2 Americans and a Russian Return From the International Space Station in a Soyuz Capsule
description: Three astronauts from the International Space Station, two Americans and a Russian, returned safely to earth in Central Asia today aboard a Russian Soyuz capsule. But a malfunctioning control system left the spacecraft far short of its intended landing site.

title: NOTES FROM UNDERGROUND
description: AN unnamed urban recluse slowly sinking into madness is the protagonist of Eric Bogosian's solo play ''Notes From Underground.'' Consisting of diary entries read by their increasingly bizarre-sounding author, the play was performed by Mr. Bogosian in 1994 at P.S. 122 in the East Village. Through May 25, the play is being read at P.S. 122, this time by the novelist Jonathan Ames, with Mr. Bogosian directing. title: Everybody Gets a Cut
description: A kiss, all moviegoers know, is just a kiss, and a sigh, by the same inexorable logic, is just a sigh, but I'm starting to wonder whether in the age of the DVD a movie -- even one as indelibly stamped on the collective memory as ''Casablanca'' -- can ever again be just a movie. The DVD's that have been piling up in the vicinity of my TV seem to be telling me that a movie is not a movie unless it arrives swaddled in ''extras'': on-set documentaries, retrospective interviews with cast and crew, trailers, deleted scenes, storyboards, even alternate endings. These days, any film for which a studio's marketing department has sufficiently high commercial expectations is issued on DVD in a ''special'' or ''limited'' or ''collector's'' edition that makes an Arden Shakespeare look skimpy by comparison. The extras on the new double-disc Director's Edition of Brett Ratner's ''Red Dragon'' include such indispensable material as hair and wardrobe tests and one of the auteur's N.Y.U. student films, and take as long to watch as the movie itself. We all, in our 21st-century paradise of leisure, have too much time on our hands. But not that much.

Soup I'd made with the hen's neck, giblets, and feet simmered on the stove. Out in the dining room, two guests, my wife, my stepson and his wife, chattered and laughed and complained they were hungry. Our Sabbath candles shone in their silver holders. The challah waited beneath its embroidered velvet cover to be blessed.

title: The Next Big Flavor
description: The dried berries of the tropical shrub Schinus terebinthifolia are as fragile as parchment and taste like a black-pepper-coated lime LifeSaver. In Paris, you might have eaten them as early as 1976, the year an enterprising spice merchant on the island of Runion in the Indian Ocean sent samples to the haute-cuisine temples Le Pr Catelan, Paul Bocuse and La Tour d'Argent. But if you cooked with them in the United States 25 years ago, chances are you were not only a pioneer but also something of an outlaw: ''pink peppercorns,'' as the berries came to be known, didn't win approval from the Food and Drug Administration until 1983. Today, pink peppercorns are distributed with mundane efficiency to A&P's and Hy-Vee's throughout North America, an essential ingredient in the peppercorn blends of all the major spice bottlers. Like balsamic vinegar, salsa and fresh basil -- foods that 25 years ago might have required an intercontinental journey to experience -- pink peppercorns have become an everyday element in the American flavor spectrum.

title: Healing Hearts And Arts
What a Mother Wants
description: It's the shopping quandary that arises every Mother's Day: what to buy for the woman who does everything? Blenders and bonbons be hanged. From young moms like Reese Witherspoon to less-conventional ones like Rosie O'Donnell, today's mothers resist stereotyping. Yet there are a few intangibles that all mothers, whether screen stars or suburbanites, crave: say, peace and quiet, time, sleep and good manners -- or simple forbearance. Below is the classic wish list, and some gifts that can help make these wishes attainable. And for goodness' sake, don't forget to make a card.

title: CRIME
description: Tony Hillerman was just waiting for someone to invent the Department of Homeland Security. As if the jurisdictional power struggles among the F.B.I., the D.E.A., the Border Patrol, the Department of Land Management and the Navajo Tribal Police were not enough to cripple local law enforcement on the Indian reservations where Hillerman sets his novels, an ber-agency like Homeland Security comes along to create total confusion. Hillerman orchestrates the chaos brilliantly in THE SINISTER PIG (HarperCollins, $25.95), devising a plot that draws all these interested parties to a lonely dirt road in the San Juan Basin in New Mexico (''the very heart of America's version of the Persian Gulf''), where an undercover agent has been murdered while investigating possible criminal sabotage of the oil pipelines. Sgt. Jim Chee of the Navajo police and his retired mentor, Joe Leaphorn, are quick to pick up on the implications for a federal inquiry into some $40 billion in oil revenues that never made it into the Tribal Trust Fund. But the F.B.I. elbows them off the case, and it is left to a rookie, Bernadette Manuelito, working Border Patrol near Mexico, to follow the cynical scheme to its bedrock, allowing Hillerman to tie all three investigative strands together in an extraordinary display of sheer plotting craftsmanship.

title: Viral Terrors
description: I 'd like to caution Abraham Verghese against using as loaded a phrase as ''more enlightened'' to differentiate one society from another (The Way We Live Now, April 20). Singapore has a policy in which the good of the many is prioritized over the liberty of the individual; in Hong Kong the trend tends toward the opposite. Whether one approach is ''more enlightened'' deserves debate. Singapore's stricter quarantine laws may have prevented the SARS outbreak there from being as devastating as the one in Hong Kong. From this, it could be argued that it is the ''enlightened'' society that recognizes when individual liberties must be curtailed for the sake of the society as a whole.

title: Vintage Cuts
description: It was a cold and raw Sunday morning, and there were chores to do. Jennifer Small and Michael Yezzi -- a married couple in their mid-30's who look as if they'd be more at ease getting lattes at Starbucks -- put on layers of sweaters and pulled on knee-high rubber boots, then headed outside to their barn. Yezzi lifted three 50-pound sacks of grain, slinging two over his shoulder and one under his free arm, then made his way up the icy bank and over an electric fence to a large drum-shaped feeder. Yezzi and Small hauled one bag after another to the feeder until they had filled it with 1,700 pounds of grain. At their feet, a dozen Tamworth pigs muscled their way in, fighting for breakfast. The pigs are relatively small -- 250 pounds -- red-haired, intelligent and friendly. They are also delicious to eat.

title: War Is Hell, TV Once Reminded Us
description: ALL wars are popular for the first 30 days," wrote the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. By the time "M*A*S*H" hit the airwaves in 1972, the year the last American ground troops left Vietnam, that deadline had long expired. An antiwar sitcom that blossomed during wartime, "M*A*S*H" ran for 11 years, and it was explicitly intended as a commentary on Vietnam. But the show's setting was the Korean War of the 1950's, a chronological remove that gave the show's creators a perverse freedom, as well as a stamp of universality. To watch it now is to gaze back at an era of angry skepticism, personified by the prankster antihero Hawkeye Pierce (Alan Alda). In the bleak universe of "M*A*S*H," spokespeople are liars, generals are bullies and anyone who mouths patriotic slogans is a dupe or a hypocrite. "By the time we waded in, by the time we came on the air, people really wanted to get the hell out of Vietnam," recalled Larry Gelbart, one of the producers. "And even a corporation like CBS was ready to do a show like that."

title: He Can Stand the Heat
description: It would be easy to say that as a writer, Anthony Bourdain makes a great chef. Easy but not fair. Bourdain, executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles in Manhattan, is a fine writer. His swaggering memoir, ''Kitchen Confidential,'' was a stomach-churning page turner. In THE BOBBY GOLD STORIES (Bloomsbury, $19.95), his third novel but first since that nonfiction best seller, Bourdain whips up a Manhattan tale with Elmore Leonard flavor: the bad guys are a little good, the good guys are a little bad, and everybody's a little funny. The story of a mob enforcer and ex-convict named Bobby, the head of security at trendy NiteKlub, rollicks along for about 40 bone-breaking, punk-slapping pages before Bourdain makes the mistake of retreating to ''Kitchen Confidential.'' A chapter is devoted to a meal with Bobby's boss, who seems to exist only to illustrate humorously every trait of the toxic restaurant customer. The story loses steam here, then stops completely as Bobby gets involved with a NiteKlub cook. She improvises a fancy dinner for him at work, which evidently passes for foreplay in chef land. Though we see this through the eyes of food-ignorant Bobby, Bourdain treats us to a play-by-play straight from his memoir. What was fascinating there is beside the point here, and ''The Bobby Gold Stories'' never quite recovers, even in the telling of a big-score robbery and getaway. Too bad. Bourdain cooks as a writer. A celebration of Frank's life will be held Monday at 4:30pm at Church of the Ascension Catholic Church with the Rev. James E. Parke, celebrant. title: Brown Upsets Princeton in Content Cup
description: Brown won a "big, emotional race," as Paul Cook, the Bruins coach called his men's heavyweight varsity victory over Princeton for the Content Cup yesterday. The Tigers were ranked fifth among Eastern crews coming into the race against eighth-ranked Brown, but Princeton never threatened Brown over the 2,000-meter distance of the Lake Carnegie course. The Bruins broke at a 44-stroke cadence and gained a six-seat lead in the opening 300 meters, before settling into the body of the course in command of the race. Brown won in 6 minutes 15.4 seconds, 3.62 seconds ahead of Princeton. All the Eastern crews meet next Sunday in Worcester, Mass., for the Eastern Sprint Championship title.

Yet there are a few intangibles that all mothers, whether screen stars or suburbanites, crave: say, peace and quiet, time, sleep and good manners -- or simple forbearance. Below is the classic wish list, and some gifts that can help make these wishes attainable. And for goodness' sake, don't forget to make a card.

The young woman with the ''Gretchen Mol'' tag asked a man, ''Am I known for my figure or my face?'' ''I don't know.'' ''Am I an Oscar winner?'' ''I don't know.'' ''Am I blond?'' Long pause. Although it's not as upscale or luxurious as his Coolfish in Syosset, Starfish, at 2095 Merrick Road in Merrick (516-377-0078), is far from the down-home, ramshackle place conjured up by that description. Like Mr. Schaudel's other restaurants, Passionfish in Woodbury and Coolfish in Syosset (he has closed E.V.O. in Syosset and sold Tease in Roslyn), Starfish offers a stylish, welcoming environment and an attention to detail that sets it apart.

The reason seems to be the increasing vigor by Internet service providers to block spam, encouraging the spammers to redouble their mailing to find messages that penetrate the defenses. On Tuesday, Virginia enacted the toughest legal move yet against spam, imposing stiff felony penalties for sending unsolicited commercial e-mail. Congress is looking at criminalizing spam. title: 'The Singular Pilgrim'
description: Afew years ago a friend of mine, whom I know to be an intelligent and compassionate woman, listened carefully as I told her about a Greek Orthodox pilgrimage I had witnessed on the tiny Cycladic island of Tinos in the Aegean Sea. Each year on August 15, the Feast of the Assumption, which marks the spiritual and bodily assumption of the Virgin Mary into heaven, the Greek Orthodox faithful travel great distances to Tinos to venerate an icon of the Virgin housed in a church atop a small hill at the end of an avenue of marble paving stones. The icon, which was discovered in the early nineteenth century amid the rubble left by an earthquake, is said to have worked miraculous cures and to have granted many pilgrims their individual wishes. The pilgrims arrive by ferry. The moment the gangplank touches the dock, they rush forward, fall to the ground, and begin making their way to the church on hands and knees. Some slither the half-mile on their bellies, poling themselves forward with their elbows in the manner of besieged soldiers creeping through underbrush. Some lie across the street and, like horizontal dervishes, roll themselves slowly up the gradual incline across stones baked torrid by the August sun. As they proceed they pray for miracles and for mercy. Some weep, others call out the name of the Virgin. Many carry on their backs offerings of wax candles the length of their bodies. In the terrible heat the candles droop and sweat. Elderly white-haired widows in black dresses inch their way silently up the hill, humbling themselves in hope of the Virgins attention, their frail backs forming saddles for the punishing sun. (Many women in need of divine intervention in some grave family matter-an illness, a wayward or disobedient child, a financial bind, an unfaithful husband-vow to return to Tinos every year if the Virgin will grant the desired outcome.) By the time they reach the church after several hours of crawling, their hands and knees are galled into raw and bloody emblems of their belief. Once before the icon they prostrate themselves in a rapture of spiritual desire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGGINS, BARBARA MERRILL
description: HUGGINS-Barbara Merrill. Died of natural causes on Wednesday evening, in her home in Waitsfield, VT. Barbara was born in NYC in 1931, to Oliver B. Merrill Jr. and Laura P. Merrill. She attended the Brearley School and graduated from the Shipley School. She received a bachelor of arts from Smith College in 1953, and completed postgraduate work in history and foreign relations at Columbia University. Barbara married Kenneth R. Huggins of Concord, MA, in 1960; Ken died in 1969. Prior to the birth of her children Barbara taught at the Brearley School and the Spence School. While raising her four children, Barbara remained active in education. She was a founding parent and member of the Board of Trustees of the West Side Montessori School. She was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Brearley School for many years and active in the development office. More recently, Barbara was a member of the New York State Supreme Court Appellate Division, First Judicial Department, Departmental Disciplinary Committee as a citizen appointee. A lifelong New Yorker, Barbara retired to the hills of Vermont where she enjoyed renovating her old farm house and other building projects, gardening, and hosting friends and family. She is survived by her four children, Melissa R. Huggins of Madison, WI (John E. Opel), Mark P. Huggins of Santa Rosa, CA, Elise M. Huggins of Portland, OR (Benjamin D. Herring), and Jennifer L. Huggins of Waitsfield, VT (Carter Scott), and her four grandchildren: Louise H. Opel, Charles H. Opel, Julia H. Opel, and Eliza B. Herring. The family is planning two memorial services, one to be held in Vermont at week's end, and a second in NYC at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to be sent to the Brearley School or the Oliver B. Merrill Fund at Amherst College.

title: What Your Genes Want You to Eat
description: A trip to the diet doc, circa 2013. You prick your finger, draw a little blood and send it, along with a $100 fee, to a consumer genomics lab in California. There, it's passed through a mass spectrometer, where its proteins are analyzed. It is cross-referenced with your DNA profile. A few days later, you get an e-mail message with your recommended diet for the next four weeks. It doesn't look too bad: lots of salmon, spinach, selenium supplements, bread with olive oil. Unsure of just how lucky you ought to feel, you call up a few friends to see what their diets look like. There are plenty of quirks. A Greek co-worker is getting clams, crab, liver and tofu -- a bounty of B vitamins to raise her coenzyme levels. A friend in Chicago, a second-generation Zambian, has been prescribed popcorn, kale, peaches in their own juice and club soda. (This looks a lot like the hypertension-reducing ''Dash'' diet, which doesn't work for everyone but apparently works for him.) He is allowed some chicken, prepared in a saltless marinade, hold the open flame -- and he gets extra vitamin D because there's not enough sunshine for him at his latitude. (His brother's diet, interestingly enough, is a fair bit different.) Your boss, who seems to have won some sort of genetic lottery, gets to eat plenty of peanut butter, red meat and boutique cheeses.

Sister of Gwendolyn O'Donnell and Everitas Houghton. Family will receive friends at Williams Funeral Home, Inc, 5628 Broadway at 232 St, Bronx, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Visitation Church, Tuesday, 10 am. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  L.A.P.
description: L.A.P.-February 4, 1945-May 5, 1991. ''Whatever we were to each other, that we are still.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, MICHAEL OLIVER
description: McCABE-Michael Oliver. 23, passed away on Tuesday, April 29, 2003. Deeply loved by his mother Eleanor Brickner McCabe, his father and step-mother Ross and Kathleen McCabe, and his brother Samuel and his sister Julie. He will be remembered but greatly missed. His passing is sadly acknowledged by so many who knew him as the shy, gentle, innocent and curious young man that he was. Donations can be made to the Michael McCabe Memorial Fund, attn: Mr. Jeff Harris, Edward R. Morrow High School, 1600 Ave L, Brooklyn, NY 11230.

title: New Smoking Ban: Already Backfiring?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Goes High Speed: A Tenfold Increase in Connections
description: While South Korea has rightfully been called a broadband paradise, Japan is fast turning into one.

title: John Lennon's Modest Beginnings, Now on Show in Liverpool
description: LIVERPOOL, England, May 2  It is a routine tour of a typical suburb until the Penny Lane street sign on one side and the gates to Strawberry Field on the other suggest that something more magical and mysterious is in store.

title: 29 Tunes in a Row (That's the Show)
description: The composer Burt Bacharach and the lyricist Hal David write confectionary songs with stick-in-the-mind melodic phrases and tidy, if none too probing, ruminations on human emotions: ''What's it all about, Alfie?'' is about as heavy as they ever get.

title: Donizetti Joins the High School Chorus; A Long Island District Imports an Opera, Singers and All
description: Friendly, seductive, her accent hard to place, the temptress asked the teenagers what they did when they did not feel brave enough, strong enough, good enough. Drugs, booze, magic pills? Right here in the school chorus room, she said, she would introduce them to a helpful doctor.

title: Blair's Goal of an Early British Embrace of the Euro Appears to Be Fading
description: The long debate that was supposed to produce a verdict this month on whether to push for the euro as Britain's currency has instead lapsed into a contest over how much longer to postpone the final reckoning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONNER, HAROLD
description: KONNER-Harold. Of Water Mill, NY, formerly of Garden City, NY, on May 3, 2003. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Kerrie Wilson, Susan Sabin, Phyllis Gallin, Barbara Hausen, Gregory and Jeffrey Konner. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A viewing will take place today, Monday, beginning at 12:30 PM at the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc., 203 Hampton Road, Southampton, NY followed by a funeral service at 1 PM. The interment will follow at Edgewood Cemetery in Bridgehampton. Memorial donations to the Harold Konner Foundation, PO Box 633, Bridgehampton, NY 11932 would be appreciated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In Iraq, religion did not play the central role. The country is made of several religions. That created tolerance.''

title: A Sidestep by Syria On Curbing Militants
description: Militant Palestinian groups in Damascus challenged American statements that Syria had cracked down on them, and Syria sidestepped the issue, refusing to confirm one of the few concessions that seemed to emerge during a visit by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. But in a round of television interviews, Mr. Powell said the United States would carefully scrutinize whether Syria's promises were carried out.

title: Release of Audit Roils Trust Fight at the Barnes
description: With the fate of one of the world's richest art collections at stake, the bitter trust battle over the cash-poor Barnes Foundation is heating up this week in Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALE, PARTRICK SINCLAIR
description: HALE-Partrick Sinclair. Died May 3, 2003, in NYC, as a result of a hit-and-run automobile accident. Mr. Hale was 29 years old and a student at Columbia Graduate School of Business in NYC. A native of Nashville, Mr. Hale was the son of R. Walter Hale III, retired executive vice-president of Suntrust Bank, and the late Janin Sinclair Hale. In addition to his father and stepmother, Fay Allen Hale, he is survived by his sister, Virginia P. Hale, of Chicago, IL, as well as two aunts, Ms. Vianda Hill and Mrs. Nancy Hoyt of Lake Wales, FL. Funeral services are incomplete, but will be held at St. George Episcopal Church. Pallbearers will be his many loving friends. The family requests that memorial contributions be made to Montgomery Bell Academy, 4001 Harding Rd, Nashville, TN 37205; or the charity of one's choice. Broadway Chapel of Roesch Patton Brentwood Funeral Home, 1715 Broadway, Nashville, TN 37203. A Dignity Memorial Provider; 615-244-6480.

title: Public Health and Civil Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: MediaTalk; Scandal Flattens Demand for Weill Memoir
description: For perhaps the first time in his long career, Sanford I. Weill, the chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, cannot seem to close a deal. His apology last week for his role in the scandal over Wall Street analysts' conflicts of interest appears to have been the final blow to a two-year effort to sign a book deal for his memoirs that were being offered for as much as $3 million.

title: Praising Syria's President, Powell Also Hints at Sanctions
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell labeled as ''significant'' today the promises he received from President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to shut down the offices of militant groups in that nation, but he said the United States would carefully scrutinize whether Mr. Assad would back up his words with actions in the coming weeks and months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8, 15

title: Sue Sally Hale, 65, a Pioneer in U.S. Women's Polo, Dies
description: Sue Sally Hale, who broke American polo's sex barrier in 1972 when she gained membership in the sport's national governing body after playing matches disguised as a man for two decades, died last Tuesday at her ranch in Coachella, Calif. She was 65.

title: Walter Sisulu, Close Collaborator With Mandela, Is Dead
description: Walter Sisulu, one of Nelson Mandela's earliest political mentors and his closest collaborator for half a century in the campaign against South Africa's racist political order, died today. He was 90 or 91; his exact date of birth is unknown.

title: Danger Lingers in Pieces of an Abandoned Arsenal
description: Just over a week ago, five young boys ages 6 to 12 -- found an abandoned artillery shell outside this oil-producing city in northern Iraq and played a popular new game. They pried the shell open, extracted its explosive propellant -- a mixture of gunpowder and cordite -- and set it on fire.

title: Schumacher Wins Race, but Not Spotlight
description: Michael Schumacher baptized his new model Ferrari with a victory at the Spanish Grand Prix, but it was the birth of a new star in Fernando Alonso that enflamed the passion of the near-record crowd of 96,000 today.

title: Floyd's Bat Is Booming In the Cleanup Spot
description: Cliff Floyd left St. Louis three days ago disgusted with his physical condition, his performance on the field and the losses that the Mets were compiling at an alarming rate. He spoke of how discouraging his first month with the team had been and how it barely resembled what he had envisioned when he signed as a free agent.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on April 28 about the nomination of Jeffrey Sutton to a federal judgeship misrepresented a nurse's account of her departure from an Alabama state hospital that Mr. Sutton defended. The nurse did not say that she was fired because she had breast cancer. She said she was demoted.

title: Top Employer Gone, Iraqis Scuffle for Jobs
description: His job gone and his savings depleted, Saman Murad clung desperately to the 13-year-old letter that constituted his one thin hope for income-producing work.

title: Madonna's CD Makes Debut at No. 1
description: Madonna's latest album, ''American Life,'' made its debut at No. 1 in the United States and 13 other countries during its first week, but it had a little help: the CD was priced at $9.99 and $11.99 at some larger retail chains in the United States instead of the label's suggested retail price of $18.98. The album sold 240,000 copies in the United States after its release on April 22, according to Nielsen SoundScan, which tracks such data.

title: Editorial Observer; Sorting Out an Eating Plan in a Nation Filled With Dietary Confusion
description: A couple months ago, I met Dr. Robert Atkins in a green room for ''New York Close-Up,'' the talk show on NY1. Dr. Atkins and I both had new books to talk about. His will sell a million copies. Mine won't. Dr. Atkins looked fit and lean, if a little worn from a busy interview schedule. I was a little worn too, but not so fit and lean. ''So how's your cholesterol?'' I wanted to ask him, but didn't, because he probably knew what his was and I didn't know my own. He also had a plan for losing weight, and I didn't. Like many Americans when it comes to thinking about health, I have lived, until recently, not in passive denial but in active avoidance.

title: INSIDE
description: 22 Killed as Tornadoes Leave Swath of Destruction

title: Belgrade Journal; For Partying Mobsters, the Morning After: Prison
description: They line up most days outside Central Prison in Belgrade dressed in elegant finery, the women in faux Chanel or tailored Italian slacks, the men in dark glasses and dark suits over black T-shirts. They clutch Louis Vuitton purses and mobile phones, the men perhaps chain-smoking Marlboro Reds and the women puffing nervously on Davidoff Lights, a local favorite.

title: Some Players Do Not Mind Jumping In Headfirst
description: Roberto Alomar knows he is going to do it the millisecond after his bat touches the ball. It can be a tapper along the third-base line or a sharp grounder in the shortstop hole, but Alomar's internal baseball clock does not wait the three or so seconds for the play to unfold. In that millisecond, Alomar has decided to dive headfirst into first base.

title: Public Health and Civil Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Hartford Bids a Bilingual Goodbye to a White-Collar Past
description: To the outside world, Hartford still conjures images of bankers and brokers, hairdressers and haberdashers, a white-collar legacy of a calmly efficient insurance empire. Indeed, that was Hartford. In 1950.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTCHEK, MIRIAM (''MIMI'')
description: ALTCHEK-Miriam (''Mimi''). Died May 4, 2003, wife of Albert Altchek, M.D., mother of Norman Jawitz, Louis Jawitz, Linda Jawitz, Judy Jawitz Balkin, and grandmother of Paul Jawitz; daughter of Morris Shargel (''the Jewish Caruso''), star of the Lower East Side Yiddish and English Theater, from Lemberg, Poland (now Lvov, Ukraine) and Sarah Wiesen Shargel.

title: Near the Border With Iran, Memories of War Blend With Hope for Better Relations
description: In the weeks of looting that followed the British Army's entry into Basra, Iraq's second largest city, the once resplendent Sheraton Hotel was ransacked, the Museum of Natural History was burned and the mansions of Saddam Hussein's relatives were taken over by squatters.

title: The Faces Of Budget Cuts
description: Cheryl Asbell was fidgety, anxious. She compulsively adjusted the soft-brimmed bucket hat that she wore during the interview in her living room. Now she stared at me, her eyes wide.

title: From Cable Star to Face in the Crowd
description: Winter 2002. Ashleigh Banfield is in Ramallah, the West Bank, interviewing Yasir Arafat. At 34, she is the anchor of her own prime-time program on MSNBC, the cable news network owned by NBC and Microsoft.

title: Subway Token: Currency of the Past
description: Those brass-colored subway tokens now collecting dust in dresser drawers across the city are still worth $1.50, technically. But riders should not try to use them to help pay the $2 fare that went into effect yesterday. And they should not try to redeem them at the local subway stop.

title: Cabdriver Is Charged In Slaying Over a Fare
description: A Long Island taxi driver has been charged with killing a passenger with a tire iron after the rider refused to pay a $5 fare, the police said today.

title: New Smoking Ban: Already Backfiring?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Hopes to Bridge Divide With Europe in Trade Talks
description: Europe and the United States clashed bitterly over the war in Iraq, but a senior American official is urging the two sides to use trade negotiations as a way to mend fences.

title: Funny Cide Will Face Smaller Preakness Field
description: He has a Kentucky Derby victory on his record and will probably face a small Preakness field, one not expected to include Empire Maker. Next time, Funny Cide is not going to sneak up on anyone.

title: What's Behind the Curtain for Network Television's Fall Season
description: For the last several weeks, executives at the broadcast television networks have been locked in screening rooms, assessing the pilot episodes of prospective new shows ordered for the coming season.

title: Justices Set Aside Teenager's Murder Conviction
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 — Awakening a teenage boy in the middle of the night, putting him in handcuffs while he is still in his underwear and taking him out of his home for questioning does indeed amount to an "arrest," the United States Supreme Court said today in setting aside his murder conviction.

title: Sports of The Times; Jefferson May Become a No. 3 Star
description: EVERYONE likes to talk about team play and role players, but the formula for an N.B.A. championship is to have a nucleus of what amounts to three great players. In an era dominated by the Los Angeles Lakers, two just won't do. Shaquille O'Neal, the Lakers' indomitable center, counts as two by himself, and Kobe Bryant, Shaq's mercurial teammate, counts as one and a half. Any team with hopes of snatching the title from them must have three great players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, EDITH
description: FRANKEL-Edith. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Fred Frankel. Loving mother of Diane and Paul Frankel. Interment on Tuesday, 11 AM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

title: Michigan Presence Felt at Training Camp
description: In one corner of the Jets' locker room, the University of Michigan could hold an alumni function. The Jets drafted Wolverines in successive rounds April 26 -- linebacker Victor Hobson in the second round and fullback B.J. Askew in the third -- and they joined a former teammate, offensive lineman Jonathan Goodwin, whom the Jets drafted last year.

title: Political Memo; Pragmatism Meets Ideology: Democrats Draw Battle Lines
description: The first Democratic presidential debate of the campaign, for all its racket and disarray, served to divide the field into two distinct camps. Each embraced a strikingly different appeal to a party that campaign aides describe as hungry to remove President Bush from office, yet deeply worried about its chances for victory next year.

title: Bush Asks Arkansas to Press Senator for Vote on Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  President Bush today carried his campaign for tax cuts to Arkansas, where he urged members of a sympathetic crowd to push Congress  including a Democratic senator whose support he hopes to gain  for "robust" tax reductions.

title: In HBO, AOL Sees a Sibling And, Crucially, A Role Model
description: For the last six months, Jonathan Miller, the chief executive of the America Online division of AOL Time Warner, has pointed to the company's own cable channel HBO as the blueprint for a revival of the shrinking AOL service. His plan is to sell subscriptions to the online equivalent of must-see programming like ''The Sopranos'' that consumers cannot find anywhere else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANSKER, SHIRLEY (NEE KOVEN)
description: DANSKER-Shirley (nee Koven) on May 2, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Raphael M. Dansker. Loving mother of Leslie Toepfer, Steven and Bruce Dansker. Adoring grandmother of Deborah and Jeffrey Pinsky and David Toepfer. Funeral from Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, 10am. Rabbi Robert Levine will officiate. Family will sit shiva Monday following the interment and Tuesday, 4-8pm.

title: Pistons Thank the N.B.A. for Those Two Extra Games
description: When a team like the Detroit Pistons overcomes a three-games-to-one deficit and wins an N.B.A. playoff series with a dominant performance like the one it produced today, the historical magnitude of the event must be acknowledged. The Pistons registered a convincing 108-93 victory over the Orlando Magic at the Palace of Auburn Hills and moved into the Eastern Conference semifinals against the Philadelphia 76ers beginning here Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about Edward L. Gaylord, publisher of The Daily Oklahoman, referred imprecisely to his involvement with the syndicated TV series ''Hee Haw.'' The series was produced by Nick Vanoff in association with Frank Peppiatt and John Aylesworth from 1971 to 1981. Mr. Gaylord's company then bought it and produced it until the series' end, in 1997.

title: Parkfield Journal; Standing on Shaky Ground, and Proud to Be There
description: Earthquakes come with much of the territory in California, a cautionary consideration for living here, like hurricanes in the South, tornadoes in the Midwest and, for now anyway, the Mets in Queens. The state is laced with hundreds of fault lines, some considered unstable enough to produce the next Big One.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Middletown: Police Say Fires Were Arson
description: Fires that occurred at almost the same time last week in two buildings on opposite sides of a street have been determined to have been deliberately set, according to the police. One fire in a house that had been subdivided into apartments and was owned by Wesleyan University was started with gasoline or some other accelerant, the police said. Wesleyan teachers and staff members living in the building escaped from the fire in the predawn hours of April 27 without injury. Less than an hour later, the second fire broke out in a garage across the street. The police said that they had also linked that fire to some form of accelerant but that they had not definitively concluded that the two fires were connected.

title: U.S. Overseer Blames Sanctions By U.N. for Iraqi Gas Shortages
description: Jay Garner, the former lieutenant general who has been in Iraq for nearly a month with a mandate to get the country running again, blamed United Nations sanctions today for the gasoline shortages that have prompted Iraqi anger at the American occupation forces here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKA, GERTRUDE (NEE HELLER)
description: OKA-Gertrude (nee Heller). Of Miami Beach, FL, died at home on May 3rd. Beloved wife of the late Judge Kenneth Oka, former Mayor of Miami Beach. Born in NYC, graduate of Hunter College. An accomplished linguist, Gertrude moved to Miami Beach in 1938 to teach Latin at the Lear School. As First Lady of Miami Beach, in the late 1950's and early 1960's, when it was called the World's Playground, Gertrude enjoyed greeting dignitaries in a catalog of languages. In the early 1960's, Gertrude taught herself Japanese, moved with Kenneth to Tokyo, and gave a speech in Japanese to the people of Fujisawa on behalf of the People-to-People Program. She will be remembered for her remarkable mind and unique style that was spare and contained before the word minimalism was spoken. She is survived by her children Basha Botnick (Daniel) and Michele Oka Doner (Frederick), of NYC, Stephanie Oka Freed and Jonathan Oka of Miami Beach, and three grandsons, Jordan Doner, Jeremy Kenneth Doner, and Randall Freed. Funeral services private.

title: Mayor's Note to Himself: Be Upbeat. Don't Discuss Taxes.
description: As City Hall buzzed yesterday with City Council members and aides poring over a deal that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had struck with state lawmakers to raise taxes, a news flash came from the mayor's office.

title: NEWS ANALYSIS: Schroeder is edging closer to Blair views
description: BRUSSELS:  The question was what he thought of Tony Blair's view of a unipolar world. The reply from Gerhard Schroeder: Blair had made an "accurate" observation, reflecting the power of the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Museums section on April 23 about coming renovations included an outdated reference to the Corcoran Gallery in Washington. It was scheduled to close temporarily later this year but now plans to stay open at least through mid-2005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ALBERT R.
description: GINSBERG-Albert R., on Friday, May 2, 2003, of Silver Spring, MD, formerly of Bronx, NY. Beloved husband of Susan T. Ginsberg, devoted father of Erica Ginsberg, dear brother of the late Arthur Gaines. Also survived by a host of loving family and friends. Interment private. Memorial service at a later date. Donations may be made to the Bronx County Historical Society, 3309 Bainbridge Ave, Bronx, NY 10467, or to a charity of choice.

title: The Carolina Nine
description: Highlight of the joint appearance of nine declared Democratic presidential candidates at the South Carolina fish fry came when the moderator, George Stephanopoulos, asked Senator Joe Lieberman if he was ''too nice'' to be president.

title: Misunderstood Mutants Rack Up $85.8 Million
description: The summer movie season, which now begins when the frost has barely left the lawn, was off to an auspicious start this weekend with the opening of ''X2: X-Men United,'' which has sold an estimated $85.8 million worth of tickets in North American theaters since Friday.

title: Pope Proclaims 5 Spanish Saints During Mass in Center of Madrid
description: Pope John Paul II had already visited Spain four times during his papacy and, before today, had already set a papal record by proclaiming more than 460 saints.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: BUSH SHIFTS FOCUS TO NUCLEAR SALES BY NORTH KOREA
description: Tacitly acknowledging that North Korea may not be deterred from producing plutonium for nuclear weapons, President Bush is now trying to marshal international support for preventing the country from exporting nuclear material, American and foreign officials say.

title: Metro Matters; Well, It Played In Peekskill. Will It in Iowa?
description: JANUARY 2008. An interview with George E. Pataki:

title: Chaos in West Africa: Unending Wars
description: Liberian mercenaries fight alongside Ivory Coast government forces. Guinean soldiers open their barracks for Liberian rebel gun-runners. Veterans of Sierra Leone's insurrection show up to assist rebels in Ivory Coast. Weapons are ferried from Burkina Faso to the Liberian capital, in brazen violation of a United Nations embargo.

title: Bucking Bush, Senator Takes A Thorny Path
description: Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, is the woman who said no -- to her president, to her party's leadership in the Senate, to the House of Representatives. It has not been easy, she says.

title: 50 Years After, Opening Senator Joe McCarthy's Closed Files
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  Fifty years after Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's communist witch hunt, the Senate today made public transcripts of his closed-door questioning of more than 400 witnesses that revealed a calculating side to McCarthy's public persona of a threatening bully who did not hesitate to destroy reputations and lives.

title: Consulting Company Acquired by Omnicom
description: The Omnicom Group in New York, the world's biggest owner of advertising agencies, has acquired Siegelgale, a corporate identity consulting company.

title: Soyuz Lands Off Course After Error Or a Glitch
description: The Russian Soyuz capsule that ferried three astronauts from the International Space Station back to Earth today landed about 260 miles short of its intended target in the steppes of Kazakhstan, officials said, after a technical malfunction or piloting error during its fiery descent.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: DRIVER SOUGHT IN FATAL ACCIDENT The police yesterday were looking for the driver of a car that killed a man early Saturday morning in a hit-and-run accident on the Lower East Side. The victim, Patrick Sinclair, 29, of Manhattan, was crossing East Houston Street near the Orchard Street intersection about 3 a.m. when he was hit by a 1997 Mercedes-Benz convertible, the police said. The car was identified by a front license plate lost at the scene, and later found by officers at the intersection of Mott and Prince Streets in SoHo, the police said. The car is registered to Joseph Saltalamacchia, and investigators were trying to determine who was driving it when the accident occurred, the police said. Mr. Saltalamacchia, 60, has an unlisted phone number and could not be reached yesterday for comment. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: China's 2 Top Leaders Comfort Kin of 70 Lost on Submarine
description: BEIJING, May 5  In another step toward official candor, the television news tonight showed the country's two top leaders comforting several relatives of the 70 men who died in a mysterious submarine accident.

title: A New Start for Mideast Peace
description: Mahmoud Abbas, the new Palestinian prime minister, wrote a book two decades ago calling the Nazi Holocaust of six million Jews an illusion. He is also mistrusted by his people. Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, is an architect of the Jewish settlement movement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, anathema to Palestinian statehood. He is popular with his public for his hard-line response to terror.

title: Yankees Fail to Shake Zito's Trust in Himself
description: Barry Zito switched his gaze from the double play that the Oakland Athletics had completed at first base in the seventh inning to the comfort of the third-base dugout and pumped his left fist. Zito's display was brief, but it was as much animation as he provided all afternoon and it highlighted a dramatic game that featured one of the best young pitchers in the major leagues in Zito and surely the best old pitcher in baseball in Roger Clemens.

title: MediaTalk; On the Cover: Just Another Pretty Face?
description: Lucky, the only leading fashion and beauty magazine to brave the newsstand without a celebrity on its cover, is about to submit to its inner stargazer.

title: Mavericks Wake Up And Avoid Meltdown
description: Dallas Mavericks point guard Nick Van Exel tossed and turned in his bed until 5:30 this morning.

title: Experts Despair of Iraq's Stopping Loss of Relics
description: The ransacking of the National Museum of Iraq in Baghdad last month may have prompted urgent calls for a clampdown on trafficking in Iraqi antiquities, but Iraqi and American officials concede that it will be almost impossible to prevent the continued illegal export of treasures from ancient Mesopotamian sites.

title: Around Alone: From Eye of Storm to American First
description: For the American solo sailor Brad Van Liew, it was a fitting final day to his winning performance in the solo circumnavigation race known as Around Alone. About 250 miles from the finish line of Leg 5 off Newport, R.I., he found himself sandwiched between a howling subtropical low and a coastal front that combined to kick up washing-machine seas and steady winds of more than 50 miles an hour.

title: Want a $38-an-Hour Job? Get in Line
description: Yesterday on the Upper East Side, the usual sidewalk queues formed for Sunday brunch, museum exhibits and Rollerblade rentals.

title: Rebuking His Critics, Head of Israeli Labor Party Steps Down
description: Lashing out at rivals within his own faction, Amram Mitzna quit today as the leader of Israel's left-of-center Labor Party -- a sign of the disarray hobbling Israel's left as the Bush administration presses a new Middle East peace plan.

title: Dueling Fund-Raising Campaigns Undercut Efforts at Stuyvesant
description: When Jinx Cozzi Perullo became principal of Stuyvesant High School in 1995, she says she was stunned to learn that Stuyvesant, one of the city's most elite high schools, made no effort to raise big private donations.

title: Innovation at Hewlett Tries to Evade the Ax
description: The gathering here of 400 of Hewlett-Packard's top scientists and engineers was intended to reassure them that the company was determined not to depart from its historic focus on research and development.

title: Patents; A 'virtual' colonoscopy could take some of the patient's angst out of a rude procedure.
description: IT'S not hard to figure out why a majority of people over 50 put off going to the doctor for a colonoscopy.

title: Trial of Palestinian Leader Focuses Attention on Israeli Courts
description: Marwan Barghouti, the Palestinian leader charged with orchestrating 26 killings in the current violence between Israel and the Palestinians, was ushered into District Court today in his brown prison uniform and unleashed what has become his familiar objections.

title: Summer Films, Already
description: The ''summer'' movie season has started earlier than ever this year, with 20th Century Fox's would-be blockbuster ''X2: XMen United'' having opened Friday and Warner Brothers' ''The Matrix Reloaded'' set for May 15. Only time and ticket buyers will tell if these or other films can match the box-office totals in recent years by successful movies that stole a march on summer.

title: Giants' Rookies Show Speed and Agility at Camp
description: Jim Fassel posed for pictures several times with defensive tackle William Joseph during the Giants' rookie minicamp this weekend, the coach and the first-round draft pick grinning together. Fassel punctuated each photo opportunity by slapping Joseph on his massive shoulders and smiling as if he were a farmer pounding on the side of a load of hay, thoroughly satisfied with his crop.

title: Swans in an Up-to-Date Lake
description: There is no old-fashioned storybook tone to the ''Swan Lake'' with a difference that Peter Martins staged so creatively with the Danish painter Per Kirkeby for the New York City Ballet in 1999 and that the company revived for the first time in three years with three casts over the weekend.

title: New 'Gypsy' Struts, Silencing Naysayers
description: By the time Momma Rose had had her turn, they knew they had a hit.

title: New Findings On Weapons To Combat Deadly Virus
description: New laboratory findings support the theory that the SARS virus can survive up to four days on contaminated household surfaces like toilets but that disinfectants like bleach are effective weapons to kill it, the World Health Organization said yesterday.

title: Green Thumbs Versus Sticky Fingers; Gardeners Rescue Parks Beset by Theft and Neglect
description: Jackie Robinson Park is green and beautiful, fixed up over the last few years by Michael Scott Lytle, a city gardener, and a squad of volunteers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONERKAMP, FREDERICK W. JR.
description: HONERKAMP-Frederick W. Jr., 86, of Southold, died at Eastern Long Island Hospital on May 2, 2003. Husband of the late Mary (Worthington). Chief Executive Officer of F.W. Honerkamp Co., Inc., of the Bronx. Graduate of Notre Dame University, Class of 1939. Father of Anne Olsen and her husband Gary of Southold, Frederick W. III and his wife Kathleen of Midland, Michigan, Joseph P. and Catherine of Garden City, NY, and Mary Beth Snee and her husband Joseph of West Chester, PA. Also leaves 11 grandchildren and one greatgrandchild and a sister, Margaret H. McNally of Breezy Point, NY. Visiting hours Monday, 2-4 and 7-9pm, at the William F. Coster Funeral Home, Main Road, Cutchogue. Prayer service 7:30pm. Mass Tuesday, 10am, at St. Patrick's RC Church, Southold, with burial following in St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: Transit Fare Increase Goes Into Effect, and Suddenly 50 Cents Buys Lots of Complaints
description: A man who had too much to drink, a woman who worked late, a couple returning from an evening at a comedy club. They were all in this together.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGHT, HOWARD ATWOOD (WOODY)
description: KNIGHT - Howard Atwood (Woody). 61, of New Canaan, CT, and Stowe, VT, died suddenly on May 1st at his home in Connecticut. Born 1942 in Providence, RI, he was the son of the late Louise Atwood and Richard Brayton Knight, and brother of James Knight of Lake Forest, IL, and the late Richard Dexter Knight. He is survived by his wife Bonnie, five children, Heather Knight Pech of Darien, CT, Heidi Knight Brackenridge of Lake Forest, IL, Howard A. (Chip) Knight Jr. of Stowe, VT, Elizabeth R. (Nifer) Knight of Stowe, VT, and Splinter Knight of Stowe, VT, and five grandchildren. Mr. Knight was a graduate of St. Georges School, Williams College, and Yale Law School, where he was on the Yale Law Review. After clerking for a federal judge, he joined the firm of Sullivan and Cromwell in New York, and was a partner at Cummings and Lockwood in Stamford, CT, and General Counsel of the Farrell Lines. Mr. Knight was a leading international businessman with responsibilities that included: Managing Director of Weeks Petroleum Ltd. (Australia), Chairman and CEO of Avalon Energy, a NYSE company, President of Investment Banking, Equity Transactions and Corporate Strategy for Prudential Securities of New York, Vice Chairman and Chief Operating Officer of SBS Broadcasting SA of London. He was a Director of Lions Gate Entertainment of Los Angeles, Agaton Fitness AB of Sweden, The Aberdeen Funds of Australia and formerly a Director of Moonie Oil Company of Australia, and Saugatuck Capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORK, DR. GERARD J.
description: STORK-Dr. Gerard J. A former radiologist who practiced medicine in Queens, New York for 43 years and was one of the first practitioners of radiation for the treatment of cancer, died on Friday, May 2, 2003, at the Memorial Hospital at Easton. He was 88. Born in Maspeth, New York in 1914, Dr. Stork graduated from St. John's University and Downstate Medical School of the State University of New York. He served as a major in the U.S. Army Medical Corps during WWII and opened offices in Fresh Meadows, Elmhurst and Ridgewood, New York after the war. A longtime member of the Queens Medical Society, his practice operated the first privately owned cobalt machine in New York City. After retiring from medicine, Dr. Stork moved to St. Michaels, Maryland in 1995. His survivors include his wife Mary, six sons and two daughters, 23 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Visiting hours will be at the Fairchild Funeral Home in Manhasset, New York on Tuesday, May 6, 2003, from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10 AM on Wednesday, May 7, 2003, at St. Mary's Catholic Church in Manhasset, New York. Burial will follow in St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, New York. Memorial donations may be made to the St. Vincent de Paul Society and Food for the Poor, Deerfield Beach, FL.

description: A body found floating near the shore of Hart Island yesterday was believed to be one of the four teenage boys who disappeared in January while on a frigid nighttime boating expedition on the Long Island Sound, the police said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Hague Tribunal Indicts 2
description: Two top henchmen of the former Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic were indicted on war crimes charges by the international tribunal in The Hague. The foreign minister of Montenegro said they would probably be sent to face trial there. Jovica Stanisic, the secret police chief, and Franko Simatovic, founder of the paramilitary unit accused of assassinating Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic, were detained with others suspected of war crimes after Mr. Djindjic's assassination on March 12. He was killed by two sniper bullets after he took steps to send more war crimes suspects to face trial in The Hague. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Council Grudgingly Approves Raising Sales and Income Taxes to Help Balance the Budget
description: The City Council voted overwhelmingly but grudgingly yesterday for a plan that would help the city balance its budget by raising sales taxes slightly and increasing income taxes on many residents.

title: Sales of U.S. Company's Drug Rise as Chinese Try It Against SARS
description: Sales of an antiviral drug produced by a small biotechnology company are surging because doctors in China are using it in an attempt to contain the widening outbreak of SARS, company officials said yesterday.

title: In Victory for Powell, Bush Names Civilian Overseer for Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  President Bush appointed a new civilian administrator for Iraq today, settling a sharp disagreement between the State and Defense Departments over how best to manage that country during its recovery and reconstruction.

title: Aide to Indicted Ex-Official Confesses to Misusing Funds
description: A former deputy to Russell A. Harding, the former president of the city's Housing Development Corporation who is charged with misusing hundreds of thousands of dollars of the agency's money, pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in the scheme, and implicated Mr. Harding.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Monument Honors Sakharov
description: Officials in St. Petersburg unveiled a monument to Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet-era physicist and human rights campaigner who won the Nobel Peace prize in 1975. The statue, 12 feet tall, is the first monument built in Russia to honor Dr. Sakharov, who died in 1989. His widow, Yelena Bonner, who has opposed the building of such monuments because of the state of human rights in Russia, reiterated her opposition but said she would not take any legal action. ''It is out of place to erect a monument to Sakharov in today's Russia,'' she said on Ekho Moskvy radio. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Howell Township: Man Dies In Crash Of Small Plane
description: A single-engine plane crashed yesterday afternoon in the woods near the Monmouth Executive Airport, killing one of the two people on board and critically injuring the other, the authorities said. The plane, a Beech A-36, was attempting to land for refueling on a flight from Sarasota, Fla., to Bridgeport, Conn., when it crashed a mile short of the runway, said Arlene Salac, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The dead man was identified as Paul Bray, 75, of Bradenton, Fla.; the injured man is his son, Peter Albright Bray, 48, of Norwalk, Conn. Robert Hanley (NYT)

description: As army troops began a rescue effort this morning, Marxist guerrillas executed a provincial governor, a former minister of justice and eight others they had been holding hostage in the mountains of northern Colombia, the presidential palace said in a statement released late tonight.

The reporters Jonathan Alter and Joshua Green, in a joint effort by the publications, explain that the conservative author William Bennett likes to gamble and ''speaks out, often indignantly, about almost every moral issue except one -- gambling.''

description: In another arresting step toward official candor, the television news tonight showed the country's two top leaders comforting several relatives of the 70 men who died in a mysterious submarine accident.

description: An American envoy trying to generate momentum for a new Middle East peace initiative said today that Palestinians must halt violence and that Israel must ease tough security measures to nudge the plan forward.

description: In a remarkable scene, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy appeared at his own bribery trial today and said he had entered into the business deal in question because Bettino Craxi, the prime minister at the time, urged him to do so for the good of Italy.

The future regime in Baghdad is intended to replace unreliable Saudi Arabia as the US' most important ally in the region. The oil industry is at the center of reconstruction efforts.

description: EARLY one morning last month, 14 small-business owners gathered around a table and, over coffee and muffins, spoke for the next two hours of their curiosity and qualms about taking the technological plunge into Web sites, company e-mail addresses and perhaps even selling over the Internet.

title: World Business Briefing: Australia
description: AUSTRALIA: DISSENT IN MINING BID The managing director of MIM, an Australian-based producer of coal and copper, is resisting a $3 billion takeover bid despite the approval of its other board members. The director, Vincent Gauci, maintained in a letter Friday that the bid, made by Xstrata, a Swiss-controlled mining company based in London, was inadequate and opportunistic. The board of MIM, founded 75 years ago, described the bid as fair and in the best interests of shareholders. Xstrata requires approval by a majority of shareholders and 75 percent of votes over all to acquire MIM. Xstrata proposes a cash payment of $2.1 billion and assumption of about $890 million debt. John Shaw (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Leader For Republican National Committee?
description: The White House is reported to be considering moving Marc Racicot, left, the former governor of Montana, from chairman of the Republican National Committee to a senior position in President Bush's re-election campaign and replacing him with Ed Gillespie, a Republican lobbyist and campaign operative. The possible move was first described in Roll Call. Mr. Gillespie worked for Representative Dick Armey of Texas, served as a spokesman for the Bush campaign in 2000 and helped steer Elizabeth Dole's successful Senate campaign last year. ''They know my jersey number,'' Mr. Gillespie said of the White House. ''If they call it, I'll run onto the field.'' Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HARTLEY J.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Hartley J., 83, died May 5, 2003. Born in New York City, July 12, 1920. Attended Columbia Grammar School and a graduate of the University of Michigan, 1941. LCDR U.S. Navy until 1945. Former President of Scout Tex, Inc. Beloved husband of Ellen, cherished father of Hartley Jr., Patricia Tarr and Barbara Washkowitz. Loving grandfather to Jennifer and Jeff Tarr Jr., Emily, Andrew and Peter Washkowitz. Devoted father-in-law to Jeff Tarr and Alan Washkowitz. Hartley possessed an unusual flair for living and treasured his friends and family. He always had a story to tell accompanied by a great sense of humor. All who knew him will mourn his passing. Services Wednesday, 11:30AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Soldiers Charge Abuse
description: A day after 14 soldiers from Russia's 58th Army deserted near their base in the southern city of Vladikavkaz, military prosecutors announced that they had begun a criminal investigation into physical abuse by two of the soldiers' sergeants, officials told the Interfax news agency. Mass desertions have become a common occurrence in Russia's military as poorly paid conscripts have fled complaining of violent harassment and abuse. Criminal cases against superiors, however, remain rare. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: ON the second floor of 336 West 37th Street in Manhattan, a sign on the door of Regency Fashion says the minimum wage is $5.15 an hour. Someone has scribbled a 1 after the dollar sign. Inside, most of the sewing machines are silent. A Chinese deity looks over the factory floor from behind a mound of partly burned incense sticks. Several of the dozen workers have tied strips of red fabric around their noses to block the dust.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Worker Hurt In Fire
description: A man was seriously injured yesterday when fire engulfed the Queens recycling plant where he worked, and a firefighter was slightly hurt when the building started to buckle, a Fire Department spokesman said. An explosion was reported at 2:50 a.m. yesterday at the plant, a one-story brick building at 49-10 Grand Avenue in Maspeth. Flames spread quickly, the spokesman said, and more than 100 firefighters worked for more than two hours before bringing it under control around 5:30 a.m. The roof and a wall of the building collapsed, injuring a firefighter. He was treated at a hospital and released. The injured worker was taken to the Weill-Cornell Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital, where he was listed in serious condition. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Businessman Robbed Of $40,000
description: Two men stole $40,000 in cash yesterday from a businessman on his way to a local bank, the police said. The man's car was struck in the rear near 56th Street and Second Avenue in Sunset Park at 11:20 a.m. by a gray Ford Aerostar minivan, they said. When the victim stopped to check on the damage, an armed man who had not been riding in the van forced him into the back of the car and stole the cash from the glove compartment, Detective Kevin Czartoryski said. The van driver and the armed man, both in their 30's, left the minivan, which had been stolen, and took off in a dark-colored car, Detective Czartoryski said. One man was said to be wearing a blue jacket with a red collar. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Missing In Action: Truth
description: When I raised the Mystery of the Missing W.M.D. recently, hawks fired barrages of reproachful e-mail at me. The gist was: ''You *&#*! Who cares if we never find weapons of mass destruction, because we've liberated the Iraqi people from a murderous tyrant.''

title: ICG Is Planning Layoffs
description: ICG Communications, a fiber optic network operator that emerged from bankruptcy protection in October, will lay off as much as 20 percent of its work force to cope with a drop in prices for its services.

title: Corrections

Valeo. The Supreme Court equated campaign spending, not donations, with constitutionally protected free speech, and it permitted limits on donations.

description: He will forever be known as the man who captured Adolf Eichmann. But more than 40 years after he snatched that fugitive Nazi off a street in Argentina to face judgment in Jerusalem for directing the mass murder of Jews, Peter Zvi Malkin is making a new mark as the man who captured Eichmann on paper.

title: Finding Ways to Afford the Safety Net

title: Transcripts Detail Secret Questioning In 50's by McCarthy
description: Aaron Copland, the composer, fiercely defended himself, declaring, ''I have not been a Communist in the past and I am not now a Communist.'' Langston Hughes, the poet, protested that he had not read much about Marxism ''beyond the introduction of the Communist Manifesto.'' Dashiell Hammett, the mystery writer, invoked the Fifth Amendment.

title: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged, but Remains Wary About Economy
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  The Federal Reserve held short-term interest rates steady today but said it was worried about the risks of a sustained fall in prices, commonly known as deflation.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Texas Court Rebuked on Illegal Arrest
description: The Supreme Court delivered an unusual rebuke to a Texas appeals court today by unanimously setting aside the murder conviction of a teenager whose confession, the justices found, was the product of an illegal arrest and should not have been introduced at his trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, MURIEL
description: BIRNBAUM-Muriel. Beloved widow of the late Harris Birnbaum and loving and wonderful mother to Rick and Janet Birnbaum, and Barry and Ellen Birnbaum. Proud grandmother of Ron, Alice and Charles Birnbaum. Maternal and nurturing aunt to Tully and Beverly Safian, Sara Ann and Stan Wallerstein, Marylin and Stanley Hookman and Susan and Les Gamza. Proud survivng matriarch of the Goldstein sisters, Lillian, Florence and Muriel, and joyful and loving great-aunt to Larry Hookman, Laurie (Gamza) Zucker, Alan Gamza, Janet (Safian) Siegelman, Marc Safian, David Safian, Jeff Wallerstein and Susan Scherr, and their loving spouses and children. She always looked at the bright side and loved her extended family with all her heart. Her upbeat presence and pot roast will be hard to replace and never forgotten. Funeral and interment will be at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, on Tuesday morning, May 6th, 2003, at 9:45 AM.

description: The crook-necked arabesque? Nowhere in evidence. The razor-elbowed cutoff? Unnecessary. There wasn't even a subtle, but ever so strategic, shove.

title: In Pakistan Border Towns, Taliban Has a Resurgence
description: It is like a scene from the old days of the Taliban in Afghanistan. Dozens of religious students, or talibs, and other Afghan exiles with thickly wound turbans and long beards gather on Thursday afternoons on two of the main squares in this city.

title: Newark Archdiocese to Close a High School
description: Bishop Francis Essex Catholic High School, which has been considered an attractive alternative to public schools for black and Hispanic students in the area, will close at the end of June, according to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark.

title: Hong Kong to Set Up a Center To Conduct SARS Research
description: Hong Kong will establish a regional medical surveillance and research center to study SARS and spot future illnesses before they can turn into epidemics, and will ask the neighboring Guangdong Province to cooperate, Hong Kong's leader announced today.

title: The Enigmatic Empire of the Vitamin King of Mexico
description: As a child, Jorge Vergara Madrigal used to hang around the sets of the low-budget action films his uncle produced, featuring the Mexican classic wrestler superhero, El Santo. Mr. Vergara and his cousins helped with special effects, operating cars without drivers and concocting spider webs from glue.

description: OXFORD HEALTH PLANS reported improved first-quarter earnings yesterday and raised its profits forecast for the year, becoming the latest health insurer to benefit from a nationwide trend of moderating hospital and drug costs.

title: This and $2 Will Get You a Train Ride
description: Barring a 12th-hour decision by a judge this month, the $2 subway fare is here to stay. So for the moment, let us put aside the report of the state comptroller and the report of the city comptroller and the hearings by state lawmakers and the case pending in state court and conduct a really important inquiry regarding the Metropolitan Transportation Authority: When will it raise your fares again and by how much?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOBA, EUGENE RICHARD
description: ZOBA-Eugene Richard, on May 2, 2003 at age 66. Loving son of Julia Augustyniak. Dear brother of Nelson and the late William Zoba. Devoted brother-in-law of Chris Zoba. Also survived by his nephews, Bruce, Scott and Greg. Services Wednesday, May 7th, 5 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment private.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deadline In Israel Terror Case
description: A magistrate's court said Scotland Yard must either charge or release by tonight the six people detained by antiterror police over the weekend in connection with the suicide bombing in Tel Aviv last Wednesday. The bombing, which killed three people, was carried out by Asif Hanif, 21, a Briton from West London. Five of the six are believed to be friends and relatives of Omar Khan Sharif, 27, a second Briton who fled after his body bomb failed to detonate and is still being sought by Israeli security forces. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Bill Reduces Blue-Collar Obligations For Pensions
description: A bill pending in the House of Representatives would allow businesses with union workers to reduce their company pension obligations by billions of dollars, because statistics show that most blue-collar workers do not live as long as other Americans.

title: Group of 8 Finds Unity On the Threat Of Terrorism
description: Despite lingering political differences, the justice and interior ministers of the world's leading industrialized countries appeared to reach unanimity today on the persistence of the terrorist threat, even if their governments differ at times on the means to counter it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINER, BENJAMIN
description: FEINER - Benjamin, died April 28 at age 91. He will be deeply missed by his children, Larry and Lisa Feiner; by his son-in-law and friend, Barry Commoner; by his brother, Isaac Feiner; by his nieces and nephews, Marc & Roberta Levine, Steve & Paul Brand, and Mauro Zulli; and by his aide and devoted friend, Indra Bisram. He was a strong, responsible, loving and generous man with a warmly sardonic sense of humor and a strong social conscience. He expressed that social conscience through his many years of work as an occupational health and safety engineer for the NYS Department of Labor, and through the chapters he contributed to a seminal work in the field, ''Dangerous Properties of Industrial Materials.'' He was an unusually decent man who lived with grace and honor.

title: City's Crisis Doesn't Mirror The Big Picture, Economists Say
description: For months, the New York City economy has been described in terms neither encouraging nor dire. Sluggish, it has been called by economists. Anemic. Weak. Joblessness is up and wages are down, but the city has seen worse. Firms are not departing, home prices have not plummeted, residents are not jumping ship.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: AMP Shares Fall
description: Shares of Australia's largest financial services group, AMP, fell 40 percent as the market responded to its decision to sell additional stock and to spin off a money-losing operation in Britain. AMP said last week that it would sell 1.5 billion Australian dollars ($951 million) worth of shares and spin off the British unit, which runs the Henderson Global Investors fund. Amp also cut its annual profit forecast by 20 percent. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Preface
description: It was the evening of April 12, 1932, and Grand Hotel was about to open with Greta Garbo and John Barrymore. Worshipers of the stars of the Hollywood firmament choked the sidewalk outside the Astor and also the theater lobby, while policemen afoot and on horse urged the throng to keep moving, Mordaunt Hall wrote in The New York Times. Chief critic of the paper, Hall was occasionally a reporter, too, and here he conveyed the electricity of a remarkable movie moment.

title: An Orchid by Any Other Name: An Asparagus?
description: Orchids can be elegant, gaudy, lurid and even downright bizarre. But while the unusual flowers of these species have excited plant lovers for centuries, they have also made it difficult for evolutionary biologists to place them in the plant family tree and identify their closest relatives.

title: Modern's Expansion Grows In Cost
description: The sound of cement grinders, sledge hammers and drills at 7 every weekday morning has regularly woken neighborhood residents near the Museum of Modern Art's ambitious expansion project. The winter's harsh weather did not slow things down, and the project is on schedule, museum officials say.
