description: DIAMOND-Hana Mackler, ''The Boot Lady.'' On May 4, 2003. Born to Albert and Lee Mackler, October 5, 1916. Wife of the late Charles. Mother of Susan Nathanson, mother - in - law of Barry, grandmother of Richard, Laurie and Greg, greatgrandmother of Julia, sister of Flore and the late Estelle. She did it her way.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Water Board Adopts Rate Increase
description: The city water board adopted a 5.5 percent increase in water rates yesterday, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection said. The new rate, $1.52 per 748 gallons (up from $1.44) will take effect July 1, said the spokesman, Charles Sturcken. The average family of four uses 100,000 gallons a year and will spend $526 a year, up from $499 last year. That figure includes the processing of waste water. Mr. Sturcken said that costs had risen in part because of the need to meet water quality standards, address security risks, and keep harbor water clean with water treatment plants, but he added that the price and increase were lower than those in many other major cities. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Death Toll From Fire at Rhode Island Club Rises to 100
description: A woman who clung to life for more than 10 weeks after being badly burned in a Rhode Island nightclub fire died on Sunday night, raising the death toll from the blaze to 100.

title: Cable and Phone Shares Fall On Verizon Price-Cut Move
description: Shares in two crucial gauges of market activity declined yesterday as cable television and telephone stocks slid after Verizon Communications cut prices for high-speed Internet service.

title: Woman on Most Wanted List Of 55 Iraqi Leaders Is Seized
description: American authorities have picked up Dr. Huda Salih Mahdi Ammash, a senior biologist in Iraq's suspected biological warfare program, according to a Defense Department official. She is the only woman on the military's 55-person most wanted list.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARMSTRONG, FRANK
description: ARMSTRONG-Frank. Born on October 8, 1895, died May 6, 1959. Always remembered, never forgotten.

title: GENCORP AGREES TO BUY SEQUA'S ROCKET UNIT
description: GenCorp Inc., a maker of automotive and aerospace components, agreed to buy the Sequa Corporation's rocket-propulsion unit for about $133 million to increase business in the military and space industries. The unit, the Atlantic Research Corporation, develops and manufactures solid propulsion systems for rockets, gas generators and auxiliary rocket motors and had sales of about $150 million in 2002. GenCorp will combine the assets of Atlantic Research with those of a subsidiary, the Aerojet-General Corporation, GenCorp said. The acquisition will help GenCorp compete in the market for precision-strike systems, propulsion and missile defense, according to Aerojet's president, Mike Martin. Gencorp is based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., and Sequa is based in New York.

title: In Most Areas, Power Lines Are Expected to Hum Smoothly
description: Electricity in New York and New England will be reliable this summer, except possibly in southwestern Connecticut, a regional electricity organization said yesterday in its annual assessment.

title: Sales Jump at Cox, Exceeding Forecast
description: Cox Communications, the cable operator, posted a first-quarter net loss of $29.2 million yesterday as expenses rose, but its sales jumped 16 percent because of growth in new services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNIDERMAN, JOHN M.
description: SNIDERMAN-John M., of Englewood, NJ. Beloved husbang of Anita. Loving father of Rosanne and Rene, Adam, Robert, Nathaniel and Dana. Loving grandfather of Max, Ruby, Lona and Lilah. Proud member of United States Marine Corp. Services were held on Monday. Shiva at residence until Monday, May 12. A caring and gentle man. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Congregation Ahavath Torah, Englewood, New Jersey.

title: Suzy Parker, Willowy Model And Actress of 50's, Dies at 69
description: Suzy Parker, the willowy, red-headed beauty whose elegant poses on scores of magazine covers defined glamour in the 1950's and paved the way for the supermodels to follow, died on Saturday at her home in Montecito, Calif. She was 69.

description: To the Editor:

title: Census Numbers for Hispanic Subgroups Rise
description: The United States Census Bureau, which had been accused of underestimating the size of many Hispanic groups in the United States as a result of a small change in the wording of a single question on the 2000 census, yesterday released significantly larger estimates of the numbers of Dominicans, Colombians, Salvadorans, Guatemalans and many other groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, PAUL C.
description: WEISS-Paul C. Beloved son, nephew, uncle, grandson, brother and cousin. He will be dearly missed.

title: BOARD AUTHORIZES INCREASES IN RENT UP TO 8.5 PERCENT
description: Setting the stage for what would be the largest rent increases since 1989, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board gave landlords preliminary approval last night to raise rents up to 8.5 percent for the one million apartments affected by rent stabilization.

title: An Urgent Task for the Court
description: Legal experts doubt that the Supreme Court will rearrange its schedule so it can rule on the vital issue of campaign finance reform before its current term ends this summer. We think, however, that it should make every effort to do so. A ruling on the McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform law by a three-judge federal panel, upholding some parts of the law but rejecting others, has created widespread confusion. For the court to delay a ruling until it convened for a new term in October would leave key questions involving the raising and spending of millions of dollars unresolved only months before the onset of the presidential primaries. This would be cutting things dangerously close.

title: DRUG MAKER TO SEEK APPROVAL FOR LUPUS MEDICINE
description: The La Jolla Pharmaceutical Corporation, a biopharmaceutical company, said yesterday that it would seek Food and Drug Administration approval for its lupus treatment Riquent, setting off a 27 percent gain in its stock price. The company, which is based in San Diego, said it planned to file the application by the end of the year. La Jolla said two studies of patients with lupus, a life-threatening autoimmune disease, showed that Riquent might prevent inflammation that can cause kidney damage and failure.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Boston Bans Workplace Smoking
description: Tobacco products can be added to the list of things banned in Boston, as the city outlawed smoking in all indoor workplaces. The ban will affect 700 bars and nightclubs. Owners who do not comply with the regulations will be fined $100 for their first offense, with subsequent violations costing businesses up to $1,000, said Kristin O'Connor, a spokeswoman for the Boston Public Health Commission. Businesses that derive more than 60 percent of their profit from tobacco products, designated hotel rooms and religious ceremonies that incorporate smoking will be exempt from the ban, she said. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ABRAHAM
description: FREEDMAN-Abraham, 79, of Mt. Vernon, NY, on May 4, 2003. Loving husband of Beverly for 53 years; devoted father of Michael (Dorothy), Steven, Alan (Marilyn); adored Pop-Pop of T.J., Stacy, Anna, David and Rachel; beloved brother of Bert, Hannah, Evelyn, and the late Wilbur. Services will be 1:30 PM at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Bank Official Says Hussein's Son Took $1 Billion in Cash
description: In the hours before American bombs began falling on the Iraqi capital, one of President Saddam Hussein's sons and a close adviser carried off nearly $1 billion in cash from the country's Central Bank, according to American and Iraqi officials here.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Says a Million Have Asthma
description: Asthma has been diagnosed in one million New York City residents -- one in every eight, including 300,000 children -- at some time, according to a city report released yesterday. The report, based on a survey of 10,000 people conducted by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, says that 17 percent of children have had such a diagnosis. Among adults, 40 percent of those who have been told they have asthma say they still have the disease. And of those, 40 percent say they went to an emergency room for asthma treatment at least once last year. Asthma leads to 25,000 emergency room visits each year in the city, and more than 200 deaths. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: In a Tentative Step Toward Iraqi Democracy, a Northern City Chooses an Interim Government
description: Iraq took its first faltering step toward democracy today, when a large ethnically diverse group of local leaders held an election to choose an interim government in this northern city, Iraq's third largest.

title: U.S. and Singapore Sign Free Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 - President Bush signed a free trade agreement today with Singapore, his first since Congress granted him trade promotion authority last summer and the largest since the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about the death of a man on Saturday in a hit-and-run accident on the Lower East Side of Manhattan misstated his surname. He was Patrick Sinclair Hale, not Patrick Sinclair.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Utility Bid Withdrawn
description: Gas Natural, Spain's biggest natural gas company, withdrew its 26 billion euro ($29 billion) bid for a rival, Iberdrola, and said it would not attempt any other takeovers after regulators opposed the move. Spain's National Energy Commission last week rejected the hostile bid for Iberdrola, Spain's second-largest power utility. Shareholders of Iberdrola also opposed the takeover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROTZKY, HELEN (NEE WIESENBERGER)
description: TROTZKY - Helen (nee Wiesenberger) died May 5, 2003 peacefully at home in her 99th year. Devoted wife to the late Nathan Trotzky, beloved sister to the late Arthur Wiesenberger, cherished mother of Doris and Dr. Bernard Weiss, Marie and Jules Rosen, adored grandmother to Wendy and Judd Meltzer, Cathy and Seymour Zises, Jonathan and Caroline Rosen and Billy and Susy Rosen, precious ''Grandma Dear'' to great-grandchildren Samantha and Jonathan, Joshua, Aaron, Sam, Ben, Natalie, Matthew, Suzanne and Ericka. Dear aunt to Nipper Von Wiesenberger. You will always be in our hearts; never to be forgotten. We love you. Interment private. Family will receive Wednesday, 7-9 PM at the home of Mrs. Jules Rosen 190 E. 72nd Street.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Electronic Arts To Develop Superman Games
description: Electronic Arts, the video game maker, said yesterday that it had won rights from AOL Time Warner to develop games based on the Superman character. Warner Brothers Entertainment and DC Comics, both AOL units, sold multiyear rights beginning in 2004 to Electronic Arts to make Superman games for personal computers, video game consoles and hand-held computers, said Shelly Eckenroth, an outside spokeswoman for Electronic Arts. Terms were not disclosed. Electronic Arts also said it had started developing ''The Sims 2,'' with improved graphics and more complex relationships among the characters, which the players control. ''The Sims Deluxe'' was No. 14 in March sales among software products using Microsoft's Windows operating system, the NPD Group/NPD Techworld said. Electronic Arts said it would publish games based on a Superman film in production by Warner Brothers. The company also said it won the right to make games based on Superman comic books. Release dates have not been set for the Superman games, Ms. Eckenroth said. Shares of Electronic Arts rose 36 cents, to $62.14, on Nasdaq.

description: Even now, slowed by a stroke and 70 years past his boyhood toiling in the fields as a tenant farmer, Isaac Lang Jr. can still recall the terrible secrets hidden inside the old tobacco barn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, IRENE
description: GARDNER-Irene. On April 7, 2003 in her 90th year, after a long illness. A resident of Amityville, LI, Mrs. Gardner was the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Loewenstein and the wife of the late Frederick Gardner. A native of Ichenhausen, Germany, she served in the British Army, North African Campaign, during WW II. She was educated at the Sorbonne, Columbia Univerity and NYU and maintained close association with the latter institution all her life. She was a passionate supporter of many causes - mainly animal protection and conservation organizations, the Democratic Party and Public Broadcasting. She loved literature and books, and with her husband, was a member of the Long Island Book Collectors. She was a vibrant and active woman who traveled extensively, and will be missed by family and friends all over the world.

description: On more than a few occasions this season, Mark Cuban contorted his face and puffed out his pectorals: the portrait of a deranged fan coiling to strike over a missed call.

title: Most Iraqi Treasures Are Said to Be Kept Safe
description: A top British Museum official said yesterday that his Iraqi counterparts told him they had largely emptied display cases at the National Museum in Baghdad months before the start of the Iraq war, storing many of the museum's most precious artifacts in secure ''repositories.''

description: Every visitor to the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, which wrapped up its 35th edition on Sunday, experiences the sensation of walking among the 10 outdoor stages and hearing two overlapping sets at once. The funny thing is how often the combined music fits together.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: More Unrest Over Sars
description: A second civil disturbance inspired by fears of SARS was reported, this time from the eastern coastal province of Zhejiang, where 1,000 villagers surrounded a government office and smashed police and government cars. The villagers were protesting the quarantining of suspected SARS patients in the building, fearing it could pose a risk to residents, Reuters reported. The Sunday before last, thousands of townspeople and villagers near Tianjin, east of Beijing, ransacked a school building that municipal officials were converting into a residence for people exposed to SARS. Later the Tianjin government dropped the plan. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Increases Chip Speed
description: Texas Instruments said yesterday that it had broken the one-gigahertz barrier for digital signal processing chips, increasing the top speed for such chips by nearly 40 percent. The company said that the new chip design would cut costs for communications systems and make new applications possible, such as image processing implants that could allow a blind person to see well enough to distinguish a face. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: U.N. AGREES ON LIBERIA SANCTIONS The United Nations Security Council agreed informally to extend existing sanctions against the Liberian government of Charles Taylor and it is likely to extend the current arms embargo to other groups in the strife-torn West African region. The resolution, expected to be adopted today, envisions an embargo on the timber exports that are said to further the flow of arms. That extension of the embargo would take effect July 7, said Munir Akram, Pakistan's envoy, who is presiding over the council. In a prepared statement, Mr. Akram said the council "called on the government of Liberia," as well as all armed rebel groups, "to enter into cease-fire talks without preconditions."    Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: New Advice To Runners: Don't Drink The Water

You may be seriously dehydrated, risking dizziness, collapse, even death. ''Stay ahead of your thirst,'' athletes and would-be athletes are told.

title: ALCOA WILL BUY OUT SOUTH AMERICAN PARTNER
description: Alcoa Inc., the world's biggest aluminum maker, said it would pay $410 million in stock to the Camargo Correa Group for the 40.9 percent of Alcoa's South American operations that it does not already own. The purchase will add to earnings within its first year and will be completed in the third quarter, Alcoa said. When the purchase is complete, Alcoa will own plants in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela. The biggest operation, including aluminum refining, smelting, parts-making and hydroelectric power plants, is in Brazil. Alcoa is based in Pittsburgh.

title: When Enforcement Becomes Harassment
description: From the instant the Enron scandal broke, it was clear that Washington would take strong action: restoring public confidence in American business would require both laws and law enforcement that were up to the task. But when government acts, as it must, there is always the question of how far it should go, and where the line is drawn between effective action and overreaching.

title: People
description: Jennifer Garr was named to the new post of director for client services at the Tampa, Fla., office of West Wayne. She had been executive vice president, chief marketing officer and management director at Publicis in New York, part of the Publicis Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe.

description: The dollar continued its slide against the euro and the yen yesterday, as new data indicated that the foreign appetite for United States stocks and bonds was slowing.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Airport Contract Voided
description: The Philippine Supreme Court has invalidated the contract awarded to a group of investors, including the German operator of the Frankfurt airport, to build a new international air terminal in Manila. The court said the partners did not have the ''requisite financial capacity'' to complete the project when the contract was awarded in 1997. The German company, Fraport, said it expected to appeal the ruling and would seek compensation for the terminal, which is completed but not open. Mark Landler (NYT)

description: For years, it seemed, women in science were like Alice Through the Looking Glass, racing frantically alongside that tedious Red Queen only to be told, sorry, m'dear, ''it takes all the running you can do to keep in the same place.''

title: Walter Sisulu, Mandela Mentor and Comrade, Dies at 90
description: Walter Sisulu, one of Nelson Mandela's earliest political mentors and his closest collaborator for half a century in the campaign against South Africa's racist political order, died yesterday in Johannesburg. He was 90.

Adored grandfather of Stephanie, Matthew, Katie, Emily, David and Lauren. Cherished brother of Jane Goldblatt and the late Andrew. Beloved ''Uncle Tony'' to many nieces and nephews and family friends. He graduated from City College of New York and spent over 50 years building and mentoring the C.P.A. firm, Horowitz & Ullmann. His loyalty, love, humor and personality will never be forgotten. Services will be today, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. description: Thunderstorms kill twice as many men as women, a new study has found.

description: The cities of Chicago and Seattle will be the focus of a $16 million exercise next week to test how well the federal government would deal with simultaneous attacks by terrorists using biological and radiological weapons, the Bush administration said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ELLIOT H.
description: MILLER-Elliot H., Sculptor and art therapist, died in New York City on April 30, at 60, of complications from heart surgery. Elliot maintained a studio in Brooklyn and his work appeared in 50 exhibitions worldwide during a 40 year career. His kind and gentle nature was most evident in his work with developmentally disabled adults at the League Center in Brooklyn. He is survived by his wife Joanne of Brooklyn, his sister Karen and niece Lisa of Miami, and many devoted friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMKOWITZ, LUCY
description: SIMKOWITZ-Lucy, born in Tula, Russia in 1912, died this Sunday, May 4, 2003. At the age of ten she came to this country with her widowed mother. She made the English Language her own and was graduated from Hunter College in New York City. She is survived by her beloved husband of 70 years, Isidore B. Simkowitz, and their four children: Elizabeth Gasser of Chatham, New Jersey, Michael Simkowitz of Miami Beach, Florida; Sara Simkowitz of Missoula, Montana; Philip Simkowitz of Cambridge, Massachusetts. She is also survived by nine grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by one of her grandchildren, Amy Simkowitz-Rogers of San Luis Obispo, California. Lucy was loved, and she will be remembered by her family and by all who knew her for her great vitality and warmth. In lieu of flowers please consider a contribution to the Amy SimkowitzRogers Fund at the National Jewish Medical Research Center, 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, Colorado 80206.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP: MAN DIES IN CRASH OF SMALL PLANE A single-engine plane crashed yesterday afternoon in the woods near the Monmouth Executive Airport, killing one of the two people on board and critically injuring the other, the authorities said. The plane, a Beech A-36, was attempting to land for refueling on a flight from Sarasota, Fla., to Bridgeport, Conn., when it crashed a mile short of the runway, said Arlene Salac, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The dead man was identified as Paul Bray, 75, of Bradenton, Fla.; the injured man is his son, Peter Albright Bray, 48, of Norwalk, Conn.    Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: 1 Killed In Flooding

He was found unconscious in a banana grove and was taken to a hospital, where he was declared dead. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Young Blacks Try Entrepreneurship
description: THERE is little official evidence to go by, but the anecdotes are pouring in: across the country, more young black professionals are stepping off the corporate ladder to become entrepreneurs. Joining a big company used to be perceived as the surest route to material success by many black professionals, but lately, owning a business has become as attractive, or more so.

title: Taxed to Our Limit
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg and legislative leaders have earned a moment to pat themselves on the back after devising a plan to get the city and state through this year's disastrous fiscal crisis. The combination of income taxes for wealthier New Yorkers and sales taxes for everybody is the only politically workable route out of this year's $12 billion financial hole for the state and $3.8 billion for the city. Still, this is no time to break open the Champagne. If this package becomes law, the state and city will have pushed taxes up about as far as they can go, and there is another budget gap looming next year.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: TELECOM PROFIT RISES Telecom Italia, Italy's largest telecommunications company, said first-quarter profit advanced 32 percent. After stripping out asset sales, profit rose to 503 million euros ($567 million) compared with 382 million euros in the first quarter of 2002. Sales, which fell 1.9 percent, were hurt by the decline of currencies in South America, where Telecom Italia has concentrated its international expansion. Telecom Italia had lower interest payments in the quarter as it cut debt and extended the maturity of existing loans and bonds.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bank Stake Sold
description: Indonesia sold a 51 percent stake in Bank Danamon for $347 million to a consortium led by the Singapore government's investment arm, Temasek Holdings. The Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency had named the Singpaore-led venture, which also includes Deutsche Bank, as its preferred bidder over another consortium comprising two Indonesian financial institutions, Bank Mega and Bhakti Capital Indonesia. The actress Sarah Jessica Parker left her apartment to shoot scenes for ''Sex and the City'' and wouldn't get home until 7 the next morning. Quite a few people saw the sun set from the observation deck of the Empire State Building, or so it seemed looking through Mr. Rodriguez's high-powered telescope.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: BODY CONFIRMED AS MISSING TEENAGER'S The police yesterday positively identified a body found on Sunday morning near Hart Island as that of Charles Wertenbaker, 16, of City Island. He was one of four teenagers who disappeared after reportedly deciding to boat to Hart Island after a party on City Island on Jan. 24. A half-hour after they were last seen, they called 911 to say the boat was taking on water, but before the call's abrupt end, the dispatcher was told that the boat was on Long Island Sound off "City I___." The boat, floating but partly submerged, was found on Jan. 31, about 30 feet off the shore of Hart Island. On April 25, the body of Max Guarino, 17, of Manhattan, was found in the same area. The police are still searching for the bodies of Andrew Melnikov, 16, of Manhattan, and Henry Badillo, 17, of the Bronx. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Wants To Change Corporate Name
description: If anyone had any doubts about computing having entered the post-PC era, the Dell Computer Corporation pretty much settled the matter yesterday. Its board wants to drop the ''computer'' from Dell's corporate name, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. So now even Dell, the clear winner in the personal computer industry, is pushing its brand away from the grim realities of the computer hardware business. In its proxy statement, which will be sent to shareholders later this month, Dell said that while the company began as a mere supplier of PC's, it is now much more: ''a leading seller of servers, storage systems and other technology products and services.'' Changing the corporate name to Dell Inc., the filing added, would represent ''Dell's evolution from strictly a computer hardware company to a diverse supplier of technology products and services.'' Dell shareholders will vote on the proposal at the annual meeting on July 18. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: U.N. Agrees On Liberia Sanctions
description: The United Nations Security Council agreed informally to extend existing sanctions against the Liberian government of Charles Taylor and it is likely to extend the current arms embargo to other groups in the strife-torn West African region. The resolution, expected to be adopted today, envisions an embargo on the timber exports that are said to further the flow of arms. That extension of the embargo would take effect July 7, said Munir Akram, Pakistan's envoy, who is presiding over the council. In a prepared statement, Mr. Akram said the council ''called on the government of Liberia,'' as well as all armed rebel groups, ''to enter into cease-fire talks without preconditions.'' title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: JUNIPER SHARES SURGE ON NEWS OF LUCENT PACT Shares of Juniper Networks rose more than 7 percent yesterday after it said that it would join with Lucent Technologies to develop Internet-protocol-based equipment for wireline telecommunications carriers, analysts said. Juniper shares rose 80 cents, to $11.95, on Nasdaq after analysts said the deal with Lucent would help Juniper, which makes network equipment, tap business with telecommunications service providers in North America, including Verizon . Carrier spending in the region has plunged during a slump, but carriers are expected to raise investment in Internet-protocol-based equipment, which sends data across the Internet over high-speed digital subscriber lines and manages it in virtual private networks. Lucent shares rose 19 cents, or 10 percent, to $2.04.

The Bush administration has yet to come up with a workable plan to deal with North Korea.

description: There is lots of activity these days at this former Nazi concentration camp, which has been a museum since 1949, a stark place full of memorials to the tens of thousands who suffered and died here.

title: MTV goes all out to grab business from the broadcast networks.
description: THIS year MTV Networks, which has been saying for some time that it has the best prices for its commercials among cable channels, wants to take on the big boys, the big broadcast networks.

title: ANOTHER REGULATORY DELAY FOR CANCER DRUG
description: The Corixa Corporation and GlaxoSmithKline said they faced another regulatory delay for their cancer medicine Bexxar, which the Food and Drug Administration first refused to consider in 1999. The companies reapplied for F.D.A. approval and predicted they would receive an answer by May 1. The agency extended the review and now will probably make its decision by Aug. 1, the companies said. Bexxar is intended to be a treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system.

title: SAKS BUYS 12% OF FAO, THE TOY RETAILER
description: Saks Inc. bought the equivalent of a 12 percent stake in the toy retailer FAO Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy protection last month. Saks, owner of the Saks Fifth Avenue, Parisian and Proffitt's department store chains, purchased 5,000 FAO preferred shares for $5 million, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The securities may be converted at any time to about 3.33 million shares, or 12 percent, of FAO common stock, the filing said. FAO, owner of the F. A. O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy chains, plans to run toy shops in about 245 Saks stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIN, LEONA
description: BRIN-Leona. Died May 3, 2003, at age 90. Beloved wife of Martin. Stepmother of Matthew. Sister of Lester Feinstein. Former member of Democratic State Committee of New York. Memorial to be held 2 PM, May 18, 2003 at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

title: Yet Another Beginning On Heartbreak Street
description: THERE are some hardships that most small businesses face -- a crumbling economy, cranky customers, sluggish suppliers, errant employees, annoying accountants and, of course, the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERK, NEIL
description: TERK-Neil, age 55, founder, Chairman & President of Terk Technologies, passed away with dignity after fighting a lengthy and courageous battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Nomi Terk and proud father of Micaela and Romi Terk, devoted son of Ruth and the late Leon Terk, cherished brother of Marilyn Weisler and Harold Terk, adored by seven nieces and one nephew. A funeral service will be held Tuesday, May 6th, 2003 at 10:15AM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York 11365, Phone 1-800-446-0406. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cancer Care, 20 Crossways Park North, Woodbury, New York 11797.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about speculation that the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, is seeking to use the case against a former Democratic Party official to distance himself from the organization misstated the party's choice for district attorney in 1989. The party and its leader, the Brooklyn borough president, Howard Golden, supported Mr. Hynes, not Daniel Feldman, an assemblyman at the time.

title: Leiter's Playoff Proposal Has a Tournament Feel
description: Interleague play? Management idea. Three divisions in each league? Management idea. Wild cards? Management again. Home-field advantage for the World Series determined by the outcome of the All-Star Game? Ditto.

title: Iowa State's Eustachy Steps Down as Coach
description: Larry Eustachy, who was suspended as Iowa State basketball coach last Wednesday for inappropriate conduct, resigned yesterday, ending a weeklong drama that had divided many in the Ames, Iowa, community where he had coached for five seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNING, SUSAN POLLARD
description: BROWNING-Susan Pollard, May 2, 2003. Devoted and beloved wife of Jackson B., Jr. Loving daughter of Frances and the late Stephen Pollard. Cherished sister of Stephen Pollard and Anne Perry. Also survived by eleven adored nieces and nephews. Reposing at Grace Church, 802 Broadway at East 10th St, NYC, 10003, Wednesday, 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Funeral service Thursday, 10:30 AM at Grace Church. Interment Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Spire Campaign at Grace Church or Duke University Chapel, Durham, N.C. 27708. For further information, please contact the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, 212-674-8055.

title: BUNGE SELLS A BUSINESS TO ITS DUPONT PARTNERSHIP
description: Bunge Ltd., the world's biggest oilseed processor, sold a Brazilian business for $256 million to its joint venture with the DuPont Company, which sells soybean-based food ingredients. Bunge expects a net gain of $111 million, or $1.12 a share, on the sale, its chief financial officer, William Wells, said. The joint venture, called the Solae Company, was formed by Bunge and DuPont last month by combining their North American and European protein businesses. Bunge is based in White Plains. Dupont is based in Wilmington, Del.

description: To the Editor:

title: Small Fry With a Scent Only a Mother Could Love
description: IT doesn't take long before the interrogator is cowering in a cavernous, formaldehyde-scented office inside the top-notch ichthyology department at the American Museum of Natural History, home to two million dead, but not forgotten, fish.

title: Former Executive at HealthSouth Pleads Guilty
description: A former chief financial officer of HealthSouth, Aaron Beam, pleaded guilty to bank fraud today.

title: Jordan Is Scheduled to Meet With the Wizards' Owners
description: Michael Jordan and the Washington Wizards' minority owner, Ted Leonsis, are expected to dine tonight in the Washington area, a supposedly gentlemanly affair with only one detail at stake: perhaps the future of Jordan with the team, a franchise he and his legions feel he rescued from the N.B.A.'s scrap heap.

title: When Goliath Comes Knocking on David's Door
description: WHEN the world's biggest companies do business with the millions of minnows on the commercial landscape, the outcome can be tough for the little guys.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Telecom Profit Rises
description: Telecom Italia, Italy's largest telecommunications company, said first-quarter profit advanced 32 percent. After stripping out asset sales, profit rose to 503 million euros ($567 million) compared with 382 million euros in the first quarter of 2002. Sales, which fell 1.9 percent, were hurt by the decline of currencies in South America, where Telecom Italia has concentrated its international expansion. Telecom Italia had lower interest payments in the quarter as it cut debt and extended the maturity of existing loans and bonds. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Supreme Court Rules Charity May Be Charged With Fraud
description: Charitable solicitations that include deliberate misrepresentations about what proportion of the money raised will go to the beneficiaries can be prosecuted as consumer fraud, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: USA Interactive to Buy Lender for $734 Million

title: Jeter to Play in Minor Leagues
description: Derek Jeter will continue his rehabilitation from a dislocated left shoulder by beginning a minor league assignment at Class AA Trenton tomorrow night, according to a person who spoke with Jeter. Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman confirmed that Jeter would begin his stint tomorrow, but he would not reveal the location. The Yankees want to maintain the flexibility of having Jeter play elsewhere if it rains in Trenton.

title: DELPHI WINS CONTRACT TO SUPPLY CITRON AUTO PARTS
description: The Delphi Corporation, the world's largest auto parts maker, won multiyear orders worth about $719 million to supply electrical components and computer controls to PSA Peugeot Citron of France for future Citron models. The contracts run until Peugeot redesigns or replaces the models that use the components. Delphi is seeking to reduce dependence on its former parent, General Motors, to increase profit. Delphi, which is based in Troy, Mich., was spun off in 1999.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about efforts by President Bush to refocus the nation on his economic agenda misstated several words in his remarks about the latest unemployment figure and his call for a tax cut. He said, ''That 6 percent number should say loud and clear to members of both political parties in the United States Congress, we need robust tax relief so our fellow citizens can find a job'' -- not ''so people can find work.''

title: Hooked Fish Feel Pain, British Scientists Say, Roiling the Waters
description: On the front line of a watery war, Christian Jervis-Reid braced for the fray, his only weapon a willowy wand of crafted bamboo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, BISHOP PAUL
description: MOORE-Bishop Paul. Dear friend of fifty years, inspiration for inner-city urban work, Chairman of the Board of Episcopal Mission Society from 1972-1985, champion of poor people, the homeless and all who have been pushed away from the mainstream of American life. Requiem-Cathedral St. John the Divine, May 10, 4 PM; burial, Calvary Church, Stonington, CT, May 12, 2 PM. Fr. Stephen Chinlund, Executive Director Marshall Green, Chairman Episcopal Social Services

title: Plan to Overhaul Medicare by Enlarging Private Health Plan Role Is Criticized
description: Congressional efforts to revamp Medicare by expanding the role of private health plans have been immensely complicated by new data suggesting that such plans would not save money and could substantially increase Medicare costs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Body Confirmed As Missing Teenager's
description: The police yesterday positively identified a body found on Sunday morning near Hart Island as that of Charles Wertenbaker, 16, of City Island. He was one of four teenagers who disappeared after reportedly deciding to boat to Hart Island after a party on City Island on Jan. 24. A half-hour after they were last seen, they called 911 to say the boat was taking on water, but the dispatcher had no information on their location. The boat, floating but partly submerged, was found on Jan. 31, about 30 feet off the shore of Hart Island. On April 25, the body of Max Guarino, 17, of Manhattan, was found in the same area. The police are still searching for the bodies of Andrew Melnikov, 16, of Manhattan, and Henry Badillo, 17, of the Bronx. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Nudging Turns to Shoving in Albany Budget Fight
description: The first victim of the Republican civil war over the state budget was Assemblyman Pat M. Casale of Rensselaer County.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Profit For Foods Group
description: San Miguel, the Philippine beer and food conglomerate, said that net profit rose 21 percent in the first quarter, less than expected, to 1.34 billion pesos ($255 million). Lower poultry prices and the effect of the SARS virus on beer consumption in China and Hong Kong held its income down despite strong sales of beer and soft drinks at home and falling interest payments. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: All-Stars May Face a Real Workday
description: In summer camp, we used to play a game called American Ball, in which every child played the field and every child batted. That made for long lineups and large crowds in the field, but the idea was that everyone deserved to play.

title: Lowe & Partners Gets Macy's Account
description: Federated Department Stores in Cincinnati said yesterday that it had selected Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York to create a television and print brand-image campaign for its Macy's retail chain. Billings on the assignment were estimated at $20 million; there was no previous agency as most of the Macy's advertising duties are handled internally.

title: Blair Hits 50 and Bookmakers Bet on Record Term in Office
description: LONDON, May 6  Tony Blair turned 50 today, grayer and paler than when he entered 10 Downing Street six years ago as the youngest British prime minister in nearly two centuries, but visibly more relaxed and certain of himself and his leadership than in his fresh-faced early days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, MURIEL
description: MARK-Muriel of Sunrise, FL died on April 30. Vibrant & loving. Muriel was formerly the Director of Communications at the Diamond Dealers Club in NY. Before moving to FL., Muriel and her late husband Louis, resided in Kew Gardens, NY. An amazing woman, full of life & energy. Muriel was gracious, unpretentious & lit up every life that she touched. Always open to discovering new places & ideas, she loved urban walks, whether in NY, FL, San Francisco, Paris, Italy, China, or Russia. Muriel was smart, wonderful at giving advice, charitable, funny & loved her family & friends. Muriel leaves behind her devoted and beloved sons, Alan P. & his partner, Jeffrey Fraenkel of San Francisco, Dr. Joel C. & his wife Joan & her adored grandchildren, Jonathan, Rebecca, & Teddy of Rye, NY; her adored, loving, & devoted sister, Roslyn Marino of Plantation, FL and other loving relatives & friends. Donations may be sent to Deborah Hospital Foundation, 1515 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL 33342. How blessed we are to have known her. May her memory be a continued blessing for all.

title: Nets' No-Name Defense Throttles the Celtics
description: The Nets did not know what to call their suffocating fourth-quarter defense. Some described it as half zone, half man and maybe even a little bit of amoeba.

title: A Look Inside Ginkgo Biloba
description: Recent tests of a variety of ginkgo biloba supplements have found that their quality has dropped sharply since a similar survey was conducted in 1999, a new study reports.

description: FRENCH wines have experienced problems in the American market before: complicated labels, unpopular wine styles, unfavorable exchange rates. But they haven't encountered difficulties as tough as the ones they are now facing since Prohibition.

She is Leslie Barr. (Joan Wohlstetter -- whose late father, Albert, a nuclear weapons theorist, taught Mr. Perle at the University of Chicago -- is married to Lorenzo Hall.)

title: Study Suggests A Higher Rate Of SARS Death
description: The death rate from SARS may be significantly higher than health officials had thought, up to 55 percent in people 60 and older, and up to 13.2 percent in younger people, the first major epidemiological study of the disease suggests.

title: Sports of The Times; Robinson Builds Legacy for All San Antonio
description: WHEN the time came last May to make the announcement of his impending retirement from the N.B.A., David Robinson chose a school library as the site and he invited a group of his biggest fans and friends, the student body.

title: Bush Signs Trade Pact With Singapore, a Wartime Ally
description: President Bush signed a free trade agreement today with Singapore, his first since Congress granted him tradepromotion authority last summer and the largest since the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Arrest In American's Killing
description: An 18-year-old man was arrested in the killing of an American artist, Margaret Muller, 27, who was stabbed to death in an East London park in February while on her daily morning jog. Ms. Muller, from Falls Church, Va., moved to Britain in 1998, and her killing drew particular attention since the area was busy with other joggers, cyclists and dog walkers, many of whom heard her screams. More than 100 witnesses gathered at the site a month later to take part in Scotland Yard's largest crime reconstruction. The suspect, who was held for questioning, was not identified. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROOCK, HANNA E.
description: STROOCK-Hanna E. On May 5, 2003 after a long illness at her home. Beloved wife of Mark E. Stroock. Devoted mother of Mark E. Stroock III, and Carolyn Klein. Fond mother-in-law of Mary T. Stroock, and Gerald Klein. Cherished grandmother of Tracey and Brian McFarland, Will and Jenica Stroock. Grandmother of Hannah B. and Brian McFarland, Jr. Loving sister of W. H. Leseman. Funeral services Wednesday 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Knitwits, C/O The Volunteers Office, White Plains Hospital, White Plains, New York.

title: U.S. Tests Iraqi Vehicle Suspected as Mobile Weapons Lab
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The Pentagon said today that American forces in Iraq are testing a trailer that they suspect the Iraqis operated as a mobile biological weapons laboratory.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bellport: Suffolk Teacher Accused Of Sodomy
description: A teacher at Bellport Middle School has been arrested on charges that he sodomized a 16-year-old boy and had sexually explicit conversations with at least three preteenage students, both online and in person, the police said yesterday. The teacher, Joseph M. Acosta, 38, of Ronkonkoma, was arrested on Monday and at his arraignment yesterday pleaded not guilty to one count of third-degree sodomy and three counts of endangering the welfare of a child. Detective Michael Connolly of the Suffolk County police said that the investigation began about two weeks ago, when the authorities received a complaint about the chats. The detective said Mr. Acosta had met the 16-year-old, who was not his student, online. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: What Some Much-Noted Data Really Showed About Vouchers
description: IN August of 2000, in the midst of the Bush-Gore presidential race, a Harvard professor, Paul E. Peterson, released a study saying that school vouchers significantly improved test scores of black children. Professor Peterson had conducted the most ambitious randomized experiment on vouchers to date, and his results -- showing that blacks using vouchers to attend private schools had scored six percentile points higher than a control group of blacks in public schools -- became big news.

title: Market Place; A new start, a new name. But have things really changed as Kmart comes out of bankruptcy?
description: FIFTEEN months after filing for bankruptcy protection, Kmart yesterday completed its reorganization and today will become a publicly traded company once more -- a much smaller one, under new management and control, with a future that remains unclear.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON REACHES AGREEMENT TO BUY LINK SPINE
description: Johnson & Johnson agreed to buy the closely held Link Spine Group for $325 million and future payments, gaining an instrument for treating spinal disorders. Johnson & Johnson will make additional payments based on regulatory and development targets, the company said. The acquisition will result in a charge of $175 million, or 6 cents a share. The purchase will give Johnson & Johnson's DePuy unit an artificial disk used to repair backbones damaged by injury or disease. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Meanwhile, Back at the Market
description: PORK belly futures -- agreements to buy or sell at a set price down the road -- have been bought and sold since the 19th century, to the mutual benefit of both farmers and food companies who want to hedge their bets against price swings. The frozen pork bellies, around 40 million pounds on any given day, sit in Agriculture Department-approved freezers, waiting to be turned into bacon.

title: DoCoMo Is Back, Leading Japan's Cellphone Market
description: After enduring staggering losses on its international alliances and a halfhearted introduction of the world's first ''third-generation'' digital mobile phone service, NTT DoCoMo and its president, Keiji Tachikawa, can finally breath a bit easier.

title: Slapstick Play Ruins Start of Six-Game Trip
description: The last time the Yankees lost three games in a row, they were bounced from the playoffs by Anaheim in October. Things are not as dire now, of course, but the Yankees are slumping for the first time this season. They looked listless tonight at the start of a challenging road trip.

title: Cheney Says He and Bush Will Keep Ticket Intact for '04
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Vice President Dick Cheney, who has often been at President Bush's side in moments of crisis, plans to be on the Republican ticket with Mr. Bush again next year.

description: Fed Holds Rates Steady

description: Morris Dancing Aplenty

title: Suspected Terrorist Questions a Witness
description: Zacarias Moussaoui has been allowed to conduct a pre-trial deposition of at least one potential trial witness in his case, a Malaysian terrorism suspect who the authorities say met with Mr. Moussaoui in Southeast Asia before the Sept. 11 terror attacks, according to court papers made public today.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: WORK TO RESUME ON SUNKEN TANKER A small French submarine is to resume work on sealing the leaking hull of the oil tanker Prestige, which sank in more than two miles of water in November, polluting much of the northern Spanish coastline. The deputy prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, said the cost of the spill already totaled $372 million. In a previous effort the mini-sub cut the leaking oil to 1 to 2 tons daily, from 125 tons, but the repairs were not expected to hold. The Spanish government has yet to decide whether it will eventually pump out the estimated 35,000 tons of oil left in the tanker or seal the wreckage with a heavy casing. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Setting Out With Energy Along the Road Most Taken
description: Since the Russian conductor Yuri Temirkanov became the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra three years ago, concertgoers and critics there have been enthusiastic about his work. So it was not surprising that a large, expectant audience came to Carnegie Hall on Saturday night to hear Mr. Temirkanov conduct the orchestra in Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1 and Mahler's Symphony No. 5. A dynamic and commanding maestro, he drew energetic, vividly colored and technically incisive performances from the Baltimore musicians.

title: Young Lives Transformed, Guided by a Camera Lens; Guatemalan Fotokids Capture Pain and Joy
description: One of the first photographs Evelyn Mansilla ever took was of a peaceful landscape of rolling hills peeking out through a thicket of trees. Not a single soul or a speck of garbage was visible, which was almost miraculous, since she took the photo inside the sprawling municipal dump where she and her mother often joined dozens of neighbors to scavenge.

title: Virgin Atlantic cuts a review short to hire an agency known for its untraditional methods.
description: AN upstart airline is hiring an upstart agency in an appropriately upstart fashion, awarding the account by abruptly halting a review that was to have run at least another month.

title: Chastened Palo Alto Council Drops Plan to Ban Rude Body Language
description: This is not a place that takes well to being the butt of jokes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, PAUL C.
description: WEISS-Paul C. Beloved son, nephew, uncle, grandson, brother and cousin. He will be dearly missed.

title: Warner Hires Elton John To Write Broadway Show
description: Hoping to strike gold with the same musical mind that has made millions for Disney, Warner Brothers Entertainment announced yesterday that it had commissioned Elton John to write a Broadway musical based on three of Anne Rice's best-selling novels about a sauve vampire named Lestat.

title: The Sting of Racial Exclusion Is Easily Recalled
description: EUGENE A. BURNETT inches along in his blue Chevy S.U.V. through the winding streets of Levittown, N.Y., the famous mass-produced Long Island suburb that turned him away more than a half century ago because he is black.

title: Iraqi Documents on Israel Surface on a Cultural Hunt
description: What began today as a hunt for an ancient Jewish text at secret police headquarters here wound up unearthing a trove of Iraqi intelligence documents and maps relating to Israel as well as offers of sales of uranium and other nuclear material to Iraq.

title: FLEMING RECEIVES BANKRUPTCY COURT APPROVAL OF LOAN
description: The Fleming Companies, a leading grocery distributor, won final court approval of a $150 million loan and vendor lien program, clearing a major hurdle in its bankruptcy case. The program approved by the court will let some vendors place liens on Fleming's assets in exchange for continuing to ship products on the same terms as before the bankruptcy filing. Fleming sought bankruptcy protection after the Kmart Corporation, its biggest customer, ended a contract. ''We need to have additional product to fill in the supply chain holes we have now,'' Ted Stenger, Fleming's chief restructuring officer, said during a court hearing yesterday. Judge Mary Walrath of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., granted approval of the loan, which is being provided by Deutsche Bank Trust Company Americas and J. P. Morgan Chase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODBODY, GARRETT
description: GOODBODY-Garrett, 57, of New York City and Sharon, CT, died suddenly of cardiac arrhythmia on May 2, 2003. He is survived by his spouse, Ann Goodbody. His parents were Garrett Goodbody Sr., a partner in Goodbody & Co., and Bambie McKenna Goodbody of Madison, New Jersey. He was a graduate of The Hotchkiss School, Yale University (St. Anthony's Hall)-Class of 1967, and of Harvard Business SchoolClass of 1971. Garrett served for two years in the Peace Corps, helping establish fishing cooperatives in Brazil and becoming fluent in Portuguese and Spanish. After graduating from Harvard, he joined Citibank, spending the early part of his 15-year career there in Brazil and Mexico. He subsequently became a Senior Executive Vice President of Marine Midland Bank and later, as President of New Milford Savings Bank, restructured the bank to profitability. He remained active in the industry, consulting on international banking issues related to USAID projects. At the time of his death, he was a director of numerous banks as well as a Principal of Goodbody/PL Capital LP, a partnership investing in domestic financial institutions. Issues of corporate governance and shareholder rights were of particular concern to him. He loved music, had a rich bass voice and was a member of various singing groups, including the 1967 Whiffenpoofs. Outdoor activities were a life-long interest, including sailing, skiing, running marathons in earlier years, hiking and especially golf more recently. He cared deeply about land use and was a member of the Board of Directors of the Sharon Land Trust. Garrett is survived also by his sister, Ducky G. Bancroft of Sharon, CT, his niece, Kelly Bancroft and his nephew, Alexander Bancroft. A memorial service will be held at The Hotchkiss School Chapel, Lakeville, CT on Friday, May 16th at 11:45AM. Additional information can be found at www.hotchkiss.org/alumnet or calling 860-435-3121. Gifts in his memory may be sent to the Sharon Land Trust at PO Box 1027, Sharon, CT 06069.

title: The Right Sift
description: Q. What is the best type of sifter for large quantities of flour? Sometimes I have to work in batches.

title: S.E.C. DROPS CONTEMPT MOTION AGAINST EX-GEMSTAR CHIEF
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had dropped its request to jail and fine the former chief executive of Gemstar-TV Guide International, Henry Yuen, for failing to testify. The S.E.C. is investigating Gemstar's accounting, and the company, which is based in Pasadena, Calif., has restated earnings three times this year. Mr. Yuen and the former chief financial officer, Elsie Leung, both left the company in October. On Monday, the S.E.C. sought an order from a federal court in California to freeze $37 million in severance payments to both executives. The agency asked that the contempt motion be dropped after Mr. Yuen appeared before the S.E.C., according to court papers.

title: How Vietnam Halted SARS And Saved the Life of a Nurse
description: Doctors and nurses clustered around the bed of Nguyen Thi Men when she emerged in mid-March from a nine-day coma, urging her to stay alive.

title: Fed Worries About Prices, But Holds Rate
description: The Federal Reserve held short-term interest rates steady today, but took the unusual step of saying that it had become worried about the risks of a sustained fall in prices, commonly known as deflation.

title: Layoffs in Special Education
description: A plan to streamline special education will mean layoffs for 856 supervisors and administrators, the Department of Education said yesterday. Many of the layoffs will involve workers in central offices, but about half will involve supervisors in the schools. The Council of School Supervisors and Administrators, the union that represents the workers, said the plan violated their recently negotiated contract, which includes a no-layoff clause. Jennifer Medina

title: Townshend of the Who Placed on Register of Sex Offenders
description: LONDON, May 7  Pete Townshend, the rock guitarist and co-founder of the Who, was given a formal police caution and placed on an official register of sex offenders today for having gained access to a pedophile Web site.

title: In California, A New Kind of Continental Cuisine
description: THE dining scene in Los Angeles is dominated by two categories of restaurant. The first is a group of glitzy establishments serving fusion food of a sort known as California cuisine. A few practitioners of this style have made names for themselves, Wolfgang Puck and Michael McCarty most notably -- and justifiably. But most cannot compare to them, and their food, beginning with tuna tartare and ending with warm, undercooked chocolate cake, exhibits the forced, bland hipness for which so many American restaurants are derided.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Guard Accused Of Theft From Prisoners
description: A guard at the federal prison in Brooklyn was arraigned yesterday on charges that she stole $1,600 in money orders from inmates and shared it with her roommate, prosecutors said. According to court papers, the guard, Debbie Austin, who works at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Sunset Park, intercepted six money orders last year that were intended for inmates. Some were deposited in her bank account; others were cashed by her roommate, Shamika Clarke, prosecutors said. Each was charged with embezzlement. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Memorial to Irish Fortitude Comes Undone in New York
description: When the Irish Hunger Memorial opened last July in Battery Park City, the sheer antiquity of the materials commanded awe in downtown Manhattan. The pedestal was made from Kilkenny limestone, age 300 million years. The fieldstone cottage -- meant to represent the dwellings where, if they were not evicted onto the roads, the Irish peasantry starved during the 19th-century potato famine -- had stood since the 1820's, until it was cut into pieces and reassembled in New York last year.

title: FORSTMANN LITTLE TO SELL HALF ITS YANKEE CANDLE STAKE
description: Forstmann Little & Company, a leveraged buyout firm, will sell half its shares in a gift retailer, the Yankee Candle Company. Yankee Candle, based in South Deerfield, Mass., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that Forstmann Little planned to sell 12.5 million shares. At Yankee Candle's Monday closing price of $21.95, Forstmann Little, which is based in New York, would receive about $275 million for its shares, cutting its current stake from 40.1 percent to about 20 percent. Yankee Candle designs and sells scented candles through 249 stores in 42 states.

description: Aaron Brown of CNN, Walter Cronkite and other broadcast journalists have been hired to appear in videos resembling newscasts that are actually paid for by drug makers and other health care companies, blurring the line between journalism and advertising.

title: Mondesi Sheds Some Weight, and It Shows at the Plate
description: SEATTLE, May 6 - When Raul Mondesi talks about the reasons for his resurgence this season, the first thing he mentions is his weight loss. Mondesi has finally applied himself as teams have implored him for years, and it shows in his performance.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lawmaker Suspended Over Iraq Remarks
description: George Galloway, a member of Parliament from Glasgow, was suspended by the Labor Party from exercising his office pending investigation of his remarks during the war in Iraq calling Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Bush ''wolves'' and urging British troops to disobey orders to fight. Mr. Galloway hit back at the decision, saying it would prejudice his libel case against The Daily Telegraph, which reported that documents recovered from the Foreign Ministry in Baghdad showed he had received $600,000 a year from Iraqi intelligence agencies in oil-for-food earnings while ostensibly campaigning for an antipoverty charity. ''Justice demands that I be allowed to pursue my legal actions without a political stab in the back going on in parallel,'' he said. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Ariel Sharon's Delaying Tactic
description: The last thing Israel should be doing at this moment of hopeful fluidity in the Middle East is slowing down a new American-backed peace plan. Yet that is what Prime Minister Ariel Sharon seems to have in mind by letting it be known that he will not be ready to move ahead on the newly published ''road map'' of mutual concessions when Secretary of State Colin Powell calls on him this weekend.

title: Amsterdam, Sunny Side Up
description: IN Northern Europe, some towns still ring church bells when asparagus stalks first emerge from the ground, and from April to June it's a rare menu that doesn't feature asparagus in some form or other. My favorite discovery on a couple of trips through the region last spring was in Amsterdam, where I was served asparagus with hard-boiled egg, ham and beurre noisette -- butter that is browned until its nutty flavor comes through.

title: Taunts Don't Distract Walker
description: The catcalls began before the opening tip. The crowd at Continental Arena needed a villain and Antoine Walker was it. Even while Paul Pierce was pouring in points from every angle, Walker took the brunt of the taunts.

title: Team Effort by Pistons Overcomes Iverson Effect
description: The Palace of Auburn Hills was rocking like a juke joint tonight, with half of the sellout crowd of 22,076 waving white tube-shaped balloons in unison and dozens of other fans wielding handmade signs. One read: ''We Don't Need a Go-To Man, We've Got a Go-To Team.''

title: Man Falls to Death From Midtown Building
description: A man fleeing from the police in a Midtown Manhattan building fell to his death from a ninth-story window yesterday, the authorities said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold Township: 3 Killed And 1 Hurt In Collision
description: A 32-year-old woman and her two children were killed and a 60-year-old man was critically injured yesterday when their cars collided on a rural road in Freehold Township, the authorities said. The woman, Melissa Holzschuh of Marlboro, was driving a 2001 Volvo about 8:40 a.m. when she veered into oncoming traffic after rounding a curve, the police said. The Volvo was broadsided on the passenger side by a 1999 Jeep driven by David Sanders of Cream Ridge. Ms. Holzschuh, her 10-year-old son and 3-year-old daughter were pronounced dead at the scene. Mr. Sanders was taken to Jersey Shore Medical Center, where he was listed in critical condition last night. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Filming the Dark Side Of Capitalism in China
description: Li Yang has spent most of the past decade and a half in self-imposed exile in Germany, and it must have been there, certainly not in the unadventurous filmmaking climate of today's China, that he decided to treat compromise as a dirty word.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Waterloo: Arsonist Sentenced In Family's Murder
description: A volunteer firefighter who set fire to an apartment, killing his estranged wife and four children, was sentenced yesterday in Seneca County Court to 25 years to life in prison. The man, Eric Parsons, 28, was convicted in March of five counts of second-degree murder and five counts of arson for the November 2001 fire in Romulus, in the Finger Lakes region, which killed his wife, Cheryl, 28, and her two sons and two daughters, all under 6. Mr. Parsons's lawyer did not return a call yesterday seeking comment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Gains Lead In Some Software Sales
description: I.B.M. the world's second-largest maker of software, behind Microsoft, gained the sales lead for the first time last year over rivals like BEA Systems and SAP for two major types of software. I.B.M.'s share of application-server software sales rose to 37 percent from 31 percent in 2001, said Joanne Correia, an analyst at Gartner. BEA's share slipped five percentage points, to 29 percent. I.B.M.'s sales of software for work collaboration increased to 13.5 percent, while SAP's share fell to 9.7 percent. I.B.M. is increasing its software sales as customers slow their purchases of computers as the economy and corporate profits sag. Two-thirds of I.B.M.'s sales this year will be from computer services and software, up from half in 1998, the company has said. Sales of its WebSphere application-server and work-collaboration software rose 14 percent in the first quarter, I.B.M. said last month. Officials from BEA Systems did not return telephone calls yesterday seeking comment.

title: U.S.-Backed Mideast Plan Runs Into New Obstacles
description: A new American-backed plan for Middle East peace hit fresh obstacles today.

title: A Mother's Haunting Presence In O'Neill's Unraveling Family
description: Even when she's not around, you can't help thinking about her, any more than the three angry, anxious men onstage can. Where is she? What is she doing now? What do you think she's thinking? When will she strike out at them next?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In Embezzlement
description: A former top official with Odyssey House, a Manhattan addiction treatment center, was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to 30 months in prison for his role in defrauding his employer out of millions of dollars. The man, Aaron Lugo, 57, the former operations manager of Odyssey House, pleaded guilty in 1999 to fraud, admitting that he had helped the chief executive of the center embezzle more than $2.3 million by arranging phony billing schemes with vendors. In exchange for a lighter sentence, Mr. Lugo testified against the executive, Benjamin Walker Jr., who was sentenced in March to two years in prison. In addition to prison, Mr. Lugo must pay $1.19 million in restitution, a Justice Department spokeswoman said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, MORTIMER JR.
description: BERKOWITZ-Mortimer Jr. Age 87, died on May 5, 2003 at his home in New York City. Beloved husband of Marjory for more than 50 years and father of Hugh J. Freund and Betsy F. Perry, both of New York City, John Berkowitz (River) of Putney, VT., and Mortimer Berkowitz III (Amelia) of New York City. Adored grandfather (''Papa'') of Caroline Loomis, Daisy Freund, Eli Berkowitz, Charlotte, Hayward, Thomas and William Berkowitz. Brother-in-law of Phyllis and Wilbur Levin and Mary Anne and Douglas Schwalbe. Adored uncle to seven nieces and nephews and many grand-nieces and nephews. Born in 1915 in Brookline, Massachusetts, Mortimer graduated from the Taft School, Class of '33 and Dartmouth College, Class of '37, where he was a member of the Green Key Society, the Casque and Gauntlet Senior Society and Palaeopitus. Following in the footsteps of his father, Mortimer began his career as a reporter with the Boston Herald and as a police reporter with the Cleveland Ohio News. Mortimer's career spanned over 50 years in the newspaper and magazine business where he was involved with publishing, advertising and marketing. He served as a Lieutenant Commander during WWII on the destroyer, U.S.S. Livermore. After the war, Mortimer joined the American Weekly as an advertising representative and then moved to Woman's Day Magazine. From 1962 until 1966 Mortimer was with BBDO before joining Fawcett Publishing in 1966 where he was Vice President and Advertising Director. From 1969 to 1990 Mortimer was the CEO of Home Garden Publishing, Universal Publishing and the Mortimer Berkowitz Company which served eight Ivy League Alumni Magazines. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St on Wednesday, May 7, from 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Thursday, May 8, at 1:30PM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his name to the Dartmouth College Fund, 6066 Development Office, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755.

description: Hoping to quell mounting anger among Iraqis over widespread fuel shortages, Iraqi and American officials here announced today that Iraq would import gasoline and cooking gas from neighboring Arab countries for at least the next month.

title: Put on the Togas and Pile On the Tapas
description: DOUGLAS RODRIGUEZ knows how to give a party. Serve cold cocktails in hot tropical colors. Make the ceviches sweet and fiery. Smother the taste buds with combinations like fig and foie gras. Heap the plate. Distract the eye. Don't give anyone time to think.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Freedom Anniversary
description: On the first anniversary of her release from 19 months of house arrest, the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi embarked on a monthlong trip into northern Myanmar, where, a spokesman said, she planned to open a branch office of her National League for Democracy. This was her seventh out-of-town organizing trip since her release, which was accompanied by promises from the military junta to allow her the freedom to travel and organize. The last two trips, however, met with harassment and obstruction. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Pentagon Surveillance Plan Is Described as Less Invasive
description: A top Pentagon research official told Congress today that a program intended to forestall terrorism by tapping computer databases -- but curbed by legislation this winter because of privacy fears -- would not look into Americans' financial or health records.

It is Deloitte & Touche, not Towers Perrin.

title: Senator Graham of Florida Begins Run for Presidency
description: Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat from the state that was the fulcrum of the disputed 2000 presidential election, began his own White House campaign today by asserting that President Bush had ''virtually ignored homeland security'' in his drive to ''settle old scores'' and remove Saddam Hussein from power.

description: You can be forgiven if you had the impression yesterday that New York had suddenly turned into a city of self-taught accountants, nervously computing number after depressing number.

description: Ten of the 15 European Union nations are falling behind in efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions and meet targets set by the Kyoto Protocol, the international agreement to combat climate change.

title: Dollar Drops and Treasuries Gain After Fed Statement
description: The dollar plunged and the bond market rallied after Federal Reserve policy makers said yesterday that the economy faced a risk of further weakness in the months ahead and, possibly, a sharp fall in inflation. The stock market gave up some gains but still finished the day in the black.

title: Women's World Cup Is Likely for U.S.
description: The United States moved closer to becoming the host of the Women's World Cup this fall after what was described as an encouraging meeting yesterday between American officials and representatives from the sport's world governing body.

title: U.S. Approves Force in Detaining Possible SARS Carriers
description: As part of the government's efforts to prevent an epidemic of SARS in the United States, the Bush administration has authorized immigration and customs agents at the nation's international airports to use force to detain arriving passengers who appear to have symptoms of the disease, senior administration officials said.

title: Topics of The Times; The Indestructible Worm
description: When last we checked in on the tiny soil worm known as C. elegans, it had reached a pinnacle of scientific success. Not only was it the first animal to have its genome deciphered, but it had also become the favored laboratory specimen for studying how cells divide, differentiate and develop into organs, a role that contributed heavily to last year's Nobel Prize in medicine.

title: An Intermission Treat for the Diminutive Theatergoer
description: The new musical ''A Year With Frog and Toad,'' at the Cort Theater, features a song about chocolate chip cookies. Figuring that the audience, mostly the young set, might be in the mood for a cookie at intermission, the producers turned to Geoff & Drew's Incredible Cookies, a Boston company, to package a cookie especially for the show. It is a large chocolate chunk cookie, on the crisp side, not overly burdened with chocolate, and tastes very much like good homemade. The Official Cookie of Frog and Toad (below) is $3 at the theater. If you need another for a bedtime snack, it can be ordered from www.geoffanddrews.com or (866) 328-5283 (minimum of six). The company also makes cookies in other flavors, which are a little chewier, and brownies.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Budget Cuts Threaten Public TV
description: Citing the state budget crisis, Gov. Theodore R. Kulongoski is proposing that the state stop financial aid for Oregon Public Broadcasting television and radio. That would make OPB the lone statewide public broadcaster to operate without state aid. Although the state provides 6 percent of the financing for the system, an executive said it might reduce emergency and Amber Alert signals, drop some local programs and reduce educational programming. Judith Berck (NYT)

WENDY KOPP, the founder and president, announced the plans yesterday, with Schools Chancellor JOEL I. KLEIN and CAROLINE KENNEDY, the city schools' chief fund-raiser. Ms. Kopp and Mr. Klein said they were seeking 200 donors to give $5,000 each to a campaign for training and recruitment. David M. Herszenhorn

description: The body of a slight blond woman was found floating on the Queens side of the East River yesterday, and detectives say they believe it is that of a 44-year-old woman who vanished in March while walking her father's dog on the Upper East Side.

title: Ahern and Blair Pursue Changes In Ulster Despite Election Delay

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Gains Market Share
description: Fiat sold fewer vehicles in Italy in April than in April of last year, but an industry group said the company's market share increased as total new car sales fell 5.8 percent. Fiat sold 52,660 vehicles in Italy last month, 28.8 percent of the market, compared with 28 percent in March. Fiat's market share was 31 percent in April 2002. Fiat has been selling assets to increase investments in its money-losing car division. Eric Sylvers (NYT)
