title: 57 New Schools Planned
description: Fifty-seven new public schools will open in New York City next year, including small high schools and charter schools, Deputy Chancellor DIANA LAM said yesterday. At a breakfast sponsored by the Institute for Student Achievement, Ms. Lam said the goal was to create ''smaller learning communities'' where no student would languish in anonymity. Some of the new high schools will focus on a single subject, like technology or drama. Abby Goodnough

title: Art Broker Charged With Fraud Involving Monet and Picasso Works
description: A Manhattan art broker was arrested in Brazil yesterday on charges that he arranged to sell a Picasso painting that he knew was stolen and tried to sell a Monet that belonged to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to two buyers at once.

title: Allowing Those Who Fight for Their Country to Be a Part of It
description: Diego Rincon decided to fight for this country after the World Trade Center was struck by terrorists on Sept. 11, 2001. He was a poor 18-year-old immigrant from Colombia, the son of a carpet cleaner.

title: Stallions Are Killed In Florida Barn Fire
description: A giant blaze swept through a barn housing nine prized thoroughbreds at Meadowbrook of Ocala Jockey Club last night in Florida, killing five.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MAN DIES IN CENTRAL PARK One man died yesterday and another was hospitalized after they were pulled from the Harlem Meer in Central Park, the police said. The man who died, Alberto Hernandez, 23, of Brooklyn, was pulled from the water by rescuers in scuba gear, then taken to St. Luke's Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. He was found about 20 feet offshore, Firefighter Sean Johnson said. The other man, Boris Fajero, 23, also of Brooklyn, was at St. Luke's in stable condition. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Dies In Central Park
description: One man died yesterday and another was hospitalized after they were pulled from the Harlem Meer in Central Park, the police said. The man who died, Alberto Hernandez, 23, of Brooklyn, was pulled from the water by rescuers in scuba gear, then taken to St. Luke's Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. He was found about 20 feet offshore, Firefighter Sean Johnson said. The other man, Boris Fajero, 23, also of Brooklyn, was at St. Luke's in stable condition. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Profit At SK Telecom
description: The SK Telecom Company reported a profit of 449 billion won ($373.3 million) in the first quarter compared with 444 billion in the first quarter of 2002 and 163 billion won in the fourth quarter. Sales gained 16 percent, to 2.2 trillion won from 1.9 trillion won. Shares of the company rose 5 percent, helped partly by the company's decision to reduce capital spending this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Memo to Prospective Bigolistas
description: EVERY Monday, Mark Ladner prepares 40 orders of duck confit for the Tuesday dinner service at Lupa, the Greenwich Village restaurant where he is the chef and an owner.

title: Cond Nast Picks Publisher of New York to Head Men's Shopping Magazine
description: Cond Nast Publications said yesterday that it had hired Alan Katz, the publisher of New York magazine, to lead a new shopping magazine for men that it is developing.

title: Old Man of the Mountain: The Spirit Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Republican Rebel
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Plot on U.S. Base Is Convicted of Lesser Charge
description: A German court today convicted a Turkish man of illegally possessing explosives, after prosecutors dropped a more serious charge that he and his American fiance had planned to bomb the European headquarters of the United States Army here.

title: Judge Allows A Confession In Sniper Case
description: A Virginia state judge ruled today that most of a long, detailed confession Lee Malvo gave to the police in a six-hour interview about his role in last fall's Washington-area sniper shootings could be used at his murder trial, scheduled for Nov. 10.

title: BACARDI IS CREATING TWO NEW CLASSES OF STOCK
description: Bacardi Ltd., the closely held maker of Bacardi rum and Dewar's Scotch whiskey, will create two classes of stock, moving the more than 140-year-old company closer to a possible initial public offering. More than two-thirds of the board voted to issue two classes of common stock. Another vote would be required before additional shares could be issued for a public offering, the company said. Analysts have speculated that Bacardi would use proceeds from a share sale to finance possible acquisitions to remain competitive as the liquor industry consolidates. A spokeswoman declined to comment on whether Bacardi was considering a public share sale.

title: Soyuz Crew Shrugs Off Rocky Plunge From Space
description: Offering a multinational display of right-stuff bravura, the three-man crew of the Soyuz space capsule met the news media today and shrugged off the notion that their steep plunge to Earth in a malfunctioning spaceship last Sunday was riskier than any other weekend drive.

title: A Problem of Transition
description: Retired Army Lt. Gen. Jay Garner, the U.S. civil administrator overseeing the rebuilding of Iraq, has said he wants to see the nucleus of a new Iraqi government in place this month.

title: INVESTIGATORS LINK SHUTTLE'S BREAKUP TO DAMAGE TO WING
description: After three months' work, the independent board investigating the breakup of the space shuttle Columbia gave a detailed working theory of the accident today, saying that superheated gas entered through a small hole in the front edge of the left wing and melted it from the inside out.

title: Savoring the Chemistry Of Southern Cooking
description: IT was in 1990 that Scott Peacock, the 27-year-old chef at the governor's mansion in Georgia, went to meet Edna Lewis, the 74-year-old doyenne of Southern cuisine, at an Atlanta train station. She was to cook at a fund-raising dinner for the American Institute of Food and Wine, and he was assigned to help her. There she was, on the platform, dragging a huge cardboard box by a rope. She knew she wouldn't have time to do things properly, so she had brought what she needed: 100 pounds of pie dough, packed in ice.

title: A Futures Market in Flavor: Pork Bellies Are Just the Start
description: TEN years ago, pork bellies were about as likely to appear on a fancy New York restaurant menu as sorghum or feed corn. Bacon in its raw, uncured state, pork belly is the fattiest part of the mature hog, thick stripes of pure white fat and rosy meat. New York chefs have, of course, long used bacon (and its European cousins pancetta, lardons and ventrche) discreetly, or as a garnish. They have been even more discreet about pork bellies. But now, pork bellies, along with other rich, unabashedly fatty cuts of the pig, have landed right on the menu. The futures market looks fat and happy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer's Profit Falls
description: The Dutch insurance company Aegon reported a 36 percent decline in first-quarter profit, largely a result of a stronger euro, declining stock markets and lower bond yields. The earnings of 393 million euros ($449 million) exceeded analysts' expectations but were lower than the 617 million euros the company earned a year earlier. Pretax profit was down 47 percent, to 845 million euros. Revenue fell 9 percent, to 8.56 billion euros. The United States is one of Aegon's biggest profit centers and its first-quarter performance was set back by a softer dollar and a 20 percent decline in sales of fixed annuity products. Aegon declined to issue a yearly profit forecast but said it was optimistic that the current recovery in some equity markets could help it improve performance. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Cablevision And YES Disagree
description: Five weeks after an agreement put the YES Network on Cablevision, ending a yearlong blackout, the companies disputed yesterday how many of the cable operator's subscribers had elected to add YES to their monthly bill.

title: Memories of the Maypole
description: To the Editor:

title: Ducks Pursue A New Fantasy From Disney
description: The symmetry is a bit weird, Paul Kariya admits.

title: Cisco Profit Narrowly Beats Expectations Of Wall Street
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the largest maker of Internet network equipment, reported yesterday that its profits slightly exceeded Wall Street expectations even though its sales dropped compared with those in the period a year earlier. But Cisco's chief executive suggested that sales might rebound, noting he saw seeds of a possible recovery in the technology industry.

title: Mets Dismiss Distractions And Dodgers
description: This was just what the Mets needed: a strong performance by a starter, timely hitting punctuated by power, errorless defense and a calm ending by their closer.

title: Oral History Project Wants Nation of Interviewers; Public Recording Booth at Grand Central Aims to Democratize Chroniclers Art
description: The voice on the recording quivers and warbles and shows the speaker's age, which is 88. The speaker is asked who he is.

title: In This Residence, College Boys Can Be Men
description: When Mickey MacDonald tells people he is spending his junior year of college living in a ''Men and Masculinity'' theme residence with four other male students, most people don't know what to make of it.

title: Campaign Begun to Reduce Toll of 'Hard Core' Drunken Drivers
description: The new chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board said today that her agency would undertake a major campaign to reduce the disproportionate toll taken by ''hard-core'' drunken drivers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Oil Profit Rises
description: The French-based oil company TotalFinaElf said its profit rose 49 percent in the first quarter, to 2.21 billion euros ($2.53 billion), helped by higher oil prices and beating market forecasts. Sales rose 19 percent, to 28.3 billion euros. ''High oil prices and a sharp rebound in European refining margins fueled the earnings increase, more than offsetting the impacts of the falling dollar and continued weakness in chemicals,'' the chairman, Thierry Desmarest, said. Total's shareholders voted to change the company's name to Total, dropping the references to Petrofina and Elf Aquitane, companies it acquired in the last few years. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC., Roseland, N.J., the world's largest paycheck issuer and a processor of stock trades, won a 10-year contract to mail documents and handle trades for E*Trade Group, Menlo Park, Calif., an Internet broker. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Crown Hts. Retrial Comes Down to 'Why?'
description: On a hot August night 12 years ago, a man named Yankel Rosenbaum lay on the hood of a car in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, bleeding from wounds that would eventually take his life. The police brought over a 16-year-old, Lemrick Nelson Jr., whom they had just arrested. Mr. Rosenbaum said he recognized the young man, and he asked him a question.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Wyndham Loss Narrows as Revenue Falls
description: Wyndham International, the hotel company controlled by the investors Thomas Lee and Leon Black, said today that its loss narrowed in the first quarter from a year earlier, when it wrote down the value of acquisitions.

title: On Second Avenue, a Bay State Fish House
description: GIVEN the downward trajectory of the economy, it was a good bet that some restaurateur would reverse the usual strategy of starting out in a low-cost neighborhood like the East Village and moving on up from there. Sure enough, Jimmy Bradley and Danny Abrams, who own the Red Cat in Chelsea and the Harrison in TriBeCa, have now planted their flag in the East Village, where they opened the Mermaid Inn a little more than a month ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPPER, DOROTHY HEALY
description: HUPPER - Dorothy Healy. Services at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 11 A.M. Thursday, May 8, 2003

title: Shattered Glass and Rubble In Village That Defied Time
description: The questions the merchants in this quaint historic village are pondering today are not when or where to rebuild the flea markets and service shops destroyed by a tornado on Sunday night. The questions are whether to even bother, and how to possibly begin.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: RESTORING LINKS TO INDIA Prime Minister Zafarullah Khan Jamali backed the full restoration of air and land travel links and sporting ties with India. The move was the latest sign of a thaw in relations between the two rival nuclear powers and came ahead of a visit to both countries this week by Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage to encourage the process. (Reuters)

title: Nothing to Sneeze At
description: As allergy sufferers sniffle their way through another pollen-laden spring, they will find an important change in the available medications. Claritin, an antihistamine that does not cause drowsiness while it battles your runny nose or itchy eyes, no longer requires a prescription. It can be bought over the counter at any retail pharmacy. That switch in status, coupled with the expiration of the drug's main patent protection, has led to a precipitous drop in the drug's retail price -- to roughly $1 for a daily tablet from $3.

title: SPRINT, UNDER COMPETITIVE PRESSURE, IS CUTTING 575 JOBS
description: The Sprint Corporation will eliminate 575 jobs after competition caused revenue to decline. Employees were notified yesterday of the cuts, which amount to less than 1 percent of Sprint's work force of 72,000, a spokeswoman, Melinda Tiemeyer, said. She declined to detail any charge or cost savings. About 100 of the jobs being eliminated are in Kansas City, Mo. The cuts are in Sprint's local- and long-distance phone unit, which has had nine consecutive quarterly sales declines as business customers pare spending and rivals take residential customers.

title: Boy Dies Suddenly and Another Is Hospitalized in Brooklyn
description: An 11-month-old boy died yesterday in Brooklyn and a second child was hospitalized after their baby sitter reported that they were having trouble breathing, the police said.

title: France Envisions a Citizenry of Model Muslims
description: The French interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, was booed and whistled at when he said at the annual conference of one of this country's most important Muslim groups last month that Muslim women would have to go bareheaded when posing for pictures for their identity cards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, LORA S.
description: COLLINS-Lora S. We mourn the untimely death and irreplaceable loss of our dear friend. Betty Satterwhite Larry Sutter

title: Corrections
description: A picture in some editions yesterday with an article about torture that was used by Uday Hussein against members of Iraq's national soccer team carried an incorrect credit. The picture, of a man pointing to a metal framework that could be clamped over a human body to enable electrical shocks, was by Craig S. Smith of The New York Times; in earlier editions, a picture of a man standing to the right of the metal form was by Farah Nosh for The Times.

title: A Sampler, With a Joke Riding on a War Horse
description: A ballet gala that pokes some fun at itself is a breath of fresh air, however air-conditioned. American Ballet Theater opened its season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night with a traditional mix of preview excerpts as well as a one-act work. In this instance it was ''Within You Without You: A Tribute to George Harrison,'' with Olivia Harrison, the rock idol's widow, in the audience to see the hit of the company's fall season at City Center.

title: A History Of Lying Recounted As Fiction
description: Stephen Glass, who was fired by The New Republic five years ago for fabricating details in 27 articles, has written a book telling his side of the story in fictional form.

title: Kings' Inside Game Stuffs the Mavericks
description: Sacramento forward Chris Webber tomahawked home a dunk seven minutes into Game 1 of the Kings' Western Conference semifinal game with the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMAREST, LEANNE HANSEN
description: DEMAREST-Leanne Hansen, on May 5, 2003, into her sixty-fourth year. Survived by her husband Kenneth L. Demarest Jr.; her sons, William H. Taft and Timothy P. Taft; & her brother, Stephen C. Hansen. Educated at the Lenox School, Briarcliff College & Columbia University. She was a resident of New Vernon, NJ. She was active with Seeing Eye, Inc. and the Neighborhood House, both of Morristown, NJ. A Memorial Service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, NJ on Saturday, May 10, 11:00 AM. Interment at Locust Valley Cemetery, Long Island is private. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may contribute in her memory to the Neighborhood House, 12 Flagler Street, Morristown, New Jersey 07960. For information call Wm. A. Bradley & Son, Funeral Directors, Chatham, New Jersey.

title: New Audiotape Renews Speculation About Hussein's Fate
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  An audiotape purportedly recorded by Saddam Hussein emerged today, further complicating the mystery about whether the deposed Iraqi leader had survived the war in Iraq.

title: Amherst Head to Lead Law Center
description: TOM GERETY, who is stepping down as president of Amherst College after nine years, will become executive director of the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University's School of Law and a university professor. The eight-year-old center, named after the former Supreme Court associate justice, has a staff of 40 and combines aspects of a public interest law firm, a think tank and an advocacy organization to promote inclusive and effective democracy. Mr. Gerety, a constitutional law scholar who was previously president of Trinity College in Hartford and dean of the College of Law at the University of Cincinnati, holds a Ph.D. in philosophy and a J.D. from Yale. He succeeds E. JOSHUA ROSENKRANZ, one of the founders of the Brennan Center. Karen W. Arenson

title: To Complete a Ramp
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Suisse Posts Increase In Net Income On Cost Cuts
description: The Credit Suisse Group, which promised investors a comeback in 2003 after its loss of 3.3 billion Swiss francs ($2.5 billion) last year, produced the first signs of one today. The company reported a net income of 652 million Swiss francs ($492 million) for the quarter ended March 31, nearly double the 368 million francs in profit it recorded in the period last year.

title: No Headline
description: Hadhrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, spiritual leader of the evangelical Ahmadiyya Muslim sect, which seeks to reinterpret Islamic doctrine in the light of the modern age, died on April 23 in London, where he had lived since fleeing Pakistan in 1984. He was 74.

title: For Blair at 50, Salutations (Sweet and Sour)
description: Tony Blair turned 50 today, grayer and paler than when he entered 10 Downing Street six years ago as the youngest British prime minister in nearly two centuries but visibly more relaxed and certain of himself and his leadership than in his fresh-faced early days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Mayor Forces Three to Quit In Inquiry at Housing Agency
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg forced three key New York City Housing Development Corporation officials to resign yesterday, charging that they had failed to prevent an embezzlement scheme that cheated the corporation out of hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Money Helps Put Miami in Play for Two Conferences
description: About a year and half ago, Donna Shalala, the president of Miami and former secretary of Health and Human Services in the Clinton administration, outlined her vision of the university's future to a room filled with presidents from Big Eastmember universities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONISCH, ROBERT B.
description: KRONISCH-Robert B. on May 5, 2003. Cherished son of Joseph and the late Doris. Dear brother of Bart. Loving uncle of Lauren & Matthew. Dear brother-in-law of Janet & dearest nephew of Shirley Karp. Service today 11:30AM at the ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: Needed: Iraqi Software
description: It isn't often you get to see a live political science experiment, but that is what we're about to witness in Iraq as the first interim Iraqi government is formed from the different factional leaders in the country. What American advisers and this Iraqi interim government will attempt to answer is the most fundamental question facing the Arab world and many developing countries: How do you get from here to there? How do you go from a brutal authoritarian regime to a decent, accountable, democratizing society, without ending up with an Iranian-style theocracy or chaos?

title: Bomb Kills Hamas Militant; Palestinian Infant Shot in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, May 7  A Hamas militant was killed today when a bomb exploded inside his West Bank apartment under disputed circumstances, and an infant Palestinian boy was fatally shot by Israeli army fire in the Gaza Strip, Palestinians said.

title: Surfing, Sumo and Restored Scenes at Film Fest
description: Maybe they were lured away by the blockbuster ''X2'' or by the sun making one of its novel spring appearances, but people were not exactly flocking to the opening days of the second annual TriBeCa Film Festival last weekend. Maybe they even considered the weekend's lineup, billed as family-friendly, as not really the start of the event.

title: Turks Reject U.S. Criticism of Opposition to Iraq War
description: ISTANBUL, May 7  Officials in Turkey today rejected criticism by Paul D. Wolfowitz, the United States deputy defense secretary, suggesting that the country had made a mistake by not opening its doors to the American military during the Iraq war.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GABRIEL, LOUIS
description: GABRIEL-Louis; Dear DAD: On the 100th Anniversary of your birth, you and Mom are remembered with love every day. Your son, RONALD

title: Even With Glut, Shrimp Farmers Want Still More and Others Balk
description: Holding a plate of freshly cooked shrimp, Wichan Maungchanburi, a 41-year-old shrimp farmer, asked what price they would fetch in the United States.

title: Hazardous Waste Is Shipped From India to U.S. Recycling Plant
description: In what environmental activists in India are hailing as a major victory, tons of hazardous waste from an abandoned thermometer factory owned by India's largest consumer products company, Hindustan Lever Ltd., is heading to a recycling plant in the United States for safe disposal.

title: C. F. Edley, 75, College Fund Leader, Dies
description: Christopher Fairfield Edley, president emeritus of the United Negro College Fund, who built upon its slogan, ''A mind is a terrible thing to waste,'' to raise more than $700 million to help aspiring students, died on Monday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WALLACE, MARION
description: WALLACE-Marion In memory of my loving Mother. Born May 7, 1903 Your son, Walter C. Wallace

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: President Vows Fight
description: Hours after rebels executed a governor, a former defense minister and eight other captives, President lvaro Uribe accepted responsibility in an emotional television speech but vowed to continue fortifying the armed forces to ''defeat terrorism.'' The hostages, some of whom had been held for years, were shot dead when the Marxist guerrillas heard helicopters that were carrying government troops on what was planned as a rescue operation. Mr. Uribe, under pressure to carry out an exchange of jailed guerrillas for other hostages in rebel hands, said an exchange was possible but only under the United Nations and only if all hostages, including many being held for ransom, were part of the deal. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Bystander Is Shot on Inwood Street as Officers Struggle With Man
description: A 52-year-old woman who was apparently a bystander was shot yesterday when a police officer's weapon discharged during a confrontation with a suspect in upper Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: Gillette Profits Rise, but a Razor Battle Looms
description: Gillette said yesterday that first-quarter profit climbed 18 percent because of higher Mach3Turbo and Duracell battery sales. Greater competition will hurt profit the rest of the year, Gillette said.

title: How to Select Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Adds Basque Group in Spain to Its Terrorist List
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 — The United States has added the Basque nationalist party Batasuna and two predecessor groups to a list subject to financial sanctions because of suspected terrorist links, the State Department said today.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Coliseum Demolition Advances
description: The New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum, a city arena that closed last year, will be razed once a demolition company is selected, officials said yesterday. The search for the company will begin next week as part of a redevelopment plan. To compete with newer facilities, the arena would have required about $30 million in renovations, said a city spokesman, James Foye. It had been losing about $2 million a year, he said. Last month, the city announced plans to house a community college, hotel and theater on the site. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Bids Due for British Department Stores
description: Selfridges & Company, the nearly 100-year-old London department store that was the precursor to the modern shopping mall, may soon be at the center of a bidding war.

title: What's Weird?
description: To the Editor:

title: Auditioning for Senator McCarthy
description: Even before he died, Senator Joseph McCarthy and his poisonous encounter with American history were being summarized in a single word, McCarthyism. A half-century later, the word continues to outlive the senator in the public mind, as well it should, for it is defined as the persecution of innocent people by sensational but unproven accusations. This low-blow tactic is ever tempting to someone or other in public life, which makes Congress's release this week of some of the more odious McCarthy archives a welcome renewal of cautionary history.

title: Boston Globe Suspends Columnist
description: The simmering rivalry between the Nets and the Boston Celtics took an unexpected and personal turn today that had nothing to do with the Nets' 97-93 victory in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference semifinals Monday night.

title: Integrity in Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Crumbs in Bed? Mom Won't Mind
description: With their signature pink macaroons and pink tins of tea, the Fauchon stores are prime territory for a gift for Mother's Day, on Sunday. This year, Fauchon offers a pink vinyl tote bag containing the fixings for breakfast in bed: fresh breakfast pastries, jams, a tin of coffee, a coffee mug and even a silvery aluminum tray for presenting it all to Mom. The bag (above) is $50 at Fauchon, 442 Park Avenue (56th Street), 1000 Madison Avenue (78th Street) and a new store at 1383 Third Avenue (78th Street). On Sunday, the stores will open at 8 a.m., for pickup. Advance orders can be placed, but are not necessary.

title: A Salad That's Born on the Plate
description: SUZANNE GOIN lifted her chef's knife and began cutting plump Deglet Noor dates in two, and swiftly removing their pits. The knife was the length of her forearm, with a long slender blade and a jagged tip abbreviated by one too many falls to the floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROTZKY, HELEN
description: TROTZKY-Helen. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Helen Trotzky, beloved grandmother of Cathy Zises, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. Cathy, a trustee at the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, and her husband, Seymour, a member of the Board of UJAFederation, are generous and devoted leaders of Jewish and humanitarian causes. We extend our deepest sympathies to Cathy & Seymour, and to their entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Investigatory Board's Assignment: Balancing Analysis and Reassurance
description: At a glance, the hypothesis laid out by the Columbia Accident Investigation Board today seems not far from what looked obvious in the first few days after the Feb. 1 accident: debris, probably insulation foam, fell from the external fuel tank about 82 seconds after liftoff, hit the shuttle and damaged its thermal protection system, leading it to burn up on re-entry.

title: George Kozmetsky, 89, Dean And a Co-Founder of Teledyne
description: George Kozmetsky, co-founder of the conglomerate Teledyne and a lifelong educator who used his work and philanthropy to bring industry and academia closer together, died last Wednesday in Austin, Tex. He was 85.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Posts Loss
description: The Korea Exchange Bank reported a loss of 191.4 billion won ($159.5 million) in the first quarter in contrast to a profit of 54.1 billion won in the first quarter of 2002. The reason was a write-down of the value of its shares of Hynix Semiconductor. The value of Hynix shares held by Korea Exchange Bank, in which the government owns a controlling stake, fell 236.4 billion won after the bank revalued the price to 166 won a share from 365 won. The bank, which is Hynix's lead creditor, said it would try to sell Hynix to Chinese investors after having failed in previous efforts to sell it to Micron Technology of Boise, Idaho, and to Infineon of Germany. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Bad Hair And Bad Knee Day
description: The messy world of the dysfunctional Mets got stickier yesterday with Rey Sanchez denying that he had plopped down in the clubhouse during a lopsided game last week to get a little off the top and a little off the sides. It never happened, Sanchez said about the haircut, repeating his denial at least five times in a four-minute interview before the Mets-Dodgers game at Shea Stadium last night.

title: Japanese Company Buys Into U.S. Shop
description: Hakuhodo in Tokyo, a large agency company, said yesterday that it had acquired a minority stake in Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising in Los Angeles for undisclosed terms.

title: Virginia Site Is Considered Possible Home Of Pocahontas
description: In American folk history, the Indian princess Pocahontas befriended English settlers and saved Captain John Smith from certain death at the hands of his Algonquin captors. It happened near the Jamestown colony in Virginia, within a year of its founding in 1607. Or it may be only a story.

title: A Flag for Spring: Green, White and Purple
description: ASPARAGUS season is running late this year, but you would never know that from a stroll down the grocery aisle.

title: Stone Harbor Journal; Endangered Bird Finds Friends in High Places
description: Pity the poor piping plover.

title: A Renoir Shines as the Spring Art Sales Begin
description: An 1882 Renoir portrait of a French gentleman's wife sitting in her garden, deemed too daring by the husband who commissioned it because of its bright colors, is heading for Las Vegas.

title: 4 States Defend Support of Vancouver Bid
description: Four states in the Pacific Northwest, citing the anticipated economic benefits the Olympics would have on their region, have passed resolutions since February supporting Vancouver's bid to play host to the 2010 Winter Games.

title: Whether a Hummer or a Hybrid, The Big Complaint Is Fuel Use
description: Drivers of Hummers and hybrids have something in common after all.

The value of Hynix shares held by Korea Exchange Bank, in which the government owns a controlling stake, fell 236.4 billion won after the bank revalued the price to 166 won a share from 365 won. description: Gov. George E. Pataki today continued his assault on the budget the Legislature passed in defiance of his veto threat, saying it would not reduce local property taxes as lawmakers maintain because they failed to revamp the Medicaid program.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Sunday about a Pentagon project to enlist exiles to help reshape Iraq referred imprecisely in some editions to official reticence. The Pentagon has been guarded in replying to inquiries about the project, citing security. But Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz made it public on Feb. 23; "under close wraps" did not signify complete silence.

title: Killed in Iraq

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: FIAT GAINS MARKET SHARE Fiat sold fewer vehicles in Italy in April than in April of last year, but an industry group said the company's market share increased as total new car sales fell 5.8 percent. Fiat sold 52,660 vehicles in Italy last month, 28.8 percent of the market, compared with 28 percent in March. Fiat's market share was 31 percent in April 2002. Fiat has been selling assets to increase investments in its money-losing car division. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: 'Butter,' Says a Spread, And Keeps On Talking
description: With bread usually comes butter or, increasingly these days, a puddle of olive oil in a dish. But at Nice Matin, a restaurant at 201 West 79th Street that is a homage to the French Riviera, the bread comes with a surprise: a slab of butter in a pool of olive oil speckled with dried herbes de Provence. The chef, Andrew D'Amico, said he remembered being served butter in oil in a cafe in Nice. Adding herbs was his touch, and for me they are what makes the combination work.

title: Russian Commander Charged in Copter Crash That Killed 127
description: MOSCOW, May 7  Russia's chief military prosecutor has filed the first criminal charges against an officer or commander in the catastrophic loss of a mammoth military helicopter in Chechnya last August, and acknowledged that the death toll was higher than reported, officials said today.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES TRIPATH IMAGING'S ASSERTION ON PAP TEST
description: Shares of TriPath Imaging Inc. rose about 34 percent after the company won federal approval to state that its liquid Pap smear detects signs of cervical cancer more accurately than traditional Pap tests. The Food and Drug Administration decision lets TriPath make the claim on labels for its SurePath test pack and PrepStain slide process. The tests are 64.4 percent more likely than traditional ones to detect high-grade cells that are a sign of cervical cancer, the company said. TriPath Imaging soared $1.45, to $5.78, on the Nasdaq.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: TRANSMETA SHARES SOAR ON DESIGN NEWS Shares of the Transmeta Corporation rose sharply yesterday on news that the chip maker had been chosen by Microsoft as a reference design partner for next-generation smart displays. Transmeta shares rose 26 cents, or about 24.5 percent, to $1.32. Smart displays are wireless touch-screen monitors that permit personal computers that use Microsoft Windows XP to be used from remote locations within a home or office. Smart Displays are now available from display and computer manufacturers, with more models scheduled for release in 2003 and 2004, Transmeta said. The company designs microchips for electronic devices that need long battery life.

title: New York City May Get a Free Ride to 2034
description: In the far-off year of 2034, a date that smacks more of George Jetson than Abe Beame and Hugh Carey, New York State taxpayers could still be paying off the tab for New York City's fiscal crisis of the 1970's.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Topics of The Times; Gambling on Forgiveness
description: William Bennett has made a small fortune by lecturing the nation on its morals, and it's a good thing because he might otherwise be one of those gambling addicts in deep hock pleading for understanding, if not credit, now that his quiet life as a high roller has been documented. The readers who made best sellers of ''The Book of Virtues'' and other umbrage-etched tomes written by Mr. Bennett can take comfort that their investment in his unflinching ethical advice has probably helped offset the millions of dollars that he lost to his private pleasure as a preferred customer at casinos in Las Vegas and Atlantic City.

title: Gingerly, Pro-Iranian Iraqi Muslim Group Lobbies for Washington's Favor
description: A Shiite Muslim cleric arrived at the Pentagon last week armed with a fatwa, or religious edict, a prop in his campaign to persuade the Bush administration of the worthiness of the Iranian-based Iraqi ayatollah he calls his leader.

title: Is You Wicked?
description: James Baker, the former secretary of state who helped make two Bushes president, the first by sniping at Massachusetts, the second by snatching away Florida, is an extremely careful man.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Loss Widens At Plane Maker
description: The European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Company, the primary owner of Airbus, reported its first-quarter net loss widened as the plane-making division delivered fewer planes and costs rose to develop the 550-seat A380. The net loss was 93 million euros ($106 million) compared with 25 million euros a year earlier. Sales fell 14 percent, to 5.5 billion euros. European Aeronautic, Defense and Space said that it expected sales and income to be about the same this year as in 2002 and that it still expected to deliver about 300 planes this year.

title: Accused of Hiding War Crimes Suspect, Liberia Says It Killed Him
description: For a week, the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, has been accused by United Nations investigators of harboring an accused war criminal, a West African warlord named Sam Bockarie. Today, Mr. Taylor's government said its forces had shot and killed Mr. Bockarie this morning as he tried to enter the country before dawn.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Everything in this city is getting expensive. How are you supposed to live? Thank God I'm nearly dead.''

title: A Place to Bring Cheeses To Just the Right Age
description: Buying cheese in peak condition can be a challenge. Underripe Camembert, overly funky Teleme and dried-out goat crottins are not uncommon on restaurant cheese carts and store shelves.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Says Too Many Teachers Leave
description: One of every four New York City teachers leaves the system within two years, compared with a national average of one out of 10, according to a new report compiled by Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz of Manhattan. The report faults the City Education Department for not keeping sufficient data on why teachers leave, and recommends that departing teachers be required to answer a survey. The report also urged training on handling discipline problems, a major reason for departures. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gates Introduces New PC Prototype
description: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, yesterday demonstrated a prototype for a new personal computer built with the Hewlett-Packard Company that will be used for handling phone calls and teleconferencing. The Athens prototype has a wide-screen display and a video camera and phone attached to the screen. Hewlett will add features from Athens to PC's next year, said Lewis Kim, marketing director for Hewlett's worldwide business desktop unit. Those advances ''encourage people to jump in and get something new,'' Mr. Gates said in an interview. ''Our innovations are why demand has gone up a little bit this year instead of going down, which, given the general economic conditions, you wouldn't expect.'' Microsoft is working with PC makers on new designs it hopes can increase computer sales, as many companies switch to replacing PC's every four to five years, rather than more frequently, said Tom Phillips, general manager of Microsoft's Windows Hardware Experience Group. Mr. Gates spoke in New Orleans at the Windows hardware engineering conference for companies that build computers and devices with Microsoft's Windows operating system. Microsoft shares rose $1.30, to $27.79.

title: Former Bosnian Serb Officer Admits Guilt in '95 Massacre
description: A former commander in the Bosnian Serb army agreed today to plead guilty to crimes against humanity in the massacre of more than 7,000 Muslim men and boys in the town of Srebrenica in 1995.

title: A Wide Income Gap Separates Commuters and City Residents
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to reinstitute a commuter tax may have expired in Albany, but an analysis of new census data suggests that suburbanites who commute to New York City are much better off on average than other New Yorkers and might not have been in a bad position to pay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZER, MICHAEL
description: SCHWEITZER-Michael. Founder and President of The RAM Group. It is with incredible sadness that we share the news of Michael's passing on May 4, 2003. Dear brother of Alan Schweitzer of New York, nephew of Irving Schweitzer of Texas, lifelong friend of David Klein of Colorado, and a true leader to his family at The RAM Group across Canada and in the United States. Born in the Bronx and educated at Harvard Business School, Michael enjoyed great success throughout his life and career and will be greatly missed by all those who knew him.

title: Niche Markets Dominate Boston's Office Scene
description: Even as office vacancy rates for Boston are exceeding those of the early 1990's, development in some significant niche markets -- life science research, academia and hotels -- is flourishing.

description: The Jets added depth to their offensive line yesterday, signing the free-agent tackle Brent Smith, who spent six seasons with the Miami Dolphins.

title: Record Label And Its Chief Told to Pay $132 Million
description: A civil court jury in Manhattan yesterday ordered the Island Def Jam Music Group and Lyor Cohen, its chairman and chief executive, to pay $132 million in damages to an independent record label after they were found liable for bad business practices.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about a Pentagon project to enlist exiles to help reshape Iraq referred imprecisely in some editions to official reticence. The Pentagon has been guarded in replying to inquiries about the project, citing security. But Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz made it public on Feb. 23; ''under close wraps'' did not signify complete silence.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Greece: Cigarette Maker Acquired
description: Philip Morris International, a unit of the Altria Group, agreed to buy a majority stake in Papastratos, Greece's biggest producer of cigarettes, for as much as 371 million euros ($424 million) to gain brands, including Assos and President. Philip Morris International said it would pay as much as 18.15 euros a share for about 76 percent of Papastratos and would make a public tender offer for the rest of the stock. The price values Papastratos at about 485 million euros. Altria's international operations have gained greater importance because the company's Philip Morris USA unit has been losing cigarette sales to the makers of cheaper brands and spending more to stem the decrease. Papastratos had sales of 404 million euros last year. Its brands make up about 15 percent of the Greek cigarette market.

title: South Korea hopes president's visit to U.S. will heal rift in alliance
description: SEOUL:  As President Roh Moo Hyun prepares for a mission to the United States, officials here and in Washington are hoping the visit will heal rifts in the alliance as the peninsula confronts the North Korean nuclear crisis.

description: KAPLAN - Abraham. The members and staff of Elmwood Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed longtime member and friend Abe Kaplan. We wish to extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Ruth, and his daughter, Ronnie, and son, Harvey.

Loving mother of Judith T. Steckler. Adoring grandmother of David and Lynn. Ev and Tyke will be together for eternity now. The family would appreciate donations in Evelyn's memory to The Fund for Park Avenue, 110 E. 42 St., Suite 1300, New York, NY 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTITE, ALBERT
description: KOTITE-Albert, 86, of Manhattan, on May 1, 2003. Loving husband for 51 years of Antoinette. Devoted father of Edward, Albert, Peter, Deborah and Toni. Beloved grandfather of Edward, Elizabeth, P.J., Christopher, Aaron, John, Harrison and Topper. A leading member of New York City's printing industry for over 62 years, he was respected and admired by all who had the privilege of working with him. His love of family, his dedication to his work and his generosity will always be remembered. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. David's School, 12 East 89th Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: EchoStar Reverses a Loss in Quarter
description: EchoStar Communications, the satellite television broadcaster, said yesterday that it had its third quarterly profit in eight years after attracting a surge of new subscribers.

title: Marriott Wins Round in Suit Filed by Hotels In New Orleans
description: A judge in New Orleans has declined to issue a temporary restraining order against Marriott International to prevent it from managing a luxury property in the city.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: DOCTORS PROTEST MALPRACTICE AWARDS About 100 of the 1,500 doctors in Jacksonville stayed off the job to protest the Legislature's refusal to limit jury awards in medical malpractice cases to $250,000. The protest, which started on Friday evening, led three of the five largest hospitals to delay elective surgery and tell some emergency room walk-in patients to go elsewhere for treatment. As of late Monday, 44 patients had been referred to the other two large hospitals. Trial lawyers fought the cap, saying it could prevent victims from being fairly compensated. (AP)

title: Devils Will Face Multiple Threats
description: John Madden has received much attention in the first two rounds of the postseason, helping the Devils win two series in five games each by shutting down Boston's Joe Thornton in the first round and Tampa Bay's Vincent Lecavalier in the second.

title: White House Clarifies Bush's Carrier Landing
description: The White House said today that President Bush traveled to the carrier Abraham Lincoln last week on a small plane because he wanted to experience a landing the way carrier pilots do, not because the ship would be too far out to sea for Mr. Bush to arrive by helicopter, as his spokesman had originally maintained.

title: Whose Side Is Bush On?
description: For the condemned man in the neoconservative revolution, Secretary of State Colin Powell is having a pretty good week. Syria is safe from invasion for the time being, President Bush is talking to the prime minister of South Korea about negotiating with the North, and the road map to Middle East peace is back on the table. It seems like just yesterday that Donald Rumsfeld and Richard Perle were on the verge of an American Empire. So who really has the upper hand in this administration? A look at history gives a pretty convincing answer: the man in the Oval Office.

description: Senior Bush administration officials in Washington said today that a joint British-American team of experts had concluded that a tractor-trailer truck found in northern Iraq several weeks ago could be a mobile biological weapons lab.

title: Beneath Emotional Clouds
description: Mysterious emotional undercurrents swirled through ''Beneath,'' the program of five dances Johannes Wieland presented on Sunday night in the City/Dans series of the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. The performers' intensity made every step seem a portent of a gathering storm.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Girls' Game Turns Violent
description: An unsanctioned touch football game involving girls from a suburban Chicago high school degenerated into hazing on Sunday that left one student with a broken ankle and another with 10 stitches. About 100 students from Glenbrook North High School were involved in the game, a version of ''powder puff'' football in which the girls are the players and the boys are cheerleaders and spectators. A tape showed girls being punched, kicked and covered in paint. The police are considering criminal charges, and Mike Riggle, the high school's principal, said some participants might face suspension. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: Paying More for Claritin

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guidelines For Donations To City
description: The city's Conflicts of Interest Board has revised the guidelines on how and when public officials may solicit funds from private donors for the good of New York City. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made soliciting private donations to help the city through its fiscal crisis a priority. Previously, the mayor, his appointees and other elected officials were forbidden to directly solicit private-sector funds for city agencies and nonprofit entities closely affiliated with the city. Now, under recent guidelines, these officials may solicit funds from private companies, except those that have matters pending before the city. Further, the city will now have to publicly name the individuals or firms that have made large donations. The board reviewed its previous opinions on gifts to the city at the request of several officials, members said. The chairman, Steven B. Rosenfeld, called the opinion the most difficult of his first year on the board. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Archdiocese To Reveal Budget
description: The Archdiocese of Boston will post a detailed account of its budget online in an effort to win back the trust of parishioners skeptical of what their donations paid for in the sexual abuse scandal and subsequent litigation, officials said. Line items from the current fiscal year will be posted on the archdiocese's Web site early next week, an archdiocesan spokesman said, and the fiscal year 2004 budget will be available in 30 to 45 days. The spokesman said the archdiocese would probably release the amount of money it has spent on sexual abuse cases in the coming months. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Armitage 'Optimistic' About Renewed India-Pakistan Dialogue
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 8  After meeting with Pakistan's president and other officials here today, Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage said he was "cautiously optimistic" about the renewal of diplomatic relations between India and Pakistan.

title: Law Firms Quit Talks
description: LONDON, May 7 (Bloomberg News)  Ashurst Morris Crisp, a law firm based in London, ended merger talks today with the New York firm of Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson. It was Ashurst's third failed attempt at a merger.

title: For Antiques in Formal Settings, Take the Freight Elevator to 8
description: The giant Lafayette Antiques Center Warehouse, which covers an entire block in East Harlem, is now home to 42 international antiques dealers offering styles from 18th-century European to American and Scandinavian midcentury modern. Customers enter on a loading dock and ride up in a freight elevator to the eighth floor, which is set up like a formal antiques show. Booths have tidy displays, and it pays to ask if you are looking for something in particular. (Some dealers store pieces on other floors.) Restoration and reupholstery are also available. The center is open Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; 401 East 110th Street, (212) 722-8400. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Israeli Missile Strike Kills Hamas Militant
description: JERUSALEM, May 8  Israeli attack helicopters fired three missiles that killed a senior Hamas militant driving in Gaza City today, and Israeli troops also shot dead two Palestinians in separate confrontations.

title: Lightning-Quick CD Burner Moonlights as a DVD Player
description: Like just about everything else inside the computer, compact-disc recorders seem to be getting faster every week. A new model now lets you burn CD's at a blazing speed. The Samsung SM-352 drive can record CD-R discs at a speed of 52x and record data to the reusable CD-RW discs at 24x. The drive can also play most prerecorded DVD data discs and DVD movies at a speed of 16x.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Intel Reiterates 2nd-Quarter Sales Estimates
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest maker of computer chips, reiterated second-quarter sales and gross profit margin estimates, and said yesterday that stock option costs would have cut first-quarter earnings 33 percent. Sales this quarter will be $6.4 billion to $7 billion, compared with $6.75 billion in the first quarter, Intel said in a Securities and Exchange Commission quarterly filing. Gross margin, the percentage of sales left after production costs, will be 50 percent, plus or minus about 2 points, compared with 52 percent in the first quarter. First-quarter net income of $915 million would have been reduced by $298 million, to $617 million, if Intel had treated stock options as a compensation expense. Accounting rules allow companies to estimate the cost of options in footnotes to income statements rather than recognizing them as a cost. Accounting-rule makers, under pressure from investors and regulators, are moving closer to forcing companies to book options as costs. Shares of Intel fell 38 cents, to $19.16.

title: Senate Votes Unanimously to Approve Expansion of NATO
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Senate voted unanimously today to ratify the expansion of NATO, and a leading senator said that the vote to add seven East European countries to the military alliance would underscore its relevance and help end bitter disagreements over the Iraq war.

title: Man Is Convicted of Murdering Girlfriend and Two Children; Jury to Weigh Death Penalty
description: In Westchester County's first death penalty trial in nearly 30 years, a man was convicted today in the fatal stabbing of his girlfriend and two of her young children.

title: For Two-Way Radios, a Mileage Test
description: OF all the phrases in English, ''up to'' is among the most powerful. Thanks to its implied disclaimer, ''up to'' provides ironclad truth protection in almost any kind of statement. You can tell your friends that you type up to 120 words a minute, that you can bench-press up to 500 pounds, and that you earn up to $2 million a year. Legally, you're covered.

title: Interpublic chooses a financial executive from outside the industry as chief operating officer.
description: A PHARMACEUTICAL executive with extensive financial credentials but no experience at an advertising agency was named yesterday as the chief operating officer of the struggling Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: NORDSTROM FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT WAS BELOW FORECAST
description: Nordstrom Inc., the upscale retailer, said yesterday its first-quarter profit was 12 cents to 15 cents a share, less than forecast, because sales were less than expected and the company had to cut prices more than planned. The average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 19 cents. Nordstrom said it would report full results on May 19. Sales at stores open at least a year fell 1 percent in the March and April period, more than Nordstrom had predicted, and the discounts the retailer offered to attract customers reduced profit margins. Nordstrom said in March that profit would miss its original forecast of as much as 27 cents.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Black Lawmaker Endorses Nominee
description: State Representative Phillip West, a Democrat who leads the 45-member Legislative Black Caucus, reversed his opposition to the nomination of Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. of Federal District Court to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Mr. West said Judge Pickering had shown ''a willingness to work for racial reconciliation.'' A majority of the caucus opposes the nomination, and some called for Mr. West's ouster. Stephanie Parker-Weaver, executive secretary of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference called Mr. West's stance a betrayal.

title: U.S. Drafts a Resolution On the Lifting of Sanctions
description: The United States has begun circulating a draft resolution to lift sanctions in Iraq.

description: Sunny skies and a cool breeze, a track record and the presence of the Kentucky Derby winner, Funny Cide, on the backstretch of this grand old Long Island racetrack made for a memorable opening to the 55-day Belmont Park spring-summer meet yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALVEN, JOSEPHINE
description: DALVEN-Josephine. Born in Coney Island and life-long Brooklyn resident, she was the daughter of the late Louis and Tillie Schwartz, loving wife of the late Dr. Joseph Dalven and stepmother of Dr. Richard Dalven of California. Beloved sister of Gertrude Sperber (Abraham) of Albany, Regina Hayden of Brooklyn, the late Etta Gitten and Bertha Rosenthal, loving aunt to Alvin Gitten, Marilyn Stecker, Jules ''Buddy'' Gitten (Cynthia), Natalie Kornblum (Stuart), Howard Rosenthal (Barbara), Mark Sperber (Linda Forenzo), Lewis Sperber (Merle), Michael Hayden, Harriet Marone, Barry Hayden, Linda Luchs (Steven), Debbie Ciappa, Judy Krutoy (Michael), as well as numerous grand and great-grandnieces and nephews. Also survived by life-long dear friend Shirley Slotnick. Graduate of New Utrecht High School, she had a great interest in charitable causes, politics and a passion for both the visual and performing arts. Funeral services to be held at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Ave (at Ave U), Brooklyn, 718-338-1500. Interment will be at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Donations may be made to a charity of your choice.
