description: Certain thoughts are bound to grip you as you slog along highways, inches from the blurring traffic, gripping a sign saying ''150 miles or bust'' so tightly that your shoulder muscles seem permanently seized, the antibiotics from last week's flu still jingling in your pocket while rain clouds billow ominously above. They go something like this.

title: Harvard Scholar to Visit Princeton Institute
description: After Cornel West and K. Anthony Appiah, two leading African-American scholars, left Harvard University for Princeton last year, the guessing game in academia was whether Henry Louis Gates Jr., the architect and chairman of Harvard's Afro-American studies department, would follow.

title: Connecticut House Passes Ban on Workplace Smoking
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives approved a bill today that would ban smoking in most workplaces, including all restaurants and bars, but exclude private clubs and certain cigar bars. Gov. John G. Rowland has said that although he is philosophically opposed to the bill, he will sign it into law nonetheless.

title: U.S. Says Foreign Fighters Held in Iraq Face Military Trial
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Among prisoners held by the United States in Iraq, more than 200 are Syrians, Jordanians, Lebanese and other foreign nationals who could become subject to military tribunals, military officials said today.

title: Europe Plan on Chemicals Seen as Threat to U.S. Exports
description: The European Union announced a proposal today that would require manufacturers of industrial chemicals to test their products before they can be used, a change that the Bush administration said could threaten the $20 billion in chemicals that the United States exports to Europe each year.

title: Shiloh Journal; A Town Springs to Life Each Year at a Cemetery
description: People around here no longer say they are from Shiloh.

title: Mohammed Dib -- Novelist, 82
description: Mohammed Dib, an award-winning Algerian novelist and poet who wrote in French, the language in which he had learned to read as a child, died on Friday at his home outside Paris. He was 82.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer's Shares Rise
description: Shares of Royal & Sun Alliance Insurance rose for the third day in a row in anticipation of the initial public offering of Promina, its Australian and New Zealand insurance unit. The shares were up 3.5 percent to 124.25 pence (79.9 cents) at the close of the London Stock Exchange. Royal & Sun is expected to raise about $1.2 billion with the initial public offering. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: KUWAITI PETROCHEMICAL IN VENTURE WITH DOW CHEMICAL
description: Kuwaiti Petrochemical Industries, the petrochemical arm of the state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, said yesterday that it would work with the Dow Chemical Company to build an ethylene plant in Shuaiba, Kuwait. The plant is expected to start production in 2007 and to serve markets in the Middle East, the Pacific, Asia and Europe, a spokesman for Dow said.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Reserve Bank left its benchmark interest rate at 4.75 percent for an 11th straight month. Economists had expected the action at the bank's monthly meeting because the domestic economy is strong but the global economy is unsteady. The country's growth rate of 3 percent is the strongest among developed countries and its currency is at a three-year high against the United States dollar. John Shaw (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bill For Noncitizen Soldiers
description: The House Judiciary Committee approved a measure intended to speed the naturalization process for noncitizens in the military. The bill, which will be presented to the House in coming weeks, would allow immigrant soldiers to apply for citizenship after serving one year in the armed forces. The current waiting period is three years. Supporters said the legislation would reward immigrant soldiers. Others warned that the bill would not prevent the deportation of the soldiers' parents. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Dieters, It's the Carbs That Count!
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia, Citing First SARS Case, Curtails Travel to China
description: MOSCOW, May 8  Russia halted some airline flights to and from China and crimped entries along the 2,624-mile Chinese border today after the authorities said they had tentatively logged the nation's first known case of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, or SARS.

title: Agent Arraigned in Tax Case
description: The agent for the jockey Javier Castellano surrendered to the authorities yesterday at the federal courthouse in Central Islip, N.Y., and was arraigned on three counts of federal tax evasion.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VOLVO, Gothenburg, Sweden, the maker of heavy trucks, said it had acquired L. B. Smith Inc., a distributor of Volvo equipment in the U.S. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about David Hicks, an Australian captured in Afghanistan and now being held at the American military base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, referred imprecisely to his parents' communication with him. They said in an interview that their recent letters had been returned unopened and stamped ''Return to Sender'' -- not that they had gotten back all their letters sent since his imprisonment in late 2001.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: BANK'S PROFIT SLIPS France's largest bank, BNP Paribas , reported a decline of 0.7 percent in operating income in the first quarter, with strong revenue from its retail and investment banking divisions almost offsetting losses in asset management. Net income was 962 million euros ($1.1 billion), down 5.6 percent from 1.02 billion euros ($1.17 billion) last year, but beating forecasts for a steeper drop. Michel Pebereau, the chairman of BNP Paribas, attributed losses in the asset management division to a volatile stock market. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Diagnosis for Hussein?
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Amato Design For L.I. Home Upsets Some In Neighborhood
description: It is part of life on Long Island. Someone wants to build a house that is taller, roomier or surrounded by a higher fence than the zoning code permits, so he takes his case before the local zoning board of appeals. A most unglamorous proceeding unfolds, with dry discussions of square footage, traffic visibility and distance from the curb.

title: Immigrant Found Guilty of Identity Fraud
description: A Chinese immigrant was convicted yesterday of making false statements on passport and immigration forms in what prosecutors described as an elaborate scheme to impersonate a dead man.

title: Faith and the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Op-Art
GARDEN Q.& A.
description: 'Cloud of Bloom'

title: Mideast Peace, One Day at a Time
description: In the last week the prospects for peace between Israelis and Palestinians appeared to be improving. The Palestinians approved Mahmoud Abbas as their first-ever prime minister, and he declared that terrorism threatened to destroy the Palestinian cause -- language one never heard from Yasir Arafat. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel reiterated his understanding that it would take painful concessions by Israel to achieve peace, including a willingness to part with areas central to Jewish history like Bethlehem, Shilo and Beit El. And Secretary of State Colin Powell is on his way to Jerusalem to promote President Bush's ''road map'' toward a peacefully coexisting Israel and Palestine.

title: Ancient Stone Found in New York Is Returned to Egypt
description: A funeral headstone dating to the pharaohs was officially returned to Egypt yesterday at a Queens ceremony, where a top Egyptian official vowed to step up his country's campaign to retrieve other illegally removed archaeological treasures.

title: As Bush Tax Plan Falters, Conservatives Find a Silver Lining
description: When the Republican leaders of the House defied President Bush last week and dropped his plan to eliminate the tax on dividends, liberals were not the ones high-fiving each other victoriously in the hallways.

title: Playboy Reports Its First Profit in 4 Years
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. posted a profit in the first quarter, its first in four years, helped by sales at its online unit.

title: Full Text of the U.N. Draft: 'to Assist the People of Iraq'
description: Following is the text of a United States-supported resolution for the United Nations Security Council, from a draft copy circulated among United Nations diplomats.

title: G.O.P. Senators Say Pataki Rebuffed Their Peace Feeler
description: Republican leaders in the State Senate said today that they had tried to get Gov. George E. Pataki back to the bargaining table to avoid an override battle that would further fracture their party, but that so far he had rebuffed their overtures for peace.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: You Can Be a Mogul

title: Toyota Profit Surges, but Carmaker Sees Hints of Slowdown
description: TOKYO, May 8  The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its profits and sales surged for the third consecutive fiscal year because of strong demand in the United States. But the company said its run of record financial results is in jeopardy in the current year because of sluggish economic growth around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, MORTIMER JR.
description: BERKOWITZ-Mortimer Jr. Age 87, died on May 5, 2003 at his home in New York City. Beloved husband of Marjory for more than 50 years and father of Hugh J. Freund and Betsy F. Perry, both of New York City, John Berkowitz (River) of Putney, VT., and Mortimer Berkowitz III (Amelia) of New York City. Adored grandfather (''Papa'') of Caroline Loomis, Daisy Freund, Eli Berkowitz, Charlotte, Hayward, Thomas and William Berkowitz. Brother-in-law of Phyllis and Wilbur Levin and Mary Anne and Douglas Schwalbe. Adored uncle to seven nieces and nephews and many grand-nieces and nephews. Born in 1915 in Brookline, Massachusetts, Mortimer graduated from the Taft School, Class of '33 and Dartmouth College, Class of '37, where he was a member of the Green Key Society, the Casque and Gauntlet Senior Society and Palaeopitus. Following in the footsteps of his father, Mortimer began his career as a reporter with the Boston Herald and as a police reporter with the Cleveland Ohio News. Mortimer's career spanned over 50 years in the newspaper and magazine business where he was involved with publishing, advertising and marketing. He served as a Lieutenant Commander during WWII on the destroyer, U.S.S. Livermore. After the war, Mortimer joined the American Weekly as an advertising representative and then moved to Woman's Day Magazine. From 1962 until 1966 Mortimer was with BBDO before joining Fawcett Publishing in 1966 where he was Vice President and Advertising Director. From 1969 to 1990 Mortimer was the CEO of Home Garden Publishing, Universal Publishing and the Mortimer Berkowitz Company which served eight Ivy League Alumni Magazines. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St on Wednesday, May 7, from 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Thursday, May 8, at 1:30PM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his name to the Dartmouth College Fund, 6066 Development Office, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755.

title: FOREST LABS DRUG FAILS TO TREAT NERVE DAMAGE IN STUDY
description: Forest Laboratories Inc., maker of the antidepressant Celexa, said yesterday that a study showed its memantine drug for Alzheimer's disease to be no better than a sugar pill in treating nerve damage and pain. An earlier finding showed the medicine worked better on diabetic pain than a placebo, and Forest is considering whether to continue developing memantine for treatment of so-called neuropathic pain, the drug maker said. Forest has said it expects approval from the Food and Drug Administration to sell memantine to treat Alzheimer's early in its fiscal year, which began April 1.

title: A Top Cavendish for Nevada
description: Las Vegas will be the bridge capital of the world this weekend. The Cavendish Pairs, starting tomorrow, will certainly be the strongest event of its kind ever played, judging by average quality. Of the 50 pairs competing, 27 are North American, and that includes almost all the best on this side of the Atlantic. Eighteen top pairs are coming from Europe, including four each from Italy and France. Germany, with Sabine Auken and Daniela von Arnim, provides the only women's pair; the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Russia, Spain and Sweden are also represented.

title: Federal Judge Unfreezes Assets Of Former HealthSouth Chief
description: A federal judge today lifted a freeze on the assets of Richard M. Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth, denying a government motion to block use of his money and property pending his trial for fraud.

title: After New Jersey Club Raid, 2 Face Sex Assault Charges
description: Five days after the police raided a club filled with teenagers here and charged two employees with sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl, the authorities said today they believed that some workers at the club had routinely had illicit sex with many other under-age girls there.

title: A Web Site Ready-Made For the Phone-In Diarist
description: Many people who want to try publishing an online journal, known as a Weblog or blog, turn to Blogger (www.blogger.com), the service that has helped to turn the journals into a flourishing Web phenomenon.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Mayor's Thankless Job
description: What Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants, he usually gets. He wanted control of the schools and he got it. He wanted a ban on smoking in public buildings. Done. Now he has won help from lawmakers in Albany to close the city's $3.8 billion budget shortfall. It was an amazing feat, accomplished with Mr. Bloomberg's trademark cool reserve and unflagging confidence. The cheers from New Yorkers are deafening. No, wait. That's whining you hear -- over higher taxes and fees, layoffs, increased transit fares, rising rents and even the slow start by the Mets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about fund-raising campaigns for Stuyvesant High School misstated the date of a fund-raiser for Convent of the Sacred Heart, a private school in Manhattan where one parent raising money for Stuyvesant has another child, and misstated the amount raised at the event. It was held Friday, not Saturday; it raised $470,000, not $250,000. The article also misstated the middle initial of the executive director of the Campaign for Stuyvesant. He is Neal H. Hurwitz, not M.

title: No Politician? The Polls Agree With the Mayor
description: The prevailing political theory at City Hall goes something like this: Politics do not matter. If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg remains true to his convictions, resists the taint of special interest groups and makes tough choices that keep the city sound, New Yorkers will appreciate and reward him.

title: MIDWAY GAMES HIRES CHIEF EXECUTIVE FROM PLAYBOY
description: Midway Games Inc., maker of the Mortal Kombat video games, said yesterday that it had replaced its chief executive, Neil D. Nicastro, with a media industry executive after reporting losses for more than three years. The shares rose as much as 16 percent. Midway said it had hired David F. Zucker, president and chief operating officer of Playboy Enterprises Inc. for the last year and an 11-year veteran of the Walt Disney Company, as president and chief executive. Mr. Nicastro, who also stepped down as chief operating officer, will remain chairman of Midway. The company's sales dwindled as home video game consoles hurt demand for arcade games, the source of more than half the company's sales three years ago. Midway, which is based in Chicago, sold the arcade business in 2001 to focus on games that can be played on home machines.

title: E.P.A. Drops Age-Based Cost Studies
description: A Bush administration policy to base some regulations on a calculation that the life of each person older than 70 should be valued less than the life of a younger person has antagonized older Americans and environmental groups, and it has stirred tensions among federal agencies.

title: Role Reversal; Volunteers Set the Grading Curve for Report Cards on Teachers
description: CAN students benefit from knowing that a teacher spits while speaking?

title: Balls, Strikes and Videotape
description: JOE SCAROLA is not one of the big names with the New York Mets. His name is never in lights. There is no Joe Scarola fan club. Many reporters who cover the team have no idea he exists.

title: Jordan Surprised and Inflamed As Wizards Show Him the Door
description: During a curt, five-minute exchange yesterday that ended with Michael Jordan making a futile case for his job, Abe Pollin, the Washington Wizards' owner, told Jordan, the man recognized as the world's greatest basketball player, that his services were no longer needed.

title: White House Celebrity (No, Not That One) Takes to the Stump
description: He stepped out of his car this morning to the flash of cameras and a scrum of television crews. Inside the Bedford Village Inn, 300 New Hampshire business and political leaders had waited nearly an hour to hear his thoughts at the forum known as ''Politics and Eggs.''

title: Given Up, A Dream Returns To Life
description: Lauren Christy clearly recalls the day she decided to give up her dream of being a pop star. The year was 1999, and she was flying back to Los Angeles from London, where she had met a talent scout who was interested in signing her. Afterward the scout called her manager, Sandy Roberton, and said he wasn't interested. ''But,'' he asked Mr. Roberton, ''can I have a song of hers to use for Natalie Imbruglia's next single?''

title: The Whale Arches Its Back Again, For Visitors Arching Their Necks
description: The blue whale sculpture will be back on May 17, this time with less bulging eyes, when the renovated and newly renamed Milstein Family Hall of Ocean Life opens at the American Museum of Natural History, after being shut since January 2002. ''The trend of exhibition design in the late 60's was to block out light and to create a mysterious, dark environment,'' said David Harvey, vice president for exhibition. The hall, which was painted black in 1969, is now off-white, with blue and white lights that create an underwater feel. Eight new displays of marine habitats, like the polar seas, are on the mezzanine. The museum is at Central Park West and 79th Street. Information: (212) 769-5100. Admission: $12 for adults, $7 for children.

title: Open Season on Open Houses
description: DIANE GROVER has a way of using the word ''festive'' that makes you want to duck.

title: U.S. Suspects North Korea Moved Ahead On Weapons
description: After assuring the White House for months that North Korea had not begun producing plutonium for nuclear weapons, American intelligence officials changed their assessment last month, concluding that the country may have produced relatively small amounts, according to senior administration and intelligence officials.

title: Recarve a Hard Drive Without Losing Data
description: Q. I receive messages that say I have run out of disk space when in fact I have space -- not in the C drive, but in the D, E or F drives. I would like to unpartition the hard drive. Would that require reformatting it? Is there a less cumbersome alternative?

title: Another Masterwork En Route to Las Vegas
description: One man may not make an entire art market, but he certainly can help.

title: McCarthy's Tactics, Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICHMANN, EVELYN
description: TEICHMANN-Evelyn. Died May 6, 2003 at age 86 in New York City. Born October 20, 1916 in Columbus, OH. Beloved wife and collaborator of the late Howard M. Teichmann. Loving mother of Judith T. Steckler. Adoring grandmother of David and Lynn. Ev and Tyke will be together for eternity now. The family would appreciate donations in Evelyn's memory to The Fund for Park Avenue, 110 E. 42 St., Suite 1300, New York, NY 10017.

title: Olympics' Ethics Panel Proposes Disbanding of Iraqi Committee
description: The International Olympic Committee's ethics commission called yesterday for the dissolution of Iraq's Olympic Committee, which Iraqi athletes have accused of employing torture.

title: Dieters, It's the Carbs That Count!
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Orders France to Cut Budget Deficit by End of Year
description: The European Commission today ordered France to cut its budget deficit by the end of the year to the level allowed under the ''stability and growth'' agreement underpinning the euro currency.

title: Reeling In Files From Your PC's Murky Depths
description: INTERNET search engines can lead you through a vast universe of data to the information you need on the Web. But there is also an ever growing pile of information on your own hard drive: e-mail messages, attachments, word-processing documents, spreadsheets and so on. Where can you turn when you need a search engine for your PC?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DANIEL G., MD.
description: MILLER-Daniel G., MD. On May 7, 2003. Pioneer in cancer research, Emeritus Professor of Medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University, Past President of Strang Cancer Prevention Center and formerly Chief of the Lymphoma Clinic at Memorial Hospital. Beloved husband of Helene for 49 years. Devoted father of Valerie of Ardmore, PA, Faith of Rye, NY, Theodore of Mamaroneck, NY, Noah of New York City. Cherished grandfather of nine. Adored brother of Shirley Cherches of Port Jefferson, LI, and loving uncle to Eric and Gary. Services Friday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Opposition Groups Work to Complete Assembly Plan
description: With raucous new political movements sprouting across the country, Iraq's organized opposition parties rushed to complete a plan today for an interim assembly that would satisfy the increasingly insistent public demand for a working government.

title: Two Militants And a Child Are Killed In Middle East
description: Two Hamas militants were killed today, one when a bomb exploded inside his West Bank apartment under disputed circumstances. And a 1 1/2-year-old Palestinian boy was fatally shot by the Israeli Army in the Gaza Strip, Palestinians said.

title: Finding a Cure for the Bad-Guest Blues
description: I WOULD like to make it clear for the record that the chocolate jellyroll incident was not my fault.

title: Bullpen Weakness Bothers Torre More Than Errors Do
description: SEATTLE, May 7 - Joe Torre was not really bothered by the Yankees' three errors in an unsightly 12-7 loss to the Seattle Mariners at Safeco Field on Tuesday night. Errors will happen, Torre knows, and besides, two were by Todd Zeile, the reserve third baseman, and the other was by shortstop Erick Almonte, who will probably be back in the minors next week.

title: Zimbabwe at the Breaking Point
description: Zimbabwe, once a shining star in southern Africa, is collapsing under the disastrous rule of Robert Mugabe. This week, a powerful troika of African presidents from South Africa, Nigeria and Malawi traveled to Harare, raising hopes that they were finally prepared to do something about the political and economic crisis in Zimbabwe. Unhappily, their visit failed to persuade Mr. Mugabe to open unconditional talks with the opposition.

title: Internet Access for the Cost of a Cup of Coffee
description: AS the Wi-Fi trend sweeps through the air, one question appears to be cropping up with increasing frequency: to charge or not to charge?

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Crude oil rallied after an Energy Department report showed an unexpected decline in inventories. In New York, crude oil for June delivery rose 51 cents, or 2 percent, to $26.23 a barrel.

title: Where to Go To See the Shows
description: For a first-hand look:

title: Quartets Inspired By a Poem And a Story
description: The Emerson String Quartet is about to begin a series of master classes at Carnegie Hall. But before ceding the spotlight to the young ensembles it will coach, the group spent Sunday evening on the Carnegie stage, offering a concert of its own. Or mostly its own.

title: SUNRISE TO SELL 44 NURSING HOMES FOR $564 MILLION
description: Sunrise Assisted Living Inc., an operator of housing for the elderly, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 44 of its properties for $564 million, allowing it to lower debt and raise cash to buy back shares. The transaction includes the sale of Sunrise's 90 percent stake in 28 assisted-living centers for $345 million to a real estate investment banking firm, Macquarie Capital Partners. Macquarie will also buy a 90 percent stake in 16 additional centers from another owner for $219 million, a Sunrise senior vice president, Charles Post, said. Sunrise will retain a 10 percent stake in all the centers and manage them under long-term contracts.

title: Top Evangelicals Critical Of Colleagues Over Islam
description: Evangelical leaders meeting here today denounced as ''dangerous'' and ''unhelpful'' the anti-Islam remarks made in the last year by leaders in their own movement and proposed new guidelines for churches to follow in relating to Muslims.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Longtime Inmate Executed
description: The nation's longest-serving death-row inmate, Carl Isaacs, 49, was executed by lethal injection at a state prison in Jackson, where he had spent the last 23 years. Mr. Isaacs was sentenced to death in 1974 for taking part in the murders of six members of a family on their Seminole County farm. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: The Zen of Tornado Survival
description: Tornadoes lashed the Midwest and South this week, killing 18 in my state and more than a score elsewhere. But in spite of all the horror -- and it is horrible -- there's a calm in this storm that you can't see in the newspaper and television pictures of sudden powerful destruction. People continue to shop, they make mad dashes to the store, cover their flowers, phone friends. It's a paradox: take cover, but first cover what you can.

title: Even Dodgers' Offense Makes Mets Look Weak
description: The Mets have laughed off the controversy surrounding Rey Sanchez's alleged haircut during a blowout loss last week. The supposed transgression may have been a sign of worsening problems off the field; the Mets still have plenty of problems on it.

title: Hussein Loyalists Rise Again, Enraging Iraqis
description: Hundreds of Iraqi doctors, nurses and health workers demonstrated today against a decision by the American authorities here to appoint Ali al-Janabi, a senior Baath Party member, to be minister of health.

title: For Tower Residents, a New Math
description: EXCITED about his purchase of a $2 million, 67th-floor apartment at the AOL Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle, the buyer decided to sit in Central Park on a spring afternoon and count the floors. ''It was presented as an 80-story building,'' said the homeowner, a marketing executive for an international company, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''I kept counting and coming up with 69 floors. If I'm right, I'm 13 floors lower. I'd be on 56. That's terribly disappointing.''

title: Former Pediatrician Arrested On New Pedophilia Charges
description: A former Brooklyn pediatrician who lost his medical license after a pedophilia conviction 20 years ago faced new charges yesterday for participating in what prosecutors called an international sex ring involving young boys.

title: Market Place; Prosecutors reconsider a former stockbroker's bail -- for his own good, they say.
description: FEDERAL prosecutors are considering revoking the bail of a former stockbroker who helped them with a sprawling investigation into organized crime on Wall Street because they fear for his safety, according to people involved in the case.

title: How the Other Half Gardens
description: THE hill behind Peggy and Walter Jones's house in Englewood, N.J., should be a cloud of pink and white rhododendrons by May 18, when they open their garden to the public as one of 400 private gardens in the Garden Conservancy's Open Days program this year. Subtle pleasures are to be had there, like the swamp azalea, with its delicate pink blossom, that seeded itself in the damp swale at the bottom of a wooded slope. In this moist, humusy soil, enriched by years of leaf mulch, the primroses are so happy they are self-seeding among the ferns and moving right into the lawn.

title: A Shift In Cultures Upends A Dynasty
description: ''Last of the Suns,'' Alice Tuan's play about a Chinese family in America, ambitiously juggles issues of assimilation, coming of age and the role of women. At its center is the assertion that the act of leaving one culture behind and settling in another is a violent change with warping emotional consequences. And though Ms. Tuan has depicted a full network of relationships here, her focus is clearly on the women, who are not merely unhappy; they are harmfully twisted.

title: 4 California Fires Are Called Hate Crimes
description: Officials today classified as hate crimes suspicious fires in churches and synagogues in the San Fernando Valley and outlined efforts to solve them.

title: Who's the Leader of the Club? The Face on Your Screen Menu
description: Hoping to capitalize on the perennial childhood fascination with its characters and their stories, Disney introduced six consumer electronics products yesterday for children 6 to 12.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Qantas Cuts Outlook
description: The Australian airline Qantas cut its profit outlook for the second time in six weeks as a result of the impact of severe acute respiratory syndrome on travel. The airline did not provide a specific figure, but it said that SARS had affected all areas of the airline. ''The outbreak of SARS, which was entirely unexpected, has compounded the difficulties facing our industry, particularly in this region,'' Geoff Dixon, the chief executive, said in a statement. As a result, the airline said it would make further staff reductions and defer delivery of new aircraft.

title: If a Palestinian Visits
description: To the Editor:

title: School Plan Faces a New Legal Challenge
description: Assemblyman Steven Sanders and the union that represents school principals said yesterday that they were seeking to join a lawsuit to block the centerpiece of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's reorganization of the New York City school system.

title: DVD Release Tests Format By Microsoft
description: YET another video release of ''Terminator 2: Judgment Day'' (1991) would not seem notable, even on DVD. But for Microsoft, the new version amounts to the first test of a concept.

title: Dieters, It's the Carbs That Count!
description: To the Editor:

title: Writers Sign Statement Denouncing Basque Nationalist Violence
description: More than a dozen prominent writers, including the Nobel laureates Nadine Gordimer and Gnter Grass, have signed a strongly worded attack on Basque nationalist violence, which they say condemns citizens of the Basque region to live in fear.

title: Electronic Data Systems Posts a Loss
description: Electronic Data Systems, the seller of computer services that has been plagued in recent months by a management overhaul, accounting questions and a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation, reported yesterday that it had swung to a loss in the first quarter.

title: Rift in India Leads M.I.T. To Abandon A Media Lab
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has pulled out of Media Lab Asia, citing disagreements with Arun Shourie, the new Indian minister of information, over the focus and management of the organization's research projects.

title: Unpacking Harlem History
description: WHEN the movers arrived at her house in Alexandria, Va., in February, A'Lelia Bundles says she begged them to be ''extra, extra careful'' with the tall Queen Anne-style desk in the foyer.

title: A Hit Single for $1
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Line Vote Sends Disputed Bush Nomination to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Senate Judiciary Committee voted along straight party lines today to send to the full Senate one of President Bush's nominees to a federal appeals court, but one of the Republicans whose vote provided the majority said he was still unsure if he would vote for her confirmation.

title: Free Fall in Iraq
description: Lines at the gasoline pump in Iraq now last up to three days. Electricity, needed for water and refrigeration units, flickers on and off. Uncollected garbage rots in the hot streets. An outbreak of cholera was reported yesterday in Basra. Cases of diarrhea in young children are also increasing. Hospitals looted of drugs and diagnostic equipment limp along. Few Iraqis are feeling nostalgic for the sadistic terror of Saddam Hussein. But in the bad old days, basic services were more dependable.

title: CLOROX SELLS BLACK FLAG AND ROACH MOTEL BRANDS
description: The Clorox Company said yesterday that it had sold its Black Flag insecticide and Roach Motel bait-trap brands to the closely held Fountainhead Group for an undisclosed price as part of a plan to shed smaller businesses. The product lines generated less than 1 percent of Clorox's $4.06 billion in sales last year, said a spokeswoman, Kathryn Caulfield. Its largest brands include Clorox bleach and Glad bags.

title: 2 Big Hospital Buying Groups Settle Lawsuit by Needle Maker
description: A small Texas company settled a federal antitrust lawsuit yesterday that accused the nation's two dominant hospital buying groups, Premier and Novation, of preventing the sale of its hypodermic needles to many hospitals.

title: CNN Anchor Backs Out Of Video Deal
description: CNN said yesterday that Aaron Brown, its nighttime news anchor, would not go forward with plans to become host of a series of corporate-sponsored videos that look like news and are broadcast on public television stations.

title: $50 Million Award in a Gun Liability Case
description: A jury here today awarded $50.9 million in compensatory damages in an accidental shooting for which a California gun maker, its designer and its main distributor had been found partly liable.

title: Metro Matters; Water Plant With a Spoon Of Honey
description: AFTER the Albany budget wars will come the legislative skirmishes, and one of the more urgent is the matter of a filtration plant that City Hall wants to build under the Mosholu golf course in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: The Word of God, Written by Committee
description: GOD'S SECRETARIES

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing's March Loss Narrowed
description: Global Crossing, the bankrupt network operator that is selling a majority stake to Singapore Technologies Telemedia, said yesterday that its March loss narrowed to $89 million as sales increased 4 percent. The net loss narrowed from $142 million in February, Global Crossing said. Sales rose to $231 million from $222 million. The year-earlier net loss of $171 million and sales of $281 million includes a stake in Asia Global Crossing, which has since been sold.

title: World Business Briefing: Australia
description: AUSTRALIA: INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED The Reserve Bank left its benchmark interest rate at 4.75 percent for an 11th straight month. Economists had expected the action at the bank's monthly meeting because the domestic economy is strong but the global economy is unsteady. The country's growth rate of 3 percent is the strongest among developed countries and its currency is at a three-year high against the United States dollar. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Claritin's Price Falls, but Drug Costs More
description: As allergy season peaks across much of the country, millions of Americans are paying much more for the medicines they rely on to keep symptoms at bay.

title: Spurs Have the Lakers Looking Vulnerable
description: The Los Angeles Lakers' run of three straight N.B.A. championships and Coach Phil Jackson's streak of 25 straight victorious playoff series have officially entered the danger zone.

title: Lincoln Center Proceeds, Modestly
description: When it was first announced in 1999, Lincoln Center's redevelopment was to cost $1.5 billion over 10 years and radically transform the campus. The architect Frank Gehry devised a glass atrium over the fountain plaza. There was talk of a new home for the New York City Opera in Damrosch Park.

title: A Building and Its Residents, No Longer Down on Their Luck
description: A derelict building in Chelsea has been turned into 18 studio apartments for 4 people with low incomes and 14 who were homeless. The building, Chelsea Court (top left), has gleaming maple cabinets and floors, sofa beds with Maharam fabric and a terrace with Philippe Starck's Bubble two-seaters and tables (top right).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the election of a record number of women to the National Academy of Sciences misspelled the surname of the woman chosen by Dr. Shirley Tilghman, president of Princeton, to be provost. (The error also occurred in an editorial on Sept. 4, 2001.) The provost is Amy Gutmann, not Guttman.

title: Spirits Account Awarded to Publicis
description: Allied Domecq said yesterday that it had consolidated the worldwide creative duties on its spirits accounts with the London office of Publicis Worldwide, assigning it duties for brands that had been handled by units of the Cordiant Communications Group in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOEL, MARTIN J. JR.
description: JOEL-Martin J. Jr. Beloved husband of Sylvia Joel and the late Dolores Joel. Died May 6 at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Loving father of Patricia (Howard Samuels) and Amy Joel, devoted grandfather of Dara and Andrew, caring brother of Alyse Klufer (Robert). Funeral services Sunday, May 11, at 10 AM at Ballard Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DICKSON, KATHRYN
description: DICKSON-Kathryn (May 8, 1997). Loving wife of Frazier Dickson, beloved friend of many. We miss you

title: China Releases 400 College Students From SARS Quarantine
description: BEIJING, May 8  With the giddy joy of a graduation party, some 400 students, teachers and workers emerged from two weeks' quarantine at a university in central Beijing today, providing some of the first cheerful television images from the SARS epidemic.

title: In Showdown of Japanese, Matsui Wins This Round
description: At Safeco Field, fans can commemorate this series by purchasing an officially licensed, $24 T-shirt with the words ''Showdown In Seattle'' printed on the chest. Images of Hideki Matsui and Ichiro Suzuki also cover the shirt, with ''Ichiro vs. Matsui'' in smaller type.

title: At 10,000 Feet, Can a Fire-Spotting Camera Discriminate?
description: WHEN it comes to fighting forest fires, time is more than money. It's acreage as well.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: First Black Supreme Court Judge
description: President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva nominated Joaquim Benedito Barbosa, an Afro-Brazilian federal prosecutor, to the Supreme Court to replace a justice who retired because of age. It would be the first time that the court has had a black justice. Almost half of Brazil's 175 million people define themselves as black. Mery Galanternick (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, JIMAN H.
description: DUNCAN - Jiman H., 58, teacher, coach, singer, minister of music and theatrical director died on April 16 in Dover-Foxcroft, Maine, after a lengthy illness. Mr. Duncan had been a teacher at the Buckley School in New York City and the Minister of Music at Grace Episcopal Church in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. He also taught at the Belmont Hill School in Belmont, Massachusetts, prior to moving to Manhattan. Born in Melrose, Massachusetts, to the Reverend James R. and Faith S. Duncan on April 27, 1944, Mr. Duncan graduated from Mount Hermon School, then received a B.A. degree from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Master's in Music Education from Boston University, Master's in Vocal Performance from George Washington University, St. Louis, Missouri, and a Master's of Divinity from the Berkeley Divinity School of Yale, New Haven, Connecticut. Mr. Duncan's baritone voice training was received from his mentor and close friend, Dr. Doric J. Alviani, formerly of Amherst, Massachusetts. His teaching career spanned many years and led Mr. Duncan to private schools in Deerfield, Massachusetts, St. Louis, Missouri, Belmont, Massachusetts, and Manhattan. He was also an organist choir master in churches in western Massachusetts, Boston and New York. He is survived by his wife, Dawn D. Duncan, and daughters, Sarajane Richter of Medway, MA, and Katherine, Mary Faith and Hannah at home. He leaves brothers, Justin of Bernardston, MA, Judson of Monmouth, ME, and Jeremy of Clayville, NY, and two grandchildren. Services will be private and at the convenience of the family. Memorial contributions may be made to the Bangor Savings Bank of Hartland, Maine, for an educational trust benefitting the daughters of Jiman H. Duncan or to the Lance Armstrong Foundation at www.laf.org.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Donation To Finance Demolitions
description: A Detroit man who made his fortune paving the area's roads will give the city $10 million to raze hundreds of forsaken buildings. The man, Robert Thompson, founder of the Thomas-McCully Company, will pay for up to 1,400 demolitions. Mr. Thompson built his asphalt paving company on hundreds of millions of dollars in state contracts. After selling the company for $422 million in 1999, he created a $100 million fund to help restore Detroit. Anand Giridharadas (NYT)

title: For Whom the Bell Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Fined For Long-Distance Violation
description: Qwest Communications, the No. 4 local telephone company in the country, was fined $6.5 million yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. The fine was for selling long-distance calling without permission. Qwest sold long-distance service before regulators cleared it to do so in some of the 14 Western states where it dominates local calling, the F.C.C. said. Qwest agreed to the fine as part of a settlement. The fine exceeds a $6 million penalty the F.C.C. gave to SBC Communications in October for denying competitors access to its phone network, an F.C.C. spokesman, David Fiske, said. Regional phone companies like Qwest must prove that their local phone networks are open to rivals before they can sell long-distance. Qwest has done so in 12 states and awaits a ruling on Minnesota next month. Shares of Qwest fell 32 cents, or 7.2 percent, to $4.11. They have dropped from a high of $66 in March 2000.

title: A Special Court for Gun Crimes Is Created Just for Five Neighborhoods in Central Brooklyn
description: In an unusual new effort aimed at reducing gun violence, the city has established a special court in Brooklyn to handle all felony gun possession cases from the five Brooklyn neighborhoods with the heaviest concentration of shootings in the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.

title: Newer, Smaller, Faster, And Not in Stores Now
description: ONE of the hottest gadgets in Japan these days is a set of clip-on headphones with enough memory in just one tiny earpiece for an hour's worth of downloaded music.

title: Scott Is Still Fuming Over Writer's Remark
description: Byron Scott, who has been prone to outbursts in his three seasons as the Nets' coach, said this morning that he did not regret calling for the Boston Globe columnist Bob Ryan to be fired for his remarks about Joumana Kidd.

title: Tribe and Pataki Near Deal on Land and Casino
description: After two decades of impasse, Gov. George E. Pataki is close to reaching an agreement with the St. Regis Mohawk tribe that would settle a longstanding land-claim lawsuit against the state. And, if the federal government ratifies the deal, it would allow the tribe to open a casino in the Catskills.

title: W.H.O. Doubles Its Estimate Of Death Rate From SARS
description: Analyzing what it said was more complete data, the World Health Organization said yesterday that the estimated overall death rate from SARS was about 15 percent -- double its previous estimate.

title: Selling the War: Disturbing Patterns (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Getaway Trucks
description: The night after President Bush gave him 48 hours to surrender, Saddam Hussein sent his son Qusay to the vault of Iraq's Central Bank to make a modest withdrawal for the family's departure.

title: Most Taiwan SARS Cases Spread by One Misdiagnosis
description: Most of Taiwan's SARS cases can be traced to one hospitalized man whose lung ailment was misdiagnosed for five days, the head of Taiwan's Center for Disease Control said today.

title: After 50 Years, a Sculptural Look Evolves From Metal to Porcelain
description: For 50 years, Namb's sculptural bowls, vases and platters have been made of a metal alloy that resembles pewter. This spring, just in time for wedding presents, Namb is introducing works in white porcelain by the designers Eva Zeisel, Karim Rashid and Fred Bould. Aurora vases by Mr. Bould are $100 and $145 (inset below). Other pieces are $75 to $200.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Indicted on More Serious Charges in Spy Case
description: A former F.B.I. supervisor in Los Angeles was indicted today on new and more serious charges of letting an informant steal classified information that she passed on to China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELTMAN, ALEXANDER
description: ELTMAN - Alexander. Be loved husband of the late Gertrude, adored father of Harriet and Mort Chwatsky, Lois Eltman and George and Karen Eltman. Treasured grandfather of Amy and Rob Feinblatt, Lynn & Jory Siegel and Clara Eltman, delighted great grandfather of Carly and Rachel Feinblatt. Services Thursday at 10AM, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Runoff For Mayor Of Denver
description: A brew pub owner and a veteran politician will compete in a runoff election for mayor of Denver on June 3 after no single candidate won more than 50 percent of the vote in balloting on Tuesday. The pub owner, John Hickenlooper, left, a 51-year old political newcomer, won 43 percent of the vote in a field of seven nonpartisan candidates. Don Mares, 46, city auditor since 1995, received 22 percent of the vote. Mayor Wellington Webb cannot seek a fourth term because of term limits. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Religious-Charities Bill Stumbles in House
description: A top Republican signaled today that the House was effectively abandoning President Bush's drive to expand religious organizations' ability to receive federal money for social services.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Yamaha's Profit Rises
description: The motorcycle maker Yamaha Motor Company said profit nearly tripled in the year ended March 31, helped by cost-cutting measures and by strong sales in the United States. The company said it earned 25.6 billion yen ($218 million), 168 percent more than a year earlier. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Selling the War: Disturbing Patterns
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says It Has Recovered Hundreds of Artifacts and Thousands of Manuscripts in Iraq
description: Teams of American investigators searching in Iraq have recovered more than 700 artifacts and tens of thousands of ancient manuscripts that had been missing from the collection of the National Museum in Baghdad, some of them stored in underground vaults before the American invasion, American officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Rises
description: German unemployment figures continued to rise in April as generally expected, even if the increase was slower than in the previous months. In seasonally adjusted terms, the number of unemployed rose 44,000, to 4.46 million, resulting in a jobless rate of 10.7 percent, up one-tenth of a percentage point from March. The Federal Labor Office said the labor market could not be expected to recover soon due to structural problems and weak economic growth. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Earnings Decline at Pixar
description: Pixar Animation Studios said yesterday that first-quarter profit declined 48 percent because it did not have a new film playing.

title: As Blossoms Open, So Do the Gates
description: TO see the gardens in the Open Days program, one must show up not only at the right place but also on the right day, bearing $5 a garden.

title: Philanthropy Her Own Way; As BET Co-Founder Reshapes Her Life, Serendipity Sneaks In
description: She does not have the name recognition of a Brooke Astor or a Sanford I. Weill. But Sheila C. Johnson has been making a philanthropic mark in the elite horse country of Virginia, where she lives; in Washington, where she lived for many years; and, most recently, in New York, which she visits about twice a month.

title: Suit Says ChevronTexaco Dumped Poisons in Ecuador
description: A group of American lawyers representing more than 30,000 indigenous people in Ecuador filed a $1 billion lawsuit against the ChevronTexaco Corporation yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about the opening-night party for the film ''The Blue Car'' supplied attribution erroneously for a characterization of the look given to Marty Richards, the Academy Award-winning producer of ''Chicago,'' by Agnes Bruckner, a star of the movie. The comment -- ''I can sing and dance as well as Rene Zellweger'' -- was intended as a Times reporter's interpretation of Ms. Bruckner's expression; she did not actually use the words.

title: Nets Stay Focused and Maintain Their Edge
description: Without looking ahead or behind or even glancing at the off-court issues gusting around them, the Nets channeled their energy tonight into a tunnel that left no room for the Boston Celtics.

title: GOODYEAR CHIEF TO TAKE OVER ROLE OF CHAIRMAN
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that Samir G. Gibara will resign as chairman on June 30 and be succeeded by the chief executive, Robert J. Keegan. Mr. Gibara, who has been with Goodyear since 1964, became chairman and chief executive in July 1996. He was succeeded in the position of chief executive by Mr. Keegan, 55, in January. Goodyear, the tire maker, has cut 1,600 jobs since September after reporting losses totaling $1.31 billion in the last two years. Mr. Gibara gave up the position of chief executive after his 1999 plan to make tires with a Japanese partner backfired and doubled the company's long-term debt. Mr. Keegan, a former executive of the Eastman Kodak Company, joined Goodyear in 2000.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline yesterday about George Kozmetsky, co-founder of the Teledyne conglomerate, misstated his age. He was 85, not 89.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: GUATEMALA: MAYOR ARRESTED IN POLITICAL KILLING The mayor of San Cristóbal Verapaz, in central Guatemala, was arrested on charges that he shot and killed an opposition campaign worker who had been painting his party's logo on a roadside, the police said. They said the mayor, Hugo Cal, a member of the ruling Guatemalan Republican Front, shot the campaign worker, Byron Mo, 20, of the Unionist Party, on a rural highway after accusing him of painting over Republican Front logos. "This looks like the start of a very violent election campaign," the Unionist Party deputy, Álvaro Rodas, said.    (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Slips
description: France's largest bank, BNP Paribas, reported a decline of 0.7 percent in operating income in the first quarter, with strong revenue from its retail and investment banking divisions almost offsetting losses in asset management. Net income was 962 million euros ($1.1 billion), down 5.6 percent from 1.02 billion euros ($1.17 billion) last year, but beating forecasts for a steeper drop. Michel Pebereau, the chairman of BNP Paribas, attributed losses in the asset management division to a volatile stock market. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Vaughn Indicates Surgery Is Likely
description: As the Mets continued to take a lighthearted approach to what has developed as the clubhouse haircut issue, a far more serious development was unfolding in their clubhouse. Mo Vaughn stood by his locker at Shea Stadium yesterday and indicated that he was likely to have surgery on his deteriorating left knee.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: SK's Rating Cut
description: Standard & Poor's, citing increasing pressure on the SK Corporation to rescue SK Global, the group's scandal-ridden trading firm, cut the credit rating on SK Corporation to the junk-bond level of BB plus. The rating agency noted that SK Global's creditor banks insist that major SK companies support SK Global. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: China Releases 400 College Students from SARS Quarantine
description: BEIJING, May 8  With the giddy joy of a graduation party, some 400 students, teachers and workers emerged from two weeks' quarantine at a university in central Beijing today, providing some of the first cheerful television images from the SARS epidemic.

title: Sports of The Times; The Arena Is Where Fans Vent Their Rage
description: FEELING a little dirty? There is an outlet for your dark side, a place where the wattage is revved up, where the beer taps pour like loose slots and the music has the pulse rate of a flamenco dancer.

title: A Shuffle in the British Water Industry
description: Once again, Britain's 10 big water utilities are figuring in a flurry of deals and deal talk. Two of them have changed hands in the last year or so and three more are in play.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB MAY DELAY REQUEST FOR IMPLANT APPROVAL
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it might delay seeking approval for an eye implant to treat a diabetes-related vision problem by as much as three years. The Food and Drug Administration wants more information about the safety of the implant, Retisert, in patients with macular edema, which causes fluid to accumulate in the eye, resulting in blurred vision, Bausch & Lomb said. The company's shares fell 7.8 percent, to $33.11. A 12-month clinical trial involving 80 patients showed that the implant reduced or eliminated retinal thickness in 49 percent of patients. But more than half the patients also experienced serious side effects, the company said.

title: Trouble In Bush's America
description: While our ''What, me worry?'' president is having a great time with his high approval ratings and his ''Top Gun'' fantasies, the economy remains in the tank. And the finances of state and local governments are sinking tragically into ever deeper and ever more unforgiving waters.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Disclosure Ruling In Homicide Is Stayed
description: The Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court ruled yesterday that news organizations had a First Amendment right to publish and broadcast the name of a 10-year-old Woodbridge boy accused of killing a 3-year-old in March, but the decision was immediately stayed after the suspect's lawyers said they would appeal to the State Supreme Court. The state public defender's office, which is representing the boy, asked the appeals court to stay the decision, and the court then ruled that the boy's name could not be made public until the higher court ruled. Earlier in the day, the appeals court ruled that the media could disclose the name of the boy accused of sexually assaulting and killing the 3-year-old, Amir Beeks, also of Woodbridge. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Fighting for the Arts and Yearning for a Spiritual Life
description: ST. PAUL had the road to Damascus. Regena L. Thomas had the Underground Railroad. Both found the same thing on the way: a calling. And when Ms. Thomas, New Jersey's exuberant secretary of state, finished retracing 180 miles along the route through her state last September, she enrolled in a seminary to become a minister.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Colonel Freed In Activist's Death
description: Human rights groups condemned a decision of an appeals court judge to free a former colonel who had been sentenced to 30 years in jail for ordering the 1990 stabbing murder of Myrna Mack, a 39-year-old anthropologist who was investigating military mistreatment of the rural population. Col. Juan Valencia Osorio, a former commander of Guatemala's presidential guard, was freed because of ''contradictions'' in his trial last year, the judge said. Ms. Mack's relatives plan to appeal. Rights advocates lamented the verdict as a setback for justice in Guatemala, where lawyers, activists and others have been the targets of a relentless campaign of death threats and harassment. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Sentenced In Parents' Deaths
description: A judge refused a woman's request yesterday to withdraw her guilty plea in her parents' murder, and sentenced her to 30 years to life in prison. The woman, Connie Leung, who was 17 at the time of the murders in November 2000, and her boyfriend, Eric Louissaint, 20 at the time, pleaded guilty to strangling her parents in their East Harlem apartment and dumping their bodies in the East River. Yesterday, Ms. Leung said that her plea was involuntary because of a ''weakened psychological state.'' But Justice Charles J. Tejada of State Supreme Court said that Ms. Leung had not only accepted the plea but had also admitted her participation in the killings of her parents, Stephen Leung, 55, and Chilin Leung, 41, above. The authorities said the Leungs were killed because they disapproved of their daughter's relationship with Mr. Louissaint, who is black. He is serving two consecutive terms of 15 years to life. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Boy, 10, Killed By Car
description: A Bronx man was arrested and charged with drunk driving after his car struck and killed a 10-year-old boy last night, the police said. Luis Carasquillo, 59, of Hoe Avenue, was driving on that street in Longwood about 9 p.m. when he hit the boy, who was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, officers said. The boy, whose name was not released, was pronounced dead at 9:30 p.m. Mr. Carasquillo was arrested at the scene, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: A Phone for Crime-Stoppers That Is Always at Hand
description: Many are those who have fished in pocket or purse for a ringing cellphone but failed to find it in time. DoCoMo, the big Japanese mobile phone provider, has addressed that issue with a wristwatch that doubles as a cellphone, like the one Dick Tracy wore in the comics.

title: Ahold Says It Overstated Earnings by More than $880 Million
description: NIJMEGEN, The Netherlands, May 8  The food retailer Royal Ahold said today that the suspected fraud at its U.S. Foodservice division was much more extensive than previously thought.

title: Walker's Woeful Shooting Continues
description: The defenders had cleared out to other spots. Kenyon Martin went to challenge a layup by Boston's Eric Williams, leaving the Celtics' Antoine Walker alone to grab the rebound and score on an easy put-back.

title: Hensons Buying Back the Muppets for $89 Million
description: From their balcony seats, even the irascible Statler and Waldorf characters might like this news.

title: Selling the War: Disturbing Patterns
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: From the Cradle

title: Marie-Claude Lalique, 67, Scion Of the Glass and Crystal Family
description: Marie-Claude Lalique, keeper of the Lalique family tradition in glass and crystal artistry until her retirement in 1994, died on April 14 on Captiva Island, Fla. She was 67 and lived on Captiva and in Provence.

title: An Age-Based Value On a Life Stirs Anger
description: A Bush administration policy to base some regulations on a calculation that the life of an elderly person should be valued less than the life of a younger person has antagonized older Americans. Instead of assuming that all lives saved from cleaner air are of equal value, two administration studies put the value of the life of a person under 70 at $3.7 million and the life of an older person at $2.3 million.

title: AFTEREFFECTS: THE OVERSEER -- Man in the News; At the Helm in Shattered Iraq: Lewis Paul Bremer III
description: It should not have been lost on anyone that President Bush introduced his new special envoy to Iraq, Lewis Paul Bremer III, this week as a ''can do'' person who ''goes with the full blessings of this administration.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, JEANETTE
description: STEINER - Jeanette. Died May 5, 2003 in Jerusalem, Israel after a long illness. Beloved wife of Dr. Alexander Steiner. Devoted mother to Hagai and step-mother to Dan, Nava and Miriam. Loving grandmother to Bar and Shir. Cherished sister of Alice Geisler and aunt of Robert Geisler. She was a very talented artist and a loyal friend. She will be greatly missed.

title: Cockroaches as Shadow and Metaphor; An Artist Began Chilling and Decorating Bugs, But Moved On to Depicting Their Executions
description: Catherine Chalmers's SoHo apartment is alive with the sound of imminent death. Crickets, food for a rubbery green tree frog, chirp loudly. The frog sits in a terrarium, a big grin on its face. What's not to smile about? Plenty of other food, a horde of crawling mealworms, is nearby.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUGH, CLARENCE S.
description: PUGH-Clarence S. Playbill mourns the loss of its esteemed colleague and valued friend of over 40 years, Clarence S. Pugh, who began working for the company in February 1961 and retired last year. Mr. Pugh died May 5, 2003 age 63, and is survived by his wife, Mildred; his children, Diane, Bernard, Bertha, Renee, Tyrone and Cynthia; eleven grandchildren; one sister and four brothers. A viewing will be held Friday, May 9th, 4-7PM at the Gospel Temple Church of God in Christ, 2056 Fifth Ave. at 127th Street; the funeral will follow that evening at 7:30 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about closing arguments in the latest trial in the 1991 disturbances in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to actions taken by an Orthodox Jewish ambulance crew at the scene after a car accident fatally injured a black child and set off the unrest. Moments after the crew arrived, the police ordered it to leave with the driver of the car, a Hasidic Jew, who was being attacked by a crowd. The crew did not choose to treat the driver rather than the boy.

title: TOWERS UNTESTED FOR MAJOR FIRE, INQUIRY SUGGESTS
description: Federal investigators studying the collapse of the twin towers on Sept. 11, 2001, say they now believe that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the government agency that built the towers, never performed the fundamental tests needed to determine how their innovative structures would perform in a fire.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: March Jobless Figures Released
description: Joblessness in the city appeared to ease in March, but labor analysts said the figure actually reflected a drop in the number of people seeking work and a shrinking number of jobs. The unemployment rate for New York City dropped to 8.5 percent in March from 8.8 percent in February, according to figures released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the state fell to 6.0 percent from 6.1 percent, slightly above the national rate of 5.8 percent. At the same time, the number of private-sector jobs in the state declined by 6,700, when seasonally adjusted. There were gains in construction, broadcasting and security services, but losses in professional and business services and in employment services in particular, analysts said. Janny Scott (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Report Criticizes Verizon Service
description: A new report criticizes Verizon, the state's largest phone company, for poor service. The report, issued yesterday by Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, says that the quality of Verizon's service has slipped in the past year, particularly in Nassau County and upstate New York cities, including Syracuse, Utica, Rome and Watertown. In February and March, the Public Service Commission received 1,314 complaints about Verizon, which has seven million customers. Cliff Lee, a company spokesman, said that service was improving, and that the company planned to spend $1 billion in the coming year to install fiber optic cables and make other improvements. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: It's Really 'Tax Shifting'
description: To the Editor:

title: Value of Witness Against 4 Arabs Is Challenged
description: The credibility of the government's main witness in the terror trial of four Arab men was challenged today in federal court here by a former jailhouse neighbor.

title: Settlement Negotiations Collapse In Morgan Stanley Sex-Bias Case
description: Renewed settlement talks between Morgan Stanley and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to resolve a sex-bias case have collapsed.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Black Box Posts Declines In Revenue And Income
description: The Black Box Corporation, a provider of computer-networking products and services, said yesterday that its fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell 68 percent as revenue dropped 16 percent. Net income in the quarter ended March 31 fell to $4.21 million, or 21 cents a share, from $12.9 million, or 62 cents, in the year-earlier period, the company said in a news release. Revenue fell to $134.8 million. Excluding costs for closing some offices and other items, profit was 55 cents. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, the company had been forecast to earn 53 cents, the average estimate of eight analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Shares of Black Box rose $2.46, or 7.1 percent, to $37.06. They had fallen 23 percent this year.

title: Missionaries' Friend Killed in Lebanon Bombing
description: An explosion killed a man outside the apartment of a Christian missionary couple in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli today, officials said, in the second attack on missionaries since November.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro tumbled against the dollar and the yen after a government report showed German unemployment surged in April. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1369, down from $1.1417 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HARTLEY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Hartley. Longtime Board Member of the 2wice Arts Foundation, dear father of our Founder and President, Patricia Tarr. We extend heartfelt sympathy to Patsy and her family.

title: Body Found In East River Is Identified
description: The police yesterday identified a body found floating in the East River on Tuesday afternoon as that of a Russian woman who vanished two months ago while walking her dog on the Upper East Side. An autopsy found that she had drowned after suffering small bruises on both shins, the authorities said.

title: Just in Time for Summer, Fewer Garbage Collections
description: Even with sales and income tax increases, New York City needs to make tough service cuts to balance next year's budget. Sanitation officials said yesterday that beginning in July they would pick up trash less frequently in much of the city.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Selling the War: Disturbing Patterns
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Leader Visits Bush, Who Delivers on a Promise
description: President Bush today rewarded one of his most loyal supporters in the Iraq war, Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar of Spain, with a meeting in the Oval Office, a dinner at the White House and the inclusion of Batasuna, a radical Basque nationalist party, on the State Department list of international terrorist groups.

title: Not the Place to Cook a Meal Anyone Would Call Square
description: Snaidero, a manufacturer of kitchen units, has introduced Acropolis, a $110,000 kitchen-in-the-round that it is advertising in Variety, aiming at movie-star clients. Acropolis is by the Italian engineer Paolo Pininfarina, of the family that also designs Ferraris.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''With this change in the country, we have the chance to give our ideas in a new democratic way. So we're starting in a nice quiet democratic way.''

title: McCarthy's Tactics, Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: William Goode, Scholar of Family Life and Divorce, Dies at 85
description: William J. Goode, a sociologist who did research on family life, marriage and divorce, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 85 and had homes in East Hampton, N.Y.; Cambridge, Mass.; and Fairfax, Va.

title: Two Ways to Pay Tribute to Queen for a Day
description: WITH Mother's Day three days away, the time has come for every dutiful husband, son and daughter to commit to one of two gift-giving strategies: practical or pretty. Better to romance the occasion with a silver picture frame? Or give her something she may really want (and actually use), like a robotic vacuum that cuts cleaning time? If it's the thought that counts, maybe a sterling silver watering can for serving lemonade? On the other hand, she may prefer a portable air-conditioner. If all else fails, there's always that old standby, chocolate-covered cherries.

title: Jeter, With an Entourage, Plays Trenton
description: Two bodyguards shadowed Derek Jeter whenever he was not swinging a bat, fielding a grounder or running the bases tonight at Waterfront Park. Three trainers -- Jeter's personal trainer and two minor league trainers -- studied his movements. And a dozen television camera operators, 60 reporters and 8,380 giddy fans analyzed Jeter's familiar mannerisms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVLIN, MSGR. RAYMOND R.
description: SHEVLIN-Msgr. Raymond R., 85, on May 5. Long time pastor of Resurrection RC Church, 2331 Gerritsen Ave, Brooklyn. Dear brother of John J. and the late Frank Shevlin. Kind and loving uncle to nieces Jeanne, Lorraine, Pat and Nancy and nephew Ray and many grand and great-grand nieces and nephews. Reposing at Resurrection RC Church Thursday 1-5pm. Mass of Transferral Thursday at 7:30PM. Funeral Mass on Friday at Resurrection Church at 10:30 AM. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery. For information contact Byrnes Funeral Home, 718-743-1099.

title: Turkey Rejects Criticism by U.S. Official Over Iraq
description: Turkish officials today dismissed critical remarks by Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz suggesting that the country had made a mistake by not opening its doors to the American military during the Iraq war.

title: Sales Increase At Faster Rate Than Inventory
description: Sales at wholesalers increased twice as much as inventories in March, led by a rebound in imported automobiles, a government report showed today.

title: Schools Try Integration by Income, Not Race
description: This city has joined a small but growing movement to use income, not race, as a primary factor in assigning students to schools.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TDK Reverses Loss
description: A leading maker of magnetic components, the TDK Corporation, posted a profit of 12 billion yen ($103 million) yesterday for the year ended March 31, reversing a year-earlier loss of 26 billion yen. Sales rose 6.7 percent. TDK, which makes parts for hard disk drives, said it expected profit to rise again this year, to about 30 billion yen. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: NEW U.S.CONCERNS ON IRAN'S PURSUIT OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Bush administration is concerned that Iran has stepped up its covert nuclear program, and the government is now seeking broad international support for an official finding that Tehran has violated its commitment not to produce nuclear weapons, officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Race Trial Jury Begins Deliberations
description: The jury in the Crown Heights racial violence trial began deliberations yesterday. The defendant, Lemrick Nelson Jr., who is black, is accused of violating the civil rights of Yankel Rosenbaum, an Orthodox Jew, by fatally stabbing him in 1991 because of his religion. Mr. Nelson's lawyers concede that he stabbed Mr. Rosenbaum. In the summation yesterday a prosecutor told the jury in Federal District Court that at Mr. Nelson's 1997 trial on the same charges -- which ended in a conviction that was later overturned -- his lawyers denied that he had stabbed Mr. Rosenbaum. On Monday, Judge Frederic Block barred mention of the 1997 denial. He reversed himself on Tuesday. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: If Martians Went to Design School
description: INSIDE ''Wave UFO,'' a space-themed interactive artwork that has just touched down in the atrium of 590 Madison Avenue, the brain-wave projections of the nerve-racked publicist to my left jitterbugged like mad. To my right, the brain waves of a visiting Japanese art critic pulsed serenely. My own beta waves blushed red -- indicating alertness or alarm -- as they too were recorded in real time by electrode receptors suctioned to my forehead and projected as images shaped like dimpled fava beans on the inner dome.

description: Motorola, the electronic communications giant that got its start as one of the first makers of car radios 75 years ago, is introducing a device that just might persuade many teenage fans of online chatting to sever their ties to the computer mother ship.

title: To Each Software User, Their Own
description: In my review of "seven-mile" two-way radios in today's Circuits, I note that in the real world, these radios have a one-mile range if you're lucky. It's all about line of sight; if there's anything at all between the radios, even humidity, the range drops drastically.

description: The increasing boldness and strength of criminal gangs here in Brazil's showcase city is sowing alarm and impatience among the residents, who complain that political rivalries and bickering between the federal and local governments are blocking an effective response.

title: Technology Briefing | Nanotechnology: House Authorizes $2.36 Billion For Research
description: The House of Representatives yesterday approved a bill authorizing an investment of $2.36 billion over three years in nanotechnology research and development. Most of the money would be funneled to academia and industry through the National Science Foundation, the Defense Department and other government agencies. Nanotechnology, which involves creating and processing materials as small as a single molecule in size, is expected to affect virtually every segment of the economy within a generation. The bill is the first major step by Congress toward asserting a role in managing national support for nanotechnology development and in specifying areas of research it wants covered, like potential social impact. The Senate is working on similar legislation that is expected to pass early this summer. At the moment, the federal government's role in nanotechnology is largely centered in the National Nanotechnology Initiative, an executive program started by President Bill Clinton and enlarged by President Bush. The investments authorized in the House bill are roughly similar to current levels of federal support under the executive initiative. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

description: Federal geologists have identified a band of counties stretching from northern Massachusetts to coastal Maine where water in private wells is likely to contain potentially harmful levels of arsenic.

title: Pistons Feel They Have Go-To Guy In Billups
description: There is one reason the Detroit Pistons are widely expected to fall short of the N.B.A. finals, one shortcoming that many analysts say could outweigh their stellar defense and deep bench at some point in the Eastern Conference playoffs. It is their lack of a legitimate go-to guy on offense.

description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Pentagon emphasized today that high-ranking officials of Saddam Hussein's ruling party would not be allowed any role in governing the new Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Shell Weighs Oil Stake
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Europe's largest oil company, is considering whether to increase its stake in a $7.4 billion Caspian Sea oil project, potentially blocking plans by two Chinese rivals to buy the shares.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: LONGTIME INMATE EXECUTED The nation's longest-serving death-row inmate, Carl Isaacs, 49, was executed by lethal injection at a state prison in Jackson, where he had spent the last 23 years. Mr. Isaacs was sentenced to death in 1974 for taking part in the murders of six members of a family on their Seminole County farm. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: GUIDELINES FOR DONATIONS TO CITY The city's Conflicts of Interest Board has revised the guidelines on how and when public officials may solicit funds from private donors for the good of New York City. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made soliciting private donations to help the city through its fiscal crisis a priority. Previously, the mayor, his appointees and other elected officials were forbidden to directly solicit private-sector funds for city agencies and nonprofit entities closely affiliated with the city. Now, under recent guidelines, these officials may solicit funds from private companies, except those that have matters pending before the city. Further, the city will now have to publicly name the individuals or firms that have made large donations. The board reviewed its previous opinions on gifts to the city at the request of several officials, members said. The chairman, Steven B. Rosenfeld, called the opinion the most difficult of his first year on the board. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Irking N.R.A., Bush Supports The Ban on Assault Weapons
description: President Bush and the National Rifle Association, long regarded as staunch allies, find themselves unlikely adversaries over one of the most significant pieces of gun-control legislation in the last decade, a ban on semiautomatic assault weapons.

title: Political Notebook: What 'emancipation' is Schroeder after?
description: BERLIN:  Richard Holbrooke, the former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and to Germany, was in town this week, talking at the American Academy in Berlin about the diplomatic aspects of the run-up to the war in Iraq, and  with some piquancy  about a couple of issues that remain short of elucidation.

description: Jack Baxter's first documentary film, on the assassination of Malcolm X, brought him controversy, death threats and years of litigation. His second film proved even riskier.
