title: Russia Charges Officer in Chechen Copter Crash
description: The office of Russia's military prosecutor has filed criminal charges against an army commander stemming from the crash of a mammoth military helicopter in Chechnya last August and acknowledged that the death toll was higher than previously reported, officials said today.

title: Vulnerable Frontcourt Holds Back Dallas
description: DALLAS, May 7 - In December 1996, Frank Zaccanelli, the interim general manager of the Dallas Mavericks, flew to Hawaii to woo Don Nelson back to the N.B.A. Retired to his beach house on Maui, Nelson drank a few beers with Zaccanelli and bit on his pitch to return to the Mavericks as general manager.

title: Shutting Down the 'Iron Pipeline'
description: In a Brooklyn courtroom last month, a Columbia University professor delivered a lesson in why existing gun laws do not work. The professor, Dr. Howard Andrews, testified that 90 percent of the guns recovered in New York crime investigations from 1996 to 2000 had been bought out of state. A large number came from five states with lax gun laws: Virginia, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina.

description: India has appointed a high commissioner to Pakistan in a first step toward normalizing relations between the two countries, officials here said today. But India has also reacted without enthusiasm to Pakistan's initial response to a peace overture last week by the Indian prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee.

description: Several administration officials Wednesday defended President Bush's flight on a Navy jet to an aircraft carrier last week, saying there was a minimal difference between the cost of the president flying to the ship in a jet versus flying in a helicopter.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOUTH AFRICA: STATE FUNERAL ORDERED FOR SISULU The government decided to grant a state funeral to Walter Sisulu, who led the decades-long campaign against apartheid alongside Nelson Mandela. Mr. Sisulu, 90, died on Monday. The state funeral will be on May 17 in the Johannesburg township of Soweto. An official state funeral means the government will bear some of the costs, members of the South African military will participate, and flags will be flown at half-staff during a period of mourning.   (Agence France-Presse)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: DONATION TO FINANCE DEMOLITIONS A Detroit man who made his fortune paving the area's roads will give the city $10 million to raze hundreds of forsaken buildings. The man, Robert Thompson, founder of the Thomas-McCully Company, will pay for up to 1,400 demolitions. Mr. Thompson built his asphalt paving company on hundreds of millions of dollars in state contracts. After selling the company for $422 million in 1999, he created a $100 million fund to help restore Detroit. Anand Giridharadas (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Infant Death Still A Mystery
description: The police were still trying to determine yesterday what killed an 11-month-old baby and sickened a 5-month-old baby in Borough Park on Tuesday. The older child, Yechzkel Kraminer, died suddenly after his baby sitter, who was not identified, noticed that he and the 5-month-old were having trouble breathing. Investigators took baby formula and some food from the baby sitter's apartment for testing, and were also considering chemical fumes from a nearby jewelry store as a possible cause of death. But they said they would have to await the results of a toxicology test by the city medical examiner before making a final determination. The 5-month-old, whose name was not released, was listed in good condition at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, a spokeswoman said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: A Bad Decision on Term Limits
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Brooklyn got it wrong when he struck down the City Council's revision of the term limits law. The ruling, now being considered by a four-judge appellate panel, will not only wreak havoc in city politics at a particularly inopportune time, but is also simply wrong on the merits. New Yorkers twice voted to limit Council members to two full terms in office. The Council's revision rightly solves a glitch that would have limited some members to six years instead of the full eight. If the ruling is allowed to stand, it will oust six Council members, including the speaker, Gifford Miller, rendering all of them ineligible to run for re-election in November.

description: President Bush, continuing to wield diplomatic leverage gained from a decisive victory in Iraq, proposed a new free trade zone for the Middle East in a commencement speech today at the University of South Carolina.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Genzyme To Eliminate Tracking-Stock Structure
description: The Genzyme Corporation, the fifth-biggest United States biotechnology company, said yesterday that it would eliminate a tracking-stock structure that allowed its cancer and experimental-surgery units to be traded as separate businesses. Shares of Genzyme Biosurgery and Genzyme Molecular Oncology will be exchanged for Genzyme stock on June 30, the company said in a statement. Genzyme introduced the tracking stocks in 1994 to help finance early-stage research. Genzyme, which had to lower profit forecasts three times last year, decided to eliminate the tracking stocks because they failed to raise enough money, said a company spokesman, Dan Quinn. Genzyme announced the change after the close of regular trading. Shares of Genzyme fell 43 cents, to $39.13.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Partial Lifting Of KFC Boycott
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals announced a partial moratorium on its five-month-old boycott of KFC, a unit of Yum Brands, which agreed last week to several of the organization's demands. KFC's farmers will expand the living space for chickens by 30 percent, and the company will put cameras in the slaughterhouses to monitor whether the animals are killed as painlessly as possible. In return PETA will suspend its demonstrations in Louisville, Ky., for two months and rewrite its boycott literature to reflect the improvements. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Ready for Summer? Not if the House Is Unfinished
description: JUST two weeks to go, and panic levels are rising as homeowners contemplate the essential question of the summer season: ''Will I get my deck/pool/kitchen finished before Memorial Day weekend?'' Construction deadlines set months ago suddenly seem laughably optimistic -- although no one is laughing -- and homeowners in resort towns are trying everything from tears to bribes to get their projects done in time. Page 6.

title: Citigroup Ousts 2 Top Investment Bankers
description: Two of Citigroup's most senior investment bankers, Robert K. DiFazio and Arthur D. Hyde III, have been removed from their positions, the company said yesterday, hinting at what might be a fresh round of high-level management changes amid a barren deal-making environment and increased levels of regulatory scrutiny.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 3 Charged In Tel Aviv Bombing
description: Three of the six people detained by police over the weekend in connection with the suicide bombing in Tel Aviv last week were charged with offenses under Britain's two-year-old anti-terrorism act and ordered to appear in a London court today. The three, two women and a man from Derby in the English Midlands, were identified as Paveen Akthor Sharif, 35, Tahari Shad Tabassum, 27, and Zahid Hussain Sharif, 46. A man and a woman arrested in Derbyshire and another man, arrested in London, were released. The bombing, which killed three people, was carried out by Asif Hanif, 21, a Briton from West London. A second Briton, Omar Khan Sharif, 27, of Derbyshire, fled after his body bomb failed to detonate and is still being sought by Israeli security forces. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: NO MERGER FOR SEGA Sega, the video game software maker, abandoned plans to merge with the Sammy Corporation after the sides failed to agree on management control. Another potential suitor, Namco Ltd., withdrew its offer because Sega declined to discuss a merger. Sega has tried to find a partner since it stopped making video game consoles two years ago because of declining sales and rising debts. Still, for the fiscal year that ended March 31, Sega earned 3 billion yen ($25 million), six times its earlier forecast. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: U.S. Official Is 'Optimistic' On India-Pakistan Dispute
description: After meeting with the Pakistani president and other officials here, Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage said today that he was ''cautiously optimistic'' about the prospect for renewed relations between India and Pakistan.

description: Graph tracks the year-to-year changes in the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, based on monthly sales at stores open at least a year since Jan. 2002.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I2 Technologies To Be Removed From Nasdaq
description: I2 Technologies Inc., which is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that the Nasdaq stock market would remove its stock from trading because the company had not filed its annual report for last year. I2, a software maker whose stock soared as high as $110.44 on March 9, 2000, said it plans to appeal Nasdaq's decision. The stock last traded on March 28, when it fell 3 cents, to 79 cents. It will be removed from Nasdaq today, an I2 spokeswoman, Melanie Ofenloch, said. I2 is reauditing results for 2001, 2000 and 1999 after two former executives said sales were booked incorrectly. The company, which was required to submit its annual report for 2002 by March 31, plans to file it next month, Ms. Ofenloch said.

title: 'Dominant' Mussina Is Pitching Better Than Ever
description: SEATTLE, May 8 - Mike Mussina was not too shy to say it. This is the best he has ever pitched in his major league career.

description: When Millat, a rebellious teenager in ''White Teeth,'' runs away from his Muslim parents, he is welcomed, a bit too warmly, by Joyce Malfen, the middle-class mother of a classmate named Josh. Tired of watching his mother moon over this handsome juvenile delinquent, Josh asks her how long the intruder is planning to stay.

title: A Raffish Reminder, Landlubbers, of Saltier Days
description: My favorite thing in Montero's is the little working model of a steam engine, greasy and coated with dust, on a ledge up above where the cigarette machine used to be. It's a foot high, 18 inches or so long, jet black, with six vertical pistons. Flick the switch hidden behind the black-and-white photograph of the two Danish seamen standing outside the bar years ago, and the pistons start going up and down, turning the propeller shaft, powering an imaginary ship through the sea.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect Tries To Escape
description: A young man who had previously been shot while running from the police was chased again Wednesday after he leaped from the third floor of the 10th Precinct station house at 230 West 20th Street, the police said yesterday. He was caught immediately. In 1999, the man, Dantae Johnson, then 16, was shot while running from Officer Mark Conway. Mr. Johnson was unarmed at the time, and his shooting, coming just months after the fatal police shooting of Amadou Diallo, led to renewed criticism of the police. Officer Conway was later convicted of a misdemeanor assault charge and fined. Yesterday, the police said, officers caught Mr. Johnson, now 20, and two others in a 2002 Lexus that had been stolen at gunpoint on West 42nd Street on Monday. Mr. Johnson was taken into custody but leaped from the interrogation room into a tree and was then charged with escape in addition to robbery and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Poison Mystery Widens After a Suicide Note
description: The mystery of who poisoned 16 churchgoers here with arsenic-tainted coffee seemed to be solved the other day when a congregant shot himself to death, leaving a note that the police said tied him to the poisonings.

title: Unraveling Iran's Nuclear Secrets
description: Until recently, Washington had a hard time convincing other countries that Iran was developing nuclear weapons in violation of its commitments under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. But earlier this year, America's case was strengthened by the discovery that Tehran had secretly developed the capacity to enrich naturally found uranium into nuclear bomb fuel. As far as outsiders can tell, Iran's nuclear program is not nearly as advanced as North Korea's. But a concerted international effort is urgently needed to keep it from progressing further.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, WITHERBEE JR.
description: BLACK-Witherbee Jr., 96, of Vero Beach, FL, died May 6, 2003, at his residence. He was born July 30, 1906, in Pelham Manor, NY, the son of Witherbee and Marion C. Black. Mr. Black was the fourth generation of his family in the old firm of Black, Starr and Frost in New York City. During WWII he joined another family firm, the Peerless Coal and Coke Company of Vivian, WV, and later Peerless Coals, Cleveland, OH. He was a member of the Racket and Tennis Club in New York City and the Chagrin Valley Hunt Club in Gates Mills, OH. He is survived by his daughters, Derith Buzby of Medford, NJ, Barbara Funk of Barre, VT, and Ruth Henchey of Rye Brook, NY; a sister, Barbara Ware of Shelburne, VT, seven grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren.

The latest entry in a crowded field is Nice Matin, named after the Riviera's biggest daily newspaper, and devoted to the cuisine of Provence. Andy D'Amico, formerly a chef at Sign of the Dove and Little Dove, keeps things honest, relying heavily on olive oil, olives, tomato, garlic and rosemary, the great ensemble cast of southern French cooking.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Actor Collapses On Broadway Stage
description: Roger Moore, the movie actor best known for playing James Bond, remained hospitalized yesterday, a day after briefly collapsing on a Broadway stage. On Wednesday night, Mr. Moore, 75, was playing the revolving role of Mystery Guest Star in the comedy ''The Play What I Wrote'' at the Lyceum Theater. The play's publicist, Jackie Green, said Mr. Moore was expected to be released from St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital yesterday or today, but she declined to elaborate on his condition or the possible cause of his collapse. She said Mr. Moore was under hot lights during the play and wearing a wig and hoop skirt when he fainted. But he regained consciousness and completed the last few minutes of the show, she said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Detective Suspended Over Escape
description: A police detective was suspended last night after a prisoner escaped in Park Slope, according to the police. Jackie Diaz, who had been arrested for possession of a controlled substance, was being escorted into the 78th Precinct station house in Prospect Heights at 6:12 p.m. when she slipped out of her handcuffs and fled. Ms. Diaz, 34, was recaptured at 198 Bond Street in Boerum Hill at 7 p.m., the police said. Detective Karan Young of the Brooklyn South narcotics squad was suspended for failing to safeguard a prisoner, the police said. It was the 11th escape from police custody this year, according to Detective Carolyn Chew. Ms. Diaz has also been charged with escape, she added. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the indictment of a former F.B.I. agent, James J. Smith, on federal charges involving the passing of classified information to China misidentified the surname of his defense lawyer. He is Brian Sun, not Smith.

description: The United States national soccer team played Mexico to a scoreless draw at Reliant Stadium tonight in front of an overwhelmingly pro-Mexico sellout crowd of 69,582.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DR. DANIEL G.
description: MILLER-Dr. Daniel G. The Board of Trustees, staff, and worldwide family of the Israel Cancer Research Fund (ICRF) express profound sorrow at the passing of Dr. Daniel G. Miller, founder of ICRF, eminent scientist, distinguished pioneer in cancer research, and caring physician. Through his creation of ICRF, Dr. Miller's vision and dedication established the State of Israel as a world center for brilliant, innovative cancer research. A member of the President's Commission on Heart Disease, Cancer, and Stroke, Dr. Miller was President Emeritus of the Strang Cancer Prevention Center. His legacy is an enhancement of science that will add innumerable future lives to the many thousands he saved during his lifetime. His passing leaves a void for science, Israel, ICRF, and his family that will forever remain unfilled. Yashar Hirshaut, M.D. President, ICRF Leah Susskind Chairperson, ICRF

title: FLEMING TO CLOSE WAREHOUSES AND CUT 800 JOBS
description: Fleming, the grocery distributor, said yesterday that it would close five warehouses and lay off about 800 employees, or 6.8 percent of its work force, to cut costs as it seeks to exit bankruptcy. About $1 billion in annual sales will be lost through the closing of the warehouses in Phoenix; Salt Lake City; Warsaw, N.C.; North East, Md.; and King of Prussia, Pa., a spokesman, Shane Boyd, said. Fleming is leaving the regions because there is not enough potential to increase sales, Mr. Boyd said. The company will discontinue the operations in June. Fleming filed for Chapter 11 protection in early April after its largest customer, Kmart, ended a supply agreement.

description: Taipei's mayor, Ma Ying-jeou, said tonight that it was unfair of the World Health Organization to advise against travel here ''because we have taken so many precautions to make the city safe.''

title: Fed Is Starting to Fret Over Falling Prices
description: In deciding this week to keep short-term interest rates at 1.25 percent, the Federal Reserve Board warned of ''an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation.'' The topic also came up at its March meeting, according to minutes released yesterday. Economists have been talking about the dangers of falling prices for several months, but why did the Fed take note now?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, KATHARINE J.
description: BAKER-Katharine J., 98, died on April 29, 2003, at her home in Englewood, NJ. Katharine Baker was born in Cleveland, Ohio on July 1, 1904, daughter of Arthur Bacon and Ida Irwin Jones. She earned degrees in biochemistry from Vassar College and Radcliffe College. During World War II, she participated in the Manhattan Project. Thereafter, she worked in basic medical research at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University. She is survived by two children and eight grandchildren. The memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood at 10 AM on May 22. Memorial gifts may be made to the Katharine Jones Baker Scholarship Fund, Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, New York; or to the Dr. Thomas Quinlan Morris Scholarship Fund, Columbia University, New York.

Later the artists can have all the old stuff back, neatly packed, if they want it. But messing up is the way to start.

title: JOURNEYS: Exploring the West By Night; Rediscovering The Brilliance Of the Stars
description: THIS is the darkest sky I have ever seen,'' Chad Moore said. At one o'clock in the morning, with no moon above, he was looking up from Bryce Point, a narrow Utah bluff with a thousand-foot drop-off on each side. In daylight, hundreds of the orange-colored limestone spires of Bryce Canyon National Park would have been visible below; on this night they were awash in darkness. But there was no danger that Mr. Moore might stumble off the edge of the rock in the dark. Against the deep, true black of this darkest sky glowed the brilliant light of 14,000 stars.

The legislation raises tobacco taxes and imposes a 3 percent surcharge on state income taxes for two years. A tax program proposed last month could not overcome Republican resistance in the state House, and the General Assembly adjourned without approving a budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1. Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, called the lawmakers back into session on Monday. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: President Thabo Mbeki, left, is to meet with the assistant secretary of state for African affairs, Walter Kansteiner, today, just days after a diplomatic mission by Mr. Mbeki and two other African leaders to Zimbabwe. Mr. Mbeki and the presidents of Nigeria and Malawi pressed President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to begin talks with opposition leaders and end a political conflict that has helped push the country to the brink of economic collapse. In an interview, Mr. Kansteiner praised the leaders' trip as ''a very good signal,'' saying it demonstrated ''seriousness by regional leaders that we had not seen before.'' Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, DAVID W.
description: RUBIN-David W. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with deep sadness the passing of our former Senior Vice President and Director of our Concert and Artist Department, David W. Rubin, on May 6 in NYC at the age of 83. Mr. Rubin began his career at Steinway & Sons in 1964 at the invitation of Henry Z. Steinway to head its Concert and Artist Department. In 1979 he was appointed Vice President and assumed additional responsibilities as head of Steinway's public relations program. In 1982 he was named Senior Vice President, a post which he held until his retirement in 1986. A graduate of Princeton, Mr. Rubin studied piano with Alexander Lipsky and Robert Casadesus. He also worked as an artist representative from 1945 to 1956, managing the careers of Ania Dorfman, Grant Johannesen, The Juilliard String Quartet, and George Tozzi among others. His dedication to the Steinway piano was unwavering. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughter, Capers, and to his family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, VP Concert and Artist Activities

Moore, and grandfather of 19, died May 1st, 2003 at home in NYC. Funeral and requiem mass to celebrate his life and work at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 110th and Amsterdam, NYC, Saturday, May 10th, at 4 PM. Reception to follow. The body will lie in state at the cathedral May 9th, 5-8PM, and May 10th, 9AM-2PM. Burial service 2pm, May 12th, Calvary Church, Stonington, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Humanitarian Project (Paul Moore Medical Clinic, East Timor), PO Box 32307, Washington, DC 20007.

Born February 28, 1913 in NYC to Martin Henry and Frances (nee Montague) Smith. Devoted mother of Richard M. Quintal (wife Catherine W.) of Darien, CT, and Barbara Q. Berglund of Pennington, New Jersey, and grandmother to Christopher W. Quintal, Barbara C. Quintal, Theodore M. Berglund, Katherine H. Berglund, and great grandmother of Lukas T. Berglund and Jack O. Berglund. Her nephew Robert M. Baylis (wife Lois W.) also survives her. Predeceased by her husband Theodore G. Quintal & sister Dorothy S. Baylis. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Airline's Loss Grows
description: The loss in the fourth fiscal quarter at KLM Royal Dutch Airlines quadrupled to 447 million euros ($514 million) as severe acute respiratory syndrome, the war in Iraq and a weak world economy caused an increasing number of concerned travelers to stay at home, the company said. For its fiscal year ended March 31, KLM reported a net loss of 416 million euros, which compared with a loss of 156 million euros a year ago. KLM said it did not expect a market improvement any time soon, forcing it to eliminate the equivalent of about 3,000 full-time jobs. Sales in KLM's fourth quarter fell 7.7 percent, to 1.4 billion euros. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Corrects Security Flaw In Passport Program
description: Microsoft, which had more than 70 security flaws last year, said yesterday that it had fixed a problem in its Passport user authentication program that could have allowed unauthorized access to millions of Web site accounts. Passport users have a single account name and password that can allow access to hundreds of Web sites without repeatedly entering the same information. There were no reports of unauthorized access caused by the flaw, Adam Sohn, a product manager for Passport, said. The program has 200 million active accounts and is used at more than 300 Web sites. Microsoft settled an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission last year by pledging to improve Passport's security. The F.T.C. said Passport deceived users by failing to protect the privacy of e-mail addresses and credit card numbers that were used to authenticate user identities. An F.T.C. lawyer, Jessica Rich, would not say whether the commission was investigating the security failure.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN SAYS TWO INVESTIGATIONS HAVE CLOSED
description: Lockheed Martin, the military contractor, said in a regulatory filing that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department had closed separate investigations. The S.E.C. ended an inquiry into Lockheed's failed merger with Northrop Grumman on May 1, Lockheed said. The S.E.C. had questioned whether the companies gave investors enough information about a government review of the proposed merger, which was announced in 1997 and terminated in 1998. On March 19, the Justice Department closed a grand jury investigation into whether hazardous waste was properly stored at a uranium plant Lockheed ran in Paducah, Ky. Workers had filed civil suits contending that Lockheed made false statements about the storage and disposal of radioactive waste.

title: Royal Ahold Says Fraud Was Worse Than Thought
description: The scandal-ridden food retailer Royal Ahold said today that the suspected fraud at its U.S. Foodservice division was much more extensive than previously thought. Ahold said its earnings had been overstated by $880 million over three years, and that it would have to take pretax charges of nearly $1 billion.

description: DALLAS, May 8 - Don Nelson admitted Wednesday that it irritated him when the Dallas Mavericks' owner, Mark Cuban, failed to offer him a contract extension as coach earlier this season.

Tickets to the event, scheduled to begin at 6:30 p.m., will be $300 a person, which includes dinner. No tickets will be sold that night. title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: RATES UNCHANGED For the third consecutive month, the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged, at 3.75 percent, despite hopes among manufacturers for some economic stimulus. Economists said the bank's nine-member monetary policy committee seemed more concerned that a reduction would raise inflation at a time when the British pound is at a four-year low, making imported goods more expensive. Inflation has been above the bank's target of 2.5 percent for several months. The current interest rate is the lowest in almost 48 years. The European Central Bank also left its benchmark rate unchanged, at 2.5 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: N.A.A.C.P. Suit Against Gun Makers Goes to Jury in Brooklyn

title: Citing SARS, Northwest Invokes Clause to Allow Layoffs

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Director Set For Scholarly Center
description: The biographer Jean Strouse has been named director of the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers at the New York Public Library. She will succeed the historian Peter Gay, 79, the founding director. Ms. Strouse, 57, is the author of an acclaimed biography of J. P. Morgan, ''Morgan: American Financier,'' published in 1999. Her term begins in September. The public library's center, founded in 1997, awards annual fellowships of $50,000 each, usually to 15 scholars and writers. In an interview yesterday, Ms. Strouse described the center as a ''vital and dynamic'' part of the city's intellectual life. But, she said, ''I need to look at everything very carefully and think through what kinds of adjustments need to be made to give it even more momentum.'' Dinitia Smith (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Profit Rises
description: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., Southeast Asia's largest phone company, said fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 72 percent as its Optus unit in Australia reported a second consecutive profit. Net income rose to 313 million Singapore dollars ($180 million) from 182 million Singapore dollars a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended March 31, rose 14 percent, to 2.73 billion Singapore dollars ($1.6 billion). The chief executive, Lee Hsien Yang, who started an overseas expansion because of a slowing local market, was able to end losses at Optus by cutting costs and selling more cellphone services.

title: Yale Hospital Plans to Halt Foreclosure for Bill Collection
description: Yale-New Haven Hospital announced today that it would stop using foreclosure on homes as a way of collecting patients' bills and would erase $84,000 owed by 170 patients with bills at least five years old.

title: Nets Return to Boston a More Confident Team
description: The Nets have been there before, tossed into the Fleet Center's boiling pot of taunts and amplified aggression.

title: Trading Barbs, Like Doris And Rock
description: Rock Hudson and Doris Day starred in only three movies together, but their names are forever conjoined in the cultural memory, signifying the guilty pleasures of a supposedly more innocent era. The comedies they made for Universal from the late 1950's to the mid-60's -- with each other and with surrogates ranging from Cary Grant to Gina Lollobrigida -- were the product of a moment when the incipient sexual revolution collided with the moribund Hollywood Production Code in an explosion of bright color, lush music and naughty innuendo.

title: 2 Big Advertisers Pick New Agencies
description: Two big advertisers changed agencies on their accounts yesterday.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Agreement In Strip-Search Case
description: The Suffolk County Sheriff's office has agreed to pay its share of a $10 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit filed in 1999 by women who say they were illegally strip-searched after being arrested for minor offenses. The payments to 1,500 women were due by Nov. 29, 2002, and the sheriff's office has agreed to pay more than $200,000 in interest and fines, which were levied after a judge last month found the department in contempt for failing to make the payments. The sheriff's office and the City of Boston were ordered to pay $5 million each last June. The city paid on Nov. 29. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Protests in Europe over benefit cuts : Pensions on line, workers walk
description: Across Europe, workers are taking to the streets this spring in a battle to protect the most highly prized perk of the postwar welfare state  the right to retire, often early, on a generous, government-guaranteed pension.

title: It's Not Bloomberg, It's the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: ELAN SAYS F.T.C. HAS ENDED INQUIRY THAT HALTED A DEAL
description: The Elan Corporation, an Irish drug maker, said yesterday that antitrust officials in the United States had ended an investigation that thwarted an $890 million sale of two medicines to King Pharmaceuticals. King said it would still not buy the drugs, Skelaxin, a muscle relaxant, and Sonata, a sleep aid. The Federal Trade Commission has ended an investigation into whether Elan wrongfully blocked rivals by listing a patent for Skelaxin, Elan said. King had cited the investigation as a central reason for backing out of the deal. The sale to King would have helped Elan raise $1.3 billion it needs to pay down debt due by the end of the year. Elan is suing King to force the sale.

title: INSIDE
description: Study of SARS Genome Shows No Big Mutations

title: U.S. Prisoners Include 200 With Origins Outside Iraq
description: Among prisoners held by the United States in Iraq, more than 200 are Syrians, Jordanians, Lebanese and other foreigners who could become subject to military tribunals, American military officials said today.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Shopping List | Turkey Hunting
description: WILD turkey populations have grown so robustly over the last three decades that the bird is now found -- and hunted -- in all of the lower 48 states. (In New York, the season runs the month of May.) A variety of tools are used for a successful hunt, like head-to-toe camouflage (to confuse the extraordinarily keen eyes of turkeys) and clever calls (to lure Tom ever closer). GEOFFREY NORMAN

title: Filtering Fumes
description: As they choke on exhaust fumes in traffic, drivers can reflect on the progress of cleaning systems for cars' inside air. Dust filters are commonplace, and a few manufacturers have filters that take out some fumes; often, in urban areas, the air inside the car is cleaner than the air outside. But Volvo is experimenting with a system that will take car air to a whole new level.

title: Israeli Helicopters Attack and Kill a Hamas Leader in Gaza
description: Israeli attack helicopters fired missiles that killed a senior Hamas militant driving in Gaza City today. Three more Palestinians were killed in scattered violence, including one who blew himself up with a car bomb next to an Israeli tank in southern Gaza.

title: After Exoneration, Then What?
description: It's bad enough to be locked up for years for a crime you didn't commit. What's worse is to get out and find that you're on your own.

title: Whizzing Swords and Violin Bows
description: Nowhere in Carl Flesch's pedagogical masterpiece, ``Art of Violin Playing,'' does it describe how to perform on your instrument with perfect poise while a murderous weapon is whizzing within inches of your scalp. And yet there was Timothy Ying, first violinist of the Ying Quartet, playing as if nothing was amiss on May 2 as a long and very sharp-looking steel sword was repeatedly thrust through the air dangerously close to his head on the stage of the Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater.

title: U.S. Envoy Says U.S. Will Not Forget Afghanistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 9  Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage made a short stop in Afghanistan today on his way between Pakistan and India, to bear a personal message from the White House that the United States would not forget Afghanistan.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Bill Expands DNA Database
description: The House Criminal Justice Committee approved by a vote of 8 to 1 a bill requiring anyone arrested for any felony or sex-related misdemeanor to provide a DNA sample for a state database. The bill was sponsored by Senator John L. Dardenne of Baton Rouge, where the police have used dragnets to collect DNA in an investigation of the deaths of five women. The state now allows DNA testing of those convicted of certain felonies. The bill would create a larger DNA database with no provision to remove the DNA of those who are not convicted. It passed the Senate, 36 to 0, and now goes to the House. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Nasdaq Official, Passed Over, Will Take Post at Citigroup
description: Richard Ketchum, president and deputy chairman of the Nasdaq stock market, is resigning to join Citigroup, after Nasdaq passed him over for a second time in naming a new chief executive.

title: France Seeks Pension Reform, Confronting Unions
description: France's social safety net is less safe than ever these days.

title: Empire Maker Will Wait For the Belmont Stakes
description: Empire Maker will not try to turn the tables on Funny Cide in the Preakness Stakes on May 17, but will wait until the third leg of the Triple Crown, the Belmont Stakes, to try to better his second-place finish in the Kentucky Derby.

title: METROSTARS SIGN 2 ARGENTINES
description: The MetroStars acquired two players - defender Juan Forchetti and midfielder Jos Galvn on loan from the Argentine club Boca Juniors. Forchetti and Galvn, both 22, played in games for the MetroStars during the club's preseason trip to Argentina in March.

title: California Ponders Big Loan in Deficit Crisis
description: Facing a huge budget shortfall and skepticism on Wall Street about the state's creditworthiness, California officials are considering floating as much as $10 billion in bonds to stave off a cash flow crisis that some are warning could come as early as this summer.

title: A Greenspan Tactic Buoys the Bond Market
description: ALAN GREENSPAN has done it again. He has played the markets like a virtuoso musician.

title: Company Accused of Threatening Workers
description: Some unusual things began happening to Jona Fleurimont, according to the National Labor Relations Board, when he and another bus driver in the Bronx decided to challenge their union's shop steward because they thought he was too cozy with management.

title: Veterans' Nuclear Exposure Underestimated, Panel Says
description: Some soldiers, sailors and aviators who developed cancer from exposure to radiation from 1945 to 1962 were denied compensation because the Pentagon grossly underestimated their doses, a panel of independent scientists said today.

title: On the Fast Track to Stardom
description: THERE were 16 fake bullet holes in the windshield of the metallic-blue 1971 Chevelle SS convertible, and Ray Claridge was not happy about it. ''I didn't know they were going to do that,'' said Mr. Claridge, who owns the Chevelle and about 1,000 other cars and trucks that he rents out to Hollywood productions. The car had acquired the bullet holes (actually made with a hammer) during filming for the Fox television series ''Fastlane.''

title: Ah, Sweet Mystery of E-Mail
description: GUYS always try to pick me up while I'm at work. And I work at home.

title: Get Me a Contractor! Memorial Day's Coming!
description: THE other night, Ellen Kapit had a nightmare. She was at her former weekend house at Ocean Beach on Fire Island, and the new owners, quite reasonably, wanted to know what she was doing there. ''I said 'Oh, I'd better go to my new house,' '' recalled Ms. Kapit, who works in national radio promotions and public relations and who recently bought another beach cottage, this time in the village of Saltaire on Fire Island. ''I went there but at first I couldn't find it, and when I did, it didn't look the way I remembered it, and my friends were saying 'Why did you move?' ''

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Free Air Or Not, Your Tires Need It
description: THE question from my daughter, a new driver, came one cold rainy evening. ''Where do I go to get air for my tires?'' she asked. I had to confess to that parental rarity: no answer. The gas station I most often used in our New Jersey town had recently removed its air pump. Another pump I knew of was broken.

title: Peace, in Experiment Form, Survives the Shuttle Disaster
description: Peace is a fragile thing, but an experiment dedicated to peace has survived the fiery breakup of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Comcast Says Loss Widened But Forecast Is Looking Up
description: The Comcast Corporation reported a wider first-quarter loss yesterday but raised its forecast for subscriber growth this year.

title: A Strong Euro With Few Admirers
description: Three years ago, Europeans were wringing their hands over a seemingly endless slide in the value of the euro. These days, the currency is pole-vaulting ahead of the United States dollar, nearing levels it has not achieved since its introduction in January 1999.

title: Heady Days for Kuwait Stock Exchange
description: Waleed al-Houtti keeps his eyes trained on the flashing stock prices streaming across the bottom of his computer screen, and sporadically answers a phone. On one call, Mr. Houtti, the assistant general manager for local investment at the Kuwait Stock Exchange, says a single word -- ''Really?'' -- and then hangs up with a wide smile. ''I just sold stocks I bought yesterday, for double the price,'' he explains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNUDSEN, LAURA (NEE BUCKNELL)
description: KNUDSEN-Laura (nee Bucknell), on March 17, 2003. A memorial service will be held Sunday, May 11, at 2PM at All Soul's Unitarian Church, Lexington Ave at 80th St. Contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, NY, NY 10017.

title: Bloomberg School Plan Redirects Money and People
description: New details of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's school restructuring plan, including the first organizational charts to be made public, show it cutting through every level of the bureaucracy, pointedly redirecting money and personnel into schools.

title: Calls Breed Talk of Conspiracies
description: The N.B.A.'s three-time defending champions, down two games to none after a blowout loss to the Spurs in San Antonio on Wednesday, are undeniably in trouble, but not for the first time. Twice before since beginning their recent run of dominance, the Los Angeles Lakers have appeared vulnerable. Each time, the league's conspiracy theorists were given enough fuel to drive from the Alamo to the Staples Center in Los Angeles.

title: G.O.P. MAKES DEAL IN SENATE TO WIDEN ANTITERROR POWER
description: Senate Republicans backed down today from an effort to make permanent the sweeping antiterrorism powers in a 2001 act, clearing the way for passage of a less divisive measure that would still expand the government's ability to spy on foreign terrorist suspects in the United States.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Which Way on the Mideast Road?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Parker Should Make Spurs Forget Kidd
description: ON the sore and speculative subject of Jason Kidd's hightailing it out of northern New Jersey next season for a charmed championship life here in steamy South Texas: not so fast. The Spurs already have an irresistible point guard who can flat-out fly.

title: G.I.'s Search, Not Alone, In the Cellar Of Secrets
description: A team of American soldiers returned today to Iraqi secret police headquarters and found a suspicious intruder whom they detained, dozens of 19th- and early 20th-century Jewish texts and records and a huge unexploded American bomb, but not the ancient copy of the Talmud for which they were searching.

title: Barclays Agrees to Buy Spanish Bank In Cash Deal
description: Barclays Bank said today that it would pay 1.143 billion euros ($1.31 billion) in cash for Banco Zaragozano in a deal that will make Barclays the sixth-biggest bank in Spain.

title: Emily Jacir
description: Debs & Company

title: Reluctantly, a Tribe Starts to See Casinos As Being Imperative
description: For years, the Cayugas wanted no part of gambling fever. As the Senecas, the Oneidas and the Mohawks began earning millions from casinos, the Cayugas held to the old rules of consensus and unanimity. If even one of the five clan mothers opposed it, it could not happen.

title: Sports of The Times; The Mets' Management Bungles, Like the Team
description: THE Mets' front office has a severe case of bone spurs of the thought process. In addition to all the gruesome things happening on the field and in the sick bay, the Mets have ticked off their best player, Mike Piazza.

title: Questions Abound Over Delay In Schools' Bilingual Program
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled his blueprint in January to overhaul the city's school system, he said that Chancellor Joel I. Klein would submit plans within 60 days for improving programs for disabled students and those who are learning English.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Special Tax Session
description: Gov. Bob Riley has asked the Legislature to meet in special session beginning on May 19 to consider more than $1 billion in revenue and government accountability measures. ''The package I will present will be comprehensive in nature, addressing both tax reform and tax fairness as well as fundamentally reforming how we conduct business in Montgomery,'' Mr. Riley, a Republican who took office in January, told Seth Hammett, the House speaker, in a letter. Mr. Hammett said Mr. Riley's plan contained measures that could produce up to $1.2 billion, nearly twice the $600 million projected spending increase next year. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Houses With Great Kitchens: You Can't Have Too Many Cooks
description: WHO: Diane Goldman, 51, New England Chapter president of the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, shown with her husband, Mark

title: State's Highest Court Hears Case on Financing of Schools
description: After wending its way through the legal system for a decade, a lawsuit accusing New York State of dodging its constitutional obligation to educate all children, particularly those in New York City, made it before the state's highest court today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 31 about art once owned by Nikolai Khardzhiev, a Russian critic who died in 1996, referred incompletely to the outcome of a lawsuit brought by a gallery that had once been his dealer. But a correction in this space on May 2 characterized the article erroneously: it was not incorrect. The article correctly reported that the suit, by Galerie Gmurzynska in Cologne, Germany, against art experts who had questioned its tactics in obtaining and selling the works, was dismissed by a United States district court.

title: N.C.A.A. Bars Michigan From Next Postseason
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association suspended the University of Michigan men's basketball program today from postseason play in the 2003-4 season and placed it on probation for four years. The penalties were the result of a scandal involving a booster and hundreds of thousands of dollars he said he paid Chris Webber and three other star players of the 1990's.

title: Way, Way Back, To the Dawn Of the Beginning
description: WHO knows, as of now, what's lost from the Iraq Museum in Baghdad. But as if to illustrate the value of the collection, ''Art of the First Cities'' opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- the most timely exhibition in years as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLOFF, EILEEN MARIE
description: GOLOFF-Eileen Marie. On May 8, 2003. Longtime resident of Manhasset. Beloved mother of Christopher, George and Kathleen. Cherished grandmother of Alexis, Christopher and Nicole. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Saturday 3-5 and 7-9. Funeral Mass Monday 11:15 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset.

title: Clinics Hold More Embryos Than Had Been Thought
description: Fertility clinics in the United States have accumulated some 400,000 frozen human embryos, about twice the number estimated, since 1986 when the in vitro fertilization procedure began, the first official inventory has found.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Hotel Chain Posts Loss
description: Four Seasons Hotels, the luxury hotel chain, cited the weak global economy, terrorist alerts and the effect of the SARS virus for a first-quarter loss of 9.3 million Canadian dollars ($6.7 million), in contrast to earnings of 7.7 million Canadian dollars a year earlier. Revenue dipped 5.6 percent, to 61 million Canadian dollars. Four Seasons, which is based in Toronto, said that SARS hurt occupancy at its hotels in Singapore, Shanghai and Toronto in the last two weeks of March, and had contributed to the overall drop in the chain's occupancy rate to about 55 percent in April, from an expected 65 percent. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Mother Russia Nurtured Her Modern Rebels, Too
description: It is not easy to find the peasant woman in the 1915 painting ''Red Square (Painterly Realism of a Peasant Woman in Two Dimensions),'' by Kasimir Malevich, a great name in Russian avant-garde art. But she's there. A bright red square set with slight asymmetry on a white ground, that painting embodied Malevich's new concept of Suprematism, the liberation of art from what he called ''the ballast of the representational world.''

title: CLOROX PROFIT IS UP BUT IT FORESEES HIGHER EXPENSES
description: The Clorox Company said yesterday that third-quarter profit more than doubled after costs fell but that marketing expenses for Glad wraps would cause income to decline later this year. Net income in the third quarter, which ended March 31, rose to $110 million, or 50 cents a share, from $46 million, or 20 cents, a year earlier, when Clorox had a loss in Argentina. Sales fell less than 1 percent, to $1.02 billion, the first decline in almost two years. Clorox will increase advertising to introduce a thicker Glad product as its first item from a venture with Procter & Gamble, hurting next quarter's profit.

title: A Designer Bids Adieu To Art Deco
description: ''I like to collect, but I'm not crazy to own things,'' said Karl Lagerfeld, the Paris-based couturier. ''I'm a fashion person. I'm excited by finding things, but in the end there's an accumulation and I want to get rid of it.'' He said that was why he is selling his collection of French 20th-century decorative arts on Thursday at Sotheby's in Paris. ''I'm buying 21st-century things now,'' he said. ''My three passions are fashion, books and photographs.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CALLAHAN, ROGER J.
description: O'CALLAHAN-Roger J. 55, died May 6, 2003 in New Haven, CT. He was the fiancee of Deborah Devylder. Father of Caitlin O'Callahan, of Woodbridge, CT, brother of James O'Callahan Jr., of Brooklyn, Mary O'Callahan of the Bronx and John O'Callahan of Brattleboro, VT. Born in Bronx, NY he was the son of the late James and Mary Mooney O'Callahan. Funeral services will be held in St. Aedan's Church, New Haven, CT Saturday at 9am. Friends may call at the Celentano Funeral Home, 424 Elm St, New Haven, CT, Friday from 3-8PM. Interment is in St. Lawrence Cemetery.

title: Nicosia Journal; On a Severed Street in Cyprus, the Healing Begins
description: What Costas Constantinou wanted most, when the border between north and south Cyprus opened, was to find the missing part of his street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Northwest Airlines Invokes Emergency Layoff Clause

title: Olivier Long, 87; Led Predecessor of the W.T.O.
description: Olivier Long, a Swiss diplomat who helped keep the Western world moving toward freer trade in the 1970's despite protectionist pressures brought on by soaring oil prices, inflation and recession, died on March 19 in Geneva, according to the Web site of the World Trade Organization. He was 87.

title: Discovering Mastery in an Intimate Space
description: New York Theater Ballet, a worthy little company, had a good big idea. On May 1 at Gould Hall, it devoted a program to Antony Tudor, an English choreographer long associated with American Ballet Theater and one of the masters of dramatic ballet.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the return of some Baath Party officials to leadership positions in Iraq misstated the surname of an American diplomat working for Jay Garner on the reconstruction effort. She is Robin Raphel, not Rafael.

title: S.U.V. Chic: Big Vehicles for Big Egos
description: To the Editor:

title: Election Law's Sponsors Seek Stay on All of Ruling
description: The Congressional sponsors of the campaign finance law that was partly struck down and partly upheld by three judges last week asked them today to suspend their entire ruling, a step that would keep the law in force until the Supreme Court decides on it.

title: School Punishes L.I. Athletes Over Visits To Strip Club
description: For years, being on the Massapequa High School varsity baseball team has meant spending spring break at the Cocoa Expo in Florida and playing baseball 8 to 12 hours a day. But this year, it is what school officials say took place after hours that is now the talk of the South Shore of Long Island, and beyond.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Indictment Of Priest In Abuse Case
description: A Baltimore priest was indicted on charges of sexually abusing a man more than a decade ago, a man who shot the priest three times last year. The indictment charges the priest, the Rev. Maurice J. Blackwell, 57, with four counts of sexual child abuse of the man, Dontee Stokes, from 1989 to 1992. Mr. Stokes, 27, admitted shooting Father Blackwell three times last May after the priest refused to apologize to him. Father Blackwell has denied abusing Mr. Stokes. Mr. Stokes was acquitted of attempted murder but was sentenced on handgun charges. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Fewer Feds at the Airport
description: The Bush administration has sometimes seemed reluctant to finance homeland security needs adequately. Still, it may come as a shock to many Americans that the Transportation Security Administration, the federal security force created in direct response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, is facing budget problems.

title: Focusing On Derby Favorites Doesn't Pay Off
description: The Kentucky Derby induces an annual case of network favorititis. No matter that only one post-time favorite had won the race in the past 23 years, NBC, and ABC before it, have usually focused on the horse with the shortest odds; when the winning horse upsets the favorite, there is invariably evidence of a tale that merited attention.

title: Yankees' Offense Backs Wells Again in Romp at Seattle
description: Last weekend, when they lost two of three to the Oakland Athletics in the Bronx, the Yankees scored 8 runs in 27 innings. Tonight at Safeco Field, they scored 10 in one inning against the Mariners.

title: JOURNEYS: Exploring the West By Day; In the Desert, A Wonderland Of Life Blooms
description: ALONG the main dirt road through Greenwater Valley in Death Valley National Park, where parched earth and sky usually stretch out nearly unrelieved to the horizon, a vivid flower-carpeted valley unfolds like a vast hallucination. Around every curve, astounding views open up in yellows and purples and reds, a fantasy scene in the desert that looks even more surreal through polarized sunglasses. In spring the desert is supposed to bloom, but in Death Valley it rarely blooms like this.

title: New Jersey Police Nominee Listens to Hours of Questioning Over Profiling
description: Joseph R. Fuentes, the acting superintendent of the New Jersey State Police and Gov. James E. McGreevey's choice to lead the agency, won approval today from the Senate Judiciary Committee after hours of questioning about his commitment to eradicating racial profiling in traffic stops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHN, ARYEH
description: ROHN-Aryeh. 83. Noted Jewish educator died May 7. Wife Rachel; children Dr. Reuven Rohn (Judy) of Virginia Beach, VA and Ruth Rohn (Paul Pascal) of Toronto; grandchildren Karen Alpert (Avi), Alisa Minden, Yoni Shalom Pascal; sisters Herta Holt and Charlotte Muenz. Services Friday, May 9 at 1:30PM East Midwood Jewish Center, Brooklyn. Burial in Long Island. Shiva is at the residence. Donations EMJC or Camp Ramah, 3080 Broadway, NY, NY 10027.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the strategy for growth at the AOL division of AOL Time Warner linked a characterization incorrectly to an executive's comment about customers who pay more than necessary to use AOL via some other company's high-speed connection. Lisa Hook, head of the AOL division's broadband service, discussed the practice (paying $24 a month for what they could receive for $10), but it was the writer -- not she -- who called it misguided.

title: Almost Any Set but 'Star Wars'
description: DVD sets, and news about them, have been the focus this week and last. Paramount announced that on Nov. 4 "Raiders of the Lost Ark," "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom" and "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade" will be released for the first time on DVD. The trilogy will make a four-disc set, with George Lucas, an executive producer of the films, Steven Spielberg, their director, and Harrison Ford, their star, adding comments to the extra features on the fourth disc.

title: Cabaret, the Champagne of New York
description: On a cold, rainy Friday in April, Feinstein's at the Regency, the 140-seat cabaret in the Regency Hotel that metamorphoses from a corporate breakfast nook in the mornings to a supper club at night, was packed with patrons who had paid a $60 cover charge to attend an extraordinary show that might never be seen again after its two-week run.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DoCoMo Reverses A Loss
description: Helped by sales of its popular camera phones, NTT DoCoMo Inc. of Japan said yesterday that it earned 213 billion yen ($1.8 billion) in the fiscal year that ended March 31, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company said it expected profit to nearly triple but revenue to grow just 1.9 percent this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Characters in Search of a Reason
description: It was easy to get interested in the dancers in Yasmeen Godder's ''Hall'' on Wednesday nignt at the Kitchen. They riveted the attention in this hourlong work by an Israeli choreographer. It was less easy to remain interested in the people they portrayed.

title: Which Way on the Mideast Road?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Tell Piazza To Consider Playing First
description: Mike Piazza sat in the Mets' dugout at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon, realizing his world was about to be altered. He stared blankly ahead, clutching his deep-brown catcher's glove and oblivious to the teammate seated next to him.

title: George Morrow, a Personal Computer Visionary, Dies at 69
description: George Morrow, a mathematician and programmer who was a member of a group of unorthodox hobbyists who were instrumental in creating the personal computer industry, died at his home in San Mateo, Calif., on Wednesday.

title: Amy Sillman
description: Brent Sikkema

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rates Unchanged
description: For the third consecutive month, the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged, at 3.75 percent, despite hopes among manufacturers for some economic stimulus. Economists said the bank's nine-member monetary policy committee seemed more concerned that a reduction would raise inflation at a time when the British pound is at a four-year low, making imported goods more expensive. Inflation has been above the bank's target of 2.5 percent for several months. The current interest rate is the lowest in almost 48 years. The European Central Bank also left its benchmark rate unchanged, at 2.5 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Port Authority and 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Which Way on the Mideast Road?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. APPROVES BB&T PURCHASE OF FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS
description: The BB&T Corporation's $2.97 billion acquisition of First Virginia Banks won Justice Department clearance yesterday after BB&T agreed to sell 11 First Virginia branches. The deal, announced in January, will create the 11th-largest bank in the nation. BB&T, founded after the Civil War to help rebuild farms and small businesses, has completed 150 takeovers in the last 14 years. The acquisition is subject to Federal Reserve Board approval. BB&T, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., also agreed to sell or lease any of the branches it closes as a result of the acquisition to any commercial bank that makes an offer that equals or exceeds any offer from another business.

title: Luc Tuymans
description: David Zwirner Gallery

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Replaces Chief
description: Kwan Cheong Ng resigned as the chief executive of the British retailer Laura Ashley as the company reported its first full-year loss in three years from sales of furniture and clothing. He will be succeeded next month by two executives, Ainum Mohd-Saaid, a lawyer and former Malaysian attorney general, and Rebecca Annapillai Navarednam, an accountant and former chief financial officer at the Regal Hotel Group and Corus, the steel maker. Announcing a full-year loss of 15.5 million ($24.7 million), the company also said it would continue to reduce its presence in Continental Europe to focus on operations in Britain.

title: Russia Urges Travel Limit On Suspicion Of SARS Case
description: Russia urged its airlines today to halt flights to and from China, Hong Kong and Taiwan and crimped entries along the 2,624-mile Chinese border after the authorities said they had tentatively logged the nation's first known case of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Redistricting Is Challenged
description: A redistricting battle may be headed to court after Democratic state lawmakers said a plan pushed through by Republicans this week was unconstitutional. The current Congressional map was drawn about two years ago by a judge when legislators disagreed on how to redraw the districts. The new plan gives Republicans an advantage, particularly for Bob Beauprez, who won his seat by 121 votes last year. Republicans hold a majority in the state House and Senate, and Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican, is expected to sign the legislation approving the new boundaries. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Michael Goldberg
description: Lennon, Weinberg

title: Laborers' Leader Takes Over Troubled Union-Owned Insurer
description: Terence M. O'Sullivan, the newly elected chairman of Ullico, the beleaguered union-owned insurer, said yesterday that he would try to save the company from going under and restore its reputation after it became the focus of four insider trading investigations.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: COURT NOMINATION ADVANCES Despite the fact that he sidestepped the chance to state his views on several issues, John E. Wallace Jr. was unanimously approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday for a seat on the State Supreme Court. Mr. Wallace declined to give his views on the death penalty, the Supreme Court's order to finance poor school districts and other issues. But the panel recommended that the full Senate approve his nomination in a vote set for May 19. If confirmed, he will replace Associate Justice James H. Coleman Jr., the first black man to serve on the court, who is retiring. Mr. Wallace, 61, is also black. (AP)

title: Moscow Musical Hit by a Chechen Bomb Fails to Survive
description: MOSCOW, May 9  The theater at the Moscow Ball Bearing Factory was thoroughly, impressively renovated. The walls that had been pocked with bullet holes were newly patched and painted. The red seats, once stained with blood, were replaced by plush blue ones. Metal detectors were installed.

description: COLLINS-Louise. Anne and Robert DelRusso mourn the death of our beloved sister and sister-in-law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOEL, MARTIN J. JR.
description: JOEL-Martin J. Jr. Beloved husband of Sylvia Joel and the late Dolores Joel. Died May 6 at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Loving father of Patricia (Howard Samuels) and Amy Joel, devoted grandfather of Dara and Andrew, caring brother of Alyse Klufer (Robert). Funeral services Sunday, May 11, at 10 AM at Ballard Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to a charity of your choice.

title: A Lofty Tone, Overall, With a Wink of Lunacy
description: Doric columns of fluted muslin, lighted from within, flank the entrance to the International Fine Art Fair, a production of the English art and antiques fair impresarios Brian and Anna Haughton. Inside the cavernous space of the Seventh Regiment Armory, a peaked ceiling of white fabric completes the picture of a Grecian temple. This is the spiritual realm of high art.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Higher Fees At Public Markets
description: The Bloomberg administration is considering an increase in the licensing and registration fees for private companies that operate in public wholesale markets like the Hunts Point produce market in the Bronx. The licensing has been used to deter organized crime at such markets. Jose Maldonado, chairman of the Business Integrity Commission, testified at a City Hall budget hearing Wednesday that the current fee of $350 for three years fails to cover the costs of criminal background checks and other procedures. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Divided Senate Panel Passes a Scaled-Down Tax Cut Bill
description: Voting mostly along party lines, the Senate Finance Committee approved a scaled-down tax cut today that satisfies few senators but moves the bill along a legislative path where it can be changed.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: MOROCCO: KING HAS AN HEIR AND FREES 9,000 PRISONERS King Mohammed VI celebrated the birth of a son and heir by ordering the release of more than 9,000 prisoners from Morocco's crowded jails, one of the biggest royal pardons in the country's history. In neighboring Algeria, the state radio said that President Abdelaziz Bouteflika had commemorated the forthcoming birthday of the prophet Muhammad by pardoning 5,000 inmates. The Moroccan baby, named Hassan after his grandfather Hassan II, is the first child of the king and his wife, Princess Salma Bennani. King Mohammed also reduced the jail sentences of more than 38,000 inmates. (Reuters)

title: Residential Real Estate; Trying to Differentiate Between Modest and Steep
description: Apartment owners throughout the city have been pummeled recently by maintenance and common-charge increases averaging 10 percent -- although some have been staggered by punches of more than 20 percent, according to co-op and condominium specialists.

title: Passengers Tumble Out as Jet's Door Fails Above Africa
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 9  The rear ramp of a Russian-made cargo plane crammed with soldiers and their families flew open high above the jungles of the Congo, officials and witnesses said today. Passengers fell from the sky.

title: 5th Resignation In Sex Inquiry Of Police Dept. In Connecticut
description: A police dispatcher here has resigned, joining four officers who have stepped down in recent days as the police force investigates allegations that they engaged in sexual misconduct while on duty.

title: To Meet Budget, Museum Sets Two-Week Shutdown
description: The Brooklyn Museum of Art has announced that it will close for two weeks in August, a casualty of the city's proposed budget cuts to cultural institutions.

title: Bomb Kills Police Officer in Chechnya's Capital
description: MOSCOW, May 9  A bomb exploded today outside the main stadium in Chechnya's capital, Grozny, killing one police officer and wounding two others, according to Russian news agencies.

title: New Setback For Taubman In Fighting Takeover Bid
description: A federal judge in Michigan yesterday stripped A. Alfred Taubman's family of its right to vote any of its shares to block a takeover bid for its shopping mall empire, Taubman Centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSNE, NORMA
description: SOSNE-Norma. Born September 20, 1925, deceased May 7, 2003. Survived by her adoring children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and countless friends. She gave us the gifts of love and laughter. She spread her cheer everywhere she went. Freed from the bondage of a terrible illness, her spirits are lifted but our hearts are broken.

description: Ryan Fraidenburgh was 14 when he was brought here shackled, kicking and screaming.

title: TOMMY HILFIGER ENDS SPECULATION ON POSSIBLE SALE
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation signaled yesterday that it was not for sale, setting off a 9 percent decline in its stock price. The company said it had hired J. P. Morgan Chase to provide advice on acquisitions of additional brands. Analysts and investors had speculated that the company was a possible takeover candidate for Jones Apparel Group because of a licensing dispute between Jones and Polo Ralph Lauren. Stock in the company fell 77 cents, to $7.85 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Reward Posted For Suspected Rapist
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has announced a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of a man wanted for the sexual assault and robbery of several women in Chelsea and the Bronx. Police officials said they were seeking the public's assistance in catching the man, who has attacked six women in elevators since Jan. 15. They asked anyone with information to call (800) 577-TIPS. The police described the attacker as a black man in his early 20's, about 5-foot-7 to 5-foot-10, weighing between 130 and 150 pounds. In two cases, he wore blue boots and a black skull cap. In the last three attacks, he wore his hair in cornrows, the police said.

description: WHEN the request for a few minutes of Pat Burns's time was relayed to the Devils' coach, the word came back that he just wanted to discuss hockey.

title: 36 Hours | Morgantown, W.Va.
description: THIS self-designated ''micro-city'' of 26,000 gets its most excited visitors in the fall when 65,000 blue-and-gold-clad football fans fill Mountaineer Stadium at West Virginia University, making Morgantown temporarily the largest city in the state. But it's actually in spring that the town explodes with life. The wildflowers are at their peak, the Cheat River is at its white-water wildest and bikers and skaters rip up and down the hilly streets. In the last decade, conservationists have converted 51 miles of rail corridor into bike trails with parks and picnic shelters. Preservationists have sparked a night-life scene along the riverfront and saved a grand old playhouse from destruction. Work has begun on a 15,000-seat waterfront theater. But the real appeal may be the lively and walkable downtown, gone neither to seed nor to preciousness. The lack of urban attitude takes some adjustment. When a store owner offers to lend you a vintage book overnight, or bikers slam on their brakes to let you cross, just smile and nod. You could get used to this. SUSAN BRENNA

title: Bush and Frist Call for Reform in Votes on Federal Judges
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 — President Bush renewed his push today to get quicker confirmation of his nominees for federal judgeships, and the Senate Republican leader offered a plan intended to do just that.

description: Philip Morris USA will not have to post more than $6.8 billion to appeal a $10.1 billion judgment stemming from assertions that the company misled smokers about the risks of ''light'' cigarettes.

title: A Brahms of Sharp Contrasts From Bavaria
description: Elite international ensembles are an exception in Germany's symphonic culture, which emphasizes many lesser orchestras serving regional needs over the exploitation of a chosen few. The Berlin Philharmonic, reconstituted as a cultural-political superweapon for the cold war, is the obvious anomaly, but we have been visited in New York by other German orchestras whose modest skills made one wonder why they were not at home tending honorably to local constituents.

description: The National Archives has given up, for the time being, efforts to determine what President Richard M. Nixon and H. R. Haldeman said during the 18 1/2-minute gap in a tape recording of a June 20, 1972, conversation about the Watergate break-in.

description: An article on March 31 about art once owned by Nikolai Khardzhiev, a Russian critic who died in 1996, referred incompletely to the outcome of a lawsuit brought by a gallery that had once been his dealer. The article correctly reported that the suit, by Galerie Gmurzynska in Cologne, Germany, against art experts who had questioned its tactics in obtaining and selling the works, was dismissed by a United States district court.

title: House Passes G.O.P. Bill to Cut Taxes by $550 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The House of Representatives voted today to cut taxes by $550 billion over the next decade, strongly endorsing President Bush's drive to stimulate the economy through lower taxes, but differing sharply with him on the size and nature of the stimulus.

title: Missing Share Of Sacrifice
description: Shoppers will soon pay more in sales taxes, and smokers more in cigarette taxes. Property owners are already paying more in real estate taxes, and upper-income New Yorkers are staring at a surcharge on their income taxes. Subway and bus fares are up. So are rents.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: SPECIAL TAX SESSION Gov. Bob Riley has asked the Legislature to meet in special session beginning on May 19 to consider more than $1 billion in revenue and government accountability measures. "The package I will present will be comprehensive in nature, addressing both tax reform and tax fairness as well as fundamentally reforming how we conduct business in Montgomery," Mr. Riley, a Republican who took office in January, told Seth Hammett, the House speaker, in a letter. Mr. Hammett said Mr. Riley's plan contained measures that could produce up to $1.2 billion, nearly twice the $600 million projected spending increase next year.

title: Into The Sunset
description: Chutzpah, according to the classic definition, is when you murder your parents, then ask for sympathy because you're an orphan. But what do we call it if after you are placed with foster parents, you try the same thing all over again?

title: Though its first quarter swung to a loss, Interpublic says it is working on a turnaround.
description: The troubles plaguing the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York continued in the first quarter. Interpublic said yesterday that higher costs, lower revenue for many units and another write-down at a struggling motor-sports operation contributed to a net loss for the quarter, in contrast to the modest profit that Wall Street had expected.

title: Germany Indicts Moroccan on Murder Charges in 9/11 Case
description: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, May 9  A Moroccan man accused of providing logistical support to the Sept. 11 suicide pilots was indicted on murder charges today by German prosecutors.
