description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today along straight party lines to send to the full Senate one of President Bush's nominees to a federal appeals court, but one of the Republicans whose vote provided the majority said he was still unsure whether he would vote for her confirmation.

title: All Right, Everyone, Into the Playpen
description: The most astonishing thing about ''Daddy Day Care,'' a comedy that would have to work harder even to justify the appellation uninspired, is that a kick in the groin is now a joke for toddlers. They are both the target audience and the co-stars of this Eddie Murphy vehicle -- more of a Big Wheel, really.

title: Iraqi Who Helped Rescue Pfc. Lynch Gets Book Deal
description: Only 10 days after receiving political asylum in the United States, the Iraqi lawyer who led United States marines to captured Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch has sold the rights to publish a book about his experience to HarperCollins for an advance of nearly $500,000.

title: Ex-Employee Sues Medical Gear Maker
description: Vital Signs, a maker of medical equipment, said yesterday that it was sued by its former chief financial officer, Joseph Bourgart, who quit amid accusations that he passed confidential data to an investor.

title: Judge Rules Disabled Student Will Be Sole Valedictorian
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that a South Jersey high school senior with an immune deficiency would be the sole valedictorian for her graduating class this year, after she contended that the school district was discriminating against her by proposing that two other students share the honor.

title: A Soldier's Story
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 9 - One of the enduring images of the war with Iraq was the sight of American M1A1 tanks rumbling through downtown Baghdad. But in this war there were many dramas that took place out of public view and away from the front lines.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Inquiry Over Tv Trial Coverage
description: Agents of the state-controlled television network, RAI, were sent to question the staff of one of its channels over its coverage Monday of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's corruption trial after the government said that a program had mocked him. For his part, Mr. Berlusconi, a conservative, accused the traditionally liberal channel of organizing an ''ambush'' at his appearance at the Milan trial by broadcasting the insults of a protester. Journalists decried the internal RAI investigation. Mr. Berlusconi, who directly or indirectly runs six of the country's seven national channels, has long been accused of manipulating the media. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: BERKSHIRE NAMES TWO BUFFETT FRIENDS TO ITS BOARD
description: Berkshire Hathaway said yesterday that it had named Donald R. Keough and Thomas S. Murphy to its board. Mr. Keough, 76, a retired Coca-Cola Company president, and Mr. Murphy, 77, a former chairman of Capital Cities/ABC, are longtime friends of Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire's chairman. They are likely to allow Berkshire to meet proposed requirements that companies have a majority of directors that are independent from management. Mr. Buffett has resisted changes to his board, which includes his wife, his son, an investing partner for the last four decades and two executives with business ties to the company. He has also argued that outside directors are not a requirement for good corporate governance. Mr. Buffett, 72, has known Mr. Murphy and Mr. Keough for decades and has been involved in several business transactions with them.

title: U.N. Draft: 'to Assist the People of Iraq'
description: Following are excerpts from a United States-supported resolution for the United Nations Security Council, from a draft copy circulated among diplomats. A full version is at nytimes.com/international.

title: 2 Men Get Stiff Sentences in China Over Worker Protests
description: BEIJING, May 9  Two men who promoted large worker protests in northeast China 14 months ago have been given stiff prison sentences, of seven and four years, on charges of subverting the state, court officials and relatives of the men said today.

title: A College as Eden, and a Most Nasty (Human) Serpent
description: Adam and Evelyn -- please note the symbolism of the names -- are graduate students who attend an Edenic Southern California college called Mercy. The institution's name is one of the many little jokes strewn like creative-writing-class rimshots through ''The Shape of Things,'' Neil LaBute's adaptation of his own play. Mercy may be the quality in shortest supply in Mr. LaBute's chilly, claustrophobic universe. His characters show as little toward one another as he does toward them -- or us.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: MICROSOFT CORRECTS SECURITY FLAW IN PASSPORT PROGRAM Microsoft, which had more than 70 security flaws last year, said yesterday that it had fixed a problem in its Passport user authentication program that could have allowed unauthorized access to millions of Web site accounts. Passport users have a single account name and password that can allow access to hundreds of Web sites without repeatedly entering the same information. There were no reports of unauthorized access caused by the flaw, Adam Sohn, a product manager for Passport, said. The program has 200 million active accounts and is used at more than 300 Web sites. Microsoft settled an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission last year by pledging to improve Passport's security. The F.T.C. said Passport deceived users by failing to protect the privacy of e-mail addresses and credit card numbers that were used to authenticate user identities. An F.T.C. lawyer, Jessica Rich, would not say whether the commission was investigating the security failure.

description: Two things are certain about the Knicks' search for three assistant coaches: the team will take its time and it wants one of the assistants to have head-coaching experience.

title: Corrections

title: Take a Spaghetti Western, Add French Dressing
description: Patrice Leconte's spare, weighted, comic melodrama, ''Man on the Train,'' features a delicious moment when Manesquier (Jean Rochefort), a garrulous retired schoolteacher, slips into the fringed leather jacket of his new friend, the taciturn thief Milan (Johnny Hallyday), who has stepped away. Manesquier pretends to be a western hero. Posing in the mirror, he rifles through a panoply of cantankerous clichs, which sound even more bizarrely likable in French.

title: The Tax-Cut Fixation
description: The best thing to be said for the tax-cut legislation being concocted in the Republican-led Congress is that the Senate version finally accepts the idea of providing emergency fiscal aid to the deficit-battered states. Even so, the $20 billion proposed is short of actual needs and is likely to be undercut by fresh state revenue losses resulting from other negative factors in the G.O.P. proposals.

title: How Iraq Can Get Over Its Past
description: Unscrupulous operators, who thrive in dictatorships, have a disturbing knack of surviving the wreckage when dictators fall, and of thriving, just as unscrupulously, under new regimes. In Japan after 1945, right-wing gangsters and bureaucrats who had done well in the war not only survived, but some ended up running the country. Shady figures of the Communist era still wield power in Romania and other parts of the old Soviet Empire. Military thugs of bygone juntas continue to have clout in South America. Nazi collaborators became cabinet ministers in postwar France. And so on.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: ELECTION BAN ON RADICAL BASQUE PARTIES Spain's highest court barred nearly 1,500 Basque nationalists from running in municipal elections this month, calling them camouflaged members of the outlawed radical nationalist Batasuna Party. After 16 hours of deliberation, a six-member panel at the Constitutional Court voted 5 to 1 to uphold most of an earlier ban ordered by the Supreme Court. That court struck down 241 lists of candidates in three Basque provinces and neighboring Navarra, totaling about 1,500 politicians. The Constitutional Court approved just 16 of those lists. The Supreme Court said that separatists had formed a party, Autodeterminaziorako Bilgunea, to skirt its March verdict outlawing Batasuna. (AP)

title: Fire-Grilling Instead of Flame-Broiling at Burger King
description: In a new strategy announced yesterday by Burger King executives, the restaurant chain will soon offer healthier menu items, try to improve customer service and market its ''flame broiled'' burgers as ''fire grilled.''

title: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; U.N. SENDS TEAM TO IRAQ
description: For the first time, the United Nations is sending a team of human rights investigators to Iraq for a long-term mission, officials said today in a news conference in Geneva.

title: Deflation Threat Dismissed
description: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said today that he saw no significant threat of deflation in the United States, three days after the Federal Reserve warned of a possible fall in inflation.

title: Air Shuttle Services Facing Hard Times
description: Airlines operating East Coast shuttles have traditionally courted travelers with all the zeal of a lovesick bachelor. They hand out free magazines, provide express check-in and sometimes shower frequent fliers with triple miles.

title: MANUFACTURED HOME BIDS FOR CHATEAU COMMUNITIES
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc., a real estate investment trust run by the financier Sam Zell, said yesterday that it had offered to buy most of Chateau Communities Inc. for $1.82 billion. Manufactured Home said the offer might be worth more than $26 a share to Chateau shareholders, a 4.4 percent premium to the closing price of $24.90 on Thursday. Manufactured Home disclosed the bid in a regulatory filing Thursday, which came after it rejected a proposed standstill agreement from Chateau that would have prevented it from buying Chateau shares for two years. This is the second time Manufactured Home has tried to buy Chateau. Chateau is based in Greenwood Village, Colo.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Bill To Tape Suspects' Statements
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich said he would sign into law a bill that would require the police to make audio or videotapes of questioning in homicide cases. The program would start in 2005. The bill was passed by the House on Thursday and the Senate on Tuesday. No statement by a suspect in custody would be admissible in court unless it had been taped, although statements outside the interrogation room would still be admissible if a judge found them reliable and obtained legally. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Englewood Theater Moves Closer to Reopening
description: The John Harms Center, a performing arts center in Englewood, N.J., closed since mid-April in the face of mounting debts, came a step closer to reopening yesterday as Fleet Bank and supporters of the center reached an agreement on restructuring its $2.3 million debt.

title: Exonerated, but on Their Own: Helping Those Cleared by DNA
description: About 20 mostly middle-aged men sat and listened politely as the young instructor went on about browsers and links and search engines, a foreign language in this room. Neil Miller, for example, had never sent or received an e-mail message, and set about creating his first account.

title: American Empire, Not 'If' but 'What Kind'
description: The 100,000 American troops patrolling Baghdad and other Iraqi cities retain ''absolute authority within Iraq,'' declared their commander, Lt. Gen. David McKiernan. At the same time, American forces are being deployed in a grand crescent surrounding the greater Middle East, from the Balkans southeast to Djibouti, east through the Persian Gulf region into Pakistan and Afghanistan, and north into Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan.

title: Jefferson Remains Calm And Has 20-Point Night
description: The noise was still deafening, a hostile screech from every corner of the Fleet Center, when Richard Jefferson floated toward the basket for his first shot of the night. But Jefferson clanged his dunk attempt off the rim, to the delight of the crowd.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Fire At Historic Market
description: A two-alarm fire ignited by grease in a pizzeria broke out in the historic Quincy Market parallel to Faneuil Hall in Boston. Flames and smoke rose up an air duct and out the roof of the three-story building, which is home to more than 50 food vendors and restaurants. More than 3,000 people were removed. Officials did not know the extent of damage. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: A Mostly Unfamiliar Four
description: It has been a stunning spring of emergence in the Stanley Cup playoffs. Three of the four remaining teams did not even exist until the 1990's and have never before reached this level in the postseason. One of them, Ottawa, is in bankruptcy protection and on the verge of new ownership. Another, Anaheim, is for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINKRANTZ, MURRAY H.

description: To the Editor:

title: Colleague Ill, So 30 Toronto Hospital Workers Are in Quarantine
description: Thirty health care workers have been placed in quarantine after a nurse administrator at a major Toronto hospital came down with symptoms that could possibly mean she is suffering from SARS, the respiratory disease that has spurred fears and throttled the city's economy in recent months.

title: New York Sniffs Out Smoke In 2 Bars, Lofty and Less So
description: With great fanfare this month, New York City set out to hunt violators of its new indoor smoking ban. So far, only two establishments have been bagged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ANN ROOKE, LEY
description: BERMAN-Ann Rooke-Ley. The Board of Governors and staff of The Museum of Arts and Design mourn the passing of Ann Rooke-Ley Berman, a longtime friend and Board member of the museum. Ann was a guiding light and inspiration to us all, and our deepest sympathies are with her family at this time. We will miss her wisdom and her smile.

title: 2 New Jersey Troopers Resign in Race-Profiling Scandal Involving 1991 Videotapes
description: Two New Jersey state troopers at the center of a new racial-profiling scandal resigned from the state police today, amid growing concern about videotapes showing the troopers stopping black drivers and using racial slurs.

title: PHARMACIA SETTLES SUIT OVER BUSINESS SOLD TO KELCO
description: The Pharmacia Corporation, which is owned by Pfizer Inc., said yesterday that it had settled a lawsuit with C.P. Kelco U.S. Inc. over the purchase of a gum-additives business. The terms were not disclosed. Kelco had sought $430 million in damages, claiming it overpaid when it bought the gum business from Pharmacia for $592 million in 2000. The settlement ended jury deliberations in a trial that began two weeks ago in federal court in Delaware. Kelco is a joint venture between Hercules Inc. and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.

title: U.S. Shifts Its Mideast Focus To Press for Easing of Tension
description: After a year of working toward publishing a peace plan for Israel and the Palestinians, the United States is setting the proposal aside for now and instead pressing both sides to take immediate steps to ease tensions, administration officials said today.

title: New York City's Terrorism Needs
description: New York City has spent $1 billion on antiterrorism efforts since the Sept. 11 attacks. But the city says it has yet to receive a dollar of antiterrorism money from the federal government. Washington has provided millions to help clean up the damage. But an estimated $44 million in antiterrorism money now in the pipeline has apparently not reached New York, the city that bore the brunt of the most disastrous terrorism strike in American history.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Israel Bombing Suspect's Relatives In Court
description: The police identified the three people under arrest in connection with a suicide bombing in Tel Aviv last week as the sister, brother and wife of Omar Khan Sharif, 27, of Derby, who is still being sought by the Israeli security forces. Mr. Sharif's wife, Tahira Tabassum, 27; his sister, Parveef Sharif, 35; and his brother, Zahid Hussain Sharif, 46, were all charged with failing to disclose information about acts of terrorism. Parveef Sharif was also charged with aiding terrorism overseas. The bombing, which killed three people and injured 50 others, was carried out by Asif Hanif, 21, a Briton from West London. Mr. Sharif is said to have fled the scene after his explosives failed to detonate. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Ways to Reach a Troubled Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Militia Men Attack Packed U.N. Compound in Eastern Congo
description: The compound of United Nations peacekeeping forces in the lawless eastern Democratic Republic of Congo came under attack this afternoon, with militia groups and angry youths hurling insults, then stones and, finally, mortar shells into the grounds. A United Nations area commander suffered a minor stab wound when a mob attacked his car, a United Nations spokeswoman said.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON NOT LIABLE IN PROPULSID CASE
description: Johnson & Johnson is not responsible for the death of a 46-year-old man who died two months after he began taking the company's Propulsid heartburn medicine, a California jury decided yesterday. The jury said Propulsid, which was removed from the market in 2000 after being linked to 70 deaths, was not a substantial factor in the death of John Calvert of Napa, Calif. The ruling is the third court victory in a Propulsid case for Johnson & Johnson. The company still faces 750 lawsuits around the country involving the drug. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: U.S. Warns Promoters of SARS-Related Products
description: The government said yesterday that it had warned more than 40 Web site operators and companies to stop making false claims that their products can prevent, cure or treat SARS. The products include air purifiers, sprays and wipes, masks, latex gloves, and supplements like colloidal silver, beta glucan, echinacea, mushrooms and other items that are said to strengthen the immune system.

title: Jack Gelber, 71, 'Connection' Playwright
description: Jack Gelber, whose play ''The Connection,'' with its raw, graphic depiction of the dead-end life of drug addicts, sent a shock wave through contemporary American theater, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reward but No Risk
description: Republicans are pushing hard to reduce the tax on dividend income, arguing that the government unfairly taxes it twice. Dividends come from corporate profits, which are taxed, and the individual stockholder who receives the dividend check also pays Uncle Sam. Therefore, President Bush argues, reducing -- or better yet repealing -- the tax on stockholders would treat dividend revenue like other income, reducing free market imperfections.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Profit For Brewer
description: AmBev, Brazil's largest brewer and the world's fifth-largest beer maker, posted a first-quarter profit of $175 million, more than double the figure from a year earlier, after an acquisition in Argentina. AmBev said profit rose to 509 million reais ($175 million) from 222.8 million reais in the first three months of 2002. The results included earnings from AmBev's 40.5 percent stake in Argentina's leading brewer, Quinsa. AmBev had more than 69 percent of the local beer market in March, up from 67 percent in December.

title: Lucent to Form a Network Sales Team
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it was forming a separate sales team to seek network-services contracts as demand for switches and other components declines.

title: Hapsburgs Ask Austria to Return Estates Seized by Nazis
description: The heirs to the Hapsburg dynasty, whose forebears ruled central Europe for over 600 years in an empire that once stretched from Russia to Spain, have asked the Austrian government to return forests, homes and a palace seized by the Nazis on the eve of World War II.

title: Bush Seeks a Free Trade Zone With the Mideast by 2013
description: President Bush today offered a powerful economic incentive to the nations of the Arab world by proposing the creation of a United States-Middle East free trade area by 2013.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about renewed efforts to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment referred imprecisely to the deadline established for state ratification when the measure was approved by Congress in 1972. The deadline was extended by three years in 1979; it was not originally 10 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDLEY, CHRISTOPHER F.
description: EDLEY-Christopher F. International House notes with sadness the passing of Christopher F. Edley, who served with distinction as a member of the Board of Trustees from 1975 until 1986. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his family. Paul A. Volcker, Chairman Donald L. Cuneo, President

title: Senate Panel Votes to Lift Ban on Small Nuclear Arms
description: A sharply divided Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to repeal a 10-year-old ban on the development of small nuclear weapons, asserting that the United States must begin looking at new ways of deterring terrorist groups and so-called rogue nuclear powers like North Korea.

title: Correspondent Is Killed in Iraq In a Car Crash
description: Elizabeth Neuffer, an award-winning correspondent for The Boston Globe, was killed today along with her translator when the car they were traveling in hit a guard rail near the city of Samarra, north of here.

title: Airline Seeks Approval for Iraq Flights
description: Northwest Airlines has filed an application with the Transportation Department to start flights between Detroit and Baghdad through Amsterdam, according to documents submitted to the department.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the effect of the SARS epidemic on some Americans' plans to adopt babies in China misspelled the name of the New York county where three babies were deemed suspect SARS cases. It is Onondaga, not Onandaga.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jocelyn Herbert, 86, British Stage Designer
description: Jocelyn Herbert, a noted British stage designer, died on Tuesday in London. She was 86.

title: Scott's Comments Irk Mayor
description: Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston demanded an apology yesterday from Nets Coach Byron Scott for agreeing in a radio interview earlier this week that Boston was still a difficult place for African-American athletes to play in.

title: Bill Offers Option of Compensatory Time
description: Congressional Republicans and corporate America thought they had a family-friendly idea that workers would love -- give them the choice of taking compensatory time or time-and-a-half overtime pay when they work more than 40 hours a week.

title: The Celtics Bring Back Ainge as an Executive
description: The Boston Celtics may be playing in the Eastern Conference semifinals, but their owners have no illusions that the team is championship caliber. So, in the midst of the series with the Nets, the team moved quickly to name Danny Ainge as the team's executive director of basketball operations.

title: PENSION FUND WILL NOT VOTE FOR AOL DIRECTORS
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the largest pension fund in the nation, said yesterday that it would not vote for five AOL Time Warner Inc. directors. The fund, known as Calpers, questioned the directors' independence and the roles they played on the audit committee of AOL Time Warner. Calpers said it would withhold votes from James Barksdale, the former chief executive of Netscape; Stephen Bollenbach, former chief executive of the Hilton Hotels Corporation; Fay Vincent, the former Major League Baseball commissioner; Franklin Raines, the chairman of Fannie Mae; and Miles Gilburne, managing director of ZG Ventures. Calpers holds 20.4 million shares of AOL Time Warner. Because there are only 13 nominees, all of them are likely to secure positions on the board regardless of Calpers's votes.

title: Oh, Life Was Sweet And Paris a Bonbon
description: Remember when Americans thought it was swell that France was such a foreign country? When good Yankees went to Paris to learn to be bad? When there were books, movies and Broadway shows devoted to celebrating la diffrence between them and us?

title: Editorial Observer; Karl Rove's Campaign Strategy Seems Evident: It's the Terror, Stupid
description: Hailed as the White House's political genius, Karl Rove was as ebullient and unrevealing as the Great Oz in journeying here this week for no apparent reason. He seemed to be scouting restlessly for some Tin Man or Cowardly Lion among the passel of Democrats on the campaign road that passes through here next winter.

title: G.O.P. Seeks To Ease Rules On Filibusters Of Judgeships
description: After weeks in which Democrats have used Senate rules to block the confirmation of some of President Bush's judicial nominees, Senate Republicans said today that they would try to change those rules.

title: Few Tears Shed for Closing Of Brooklyn's Big House; Rikers Would Take Inmates in Consolidation Enabled by a Decline in People Behind Bars
description: Say goodbye to all that. To the long lines of girlfriends carrying babies and grandmothers carrying bail. To the sad comings and goings, and occasional escape, of men already convicted or just accused. To the catcalls and shouts mysteriously emanating from behind the multitude of tiny, reinforced panes of glass looming over Atlantic Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A rock review of the reconstituted Doors on April 26 referred incorrectly to the way the keyboardist, Ray Manzarek, played bass lines onstage for the original group in the 1960's. He used a Fender Rhodes piano bass, not organ pedals.

title: They're Innocent, But Not Truly Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Legends' Shadows Don't Scare Alabama's Shula
description: Mike Shula was introduced as Alabama's 26th football coach today in the Crimson Tide football complex, which is on Paul W. Bryant Drive and down the street from Bryant-Denny Stadium, the Paul W. Bryant Museum and the Bryant Conference Center. Shula is the seventh coach since 1983 to have to compete with the legendary status of Bear Bryant and the brick-and-mortar reminders of his legacy.

title: They Were Funny Guys (Is That the Punch Line?)
description: SERIOUSLY FUNNY

title: Ways to Reach a Troubled Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Taubman Centers Reports a Quarterly Loss
description: Taubman Centers Inc. said yesterday that it had a first-quarter loss because of legal expenses as it defended itself against a hostile takeover attempt by a rival mall owner.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Woman Dies In Flooding
description: A flooding Chattahoochee River has led to a death. On Thursday, a woman, Ethel Bray, 47, of Pine Mountain, drove into a hole where a stream had washed out a culvert. She was found a mile from her car, troopers said. Officials also shut an Interstate 85 bridge. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Boston Mayor Wants Apology
description: Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston demanded an apology yesterday from Nets Coach Byron Scott for agreeing in a radio interview earlier this week that Boston was still a difficult place for African-American athletes to play in.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: A Bill To Sell Park Names
description: Lawmakers are considering a measure to sell corporate naming rights to the state's parks and forests. The House of Representatives voted this week to draft guidelines for sponsoring sites, which include Walden Woods. A spokesman for Representative Bradley Jones Jr., the House minority leader who drafted the bill, said it offered ''intriguing, interesting ways in increased revenues'' without raising taxes. The guidelines now move to the Senate. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: An Overseas Penalty Stays; Tax Cut Goes
description: Advocates of a crackdown on the overseas operations of United States companies won two victories this week during Congressional negotia tions over an economic stimulus plan.

title: Jury's Query Heartens Defense In Crown Heights Stabbing Trial
description: The jury in the Crown Heights racial violence retrial finished its third day of deliberations yesterday without returning a verdict. But before they left federal court in Brooklyn for the weekend, the jurors sent out a note that stirred hope among some of the defendant's lawyers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Internet Bankruptcy
description: The district court in Suwon has placed Onse Telecom, 28.3 percent owned by Hynix Semiconductor, in court receivership. The decision means that Onse, the smallest of South Korea's four Internet service providers, is bankrupt and does not have to meet deadlines repaying its loans, which total 420 billion won ($352 million). The ruling adds to pressure on the banks that hold most of the equity in Hynix to sell its assets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Neighbor's Vision of the New Iraq
description: In the mid-1980's, when Saddam Hussein started attacking commercial ships in the Persian Gulf, initiating the ''tanker war,'' Iran proposed the establishment of a security and cooperation arrangement in the region to prevent the widening of the Iran-Iraq war and to ensure stability in the area. This idea was later enshrined in United Nations Security Council Resolution 598. The resolution brought the Iran-Iraq war to an end, but the provision on regional security foundered.

title: Israel Agrees With End But Not Means Of Peace Plan
description: On the eve of the first visit to Israel by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell in more than a year, the government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon faces a delicate diplomatic task: seeking to substantially change a new American-backed peace initiative without appearing to obstruct it.

title: Summer May Bring a Bottled Water Price War
description: The bottled water industry is on the verge of a price war that could drive down the substantial profit margins enjoyed by bottlers like Coca-Cola, Pepsi and Nestl and, according to some analysts, drive smaller competitors out of business.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: BANK'S PROFIT FALLS Korea First Bank, 51 percent owned by Newbridge Capital, reported a net profit of 12.4 billion won ($10.4 million) for the first quarter compared with 26.8 billion won a year earlier. The bank, the smallest of South Korea's eight commercial banks, said the loss was in large part a result of the need to provide extra funds to cover defaults in credit card payments. Most other South Korean banks have also reported large declines in first-quarter earnings as a result of delinquent payments on o credit card loans.

title: Israel Arrests 2 Rights Workers in New Crackdown on Activists
description: Israel increased its pressure on foreigners in the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, arresting a human rights worker and a pro-Palestinian activist and imposing new restrictions on travel to Gaza.

title: Bryant, With Help, Leads Lakers
description: The Los Angeles Lakers returned home to the arena where they had won three championships tonight and found something they were unsure they still had: a genuine supporting cast, someone other than Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant to combat the size and depth of the streaking San Antonio Spurs.

title: 2 Promoters of Worker Protests in China Get Prison Sentences
description: Two men who promoted large worker protests in northeastern China last year have been given stiff prison sentences on charges of subverting the state, court officials and relatives of the men said today.

title: Tough Competitive Standard In Cavendish Teams Event
description: If asked to select the toughest 16-team event ever played, the cognoscenti would probably select a round of 16 in one of the world championships, the Spingold Knockout or the Vanderbilt Cup. That would have been the right answer last week. Today, however, it is the Cavendish Teams played in Las Vegas on Wednesday and Thursday. Almost every player was a national or international champion, and the conditions of contest allowed each team to play its best lineup at all times.

title: Star of 'Gypsy' Returns After Prolonged Absence
description: The producers of the hit Broadway revival of ''Gypsy'' were promising yesterday that the musical's star, Bernadette Peters, would be back in the show last night after several days of cancellations because of a respiratory infection.

title: Looking for Hope in an Apartheid Monster's Eyes
description: The black woman saw him whenever she thumbed through her newspapers or switched on the television: the tall white man with thick glasses.

title: No Relief Dooms Weaver and Yanks
description: Jeff Weaver has been the most inconsistent of the Yankees' starters this season, but Joe Torre believes in him. ''He's going to be one of the great ones, I think,'' Torre, the Yankees' manager, said before tonight's game. ''He's special.''

title: TROY GROUP RECEIVES BUYOUT OFFER FROM WESTAR
description: The Troy Group, a maker of systems to transfer funds between bank accounts, said yesterday that an investment firm had offered $37.3 million for the company, topping a bid from Troy's chief executive. Westar Capital offered to buy Troy, including the majority stake held by its chief executive, Patrick Dirk, and his family. Westar bid $3.50 a share, 39 percent more than the closing price Thursday, the company said in a regulatory filing. Mr. Dirk, the founder of the company and holder of more than half its stock, is not interested in selling his stake, Troy said. In March, a company controlled by Mr. Dirk and his family agreed to buy the rest of Troy for $2.70 a share.

title: On Order From Bush, U.S. Troops in Iraq Begin Disarming Iranian Opposition Group
description: Acting on a decision by President Bush, American commanders in Iraq have begun efforts to disarm an Iranian opposition group whose status had been the subject of weeks of review at the highest levels of the Bush administration.

title: Ways to Reach a Troubled Child (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Webber To Miss Remainder Of Playoffs
description: Despite the offensive outburst by the Dallas Mavericks in Game 2 of their Western Conference semifinal series, the focus has shifted to the health of the Sacramento Kings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AAYER, ABETHA
description: AAYER-Abetha. My wife, my love, my friend. Unbelievably, a year, unforgettably, a life. Forever, Aaron.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, the text of a peace plan for the Middle East on May 1, as provided by the State Department via The Associated Press, misstated a word in the final paragraph. The affected passage, referring to "The Permanent Status Agreement," should have read: "Arab state acceptance of full normal relations with Israel and security for all the states of the region in the context of a comprehensive Arab-Israeli peace"  not "compressive."

title: Iraq's Old Money Elite Vies for Stake in Rebuilding the Nation
description: Khalil al-Bunnia, heir apparent to one of Iraq's biggest family empires, says he had to be ''flexible'' to thrive under Saddam Hussein.

title: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; AFGHANISTAN: U.S. ASSURANCES
description: Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage made a brief detour to Afghanistan today, on his way from Pakistan to India, to deliver a personal message from President Bush that he would not forget Afghanistan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about women's representation in the National Academy of Sciences miscalculated the percentages of women on physics faculties at American universities in 1994 and 2002. The percentage rose to 10 percent from 6 percent -- not to 32 percent from 23 percent.

title: KEY3MEDIA WINS COURT RULING ON ITS RECOVERY PLAN
description: A federal judge said yesterday that the Key3Media Group, the technology trade show company that produces Comdex, could line up the support of creditors for a bankruptcy recovery plan. Judge Jerry Venters of United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware said the company could send its revised plan to creditors, moving it a step closer to exiting Chapter 11. The company will ask the court for final approval June 4. Key3Media filed for bankruptcy protection in February and said it would reduce its debt and transfer ownership to Thomas Weisel Capital Partners.

title: Victim of Terror, Russian Musical Closes
description: The theater at the Moscow Ball Bearing Factory was thoroughly, impressively renovated. Walls once pocked with bullet holes were newly patched and painted. The red seats, once stained with blood, had been replaced with plush blue ones. Metal detectors had been installed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, PAUL, JR.
description: MOORE-Paul, Jr., 83, bishop, activist, father of Honor, Paul, Adelia, Rosemary, George, Marian, Daniel, Susanna and Patience, brother to William H. Moore, and grandfather of 19, died May 1st, 2003 at home in NYC. Funeral and requiem mass to celebrate his life and work at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 110th and Amsterdam, NYC, Saturday, May 10th, at 4 PM. Reception to follow. The body will lie in state at the cathedral May 9th, 5-8PM, and May 10th, 9AM-2PM. Burial service 2pm, May 12th, Calvary Church, Stonington, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Humanitarian Project (Paul Moore Medical Clinic, East Timor), PO Box 32307, Washington, DC 20007.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Backs a Tax Cut Bill; Senate to Vote Next Week

title: ENRON PLANS NEW COMPANY FOR OVERSEAS ASSETS
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to form a company for most of its overseas utilities, power plants and pipelines, ending an effort to auction the assets. The new company, temporarily named InternationalCo, will be governed by an independent board and will be protected from liabilities related to the bankruptcy, Enron said. The assets include 19 companies in 12 countries and Guam, including Elektro, an electric utility in Brazil, and SK-Enron, the largest natural gas distributor in South Korea. Enron said in August that it would auction the assets to help repay more than $50 billion in debts. After reviewing bids, Enron decided to keep the businesses, a spokesman, John Ambler, said. About 8,000 of Enron's 12,000 employees will become part of the new company, Mr. Ambler said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOEL, MARTIN J. JR.
description: JOEL-Martin J. Jr. Beloved husband of Sylvia Joel and the late Dolores Joel. Died May 6 at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Loving father of Patricia (Howard Samuels) and Amy Joel, devoted grandfather of Dara and Andrew, caring brother of Alyse Klufer (Robert). Funeral services Sunday, May 11, at 10 AM at Ballard Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to a charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Wednesday about the retirement of Alain Dominique Perrin, chief executive of Richemont, the Swiss luxury-goods manufacturer, misstated the location of Domaine de Lagrezette, a wine estate that he owns in France. It is in Cahors, not in Bordeaux.

title: Bloomberg Aims to Move Many Infirm Welfare Recipients Into Work Force
description: The Bloomberg administration is embarking on an ambitious plan to move a large number of the last group of welfare recipients not enrolled in a work program into the work force. They include the sickest recipients, who now account for the majority of people on welfare.

title: In Grip of AIDS, South African Cries for Equity
description: IT'S not unusual to sense urgency in a dying man. For Abdurrazack Achmat, every emotion -- rage, fear, pride -- feels magnified by a factor of five million.

title: Billions in Charity Money Could Be Saved, Study Says
description: When he was in politics, Bill Bradley, the former senator from New Jersey, was known for proposing big ideas to shake up the established order and entrenched constituencies. So perhaps it should not be a surprise that he is now doing the same thing to the world of philanthropy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Record Chief Who Lost Case Expected to Keep His Tempo
description: Competitors and colleagues of Lyor Cohen, the chairman and chief executive of the Island Def Jam Music Group, do not expect him to become less aggressive about his business even though he was ordered to pay $132 million in a civil court case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, EDNA
description: BRENNER-Edna, 83. Devoted and adored wife of the late Morton R. Brenner. Most exceptionally loved mother of Susan and Steven. Mother-inlaw of Lili. Loving and cherished grandmother of Marjorie and Jill. Admired and loving sister of Bebe Davis and Philis Weiss. Funeral services Sunday 11:30AM, Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, DAVID W.
description: RUBIN-David W. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with deep sadness the passing of our former Senior Vice President and Director of our Concert and Artist Department, David W. Rubin, on May 6 in NYC at the age of 83. Mr. Rubin began his career at Steinway & Sons in 1964 at the invitation of Henry Z. Steinway to head its Concert and Artist Department. In 1979 he was appointed Vice President and assumed additional responsibilities as head of Steinway's public relations program. In 1982 he was named Senior Vice President, a post which he held until his retirement in 1986. A graduate of Princeton, Mr. Rubin studied piano with Alexander Lipsky and Robert Casadesus. He also worked as an artist representative from 1945 to 1956, managing the careers of Ania Dorfman, Grant Johannesen, The Juilliard String Quartet, and George Tozzi among others. His dedication to the Steinway piano was unwavering. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughter, Capers, and to his family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, VP Concert and Artist Activities

title: Tall Tales Of Appalachia
description: CBS is developing a reality TV series modeled after ''The Beverly Hillbillies,'' the 60's sitcom. A poor family from a remote corner of southern Appalachia will be transported to a California mansion, the ensuing comic antics shown to America.

title: In a War of Fluid Front Lines, A Soldier's Struggle and Death
description: It was on a stretch of highway near Baghdad that Pvt. Kelley Prewitt was shot, and to this day Staff Sgt. Jimmy Ealon Harrison, an Army medic, cannot get the young man's slow death out of his mind.

title: Sports of The Times; Muzzling Scott Isn't Best Option
description: Here's a thought for Lou Lamoriello and Rod Thorn: If you're thinking of calling Byron Scott on the rug for recent inflammatory comments he has made, don't. The Nets are on fire.

description: It was a quiet day at the open-air market for stolen government cars today. But then the American troops arrived to restore order.

description: Korea First Bank, 51 percent owned by Newbridge Capital, reported a net profit of 12.4 billion won ($10.4 million) for the first quarter compared with 26.8 billion won a year earlier. The bank, the smallest of South Korea's eight commercial banks, said the loss was in large part a result of the need to provide extra funds to cover defaults in credit card payments. Most other South Korean banks have also reported large declines in first-quarter earnings as a result of delinquent payments on o credit card loans.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Mets Start to Repair Rift With Piazza on Shift to First
description: The Mets could not shut the Pandora's box they opened Thursday when they fumbled the job of telling catcher Mike Piazza they wanted him to begin working out at first base, but they began the slow process of trying to repair their relationship with him yesterday.

title: Get Ready for Britons Bearing 1,290-Pound Stoves
description: Will Americans, confused by a lackluster economy and wearied by higher energy costs, pay $12,000 for a nearly five-foot-wide enameled iron stove that has no dials, no gauges -- and is designed to stay on all the time?

title: Corrections
description: The On Stage and Off column in Weekend yesterday, about front-runners for Tony nominations, misstated the timing of Bernadette Peters's return to ''Gypsy'' after an illness. Ms. Peters returned to the show last night, not on Thursday night. An article about her absence and its effect on the show appears on Page B12.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, the text of a peace plan for the Middle East on May 1, as provided by the State Department via The Associated Press, misstated a word in the final paragraph. The affected passage, referring to ''The Permanent Status Agreement,'' should have read: ''Arab state acceptance of full normal relations with Israel and security for all the states of the region in the context of a comprehensive Arab-Israeli peace'' -- not ''compressive.''

title: Big Dreamer at Small College
description: At a select liberal arts school like Allegheny College, ''raising the bar'' most often refers to academic rigor, not pole-vaulting. Rarer still is the vaulter who stands 6 feet 9 inches, as does Jeremy Scott, a height that makes him more likely to be a power forward than a power jumper.

title: After Game 3, Nets-Celtics Rivalry Looks a Bit One-Sided
description: Jason Kidd's desire burned far more than his ears did tonight as raucous Celtics fans hurled insults and booed him all game.

title: Nine Are Accused of Faking Money Orders Worth Millions
description: They called themselves ''Al Moroccan Empire,'' or, more simply, ''the Moors.'' They have renounced American citizenship, do not feel encumbered by any laws and believe the United States owes them money, federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Bob Walter, 86, California Horse Breeder
description: Bob Walter, a prominent horse breeder whose champion Cavonnier finished second in the 1996 Kentucky Derby, died on Wednesday at his home in Sebastopol, Calif. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEYER, GERMAINE M.
description: SPEYER-Germaine M. Wife of the late Ernest A. Speyer. Died in her 90th year. Mother of Vivian and Donald Sonnenborn, Jerry Speyer and Katherine Farley. Grandmother of Valerie and Jeffrey, Robert, Holly and Jonathan, Laura, Jonah, Andrew and David. Great-grandmother of William, Charles and Arden. Special friend and ''Grandmother'' to many. Funeral services private. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Columbia University for the Germaine M. Speyer Scholarship or to the Shoah Foundation.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bank Acquired
description: Britain's fourth-largest bank, HBOS, said it would buy the 43 percent of the Bank of Western Australia that it did not already own for 1.05 billion Australian dollars ($664 million) to ''maximize the value of its investment'' in the bank. HBOS purchased a stake in BankWest, which has 24.43 billion Australian dollars in assets, in 1995. Last year BankWest's profits fell 7 percent, to 212.6 million Australian dollars, because of a rise in bad business loans. HBOS said it would finance the deal with existing capital. BankWest is based in Perth. Its shares rose 19 percent on the news while shares in HBOS were flat. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Bio: Erika Nickrenz
description: Erika Nickrenz, the pianist with the Eroica Trio, began playing when she was 6 and made her concerto debut when she was 11, at Town Hall in New York. By then, she was already playing sonatas with Adela Pena, who became the violinist in the Eroica Trio. And when she was 12, Ms. Nickrenz met the violist Sara Sant'Ambrogio after studying with Ms. Sant'Ambrogio's grandmother at a music camp. Sara Sant'Ambrogio is the cellist in the Eroica Trio.

title: End of Dispute Between New York and Indian Tribe Removes Obstacle to a Catskill Casino
description: The Pataki administration and the St. Regis Mohawk tribe have resolved a last-minute dispute that held up the signing of an agreement to settle the tribe's land-claim lawsuit and open the way for a new Mohawk-run casino in the Catskills, an administration official said today.

title: Panel Urges Complete Ban On Products With Asbestos
description: Asbestos should be banned from all new products sold in the United States, according to a draft study from a panel that included doctors, business and government experts and union representatives.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STOFFMAN, ANNA BIROVA
description: STOFFMAN-Anna Birova. In loving memory of our grandmother, who died on Mother's Day 50 years ago, May 10, 1953, but whose strength, dignity, courage and devotion to family lives on in the hearts of her grandchildren, Alan M. Koral and Marianne K. Smythe

title: Two at Times Win Journalism Awards
description: Floyd Norris and Glenn Kramon of The New York Times are among the winners of the 2003 Gerald Loeb Awards for Distinguished Business and Financial Journalism.

title: NASA Appoints New Chief For Space Shuttle Program
description: William W. Parsons, an engineer who directs a NASA field center, was appointed today to manage the space shuttle and take charge of sending the spacecraft flying again, the space agency announced.

title: Amid Concerns Over Deflation, Bond Market Has Strong Week
description: The bond market had its best week in years, the stock market eked out small gains and the dollar fell sharply after the Federal Reserve's surprise announcement that it was worried that continued economic weakness could convert falling inflation rates into a bout of deflation.

title: U.N. Reaction to Resolution Seems Positive but Reserved
description: Anxious to avoid a repetition of the battles that split the Security Council before the war, most diplomats here put a positive face on the resolution presented today by the United States, Spain and Britain seeking approval for allied forces' control of Iraq's political development and oil revenues.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''The Trip'' misspelled the brand name of steak knives often advertised on television as a bonus -- an extra to which the story's third act was compared. The brand is Ginsu, not Ginza.

title: Abortion Foe Who Killed Doctor Is Sentenced to 25 Years to Life
description: An abortion opponent who fatally shot an obstetrician in the doctor's suburban home was given the maximum sentence of 25 years to life today, after a rambling 90-minute speech in which he exhorted his ''younger brothers and sisters in the movement'' to carry on his crusade.

title: Senate version would revoke exclusion : House tax bill spares Americans overseas
description: WASHINGTON:  Two tax bills, one of which requires Americans overseas to take the brunt of lost federal tax revenues, started winding their way through Congress on Friday.

title: Brooklyn to Celebrate Its Bridge on May 24
description: Brooklyn will celebrate its famous bridge this month -- one year after an anniversary festival was canceled over fears of terrorism.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ESTE LAUDER COS., New York, maker of Clinique and Bobbi Brown cosmetics, said it had acquired the Michael Kors Fragrances business from LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Paris. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Law Firm Got Big M.T.A. Fees In Troubled Job
description: Six years ago, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority hired a small law firm to negotiate a lease for a huge office building that was supposed to provide an affordable answer to the authority's long-term need for space.

title: Scores May Have Fallen to Death as Plane Loses Door Over Congo
description: The rear door of a Russian-made cargo plane crammed with Congolese soldiers and their families flew open in midair, 33,000 feet above the jungles of Congo, dropping scores of passengers down a ramp and into the sky, survivors said today.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: 'Lockdown' At Columbine High School
description: Columbine High School near Littleton was ''locked down'' all day after officials became aware of threats in graffiti at the school. Students could not leave the building unless they had specific appointments. Officials said the messages were penciled on restroom walls and a sidewalk and warned of harm, but not to any individual or group. On April 20, 1999, two seniors shot and killed 12 students, a teacher and then themselves. Since those shootings, the school has received threats and imposed lockdowns a few times. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, ELIAS
description: STEINBERG-Elias. Died at 85 on May 8, 2003 in Nashville. Beloved father of Ronnie and Arthur, brother of Leo, grandfather of Jennifer Levine, David and Peter Steinberg, and Brian and Elizabeth Ames. He was a decorated test-pilot during WW II. He was the manager of the family bakery, and a golfer in his retirement. Funeral services Sunday at noon at Schwartz Bros. in Forest Hills, and burial will be in Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. We loved him dearly, he made a difference in our lives, and he will be missed.

title: Turkey's Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Loss Widens as Softbank Spends Heavily
description: The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese telecommunications and Internet holding company, said today that its losses mounted last year as it continued to spend heavily to promote its high-speed Internet service.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about the development of Boston area buildings in niche markets, like life science research and academia, misstated the location of Harvard's new biotechnology building. It is in Boston, not Cambridge.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Request To Delay Campaign Finance Ruling
description: Government lawyers asked a three-judge federal panel to delay imposing a decision last week that overturned parts of the campaign finance law until the Supreme Court ruled on it. The Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission said failing to grant a stay ''would have tumultuous consequences for the nation's federal electoral system.'' Noting that the panel struck a ban on national parties' raising and spending large corporate and union gifts, the government said, ''Millions of dollars of soft-money transactions by the national party committees might go unreported'' if they relied on the recent ruling to resume collecting soft money. Richard A. Oppel Jr. (NYT)

title: Taipei Seals Housing Project As Taiwan Tries to Halt SARS
description: Two buildings in a public housing project here were quarantined today because of three suspected SARS cases inside, raising the anxiety level of a city trying to clamp a lid on the epidemic's spread.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Spare Times listing in some copies of Weekend yesterday about the Brooklyn Botanic Garden misstated a closing time and the admission prices. On Tuesdays through Sundays the garden closes at 6 p.m., not 4:30. Admission is $5 ($3 for students and 65+; under 16 free) -- not $3 ($1.50 for students and 65+; 16 and under, free).

title: Defining the U.N. Role in Iraq
description: Since the diplomatic meltdown at the Security Council in March, the Bush administration has treated the United Nations with disdain, giving it only a minimal role in the reconstruction of Iraq. That would remain largely so under a new resolution presented to the Security Council yesterday, but the American plan would at least bring the U.N. back into play and might begin to heal the divisions produced by Washington's decision to go to war.

title: AFTEREFFECTS: Briefly Noted; GERMANY: SEPT. 11 INDICTMENT
description: German prosecutors indicted Abdelghani Mzoudi, a 30-year-old Moroccan and a suspected member of Al Qaeda who is accused of providing logistical support to the pilots in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. He was charged on 3,066 counts of accessory to murder in connection with the attacks.

title: Celtics Bring Back Ainge as an Executive
description: BOSTON, May 9 — The Boston Celtics may be playing in the Eastern Conference semifinals, but their owners have no illusions that the team is championship caliber. So, in the midst of the series with the Nets, the team moved quickly to name Danny Ainge as the team's executive director of basketball operations.

description: Disarming Group in Iraq

National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: BILL TO TAPE SUSPECTS' STATEMENTS Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich said he would sign into law a bill that would require the police to make audio or videotapes of questioning in homicide cases. The program would start in 2005. The bill was passed by the House on Thursday and the Senate on Tuesday. No statement by a suspect in custody would be admissible in court unless it had been taped, although statements outside the interrogation room would still be admissible if a judge found them reliable and obtained legally. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Third Arrest as Inquiry Widens Into Under-Age Sex at a Club
description: Officials involved in an investigation into illicit sex and other possible crimes that centered on a club for teenagers here said that they had arrested a 19-year-old man on witness-tampering charges and had found three additional under-age girls who said they had had sex with adult employees of the club.

title: NVIDIA SHARES SURGE AFTER STRONG SALES FORECAST
description: The Nvidia Corporation, whose computer graphics chips help run Microsoft's Xbox video game console, said yesterday that its second-quarter sales might top forecasts, setting off a 33 percent gain in its share price. Sales in the second quarter ending in July may rise as much as 18 percent, to $478 million, from the first quarter because of demand for Xbox chips, Nvidia executives said. Shares of Nvidia, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose $5.31, to $21.37.

title: David W. Rubin, 83; Matched Pianists With Their Instruments
description: David W. Rubin, a longtime Steinway & Sons executive whose deep love of the piano compelled him to spend his career prodding talented musicians to try even harder as he matched them with their concert instruments, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Man Is Slain in Chinatown
description: A 27-year-old man was shot to death last night in Chinatown, the police said.

title: Berlusconi, in a Rough Week, Says Only He Can Save Italy
description: Even for Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, it was an unusually tumultuous week.

title: Seo Shows Inexperience, And Mets Show Ineptitude
description: Jesse Orosco leaped off the mound and hurled his glove into the air the last time the Mets won a World Series. That was 17 years ago, but the way the Mets are playing, it's a moment that seems from another lifetime.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: JOBLESS RATE RISES Layoffs by hotels and restaurants in Toronto resulting from the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, contributed to a rise in Canada's unemployment rate to 7.5 percent in April from 7.3 percent in March, Statistics Canada reported. Almost 19,000 jobs were lost last month, including 18,400 in accommodation and food services. Manufacturing and construction also cut workers, reinforcing recent evidence of a weakening economy. The losses in these sectors were partly offset by higher employment in government, financial services and retailing. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: White House Aides Confer With 200 Gay Republicans
description: At a time of intense debate over the relationship between gays and Republicans, 200 members of the Log Cabin Republicans, a gay group, met today with senior White House officials. The name of Senator Rick Santorum, the Pennsylvania Republican whose impolitic remarks about gays prompted the current debate, did not come up.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: A BILL TO SELL PARK NAMES Lawmakers are considering a measure to sell corporate naming rights to the state's parks and forests. The House of Representatives voted this week to draft guidelines for sponsoring sites, which include Walden Woods. A spokesman for Representative Bradley Jones Jr., the House minority leader who drafted the bill, said it offered "intriguing, interesting ways in increased revenues" without raising taxes. The guidelines now move to the Senate. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Shock Therapy for Police Recruits
description: What kind of person constitutes a threat to public safety and the general welfare? When do you unholster a gun and when do you use it? Where is the line between a rights-bearing citizen and a rights-forfeited lawbreaker? Law enforcement aspirants generally expect answers in concrete terms, with strict guidelines made clear as to what separates the good cop from rogue cowboy. And it's what civil rights advocates, editorialists and the public also expect.

title: Mayor and Union Head Agree: The Other One Needs to Budge
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg lashed out yesterday at New York City's municipal labor unions, saying they have yet to do their share to help reduce the city's expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHULSKY, ANNE
description: SCHULSKY-Anne and Alexander. We're sorry you're not with us to celebrate your 61st wedding anniversary. What a time you'd have with Grady. What a grand time we'd all have together.

title: Report Raises Questions on Success of Immigrant Interviews
description: Law enforcement officials have interviewed more than 3,000 Muslim and Arab immigrants living in the United States as they have hunted for terrorists in the months after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, a Congressional report has found.

title: WELLS FARGO WINS COURT RULING IN CALIFORNIA DISPUTE
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that a federal judge ruled in its favor in a dispute with California over how the bank charges interest on loans. Judge Garland Burrell of United States District Court ruled that the federal government has the exclusive right to regulate national banks and their operating units, Wells Fargo said in a statement. Earlier this month, a California agency revoked Wells Fargo's ability to make home loans under a state law that says lenders cannot charge interest until the day before a mortgage is officially recorded with the state.

title: Facing Diapers, Drool And Even Doubts
description: ''Baby I'm Yours,'' a look at three new mothers with varying degrees of attachment to their young, is a documentary, though it could easily be called ''reality TV'' if that term were not an instant hyperlink to the image of two dozen women in a Jacuzzi angling for the attention of one tire-fortune heir.

title: Korea's New Wave
description: I was born and raised in South Korea until immigrating to the United States in the 1980's when I was 13. Last year, I visited both Koreas and witnessed anti-American protests in Pyongyang and Seoul. Fifty years after the armistice ended the Korean War on July 27, 1953, significant factions on both sides of the 38th Parallel hate America.

title: Flames of Nazi Oblivion
description: Seventy years ago today, a series of conflagrations lit up the night in a number of German cities. By the standard of the Reichstag fire earlier that year or the firestorms to come in the years ahead, these fires were unimpressive. But each was surrounded by a sizable crowd -- many people there students and most of them giddy with ideological fervor -- that fed the flames with piles of books. The aim was to cleanse Germany of un-German literature, ''Jewish intellectualism'' and works by Nazi enemies. Students had cleared their own shelves and the shelves of libraries of books by a list of authors that would make a respectable library in itself. The events of that day and the American response to it are the subject of a new exhibition called ''Fighting the Fires of Hate'' at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.

title: Man's Case in 9/11 Inquiry May Be Moved to Illinois
description: Federal prosecutors have agreed to dismiss charges in Manhattan against a Qatari man who prosecutors say was associated with Al Qaeda, and will instead prosecute him in Illinois, a new court filing shows.

title: Fight for Tax Increases Raises Profile of City Council Speaker
description: The West Wing of City Hall feels a bit like a ship riding out a storm. Taxes are going up. The number of city employees is going down. Public outrage is cresting. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's poll numbers are bottoming out.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Governor In 165 M.P.H. Crash
description: Gov. Michael F. Easley was uninjured except for ''a bruised ego'' when he crashed a race car at 165 miles an hour into a foam wall at 11:45 a.m. at Lowe's Motor Speedway in Concord, said a spokeswoman, Cari Boyce. Mr. Easley, far right, was practicing to run today in the Winston Cup Nascar all-star race. He is trying to keep the race in the state past its one-year contract and raise donations for a school program if he exceeds a certain speed, Ms. Boyce said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Saudis Seek 19 Suspected of Terrorist Plot
description: After a shootout in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, and the discovery of a major arms cache there, Saudi authorities are pursuing 19 Islamic militants with ties to Al Qaeda who now appear to have been planning a substantial terrorist attack, Saudi and American officials said today.

title: Sales Decline at French Media Company
description: Lagardre, the large French media company, said today that first-quarter sales fell 12 percent, hurt by lower revenue at its aerospace business.

title: Fear, Not SARS, Rattles South Jersey School
description: For three years, artists and dancers from the New York Chinese Cultural Center have traveled in May to Vineland, N.J., to perform folk dances and discuss Chinese culture with students at two middle schools. But this week, when five of the artists arrived at Landis Intermediate School to begin their program, they were met at the door by school officials who told them they were not welcome after all, because parents were fearful that the visitors might be infected with SARS.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Cost Cuts At Airline
description: Cathay Pacific Airways asked all of its 14,000 workers to take four weeks special leave to cut costs after the SARS outbreak caused the worst slump in bookings in the airline's 57-year history. All employees, including the chairman, James Hughes-Hallett, and the chief executive, David Turnbull, will be asked to take four weeks off from June to September, the airline said.

description: Layoffs by hotels and restaurants in Toronto resulting from the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, contributed to a rise in Canada's unemployment rate to 7.5 percent in April from 7.3 percent in March, Statistics Canada reported. title: A Suspected Weapons Lab Is Found in Northern Iraq
description: An American military unit found an abandoned trailer outside a missile testing site in northern Iraq today that they suspect was a mobile biological weapons laboratory. It was the second such find in recent weeks, and could potentially bolster the United States' claim that Saddam Hussein's government was producing biological and chemical weapons.

title: Smoothing Bebop's Edges Into Voluptuous Curves
description: Over the last decade or two, as the musicians of the bebop years have grown older, we've been lucky to notice something: the salutary effects of aging on that youthful music. Barry Harris's commitment to the pianists of the bop era, particularly Bud Powell and Thelonious Monk, has been unequaled. And as he continues -- as a teacher and as a performer -- to reveal the mysteries of their music, the hard glint of the originals grows softer, the edges rounder, the lines more flexible and permeable.

title: NEW TRAIN ALMOST READY TO ROLL

The agency expects the line to serve about 6,000 passengers daily. Stacy Albin

title: The Rickety Ladder to Space
description: The fragile underpinnings of human spaceflight were spotlighted last week when an investigating board described how the shuttle Columbia disintegrated, and a Russian space capsule carrying three crew members back from the International Space Station landed 300 miles short of its target. With the American shuttle fleet temporarily grounded and the Russians unsure what caused their Soyuz capsule to plunge off course, the way into space looks increasingly uncertain. Some difficult decisions will have to be made in coming months as to whether the aging shuttle fleet can be resuscitated quickly at a bearable cost or whether some newer means of vaulting into space should be pursued more aggressively.

title: Editors' Note
description: Ten days ago, Jayson Blair resigned as a reporter for The New York Times after the discovery that he had plagiarized parts of an article on April 26 about the Texas family of a soldier missing in Iraq. An article on Page 1 today recounts a chain of falsifications and plagiarism that unraveled when The Times began an inquiry into that Texas article. At least 36 more articles written by Mr. Blair since October reflected plagiarism, misstatements, misrepresentation of the reporter's whereabouts or a combination of those. title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: CHOOSING a favorite scene from LOVELY AND AMAZING (2001) is tough -- so many are so painfully true. Some people like the one in which Emily Mortimer stands stark naked and asks her one-afternoon-stand to criticize every aspect of her face and body, please --and he actually does it. I'm taken with Catherine Keener and her husband discussing the frequency of their lovemaking while never taking their eyes off a ''Deputy Dawg'' cartoon on TV. And everyone agrees that Raven Goodwin is astonishing in every one of her scenes. Playing the youngest of the three sisters, she is adopted, black and, at age 8, already plagued by hairstyle insecurities and body-image issues. This absurdist drama -- written and directed by Nicole Holofcener, who did ''Walking and Talking'' -- stars Brenda Blethyn as the sisters' mother, who goes into the hospital for a little abdominal liposuction and ends up at death's door -- Friday at 7 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: Stravinsky's Psalm On Psalm Singing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREDA, VINCENT J. M.D.
description: FREDA-Vincent J. M.D. The faculty, staff, and students of Columbia University Health Sciences mourn the passing of a highly esteemed and accomplished mentor, colleague, and friend, Dr. Vincent J. Freda. Dr. Freda has been a member of the Columbia community for over five decades, first as a student in the 1940s and then as a respected member of the teaching faculty from the 1960s to the 1990s. Dr. Freda's contributions to the fields of obstetrics and maternal-fetal medicine are both numerous and far-reaching, and have helped to save thousands of lives throughout the world. Dr. Freda led the research team that developed Rhogam, the antibody that enables women with Rh-negative blood to deliver healthy Rhpositive babies. In 1959, he became the first doctor in the United States to perform amniocentesis; five years later, he was the first in the world to perform surgery on a fetus. The 1980 Albert Lasker Clinical Medical Research Award winner for his discovery of Rhogam, Dr. Freda was named clinical professor emeritus of obstetrics and gynecology at Columbia and honored with a fellowship in his name for perinatalogy research in 2000. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Vincent Freda Fellowship Fund in Perinatalogy at the Sloane Hospital for Women (c/o Chairman, Department of OB/GYN, 622 W. 168th St., 16th Floor, New York, NY 10032). We extend our most heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Carol Ury, his daughter Pamela, his two sons, Andrew and Bradley, and his three grandchildren. He will be missed by all who knew him. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences Dean, Faculties of Medicine and Health Sciences, Columbia University Mary D'Alton, M.B.B.C.h. Chairman, Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology, Columbia University, College of Physicians & Surgeons

title: May 4-10; HOPE EMERGES FOR MUSEUM RICHES
description: Like hunters for lost treasure, American and British officials are still trying to locate the missing jewels of the National Museum of Iraq in Baghdad. At first, it was feared that all its archaeological riches were looted when the museum was ransacked. Now, a month later, it appears that the looting, while extensive in scope, did not affect all parts of the museum's collection. Most of the looting, authorities now say, took place in storage areas where more than 100,000 more commonplace objects, of importance principally to scholars, were kept. But many of the museum's jewels may have been spared because Iraqi officials apparently stored them safely in repositories before the war, a top British Museum official said. American authorities in Iraq say that the hunt for those repositories is on, but what officials will find when they open these modern-day tombs is anybody's guess. Barry Meier

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, LEANNE BOVET
description: ROBERTS - Leanne Bovet. Passed away on Wednesday, May 7, 2003, after a short illness. She was at home, surrounded by her family. Leanne grew up on the Borel Family estate in San Mateo. It was there that she began her lifelong love of animals. She was known in the neighborhood for her unusual pets. As a 4H project she raised a lamb that bonded with the family's dog. The two would roam the neighborhoods to the surprise of the residents there. As a result she got to know the local SPCA well. She subsequently served on the Board of the San Francisco SPCA. Mr. Ed Sayres, President of the SPCA, had this to say: ''We have lost a great friend and supporter. During her long tenure on our Board of Directors, Leanne brought passion, vision and unwavering support to our mission. She was engaged, forward-thinking and dedicated to the cause of saving homeless animals. Thanks to a lead gift from Leanne and George Roberts, The Roberts Medical Center at the San Francisco SPCA will provide a new level of health care for animals throughout the Bay Area. The Roberts Center will be a lasting tribute to Leanne's remarkable compassion and generosity.'' Leanne was a long time member of the Board of Directors of the San Francisco Zoo. President of the Zoo, David Anderson said, ''Leanne Roberts was a cherished friend of the San Francisco Zoo. She was devoted to the animals and helped us ensure the very best care possible for animals at the Zoo. We will always remember her quiet, graceful strength.'' Additionally, Leanne served as a Board Member of the SFMOMA. She had an uncanny ability to appreciate the best in art. Leanne was educated at Orme school in Arizona, and Pitzer College in Claremont, where she met her future husband George. They were married over 35 years. She is survived by her husband, and their three children, Eric, Mark and Courtney, and her two daughters-in-law, Poppy and Kelley. Leanne is also survived by her mother, Mrs. Henry Howard, her two sisters Mrs. Howard Egger-Bovet and Mrs. Robert I. MacDonnell, and her beloved companions Sherman, Chauncey and Lykon. Her eldest son and daughter will carry on her legacy by taking over the management of Stone Canyon Ranch, where she raised world-class American Horses. Leanne will be remembered for her grace, poise, her style, her quiet strength, her serenity, her love and devotion to her family, friends, and all of God's creatures. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in her memory to the San Francisco Zoo, 1 Zoo Road, San Francisco, CA 94132 or the SF SPCA, 2500-16th Street, San Francisco, CA 94103. Services will be private.

title: Up With the Originals
description: IN its fabled appetite for self-cannibalization, Hollywood has a way of replicating successful ideas until even the originals become tainted by the tacky remakes and rip-offs. Such was the undeserved fate of the Doris Day-Rock Hudson comedies, which had the misfortune to outlive the mindset in which they began, dwindling into stale genre comedies pairing Ms. Day with Cary Grant and James Garner. In 1959, when ''Pillow Talk,'' their first film together, opened, we were still very much in the peppy-preppy repressive 50's. Only a few years later, Hollywood's strait-laced Production Code was losing its grip, the sexual revolution was on the horizon, the smell of pot was in the air, women were preparing to storm the barricades, black was becoming the mandatory color and Ms. Day was still defending her virginity. title: Sing to Us, Muse, of the Rage of the Hulk

What to make of this overgrown mama's boy, so often petty, jealous, sulking and, when called finally to action, murderous? That he also, at the end of Homer's poem, sits and cries, in mutual mourning, with his enemy, King Priam, whose sons he has slaughtered, only adds to our confusions about the nature of his heroism, and of the heroic legacy he has left us. For as every reader of Homer knows, Achilles would soon go on to kill more of Priam's people, all the while knowing he himself was doomed to die in Troy.

title: On Top of the World
description: The allure of the Himalayas, the appeal of the region to mountaineers, religious pilgrims and armchair trekkers alike, is on full and resplendent display in EVEREST: Summit of Achievement (Simon & Schuster, $50), a collection of photographs, documents and maps, with accompanying essays from the Royal Geographic Society of London. Its publication coincides with the 50th anniversary of the first successful ascent of the world's highest peak by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay on May 29, 1953. The society's Everest Archive, begun in the 1850's, includes the expected images of eerily beautiful mountain expanses, dogged climbers and variegated Tibetan monasteries (some since destroyed by the Chinese), all of which resonate with historical and cultural interest. The archive is described almost wistfully as ''part of the Victorian legacy of empire'' because the intrepid exploration of the Himalayas, which featured prodigious feats of surveying and mapping from the late 1700's on, followed expanding imperial rule in India. The spiritual significance of the area to Sherpas and Buddhists also elicits postcolonial concern: the famous reply of the English climber George Mallory to the question of why he wanted to climb Everest -- ''because it's there'' -- is interpreted as a myth ''expressing a basic human desire to explore -- but he missed the myths of the people already living there.'' John Motyka
