I'm aware that the law does not require interest-bearing accounts for buildings with fewer than six units. But the law also states that if deposits were held in interest-bearing accounts, that interest is due the tenant. Whose responsibility was it at closing to make sure any interest was transferred? . . . Jim Carden, Brooklyn.

title: 'White Teeth' in the Flesh
description: CONTRARY to the ideas of your average male M.F.A. student, fiction writing is not really about power. Properly executed it becomes the exact opposite of worldly power. It neither hurts nor heals in any material sense; no phalanx of soldiers will broach borders for it, no one will lose or gain employment as a result, and no babies shall be birthed. Its sublime bloody uselessness -- here lies its attraction for this particular novelist. For even if I am very bad at it, nothing too bad will come of it. I am a bit like my Archie Jones that way: the less practical effect I have in this world, the happier it makes me.

title: SUMMER MOVIES DVD's; The 'Hours' Extras? Just Buy 'Mrs. Dalloway'
description: YES, there are all kinds of DVD's. Some come so many decades after the original movie that the event can be as touching as it is informative. And others are so swift and upholstered, you feel they are part of the academy campaign. So, on the one hand, it's heady having Nicole Kidman, Julianne Moore and Meryl Streep all at the same hushed level of intimacy, very definitely three voices from one anima, whispering into your ear about ''The Hours'' and how lovely it was and how privileged they were to do the film. And at first you think you're bound to get a lot of insight from this commentary. But no, the voices don't actually talk to one another; it's not as if the three ladies are all in one booth together, giggly and dishy and naughtily alive. No, they've been recorded in hallowed privacy, like voices from Art's grave. And quite quickly you get the impression that they're going to tell you how marvelous Ed Harris was, and how looking into his bright blue eyes made Ms. Streep feel that all the necessary rehearsal and preparation had been done. Instead of the slightest hint about, didn't you think Ed was over the top and a bit of a pain in the neck?

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODE, WILLIAM JOSIAH
description: GOODE-William Josiah. The former Franklin H. Giddings Professor of Sociology at Columbia University, and former President of the American Sociological Association, died unexpectedly on May 4, 2003. The author of 20 books and over 80 articles on a wide range of topics, ranging from ''Religion Among the Primitives'' (1951) to ''World Changes in Divorce Patterns'' (1993), he was an Emeritus Professor of Sociology at Stanford University at the time of his death. William J. Goode was best known for his pioneering cross-cultural analysis of marriage and divorce. Drawing on his knowledge of nine languages, his pathbreaking monograph World Revolution and Family Patterns (The Free Press, 1963) analyzed data from over 50 countries to reveal the critical impact of family systems on what was previously assumed to be purely economic forces. Born in Houston TX in 1917, and encouraged by his high school debating coach Lyndon B. Johnson, he attended Rice Institute and the University of Texas, Austin. He served in World War II as a radarman on an attack transport ship in the Pacific. He joined the Columbia University faculty in 1950 where he taught for 27 years (1950-1977). In 1977 he became a Professor of Sociology at Stanford University, and in 1986 he joined the Sociology Department at Harvard University. He was a distinguished quest lecturer in China for the Chinese Academy of Science in 1986, and a Visiting Professor at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in 1992. Known as Si to his friends, he was often referred to as a ''Renaissance man'' excelling in a wide range of activities including painting, sculpting, sailing, mycology, tennis, and birding. In the past 5 years he won several tennis trophies and published an article on ''bird watching with your ears.'' He is survived by his wife, Lenore J. Weitzman, Robinson Professor of Sociology and Law at George Mason University; three children, Erich Goode, Visiting Professor of Criminology and Criminal Justice at the University of Maryland and an Emeritus Professor of Sociology at the State University of New York at Stonybrook, Barbara Baldwin, Women's Health coordinator for the Washington DC Department of Heath; and Andrew Josiah Goode, an architect in Shingle Springs, CA; and a sister Rosalie Grizzle of Magnolia, TX. His family is planning a ceremony with military honors at the Columbarium of Arlington National Cemetery (date to be announced.) They would welcome contributions to the William J. Goode international fellowship which is being established in his honor by the American Sociological Ass'n in Washington, DC.

description: RUBIN-David W. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with deep sadness the passing of our former Senior Vice President and Director of our Concert and Artist Department, David W. Rubin, on May 6 in NYC at the age of 83. Mr. Rubin began his career at Steinway & Sons in 1964 at the invitation of Henry Z. Steinway to head its Concert and Artist Department. In 1979 he was appointed Vice President and assumed additional responsibilities as head of Steinway's public relations program. In 1982 he was named Senior Vice President, a post which he held until his retirement in 1986. A graduate of Princeton, Mr. Rubin studied piano with Alexander Lipsky and Robert Casadesus. He also worked as an artist representative from 1945 to 1956, managing the careers of Ania Dorfman, Grant Johannesen, The Juilliard String Quartet, and George Tozzi among others. His dedication to the Steinway piano was unwavering. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughter, Capers, and to his family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, VP Concert and Artist Activities

title: Polgar Starts Mightily, Then Collides With Leko
description: The Hunguest Hotels Super Tournament, which began in Budapest on April 11, saw the strongest woman in the world, the Hungarian grandmaster Judit Polgar, get off to a fiery start with 3-0 in her first three games. Her victims were Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, Peter Acs of Hungary and Zoltan Almasi of Hungary. She fought for and achieved the initiative in each game and won with sparkling play. It looked as though she would run away with this all-grandmaster event.

title: The Way We Live Now: Encounter; The Odd Lady and the Sea
description: It's not easy to find good scallops in St. Petersburg. But, then, Ingrid Bengis, one of America's most famous fishmongers, wasn't preparing seafood for her guests. On a recent Saturday, she had gone to the farmer's market with an eye to Chinese stir-fry for her dinner party but returned with a squash, bok choy and pieces of bacon. Now, Bengis bustled around the apartment she shares with her husband, Edouard Palei -- and where she has spent half of every year since 1996 -- fussing over napkins and serving spoons. Her curly salt-and-pepper hair frothed over her ears. She moved with a decisiveness that made her gait look like marching. At last her guests were assembled. Andrei, a dean at the aviation institute and a friend of Edouard's from his days as a ballet dancer, and Rebecca, a soft-spoken American art student on a Fulbright, tasted the arrestingly sweet onion soup. After the next course, a salad of shredded beets, raisins, bok choy and cheese, Andrei's face clouded with confusion. ''American salad?'' he said to Rebecca, smiling bravely. Bengis chattered on, unaware of the cold reception her food was getting. Her husband helped carry in the main course, grainy buckwheat and squash flavored with bacon. It was the final straw for Andrei's palate. He took a few polite bites, then put his fork down. Edouard chewed dutifully.

title: Homicidal Monster Seeks Same
description: WHEN the first ''Nightmare on Elm Street'' was released in 1984, it was in a sense already redundant: teenage horror films had become a predictable franchise of disfigured monsters seeking vengeance among semi-clothed young people. By then there had been three ''Halloween'' films; that same year the ''Friday the 13th'' series would reach its fourth installment, called ''The Final Chapter,'' though that must have been a joke even then.

description: To many who knew him, Brian Morris seemed to lead a charmed life. Tall, handsome, and popular, he was a star of the football and baseball teams at Tuckahoe High School, where he was to have graduated from next month. And he had a girlfriend who many considered the most beautiful girl in the school.

title: Introduction
description: Was Niall Ferguson serious? Or was he playing devil's advocate in his essay, which drew the overwhelming majority of mail, by suggesting that we might take a page from the governance by the British in, say, the Raj? Others weighed in on the expat actor John Malkovich and his world-class ego.

title: The Way We Live Now: Page Turner; Maile Meloy, writer An Author With Authority
description: To ignore a couple of time-honored writerly rules of thumb -- write what you know; show, don't tell -- takes nerve. To do so without showboating or proclaiming yourself a literary rebel takes self-possession. And to create vital, persuasive fiction while you're at it takes something else -- talent, obviously, and that rare quality readers long for and seldom find in an author: authority. Maile Meloy has it in spades. Somehow she pulls off what never quite seemed possible before: combining the meticulous realism of domestic fiction with the witchery of a natural-born storyteller.

title: The Way We Live Now; The Country Of Country
description: Last week, I watched ''Wag the Dog,'' the 1997 Barry Levinson film about a Hollywood producer who is hired to create a television war to cover up a domestic crisis. The first call he makes is to a character played by Willie Nelson. Every war needs a theme song after all, even a fake war, and so Willie flies out to California and walks around the swimming pool, strumming his guitar and riffing on words like ''America'' and ''proud'' and ''free.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLLAGE, ARTHUR H.
description: KROLLAGE-Arthur H. of Scott's Beach, Long Island, a decorated World War II veteran and employee of the New York Times for 37 years, died on May 2, 2003 at the age of 81 after an eight year battle with cancer. Mr. Krollage began his career with the New York Times as a security guard. For 32 years he served as the executive in charge of security and reception for the executive floor. He served under publishers Arthur Hays Sulzberger, Orvil Dryfoos and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger. Mr. Krollage hired and trained many office boys who went on to achieve prominent positions within the company. He also served as the Chairman of the Supervisory Committee for the New York Times Credit Union. He retired in 1985. Gay Talese, in his book about the New York Times ''The Kingdom and the Power'' once described Mr. Krollage as, ''polite, soft spoken; an individual with...reddish hair who seems large and tall enough to redirect angry visitors from the street who occasionally intrude to complain about the state of the world or about one of John Oakes's editorial indiscretions against some distant sultan.'' Known for his friendly manner and dedication to his job, Mr. Krollage, seated at his desk outside the publisher's office on the 14th floor, greeted presidents, heads of state and some of the most famous personalities of our time. During WWII, Mr. Krollage served as a corporal in the Army Air Force and was a decorated veteran of campaigns in Bismark, Archipelago, Luzon, New Guinea, the Northern Solomons, the Southern Philippines, and the Western Pacific. He was honored with seven medals of valor. All who knew Mr. Krollage will mourn his passing. A dedicated family man, he is survived by his wife of 57 years, Gladys; two sons, Arthur and Robert; a daughter, Susanne Avino; six grandchildren and countless friends.

It has managed to climb the slippery pole, and it's trying to work around the large plastic baffle that blocks its way to the bird feeder. Sooner or later, I think, I'll feel sorry for it and go out to scatter a few seeds on the ground. But suddenly, with a great wriggle it's up and over the baffle and feasting on my expensive birdseed.

description: DESPITE its grandiose title, ''The New Vulgarians: New York Pop '' at the Princeton University Art Museum is a modest little survey show. Organized by the Princeton art history lecturer Branden Joseph, it draws together 18 minor Pop art prints, drawings and a few sculptures to illustrate how appropriation and mass reproducibility played a major part in the Pop aesthetic. This is hardly a new idea, although the show tries to broaden the notion of what Pop was by highlighting some of the more discomforting aspects of the popular that it invoked. Helen Cunningham, the mother of the former N.B.A. star forward and coach of the 1983 champion Philadelphia 76ers, is one of the more than 1,700 people who in the last two weeks sent e-mail messages or wrote letters of appreciation to Cheeks, the Trail Blazers' reserved but effective coach.

title: The Price of Power
description: On July 24, 1998, a lone gunman entered the United States Capitol. He wore a green fedora and carried a .38 Smith & Wesson, with extra bullets in his pockets. He was not a particularly good shot, but he had the rare clarity of mind of someone propelled by delusion, including the firm belief that there was a ''ruby satellite system'' in the Capitol that could reverse time. At the front door, he drew his pistol only inches from a Capitol Police officer's head and shot him, point-blank. He then turned near a statue of Abraham Lincoln and began shooting at another officer. In the exchange of gunfire, a tourist was hit in the face. As the intruder approached the office of Representative Tom DeLay, a detective named John M. Gibson yelled for everyone to get down. Staff members hid under their desks. Gibson opened fire, hitting the gunman again and again before collapsing himself.

Since 1972, the league has organized seven show houses to raise money in support of its mission, ''Children at Risk,'' for underprivileged children. Most of the houses -- multiroom dwellings that could spark a decorator's imagination -- were distressed and about to be sold. At the league's event three years ago, the owners had just moved in. When Piazza's two-run homer landed 395 feet away, the Mets had beaten the Padres in 10 innings, 4-2, and they now had an opportunity to enact a ritual that has become increasingly rare this season: they leapt over the dugout railing and jumped onto Piazza as he crossed the plate, haircuts and position changes forgotten for at least a few minutes.

description: ROBERT GLASPER: Over the last few years, mostly at the Up Over Jazz Cafe in Brooklyn and the Jazz Gallery in Manhattan, this 23-year-old pianist has been perfecting a free-range style: he seems to have his eye not on the bar of music he's playing but on the whole piece as one great canvas, and he moves around in it, bass and drums synched to the ebb and flow. ''Mood'' (Fresh Sound), his first album, with the bassist Bob Hurst and the drummer Damion Reid, does the trick several times, through standards (''Blue Skies'') and originals (''Lil Tipsy''). It owes a lot to Keith Jarrett, but there's more gospel in its harmonies and hip-hop in its rhythms. And Bilal, the R & B singer, puts in two eccentric but fascinating performances.(Available from www.freshsoundrecords.com)

Some of the grander examples, like the nation's first hospital and its first zoo, simply carry on uninterrupted, while the less noted may be luncheonettes or shoe stores, medical offices or condominium apartments. This is the unselfconscious city that an outsider probably sees better than a native.

title: The Empire Slinks Back
description: Ferguson says the United States can't rule the world because, unlike British civil servants, Americans won't spend years overseas. Perhaps to the good! Why imitate the British Empire? After years of occupation, its colonies (except for offshoots like Canada and Australia) remained desperately poor and politically unstable. Better to imitate the short United States occupation of Japan, where people benefited from land reform, more open education, workplace rights, government-led economic development and political democracy.

title: North Dakota, When It's for Music Lovers

For most classical music lovers, the actual Dakotas remain as remote now as they were then. For some, the only association will be Peter Schickele, supposed professor at the University of Southern North Dakota at Hoople and inventor of the hapless Baroque composer P. D. Q. Bach. (No matter that Mr. Schickele, a real-life composer, was born in Ames, Iowa, and Hoople is in northeastern North Dakota.)

He writes that he and like-minded thinkers are people ''for whom the Holocaust remains central to our whole understanding of liberal politics.'' How then can he argue that we should not worry about hatred of Jews in the heart of Holocaust Europe because much of it is merely the ''residual, mainly verbal anti-Semitism of parts of the wider population''? Anybody, Jewish or not, who can dismiss anti-Semitism as ''residual'' and ''mainly verbal'' does not understand a thing about the Holocaust or anti-Semitism. title: Deals and Discounts

Departures on the 11-night trips are Aug. 10, 20 and 31 and Sept. 10. Rates are $3,499 to $4,749 a person, double occupancy, versus the regular rates of $4,689 to $6,339 in those same cabin categories, first-class DD, C and CC. The prices include shore excursions (including a ride on the White Pass & Yukon Railroad), but not air fare. The cruises go from Seattle to Juneau or reverse, with the itinerary including Victoria and Vancouver in British Columbia and Ketchikan, Sitka, Skagway, Glacier Bay National Park and Misty Fjords in Alaska. Add $199 a person for port charges and taxes. Information: (800) 434-1232 or on the Web at www.empressofthenorth.com.

title: The Unmistakable Lightness of Lena Olin

''To be a good actor, you have to be very smart. But to be a great actor, you also have to have a streak of, 'I'm an idiot, a complete lunatic.' Sometimes I think, 'Wow, why didn't I grow up the way other people do? Why do I have this idiotic side to me?' Because even the wish to do what actors do is somewhat idiotic: 'O.K., I'm really sad and I have to show you how sad I am.' I mean, who would want to do that?''

title: The Empire Slinks Back

title: The Insecurities and Iron Fist That Built I.B.M.

Watson Jr., who ran the International Business Machines Corporation during its climb to dominance in the computer industry, published his memoirs in 1990, he called the book ''Father, Son & Co.'' His father -- who had taken over a motley assortment of business machine companies in 1914 while awaiting sentencing on a criminal antitrust conviction -- loomed large in the story. Indeed, one reason the book has become a business classic is surely its poignant, child's-eye view of the flawed yet fascinating father who created I.B.M. and brought it to the brink of the computer age before passing it to his son, who died in 1993.

title: Keep-Out Signs in the Global Village
description: THE world is shrinking. Or so the conventional wisdom has insisted for decades. Television, telecommunications, the World Wide Web, international free trade and, not least, jet travel have all supposedly combined to create what Marshall McLuhan called the global village. Soothed by this notion of our seamless universal connectedness, we have come to take it for granted that we can climb on a plane at a bargain price and fly anywhere we want, safe in the assumption that wherever we land there will be an airport identical to the one we just left. Not only that, there'll be familiar hotel franchises, fast food chains, CNN by satellite and local people eager to put themselves at our disposal in exchange for dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODBODY, GARRETT
description: GOODBODY-Garrett, 57, of New York City and Sharon, CT, died suddenly of cardiac arrhythmia on May 2, 2003. He is survived by his spouse, Ann Goodbody. His parents were Garrett Goodbody Sr., a partner in Goodbody & Co., and Bambie McKenna Goodbody of Madison, New Jersey. He was a graduate of The Hotchkiss School, Yale University (St. Anthony's Hall)-Class of 1967, and of Harvard Business SchoolClass of 1971. Garrett served for two years in the Peace Corps, helping establish fishing cooperatives in Brazil and becoming fluent in Portuguese and Spanish. After graduating from Harvard, he joined Citibank, spending the early part of his 15-year career there in Brazil and Mexico. He subsequently became a Senior Executive Vice President of Marine Midland Bank and later, as President of New Milford Savings Bank, restructured the bank to profitability. He remained active in the industry, consulting on international banking issues related to USAID projects. At the time of his death, he was a director of numerous banks as well as a Principal of Goodbody/PL Capital LP, a partnership investing in domestic financial institutions. Issues of corporate governance and shareholder rights were of particular concern to him. He loved music, had a rich bass voice and was a member of various singing groups, including the 1967 Whiffenpoofs. Outdoor activities were a life-long interest, including sailing, skiing, running marathons in earlier years, hiking and especially golf more recently. He cared deeply about land use and was a member of the Board of Directors of the Sharon Land Trust. Garrett is survived also by his sister, Ducky G. Bancroft of Sharon, CT, his niece, Kelly Bancroft and his nephew, Alexander Bancroft. A memorial service will be held at The Hotchkiss School Chapel, Lakeville, CT on Friday, May 16th at 11:45AM. Additional information can be found at www.hotchkiss.org/alumnet or calling 860-435-3121. Gifts in his memory may be sent to the Sharon Land Trust at PO Box 1027, Sharon, CT 06069.

They were there to be interviewed for jobs at a new place that would open in June and be featured in July on a reality show on NBC called ''The Restaurant.'' The drill was simple, too: when a car came, run to the curb; when you broke a window, just run. Even when the suburban ring around New York City began to expand, the equation was not much more complicated: a town baseball diamond for every 1,000 residents or so, and a football field at the school.

title: Witnesses and Documents Unveil Deceptions in a Reporter's Work
description: Following is an accounting of the articles in which falsification, plagiarism and similar problems were discovered in a review of articles written by Jayson Blair, a reporter for The New York Times who resigned May 1. The review, conducted by a team of Times reporters and researchers, concentrated on the 73 articles Mr. Blair wrote since late October, when he was given roving national assignments and began covering major news events including the Washington-area sniper attacks and the rescue of Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch. Spot checks of his previous stories also found errors of fact and possible fabrications.

title: NEW LEADER
description: The Rev. George Edward Councell from Lake Forest, Ill., was elected last Sunday as the 11th bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey. He succeeds Bishop Joe Morris Doss, who resigned after heavy criticism for management style and budget cuts. The diocese, which includes 164 congregations in central and southern New Jersey, had been led by Assisting Bishop David Joslin since Bishop Doss's resignation four years ago. Consecration is scheduled for Oct. 18 at Trinity Cathedral in Trenton. Karen DeMasters

At the center of this first novel by a Yale law professor is the patriarch of a wealthy black family who dies under mysterious circumstances after he is forced to withdraw as a nominee for the Supreme Court. Set in academia and the well-heeled environs of Martha's Vineyard and Washington, the narrative combines politics and suspense with ruminations on race relations and the pleasures and miseries of family life. ''It's not much of an exaggeration to suggest that in Stephen Carter the black upper class has found its Dreiser,'' Ward Just wrote here last year.

title: Editors' Note
description: Ten days ago, Jayson Blair resigned as a reporter for The New York Times after the discovery that he had plagiarized parts of an article on April 26 about the Texas family of a soldier missing in Iraq. An article on Page 1 today recounts a chain of falsifications and plagiarism that unraveled when The Times began an inquiry into that Texas article. At least 36 more articles written by Mr. Blair since October reflected plagiarism, misstatements, misrepresentation of the reporter's whereabouts or a combination of those. An accounting of the flaws will be found on the right side of this page, as the first headline under "Related."

My job was to clean and sandpaper the eggs to ready them for sale. To this day, I can't stand eggs.

title: LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT
description: IN what is regarded as his masterpiece, Eugene O'Neill appears onstage in his 1941 autobiographical play ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' as the character Edmund, the troubled Tyrone family's younger son. Weakened by what will be diagnosed as tuberculosis, Edmund is witness to the unraveling of his family. The play opened on Broadway last Tuesday in a revival at the Plymouth Theater directed by Robert Falls, with Brian Dennehy and Vanessa Redgrave as Edmund's parents, James and Mary, Philip Seymour Hoffman as his brother, Jamie, and Robert Sean Leonard as Edmund. In this Act IV excerpt from the Nota Bene paperback edition of the play, published by Yale University Press in 2002, Edmund and his father are in the living room of the family's Connecticut summer home near the water. It is a late August night in 1912 and the two are drinking whiskey while playing a desultory game of cards.

Know that you will always be loved so very much. Miriam

Some would mix in a little golf before returning to their campuses.

description: Forget Republicans and Democrats. The lawmakers who seem least to understand each other are senators and representatives -- no matter the party.

title: Refashioning Time Inc. From the Outside In
description: The power was there all along, but for the first six years of his tenure, Norman Pearlstine wielded it only implicitly -- a cerebral, almost spectral presence as editor in chief of Time Inc. He has been a steady guardian of the division's editorial independence since he was hired from outside the company in 1995. But in the early going, Mr. Pearlstine was mainly a ferocious reader and e-mailer, sending the managing editors of the company's various magazines suggestions for improving headlines or expressing concern about an article's legal problems. He chose new editors, but only when the need arose.

description: In theory, Taiwan is the perfect laboratory for quarantines.

title: Insider's History Of Clinton's Presidency
description: Sidney Blumenthal, journalist turned Clintonist, has written a deeply reported, deeply partisan book about his time as a senior White House aide. Scores are settled, both petty and portentous, and the book is being passed around Washington, samizdat-style, so the various players can check the index for their names.

title: Patents; Tracking termites by monitoring their digestive problems and using hot chili peppers to kill them.
description: TERRY CLARK, whose family runs a pest-control empire in Lodi, Calif., believes he has a better way to find termites: monitoring the methane they expel.

Which raises the question: short of calling in the Marines, what would constitute a get-tough policy with Cuba?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on May 1 about the power drain in electronic devices that require direct current referred imprecisely to equipment that converts alternating current. Although the equipment is commonly referred to as a transformer (or a ''two-pronged vampire''), it actually consists of both a transformer, which changes the voltage, and a rectifier, which converts alternating current to direct.

title: Tension Between Dean and Kerry Helps Recast Race for Democrats
description: The political fortunes of two New Englanders battling for the Democratic presidential nomination, Howard Dean and John Kerry, have become entangled in a way that has sharpened tension between them and recast the dynamics of the party's presidential competition.

title: Argentine Contender Dogged by Questions
description: For most Argentines, the man who would be president is a cipher, an unknown who seems to have emerged from nowhere. But here at the extreme southern tip of Patagonia, in the sprawling, oil-producing province he has governed for the past dozen years, Nstor Kirchner has built a reputation both for largess and for questionable methods.

title: Burmese Women Are Reporting Systematic Rapes by Military
description: Women from the Shan minority and other ethnic minority groups in northeastern Myanmar are telling stories of rapes by the military that are sometimes characterized by sadism and that human rights groups say appear to be authorized and systematic.

title: 'Huge Black Eye'
description: Just about everyone at this newspaper is sick at heart at the way one Times reporter betrayed our readers and all of us with his sustained deceit and plagiarism.

title: Sam Lacy, 99; Fought Racism as Sportswriter
description: Sam Lacy, a sports reporter for black newspapers for almost 70 years who struggled with the segregation and racial intolerance experienced by the black athletes he covered, died last Thursday morning at a hospital in Washington. He was 99.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Flower Seller Mauled And Robbed
description: A Brooklyn flower seller hawking Mother's Day bouquets was bitten in the abdomen yesterday by a pit bull handled by a group of teenagers, who then grabbed two bouquets of roses and fled, the police said. The seller, Sung Bae Joh, 30, was standing outside his family's store at 1426 St. Johns Place near Utica Avenue, said his sister, Eunatee Joh, 31. Her brother was taken to St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn, where he was treated and released, a hospital official said. There had been no arrests as of last night. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Santos Knows How To Handle Adversity As Well as a Whip
description: One day, Jose Santos was a big part of one of racing's sweetest stories, about how the regular guys with their modestly bred gelding from New York and their jockey whose career had been given up for dead beat a wealthy Arab prince and proved that anyone could win the Kentucky Derby. The next, he was swept up in a maelstrom that threatened to destroy his career and tarnish his sport.

title: Newspapers Identify Man Said to Be British Agent in I.R.A.
description: A man believed to be Britain's longtime top intelligence agent within the Irish Republican Army was reported to have been moved to a safe house in England this weekend after it emerged that Sunday newspapers in Ireland and Scotland would identify him by name.

title: Corrections

This could be a huge mistake. We need to develop and put in effect a strategy that tries to prevent future SARS-like outbreaks now.

title: Treasury Chief's Comments Weigh on Dollar as Euro Jumps
description: LONDON, May 12  The dollar's decline accelerated today, pushing the euro within striking distance of its all-time high, after Treasury Secretary John W. Snow gave what analysts called a tacit endorsement of a weaker American currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECARLO, DR. JOSEPH DOMINIC
description: DeCARLO-Dr. Joseph Dominic. Joseph Dominic DeCarlo, ophthalmologist, died on May 10, 2003. Born in the Bronx on July 8, 1907, he graduated from Manhattan College in 1930, and University of Bologna, Italy, in 1934, where he received a degree in medicine. After interning in Morrisania City Hospital, he completed an ENT residency in Bronx Eye and Ear Infirmary in 1939, where he remained as staff surgeon until 1943. He then joined Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx as its Director of Ophthalmology from 1943-1970. He maintained a private practice in general ophthalmology for more than 55 years in the Bronx. He had been affiliated with Union Hospital, Montefiore Medical Center, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary and Our Lady of Mercy Hospital. He leaves behind his devoted wife, Theresa; two loving children: a daughter, Enes, a teacher who lives and works in New York, and a son, John, a cornea surgeon in Wisconsin; his adoring grandchildren, Jennifer and Kristen, and his daughter - in - law, Kathleen. Private viewing at the Harrison Funeral Home. Funeral Mass to be held on Wednesday, May 14, 10:00 a.m., at St. Gregory the Great Church, Harrison, N.Y. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: The Evelyn Wood of Digitized Book Scanners
description: Putting the world's most advanced scholarly and scientific knowledge on the Internet has been a long-held ambition for Michael Keller, head librarian at Stanford University. But achieving this goal means digitizing the texts of millions of books, journals and magazines -- a slow process that involves turning each page, flattening it and scanning the words into a computer database.

title: Egyptians Lead Pairs Event, Defying Pundits' Predictions
description: The Cavendish Pairs tournament in Las Vegas this weekend is well provided with national and international champions but has proved a shock for the pundits. With one session remaining to be played yesterday, the lead was held by Tarek Sadek and Walid el-Ahmady of Egypt, the only pair from outside North America and Europe. They finished second a year ago but were not expected to match that performance this year.

title: Geoffrey Bardon, Advocate of Aboriginal Art, Dies at 63

title: Newspaper Surfing
description: The latest six-month review of newspaper circulation figures, released last week, showed many of the nation's major newspapers losing readers. But a year-to-year comparison of traffic to major newspapers' Web sites tells a different story. Most of the big newspapers had significant gains in Web traffic in March, compared with March 2002, according to Nielsen/NetRatings. (Traffic to the Los Angeles Times site in March 2002 was unusually high because of interest in the Winona Ryder shoplifting trial.)

title: British Department Store Reviews Bids for Buyout
description: The board of Selfridges & Company, the London department store that dominates Oxford Street, met this evening to discuss rival buyout offers.

He also built the Park East Synagogue Day School in New York. He was a giant among men and will be missed by all. Temple service Sunday, May 11th, 1:30 PM, at Temple Beth Torah, 9105-15 NW 57th Street, Tamarac, FL. For information, Star of David; 954722-9000.

description: Governor General Peter Hollingworth, who represents the British Crown in Australia, announced today that he was stepping aside while a court dealt with an allegation that he committed a rape in the 1960's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Candidate For District Attorney
description: David W. Lehr, chief assistant district attorney of Richmond County, has announced his candidacy for Staten Island district attorney. Mr. Lehr, who has been chief assistant for 21 years, made his announcement on Saturday and is expected to get the Democratic nomination at the county convention on Wednesday. His Republican opponent is Deputy Borough President Daniel M. Donovan Jr. The incumbent, William L. Murphy, is not seeking re-election.

title: Mets' Struggles Add to Cone's Uncertainty

But now Cone is coming back from a hip injury and is ostensibly in the same position he was in when he came out of retirement: nothing has been promised to him.

description: For many American executives doing business in Asia, teleconferencing really is the next best thing to being there, and in many cases the only option available.

description: Clouds are gathering over Take-Two Interactive Software, distributor of the immensely popular video game ''Grand Theft Auto,'' as new questions are being raised about the executive hired last fall to restore the company's financial credibility.

description: BERANBAUM - Samuel L., M.D., 88. Beloved husband of Betty for 54 years, loving father of Joan and John, Nancy and David, and John and Nancy, and the proud grandfather of Rebecca, Daniel, Elyssa, Jacob, Joshua, Nina, Julianne, Sarah, Laura, Peter, Daniel and Ross. He was a founding member of the radiology practice of Beranbaum, Khilnani, Neistadt, Jacobs and Hertz. He was Clinical Professor of Radiology and acting Chairman of Radiology at New York University, Director of Radiology of the St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases and the author of many articles and coauthor of two books on radiology. The funeral will be held today at 1:30 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st St. and Madison Ave.

title: Viruses seem to attack cells in the same fashion, expert says : AIDS offers a clue in SARS fight
description: HONG KONG:  The SARS virus appears to attack human cells in the same way that the AIDS virus does, which may give scientists clues about how to treat the respiratory disease, a leading AIDS researcher said Sunday.

title: Study Finds Number of Chiefs Forced to Leave Jobs Is Up
description: The chairs under the desks of chief executives are looking less like thrones and more like hot seats, according to a study scheduled to be released today.

title: What Drove 2 Britons to Bomb a Club in Tel Aviv?
description: Something changed Omar Khan Sharif, sent him in a new direction, and Derby's older Pakistani population cannot begin to fathom what it was.

title: Missing the Smallpox Goal
description: When the Bush administration announced plans last year to vaccinate some 500,000 health workers and then 10 million emergency responders and other health personnel against smallpox, we welcomed the initiative. With the World Trade Center attack and anthrax mailings still in mind, it seemed like a reasonable step toward protecting the nation against a possible bioterror attack. We still believe that the more health workers vaccinated the better, but the vaccination campaign has encountered such difficulties and is so far from meeting its goals that a reassessment is now in order.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Airport Terminal Evacuated
description: A terminal at La Guardia Airport was evacuated for about an hour last night in what proved to be a false alarm after security screeners thought they spotted a weapon in someone's bag, the authorities said. The evacuation of the Delta Airlines terminal was ordered about 7:15 p.m., resulting in long delays for passengers. The Associated Press said 1,500 passengers were required to clear the area and have their luggage screened a second time. The authorities said the problem occurred when security screeners, whose suspicions had been raised by an X-ray image of carry-on luggage, grabbed the wrong bag for further examination. A passenger took the bag that had been considered suspicious and walked into the terminal before security personnel realized their mistake. The terminal reopened about 8:15 p.m.. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: In Germany, Customers Scan As They Shop
description: At an experimental store that opened last month in Rheinberg, Germany, customers do not just squeeze loaves of bread: they scan them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Congressman Criticizes School Scaffold Budget
description: New York City's Department of Education is spending millions of dollars to build scaffolding at schools across the city where repairs have not yet started, according to a report released yesterday by United States Representative Anthony Weiner, a Democrat who represents parts of Queens and Brooklyn. Nearly $3 million has been spent on scaffolds since September 1999 on schools that still need repairs. The report cited a Manhattan school where scaffolding cost more than $12,000 per month, for a total of $152,000 this year. Mr. Weiner called on the School Construction Authority to move quickly and spend the money on repairs. Department of Education officials said the authority was already making plans to complete construction at some sites by the end of next year. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Taiwan SARS Cases Reach a One-Day High
description: HONG KONG, May 12  The number of new SARS cases surged to a single-day record in Taiwan today, while outbreaks elsewhere in Asia showed continuing signs of receding.

title: Plant Workers Say Bush Speech Will Cost Them
description: President Bush plans to speak at an Omaha plastics factory today to sell his message that his tax cut plan will put money in workers' pockets. But some workers at the factory, Airlite Plastics, are complaining that Mr. Bush's speech will have the opposite effect.

title: Growth Stops Short of Division I

Inside, a tattered wooden table that holds condiments during games also serves as a desk during the lacrosse lectures of Russ Bolling, an all-American attackman at Army in the early 1970's.

title: Business Leaders Warn of Problems if Britain Rebuffs Euro
description: LONDON, May 12  With a reluctant Britain set to signal whether it wants to join the euro, a group of 26 senior executives from large corporations warned Prime Minister Tony Blair today that rejecting the single currency would have "serious consequences for Britain's future prosperity."

title: Margaret Thatcher as Muse; Mixed Messages but No Love Letters in a London Exhibition
description: The best-known artistic depiction of Margaret Thatcher in recent years is a huge marble statue showing her standing magnificently erect, gripping her famous handbag. This work was decapitated last year at the Guildhall Art Gallery by an anti-Thatcherite Londoner (''We can ill afford to ever lose our sense of humor,'' he said, before being sentenced to three months in prison), which is as telling a comment as any on the passions this former prime minister still stirs up here.

title: Found: A Twain Play Good Enough to Stage
description: Politely put, Mark Twain was not known for his skills as a dramatist. Despite one early commercial success and many subsequent attempts, most of Twain's output as a playwright is, as one scholar puts it, ''well worth burying.''

title: Compressed Data; Apple Tweaks Microsoft Over a New Computer

Lucille spent most of her adult life in Weston, Connecticut, where she taught English in the school system, served on the St. Francis parish committee and was active in other town and church affairs. She was a key person in the development of the Weston Field Club swim team. She was a devoted wife and mother and a role model and mentor to many whose lives she touched. Earlier in her life, she was the first woman executvie trainee ever chosen by the advertising agency McCann - Erickson. She was born on Long Island, the daughter of William F. and Josephine M. Shore, and was a graduate of Hofstra College. She leaves behind her husband of fifty years, Nils, of Jupiter and Weston, and her daughters, Betsy Kindwall Luminais of Berwyn, Pennsylvania, Amy Kindwall Sanborn of Weston, Connecticut, and Sukie Kindwall of Conway, Massachusetts, a sister, Nancy A. title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: INTEL DISCLOSES FLAW IN ITANIUM 2 PROCESSORS Intel, the world's largest semiconductor maker, said yesterday that a flaw in some of its Itanium 2 processors can cause corporate servers to act unpredictably or shut down altogether. The problem was discovered by an equipment manufacturer during routine laboratory stress-testing, said a spokesman, Robert Manetta. As a result, I.B.M. , whose servers contain Intel's chips, said it would immediately halt shipments of its high-end eServer x450 server, which uses the Itanium 2 processor and has been available only since the end of April. Lisa Lanspery, an I.B.M. spokeswoman, said that no customers had contacted it with the problem, and added that I.B.M. remained committed to the Intel chip regardless. The problem affects servers based on the 1-gigahertz chip only in certain highly specific situations. Customers can contact Intel for a replacement or they can opt to run their systems at 800 megahertz, rather than 900 megahertz or 1 gigahertz, which would eliminate the risk of a problem. Customers will also able to replace the chip with a higher-speed version, running at 1.5 megahertz, within a few months, Mr. Manetta said. Intel is distributing software that can detect if a system is affected. "All processors have errata to some extent," Mr. Manetta said. "We've learned that you don't judge what is a major erratum and what is a minor one. You leave that to your customers."

He was responsible for design, sales and service, manufacturing and purchasing, research and development, and marketing. Silver Lake last month hired a former Accel Partners general partner and chief operating officer for a similar role. Private equity firms typically begin to prepare for raising a new fund when they have invested half of their current fund. Mr. Zander joined Sun in 1987 as vice president for corporate marketing. He received an M.B.A. from Boston University and a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Mr. Zander's appointment was reported by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Images of Evil's Flowering Disagree About Its Roots
description: If Jack Bauer, special agent for the Counter Terrorist Unit in Los Angeles, had been a passenger on the hijacked Achille Lauro cruise ship in 1985, things might have turned out differently. This grim hero of ''24,'' the Fox television drama, regularly races the clock to vanquish terrorists, block assassinations and stave off catastrophe.

title: Speaking Her Mind, Using Her Checkbook
description: Even with two aides monitoring the interview, Teresa Heinz Kerry, the first Democrat to generate serious buzz in the presidential campaign, could not resist being candid when she was asked the other day her opinion of a warning issued by Richard M. Nixon in 1992. ''If the wife comes through as being too strong and too intelligent,'' Nixon had said, referring to a newcomer named Hillary, ''it makes the husband look like a wimp.''

title: Proteins Are Transformed, Then Put to More Uses
description: Scientists say they have developed powerful computational techniques to alter proteins, the workhorses of biology, so they can perform new functions.

title: Game Maker Snubs Microsoft's Xbox
description: Electronic Arts, the video game publisher, said today that it would not make online versions of its popular sports games available for Microsoft's Xbox game console for at least a year, signaling a failure of more than two years of negotiations between the companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer Selects Executives
description: The Dutch grocer Royal Ahold disclosed several management changes, including the appointment of a new chief financial officer for Ahold Europe, Dirk Anbeek. Ahold's shareholders planned to meet with executives today for the first time since an accounting scandal now estimated at $880 million in overstated earnings became public in February. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINALE, GIANNI
description: MINALE-Gianni. On May 11th, 2003. Beloved husband of Rene (nee Fisher). Devoted father of Angela, Maria, Pamela and Stefano. Loving grandfather of Peter and Stefano. Reposing Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC.

title: Fashion From India, Beyond the Bangles
description: Considering that it is the country historically credited with giving the world paisley, seersucker, calico, chintz, cashmere, crewel and the entire technique of printing on cloth, it is anybody's guess why India barely registers on the global map of fashion. True, there is the occasional flurry of interest in Bollywood's frothy excesses, or the beauty assembly line that keeps South Asian Bond girls and Miss Universes in steady supply. True, too, there remains a widespread, and often justified, perception that the lavish embroideries that can hike the cost of a European couture frock to six figures are sewn not in some rarefied French atelier but in a workshop in downtown Madras.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the decision of Randi Weingarten, the New York City teachers' union president, to withdraw support for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's school reorganization plan misstated the name of another organization she leads and her title in it. (The name was also misstated in articles on May 8, May 3 and April 11; the title was wrong on April 11.) The organization is the Municipal Labor Committee, not Municipal Labor Council. Ms. Weingarten is chairwoman, not president.

title: INSIDE
description: Bombing in Chechnya

title: Little Guy Has Big Heart
description: MetroStars midfielder RICHIE WILLIAMS has proved that on the soccer field, sometimes size does not matter.

title: The Domestic Spying Trap
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's supporters in Congress recently made a quiet effort to give it broad new powers to engage in domestic spying. Given the agency's troubled history in domestic intelligence gathering -- and its success since the Sept. 11 attacks in tracking down leaders of Al Qaeda overseas -- it is hard to understand why the C.I.A. would want to be entangled in domestic operations again. The proposal, which failed to win sufficient backing in Congress, should not be revived.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Talks On Scooter Stake
description: The Italian financier Roberto Colaninno reached an agreement with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, a unit of Deutsche Bank, for Mr. Colaninno to negotiate exclusively taking a controlling share in the Piaggio group, the Italian maker of Vespa scooters. Piaggio's largest shareholders are Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, with 57.4 percent, and the Texas Pacific Group of Forth Worth, with 8.1 percent. The agreement gives Mr. Colaninno and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell until June 15 to reach a final agreement. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Sentences For Corruption
description: Two former Atlanta officials were sentenced on federal corruption charges, part of a three-year investigation of former Mayor Bill Campbell's administration. The city's former chief operating officer, W. Lawrence Wallace, 53, was sentenced to 46 months in prison for taking bribes. A former Department of Administrative Services commissioner, Herbert McCall, 52, got 21 months for perjury and obstruction of justice. Mr. Campbell has not been charged. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Fishing for Clarity in the Waters of Consciousness
description: The study of consciousness has always fascinated me. I love all the impossible arguments about the self and the nature of experience. I also love fishing, but I never expected the two interests to coincide or, more precisely, collide.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Man of Internet Fraud
description: Regulators filed fraud charges today against a 20-year-old Kentucky man who reportedly took money from would-be investors by creating a Web site for a fictitious federal agency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 5 about the Fresh Air Fund misstated the number of children who take part in its programs each year. It is more than 10,000, not 13,000. Nearly 6,000 of those -- not 10,000 -- stay for at least two weeks with families in suburbs and small towns in 13 states and Canada.

title: 'Hairspray' Leads Field of Tony Nominees
description: The new musical ''Hairspray'' dominated the Tony Award nominations yesterday, named in 13 categories that included best musical, best original score and best costumes. ''Movin' Out,'' Twyla Tharp's dance show set to the music of Billy Joel, received 10 nominations, including one for best musical, even though it has no words and only one singer.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: MERCURY BUYS PERFORMANT FOR $22.5 MILLION The Mercury Interactive Corporation has bought Performant Inc. for $22.5 million. Mercury will add products that find errors in the Java language for writing Internet programs. Performant is backed by Washington Mutual Inc. and investors including the Madrona Venture Group, Performant's Web site said. The company has worked on products with Mercury previously, Mercury said in a statement on its Web site. The transaction closed May 5. Sun Microsystems developed Java, which became popular because it works with various computers and software. Java vies with Microsoft's .Net software for program developers. Shares of Mercury rose $1.77, or about 5 percent, to $37.52.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: TALKS URGED TO AVERT LAYOFFS The municipal unions called yesterday for talks to avert city layoffs, and the city said it would meet with the unions, but only if they had something new to say on achieving labor savings. Randi Weingarten, the chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee and the president of the teachers' union, wrote to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg urging him to begin round-the-clock negotiations. The mayor sent out 3,000 pink slips after the unions failed to agree to $600 million in labor savings. In a letter responding to the unions, the mayor's representative, James F. Hanley, the labor commissioner, said he might be willing to meet. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPLIN, FRANK E. JR.
description: TAPLIN-Frank E. Jr. It is with tremendous sadness and a profound sense of loss that the officers, directors, managers and staff of The Metropolitan Opera mourn the death of Frank Taplin, a key figure in The Met's history, whose involvement with this house over many years was integral to the success of our company today. President of The Metropolitan Opera's board of directors from 1977 to 1984, Frank Taplin was first elected to the board in 1961. He led The Met's National Council from 1961 to 1964, and was an honorary director at the time of his death. Frank was elected president of The Met at a time of dire financial difficulty for the company. His energy, optimism and belief in the glory of music, as well as his eloquent ability to persuade others to share his excitement and give their support, transformed our company. During his presidency, Frank launched the Golden Horseshoe, a key group of major donors. He also initiated the Centennial Campaign, The Met's first endowment drive, which raised one hundred million dollars. His practical focus on the bottom line made him indispensable to The Metropolitan Opera at a critical period, and his generous heart, humor, musical talent and personal grace endeared him to all who were fortunate to know him. Among his many gifts to The Met is our company cafeteria, which serves every day as the central, informal meeting place for artists, technical and administrative staff, stage crew, ushers and guards, indeed the entire Met family. His pride in the excellence of this house, his wisdom to plan not just for the present but for the future, and his joy in this company's artistic achievements will continue to inspire us all. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Peg, and to their children and step-children, Caroline Taplin Ruschell, Jennifer Taplin Jerome, David F. Taplin, Jennifer Sichel Dickerman, Martha Sichel Kelly, and Susan Sichel. Bruce Crawford Chairman Emeritus James W. Kinnear, Honorary Chairman of the Board Beverly Sills Chairman of the Board Mrs. Ezra K. Zilkha Vice Chairman Paul M. Montrone President William C. Morris, Chairman, Executive Committee Joseph Volpe General Manager James Levine Artistic Director

title: OfficeMax Makes Sudden Shop Change
description: OfficeMax said unexpectedly yesterday that it had named the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson to handle its account, which had been handled by offices of Publicis Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe , for the last three years. Though billings were not disclosed, OfficeMax spent $42.4 million to advertise last year in major media, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of TNS.

title: NETHERLANDS TRIAL
description: Twelve suspected Islamic militants went on trial in Rotterdam on charges of providing logistical and financial support for Al Qaeda. Prosecutors said that the men were involved in a range of terrorist and criminal activities including forging documents, dealing drugs, and possessing illegal weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, HAROLD D.
description: JONES-Harold D. Of Brooklyn, N.Y. Husband of the late Ferrell Jones. Survived by beloved brother Paul, sisterin-law Myra, niece Janice and nephew Thomas. Funeral at Cronin Funeral Home, 115 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, on Friday, May 16 at 2 PM.

title: The Last Battle
description: As the Americans begin to commit "suicide before the walls of Baghdad," Abu Mush' Republic Guard company is engaged in early morning exercises 180 kilometers north of the Iraqi capital. It is 7:30 a.m. on April 6, and the troops are assembled on the parade grounds of the main barracks at Tikrit, Saddam's and Saladin's home town. The city, built on a flat plain that stretches to the horizon, appears small under a vast sky.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Infosys Settles Sexual Harassment Case
description: India's second-largest software exporter, Infosys Technologies, said on Sunday that it had settled out of court a sexual harassment case filed by a former employee against the company and its former head of global sales and marketing, Phaneesh Murthy. Infosys said in a statement from its Bangalore headquarters that the former employee, Reka Maximovitch, would be paid $3 million, and the amount would be contributed equally by the company and its insurers. Under the terms of the settlement, the company retained rights to proceed legally against Mr. Murthy. Infosys said he did not disclose crucial facts including the fact that he had a relationship with Ms. Maximovitch. The sexual harassment suit was the most high profile in India's corporate history. Mr. Murthy quit in July last year after Ms. Maximovitch sued him and the company, contending sexual harassment and wrongful termination. Mr. Murthy, who was based in Fremont, Calif., was also an Infosys board member and the company's highest-paid employee. In her suit, filed in Alameda County Superior Court in Oakland, Calif., Ms. Maximovitch, who had been Mr. Murthy's executive assistant, contended that she was subjected to verbal and visual sexual harassment and unwanted sexual advances. She also contended that the company failed to take reasonable steps to keep the harassment from occurring and recurring. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Doing Science at the Top of the World
description: Three broken bolts. A vital part of the first sustained effort to monitor big climate shifts at the top of the world was being threatened by three broken bolts.

title: Smaller U.S. Airports Are Increasingly Popular
description: There are many ways to size up the worst or at least the most irritating airports in the country. Some people count the number of delayed flights, others gauge the difficulties of getting in and out, and some critique the amenities. Doctors have even ranked the busiest airports based on the unhealthiness of the food served in them.

title: China Issues Tough Rules on Reporting Outbreaks
description: BEIJING, May 13  Stung by the ruinous effects of an initial cover-up of SARS, the Chinese government has issued stringent new rules requiring local officials to report disease epidemics to Beijing immediately, on pain of dismissal or even criminal charges.

title: Officials Say Santos Carried Only a Whip
description: Horse racing's 48-hour mystery was solved yesterday when racing officials ruled that Jose Santos was not carrying an illegal device in his victorious ride aboard Funny Cide in the 129th running of the Kentucky Derby, thus exonerating him of any wrongdoing.

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Warning Labels
description: The nation's attorneys general, led by Thomas F. Reilly of Massachusetts, have reached an agreement with a paint trade organization requiring manufacturers to place labels on their paint cans warning consumers about the dangers of lead paint and dust exposure during renovations. The trade organization, the National Paint and Coatings Association, will offer free training to inspectors, contractors and government officials and produce pamphlets for customers. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: US AIRWAYS ORDERS 170 COMMUTER JETS
description: US Airways has placed an order worth $4.3 billion for at least 170 commuter jets, split equally between Bombardier Aerospace of Canada and Embraer of Brazil. The airline, which emerged from bankruptcy protection at the end of March, said the 50- and 70-seat aircraft would enable it to add routes to its hubs in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and Charlotte, N.C., from cities that were too distant for turboprop aircraft. On some routes, the commuter jets will replace larger planes that will be used in more profitable markets, like the Caribbean. The deal includes options to buy another 380 aircraft. US Airways is based in Arlington, Va. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Elizabeth Neuffer, 46, Reporter Overseas for The Boston Globe
description: Elizabeth Neuffer, the award-winning foreign correspondent for The Boston Globe who died on Friday in in an automobile accident in Iraq, had traveled there to cover the aftermath of the war. She was 46.

title: WEIGHT ESTIMATES ON AIR PASSENGERS WILL BE INCREASED
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today ordered airlines that fly planes with more than 19 seats to raise the assumed average weight of each passenger by 10 pounds and the assumed weight for each checked bag by an additional 5 to ensure that their planes are not overloaded.

title: Powell Asks Arabs to Help Rein In Palestinian Militants
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell opened a drive today to line up Arab backing for a crackdown on Hamas and other militant groups by the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas. But he ran into sharp criticism in Egypt of Israel's continuing military presence and restrictions in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: $350 Billion, 100 Senators And, Oops, One Mistake
description: Just when the Senate was about to begin debate on the biggest legislation of its term, the bill to cut taxes, Republicans learned today that they had committed the most basic of errors and would have to wait an extra day or two.

title: The N.B.A. Playoffs on ABC: Getting Behind the Ratings
description: Each week, ABC Sports informs the world how much better its life is now that it broadcasts Sunday afternoon N.B.A. playoff games, which it can because ESPN, its cousin at the Walt Disney Company, buys the time. The numbers backing ABC's glee sound wonderful -- for ABC.

title: New Rockefeller Chief Discovered Lessons of Life in a Cell of Yeast
description: When the trustees of Rockefeller University were searching for a new president, they turned to Sir Paul M. Nurse, a 54-year-old Nobel laureate who was, at once, an acclaimed research scientist and a successful charity administrator.

title: Israel Seals Off Gaza After Brief Opening Meant to Ease Plight of Palestinian Workers
description: Despite a pledge to ease Palestinian hardships, Israel sealed off the Gaza Strip today after partly opening the border to workers from there on Sunday. Israeli soldiers today killed three Palestinians in the southern part of the strip, Palestinians said.

title: The Eye of the Tiger, a Thrill of a Sight; Bronx Zoo's New Exhibit Offers Visitors Nose-to-Nose Views
description: Steven E. Sanderson missed his 11 a.m. meeting yesterday. He was busy tiger-watching.

title: Exercise That's Hot and Slow
description: ''Power of 10: The Once-a-Week Slow Motion Fitness Revolution,'' by Adam Zickerman and Bill Schley. HarperCollins, $24.95.

title: The China Syndrome
description: A funny thing happened during the Iraq war: many Americans turned to the BBC for their TV news. They were looking for an alternative point of view -- something they couldn't find on domestic networks, which, in the words of the BBC's director general, ''wrapped themselves in the American flag and substituted patriotism for impartiality.''

title: Loss Deepens at Nikon
description: The Nikon Corporation, one of Japan's leading camera makers, said yesterday that its losses grew in the fiscal year that ended March 31 as a glut of digital cameras drove prices down.

title: Mavericks And Kings Won't Quit
description: The Mavericks assistant coach Donn Nelson can tell the Western Conference semifinal series between Dallas and Sacramento is special by watching the body language of his coaching colleagues. As the four-of-seven-game series heads to Game 5 here on Tuesday tied, 2-2, he sees his father, Mavericks Coach Don Nelson, and experienced assistant coaches like Del Harris enjoying the frantic pace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENSEN, GERBER, JU DIANNE
description: DENSEN - GERBER - Ju dianne: psychiatrist, lawyer, educator, daughter of Gustave Gerber and Beatrice Densen died on May 11, 2003 in her sleep from complications of cancer. She was graduated from Bryn Mawr College (1956) and received her JD (1959) from Columbia University, MD (1963) from New York University, and D.Sc. (Hon. 1983) Lebanon Valley College. She dedicated her professional life to fighting substance abuse, child abuse, battery of women, and pornography. She pioneered the therapeutic community concept, which was embodied by Odyssey House, which she founded. Through her tireless work Odyssey House expanded to have facilities in over a dozen states and 3 continents. Through the hands-onwork that she did and her prolific writings (including 3 books: Drugs, Sex, Parents and You; We Maineline Dreams; and Walk in My Shoes), she influenced societies conception of addiction and in many ways formulated its approach to treatment. She was appointed to numerous local, state, and federal bodies to address these issues and served as personal advisor to several members of congress. She received innumerable awards for her work including a Congressional Certificate of Merit, Nobless Order of the White Cross (from the government of Austrailia), Dame Commander of the Knights of Malta, and appointed an Honorary New York State Fire Chief. She was on the faculty and lectured at several medical and law schools. She directly touched the lives of tens of thousands of drug-addicts and abused children and women and developed an approach which helped hundreds of thousands more. She is predeceased by her son, Jud, and her infant daughter, Julianne. She is survived by her three children (Trissa, Lindsey and Sarah), daughter-in-law (Carolyn Lasar), two grandchildren (Eli and Ruby) and ex-husband (Michael Baden). Funeral Services will be held at All Souls Church, 80th Street and Lexington Ave, at 3:30pm on Tuesday May 13, 2003. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., before church services, 1:30-2:30. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Flint Odessy House, 529 Martin Luther King, Jr. Ave., Flint, MI 48502 or The Breast Cancer Research Foundation in memory of Judianne Densen Gerber, 645 Madison Ave., Suite 1209, NY, NY 10021

title: AOL Picks Chief for Broadband Service
description: The America Online division of AOL Time Warner yesterday named Kevin Conroy, senior vice president and general manager of AOL Entertainment, to the new position of executive vice president and chief operating officer of broadband service.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about Pixar Animation Studios misspelled the name of a character from the company's latest animated film, ''Finding Nemo.'' It is Dory, not Dori.

title: Mets and the Wilpons Must Share the Blame
description: Among its 30 teams, Major League Baseball has hands-off owners, hands-on owners and some who manage to fall in between. To some extent in this expensive era, all owners are hands-on because no general manager would sign an $86 million contract without clearing it with his owner. But hands-on in another respect involves personnel decisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSMAN, EPHRAIM, M.D.
description: GLASSMAN-Ephraim, M.D. The Department of Cardiovascular and Thoracic Surgery at North Shore University Hospital expresses with sorrow the passing of Dr. Ephraim Glassman. Dr. Glassman, former Chief of Cardiology at NYU, and ultimately senior consulting Cardiologist at North Shore University Hospital, made great contributions to clinical and interventional Cardiology. His leadership and role as educator will be remembered. Our condolences to Larry, wife Jessica, grandchildren, and to the entire family. The Staff and Surgeons Dept. of Cardiovascular and Thoracic Surgery at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Paris; A City of Good Food, Fashion and Corporate Drama
description: Probably best known for its high fashion and haute cuisine, Paris is the center of French business, headquarters to companies like L'Oral, TotalFinaElf and Publicis, and the scene of corporate dramas like Vivendi Universal's struggle to right itself after the ouster of Jean-Marie Messier as chief executive last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAULETTI, NICHOLAS
description: LAULETTI - Nicholas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nicholas Lauletti, associated with The Times from June 1974 until retiring in August 1992.

title: Takeover Action Heats Up For British Department Stores
description: On Oxford Street, London's premier shopping district, the hottest items for sale are two of its oldest department stores.

description: A Dal of Window Display

title: Merrill's Chief Comments About Settlement
description: The chief executive of Merrill Lynch, E. Stanley O'Neal, told employees yesterday that he took seriously the firm's settlement with regulators on conflict-of-interest claims after authorities expressed concern that Wall Street executives were not sufficiently contrite.

title: Universal Sues Bertelsmann Over Ties to Napster
description: Universal Music Group, the world's largest record company, sued Bertelsmann yesterday over its investment in Napster, the former file-swapping network, contending that the company contributed to widespread copyright infringement by keeping the service afloat.

title: It's May in France: Time for Striking Workers to Hit the Street
description: PARIS, May 13  May in France is the month of lilies-of-the-valley, the first red cherries, the Cannes film festival  and workers' strikes.

description: ASPLOTCH of green. That's what I see between the index finger and the ring finger on the right hand of Jose Santos, as he rides Funny Cide to victory in the Kentucky Derby.

description: The Power of Bubbles

title: In a First, Piazza Works Out At First
description: Mike Piazza took ground balls at first base today for an undetermined amount of time, beginning a process the Mets have said would be long and arduous but one they hope will eventually make Piazza, their all-star catcher, a first baseman, at least part time.

title: Carter Says It's Time For Piazza To Try First
description: Gary Carter has believed for at least two years that Mike Piazza would lengthen his career, decrease the abuse that his body absorbs and probably increase his offensive output if he shifted from catcher to first base. Carter shared his thoughts with a reporter during the 2001 season, when Piazza struggled to throw out base stealers, and he has tried offering his opinions to Piazza since then, with scant success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKER, ROSE BERNSTEIN
description: MARKER-Rose Bernstein of Brooklyn, New York, died peacefully at home in her hundredth year on May 11, 2003. She is survived by her loving children, daughter Marcia Marker Feld of Newton Centre, Ma, her husband Alan, three grandsons, and daughters-in-law and four great grandsons, and daughter, Linda Eve Marker Wray of New York City, her husband, Colonel Bernard Wray and her granddaughter Laura Frances Wray. She is also survived by her sister, Joyce B. Rosen, her husband, Burt Rosen and their children, Ann, Julie and Leonard. Rose B. Marker, widow of the Hon. Herbert H. Marker, Assemblyman from Brooklyn, was a pioneer career insurance broker in the 1920's when there were few women pursuing this field; She organized many charities particularly for persona with Tuberculosis, and for veterans. She was very active in the Order of Eastern Star, rising through the ranks of her home Chapter, Menorah Chapter #

title: A Few Drinks (of Soda) Too Many
description: What happens if someone drinks eight liters of soda a day? Nothing good, surely. But for a 63-year-old who favored a citrus drink called Ruby Red Squirt, one result was rare and unpleasant skin lesions.

title: Yelps of Critics Are a Good Thing, Mayor Says
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, who has been under attack in recent weeks over various aspects of his plans to reshape the city's public schools, lashed out yesterday at some of his critics in a manner unusual for this normally nonconfrontational mayor.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Washington To Hear Marijuana Plan
description: Justice Minister Martin Cauchon is planning to travel to Washington today to confer with American officials about Canada's plan to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, which has already been criticized by Bush administration officials. The American ambassador, Paul Cellucci, has warned that if the marijuana legislation, expected to be introduced in Parliament this week, is passed, it could slow commerce and transit at the border. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Under the Influence of Exhaustion
description: Medical residents placed in a driving simulator when they were fatigued performed at least as badly as they did after they had consumed a drink or two, researchers have found.

title: Iraq's Mobile Laboratories
description: American military inspectors have found what they consider their most persuasive evidence yet that Iraq was pursuing weapons of mass destruction: three trailers that look as if they may be mobile biological weapons laboratories. Should the evidence hold up after more thorough analysis, it would validate at least one of the claims made by the Bush administration in arguing that Iraq had an active biological weapons program. But at this point it is difficult to know for sure whether these mobile units were part of a program to produce unconventional weapons or served a more benign purpose.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Shooting Suspect Ruled Fit For Trial
description: A man charged with fatally shooting a priest and a parishioner inside a Long Island church last year is competent to stand trial, a judge ruled yesterday. The man, Peter J. Troy, 36, was charged with bursting into the Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church, in Lynbrook, and shooting the Rev. Lawrence M. Penzes as he stood near the altar, and a parishioner seated in a front pew. Judge Daniel J. Cotter of Nassau County Court gave Mr. Troy until May 21 to decide whether to pursue a psychiatric defense. His lawyer, James P. McCormack, said yesterday that Mr. Troy had resisted the idea. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Clinton Wins 18th P.S.A.L. Team Title
description: De Witt Clinton, led by Carldon Murray and Jeremy Alvarez, captured the team title for the 18th time yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Bronx Borough Boys Championships.

description: The government proposed the most significant overhaul of its media ownership rules in a generation today, including a change that would allow television networks to own enough local stations to reach 90 percent of the nation's viewers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELIDES, ALEXANDER CONSTANTINE, M.D.
description: ANGELIDES - Alexander Constantine, M.D., March 16, 1934 to May 11, 2003. Passed away peacefully surrounded by his loving family after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in Berlin, New Hamsphire, to Greek immigrant parents, he was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Amherst College and a graduate of Cornell Medical College. He went on to fellowship training in hand surgery with Dr. Robert E. Carroll and opened his practice in the South Florida area in 1968. He went on to develop a successful group practice and throughout his thirty years became a prominent surgeon and a published author in his specialty of orthopedic hand surgery. He was a member of the prestigious American Society for Surgery of the Hand. He was a co-founder and Chief of Staff of Palmetto General Hospital. He traveled the four corners of the world in quest of his love of life, culture and art. He was an avid skier and sailor. He was a gifted artist, painting until the end of his life. He was also an accomplished photographer who had the rare privilege to be trained by Ansel Adams. He was a patron of the fine and performing arts in both South Florida and New York. His last great journey was to Antarctica shadowing the trail of Shackelton's adventure on the ship ''Endurance''. Through this adventure Alex embodied the true meaning of the word ''endurance'', carrying this inherent courage through his battle with cancer. He is survived by his loving daughters, Alexandria, Christina and Nicole and his loving grandchildren, Austin, Isabel, Hannah, Gillian and Elijah Alexander. A private memorial service will follow. Our deepest thanks to the ''Yellow Team'' at Catholic Hospice for their unending compassion, support and understanding during our time of need. Donations may be made in honor of Alexander Angelides to Catholic Hospice, 14160 Palmetto Frontage Road, Miami, Florida 33016. Phone 305-822-2380

title: City Opposes Power Plant On Waterfront
description: The Bloomberg administration said yesterday that it would oppose a plan to build a 1,100-megawatt power plant on the Brooklyn waterfront. The plant has been proposed on a scenic parcel in Williamsburg that many regard as one of the most promising tracts of undeveloped land in the city.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a visit to the White House by Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar of Spain, who supported the United States in the Iraq war, misstated the title of Jacques Chirac, the French leader who opposed it.
