title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Charges Pressure
description: The head of the union that represents police officers said yesterday that the Police Department was pressuring officers to write more tickets for traffic, parking and other infractions, which the department denied. The union chief, Patrick J. Lynch, said the pressure was an effort to balance the city's budget, saying that the number of summonses was up nearly 7 percent as of April 21 over the same period last year. He said the pressure to write more tickets was damaging the officers' relationship with the communities they serve. But Police Department officials said the number of traffic and parking tickets had dropped more than 17 percent, while summonses for criminal violations, like quality of life crimes, had risen about 15 percent. description: Stillwater Mining, the nation's only producer of platinum and palladium, rejected a takeover offer by an unnamed investment bank, saying it was inferior to an agreement with the MMC Norilsk Nickel Group of Russia. The unnamed bank's offer would provide less than $35 million, and Norilsk would pay the equivalent of about $111 million, Stillwater said. Stillwater, based in Columbus, Mont., has said it needs cash after a two-year slide in palladium prices. Norilsk, the world's largest palladium miner, agreed in November to buy a controlling stake in Stillwater.

title: World Briefing: Asia

The chief security minister, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, said President Megawati Sukarnoputri would decide the timing in the next few days. In Sweden, a spokesman for the separatist group, Free Aceh Movement, widely known as GAM, said it was up to Jakarta and the international community to prevent violence. Earlier yesterday, a team of 50 mostly Thai and Filipino peace monitors pulled out of Aceh's capital, Banda Aceh. Several thousand government troops embarked for the province last week to reinforce tens of thousands already there.   (Reuters)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Discloses Flaw In Itanium 2 Processors
description: Intel, the world's largest semiconductor maker, said yesterday that a flaw in some of its Itanium 2 processors can cause corporate servers to act unpredictably or shut down altogether. The problem was discovered by an equipment manufacturer during routine laboratory stress-testing, said a spokesman, Robert Manetta. As a result, I.B.M., whose servers contain Intel's chips, said it would immediately halt shipments of its high-end eServer x450 server, which uses the Itanium 2 processor and has been available only since the end of April. Lisa Lanspery, an I.B.M. spokeswoman, said that no customers had contacted it with the problem, and added that I.B.M. remained committed to the Intel chip regardless. The problem affects servers based on the 1-gigahertz chip only in certain highly specific situations. Customers can contact Intel for a replacement or they can opt to run their systems at 800 megahertz, rather than 900 megahertz or 1 gigahertz, which would eliminate the risk of a problem. Customers will also able to replace the chip with a higher-speed version, running at 1.5 megahertz, within a few months, Mr. Manetta said. Intel is distributing software that can detect if a system is affected. ''All processors have errata to some extent,'' Mr. Manetta said. ''We've learned that you don't judge what is a major erratum and what is a minor one. You leave that to your customers.'' Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Pressure On North Korea
description: A senior official said Japan would tighten inspections and other controls on maritime traffic and trade with North Korea to raise pressure on the country to seek a solution to the crisis over its suspected nuclear weapons program. The official, Deputy Chief Cabinet Secretary Shinzo Abe, said Japan had already stepped up the monitoring of banks run by pro-North Korean groups in Japan. ''We must strictly review again whether we are doing what we should do,'' Mr. Abe said. He apparently ruled out penalties, however, saying ''the Japanese government for its part is not considering them at this point.''

title: Body Discovered in Brooklyn Is Identified as Hunter Student
description: A body found wrapped in a blanket behind a boarded-up house on Saturday was identified by the police yesterday as that of Ramona Moore, a 21-year-old Hunter College student who lived at home with her parents in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, until she disappeared in April.

title: Plenty of Extremes To Challenge Young Players
description: Musicians From Marlboro

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, JACK
description: GROSS-Jack. On May 11, 2003, at age 93. Husband of the late Rita B. Gross and Ruth L. Gross; loving father of Stephen H. Gross, Deborah G. Green and the late Jeffrey S. Gross; grandfather of Elizabeth G. McCracken, Richard J. Gross, Barbara G. Guzman, Patricia A. Gross, Wendy S. Gross, Katherine G. Curtin, Shaine, Shannon and Sarah Gross; great-grandfather of Samara and Aidan McCracken; Jessica, Allison and Benjamin Gross; Emma and Julia Curtin. A graduate of New York University and its law school; retired as Senior Partner and Chairman of the bankruptcy department of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. He retired as a lieutenant in the United States Navy. Past President of Temple-Kol Ami in White Plains, NY, and Sinai Temple in Mt. Vernon, NY. A member of Fairview Country Club. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 14th at 1:00 PM, at Temple Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave in White Plains. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UJA-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies or the charity of your choice.

title: Market Place; Why Washington Isn't Sweating The Dollar's Drop
description: The dollar is weaker, but is it too weak?

title: Franco Returns To Mound
description: John Franco trotted to the pitcher's mound tonight to warm applause. This was not Shea Stadium, it was Thomas J. White Stadium. And he wore the Mets jersey of the organization's Class A affiliate here. Yet Franco was more nervous than he had been in a long time.

title: Most Airlines Increase Domestic Fares by $5
description: The six major airlines increased domestic air fares $5 each way on almost all tickets over the weekend, the most significant fare increase in more than a year.

title: Ex-Professor At Yale Wins Resentencing In Pornography
description: A federal appellate court has upheld the conviction but ordered a review of the sentencing of a former Yale University professor convicted of downloading tens of thousands of images of child pornography.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Disputed Custody For Infant Survivor
description: A man who said he was the father of a toddler who was the only survivor of a Feb. 5 hit-and-run accident in Brooklyn in which three pedestrians were killed, including the toddler's mother, was denied custody yesterday. DNA tests determined that the man, Riquelmy Nivar, 31, of the Bronx, is not the father or a blood relative. Mr. Nivar lost visitation rights for the 1-year-old boy and is not required to pay child support. A lawyer for the baby's family, John Carrow, said he had asked for the test as a safeguard. ''This was a complete shock,'' Mr. Carrow said. Mr. Nivar's lawyer, Kevin Watson, said Mr. Nivar was saddened because ''he'd become attached to the child.'' The baby's grandmother, Nery Paradis, wants full custody. A hearing in Brooklyn Family Court is scheduled for July. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Times Editor Details Steps to Prevent a Recurrence of Fraud
description: The executive editor of The New York Times outlined a series of steps yesterday that he said the newspaper would take to prevent any recurrence of journalistic fraud, in reaction to revelations of extensive plagiarism and fabrication by a reporter.

title: A Kentucky Derby for New York
description: So a New York horse finally wins the Derby, and wouldn't you know it, a week later there's an official inquiry. We needed that, just the ticket to take the swelling out of a little sorely needed state pride? A news photo and an article last week in The Miami Herald questioned whether Jose Santos, the jockey who rode Funny Cide to a surprise triumph on May 3, used an illegal gadget to win the race. The photo seemed to show something besides a crop in Mr. Santos's right hand, perhaps even an illicit ''battery'' device to shock the horse across the finish line. As the story took hold over the weekend, you could almost hear the harrumphs and the tut-tuts from the mint julep crowd, which had barely considered the New York team in the running.

title: New York Pays for the Steak, Boston the Cigar
description: New York area residents spend more on meat and poultry than those in other large metropolitan areas in the United States, a new federal survey reports.

title: Cause of Death Unknown For Cowboys' Haywood
description: An autopsy yesterday on Ennis Haywood, the Dallas Cowboys running back who died Sunday at a hospital in Arlington, Tex., did not determine the cause of death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSTEN, GEORGE F.
description: CUSTEN - George F., of Brooklyn, New York and Montgomery, VT. Passed away on May 10. Beloved son of Allen and the late Lenore, brother of Martin & Barbara. Professor of Communications and Film, CUNY Graduate Center. Burial on Thursday 2:30 PM, Menorah Gardens & Funeral Chapel, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Iranian Leader Visits Beirut In Show of Shiite Solidarity
description: Sprinkled with rose petals and rice, President Mohammad Khatami of Iran arrived here today to a glowing embrace from the Lebanese government and tens of thousands of chanting and cheering Lebanese Shiites.

title: Rude Awakening
description: Only a few months ago, in what already feels like a different era, China's leaders were riding high. No one, neither critics nor partisans of the Communist Party, imagined that a viral disease was about to cause the equivalent of a national train wreck.

title: Navajo Miners Battle a Deadly Legacy of Yellow Dust
description: I drove west across an ocher sagebrush plain, past pinto ponies grazing next to a Pentecostal revival tent, past the ribbed, rutted dirt road that leads north to Chaco Canyon, the sacred, ancestral home of the Anasazi, the ancient ones.

title: U.S. to Rely More on Private Companies' Satellite Images
description: President Bush is ordering federal agencies to rely much more heavily on private satellite companies to provide images from space, a significant shift from current policy, administration officials said today.

title: Betrayal of Trust: The Jayson Blair Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 18 about experts who doubt that Iraq has unconventional weapons misstated the connection of a former United Nations inspector, who is among the skeptics, to the book ''War on Iraq: What Team Bush Doesn't Want You to Know.'' And a correction in this space on April 19 misspelled the former inspector's surname. He was Scott Ritter, not Ridder; he was a contributor to the book, which is by William Rivers Pitt.

title: Lullabies In a Bottle: Prescribing For Children
description: More than half of primary care pediatricians have prescribed drugs for sleep problems and nearly three-quarters have recommended over-the-counter medicines, a new study has found.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertising Company's Hopes Fade
description: Britain's debt-laden, second-largest advertising company, Cordiant, said takeover offers were unlikely to reach its current share price. Cordiant's stock fell by almost one third after the announcement, then recovered to close at 8.5 pence (13.7 cents), a fall of 11 percent for the day. Analysts said investors were counting on the company's lenders, which are owed more than $260 million, taking shares in a debt-for-equity swap. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Iraqis Race To Fill Void In Journalism
description: In the rush to fill the void left by the demise of the old state-run Iraqi news outlets, dozens of new ventures are starting up, representing a spectrum of religious groups and political parties, as well as some projects planned by the Americans.

title: Israel and the Settlers
description: To the Editor:

description: An article on April 18 about experts who doubt that Iraq has unconventional weapons misstated the connection of a former United Nations inspector, who is among the skeptics, to the book ''War on Iraq: What Team Bush Doesn't Want You to Know.'' And a correction in this space on April 19 misspelled the former inspector's surname. He was Scott Ritter, not Ridder; he was a contributor to the book, which is by William Rivers Pitt.

title: Experts Fear a Cholera Epidemic in Basra
description: As sewage continues to spill into the streets of this city, Iraq's second largest, and the local population is increasingly relying on water from fetid canals, the World Health Organization warned today that Basra was poised for an epidemic of cholera.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Mercury Buys Performant For $22.5 Million
description: The Mercury Interactive Corporation has bought Performant Inc. for $22.5 million. Mercury will add products that find errors in the Java language for writing Internet programs. Performant is backed by Washington Mutual Inc. and investors including the Madrona Venture Group, Performant's Web site said. The company has worked on products with Mercury previously, Mercury said in a statement on its Web site. The transaction closed May 5. Sun Microsystems developed Java, which became popular because it works with various computers and software. Java vies with Microsoft's .Net software for program developers. Shares of Mercury rose $1.77, or about 5 percent, to $37.52.

title: KODAK TO BUY RAPID-PROCESSING TECHNOLOGY FOR KIOSKS
description: Eastman Kodak said it had agreed to buy the 's rapid-film-processing technology of Applied Science Fiction Inc. to increase sales at photo kiosks. The price was not disclosed. The system develops conventional film without chemicals, converts photos into digital files, prints pictures and stores them on a compact disc in minutes, Kodak said. Kodak is trying to encourage photo printing because photographic paper is one of its more profitable products, and because sales of regular film are declining as consumers shift to digital cameras, which do not use it. The company has hired executives experienced in digital imaging, including Antonio Perez, formerly of the Hewlett-Packard Company, as chief operating officer. Kodak, based in Rochester, has more than 40,000 kiosks, or free-standing photo-developing machines, worldwide.

title: Executives Warn Britain Not to Reject The Euro
description: With a reluctant Britain set to signal whether it wants to adopt the euro currency, a group of 26 senior figures from major corporations warned Prime Minister Tony Blair today that rejecting it would have ''serious consequences for Britain's future prosperity.''

title: Azteca in Debt Deal
description: The company that controls TV Azteca of Mexico has negotiated an exchange with holders of slightly more than half of $150 million in bonds maturing in July.

title: Asbestos Fund At Hartford Nearly Triples
description: With a new surge of asbestos litigation hitting the insurance industry, the Hartford Financial Services Group said yesterday that it was nearly tripling its reserves to pay for potential claims for asbestos-related illnesses and deaths.

title: Bertelsmann Agrees to Sell Its Science and Trade Unit
description: Bertelsmann has agreed to sell its science and trade publishing business to two British buyout firms for about $1.2 billion, executives close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, FRED S.
description: RUBEN-Fred S. Of White Plains, N.Y. Formerly of Forest Hlls, N.Y. and Mannheim, Germany. Passed away May 11, 2003 at age 93. He served as President and Chairman of Simon Manges and Son, Inc. until his retirement. He was the devoted husband of Ilse, beloved father of Jane Guttman, cherished grandfather of Jennifer and Robert Schlau and Catherine and Christopher Guttman-McCabe, proud great grandfather of Steven and Alexa Schlau and Anna and Abigail Guttman - McCabe. Funeral services were held Monday, May 12th. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association or the Arthritis Foundation of New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Growth
description: India's industrial output rose 5.8 percent in the year ending in March, up from 2.7 percent the previous year, helped by growth in the manufacturing sector. According to the government's Central Statistical Organization, manufacturing grew 6.0 percent in the period. India's financial year runs from April to March. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: A Bombshell of Modernism Recaptured
description: In the spring of 1927 two European capitals witnessed profound portents of progress. One, in Paris, had global implications: the landing of Charles Lindbergh at Le Bourget Airport, completing the first solo transatlantic flight and heralding the age of air travel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, DOROTHY
description: ISAACS - Dorothy. Beloved wife of the late Martin Isaacs. Cherished mother of Joan and Daniel Siff, Susan and Sanford Zeitler. Loving grandmother of Dara and Laurence Sheller, Jason Sheller, Andrew and Michael Siff. Services will be held Tuesday, May 13th, at 11:30AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Turner Drops Out Of Games Bidding
description: AOL Time Warner dropped out of the bidding to acquire the media rights to the 2010 and 2012 Olympics yesterday, citing the rigorous definition of a broadcast network by the International Olympic Committee.

title: New Study Finds 60 Million Uninsured During a Year
description: Nearly 60 million people lack health insurance at some point in the year, the Congressional Budget Office said today, adding that official estimates fail to distinguish between people who lack coverage for a few months and those who are uninsured for a full year or more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURO, CARMINE J.
description: MAURO-Carmine J. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CITADEL BROADCASTING CORP., a unit of Forstman Little & Co., New York, said it would buy 11 radio stations from Wilks Broadcasting, a unit of the Wicks Group of Cos., for $133 million.

title: KRISPY KREME TO OPEN STORES IN MEXICO IN JOINT VENTURE
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc. said yesterday it planned to open 20 doughnut shops in Mexico in the next six years in a joint venture with the closely held Grupo Axo of Mexico City. Krispy Kreme will have a 30 percent interest in the partnership. Financial terms were not disclosed. The foreign venture is its fourth, after agreements to move into Canada, Australia and New Zealand, and Britain. Krispy Kreme, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has more than 280 stores in the United States and Canada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILNA, GAIL J.
description: SILNA-Gail J., 39. Our beautiful shining light, died on May 11 after a long, courageous battle with Aids. A ray of sunshine with her warmth, wit, compassion and generosity, her untimely passing will be a void in all our lives. A graduate of Boston University, Gail was one of a kind, a free spirit who will always be remembered by those who were lucky enough to have known and loved her. Cherished daughter of Ozzie Silna of Malibu, CA. and Arline Silna Altman of NYC. Loving sister to Robin and Jeff, and adoring aunt to Matthew, Corey and Charlotte. Gail and her endearing smile will be missed by her entire family as well as many friends. Services will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue on Wednesday, at 11:15 AM. Contributions may be made to Concerned Parents for AIDS Research (CPFA), 120 Wall Street, NY NY 10005-3902 or any AIDS organization of your choice.

title: Report Backs H.I.V. Drug
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, the biggest maker of AIDS drugs in the nation, has demonstrated that its experimental drug, atazanavir, for H.I.V. is safe and effective, according to a Food and Drug Administration report.

title: Old Buildings? He Loves Them and Their Values
description: IT is late afternoon in Greenwich Village, with gray storm clouds lowering over Manhattan and the tolling of the Jefferson Market clock heard through the open windows. On afternoons like this, when the sun is enveloped in haze and the city is caught in a reverent Sunday hush before evening, Paul Gunther likes to look at the federal-style facades of the brownstones along 10th Street, where he lives, finding comfort in their form. He leans out the window and points to the columns, the brick facades and the volutes, the ornamental scrolls that curl under the eves of the houses.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Bank Merger Advances
description: A Malaysian bank, EON Bank, and AMMB Holdings, the parent of AmBank Group, another leading Malaysian bank, have begun talks on a potential merger after winning the approval of the central bank. The combined bank would be the nation's third-largest. The proposed merger could represent the start of a new round in Malaysia's efforts to consolidate its banking industry ahead of deregulation in 2007, when foreign banks will be allowed to compete locally. The country has already succeeded in combining 54 institutions into 10. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Company Sues MasterCard Over Fees for Online Sales
description: Paycom Billing Services, a company that processes credit card and check transactions for online merchants, sued MasterCard International yesterday, asserting that MasterCard violated antitrust laws and charged excessive fees.

title: Boat Flips; Man Is Missing
description: Divers were searching the waters of the Charlotteburg Reservoir in Kinnelon, N.J., late last night for a man who was still missing hours after the fishing boat he was in with two other men capsized, the authorities said.

description: There are many different ways to categorize the subway's 468 stations: the oldest, the busiest, the deepest, the darkest, the hottest, the most fragrant.

title: Bush Trails a Democratic Senator to Nebraska for His Tax Cut Vote
description: President Bush landed here today to chase after the crucial swing vote of Senator Ben Nelson, a moderate Democrat who is the target of an all-out White House lobbying effort with Congress for passage of Mr. Bush's half-trillion-dollar tax cut plan.

title: Mets Take Advantage Of Being the Visitors
description: The Mets' season unraveled here last August as their losing streak reached 12 games and Manager Bobby Valentine had a postgame meltdown on live television.

title: RIVERSIDE TO ACQUIRE DWYER GROUP FOR $50 MILLION
description: The Riverside Company, a buyout firm that manages more than $500 million in capital, agreed to acquire a franchiser, the Dwyer Group, for about $50 million. Riverside will pay $6.75 for each of Dwyer's seven million common shares outstanding, the companies said. The price represents a 59 percent premium to Dwyer's closing price of $4.25 a share on Friday. Including the cost of Dwyer warrants and options, the transaction is valued at about $50 million, Dwyer's chief financial officer, Tom Buckley, said. Dwyer Group, the owner of franchise companies like Mr. Electric and Mr. Rooter, will become a closely held unit of Riverside after the sale. Riverside, which has offices in New York, Cleveland, Dallas and San Francisco, manages three funds and has completed 69 acquisitions since 1988.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Education Plan Not Blocked
description: A judge yesterday refused to temporarily block Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to reorganize the city's local school districts. A group of state lawmakers and the school principals' union have sued to stop the plan, which would reorganize the districts into 10 geographically larger instructional zones. They argued that it violates state law by eliminating the local districts. Some lawmakers had asked for a temporary restraining order, but Justice Doris Ling-Cohan of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday rejected the request. She noted that the city education department has said that school district offices will remain open through the end of this school year. She scheduled a June 3 hearing on the larger lawsuit. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Truckers On Strike
description: A strike by truck drivers has shut down two-thirds of the shipments of containerized cargo through Pusan, the major port city on the southeastern corner of the Korean peninsula. About 80 percent of Korea's containerized exports pass through Pusan. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONEY, HELEN
description: MOONEY-Helen. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Myron Fenster, Int. Sr. Rabbi Steven Markowitz, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Telecom Profit
description: The Dutch telecommunications concern Royal KPN reported a first-quarter net profit of 113 million euros ($130.3 million), reversing a year-earlier loss of 225 million euros. Including a one-time gain of 657 million euros, the company earned 770 million euros ($888.2 million), its best quarterly result since a management change two years ago. Most of the one-time gain was related to the sale of its directory services business. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: 2 Men Fire at a Police Officer in Newark
description: Two men shot at a police officer patrolling the West Ward in Newark last night, but the officer was not injured, the authorities said.

title: Interior Dept. Official's Role As Oil Lobbyist Is Investigated
description: Responding to a request from Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut and a candidate for president, the inspector general of the Interior Department is investigating possible conflicts of interest involving a top Interior official who used to be a lobbyist for the oil, gas and mining interests he now regulates.

title: George of Arabia
description: As the scene of a summit with the most important emissary of the American superpower, the office of the new prime minister is certainly quite modest: Mahmud Abbas, 68, temporarily has only a rented floor in a plain, four-story residential building on the dusty road leading from Ramallah to Nablus in which to receive US Secretary of State Colin Powell.

title: F.S.U.'s Bowden Endorses Expansion of the A.C.C.
description: Bobby Bowden, the Florida State football coach, does not own a vote on expansion in the Atlantic Coast Conference, but he does possess two national championship trophies and plenty of gumption. Age has only sharpened his sense for what makes for great theater. In sports, it is competition. And in the A.C.C., Bowden said, it should be Miami.

title: Thieves Take Cellini Sculpture From Art Museum in Vienna
description: In an audacious caper that matched cunning thieves against apparently complacent security guards, intruders broke into Vienna's art history museum before dawn on Sunday, stealing a 16th-century gold-plated sculpture by the Florentine master Benvenuto Cellini.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTER, WILLIAM
description: WITTER-William., age 73, of New York, NY died Sunday, May 11, 2003, at his home after a short illness. Born in San Francisco, California, Mr. Witter has been a New York resident since 1953. He was the principal of William D. Witter, Inc., an investment counseling firm that he founded 26 years ago. He is survived by his wife, Inger Kullberg Witter, their two children, Michael and Christina, of New York City, and his sister, Ann Witter, of San Francisco, CA. He is also survived by his former wife, Susan Rentschler Witter, of New York City, and their four children, Virginia Woods, of Altamont, NY; Elizabeth Tacy Mayer, of Los Altos, CA; Sidney Daire, of New York City; and William Perkins Witter, of Boulder, CO. He is survived by nine grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, New York City, on Tuesday May 20, 2003, at 2:00 PM. An informal reception in the offices of William D. Witter, Inc. 51st floor, Citicorp Center, 153 East 53rd Street, will follow these services

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: MORE RUNWAYS URGED The company that runs London's biggest three airports, BAA, urged the authorities to build three new runways in southeast London to keep pace with an expansion in air travel. The government, which has forecast that the number of people flying in and out of the London area will almost triple to 300 million a year by 2030, is considering how to cope with the increase.   Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Pataki Defends An Old Budget Despite the Gap In a New One
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today fiercely defended his handling of last year's budget, even as some prominent Democrats in Albany questioned his truthfulness and called for his budget director, Carole E. Stone, to step down.

title: One Faith, One Political Goal, and Set to Collide
description: Iraq's Shiite Muslims have emerged from years of official repression and slaughter only to face a potentially dangerous new battle between rival clerics competing for political power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEYLON, ANNE M. (NEE DONOVAN)
description: NEYLON-Anne M. (nee Donovan). On May 10, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Walter J., loving sister of Jeremiah F. and the late John, Charles, Julia Kelly and Daniel J. Also survived by many nieces and nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews, and many fond cousins. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 9:30 AM at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: 11th-Hour Top Dog For Nets Is Martin
description: When the Nets' Kenyon Martin walked behind the curtains, away from the glare of the television lights, the Celtics' Antoine Walker was standing there, waiting his turn to face the reporters' questions. Martin walked out, almost oblivious to Walker, perhaps the first time in the last eight days that Martin did not know exactly where Walker was and what his next move would be.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the decision of Randi Weingarten, the New York City teachers' union president, to withdraw support for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's school reorganization plan misstated the name of another organization she leads and her title in it. (The name was also misstated in articles on May 8, May 3 and April 11; the title was wrong on April 11.) The organization is the Municipal Labor Committee, not Municipal Labor Council. Ms. Weingarten is chairwoman, not president.

title: Bali Bombing Case Opens With Morning-Long Indictment
description: It took a team of prosecutors all morning today to read out the 33-page indictment of the first man to go on trial for the bombing of two Bali nightclubs last year that killed more than 200 people.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: An SK Warning
description: Sovereign Asset Management threatened to sell its 14.99 percent stake in the SK Corporation, South Korea's largest oil refiner, if the company keeps up ''unconditional support'' for SK Global, the SK group's trading firm. Sovereign Asset, based in Monte Carlo, Monaco, charged that the SK Corporation's commitment to SK Global was ''needlessly weakening the company's condition.'' Don Kirk (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL DROPS. Heating oil prices fell on speculation that refiners will increase reserves before next winter. In New York, heating oil for June delivery fell 1.07 cents, or 1.5 percent, to 70.82 cents a gallon.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MAZDA REPORTS PROFIT SURGE The Mazda Motor Corporation said its profit tripled in the year that ended March 31, helped by cost cutting and the introduction of new products. Mazda, Japan's fifth-largest carmaker, earned 24.1 billion yen ($205.6 million) last year as sales grew 13 percent. The company, one-third owned by the Ford Motor Company , expects net income to increase 24 percent this year, though sales are projected to increase just 2.3 percent.   Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Guilty Plea In Corruption Trial
description: The former executive director of the Asbury Park Housing Authority pleaded guilty to federal tax fraud yesterday, the United States attorney's office announced. The executive director, Kenneth E. Nixon, Jr. admitted to participating in a scheme to regain his $80,000 a year position after he was dismissed in 1995 for mismanagement. The charge involved bribing Monmouth County officials so Mr. Nixon could eventually be voted back into office. Mr. Nixon is scheduled for sentencing on Aug. 26, when he faces a maximum of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: New Overseer Arrives in Iraq In U.S. Shuffle
description: America's new civilian administrator for Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, arrived in Baghdad today as several members of the team of his predecessor, retired Lt. Gen. Jay Garner, and General Garner himself prepared to leave over the coming weeks in a sudden overhaul that has rattled Iraqi political leaders.

title: Critics of Graduation Exam Threaten Boycott in Florida
description: A small group of minority politicians and prominent religious leaders in Florida is threatening a boycott of some of the state's largest industries in the hope of forcing the suspension of an achievement test that thousands of high school seniors recently failed.

title: Heart Pump and Brain Injury: A Riddle Deepens With Time
description: Each year, 300,000 Americans have bypass surgery to improve blood flow to their hearts. Most of the operations succeed. But a minority of patients leave the hospital confused or forgetful, unable to think clearly or unable to concentrate.

title: Russia's Latest Oil and Gas Oasis
description: On this desolate shore of Sakhalin Island, where sea ice blurs into treeless tundra, stands a bright blue drilling rig, 22 stories high and fresh from Louisiana.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a visit to the White House by Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain, who supported the United States in the Iraq war, misstated the title of Jacques Chirac, the French leader who opposed it. (The error also occurred in an article on April 10 about European reaction to the arrival of American troops in downtown Baghdad.) Mr. Chirac is president, not prime minister.

description: SCHULMAN-Molly. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, N.Y. mourns the passing of our esteemed member and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Jeffrey Sinensky, Pres.

description: At least 20 people, including seven Americans, were killed in Monday night's synchronized truck bomb attacks.

description: A mass grave, holding the bodies of Shiites who rose up against Saddam Hussein in 1991, has been uncovered about 50 miles south of Baghdad.

title: Tear Off a Strip And Apply Elbow Grease
description: For those who own silver, keeping ahead of the tarnish is always a challenge. Now, for a quick touch-up of that belt buckle or picture frame, or a bigger job like cleaning a long-unused serving dish, there are Mrs. Cooper's Silver Wipes. They are used dry for most polishing jobs, but when moistened, are capable of tackling heavy tarnish.

title: Justice Dept. Plans to Step Up Gun-Crime Prosecutions
description: Justice Department officials said today that they planned to step up prosecutions of gun crimes as part of a new initiative, even as a private study said prosecutors had ''ignored'' a vast majority of gun crimes.

title: Disorder in Iraq: Who Is to Blame?
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Argentine Leader Still in Presidential Race
description: In a day that began with political drama but quickly degenerated into farce, a former Argentine president, Carlos Menem, was reported Tuesday to have withdrawn from a runoff election scheduled for Sunday, then to have retracted his resignation after aides convinced him not to give up his uphill battle for a third term.

title: Troubled Teenagers
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Defend Differences In Searches For 2 Women
description: When Svetlana Aronov, a 44-year-old rare-books dealer who lived on the Upper East Side, disappeared on March 3 while walking her father's dog, the Police Department mobilized. The commander of Manhattan detectives held a news conference with a giant photograph of the missing woman.

title: College President's Rsum Fails Student Exam
description: When people here suggest to Joel Elliott, the soft-spoken student newspaper editor at Toccoa Falls College, a tiny evangelical institution tucked into the northeast Georgia hills, that he ''do the Christian thing'' and soft-pedal a story, he now has a ready retort.

title: Inside Minnesota, N.H.L. Is a Local Call
description: In a land of 10,000 lakes, some of them will freeze in the winter. In that children will still have energy to burn, the sometimes heated sport of hockey is a natural fit with the sometimes chilly state of Minnesota.

title: Meanwhile, Back at the Market
description: SHAD are widely considered the boniest of all fish. There is, in fact, an Indian legend about them that holds that the shad was once a porcupine unhappy with its lot in life. When it complained, the Great Spirit turned the animal inside out and threw it in the river.

title: Revamped S.U.V. Found To Cause Worse Injuries
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that a crash test of the 2003 Lincoln Navigator sport utility vehicle indicated that it had become more harmful to people riding in passenger cars than the 1999 model.

title: He's 20, and at 93, She's His Oldest Friend
description: Late in the afternoon, the old woman knew to look for him. Four o'clock. Their time.

title: Sharon Rules Out Dismantling Settlements
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon has dismissed the idea of restraining Israeli settlements as not ''on the horizon,'' taking a hard line against a goal of a new American-backed peace plan in remarks published today.

title: Dallas Holds Serve Against Sacramento
description: With one shriek of a referee's whistle, the momentum in the tumultuous Western Conference semifinal series between Dallas and Sacramento took a defining swing.

title: U.S. Contests Europe's Ban On Some Food
description: The Bush administration filed suit today at the World Trade Organization to force Europe to lift its ban on genetically modified food, a move that was postponed earlier this year by the debate on Iraq.

title: J.P. MORGAN FORMS PARTNERSHIP WITH INTRAWEST
description: J. P. Morgan Chase & Company and the Intrawest Corporation, which owns ski slopes like Stratton in Vermont and Whistler in British Columbia, formed a partnership to finance and develop residences at resorts in the United States. J. P. Morgan's Fleming Asset Management unit and Intrawest will own the partnership, which will be called Leisura Developments US, said Larry Ellman, head of acquisitions for the real estate group at Fleming. J. P. Morgan will own two-thirds of the partnership. Intrawest builds hotels, vacation homes and golf courses at its resorts. Intrawest, which is based in Vancouver, will pay $40 million to $50 million for its minority interest.

title: Experimental Drug May Fight SARS, Researchers Say
description: An experimental drug tested as a common cold remedy and then shelved may, with chemical tinkering, fight the virus that causes severe acute respiratory syndrome, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Powell Gets Warm Words in Moscow but No Deal on Iraq
description: MOSCOW, May 14  After weeks of pointed Russian protests over the war in Iraq, President Vladimir V. Putin and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell declared today that Russia and the United States had overcome their recent differences. They then met in the Kremlin and failed to resolve most of those involving the future of Iraq.

title: Sports of The Times; Can't Yankees Be a Little Vulnerable?
description: With all due respect to Derek Jeter and, for that matter, Mariano Rivera, the big, bad Yankees seemed a bit more cuddly with Erick Almonte at shortstop and Juan Acevedo coming out of the bullpen to close.

title: A Season for Fresh and Often Colorful Eggs
description: A hundred years ago, spring was egg season. ''Spring sunlight once signaled the hen to lay; lack of sunlight in fall and winter signaled her to cease laying,'' reads a pamphlet from the American Egg Board, which then explains that ''scientifically-controlled light'' makes the year-round egg possible.

title: Cheney Tells of Meeting Rumsfeld 35 Years Ago
description: It is part of Washington lore that Donald Rumsfeld gave young Dick Cheney his start in government, hiring him as an assistant in the Nixon administration.

title: Multicolored $20 Bill Is Coming in the Fall
description: The Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve today introduced a new design for paper currency, which will include colors other than the standard black and green, in an effort to deter counterfeiting.

title: Brandeis Scholarships Create Unlikely Partners in a Program to Foster Peace
description: Maisa Khshaibon, a senior at Brandeis University, spends many of her evenings laughing and joking with her best friend, Marina Pevzner, a junior. Their conversations go beyond classes and clothes, and often turn to human rights, suicide bombings and the future of their homeland, Israel.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: NEO-NAZI CRIME UP Right-wing extremist groups have become more violent, even as their overall numbers have declined, the country's domestic intelligence agency said in a report. The report, released by Interior Minister Otto Schily, said that while membership in right-wing organizations had declined by 10 percent at the end of 2002, to around 45,000, the number of acts of violence they motivated increased by 8 percent, to 772. The report also noted a rise in the number of foreign organizations based in Germany that are believed to present a security threat. Radical Islamic groups make up a large part of them, with about 30,000 members. Hugh Eakin (NYT)

title: Briefly Noted
description: AMERICAS

title: In Shift, Appeals Court Opens Hearing on a 9/11 Suspect
description: A federal appeals court agreed today to hold a public hearing over a long-secret legal struggle that is threatening to derail the civilian prosecution of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Xanadu in the Meadowlands: Exotica Close to Home
description: Three years ago Mack-Cali Realty, of Cranford, N.J., made a forceful move to expand its focus beyond the Northeast, announcing the intention to acquire another large real estate investment trust in Texas. But after Wall Street analysts criticized the plan and the stock price dropped, the company's chief executive, Mitchell E. Hersh, called off the nearly completed deal, pivoted back in the direction from whence he came and renewed concentration on Mack-Cali's core market, the Northeast.

title: John L. Petrarca, 51, Architect Who Made Old Look Like New
description: John L. Petrarca, an architect who brought a modern sensibility to the old blocks of TriBeCa in Lower Manhattan, died last Friday at his home there. He was 51.

title: Letters
description: Food for the Emotions

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Posts $62 Million Loss
description: Applied Materials Inc., the largest supplier of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, yesterday reported a net loss of $62 million, or 4 cents a share, down from a net profit of $52 million, or 3 cents a share, for the second quarter of last year. The company has suffered during the prolonged slump in the world chip market. Net sales for the quarter, ended April 27, were $1.11 billion, down 4 percent from $1.16 billion in the second quarter of 2002, but up 5 percent over last quarter. In March, Applied Materials, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., announced a realignment plan that resulted in charges of $152 million because of layoffs and restructuring. Excluding charges, Applied earned 3 cents a share -- a penny better than the consensus estimate from analysts. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: F.C.C. Vote on Media Ownership Unlikely to Be Delayed
description: Two Democratic members of the Federal Communications Commission tried today to postpone a final vote on rules that would expand the reach of the nation's largest media conglomerates, but two Republican commissioners promptly opposed the delay.

title: Like Potato Fields, His Memorial Lies Fallow
description: BRIAN TOLLE, the artist behind the Irish Hunger Memorial in Lower Manhattan, is standing in front of it on a recent gray afternoon. But he is not setting foot onto the memorial, which was quietly closed in April for emergency repairs, less than a year after it opened to much acclaim.

title: Washington Asks, How Firm Are Saudis on Extremists?
description: The suicide bombing on Monday night in Riyadh that killed at least seven Americans has revived a sharp debate here over whether Saudi Arabia has moved firmly enough to fight Islamic militancy within its borders and to stanch the flow of money to terrorist groups overseas, lawmakers and Middle East experts say.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOUTH AFRICA: MAN GUILTY OF KILLING EX-FIRST LADY A security guard was found guilty of the 2001 murder of Marike de Klerk, the former wife of F. W. de Klerk, the last president in South Africa's era of apartheid. Mrs. de Klerk, 64, who was married to the former president for 39 years before their divorce in 1998, was stabbed and strangled in her luxury apartment near Cape Town. The guard, Luyanda Mboniswa, 23, who worked at the apartment complex, was convicted by the Cape High Court of murder and house breaking with aggravating circumstances. Sentencing is expected on Thursday. (Reuters)

title: INSIDE
description: F.D.A. Faulted on Implants

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Advertiser's Sales Fall
description: The big advertising group Havas said revenue fell 20 percent in the first quarter, to 402 million euros ($465 million). Havas said it suffered from a sharp drop in the exchange rate between the dollar and the euro and weak business in the United States and Europe, which has hurt the advertising sector over all. Excluding currency exchange factors, its sales fell 5.8 percent. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 30 about ramps, a wild relative of onions, misidentified the disease that might be prevented by their high levels of vitamin C. It is scurvy; rickets is usually caused by a lack of vitamin D.

title: U.S. Lowers 'Normal' Levels for Blood Pressure Readings
description: Millions of people who in the past would have been told that their blood pressure was fine actually have a condition called "prehypertension," and should do something about it, according to a new report by government health experts.

title: Devils Remember to Bring Their Offense for Game 2
description: The Eastern Conference playoffs have developed a theme: whoever scores first, wins. Coming into tonight, both the Devils and the Ottawa Senators were 5-0 in the postseason when scoring the game's first goal.

title: Two Wilsons In Cahoots For Archive
description: There are two Robert Wilsons deeply involved in the arts in New York: Robert M. Wilson, the theater and opera director, and Robert W. Wilson, the philanthropist and former chairman of the New York City Opera.

title: AMERICA WEST IS ENDING MEALS FOR PASSENGERS IN COACH
description: America West Airlines, which recently laid off managers and sought concessions from suppliers to reduce costs, will end free meals in the coach sections of its planes after this week. The move, on eight long-distance flights, will save ''a couple million dollars a year,'' said Janice Monahan, a spokeswoman for the airline, a unit of the America West Holdings Corporation. America West reported a loss of $62 million in the first quarter after the war in Iraq reduced air travel and raised fuel prices.

title: Tests Found Fake Papers Helped Agents Enter Country
description: Undercover agents testing security measures at the country's airports and border crossings were repeatedly allowed to enter the country after showing customs inspectors counterfeit driver's licenses and birth certificates, Congressional officials said today.

title: 20th-Century Masters Dominate Art Auction
description: Penny-pinching, not passion, dominated the behavior of last night's audience at Sotheby's, in the first of three back-to-back auctions of contemporary art. Up for sale were classic works by masters whose price levels have, for the most part, either risen or stayed consistently high over the last few years.

title: NAVISTAR SAYS IT WILL RAISE OUTPUT BY 17% AT OHIO PLANT
description: The Navistar International Corporation plans to increase an Ohio factory's daily production of medium-duty trucks and school buses 17 percent starting in July. The plant, in Springfield, will begin building 167 of the trucks and buses on July 21, up from 143 now, a spokesman, Roy Wiley, said. Navistar has not decided whether to increase employment at the factory, which has a single shift with 1,500 workers and 1,700 on indefinite layoff, he said.

title: Rising Costs Threaten Field at Indy
description: The final day of time trials for the Indianapolis 500 is known around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway as Bump Day, because a slowpoke can be bumped from the 33-car starting grid by a faster car. Bump day is almost as frantic, and as harrowing, as race day itself.

title: Eerie Echo Of Present In Futurist Fantasy
description: It's the early 21st century, and a tremor at the San Andreas Fault has devastated nuclear power plants in California. War and environmental havoc have caused famine and infertility throughout the United States. Right-wing Christian fanatics have assassinated the president and the Congress, reconstituting the nation as a male-controlled totalitarian state called Gilead in which women are deprived of all rights. Some of those still able to breed are enslaved as handmaids, after the biblical story of Jacob and Rachel, and forced to copulate with high-ranking commanders in degrading threesomes involving the commanders' barren wives.

title: U.S. Repeats North Korea Stance Before Visit From South's Leader
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 - As President Bush prepared to meet the President of South Korea, the White House reiterated its tough stance against North Korea today. It refused to rule out military force against the North but said again that it hopes for a diplomatic solution to problems with that country.

title: Zany New Music, But Quirkily Compelling
description: Music at the Anthology, started in 1997 by the composers Eleanor Sandresky and Lisa Bielawa, with Philip Glass as its patron saint, has transformed itself from a loose series of concerts to a concentrated festival that bears an uncanny resemblance to Bang on a Can in its salad days. Like Bang on a Can then, MATA - which now goes by its initials, since it is no longer based at the Anthology Film Archives - thrives on composers playing their own works, and on visiting ensembles. The revamped MATA festival is a welcome development for anyone who missed the freewheeling spirit that Bang on a Can brought to New York's new music world in the late 1980's.

title: Japanese Cult Vows to Save a Seal and the World
description: The trees were doing just fine in this tiny mountain hamlet, before the people in the odd white suits showed up the other day. Indeed, in a manner commonly seen in Japan, the pines grow straight and tall here, as neat as columns.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Chancellor's Aide Is Resigning
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is planning to replace the press secretary of Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein with a mayoral press aide in a sign of tightening City Hall control over the Education Department, officials said yesterday. Mr. Klein's press secretary, David K. Chai, is stepping down next week. He will marry in June and said he was following his fiance to Pennsylvania, where she has taken a job. Education officials said that in searching for a successor, Mr. Klein interviewed only one candidate, Jerry Russo, who works in Mr. Bloomberg's press office. The mayor's spokesman, Edward Skyler, declined to comment. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: For Antipasti, Plates of Tapas or Pea Soup, Bring Out the Chilled Sherry
description: SHERRY, served cool in its traditional short, narrow glass, is hard to take seriously at first as something to drink with a meal. The glass is too light, and the wine appears to be insubstantial, too meek to stand up to food.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: PANAMA: STOLEN TREASURES RECOVERED The police said they had recovered Panama's most important collection of pre-Columbian gold artifacts, stolen from the Reina Torres de Arauz Museum in Panama City in February. Undercover agents tracked down the 292 gold relics on Monday afternoon by posing as black-market buyers, the police said. A Panamanian man, whom the police arrested but declined to identify, tried to sell the officers the relics for $10 million. Thirteen people suspected of collaborating in the robbery, including eight culture institute employees, were in custody, the police said. The items date from 500 to 1000 A.D. (Reuters)

title: M.T.A. Describes Steps to Make Financial Data More Available to the Public
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it planned to make substantial changes in the next few months in the way it reports its financial plans. But top officials said the action was not a response to widespread complaints that the authority deceived the public before the recent increase in subway and bus fares.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Orders for new machinery in Japan increased a greater-than-expected 3.8 percent in March from February, pushing total orders 5.8 percent higher in the first quarter. A government survey, however, forecasts that orders, which are a leading indicator of capital spending plans, will fall 10.5 percent from April to June. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SIRIUS RADIO TO BE OFFERED IN SOME FORD CARS Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. , the No. 2 satellite radio broadcaster, said yesterday that the Ford Motor Company would offer Sirius's service in 10 of its 2004 model cars, helping Sirius get more customers. Starting in September, satellite radios will be offered as a dealer option on cars including the Ford Thunderbird, the Lincoln Navigator and the Mercury Mountaineer, Sirius said in a statement. It is the first time the Sirius service will be offered through Ford, although the two companies have had a partnership since 1999, a Ford spokeswoman, Emily Foley, said. Sirius's $12.95-a-month radio service offers 100 channels of programming via satellite. Sirius is counting on Ford to help it sign up the two million subscribers it needs to generate enough revenue to finance its operations and cover debt payments. XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. , the biggest provider of radio service via satellite, has said it has more than 500,000 subscribers. Sirius shares rose 17 cents, or 16 percent, to $1.23.

title: Jeter Is Back, but Yankees Take the Night Off
description: Even before the first pitch, it had already been an unsettling day for Derek Jeter. His life story played out on the video board during batting practice. His every move was cheered robustly. For Jeter, the Yankees' returning star, it was almost too much to take.

title: A Surprising Bit of Theater in a Birthday Tribute
description: It's not often that the world premiere of a New York Philharmonic commission has anything remotely in common with an Eminem vehicle, but such was the case on May 7 in Avery Fisher Hall for a few moments in the middle of Siegfried Matthus's ``Concerto for Two.'' The soloists were the trumpeter Philip Smith and the trombonist Joseph Alessi, and, in place of a typical cadenza, the two squared off in a scene reminiscent (albeit distantly) of the rap battles from Curtis Hanson's hip-hop-fueled movie ``8 Mile.''

title: HASBRO MAKES ITS PRESIDENT ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE, TOO
description: Hasbro Inc., the toymaker, promoted its president and chief operating officer, Alfred Verrecchia, to chief executive to succeed Alan Hassenfeld, who will remain chairman. Mr. Verrecchia, a 38-year Hasbro veteran, said he would be the first person not related to the founder to lead Hasbro, the maker of Mr. Potato Head and Playskool toys. Mr. Hassenfeld, 54, is the third generation of the founding Hassenfeld family. Hasbro, based in Pawtucket, R.I., said it was separating the jobs of chairman and chief executive to free Mr. Hassenfeld to concentrate on corporate governance. Mr. Verrecchia, who is 60, will remain president.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the growing popularity of pork belly on restaurant menus misstated the location of the Niman Ranch, a producer. Its headquarters are in Oakland, Calif., and its hogs are raised in the Midwest. It is not in Colorado.

title: Deep-Fried Turkey To Eat In or Trot Out
description: For the past two Thanksgivings, Aricka Westbrooks (above, right), has fried turkeys in her backyard in Brooklyn. Now she has opened a catering shop specializing in deep-fried turkey to go with a few seats for diners. The shop, called Jive Turkey, is at 441 Myrtle Avenue (Waverly Avenue) in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Echoes of Spain in Just a Few Sips
description: ''IF I had a thousand sons,'' Falstaff pronounced, ''the first humane principle I would teach them should be, to forswear thin potations and to addict themselves to sack.''

title: Vonage Hires Agency For Creative Duties
description: Vonage Holdings in Edison, N.J., which offers telephone services to users of cable and D.S.L. high-speed modems, has named the Gardner-Nelson Project in New York to handle creative duties on its account, which had been handled internally. Billings have not been determined.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: SONY TO SELL PORTABLE GAME PLAYER Sony said it would begin selling a portable game player by the end of 2004. The device, called PSP, is aimed at extending Sony's lead in the market for video game players to hand-held devices. Sony's PlayStation 2 is the top game console, selling more than twice as many units as the Xbox from Microsoft and the GameCube from Nintendo combined. Detailed specifications of the device and its price were not disclosed.   (Bloomberg News)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Chef on the Double

title: A Free Trip For Advocates Of Rent Rules
description: The New York City Council has spent $75,000 in taxpayer money to help galvanize city residents and even bus them here today to lobby state leaders to support rent regulations.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: U.S. General Unsure When or if Weapons Were Destroyed
description: An Army general in northern Iraq said today that Saddam Hussein's government might have destroyed stocks of chemical weapons some time before the United States attacked Iraq to topple Mr. Hussein.

title: A Steinway Brings Back Memories . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Also Not Suave: Knocking Over Props

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGIN, THOMAS P.
description: BERGIN-Thomas P. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Thomas P. Bergin, a Life Member of the Society and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, President Henry F. White Jr., Historian

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Judge Limits Alligator Marketing
description: A federal judge has barred the state from using money from hunting license fees and export taxes to advertise Louisiana's alligator industry. Pelts and Skins, a luxury alligator skin company, had argued that it was forced to pay for generic marketing that detracted from the image of its particular product. Resident alligator hunters pay $25 a year and skin processors are taxed $2 on each hide shipped out of the state, and Pelts and Skins exported more than 80,000 alligator skins in 2002. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: A Surprising Bit of Theater in a Birthday Tribute
description: It's not often that the world premiere of a New York Philharmonic commission has anything remotely in common with an Eminem vehicle, but such was the case on May 7 in Avery Fisher Hall for a few moments in the middle of Siegfried Matthus's ``Concerto for Two.'' The soloists were the trumpeter Philip Smith and the trombonist Joseph Alessi, and, in place of a typical cadenza, the two squared off in a scene reminiscent (albeit distantly) of the rap battles from Curtis Hanson's hip-hop-fueled movie ``8 Mile.''
