description: Head of Troubled Food Unit Of Royal Ahold Steps Down

title: Recipe: Shad Roast
description: Adapted from Marian Cervone

title: Two Right Feet
description: Two right feet. That was the tipoff. The skeleton in the coffin had two right feet.

title: We'll Always Have Pork Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Condemns Saudi Blasts; 7 Americans Are Dead
description: At least 20 people, including seven Americans, were killed in the synchronized truck bomb attacks here on Monday night, Saudi officials said today, and President Bush vowed to hunt down and punish those responsible. Nine additional bodies appeared to be the charred remains of some of the attackers, the officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on May 11 about the resilience of Hezbollah, the militant group based in Lebanon, referred incorrectly to one of many popular public images dotting the country's south and intended as signals of Shiite might. It shows a cutout of a larger-than-life Ayatollah Khomeini standing on top of a tank, but the vehicle is one of those that were left behind when the Southern Lebanon Army, Israel's ally in the region, withdrew; it was not a captured Israeli tank.

title: In This Washington, Not All That's Local Is Politics
description: Washington, a city filled with attractions dedicated to preserving the nation's history and culture, now has a museum to call its own.

title: A Culinary Adventure in a Modest Setting
description: PARISH & COMPANY builds a big bank account of good will before the meal even begins. A small bread basket appears out of nowhere, filled with thin strips of warm, chewy focaccia. With the basket comes a plate with a pool of olive oil flavored with garlic, parsley and tiny flecks of anchovy. The flavors are fresh, potent and beautifully balanced. The garlic doesn't overpower the fruit in the olive oil. The anchovies assert themselves without shouting. The olive-oil dip is so intoxicating, in fact, that it represents a clear and present danger to the meal. Undisciplined diners will binge.

title: Bloomberg Faces the Public, and the Music, With Some Assurance
description: He did not emote, in a Bill Clinton-I-feel-your-pain way. Nor did he spar with questioners, in a Rudolph W. Giuliani-confrontational way.

title: U.S. and Saudis Sensed Attacks Were Imminent
description: For more than two weeks before the Monday bombings, American and Saudi officials had grown increasingly alarmed by intercepted communications that provided what they called ''strong indications'' that Islamic militants were preparing a terrorist attack against Americans in Saudi Arabia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOJKA, CASIMIR F.
description: SOJKA-Casimir F. On May 13, 2003, beloved husband of Anne W. (nee Wareniski), father of Theodore, Gregory, and Kenneth, and four grandchildren. Graduate of The University of Michigan, and Boston University Law School. Former Commander, The American Legion, New York State Department. Reposing Stout Funeral Services Inc, Wednesday & Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Burial to follow on Saturday, in Montague, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to: The American Legion Children Camp, 191 Canal Street, 5th Floor, New York, New York 10013.

title: Finding the Next Great Sitcom
description: Americans may not want to live at Ray Barone's house -- or across the street from his parents -- but they do want to be part of the extended family, near enough to see the goings-on from week to week. That's what the long-term success of a situation comedy like ''Everybody Loves Raymond'' really means, a half-hour dose of familiarity. Getting the formula right was never easy, not even in what once looked like a slower-paced, more homogeneous America. But even as the networks roll out their fall schedules for advertisers this week, the discussion in television circles seems to be just when and why the sitcom died. Was it the explosion in reality programming? Sept. 11? The impatience of studio executives? A change in the American sense of humor?

title: 500 More Apartments Seen In Downtown Building Boom
description: A developer is buying two office buildings in the financial district for more than $100 million. Until recently, the buildings were part of a site where a new trading complex for the New York Stock Exchange and a 50-story skyscraper had been planned.

title: Mets' 7-0 Lead Disappears in the Thin Air
description: Catcher Mike Piazza spent most of this afternoon in a faded blue T-shirt and shorts in the recesses of the Mets' clubhouse, out of view of reporters. The Mets did not take early batting practice, so he did not take ground balls at first base, as he did Monday for the first time in 10 years.

title: Bucking the Tide, eBay Expands in Silicon Valley
description: Last month, eBay, the Internet auction company, brought some welcome news to a city and region that have been suffering from one of the worst office market slumps in the nation. The eight-year-old company, which had toyed with giving up its headquarters here, announced that it would not only keep its West San Jose complex but would also buy a 32-acre campus from the software developer Novell on the opposite side of town.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: NEW AMBASSADOR TO PAKISTAN India has appointed Shiv Shankar Menon, currently ambassador to China, as its next ambassador to Pakistan, the Foreign Ministry said. Mr. Memo, 53, is a career diplomat. Press Trust of India said Mr. Menon had been accepted by Pakistan, clearing the way for his move to Islamabad. As part of fresh peace initiatives, India and Pakistan recently announced steps to restore full diplomatic relations. Diplomatic links were broken after an attack on Parliament in 2001. India blamed Pakistan for the attack, and recalled its ambassador. A few months later, it asked Pakistan to do the same. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on May 11 about the resilience of Hezbollah, the militant group based in Lebanon, referred incorrectly to one of many popular public images dotting the country's south and intended as signals of Shiite might. It shows a cutout of a larger-than-life Ayatollah Khomeini standing on top of a tank, but the vehicle is one of those that were left behind when the Southern Lebanon Army, Israel's ally in the region, withdrew; it was not a captured Israeli tank.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest Rate Cut
description: The South Korean central bank lowered its basic interest rate to 4 percent from 4.25 percent amid signs of a slowing economy. It was the first interest rate cut since the week after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, and Park Seung, governor of the central bank, said another cut was possible if weakness persisted. The bank has forecast that the country's economy will grow at a rate of 4 percent this year, down from more than 6 percent last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Pataki Banks Heavily on Gambling in New Plan to Rescue New York City
description: A day before his promised veto of the State Legislature's budget plan, Gov. George E. Pataki today tried to change the subject, unveiling a new plan for bailing out New York City that avoids raising taxes but counts on money from gambling, leasing a water pipeline and selling off city assets.

title: Israel Arrests Arab Citizens Said to Back Terrorist Acts
description: The Israeli police today detained 15 members of the country's largest Arab organization, the Islamic Movement, accusing them of secretly providing millions of dollars to support the bombing campaigns waged by militant groups like Hamas.

title: Colombia's Struggle
description: These are appreciation days for the coalition of the willing, as President Bush welcomes a parade of foreign leaders who supported his war in Iraq. Colombia's president, lvaro Uribe, who has supplanted Vicente Fox of Mexico as Mr. Bush's favorite Latin American leader, recently took his turn.

title: Wal-Mart Profit Rises 14%; Net Falls at Penney
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that first-quarter operating profit rose 14 percent, bolstered by cost-cutting and a falling dollar. Sales increased at the slowest pace in more than a decade.

title: CALENDAR
description: Sherry and Cheese

title: Lessons of Apartheid
description: To the Editor:

title: Pushing Brazilian Folklore Into Interesting Territory
description: When Brazil's military dictatorship ended in 1985, after 21 years, there was hope that a democratically elected government could respond to the country's economic and social problems. Instead, Brazilians got corruption and more corruption, to the point that a healthy society seemed nearly impossible. And there has been perhaps no better reaction to that quagmire than the dreadlocked, camouflage-wearing metal singer Max Cavalera howling in stubborn rage.

title: Former Chairman Of Qwest Agrees To Give Up Gains From Stock Deals
description: Philip F. Anschutz, the former chairman of Qwest Communications, agreed yesterday to give up $4.4 million in personal profits from shares in hot stock offerings that prosecutors say were allotted to him by an investment bank that hoped to win additional business from Qwest.

title: MCDONALD'S REPORTS FIRST U.S. SALES GAIN IN 14 MONTHS
description: The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest hamburger chain, said sales in the United States rose 1.3 percent in April, the first increase in 14 months, because of demand for new salads with Newman's Own dressings. Global sales at restaurants open at least 13 months dropped 0.8 percent, the 14th straight monthly decline, the company said. McDonald's, based in Oak Brook, Ill., introduced $4 grilled-chicken salads with dressings provided by the actor Paul Newman's business to try to attract more health-conscious consumers. James Cantalupo, the chief executive, said the salads are starting to help even though advertising for them started only three weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEINHAKER, SADIE
description: BEINHAKER-Sadie. Yeshiva University and its affiliate the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary family is saddened by the passing of the highly respected, beloved mother of Philip (and Connie) Beinhaker of Jerusalem (and Toronto, Ontario, Canada) who are YU Guardians and widely recognized leaders on behalf of our institution's efforts in Jerusalem and Canada. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Robert Eli Rubinstein, National President Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University (CFYU) Kurt Rothschild, President Ontario Region (CFYU)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Private Firehouse Effort Ends
description: The end came yesterday to Keep NYC's Firehouses Open, a nonprofit group formed by a former public relations executive on Wall Street to raise money to spare eight firehouses that are to close under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget plan. The two-month-old campaign ended because of the mayor's insistence that private money not be used to run city firehouses, Adam Brecht, the group's founder, said. The $1.5 million raised will be returned, he said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Pushing Brazilian Folklore Into Interesting Territory
description: When Brazil's military dictatorship ended in 1985, after 21 years, there was hope that a democratically elected government could respond to the country's economic and social problems. Instead, Brazilians got corruption and more corruption, to the point that a healthy society seemed nearly impossible. And there has been perhaps no better reaction to that quagmire than the dreadlocked, camouflage-wearing metal singer Max Cavalera howling in stubborn rage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPLIN, FRANK E. JR.
description: TAPLIN-Frank E. Jr. On May 11th, 2003 in Princeton, NJ. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 8 at 4 PM in the Princeton University Chapel, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made in support of environment, music, education or human rights.

title: Autism Diagnoses Double In California
description: Diagnoses of autism have nearly doubled in the last four years among children in California, state officials reported yesterday. They said they could not explain the increase.

title: NEW POLICY IN IRAQ TO AUTHORIZE G.I.'S TO SHOOT LOOTERS
description: United States military forces in Iraq will have the authority to shoot looters on sight under a tough new security setup that will include hiring more police officers and banning ranking members of the Baath Party from public service, American officials said today.

title: Heine on Book Burning
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Court Acts Against State Control Of Concerns
description: The European Union's highest court ordered the British and Spanish governments today to scrap ''golden share'' laws and similar mechanisms that let them continue to wield control over companies they once owned. The ruling is a significant step forward in the European Union's drive to create a single market for capital.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Neo-Nazi Crime Up
description: Right-wing extremist groups have become more violent, even as their overall numbers have declined, the country's domestic intelligence agency said in a report. The report, released by Interior Minister Otto Schily, said that while membership in right-wing organizations had declined by 10 percent at the end of 2002, to around 45,000, the number of acts of violence they motivated increased by 8 percent, to 772. The report also noted a rise in the number of foreign organizations based in Germany that are believed to present a security threat. Radical Islamic groups make up a large part of them, with about 30,000 members. Hugh Eakin (NYT)

title: Tests Help Rule Out Tile Damage as Cause of Shuttle Loss
description: New tests show that it would have been very difficult for falling debris to inflict major damage on the tiles on the underside of the shuttle Columbia during its launching in January, a member of the board investigating its fatal accident said today.

title: Workout Pleases Funny Cide's Team
description: Exonerated from any wrongdoing in the Kentucky Derby, the jockey Jose Santos watched the workouts from the apron at Belmont Park yesterday. Increasingly overwhelmed by news media attention, the trainer Barclay Tagg sat stoically on horseback and watched from the track. But it was Robin Smullen who had the best seat of all: on the back of the Kentucky Derby winner, Funny Cide, in his last workout before heading to Baltimore for the Preakness Stakes.

title: Another Ahold Executive Resigns in Wake of Scandal
description: Moving to put an $880 million accounting scandal behind it, the food retailer Royal Ahold said today that James L. Miller, the chief executive of U.S. Foodservice, the subsidiary where the problems were centered, had resigned.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sirius Radio To Be Offered In Some Ford Cars
description: Sirius Satellite Radio Inc., the No. 2 satellite radio broadcaster, said yesterday that the Ford Motor Company would offer Sirius's service in 10 of its 2004 model cars, helping Sirius get more customers. Starting in September, satellite radios will be offered as a dealer option on cars including the Ford Thunderbird, the Lincoln Navigator and the Mercury Mountaineer, Sirius said in a statement. It is the first time the Sirius service will be offered through Ford, although the two companies have had a partnership since 1999, a Ford spokeswoman, Emily Foley, said. Sirius's $12.95-a-month radio service offers 100 channels of programming via satellite. Sirius is counting on Ford to help it sign up the two million subscribers it needs to generate enough revenue to finance its operations and cover debt payments. XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc., the biggest provider of radio service via satellite, has said it has more than 500,000 subscribers. Sirius shares rose 17 cents, or 16 percent, to $1.23.

title: The Dutch Way
description: To the Editor:

title: More Conflicts on Wall Street
description: After spending much of the last year boasting of its efforts to restore investors' confidence -- surely you saw the ads featuring earnest investors demanding fairness -- the New York Stock Exchange suddenly finds itself on the defensive, having to answer serious questions about some of its own practices, which appear less than sensible in today's post-Enron environment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCANCARELLI, HON. AD RIENNE H.
description: SCANCARELLI - Hon. Ad rienne H. On May 13, 2003. Beloved wife of Eugene. Loving mother of Janine Scancarelli (Christopher McMahon), Lauren Seem (Gary) and Justine Diamond (John). Also survived by one brother Arthur Hofmann and four grandchildren Mary and Nancy Seem, Kate and Emma Diamond. Friends may call the Yannantuono Funeral Home, 584 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y. on Wednesday and Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM. Religious services on Friday at 10AM. Donations to the Salvation Army or the Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, New York 10707, would be appreciated.

title: An Idealized World And a Troubled Hero
description: ''I wish I knew what I was supposed to do,'' Neo (Keanu Reeves) says early in ''The Matrix Reloaded'' after a violent, apparently premonitory dream. Of course he does know what to do: he's ''the One,'' as murmured in the mellifluous, currant-scented voice of his mentor, Morpheus (the righteous Laurence Fishburne).

title: At Mass Grave in Iraq Marsh, An Open Secret Is Laid Bare
description: When the buses and vans started coming twice a day in April 1991 to disgorge their loads of victims, Hassan Maki tried to keep a rough count of the Shiites who were disappearing before his eyes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 6 about a legislative budget package under which the taxes of New York City residents would go up misstated the proposed increases in the state and city sales taxes. (One or both of those figures were also misstated in articles on May 3, 4 and 5.) They are one-fourth of 1 percentage point for the state one-eighth of 1 percentage point for the city -- not one-fourth of 1 percent and one-eighth of 1 percent.

title: The Agents of Change in Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Rises
description: Propelled by near-record oil and natural gas exports to the United States, Canada's trade surplus widened to 5.9 billion Canadian dollars ($4.2 billion) in March from 4.8 billion Canadian dollars in February, Statistics Canada reported. The surplus with the United States, which accounts for more than 75 percent of Canada's foreign trade, grew by 16 percent, more than offsetting a deficit with the rest of the world. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, BARBARA
description: ROTHSTEIN-Barbara. The Young Israel of Oceanside mourns the loss of our dear member and friend, and extends heartfelt condolences to her bereaved family. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi Alan Pelikow, President

title: A Whiff of Camelot as 'West Wing' Ends an Era
description: NBC can resist everything except temptation. Diane slept with Sam on ''Cheers,'' Niles married Daphne on ''Frasier,'' and even in the busy emergency room of ''E.R.'' no doctor ever went unloved for more than a season. This network, which has only one season left of ''Friends,'' plans to introduce a sitcom called ''Coupling'' in the fall. On that show six single friends have a lot of sex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBARD, FANNIE
description: GELBARD-Fannie, 90. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL. Died on May 7, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Harry for 59 years. Mother of Miriam, Arlene and Allen. Proud grandmother of seven grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. A true woman of valor who was loved by many.

title: An Indulgence, Vindicated
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS INC., Teterboro, N.J., the largest medical laboratory company in the United States, said it would buy back as much as $300 million worth of common shares; the shares have fallen by a third over the last year.

title: China Issues Strict Rules On Reporting Of Disease
description: Stung by the ruinous effects of an initial cover-up of the SARS epidemic, the Chinese government has issued stringent new rules requiring local officials to report disease outbreaks to Beijing immediately or face dismissal or even criminal charges.

title: U.S. Prosecutor Asks for Data On Reporter Who Resigned
description: The United States attorney's office in Manhattan has asked The New York Times for information about Jayson Blair, the former staff reporter who was found to have committed widespread fabrication and plagiarism in news articles, a spokeswoman for the newspaper said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 19 about a financial and academic crisis at Morris Brown College in Atlanta misstated events that preceded the resignation of Dolores Cross as president. In January 2002, the college failed to freeze $8 million for student loans and notify the federal government that it had received the money erroneously. A college employee did not download the money contrary to an Education Department order. Dr. Cross resigned the next month. Dr. Cross, who could not be reached for comment for the article, has since said that she resigned not because of the college's use of the $8 million but because of her fractured relationship with the trustees.

title: The Agents of Change in Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARISER, LORA
description: PARISER-Lora. The Young Israel of Oceanside mourns the loss of our dear member and friend, and extends heartfelt condolences to her bereaved family. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi Alan Pelikow, President

title: Osama's Offspring
description: We've had our regime change in the Middle East. Now Qaeda terrorists want theirs.

title: Helped by Fox, News Corp.'s Earnings Soar
description: The News Corporation, the media giant controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that it returned to a profit in its fiscal third quarter, propelled by the popularity of reality television hits like ''Joe Millionaire'' and ''American Idol'' as well as strong sales of DVD's from its Fox Entertainment Group subsidiary.

title: Disorder in Iraq: Who Is to Blame?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Debate to End All Debate
description: Frustration over the use of the filibuster is as old as the filibuster itself. Virtually every decade for at least the last 80 years, presidents or Senate leaders have called for reform of the filibuster rule. Now it is Bill Frist's turn -- but he should think twice before acting. Any rule changes could have unhappy consequences.

title: Frank E. Taplin Jr., 87, Lawyer And Fund-Raiser for Met Opera
description: Frank Elijah Taplin Jr., a lawyer, arts patron and amateur pianist who as president of the Metropolitan Opera raised a large endowment fund in the 1970's, died on Sunday in Princeton, N.J. He was 87.

title: Dr. Judianne Densen-Gerber Is Dead at 68; Founded Odyssey House Group Drug Program
description: Dr. Judianne Densen-Gerber, a lawyer and psychiatrist who founded the drug treatment program Odyssey House and went on to give widely quoted but sometimes disputed testimony on subjects like child abuse and pornography, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 68.

title: A Suit Seeks to Bar Oreos as a Health Risk
description: CRITICS of food industry practices have been unable to persuade most manufacturers to abandon unhealthful ingredients, or to let the public know what is in their products, so they are going to court. Whether they are successful or not, they have turned the spotlight on some probable risks for obesity, heart disease and other health problems.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: POLICE OFFICERS SUSPENDED Two police officers were suspended without pay yesterday for the unauthorized discharge of their guns, the police said. The officers, Linda Martin and Kathy Pappas, are assigned to the 78th Precinct. They also failed to stop pursuing a vehicle, despite an order, and reloaded their weapons before they could be inspected, the police said. No one was injured, Detective Robert Price said. The police did not elaborate on the chase and said the investigation was continuing. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Beating the Path to Organic, Through a Paperwork Jungle
description: SO you want to open an organic restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERGAMENT, IRENE
description: PERGAMENT - Irene. The trustees and staff of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System mourn the passing of our esteemed friend and benefactor, Irene Pergament, wife of the late Murray Pergament, and extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family, including Linda and Richard Horowitz, Bruce and Randi Pergament, son-in-law Caleb Koeppel, and grandchildren Jill, Kyle, Max, Sam, Scott, Cole and Wesley. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael Dowling President & CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Warrant Issued For Arrest In Stabbing
description: The police have issued a warrant for the arrest of a man they believe was involved in the fatal stabbing of a teenage girl Sunday morning. The man, Richard McCullough, 29, of Newark, faces murder, weapons and bias-intimidation charges, Detective Todd McClendon said last night. The victim, Sakia Gunn, 15, was with a group of young women at a bus stop at 3:30 a.m. Sunday when they were approached by two men. The men made advances, and one girl told them they were not interested because they were lesbians, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Mushroom Heaven
description: MY daughter's vegetarian and vegan friends seem to eat portobello mushrooms nonstop, pausing only to say, ''They taste exactly like meat.'' Though these young people may have forgotten what meat tastes like, they are right about the striking similarities in flavor. A slow-cooked portobello gains an amazingly dense texture, and it has the dark, earthy flavor that is associated more with animal products than with vegetables.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: OHIO: NURSE CHARGED WITH KILLING PATIENT An unlicensed nurse has been charged with killing a multiple sclerosis patient who could not swallow solid food by feeding her a piece of bagel and letting her choke to death. The authorities said the nurse, Wanda Kanner, killed the patient, Darlene Amberik, in 2001 so she could carry on an affair with Ms. Amberik's husband, John. The police say Mr. Amberik bought an engagement ring for Ms. Kanner four months before his wife died. Ms. Kanner, 49, was charged on Monday with murder and involuntary manslaughter. Mr. Amberik, 52, was charged with theft and records tampering. Investigators say he helped Ms. Kanner submit false bills to an insurance company. (AP)

title: After 14 Years, the Pros Are Back at Forest Hills
description: The Long Island Rail Road still rumbles high above the green grass of the West Side Tennis Club, and the women practicing yesterday still wore the obligatory white.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURO, CARMINE, M.D.
description: MAURO-Carmine, M.D. Our deepest condolences to Norma, Leslie, Matt, Eleanor and Tanner. We will miss Tomloving husband, father and grandfather, excellent and caring surgeon, good friend. Love Bob, Mary, Jim and Sharon

title: New Challenge to Saudis: Royal Family's Resolve Against Terrorism Questioned
description: The brazen attacks against three residential compounds for foreigners in the Saudi capital of Riyadh late Monday brought home at least one stark truth: the kingdom's ruling family seems unwilling to confront the threat posed by extremists in their country.

title: Cup Returns to U.S., But Only for a Hello
description: Josh Belsky, the 36-year-old Alinghi pitman, was just a teenager when the Australians defeated Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes for the America's Cup in 1983, ending the longest winning streak in sports. He remembers how it felt to watch his heroes lose and to see the television footage of the Auld Mug as it was unbolted from its perch in the trophy room of the New York Yacht Club on West 44th Street and handed over to the Australians.

title: Huge Strike by Public Workers Paralyzes France
description: May in France is the month of lilies of the valley, the first red cherries, the Cannes film festival -- and workers' strikes.

title: That Woody Aroma Is Black Bass
description: COOKING fish over cedar planks is one of those techniques that has a sort of rugged, coastal sexiness to it. But at Yujin, a slick, seaweed-toned Japanese restaurant in Greenwich Village, the method takes on a slightly more elegant cast.

title: Dollar's Neighbors Feeling Uneasy
description: Canadians tend to disparage their dollar, calling it the loonie (after the loon depicted on the one-dollar coin) or, when it was sinking to historic lows against the American dollar in 2001 and early 2002, the northern peso. Now many Canadian businesses find themselves wishing that the currency would live down to its reputation.

title: Loss at Cablevision Narrows As New Customers Sign Up
description: Cablevision Systems, the largest cable television company in the New York area, said yesterday that it had a smaller first-quarter loss after adding customers for services like digital cable.

title: Co-ops Win Right to Evict Tenants Without First Taking Court Action
description: It is a familiar New York complaint. You live in a co-op. Your neighbor is a nightmare. You want the co-op board to evict him. So does everyone else. But to do that, you are told, the board must take the neighbor to housing court and prove that he is worthy of eviction -- an excruciating process that could take months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, JULIAN M.
description: WIENER-Julian M. On Monday, May 12, 2003 of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Claire (nee Harrison), loving father of David Jay and Paul Ross Wiener, dear brother of Helen Levine, cherished grandfather of Jaime, Jessie, Eric, Matthew and Jesse. Graveside services on Thursday, May 15, 2003 at 11:00 AM in Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY. For information Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ 1-800-437-5151.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New York City Women Lag In Mammograms
description: Women in New York City are far less likely than their counterparts around the state and the country to have mammograms, and black women are less likely than whites to have the exams, according to a study released yesterday. The study, by IPRO, a health care policy group based in Lake Success, N.Y., looked at two years of Medicare billing for women 52 to 69 years old. Of that group, 47 percent of city women had mammograms during the two years, compared with 63 percent of the women in the rest of New York State and 60 percent nationally. Brooklyn had the lowest rates for any county in New York, at 43 percent over all and 37 percent for black women. Statewide, black women lagged behind whites, 47 percent to 61 percent. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Homey Sandwich Makes Good; Becomes the Darling of Chefs
description: Grilled cheese is the big news on New York's sandwich front. Say Cheese, a sliver of a cafe and take-out shop at 649 Ninth Avenue (45th Street), opened last week and goes well beyond a slice of American on white bread. Alex Adorno, the managing partner, splits a bread called pizza bianca from Sullivan Street Bakery, fills it with mozzarella, grilled mushrooms and garlic, then gives it a deliciously gooey finish on a sandwich press, above. He also uses bread from Amy's bakery, a block away, and ingredients like artichokes for his excellent sandwiches, which are $3.50 to $6.75. ''I'm using ingredients from the neighborhood as much as possible,'' said Mr. Adorno, who grew up nearby. ''I'm starting by selling sandwiches that I like, but I'm willing to adapt to my customers.''

title: Day of Notes And Confusion In '91 Retrial
description: The jurors in the Crown Heights racial violence retrial sent out two notes that they were at an impasse yesterday and a third note that the judge would not reveal during an emotional day that also included a defense motion for a mistrial.

title: Manhattan Judge Orders M.T.A. to Roll Back Fare Increase
description: AState Supreme Court judge in Manhattan ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to rescind the transit and commuter fare increases that were approved two months ago, ruling that the authority violated state law by misleading the public about its finances.

title: How High Can the Euro Go? Analysts Raise Targets
description: How far will the dollar fall and the euro rise? A lot further than many forecasters thought just a few months ago, or even a few weeks ago.

title: Deal Expected by Summer for ABB Oil Unit
description: ABB Ltd., the troubled Swiss builder of industrial and automation equipment, is expected to announce by the end of June the sale of its lucrative oil, gas and petrochemical business, valued at $1.5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARBASH, PHILIP
description: BARBASH-Philip. 5/15/095/14/93. Optimist, environmentalist, fine lawyer, loyal husband to Roslyn (52 years) and Vicky. Your family fondly remembers.

title: Contreras Not Ready to Return
description: Jos Contreras was not quite ready to join Derek Jeter on the Yankees' active roster last night. Contreras, a right-hander who has been starting for Class AAA Columbus, felt stiffness in his shoulder after a rain delay in his last start and will need at least one more minor league outing.

title: In Midtown, Something New Under the Sichuan Sun
description: I HAVE never met John Zhang, but I feel as if I know him. Mr. Zhang, an owner of four of the five Grand Sichuan restaurants in Manhattan, has made it his personal mission to bring to New York the best that the Chinese province of Sichuan can offer.

title: Bush Offers Comfort to Tornado Victims
description: President Bush finished off a two-day, three-state campaign for his half-trillion-dollar tax cuts this afternoon with a stop in a driving rain to see the damage in Pierce City, a town about 45 miles southwest of here that was devastated last week when a tornado tore through its center.

title: ABC and WB lean toward comedies in their fall lineups.
description: ABC announced a schedule for fall yesterday that will rely heavily on comedy to help make what the network hopes will be a ratings comeback.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the growing popularity of pork belly on restaurant menus misstated the location of the Niman Ranch, a producer. Its headquarters are in Oakland, Calif., and its hogs are raised in the Midwest. It is not in Colorado.

title: The School Wars Continue
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg's plan for combining administrative functions across the city's 32 school districts would trim down a sprawling bureaucracy and free up as much as $100 million for classroom instruction. But what is potentially the most far-reaching school reform in city history is having a tough time with labor unions, which naturally wish to preserve jobs, as well as with state legislators who persist in questioning the new plan. Many of the politicians' objections, like those of the unions, are simply self-serving. But the mayor could make this process much easier if he spent more time talking with his opponents.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: U.S. Seeks Proceeds Of Film
description: Federal prosecutors have filed court papers asking that the proceeds of a film promoted by a hip-hop label be confiscated because, they said, it was produced using drug money. In the papers, filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, prosecutors said that Kenneth McGriff, a Queens drug dealer, had delivered illegal proceeds to the record label, Murder Inc., in exchange for checks payable to a company formed to conduct business relevant to the straight-to-video movie ''Crime Partners.'' There was no immediate response to a message left with Mr. McGriff's lawyer last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Popping Corks: A Sound Bound For Oblivion?
description: FOR years the wine industry has talked vaguely about someday replacing the corks on bottles of fine wine with screwcaps. Now somebody is doing something about it. Recently, the Napa Wine Company in Oakville, Calif., converted one of its bottling lines to accommodate screwcap bottles. The Napa Valley Wine Company is not a manufacturer of jug wine. It is where boutique wineries like Pahlmeyer, Fife, La Sirena, Staglin Family and Bryant Family have their grapes transformed into wine.

title: Bridgeport to Auction Off a Troublesome Past
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 13  In the market for two classic Persian carpets and a huge S.U.V., emblems of a well-appointed Fairfield County life, not to mention the cocktail party chatter inspired by their provenance? Try the auction at City Hall on Thursday, where these three remnants of former Mayor Joseph P. Ganim's administration will be sold to the highest bidder.

title: Eerie, Flickering Images Of a Vulnerable Dracula
description: By turns voluptuous, whimsical and exceedingly strange, Guy Maddin's film ''Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary'' suggests that silent movies and ballet may have always been natural dancing partners. At least they seem that way when folded into each other by a quirky visionary like Mr. Maddin, the Canadian experimental filmmaker whose work has acquired a fervent cult following.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11, 16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, JACK
description: GROSS-Jack. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Jack Gross, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. Devoted to supporting Jewish and humanitarian causes, Jack was a guiding force in the formation of the Bankruptcy and Reorganization Group of the Lawyers Division, and served for many years as the group's chair. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Tougher Measures Appear to Be Paying Off
description: Captured terrorism suspects questioned by the F.B.I. in Europe and the Middle East have told their interrogators that increased security in New York made the city a more difficult place for terrorists to operate, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday.

title: Disorder in Iraq: Who Is to Blame?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Offers Plan To Rescue the City
description: A day before he had promised to veto the State Legislature's budget, Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a plan to bail out New York City that avoids raising taxes but counts on money from gambling, leasing a water tunnel and selling off city assets.

title: Compound Was a Lure for Terror, Experts Say
description: The battered compound that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell visited yesterday is like a little walled village on the eastern edge of the Saudi capital of Riyadh.

title: Wesleyan Bans Chalking, Citing Sidewalk Incivility
description: Students at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., were ordered to sheath their chalk this week when the university president permanently banned a colorful but controversial tradition on campus: chalking.

title: Al Qaeda Is Now Suspected in 1996 Bombing of Barracks
description: In June 1996, a truck bombing killed 19 Americans at the Khobar Towers barracks in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Iran was initially blamed for that attack, with American officials initially saying that at least some Iranian government officials were behind the bombing plot.

title: Brooklyn's Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Officers Suspended
description: Two police officers were suspended without pay yesterday for the unauthorized discharge of their guns, the police said. The officers, Linda Martin and Kathy Pappas, are assigned to the 78th Precinct. They also failed to stop pursuing a vehicle, despite an order, and reloaded their weapons before they could be inspected, the police said. No one was injured, Detective Robert Price said. The police did not elaborate on the chase and said the investigation was continuing. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sony To Sell Portable Game Player
description: Sony said it would begin selling a portable game player by the end of 2004. The device, called PSP, is aimed at extending Sony's lead in the market for video game players to hand-held devices. Sony's PlayStation 2 is the top game console, selling more than twice as many units as the Xbox from Microsoft and the GameCube from Nintendo combined. Detailed specifications of the device and its price were not disclosed.

title: Writer's Youths in Pain Have the Will to Survive; Adam Rapp Parlays the Angst Of His Childhood Into Plays and Novels
description: Look at the plays and novels of Adam Rapp, and you're likely to flinch. In ''Nocturne,'' produced at New York Theater Workshop in 2001, a young man accidentally kills his sister, comes to New York to be a writer and finally returns home, only to have his father die in his arms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, EDITH ALTSCHUL
description: GRAHAM - Edith Altschul. Passed away Friday May 2, 2003 in Stamford, CT. Wife of the late Robert C. Graham, Sr. Survived by her three children: Robert C. Graham, Jr. and Michael C. Graham of Stamford, CT and Kathryn G. Graham of NYC, NY; three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Services are being held privately.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer Acquired
description: The British brewer Scottish and Newcastle said it would pay 342 million euros ($395 million) to buy the 51 percent it does not already own in a Portuguese brewer, Sociedade Central de Cervejas, and the Luso mineral water business. Scottish and Newcastle, Britain's biggest brewer, makes Kronenbourg and Beck's beer and with the acquisition will add Sagres beer, which has a 34 percent market share in Portugal. Luso is the country's leading brand of bottled water. Scottish and Newcastle said it would also assume about 157 million euros ($182 million) of debt from the two businesses. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKWELL, JAMES MADISON IV
description: BLACKWELL-James Madison IV. Died May 12 after complications from surgery. A native New Yorker, he was the son of James Madison Blackwell III and Betsy Talbot Blackwell who for 35 years was the Editor-in-Chief of Mademoiselle Magazine. Mr. Blackwell graduated from Harvard in 1952 and then served in the Army during the Korean Conflict. In 1963 he joined the staff of Newsweek Magazine, becoming a Senior Editor in 1972. He remained in that position until 1985, after which he started his own company, Blackwell Consulting. He is survived by his wife Anne Stires Blackwell, three children: Stephen Hardwick Blackwell, Hillary Abrams, and Carolyn Talbot Blackwell, his sister Barbara B. Hird, as well as a grandson, Timothy George Blackwell. He was much loved and will be sorely missed by all of us as well as by all who knew him. Contributions may be made to Nantucket Cottage Hospital, 57 Prospect St., Nantucket, MA. 02554, or the National Alzheimer's Assoc.

title: Pro League Plans To Double Teams
description: Major League Lacrosse, which will begin its third season May 31, said it planned to add six teams to the six-team league by the 2005 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENSEN, GERBER, JU DIANNE, M.D., J.D.
description: DENSEN - GERBER - Ju dianne, M.D., J.D. The Board of Trustees, officers, staff and residents of Odyssey House mourn the passing of Dr. Densen-Gerber. As the founder of Odyssey House 35 years ago, Dr. Densen-Gerber pioneered therapeutic community treatment programs that helped save the lives of thousands of men and women addicted to drugs. We extend our deepest sympathies to her loved ones. George Rosenfeld, Chairman Peter Provet, Ph.D., President

title: Arrest of Ex-Patient Is Planned In Hartford Fire That Killed 16
description: The Hartford police have prepared an arrest warrant for a 23-year-old woman suspected of intentionally starting an early-morning fire that killed 16 people in a nursing home here in late February, a city official said today.

title: Commercial Fishing Is Cited in Decline of Oceans' Big Fish
description: In just 50 years, the global spread of industrial-scale commercial fishing has cut by 90 percent the oceans' population of predatory fishes, from majestic giants like blue marlin to staples like cod, a new study has found.

title: Bills on Tax Cut and Debt Are Set to Collide
description: Senate Republicans repaired the faulty bill number today that had delayed their tax-cut legislation, but immediately ran into more substantive criticism from Democrats challenging an increase in the nation's debt ceiling.

title: College Graduates Lower Sights In Today's Stagnant Job Market
description: In years past, most seniors at the University of North Carolina ignored the recruiters from Newell Rubbermaid, the maker of dishwashing gloves and Calphalon cookware, dismissing the company as another unfashionable manufacturer. This year, the handful of students Newell hired as management trainees became minor campus celebrities, simply because they had secured jobs months before graduation.

title: A.C.C. Nears Expansion, and Big East Nears a Breakup
description: The university presidents of the Atlantic Coast Conference moved closer to expanding the league to 12 teams from 9 today at the conference's annual spring meeting, the first splash in what could be a tidal wave of change in college athletics.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH RESCINDS EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, the maker of Claritin allergy pills, retracted its estimate for annual profit yesterday and said that its first-quarter earnings tumbled 71 percent as competition from generic drugs hurt sales. The new chief executive, Fred Hassan, who joined Schering-Plough last month after reviving profit at Pharmacia and overseeing its sale to Pfizer Inc., plans to cut jobs and reorganize to increase earnings. He said in a statement that he did not want to be ''constrained'' by Schering-Plough's previous forecast that it would earn 75 to 85 cents a share in 2003. Schering-Plough said its first-quarter net income fell to $173 million, or 12 cents a share, from $600 million, or 41 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales decreased 19 percent, to $2.07 billion from $2.56 billion. Shares of Schering-Plough, which is based in Kenilworth, N.J., rose 41 cents, to $18.71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOBMAN, MARTIN
description: BOBMAN-Martin. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its distinguished member, Mr. Matthew Bobman. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a European proposal to require testing of industrial chemicals before they are imported misstated the purpose of public meetings organized by the United States Commerce Department, which has criticized the proposal. They are part of a broad initiative to discuss a range of manufacturing issues; they were not called specifically to organize opposition to the proposal.

title: Getting a Grip on Survival Skills For Fending in an Unfair World
description: THE classroom discussion turned to the ways middle class people were different from them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, ELAINE
description: JACOBSON-Elaine. On May 12 in Tucson. Dearly beloved wife of Jim for 51 years, loving mother of Anne (Rick), Tom and Nancy, proud grandmother of Matthew, Emma and Julian and loving sister of Dr. George Pomerantz. Devoted and tireless volunteer for charitable causes. She will be greatly missed by all who had the good fortune to know her.

title: Striving to Punish Cuba, U.S. Expels 14 of Its Diplomats
description: The United States ordered the expulsion of 14 Cuban envoys today for ''inappropriate and unacceptable activities,'' a common diplomatic reference to spying.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about NASA's appointment of William W. Parsons as manager for the space shuttle program misidentified the official shown with him. The official was Michael C. Kostelnik, the agency's deputy administrator for the International Space Station and shuttle programs, not William F. Readdy, its associate administrator.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about public awareness of obesity among children referred imprecisely to the increase in diabetes among the young. The condition that is increasing because of obesity is Type 2 diabetes. The term ''child diabetes,'' used in the article, generally refers to Type 1.

title: The Mayor of Iraq
description: The American-led effort to restore stability in Iraq is off to a rocky start, in part because of the United States' reluctance to acknowledge its occupation for what it is. By equivocating on how fast it would relinquish the reins to a locally chosen government, the Bush administration sowed confusion for its own appointed officials, and for the Iraqi people.

title: Jury Delivers Mixed Verdict in Crown Heights Case
description: In a mixed verdict that delighted the defendant, the federal jury in the third Crown Heights racial violence trial convicted Lemrick Nelson Jr. yesterday of violating the civil rights of an Orthodox Jew by stabbing him during a night of racial unrest in Brooklyn 12 years ago, but found that Mr. Nelson did not cause the death of the victim, Yankel Rosenbaum.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article last Wednesday about the TriBeCa Film Festival misstated the running time of the version of ''Once Upon a Time in America,'' a 1984 film by Sergio Leone, that was shown on Sunday. It is 229 minutes, not 161.

title: A Steinway Brings Back Memories . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Once-Weakening Peso Rebounds, Creating Economic Commotion
description: Two months ago, Mexico's financial authorities were worried that the peso was weakening too fast and that too many dollars were piling up in the country's reserves. Now, economists and business people say the government's moves to address those issues have created the opposite problem: the peso has become too strong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANKAUER, THEODORE III (TIM)
description: YANKAUER - Theodore III (Tim), 71. Died on May 11, 2003 after a short battle with brain cancer. Devoted father of Jeff and Stephen. Loving brother of Ellen and adoring grandfather of Sarah. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Ofc. of Dev., 654 West 170th Street, NY, NY 10032.

title: Suspected SARS Outbreak in a Hospital Deals a Setback to Taiwan
description: This island may have suffered another hospital outbreak of SARS, the leader of the fight against the epidemic here said today.

title: Pressure Put On Official To Make Run For Senate
description: Only four months after he was sworn in as the top law enforcement official at the Department of Homeland Security, Asa Hutchinson is being pressured by Arkansas Republicans to run for the Senate next year and has talked to the White House political director about the possibility, Republican Party officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Loss Grows
description: Italy's largest industrial company and its No. 1 carmaker, Fiat, reported a larger first-quarter loss and said the rest of 2003 would be ''difficult and challenging.'' The company lost 681 million euros ($787 million) in the first three months of the year compared with a loss of 529 million euros in the same quarter of 2002. Revenue fell 15 percent, to 12.3 billion euros ($14.2 billion). Fiat's car unit posted a drop in sales and an operating loss of 334 million euros. The company predicted that its 2003 operating loss will be less than what it lost last year. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Lower Supply Raises Oil Prices
description: Crude oil prices rose to their highest level in four weeks yesterday after the International Energy Agency said inventories had tumbled 10 percent from last year. Bombings in Saudi Arabia, the world's top producer, also contributed to the rally.

title: Agencies Fill Top Positions
description: Several agencies are filling top posts.

title: France Says It Is Ready to Send Troops to Quell Congo Fighting
description: As tens of thousands of troops from rival Congolese militias skirmished in the northeastern province of Ituri and the death toll from the weeklong spasm of violence rose past 160, the French government indicated today it was preparing to respond to a call by the secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, to send troops to quell the disturbances before they escalated further.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BREWER ACQUIRED The British brewer Scottish and Newcastle said it would pay 342 million euros ($395 million) to buy the 51 percent it does not already own in a Portuguese brewer, Sociedade Central de Cervejas, and the Luso mineral water business. Scottish and Newcastle, Britain's biggest brewer, makes Kronenbourg and Beck's beer and with the acquisition will add Sagres beer, which has a 34 percent market share in Portugal. Luso is the country's leading brand of bottled water. Scottish and Newcastle said it would also assume about 157 million euros ($182 million) of debt from the two businesses. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: F.D.A. Delays Regulation Of Tissue Transplants
description: The Food and Drug Administration has delayed regulation of the booming commerce in human tissue transplants for more than six years, even though the agency acknowledges that the use of infected tissues poses a serious threat to public health, Congressional investigators said today.

title: Paving the Past, Keeping an Ear to the Ground
description: A small bulldozer in recent days has been spreading fine sand over the rocky beach belonging to the Mvenpick Hotel, one of the gleaming new buildings that have sprung up here since the Lebanese civil war ended about 13 years ago. The beach will soon be ready to receive its wealthy guests from the Persian Gulf region and elsewhere; the rocks will remain lodged underneath.

title: GEMSTAR, TV GUIDE'S PUBLISHER, NAMES NEW FINANCE CHIEF
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc., the publisher of TV Guide magazine, named Brian Urban chief financial officer as the company tries to clean up its accounting after restating earnings three times this year. Mr. Urban, 41, will replace Paul Haggerty on July 1, the company said. Mr. Urban had been chief financial officer of the Unilab Corporation for the last six years. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Gemstar's accounting. The chief executive, Jeff Shell, began an accounting review last year.

title: First, You Have To Catch The Fish
description: IT is shad season, and for New Yorkers, a time of gastronomic paradox.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Sprint's Holders Rumbling Over Conflicts by Auditor
description: An effort by shareholders to prod the Sprint Corporation into dropping its longtime auditor, Ernst & Young, appeared to fall short yesterday. But Sprint's new chairman and chief executive, Gary D. Forsee, noting the size of the opposition vote, said he had received a very strong message and would review the matter.

title: Murder, He Drew (Sex, Too); A Master of Pulp Art Survives to Enjoy a Tribute
description: Growing up on the Lower East Side in the early 20th century, Ernest Chiriacka was simply possessed by the need to draw, using whatever was available -- a leftover lump of charcoal, a spent match or a piece of chalk at school.

title: Confident Nets Savor Sweep Of Celtics
description: The Nets were dancing again in the visitors' locker room of the Fleet Center, dancing in the now hallowed site where they have celebrated the franchise's most significant postseason accomplishments in the N.B.A. -- all two of them -- in back-to-back years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 24 about the arrest of Justice Gerald P. Garson of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on corruption charges misidentified the court where his wife, Robin Garson, is a judge. It is Brooklyn Civil Court, not the State Supreme Court.

title: Zany New Music, But Quirkily Compelling
description: Music at the Anthology, started in 1997 by the composers Eleanor Sandresky and Lisa Bielawa, with Philip Glass as its patron saint, has transformed itself from a loose series of concerts to a concentrated festival that bears an uncanny resemblance to Bang on a Can in its salad days. Like Bang on a Can then, MATA - which now goes by its initials, since it is no longer based at the Anthology Film Archives - thrives on composers playing their own works, and on visiting ensembles. The revamped MATA festival is a welcome development for anyone who missed the freewheeling spirit that Bang on a Can brought to New York's new music world in the late 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEYLON, ANNE M. (NEE DONOVAN)
description: NEYLON-Anne M. (nee Donovan). On May 10, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Walter J., loving sister of Jeremiah F. and the late John, Charles, Julia Kelly and Daniel J. Also survived by many nieces and nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews, and many fond cousins. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 9:30 AM at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Bush's Support Strong Despite Tax Cut Doubts
description: Americans have persistent reservations about the tax cuts that are the centerpiece of President Bush's postwar agenda, but those concerns have not hurt Mr. Bush, who continues to ride a huge wave of support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Trade Deficit Widened in March to Near Record
description: The trade deficit widened in March to the second-largest on record as imports of oil jumped, a government report said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGA KHAN, PRINCE SADRUDDIN

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: CARMAKER'S PROFIT SLIPS Hyundai Motor reported a net profit of 417.6 billion won ($354.3 million) in the first quarter of this year, 29 percent below the 586.6 billion won posted in the first quarter of 2002. The company blamed a 4.8 percent decline in domestic sales as well as a decline in the value of its shares in its affiliate, Kia Motors, in which it holds a 36 percent stake. Nonetheless, Hyundai reported total first-quarter sales of 6.09 trillion won ($5.17 billion), up 7 percent, and a first-quarter operating profit of 612.9 billion won, up 6 percent. Kia reported a first-quarter net profit of 141.6 billion won, up 43.2 percent, as sales rose 18.3 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: 2nd Suicide Blast in Week Claims New Victims in Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, May 14  A suicide bombing in Chechnya  the second there this week  killed at least 14 people and wounded dozens more today during a religious festival in an attack that appeared to target the republic's pro-Kremlin leaders, officials in Chechnya said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LOUIS, PH.D.
description: STONE-Louis, Ph.D. Age 77, husband of Lillian Helen Jason Stone, of 590 Field Street, Naugatuck, died Tuesday May 13, 2003. Dr. Stone was born March 24, 1926 in New York City, son of the late Thomas and Esther Frenchman Stone. He graduated from NYU with a BCHE, MS (metallurgy), ENG, Sc, D. He formerly worked at New York University, Anaconda American Brass Co in Waterbury, CT, and retired as a Senior Research Metallurgist from Olin Metals in New Haven, CT. Beside his wife, he leaves a son, Louis A.G. Stone, of Naugatuck, CT, and daughter, Andrea Dawn-Michel, of Clinton, CT, a brother, Thomas Edward Stone, of Staten Island, NY, two grandsons, and a granddaughter. Funeral services and burial will be at the convenience of the family. Calling hours will be Thursday, May 15, 2003 from 6-8 P.M. at Buckmiller Brothers Funeral Home, 82 Fairview Avenue, Naugatuck, CT. Memorial contributions to The American Cancer Society, PO Box 1004, Meriden, CT 06450-1004.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: FORMER S.L.A. MEMBER IS SENTENCED The last member of the Symbionese Liberation Army to be apprehended, James Kilgore, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the 1975 shooting death of a woman depositing church funds in a bank that he and several others were robbing. After Mr. Kilgore expressed remorse, Judge Thomas Cecil of Sacramento Superior Court told him that he would face no more than six years in prison when he is sentenced on Aug. 15. Four other former S.L.A. members were sentenced to six to eight years earlier this year in the robbery. ( Reuters )

title: Lakers Ignore the Spurs' Lead, Until It's Too Late
description: With just over a minute left in the first half tonight, Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal chatted as they walked onto the court after a timeout. As the conversation ended, Bryant gripped O'Neal on the back of his head, and the two shared a laugh.

description: TIERNEY-Marie C. (nee Prunty). May 12, 2003. Devoted wife of the late William J., dear cousin of Helen, Martin, Joanne Moore, and Msr. Joseph Devlin. Reposing at John J. title: ALCOA PLANS TO LAY OFF 4,250 WORKERS IN MEXICO
description: Alcoa said that its auto parts division, Alcoa Fujikura Ltd. Automotive, would lay off 4,250 employees at its Mexican operations in the northern cities of Ciudad Acuna and Torreon. The Mexican plants produce electrical distribution systems and other products for the North American vehicle markets. Alcoa said the layoffs were needed to remain competitive in the slowing market. Alcoa employs about 30,000 people in Mexico, most of them in its northern factories. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

description: Joe Dumars had everyone fooled. As the Detroit Pistons were taking on the Philadelphia 76ers in Game 2 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series last Thursday, Dumars appeared to be unruffled, the picture of cool in his midlevel suite.

title: Clinton Wins 18th P.S.A.L. Team Title
description: De Witt Clinton, led by Carldon Murray and Jeremy Alvarez, captured the team title for the 18th time yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Bronx Borough Boys Championships.

title: 17 Europeans Held Captive in Algiers Freed in Army Raid
description: BERLIN, May 14  Seventeen European tourists held captive in the Sahara in Algeria were released unharmed today after Algerian armed forces raided a camp said to be controlled by an extremist Islamic group.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about New York restaurant openings misstated the ownership of Jarnac and Cafe Topsy in Greenwich Village. Tony Powe is their sole owner; Maryann Terillo is their executive chef.

description: He never attended journalism school himself, and he has taught only one journalism course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LEARY, MICHAEL JOHN
description: O'LEARY-Michael John, of Ft. Pierce, Florida died peacefully on May 12 after a short illness at age 84. Mr. O'Leary was a Public Relations executive with AT&T for more than 30 years until his retirement in 1983. He was educated at Fordham Preparatory School and received degrees from Fordham University (B.A.) and Columbia University (M.A.) in New York. He served proudly in World War II and was a talented writer, artist & actor with a keen intellect and a lively wit. He will always be remembered for his kindness, genuine decency and wonderful, irreverent sense of humor. He is survived by his wife Mary Harnett O'Leary, his sons John and Vincent, his daughter Jean, numerous stepchildren and grandchildren, his daughters-in-law and son-in-law. His first wife, Jean Donohoe O'Leary, and his eldest son, Michael J. O'Leary Jr., M.D., predeceased him. Visiting hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY from 2-4 PM & 7-9PM on Thursday, May 15. Mass of Christian Burial at Annunciation Church in Crestwood, NY at 10 AM on Friday, May 16. Friends may send memorial donations in his name to Fordham Preparatory School, East Fordham Road, Bronx, New York 10458.

title: Iran's Chief, in Lebanon, Urges Quick U.S. Exit From Iraq, but Favors Vote
description: In a speech both defiant and conciliatory, President Mohammad Khatami of Iran called on the United States today to leave Iraq quickly but pledged that his country would support a new, inclusive government there based on one Iraqi one vote.

title: GAP NAMES MANAGERS FOR OLD NAVY AND OUTLET STORES
description: Gap Inc. promoted Tom Sands to manager of its Old Navy stores and placed Brian Lynch in charge of store operations at its factory outlets. Mr. Sands, 42, was named executive vice president of Old Navy Stores, and will continue to report to Old Navy's division head, Jenny Ming, the company said. Mr. Lynch, 45, was named senior vice president and will oversee factory stores for the Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy chains. Gap's chief executive, Paul Pressler, has been assembling his own management team since he took the helm in September.

title: Putin Likens Truck Bomb In Chechnya To Saudi Raid
description: As the death toll from a truck bombing in Chechnya on Monday rose steadily higher, President Vladimir V. Putin drew a direct parallel today between that attack and those that occurred in Saudi Arabia only hours later.

title: After a Long Struggle, Cancer Drug Wins Approval
description: Julian Adams never gave up on the cancer drug he helped to invent, even as it passed from company to company. He defied the skeptics who said it would never work. He persuaded nonprofit foundations and the government to pay for clinical trials when the companies he worked for could not.

title: An Emerging of Talents
description: Say what you want to about the works, or quibble if you must about the selections for the New York City Opera's annual showcase of works by American composers. But there is no question that the company is doing something important by presenting excerpts of either works in progress or completed works that have yet to be professionally staged. No other company does anything comparable to ``Vox 2003,'' as this year's showcase, on May 7 and 8 at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew on 86th Street and West End Avenue in Manhattan, was called. As in past years, the free peformances were well attended and representatives of opera companies, management agencies and publishers were in the audience.

title: U.S. Repeats North Korea Stance Before Visit From South's Leader
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 - As President Bush prepared to meet the President of South Korea, the White House reiterated its tough stance against North Korea today. It refused to rule out military force against the North but said again that it hopes for a diplomatic solution to problems with that country.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Concrete Profit Falls
description: First-quarter net profit for Holcim Ltd., one of the world's largest concrete and cement makers, fell 87 percent, to 10 million Swiss francs ($7.6 million). The company said its results were held down by a high tax rate of 59 percent and by the write-down of 19 million francs from its investment in the struggling Swiss International Air Lines. The company said sales fell to 2.47 billion francs from 2.85 billion, hurt by bad weather in the United States, low demand in Europe, and the effect of a strong Swiss franc versus the dollar. Operating profit, which excludes various one-time items, was down 7.4 percent from the year-earlier quarter. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Nassau Audit Finds Flaws In Assessments Of Businesses
description: Last fall, as soon as Nassau County received the results of its first complete property tax reassessment in more than 60 years, homeowners started to complain.

title: As Funds Disappear, So Do Orchestras
description: After the Florida Philharmonic Orchestra finished playing Wagner and Tchaikovsky to an audience of 1,300 in Boca Raton on Friday, the orchestra's executive director, Trey Devey, took to the stage to announce that this might be its last concert.

title: Food for the Emotions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Carnivore Finds Joy, Meatlessly
description: THERE is a Graham Greene play, ''The Potting Shed,'' that tells the angst-ridden story of the impact on an atheistic family when one of their number has a religious vision, followed by a stunned conversion, in the shed of the title. The fear and tension of a family whose scornful disbelief is so suddenly shot to pieces resounds particularly with me, for I have a concomitant fear. My almost unutterable nightmare is this: One day I could wake up and find myself a vegetarian.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 6 about a legislative budget package under which the taxes of New York City residents would go up misstated the proposed increases in the state and city sales taxes. They are one-fourth of 1 percentage point for the state one-eighth of 1 percentage point for the city -- not one-fourth of 1 percent and one-eighth of 1 percent.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Directors Told To Return Profits
description: The new directors of Ullico, the troubled union-owned insurer, voted to require directors who made more than $6 million trading company stock to return those profits within 30 days. Seventeen directors bought Ullico shares and then resold them to the company in 2000 at a far higher price set by the board in a deal that is the subject of four insider trading investigations. Three directors have already agreed to return their profits, and the board's resolution said Ullico would take steps to remove directors who did not repay the money and would seek to recoup money from them. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANNARD FESSENDEN MARION S.
description: BANNARD FESSENDEN Marion S. Formerly of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., died peacefully on May 6, 2003 in Greenport, N.Y. at the age of 80. She was married for 45 years to the late William N. Bannard, and is survived by her husband of nine years, Edward E. Fessenden. Loving mother of Marie B. Lockwood of Dover, MA., David N. Bannard of Richmond, VA., and Barbara B. Haller of South Salem, N.Y. Devoted grandmother of 11 grandchildren: Thomas and Charles Cartier, Preston, Thomas and William Bannard, Jason, Whitney, Ashley, Macky and Madison Haller and the late William B. Cartier. She also leaves three stepchildren: Edward Fessenden, Jr., Joan Hunt and Suzanne Fessenden, three step-grandchildren and four step-great grandchildren. Mimi was a longtime member of St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor. She volunteered her services tirelessly to many organizations including the Multiple Sclerosis Chapter of Long Island, The Garden Club of America, and the Red Cross Blood Services of N.Y. She was an avid gardener, accomplished bridge player and enthusiastic traveller, who most especially cherished her time spent at her second home, ''Cloud High'', Smith Parish, Bermuda. She will be deeply missed by her adoring family and a wealth of friends. A Memorial Service will be held on May 20, 2003 at 11AM at St. John's Church, Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. Contributions may be made in her memory to St. John's Church, P O Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. 11724 or Eastern LI Hospital, 201 Manor Place, Greenport, N.Y 11944.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Rapist Won't Seek New Trial
description: Alex Kelly, convicted in 1997 of raping a teenage girl, has withdrawn his petition for a new trial, his lawyer said yesterday. The lawyer, Norman A. Pattis, said Mr. Kelly had sought a new trial because the jury had been unfairly influenced by news reports. Mr. Kelly, now 36, fled to Europe after being accused of sexually assaulting teenage girls in 1986. He was sentenced to 16 years in prison, but may be freed by 2008. Mr. Pattis did not explain the withdrawal. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: BEAR STEARNS AND TRIMARAN AGREE TO BUY PACKAGED ICE
description: Bear Stearns & Company's private equity unit and Trimaran Capital Partners agreed to buy Packaged Ice Inc., the largest ice maker in the nation, for about $450 million. Packaged Ice, which is based in Dallas, sells products under the Reddy Ice brand to more than 73,000 locations. Bear Stearns Merchant Banking and Trimaran Capital, a closely held asset-management firm based in New York, will be equal partners. Bear Stearns and Trimaran will pay about $3.62 a share if the transaction closes on or before Sept. 15, and $3.50 a share if it closes after that date, Packaged Ice said.The price is at least 56 percent more than the closing price of $2.24 Monday on the American Stock Exchange. The stock rose $1.12, or 50 percent, to $3.36 yesterday.

description: ''These are people who are determined to try to penetrate facilities like this for the purpose of killing people in their sleep, killing innocent people, killing people who would try to help others.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Carmaker's Profit Slips
description: Hyundai Motor reported a net profit of 417.6 billion won ($354.3 million) in the first quarter of this year, 29 percent below the 586.6 billion won posted in the first quarter of 2002. The company blamed a 4.8 percent decline in domestic sales as well as a decline in the value of its shares in its affiliate, Kia Motors, in which it holds a 36 percent stake. Nonetheless, Hyundai reported total first-quarter sales of 6.09 trillion won ($5.17 billion), up 7 percent, and a first-quarter operating profit of 612.9 billion won, up 6 percent. Kia reported a first-quarter net profit of 141.6 billion won, up 43.2 percent, as sales rose 18.3 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 6 about a legislative budget package under which the taxes of New York City residents would go up misstated the proposed increases in the state and city sales taxes. (One or both of those figures were also misstated in articles on May 3, 4 and 5.) They are one-fourth of 1 percentage point for the state one-eighth of 1 percentage point for the city -- not one-fourth of 1 percent and one-eighth of 1 percent.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: NTT Reports A Profit
description: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the Japanese telephone company, earned 200 billion yen ($1.7 billion) in the half-year ended March 31, helped by a strong turnaround at its mobile phone subsidiary, NTT DoCoMo. The profit was in line with earlier company estimates and slightly better than analysts' forecasts. The profit reversed a year-earlier loss of 603 billion yen. For the year that began April 1, NTT said it expected profit to rise 94 percent, to 453 billion yen ($3.9 billion), though sales are unlikely to change. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: From Quaver to Screech: Wild but Cagey Enough
description: Karen O's fishnet stockings didn't survive the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' set at Irving Plaza last Wednesday night. As she sang, she mangled her hosiery with high kicks, deep bends, hops, twirls and a little crowd-surfing. Her voice was just as hyperactive, bouncing from quaver to yowl to cackle to screech. She was a wild thing, and she was also, like the band she leads, just cagey enough.

title: For the Most Unusual Bulbs, A Backup Plan to the Rescue
description: Company is about to arrive, and the light bulb in the front hall burns out, the one that is impossible to buy at the corner store. But with some advance planning, it is possible to be ready for lighting emergencies without having to go to a specialty shop. A Web site, Topbulb, offers more than 5,000 bulbs for indoor and outdoor lamps; most are shipped the day you order. And if you have new bulbs lying around that you cannot use, they will buy them, cash, or give you a credit toward the bulbs you need. Prices are discounted, and there is a closeout area on the site. Shipping for any order is $6.95. Topbulb is at www.topbulb.com or (800) 867-2852. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: For a Little More Bulk, the Sailor Gets a Better Idea of His Location
description: Like the sextant, the clock has long been a critical navigation tool for mariners. The latest model from the Finnish watchmaker Suunto is much more than a mere timepiece, however. The M9, designed for sailors, can store digital versions of nautical charts, as many as 5,000 navigation points and even wind-direction data. And, at the cost of being a bit bulkier than an ordinary wristwatch, the M9 includes a Global Positioning System receiver.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Attorney General Sues Over Map
description: The state attorney general, Ken Salazar, left, has gone to the State Supreme Court to block a new redistricting map that the Republican-controlled Legislature passed in the final hours of its session and that Gov. Bill Owens signed into law last week. The map replaced one imposed by a judge for the 2002 election. Mr. Salazar, a Democrat, argues that the new redistricting plan is unconstitutional because there can be only one such plan after each census. Mr. Salazar has also refused to represent the governor or secretary of state, both Republicans, in a separate suit by Democratic lawmakers seeking to block the plan. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPLIN, FRANK E. JR.
description: TAPLIN-Frank E. Jr. The trustees and staff of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation mourn the death of our longtime trustee and benefactor Frank Taplin. A member of the Board from 1972 to 1993, Vice Chair for the last six of those years and since then Trustee Emeritus, Frank continued his active engagement and deep personal commitment to the work of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation to the last days of his life. Among his many important contributions, he played a key enabling role in establishing Teachers as Scholars, a program that now offers intellectual revitalization for K12 teachers at 26 universities nationwide. In establishing the new Frank E. Taplin Jr. Public Intellectual Award (an initiative that Frank enthusiastically supported), the Foundation celebrates Frank's lifelong dedication to the liberal and performing arts and to their relevance in the world of affairs. Frank was a wonderful inspiration and great friend to us all, and he will be greatly missed. We extend heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathy to his wife, Peg, and to their family. Nancy Weiss Malkiel, Chair Robert Weisbuch, President The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation Princeton, New Jersey
