title: Homegrown Fanatics
description: On Monday night, Riyadh didn't sleep. Phone lines were jammed and streets were crowded. The news was devastating: three suicide bombings at housing complexes for Westerners here in the Saudi capital had killed more than 20 people and wounded nearly 200, some of them Saudi. Only days earlier, Saudi officials had described Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda as ''weak and nonexistent.'' But on Monday night, Saudis were asking, ''Is Osama behind these attacks?''

title: GOVERNOR VETOES INCREASE IN TAXES

title: National Briefing: South
description: VIRGINIA: BOY SCOUTS DROP ROBERT E. LEE The name of Gen. Robert E. Lee is being removed from the uniforms of Boy Scouts in central Virginia, a change applauded by some black Virginians but criticized by a Civil War heritage group. The Confederate general's name has been used to identify the Richmond-area Boy Scouts of America since 1942. The executive board of the Robert E. Lee Council voted last week to drop the name from its title and logo, starting sometime next year. Local Scout executives plan to have a new name in place by June 2004. (AP)

title: Insights for Washington (With a Hey Nonino)
description: This city provides a perpetually apt backdrop for Shakespeare, whose scrutiny of power always penetrates to the corruptible bones. In other words, it doesn't take a volatile world moment to recognize that his Elizabethan insights are at home in our capital. All it takes is a play, and there are currently two prominent examples that together make the crucial point about Shakespeare's contemporary relevance, which is that it is self-evident.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Names Chief Financial Officer
description: Cisco Systems said yesterday that Dennis Powell had been chosen to succeed Larry Carter as chief financial officer. Mr. Carter is credited by shareholders with helping Cisco, the world's biggest maker of equipment to direct Internet traffic, amass more than $20 billion in cash and investments with no debt. He had said he would retire this month, after more than eight years in the position. Mr. Powell was Mr. Carter's deputy. Mr. Powell, 55, will report to the chief executive, John Chambers, who is trimming costs, cutting prices and focusing on new products as he seeks to counter declines in sales at the company. As vice president for corporate finance and corporate controller, Mr. Powell had been in charge of Cisco's financial planning and analysis. Cisco shares dropped 5 cents yesterday, to $16.42; they have risen 25 percent so far this year. Mr. Powell joined the company in 1997.

title: The Favelas of Brazil Make a Throne of the People
description: The Favela chair (above) from the Italian company Edra gets its name from the shantytowns in Brazil. Irregular pieces of wood are hand-glued and nailed into this pauper's throne (at $2,630). The faces of the chair, the work of the brothers Humberto and Fernando Campana, who work in So Paulo, are smooth, planar and deceptively comfortable. The chair, along with the brothers' Swarovski chandelier, will be shown at Moss in SoHo starting on Tuesday (in conjunction with the United States debut of the book ''Campanas,'' about their work). Moss is at 146 Greene Street (Houston Street); (212) 204-7100.

title: ROYAL AHOLD SAYS TWO MORE EXECUTIVES RESIGN
description: Royal Ahold, the Dutch grocer that misstated its earnings because of accounting irregularities at its U.S. Foodservice division, said yesterday that two more of its executives had resigned. The executives, Michael Resnick, the chief financial officer, and David Abramson, executive vice president and general counsel, both stepped down yesterday, officials at Ahold said. Mr. Resnick came to U.S. Foodservice in October 2000 and became chief financial officer in 2001. Mr. Abramson had been with the company since July 1996. On Tuesday, James L. Miller, the president and chief executive of U.S. Foodservice, resigned, a week after the company said it had found that its accounting problems were worse than it had thought. Mr. Miller was not implicated in any wrongdoing, the company said. Ahold has said it misstated its earnings by $880 million over three years.

description: A shooting in a nail salon here on Tuesday night in which three people were killed was characterized by the police today as a murder-suicide.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trader's Profit Rises

This year, Mitsubishi expects profits to grow 61 percent, to 100 billion yen. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: The House of Representatives passed a bill today that would allow financial services companies to sell investment advice to workers in 401(k) retirement programs while also giving the workers the ability to sell company stock in those accounts sooner than they can now.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: U.S. Case Against Abortion Opponent
description: The federal case against James C. Kopp, left, a militant abortion opponent sentenced in state court last week for murdering a Buffalo-area doctor who performed abortions, moved a step closer to trial yesterday. Kathleen Mehltretter, an assistant United States attorney, said prosecutors were ready to go to trial. Mr. Kopp faces a possible life sentence if convicted of violating a federal law that bars the use of deadly force to deny patients access to abortions. Mr. Kopp was convicted of state murder charges and sentenced to 25 years to life in prison for killing the doctor, Barnett A. Slepian, in 1998.

title: TOM BROWN TO BUY MATADOR PETROLEUM FOR $373 MILLION
description: Tom Brown Inc., a natural gas producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Matador Petroleum Corporation for $373 million to add reserves outside the Rocky Mountain region. Tom Brown, which is based in Denver, will pay $268 million in cash and assume $105 million in debt from Matador, which has the equivalent of 269 billion cubic feet of natural gas reserves in Texas and New Mexico. Acquiring Matador will increase Tom Brown's reserves by 37 percent. The Unocal Coporation holds a 15 percent stake in Tom Brown.

title: A Job Half-Done in Afghanistan
description: Iraqis worried about the future of their country cannot be encouraged by what they see in Afghanistan, America's first effort at nation-building in the Islamic world. Nearly 18 months after American-backed forces ousted the Taliban from power, Afghanistan languishes in a strange limbo between war and peace. Though Washington's efforts have brought a measure of freedom and democracy, many of America's promises about rebuilding Afghanistan have yet to be realized.

As the ball bounced off every part of the rim and the clock ticked toward zero, Derrick Coleman did what his instincts told him to do. After waiting impatiently and hoping against hope that the shot would bounce out, he leapt, his hand rising through the bottom of the rim, and poked the ball out.

title: STARBUCKS IN JOINT VENTURE TO EXPAND INTO CHILE
description: The Starbucks Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to a joint venture with Grain Red to open coffee shops in Chile. Financial terms were not disclosed. The joint venture, Sur-Andino Cafe, plans to open the first Starbucks store in Santiago during the second half of this year, Starbucks said. It will be the company's first foray into South America. In September, Starbucks expanded into Mexico and Puerto Rico. Grain Red, majority owned by Castano, is a Chilean company that focuses on food and beverage retail development.

title: Maverick Senator Relishes Role as 'M.T.A. Killer'
description: EXCEPT for a struggling bamboo plant, a derelict microwave oven and a paper napkin designed like a Dominican flag, most everything in Senator Eric T. Schneiderman's bargain basement, out-of-district office on West 60th Street is packed in boxes. The office is, like its momentarily missing owner, in transit, transit being something of a leitmotif for Mr. Schneiderman, whose history of productive legal challenges to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority justifies what he calls, with relish, his ''M.T.A.-killer niche'' courtroom status.

title: 'Under the Radar' Museum Plans New Home on the Bowery
description: As the proposed grand architectural projects of the 1990's fade from the horizon -- the Whitney, the Guggenheim and Lincoln Center have all backed off ambitious plans by world-famous architects over the past few months -- one modest museum is trying not to appear smug as it chugs determinedly forward.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Police Chief Sues County
description: The Montgomery County police chief, Charles A. Moose, filed a federal lawsuit seeking to bar the county ethics commission from penalizing him for writing about last fall's Washington-area sniper investigation. The suit argues that the commission violated his right to free speech when it ruled that Chief Moose could not work on a book or screenplay about the shootings, and warned him that he could face up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine for violating a county code that forbids a public employee to use the ''prestige of his office for private gain.'' Gary Gately (NYT)

title: A Columnist's Postscripts
description: One of the glories of an e-mail column like this is that it's free, it's instantaneous, and it goes only to people who have explicitly asked for it. Still, it's not quite as good as a Web page, which can be updated or corrected constantly, leaving little trace of its earlier editions. Here, for example, are a few postscripts to some recent columns that I would amend if I could:

title: Trunks of Treasure In Linen, Cotton or Silk
description: John Robshaw travels to India and Southeast Asia for designs for his bedding and textiles. ''I studied the trade routes to learn about traditional techniques and find out where they are still alive,'' he said. Silks come from Cambodia and Thailand, batiks from Indonesia and India (he operates a workshop in Jaipur). Authenticity is important for Mr. Robshaw, 37, who studied painting.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.S. Officials Ground an Entrepreneur in Iraq
description: As the Bush administration rushes to jump-start the reconstruction of postwar Iraq, it may want to consider the recent woes of Pete Henderson.

title: Poised for Pimlico
description: Ten horses, four of whom ran in the Kentucky Derby, are set to compete in the 128th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. Joe Drape listed the horses in order of preference; Frank Carulli, the oddsmaker at Pimlico Race Course, provided the morning-line odds.

title: Radio With a Long Memory Lets You Redefine Drive Time
description: You can listen to AM and FM broadcasts on the Radio YourWay from PoGo Products. But there is no need to linger near the radio to catch ''Fresh Air'' or a Howard Stern monologue; just press its Record button and come back to the program whenever you like.

title: F.C.C. Studies Market Power Of Radio Giant
description: The Federal Communications Commission is trying to devise rules aimed at breaking the hold Clear Channel Communications has on radio markets in some rural areas, a commissioner, Kathleen Abernathy, said today.

title: In Italian Dust, Signs Of a Past Jewish Life
description: Amid rolling pastureland about 180 miles southeast of Rome, dust is flying. Workers carefully dig through crumbling sandstone deep beneath the surface of a grassy hillside. Stout wooden beams support a makeshift entrance and a labyrinth of newly exposed passageways that lead into an ancient underground maze. A loopy string of construction lamps illuminate the way.

title: U.S. Recovers $950 Million In Assets Stolen From Iraq
description: American Treasury officials announced today that they had recovered $950 million in Iraqi assets that they believe constitutes the bulk of the $1 billion looted by Saddam Hussein's family hours before war began in mid-March.

title: Big East Official To Fight The A.C.C.
description: On a day when officials from the Atlantic Coast Conference left here with an agreement to expand to 12 members from 9, the Big East Conference commissioner, Mike Tranghese, questioned the tactics of the A.C.C. commissioner, John Swofford, and vowed to hold his conference together despite attempts to alter it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fraud and Forgery Charges Are Brought in Spam Case

title: Israeli Troops Kill 5 Palestinians and Wound More Than 30
description: Israeli troops shot five Palestinians to death, wounded more than 30 and arrested 15 suspected militants today during army raids throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, the two sides said.

title: The Guantnamo Scandal
description: For a year and a half, the United States has held hundreds of people captured during the war in Afghanistan as prisoners in Guantnamo Bay without access to family, lawyers or any semblance of due process. Another small group was shipped home recently, and there are reports that military trials for some prisoners may start soon. But that does not alter the fact that the detentions insult some of our most cherished ideals and harm our national interest.

title: Burmese Rape Horrors
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a shooting attack at Case Western Reserve University referred incorrectly to the suspect, Biswanath Halder. He is not a former university employee.

title: AMBASSADOR SAYS SAUDIS DIDN'T HEED SECURITY REQUEST
description: The United States Ambassador to Saudi Arabia charged today that some weeks before the car bombs of Monday night, American intelligence operatives picked up signs of an imminent terrorist attack and urged the Saudi government to improve security at foreign compounds here, but got little or no response.

title: With Plan for State Aid, Senate Republicans Gain Crucial Democratic Vote on Tax Cut
description: A bipartisan group of senators reached agreement with Republican leaders today on a financial aid package for the states, adding a crucial Democratic vote to President Bush's plan for eliminating taxes on dividends.

title: Sadruddin Aga Khan, 70, U.N. Relief Official
description: Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, a philanthropist and environmentalist who served as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and was the uncle of Prince Karim Aga Khan IV, current leader of the 20 million Shiite Ismaili Muslims , died on May 12 in Boston, Mass. He was 70.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ROBERT I.
description: GREENBERG-Robert I., on May 13, 2003. Beloved husband of Jimi York. Loving father of Nancy Cahey and Jonn Greenberg. Proud grandfather of Griffin. Devoted brother of Adrienne (George) Orlan, Aline (Seth) Lawrence

title: New York Cultural Groups Outline Budget-Cut Toll
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art would close some galleries. The Bronx Zoo would close for the winter and charge school groups for the first time in its 104-year history. The American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, would shut it doors two days a week.

title: Speed-Dial Grandeur
description: As the creative muse of Soho House, a new members-only hotel and club in New York's meatpacking district, Ilse Crawford has imported an updated rendition of British bohemianism. Its prime ingredients are unstudied elegance with a fillip of lip-pursing naughtiness and the promise of putting within reach perks that nobody really has time for.

title: The Meaning of Terror in Riyadh
description: To the Editor:

title: 2nd Bombing This Week in Chechnya Kills 15 at Festival
description: A suicide bombing in Chechnya, the second there this week, killed at least 15 people and wounded dozens more today during a religious festival. The attack appeared to be an attempt to assassinate the republic's pro-Russian leader, officials in Chechnya said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Names Executive
description: The bank BNP Paribas selected Baudouin Prot, joint managing director, to replace Michel Pebereau as chief executive. Mr. Prot, 51, will take the position within three months, Mr. Pebereau told shareholders at the annual meeting in Paris. Mr. Pebereau, 61, will remain chairman.

title: A Consummate Role Player, Pandolfo Takes a Star Turn
description: In 70 career playoff games, Jay Pandolfo had scored two goals.

title: The Meaning of Terror in Riyadh
description: To the Editor:

title: Antismoking Group Hires 3 Agencies
description: The American Legacy Foundation in Washington, which sponsors the ''Truth'' smoking-prevention campaigns aimed at teenagers, said yesterday that it had completed a required review for the creative part of its account by rehiring the incumbent team and adding a third agency to work on persuading young smokers to quit. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $60 million.

title: Mind the Gap
description: The Senate debate over President Bush's tax plan has focused so far on the plan's short-term effects, like whether a reduction in the dividend tax will help the stock market. While economic stimulus is important, Congress and the president should also take up an issue with far more consequence for America's long-term growth and stability: economic inequality.

title: A New Tool for Translating Ancient, Flowing Script
description: SANSKRIT, in which classical Indian literature was composed, is among the world's oldest recorded languages. But putting works created over the last 3,000 years onto the Web has not been easy.

title: Shuttle Investigator Chides NASA on Safety
description: The leader of the commission investigating the breakup of the space shuttle Columbia told a Senate committee today that the NASA engineers in charge of safety are so few and so poorly supported that they cannot do their jobs properly.

title: Cabalistic Gleanings That Deliver a Jolt
description: 'Yiddishbbuk'

title: Tokyo Urges Set of Moves To Shore Up Stock Market
description: Hoping to shore up Japan's floundering stock market, economic and financial regulators approved a series of proposals today to stem the heavy selling of stocks by pension funds and to expand the use of public money to buy shares.

title: MEADWESTVACO TO TAKE CHARGES AND CLOSE 3 PLANTS
description: The MeadWestvaco Corporation, the maker of coated paper used in magazines, said yesterday that it would take a $13 million charge this quarter for management changes that included replacing its finance chief. The company disclosed the expense in a regulatory filing and was not specific about what costs it had incurred. MeadWestvaco will also record an expense of $2 million to close three plants. By the end of June the company will shut plants in Virginia, Tennessee and Delaware. The company has cut 4,000 jobs since it was formed in the January 2002 merger of the Mead and Westvaco corporations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, MARGARET
description: MOORE-Margaret. Died in Christ May 10, 2003. Funeral and Reception, St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St., Thursday, May 15, at 4 P.M. Beloved wife of Thomas R. Moore, Esq., noted NY lawyer, mother of Willard, Clarissa, and Charles Moore, grandmother of Sarah Moore, daughter of Margaret and Willard L. King, Esq., famed Lincoln scholar. Mayflower. Huguenot. Great beauty and brilliance. Phi Beta Kappa. Valedictorian, Connecticut College for Women. Reporter, Time Magazine. Bylined Columnist, Boston Herald Traveler. Director of Development, The Spence School. Director of Special Events, New York Hospital. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Margaret Moore Scholarship Fund (Eleanor T. Elliott, Founder), NY Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, Suite W115, New York City.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the novelist and short-story writer Leonard Michaels on Tuesday misstated his graduate-school record and omitted a survivor. Mr. Michaels indeed received a doctorate in English, from the University of Michigan in 1967. He is survived by his mother, Anna Michaels of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MANUEL
description: GORDON-Manuel, of Continental Village, Town of Cortlandt, NY. Beloved husband of the late Edith, devoted father of Bonnie Robins and the late Robert Gordon. Loving brother of Julius Gordon, cherished grandfather of David, Jesse and William Robins. Services 10:00AM Friday, Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Road, Croton - on - Hudson. Contributions to Temple Adath Or, 10400 Griffin Road, Suite 302, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33328. For additional information, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a shooting attack at Case Western Reserve University referred incorrectly to the suspect, Biswanath Halder. He is not a former university employee.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: AIRLINE POSTS LOSS Buffeted by the outbreak of SARS in Asia and a generally weak global economy, Lufthansa of Germany reported a first-quarter loss of 356 million euros ($409 million), nearly double its loss in the quarter last year. The airline gave little hope for a quick rebound, saying it expected to report an operating loss for the full year. Lufthansa's passenger traffic plummeted 2.8 percent over all, and nearly 20 percent in Asia, forcing it to scale back routes and ground planes. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: 400,000 Embryos and Counting
description: Without anyone paying much attention, some 400,000 frozen embryos have accumulated in freezers at the nation's fertility clinics. This astonishing total -- twice as high as any previous estimate -- reflects the growing use of in vitro fertilization by couples unable to conceive without reproductive assistance. Given the likelihood that the number of embryos in storage will continue to grow, bioethicists ought to focus soon on how best to handle this ever-expanding stockpile.

title: Late Miss By Horry Bodes Ill For Lakers
description: There have been several omens for the Los Angeles Lakers this season: an 11-19 start, the failure to gain home-court advantage for a playoff round, the season-ending injury to Rick Fox. But perhaps the most powerful one was the way in which Tuesday's Game 5 loss to the San Antonio Spurs ended.

title: Clubby, With a Twist
description: TWO men in a steam room talking business. A beefy Scandinavian masseuse briskly at work. Cigar smoke blending with the steam. It is a familiar scene from old movies depicting the good life, a life that, naturally, includes such afternoons at the club.

title: Documents on the Move Find Three New Ways to Travel
description: Because of its ability to translate a document's original fonts, colors and images into a file that can be opened and read on most computer systems, the Portable Document Format, created by Adobe Systems, has become a staple of modern business. This month Adobe will release new versions of its Adobe Acrobat program that can create PDF files out of just about anything. Adobe Acrobat 6.0 will come in three versions, each designed for users with specific needs and ways of using files.

title: Noel Redding, 57, Rock Bassist Who Played With Jimi Hendrix
description: Noel Redding, who played bass behind Jimi Hendrix as one of the two Englishmen in the Jimi Hendrix Experience, was found dead on Monday at his home in Clonakilty, Ireland. He was 57.

title: L. W. Pogue, 103; Helped Write Rules For Civil Air Travel
description: L. Welch Pogue, a Washington lawyer who helped write the original rules for commercial air travel at the Civil Aeronautics Board, which he headed in the 1940's, died on Saturday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 103.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a brief review of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' at the New Victory Theater in Times Square misidentified two actors who were embracing and omitted the identification of a third. The couple were Lindsay Rae Taylor and Andrew Schwartz. (Renata Friedman and Ryan Conarro are other members of the cast.) Kenn Sabberton was seated at the left on the stage.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: 63 KILLED IN MINE EXPLOSION At least 63 people were killed and 23 are missing after a gas explosion in a coal mine in eastern China, the state television reported. A mine official said there was little hope that those missing would be found alive after the Tuesday explosion, the latest major accident in China's mining industry, the world's largest and deadliest. The State Administration of Work Safety said on its Web site that more than 100 workers were in the Luling coal mine in the city of Huaibei, 420 miles south of Beijing, and that 28 had been rescued. About 7,000 people were killed in Chinese mine accidents last year.    ( Reuters )

title: Africans Suffer, As We Look Away
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance
description: THEATER

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 5 about the growing Latino influence in Hartford misidentified Mayor Eddie A. Perez's place of birth. It is Corozal, P.R., not New York City.

title: Fighting Women Enter the Arena, No Holds Barred
description: IN a futuristic penthouse with floor-to-ceiling windows and holographic artworks, two fierce combatants stare each other down. Muscles ripple and hands clench with menace before the first blow -- whack! -- is thrown.

title: Bush and New President Of South Korea Are Vague On North Korea Strategy
description: President Bush and South Korea's new president, Roh Moo Hyun, emerged tonight from their first meeting declaring that the two countries ''will not tolerate nuclear weapons in North Korea.'' But in a series of vague diplomatic statements they stepped around serious differences about whether to isolate the country with an economic embargo or threaten it with a military strike.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Cuts Flights
description: Air Canada, based in Montreal, is grounding 11 percent of its fleet and suspending service on a dozen routes in response to a steep decline in traffic caused by intensifying competition and the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome. The airline, which is in the process of restructuring under court protection, reported a first-quarter operating loss of 354 million Canadian dollars ($257 million), up from 160 million a year earlier. The operating loss in April was 152 million Canadian dollars, with traffic between Canada and the United States down 18 percent from a year earlier. Traffic on Asian routes has fallen by about 60 percent. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Loss Narrows at British Cable TV Provider
description: NTL Inc., the biggest cable television company in Britain, said yesterday that its loss in the first quarter narrowed as interest costs fell by almost half after a reorganization that ended with its emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January.

title: France Offers More Talks in Bid to End Union Walkouts
description: PARIS, May 15  Trying to end the worst labor unrest in almost a decade, France's government offered more talks today to seek to gain the support of labor unions whose views on pension reform, the reason for the strikes, are most like its own.

title: Mixed Verdict On Crown Hts.; Defense Happy
description: In a mixed verdict that delighted the defendant, the federal jury in the third Crown Heights racial violence trial convicted Lemrick Nelson Jr. yesterday of violating the civil rights of an Orthodox Jew by stabbing him during a night of racial unrest in Brooklyn 12 years ago, but found that Mr. Nelson did not cause the death of the victim, Yankel Rosenbaum.

title: Rothkos Rise to the Top of Art Sale
description: Classic contemporary art, especially from the late 1950's, reassured a nervous art market at Christie's last night. Choice examples by artists like Mark Rothko, Yves Klein and Andy Warhol tore at the purse strings of collectors, who parted with millions of dollars more than they had probably bargained for.

title: Niagara Hopes Casino Visitors Won't Mutter, 'What Falls?'
description: They had a traffic jam here one day last winter. The city was delighted.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: MICROSOFT CUTS PRICE OF XBOX CONSOLE Microsoft reduced the price of the Xbox video game console to $179.99 in the United States yesterday, matching the price cut announced a day earlier by Sony for its dominant PlayStation 2. A Microsoft spokeswoman said the 10 percent price reduction from $199 would take place immediately. Some retailers were already showing the new price on their Web sites. Sony said on Tuesday that it cut the PlayStation price from $199 to clear out inventory ahead of the introduction in June of a redesigned version, which includes an adapter for networking. That package is expected to sell for $199. Both price cuts took industry watchers by surprise, coming as they did at the start of the Electronic Entertainment Expo, the video game industry's annual trade show. Satoru Iwata, the president of Nintendo , which makes GameCube, played down the possibility of a price cut for its $149 console, which currently comes with a free game. "I really don't think there is an urgent necessity to cut the price," Mr. Iwata said. Retailers have been clamoring for cuts in the prices of consoles, according to game industry executives, as the move usually brings a sharp rise in sales. Most, however, were expecting that Microsoft and Sony would take $50 off the price, rather than $20.    ( Reuters )

title: CALENDAR
description: The Greening of New York

title: Sotheby's Loss Widens to $27.6 Million
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the world's largest publicly traded auctioneer, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss widened because of job cuts and payments made to retain executives and art experts.

title: Tom DeLay Stars in Texas Donnybrook
description: Those close to Tom DeLay say he always harbored a secret ambition to be speaker of the House -- of the Texas House, that is.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Monday about possible expansion of the Atlantic Coast Conference in college athletics, as well as past changes in it, misstated the year that South Carolina withdrew. It was in 1971, not within a few months of the conference's inception in 1953.

title: A Scanner Skips the ID Card and Zeroes In on the Iris
description: EVERY year, millions of travelers pass through Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport. For most of them, waiting at the passport-inspection counter is part of the routine. But about 7,000 frequent travelers have a way to speed up the process. In exchange for an annual subscription fee and background check, they are able to confirm their identities to the Dutch immigration service by letting one of seven infrared cameras scan their irises.

title: Thousands Are Quarantined at Taiwan's Top Hospital
description: Taiwan's leading hospital, overwhelmed by an internal outbreak of SARS, was effectively shut down tonight, dealing a serious blow to the crown jewel in this island's medical system.

title: Fear of Baghdad Unrest Prompts A Halt in Sending Troops Home
description: The Third Infantry Division has been told to stop sending troops home and to step up patrols, a move that reflects mounting concerns within the Bush administration about security in Baghdad, military officials said today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline prices rose because of refinery shutdowns and a smaller-than-expected increase in supplies. In New York, gasoline for June delivery rose 2.92 cents, or 3.5 percent, to 87.37 cents a gallon.

title: A Soldier's Death in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: KODAK AND HEWLETT-PACKARD END PRINTING VENTURE
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that they were dissolving Phogenix, the joint venture they formed three years ago to develop inkjet-based minilabs that any retailer could use to make prints from digital cameras. Kodak will continue to pursue labs that are not inkjet based for specialty photo retailers, but Hewlett is abandoning retail photo printing for now. ''There's a limit to our investment dollars, and we decided that our best opportunities in digital imaging rested with home printers and digital cameras,'' said Jennifer Boggs, a Hewlett spokeswoman. Anthony Sanzio, a Kodak spokesman, said the Phogenix minilabs, which were to sell for $40,000 and up, would need to make 500 to 1000 prints an hour to be economically viable; the machines never got beyond 250 prints an hour.

title: Politics and Sacred Ground, 1853; Birth of Central Park Holds Parallels With Ground Zero
description: What vast Manhattan architectural and public works project, the likes of which New York City had never seen before, was begun in a time of economic crisis and changed the city forever?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think we have good control, but we may need to police up some meat-heads.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Threat To Poison Hospital Food
description: The country's top law enforcement official said the government was prepared to negotiate with a blackmailer who threatened to poison food in state hospitals unless he was paid $10 million. ''We are ready to do everything so that he does not carry out these threats,'' the interior minister, Stanislav Gross, told Czech Radio. To prove he is serious, the blackmailer has led the police to two vials of cyanide hidden in a Prague maternity hospital. In March, an extortionist blew up part of a railroad bridge in the northern city of Ostrava and threatened further attacks unless a police helicopter dropped packages containing $350,000 at 25 locations. The money was dropped, but the blackmailer failed to pick up any of the packages. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Truckers Persist In Strike
description: Truck drivers serving the port of Pusan vowed to remain on strike until they won significant pay increases. About 1,500 drivers rallied at Pusan National University, breaking through a police barricade, according to Yonhap, the Korean news agency, while the defense ministry sent more army trucks to haul cargo. The strike has paralyzed the port of Pusan, the shipping site of 80 percent of the country's exports that move in cargo containers, and has spread to smaller ports. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Intuit's Earnings More Than Double in Quarter
description: Intuit Inc., the world's biggest maker of tax-preparation software, said yesterday that its profit more than doubled in its most recent quarter because of gains on the sale of its Japanese unit and a 29 percent increase in sales.

title: New Protections for Nannies Are Approved by Council
description: The City Council unanimously approved a bill yesterday that increases protections for nannies and housekeepers by seeking to make sure that families who hire them know these workers' rights on overtime and other matters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVA, HUMBERT L., MD.
description: RIVA-Humbert L., MD. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the recent death of their Life Fellow, Humbert L. Riva, MD

title: BANK OF NEW YORK REPORTS FEDERAL FRAUD INQUIRY
description: Bank of New York, the third-largest New York-based bank, and several of its employees are the subject of a federal inquiry into leasing fraud, the bank said yesterday in a regulatory filing. ''The bank is cooperating fully in that investigation,'' a spokesman, Robert Grieves, said. Last June, the F.B.I. arrested four officials of RW Professional Leasing, a former customer of the bank, on charges they defrauded banks by obtaining loans to lease medical equipment without passing the money to doctors. Bank of New York is also a defendant in two lawsuits related to the case seeking $46 million.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Official Leaving Justice Department
description: Viet Dinh, a senior Justice Department official who was a key architect of the counterterrorism legislation that grew out of the Sept. 11 attacks, will return to the faculty at the Georgetown University Law Center after his leave of absence ends on May 31, officials said. The legislation, known as the Patriot Act, significantly expanded the power of federal agents to use surveillance, wiretaps and other tools to investigate suspected terrorists. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Man Charged With Fraud in Spam Case
description: A man was arrested outside his home in Buffalo on Tuesday and charged in state court with forgery and fraud in connection with millions of unsolicited e-mail messages, commonly known as spam, Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Current Account Surplus Falls
description: Japan's current account surplus contracted 27 percent because of weakening exports. The surplus fell to 1.6 trillion yen ($13.7 billion) in March, the first decline in four months. The trade surplus, the largest component of the current account, fell 7.1 percent. A smaller portion of the trade balance, the service sector, usually runs at a deficit because large numbers of Japanese travel and spend money abroad. But the number of Japanese taking trips overseas declined and the service deficit fell 21.3 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: 2 Cents on 2 Quarters: Skeptics Aren't Counting Fare Savings Yet
description: In the good old days, the Yankees were off to a strong start, the cold weather was leaving for good and a subway ride could be had for $1.50. New Yorkers do not expect those days to return.

title: Cavendish Pairs Winners, and an Example of Talent
description: The Cavendish Pairs, perhaps the strongest event of its kind ever staged, was won on Sunday in Las Vegas by Brad Moss of Manhattan, a member of a famous bridge-playing family, and Fred Gitelman, a Canadian international player.

title: Owner of Miller Beer to Buy Most of Big Italian Brewer
description: SABMiller, one of the world's largest brewers, said today that it was buying a majority stake in Peroni of Italy for as much as $280 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Clinton: New College President
description: Hamilton College has named Joan Hinde Stewart, a professor of French and dean of the College of Liberal Arts at the University of South Carolina, as its president, effective July 1. She will be the first woman to be president of the 191-year-old liberal arts college, which has about 1,750 students. She succeeds Eugene M. Tobin, who will become a senior adviser at the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. A Brooklyn native, Dr. Stewart, 58, graduated from St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn and earned her Ph.D. at Yale. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: It's Not a Total Lie: She Can't See a Thing

title: Korea Distiller Is Ordered Into Bankruptcy
description: A South Korean court ordered Jinro, the country's largest distiller, into bankruptcy yesterday and removed its management.

title: Administrator Of Schools Predicts Profit By Late June
description: Edison Schools, the nation's largest for-profit manager of public schools, reported yesterday that its losses continued to shrink in the first three months of this year and that it expects to report the first quarterly profit in its history by the end of June.

title: France Claims U.S. Is Engaging in Disinformation Campaign
description: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

title: Powell and Putin Say Iraq Rift Is Mended, and Then Disagree
description: After weeks of pointed Russian protests over the war in Iraq, President Vladimir V. Putin and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell declared today that Russia and the United States had overcome their recent differences. They then met in the Kremlin and failed to resolve some of the most contentious of those, involving the future of Iraq.

title: Worries on Retailers and Chip Industry Lead Shares Down
description: Stocks declined yesterday as a disappointing forecast from Applied Materials, the world's biggest supplier of equipment for making semiconductors, hurt shares of chip-related companies.

title: A Tilt to the Right, a Nod to the National G.O.P.
description: Six months after he won re-election as a liberal Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki today cemented his reputation as a fiscal conservative, vetoing tax and spending increases the Legislature had passed.

title: Jury Finds What Many Already Knew
description: Even before yesterday's anticlimactic end, the latest Crown Heights trial was a muted drama. Maybe that was because, for many New Yorkers, it has been a long time since there was any real question about whether Lemrick Nelson Jr. stabbed Yankel Rosenbaum that August night in 1991.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Higher Rating For Telephone Concern
description: Standard & Poor's raised the short- and long-term credit ratings of France Tlcom after it announced a plan to reduce its 68 billion euro ($78 billion) debt. The long-term rating of France Tlcom and its sister company Orange, a cellular service provider, were raised one level, to BBB, after the company went ahead with a government-backed 15 billion euro rights offer and a new strategy to increase cash flow.

title: S.E.C. Investigates Transkaryotic Over Drug Approval
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Transkaryotic Therapies misled investors about the regulatory status of a drug it was developing, the company said today.

title: At Ground Zero, a Conduit of People and Memory
description: AT the sight of those escalators, travelers may weep.

title: Diplomacy in Design, Life in One Room
description: TWO years ago, Ilse Crawford and her new husband, Oscar Pena, were making a pilgrimage to the organic market near the Tate Modern here and saw a ''For Sale'' sign on a warehouse. It took $480,000 to buy 1,400 square feet on its third floor, and $320,000 more for renovations by a Belgian minimalist architect, Vincent van Duysen, to make it home.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bids For Power Unit
description: Alstom, whose power stations generate a fifth of the world's electricity, has received four bids for its power-transmission unit as it sells assets after a record loss. The company, which is based in France, lost 1.38 billion euros ($1.58 billion) for the fiscal year ended March 31, is trying to raise 3 billion euros selling assets to repay debt. It intends to sell the transmission unit this year. ''We have received preliminary offers and have selected four potential buyers to proceed to the next phase,'' the chairman, Patrick Kron, told analysts. ''These four bidders are financial buyers. We have also got expressions of interest from industrial groups.''

title: Commercial Fleets Reduced Big Fish by 90%, Study Says
description: In just 50 years, the global spread of industrial-scale commercial fishing has cut by 90 percent the oceans' population of large predatory fishes, from majestic giants like blue marlin to staples like cod, a new study has found.

title: College Board Corrects Itself On Test Score
description: For the first time in almost 20 years, the College Board has rescored the PSAT to give the 1.8 million students who took the test on Oct. 15 credit for a different answer on an ambiguous grammar question.

title: Synagogue With an Expansive Nature
description: The Bet Shalom Synagogue (below) in Minnetonka, Minn., was designed by the firm of Bentz Thompson Rietow of Minneapolis. It incorporates six 4-ton panels, which form the walls of a hexagonal sanctuary. The panels glide into the ceiling and floor to double the size of the sanctuary during the High Holy Days, or reduce it to an intimate size for smaller services.

title: Putin Proposes Amnesty for Chechen Rebels Who Disarm
description: MOSCOW, May 15  President Vladimir V. Putin today proposed granting amnesty to Chechen separatists who agreed to lay down their arms by Aug. 1, but the offer would exclude any accused of murder, rape, kidnapping or other crimes.

title: Parole Denied a Second Time For Former Radical in Killings
description: A former member of the Weather Underground, Kathy Boudin, who has served 22 years in prison for her role in a 1981 armed robbery in which a security guard and two police officers were killed, was denied parole today in a special hearing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MARVIN, M.D.
description: STERN-Marvin, M.D. The faculty, staff and students of NYU School of Medicine express their deep regret and sadness on the death of our friend and colleague, Marvin Stern, M.D. Dr. Stern passed away suddenly on May 13th at NYU Medical Center on his way to see patients. Dr. Stern was an outstanding clinician, gifted teacher, and devoted member of the NYU community. He graduated from NYU School of Medicine in 1939 and began his career here as an Assistant in Psychiatry in 1947. He was appointed Assistant Professor of Psychiatry in 1948 and was appointed Professor of Psychiatry in 1962. In 1979, Dr. Stern was appointed the Menas S. Gregory Professor of Psychiatry. He retired from the faculty in 1995 and was appointed Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry. In recognition of his many years of service to our institution and his patients, the School of Medicine established the Marvin Stern Lecture and the Marvin Stern Professorship. Dr. Stern is survived by his wife, Libby, a graduate of the Bellevue School of Nursing, and their three children, all of whom are graduates of the NYU School of Medicine. Our deepest sympathies go to the entire Stern family. Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean, NYU School of Medicine Robert Cancro, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Psychiatry, NYU School of Medicine

title: State Dept., Not the F.B.I., Expelled Cuban Diplomats
description: White House and State Department officials not law enforcement officials -- were behind the expulsion of 14 Cuban diplomats from the United States for ''inappropriate activities,'' including spying, F.B.I. officials said today.

title: Menem, Polls Slipping, Quits Argentine Race
description: Facing the prospect of a humiliating defeat in a runoff vote scheduled for Sunday to choose Argentina's next president, Carlos Sal Menem, who governed the country from 1989 to 1999 and was seeking a third term, withdrew from the race today.

title: U.S. Guidelines Reassess Blood Pressure
description: Millions of people who in the past would have been told that their blood pressure was normal or ''high normal'' should now be told that they actually have a condition called prehypertension that threatens their health, according to guidelines issued yesterday by government health experts.

title: Bell Took Long Road To the N.B.A.
description: Dallas Mavericks guard Raja Bell has a litany of travel horror stories from his two seasons in the Continental Basketball Association. His best comes from the back seat of a teammate's car.

title: Naples Journal; Oh, What a Mess! It's a Volcano of Reeking Trash
description: Less refined than Milan and less revered than Rome, Naples has long struggled against the image of unkempt, unlucky stepsister to Italy's other major cities, with too much dirt under her nails and too little discipline in her ways.

title: Harmony Tries to Overcome the Biases
description: Much has changed in Crown Heights since that seething August night 12 years ago that left a black child and a young Hasidic man dead, and a neighborhood infamous.

description: Arturo Moreno, a Mexican-American, moved one step closer yesterday to becoming the first member of a minority group to be a majority owner of a Major League Baseball team.

description: Someone holding a guitar for the first time could be forgiven for wondering, ''Now what?''

description: John Davis sauntered casually through the crowded set of ''Garfield'' one recent afternoon, stepping over cables and around false walls, looking much more like a member of the movie's production crew than like the unassuming son of a billionaire and this film's unlikely producer.

description: Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, dampened any notion today that relations between Iran and the United States might be warming.

title: Taiwan SARS Cases Jump, but Officials Think Tally Is Low
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 15  Even as Taiwan was reporting its biggest one-day jump in probable SARS cases, health officials said today that the outbreak here is being inaccurately counted and is probably much bigger than reported.

description: Stocks of Big Fish Fall 90%

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES REPORTS NARROWER NET LOSS Computer Associates International Inc. posted a narrower quarterly net loss yesterday as sales benefited from its shift to a new way of booking revenue. The company, which makes software for mainframe and network computer systems, reported a net loss of $106 million, or 18 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 2003 compared with a net loss of $238 million, or 41 cents, for that period the year before. Revenue for the company, which is the subject of two federal investigations into its accounting practices, rose to $801 million from $772 million a year ago. Computer Associates had forecast revenue of $780 million to $800 million. Shares rose 60 cents, to $18.19.

title: Interpublic Agrees to Sell Research Unit
description: After months of negotiations, the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its NFO WorldGroup research division to Taylor Nelson Sofres in London.

title: Saying Public Was Misled, Judge Rescinds Transit Fare Increases
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to rescind the transit and commuter fare increases that were approved two months ago, ruling that the authority violated state law by misleading the public about its finances.

description: The Subway Restaurants chain of sandwich shops is beginning a review for the creative and strategic-planning duties on its account, which have been handled by Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners in New York since March 2000. Though billings were not disclosed, Subway spent $218.6 million in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: 2 Yemeni Fugitives Indicted in Qaeda Attack on U.S.S. Cole
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  Two Yemeni fugitives who federal officials say have vowed to kill Americans whenever and wherever they can have been indicted on charges of helping to bomb the American destroyer Cole in Yemen in 2000, officials said today.

title: Italy Starts Work on Sea Gates Intended to Avert Venice Floods
description: After decades of indecision and bickering over how to protect Venice from increasingly frequent flooding, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi started Italy on one of its biggest public works projects in years today: a series of 79 sea gates for the city.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airline Posts Loss
description: Buffeted by the outbreak of SARS in Asia and a generally weak global economy, Lufthansa of Germany reported a first-quarter loss of 356 million euros ($409 million), nearly double its loss in the quarter last year. The airline gave little hope for a quick rebound, saying it expected to report an operating loss for the full year. Lufthansa's passenger traffic plummeted 2.8 percent over all, and nearly 20 percent in Asia, forcing it to scale back routes and ground planes. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: U.S. Officials Worried Saudi Attacks Could Be First in Series
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 15  As a team of American investigators landed in Saudi Arabia, American officials said today that warnings to Americans and others to leave the country were based on conclusions that the bombing attacks of Monday night could be the first in a series of such attacks in Saudi Arabia and the region.

title: A Little Modern, At the Javits Center
description: Bored at home? Shopping frustrate you? Travel not an option? Check out the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York. The trade show, which runs Saturday through Tuesday, is open to the public on its last day.

title: Corrections
description: The Outdoors column in the sports pages on Sunday about the sanctuaries known as Marine Protection Areas, and the debate over how they should function, misstated the name of the organization for which Kate Wing works as an ocean policy analyst. It is the Natural Resources Defense Council, not National Resources.

title: Accounts

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Help For Beating Victims
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would seek to help victims of domestic violence who do not go to the police. The city will use a new comprehensive system administered through its 11 public hospitals, called Project HEAL, for Health Emergency Assistance Link. The system is intended to help the hospitals document the injuries of women who show up after domestic violence disputes, and to help them contact social and legal services. Digital cameras will be placed in all emergency rooms of city hospitals to help document the injuries. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

description: Dave DeBusschere, the Hall of Fame forward whose tenacious defensive play, rebounding prowess and timely scoring helped propel the Knicks to their only two N.B.A. championships, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 62.

description: Paul J. Griswold, the chief executive of the Paxar Corporation, a maker of electronic bar-code printers and labeling devices, has resigned to ''pursue other business interests,'' according to the company.

title: Gun Makers Not Liable for Violence, Jury Says
description: A federal jury in Brooklyn found yesterday that the marketing practices of 45 gun manufacturers and distributors were not responsible for fostering gun violence in minority communities in New York City, a finding that was seen as a victory for the gun industry.

title: China Threatens Execution in Intentional Spreading of SARS
description: BEIJING, May 15  Adding a stern new chord in its campaign to stop SARS and rebuild international confidence, the Chinese government said today that anyone who intentionally spreads the disease could be liable to punishment ranging from 10 years to execution.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global PC Shipments To Rise, Study Says
description: Global personal computer shipments are expected to rise 6.4 percent in the second quarter, helped by demand for portable computers, the market research company Gartner Inc. said in a report released yesterday. Shipments are forecast to increase to 30.7 million units this quarter, Gartner said in an e-mail statement. The PC market is expected to expand 2.6 percent, to $38.3 billion in revenue in the quarter. ''The good news for the global economy is that the U.S.-led war against Saddam concluded more quickly and with fewer damaging economic consequences than many expected,'' George Shiffler, the principal analyst for Gartner's computing platforms and economics research, said in the statement. ''The bad news is that the global economy does not appear to be experiencing the uplift that so many anticipated once the war was concluded, at least not yet.''

title: Aide Says Blair Has Not Yet Decided to Abandon Euro Vote
description: LONDON, May 15  Sidestepping critics' demands to state its intentions on joining the euro, the British government said today that it would announce its plans next month and seemed to distance itself from reports that Prime Minister Tony Blair had already given up on the idea of a referendum on the contentious single currency.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: WEST TRENTON: ARREST IN GANG CASE The authorities have arrested six New Jersey men who they say are part of a street gang, the Latin Kings. The police identified the men yesterday as Daniel Gomes, 27, of West New York; Rafael Melendez, 32, of Elizabeth; Robert Villalta, 23, of North Bergen; Luis Perez, 24, of Jersey City; Jonathan Matias, 29, of Jersey City; and Renzo Castello, 25, of Guttenberg. Charges include conspiracy to sell handguns, drug distribution and racketeering. Detective Sgt. First Class Keith Bevacqui of the state police said Mr. Gomes and Mr. Melendez are members of a council overseeing the gang on a state level. The arrests are part of a continuing statewide investigation. Since last October, 47 people the authorities have identified as gang members have been arrested. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: When President Bush travels to St. Petersburg early next month, he will again urge President Vladimir Putin to stop supplying Iran with the means to develop nuclear weapons. Putin will insist, as usual, that his dangerous trade is all for peaceful purposes.

description: There's a sculptural quality to George Walker's music. He grasps a chord and shapes it into a range of permutations as if squeezing wet clay, violently. The handful of clay remains the same, but its surface changes with new indentations and promontories, thick and wet and dense.

description: With more than 300,000 Liberian refugees across West Africa in his care, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Ruud Lubbers, arrived today to see their president, Charles Taylor, in the bullet-riddled capital of this ravaged country.

title: And Here's Where It Gets Uninteresting
description: THERE are plenty of boring Web logs out there, online diaries whose authors dutifully recount their thoughts and actions in excruciating detail. But Dave Walker, a 32-year-old cartoonist and Web editor from Cookham, England, has claimed the distinction of writing ''The Dullest Blog in the World.''

title: A Husky Voice and a Flair for Melodrama
description: Over the past few years, a 29-year-old singer named Mariza has helped repopularize fado, the tear-jerking Portuguese genre. Her approach is counterintuitive: instead of reinventing fado for modern listeners, she delights in the music's melodrama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YING, DR. SAI HOU
description: YING-Dr. Sai Hou on May 7, 2003, at the age of 95. He devoted more than sixty years to his patients, students, and family. He came to the U.S. as a visiting scholar at P.& S. College, Columbia University. Later, he served as a physician at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Disease, assistant professor at the Cornell University Medical School, and a founding member at the Strang Clinic of the New York Preventive Cancer Research Institute. He had a private practice in Manhattan for more than 15 years. He saved lives, made contributions to the medical science, and established the image of a man of professionalism and integrity. He is survived by his wife, four daughters, six grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Memorial service, Friday, May 16, 5 PM at Chun Fook Funeral Home, 134-35 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY, 11354.

title: Editor of Times Tells Staff He Accepts Blame for Fraud
description: The executive editor of The New York Times told a town-hall-style meeting of newsroom staff members yesterday that he accepted blame for the breakdown of communication and oversight that allowed a Times reporter to commit frequent acts of journalistic fraud in recent months.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwalk: TB Found At High School
description: Fifteen students at Brien McMahon High School have tested positive for exposure to pulmonary tuberculosis in a schoolwide screening after the disease was diagnosed in one student last month, the director of the city's Health Department, Tim Callahan, said yesterday. None of the 15 have contracted the disease. In all, 515 faculty members, staff members and students were tested. The student, whose name and age have not been released, is recovering, Mr. Callahan said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Criticizes Rent Rally Spending
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the City Council's decision to spend $75,000 promoting a rent control rally in Albany on Tuesday and sending 31 busloads of people to it was unhelpful while the city was trying to win more money from the state. Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, defended his decision to spend taxpayers' money, saying he was simply empowering regular citizens to lobby for their interests. Several government watchdogs noted that if the Council bused people to Albany to be heard on every issue, the practice would get expensive. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Housewares With a Hint Of Normandy, in SoHo
description: Catherine Memmi, top, opened her first store in Paris 10 years ago, followed by shops in Deauville, France; London and Tokyo. This week her newest store, a 3,000-square-foot space that looks like a large loft, above, opens in SoHo. The downstairs (opening next week) will be set up like a hotel suite. Her neo-minimalist furnishings include Zen side tables in dark brown oak, wenge or sycamore ($1,050), couches and pillows in pale leathers and washable cottons (from $200 to $1,300), lamps in zinc, bedding and scented candles ($47). Fabrications, colors and sizes can be customized. Her palette, she says, is ''inspired by summers in Normandy'' and the paintings of her grandparents. Catherine Memmi is at 45 Greene Street (Broome Street); (212) 226-8200.

title: Film Rentals Via the Web: A Studio Cut
description: DECADES ago, a Mad magazine cartoonist, Dave Berg, offered a vision of how the Soviet Union might win the cold war. Here in America, a never-ending succession of labor-saving devices -- escalators, cars, remote controls and so on -- had already created the most sedentary society on earth. All the Soviets had to do was wait until we evolved into living Weebles, complete with tippy, round bases and vestigial leg sprouts. Then they would just knock us over with the butts of their rifles.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: A SURPRISE SECOND DAY OF STRIKES In a surprise shutdown that left many Parisians stranded at bus stops and subway stations, transport workers extended their crippling strike into a second day and threatened a third if the government refuses to bend on planned pension changes. Armed with the growing pressure, union leaders entered a fresh round of talks with the government, but bitterness was building. "If they tell us they're just going to change the ribbon on the package, that will not do," said Marc Blondel, the head of the Workers Force union. Earlier, the Labor Minister, François Fillon, insisted, "I will give up nothing."    (AP)

description: The nostalgia got to Jerry Lucas, what with Saturday's 30th anniversary of the last Knicks team to win a championship. All week he had reflected on his teammates and a time that stood still on a 1973 calendar.

description: As President Bush's chief lobbyist on Capitol Hill, David Hobbs is part salesman, part vote counter and part enforcer for an administration that has in recent months taken a hard line in dealing with Congress.

description: McWane Inc., a major manufacturer of cast-iron pipes and one of the nation's most persistent violators of workplace safety and environmental laws, is the target of a federal criminal investigation, according to law enforcement officials and current and former employees who have been questioned in the inquiry.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: War Crimes Complaint Against Franks
description: A lawmaker filed a lawsuit charging the commander of American troops in Iraq, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, with war crimes, prompting an angry demand by the United States that Belgium take action to prevent its laws from being used for political purposes. The suit was filed under Belgium's universal competency law, which gives the courts jurisdiction to bring charges of international crimes even if the case has nothing to do with Belgium or Belgians. Earlier this year, the Parliament, concerned about an earlier lawsuit against the first President Bush, revised the law to prevent such charges, and it seemed very likely that the new case would be dismissed in court. The suit, brought on behalf of 19 mostly Iraqi plaintiffs, charges General Franks with responsibility for civilian casualties. A State Department spokesman, Philip Reeker, dismissed the action as ''ludicrous,'' adding, ''we certainly expect that the Belgian government will take the necessary actions to dismiss the lawsuit under its laws.'' Richard Bernstein (NYT)

description: MILLER-Aileen Gabel. Of Ft. Lee, NJ. Beloved wife of the late William. Dear sister of Martin Klein, sister in law of Myrna Klein. Loving aunt. Services ''Wien & Wien'', phone 1-800-378-1892.
