title: Trapped in Heat In Texas Truck, 18 People Die
description: Sheriff's deputies found the bodies of 17 people early this morning on the outskirts of this southern Texas city, the victims of stifling heat inside a trailer truck that was apparently being used to smuggle them into the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Another Loss At Hynix
description: Hynix Semiconductor, which is 70 percent owned by the banks that have kept it alive with more than $6 billion in loans, posted a net loss of 1.05 trillion won ($87 billion) in the first quarter of this year in contrast to a profit of 3.7 billion won in the first quarter of 2002. The company reported first-quarter sales of 682 billion won ($568 million), down from 823 billion won in the period last year. The company has posted losses for four consecutive quarters but predicted ''a better sales performance in the months ahead'' on the basis of new technology and its $100 million investment in its plant in Eugene, Ore. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Acquires Think Dynamics
description: I.B.M. took another step yesterday in its strategy of offering corporate customers computing as a utilitylike service with the purchase of Think Dynamics, a small software company. Terms of the purchase of the privately held company were not disclosed. Think Dynamics, based in Toronto, has just 34 employees, but it has developed innovative software for shifting computing workloads among different machines as demand rises and falls. I.B.M. executives say the technology promises to be an important building block in efforts to improve the efficiency of the data centers of its customers and those run by I.B.M.'s big services unit. I.B.M. has had the technology for shifting computing workloads on its large mainframe computers for years. But the Think Dynamics software enables the flexible movement of computing resources across many kinds of hardware and operating systems. Other start-ups, including Opsware, have developed similar technology. And several big companies like Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard and Sun Microsystems are pursuing utility computing strategies in competition with I.B.M. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Hedge Funds Favor Raising Investor Wealth Requirement
description: Hedge fund executives said at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today that they would support raising the minimum wealth requirement for their investors in a bid to stave off new regulations.

title: Gov. Jeb Bush to Seek Guardian for Fetus of Rape Victim
description: Gov. Jeb Bush has asked a court to appoint a guardian for the fetus of a developmentally disabled rape victim, a move that has angered women's rights groups and reignited the debate over abortion in Florida.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The euro fell on concern that the currency's rally will curtail economic growth and lead the European Central Bank to cut interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1511, down from $1.1519 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, ALISON
description: FAY-Alison, May 12, 2003, Beloved wife of Richard. Loving mother of Lisa and Keith. Devoted daughter of Margaret MacBain and the late Gavin MacBain. Her compassion for love and life will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Tuesday, May 20, 9:30 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 Street, NY NY 10019-3984 or Trustees of Columbia University, C/O Department of Medicine, 630 West 168 St. PH8E-105, NY, NY 10032.

title: Bequeath the Steinway
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Sellers Fall Victim to Counterfeit Cashier's Checks
description: IN a new twist on a fraudulent money-transferring scheme, a growing number of people who sell goods online are falling victim to con artists who locate their victims through mass e-mailings.

title: People
description: * Michael J. Sheehan, president at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named to the added post of chief executive, assuming those duties from Jack Connors, who continues as chairman.

title: A Great Estate Opens Its Gates
description: On a misty day last week, I toured 700 acres of a vast pastoral landscape here that could have been in England. Deer raised their heads in an emerald-green meadow. Alles of London plane trees led to arched bridges over quiet lakes fed by meandering streams and gushing waterfalls. Fountains and classical statues greeted me at every turn, even in the picturesque ruins of a stone hay barn.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH SAYS PROFIT MAY RISE 13% THIS YEAR
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies yesterday forecast per-share earnings increases of as much as 13 percent this year and 12 percent next year as higher prices and new beers help sales. The company, which makes Budweiser and Bud Light, previously said 2003 profit would rise 12 percent. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had average estimates of $2.48 for 2003 and $2.74 a share for 2004. Anheuser-Busch has raised prices for four straight years and plans to increase them again in the third quarter, executives said during an investor meeting today.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MODEL AGENCY ORDERED TO PAY A jury in State Supreme Court yesterday ordered Elite Model Management to pay $5.27 million to a former employee who said she had been fired after she complained that the cigarette smoke in the agency's offices made her sick. The jury awarded the money to the woman, Victoria Gallegos, 32, after finding that Elite had subjected her to a hostile work environment and had fired her because of her disability, asthma, and her complaints. Ms. Gallegos was fired after seven weeks at Elite, whose models include Claudia Schiffer and Laura Cisneros. She said the agency's owners hired her in 1999 at $100,000 a year to eventually run its New York office. Elite's lawyer, Robert Goodman, told the judge that he would file a motion to vacate the award. (AP)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Meadow Trumps Mall in New Jersey
description: The first thing that travelers from New York see of the Garden State is not a garden at all but a swampy mosquito-breeding wasteland known, counterintuitively, as the Hackensack Meadowlands. Now, however, under a plan being cobbled together by environmentalists, business leaders and state and local officials, New Jersey's worst eyesore -- which comes into view just west of the railroad tunnels -- may one day become a watery ecological preserve covering 8,400 acres of protected wetlands, wildlife refuges, hiking trails, playing fields and even a golf course or two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENSEN, GERBER, JU DIANNE
description: DENSEN - GERBER - Ju dianne. Neither the world nor I were ready for you to leave. You-with so much knowledge and charm have left an awesome army of friends and admirers. Love, Marty Edelston, Publisher BottomLine/Personal

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADER'S PROFIT RISES Japan's biggest general trading company, the Mitsubishi Corporation , earned 62 billion yen ($534 million) in the year that ended March 31, 3.2 percent more than the year before. The company said profit from its expansion in the convenience store market offset losses accumulated in the company's stock portfolio. This year, Mitsubishi expects profits to grow 61 percent, to 100 billion yen. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLMER, HELEN (LEVEN SON)
description: WOLMER - Helen (Leven son) on May 13, formerly of New York City, wife of the late Sam Wolmer, sister of the late Herman Levenson, aunt of Sherry and Stephen Brass and Joshua and Susan Levenson. Services at Wellwood Cemetery on Friday, May 16 at 2PM.

title: Suit Accusing French Railways of Holocaust Role Is Thrown Out
description: A Paris court today rejected a lawsuit charging France's national railroad company with the equivalent of complicity in crimes against humanity for deporting Jews to Nazi death camps during Germany's wartime occupation of France. The court ruled that a 10-year statute of limitations applied in this case.

title: Jet Flies Low Over Manhattan, Putting Some on Ground on Edge
description: A Boeing 777 jet flying near the Statue of Liberty and across Midtown Manhattan yesterday morning to give returning military personnel a closer view prompted numerous calls to the police and to aviation officials, the Federal Aviation Administration said. The incident showed how nerves continue to be frayed after the attack of Sept. 11.

title: U.S. Military Chief Vows More Troops to Quell Iraqi Looting
description: Warning that ''it will take time'' to end the near-anarchy of violence and robbery here, the top American military commander in Iraq vowed today to greatly increase the number of troops in the streets and to take tougher action against looters.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cairo Hotel Not Liable In Attack
description: A federal jury found yesterday that the Semiramis Inter-Continental Hotel in Cairo was not liable in the fatal shootings of two New Jersey businessmen, Coby Hoffman of Edison and Robert L. Guidi of Rahway, in the hotel's restaurant in 1993. The families of the victims sued along with a Washington lawyer who had been critically injured in the attack, blaming lax security. The hotel said that it had followed all security standards mandated by the Egyptian government, and that the attack, carried out by a gunman, was not foreseeable. A lawyer for the plaintiffs, Harvey Weitz, said the families, who had wanted the trial in New York, were considering whether to appeal. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Consumer Pullback: Retail Sales Fell 0.1% in April
description: Consumers spent a shade less in retail stores and food service outlets in April than in March, according to figures released yesterday by the Commerce Department. Experts attributed the sluggishness to job-related uncertainty and the psychological hangover from the war in Iraq.

title: How Microsoft Warded Off Rival Software
description: At least 90 percent of the world's personal computers run on Windows software. But Microsoft wanted still more.

title: To Register Doubts, Press Here
description: AFTER the 2000 presidential election, with its disputes over the balloting in Florida and its hanging chad, the federal government moved swiftly to revamp the country's largely paper-based and mechanical voting systems. More than $1 billion has been appropriated for buying electronic voting systems, including optical scanners and touch-screen machines, that eliminate ballots written or punched on paper or tallied by mechanical equipment.

title: The Meaning of Terror in Riyadh (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Is Reported to Have Decided Against Adopting the Euro
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair and Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown, often depicted as rivals for the future leadership of Britain, met today to debate whether this country should adopt the euro, inspiring news reports that a decision had been reached against adopting the single currency.

title: A Lot Softer Than the Floor
description: AS summer approaches you can always count on a few hardy perennials: tulips and daffodils, flies and mosquitoes, and weekend guests.

title: U.S., Europe and Canada Investigate Copper Pricing
description: Antitrust authorities in the United States, Europe and Canada are investigating whether several large copper companies colluded to fix prices, regulators said today.

title: Residents of Compound Weigh Cost of Staying
description: Outside a group of villas with their walls blown away, bulldozers cleared away rubble today from the explosions that wrecked the Al Hamra residential compound this week. A couple of teenagers collected small black pieces of metal, souvenirs of what they thought was the car bomb that caused the disaster.

title: For Summer Listening in Two Parks
description: Two of New York's popular summer concert series have announced their seasons without resorting to a fare hike: they are still free. Mostly.

title: A Remote Surfs the Web, Dims Lights And Even Changes Channels
description: In the iPronto TSi6400, a slender, book-size device that resembles a tablet PC, Philips Electronics has crossed the remote control with the Internet. The iPronto gives you control over almost any device in your home that has a remote control of its own, including the TV, VCR, DVD player, stereo and indoor lighting -- essentially anything that can be turned on and off or up and down with infrared or radio signals.

title: Online and Off the Record
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ballet When It's Beastly
description: The 50's-flavored costumes never camouflage the characters in Christopher Wheeldon's "Carnival of the Animals." Rather, each is adorned with a subtle animal accent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fuel Project Approved
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and its partners approved a $10 billion project to tap deposits off Russia's Pacific coast after finding a buyer for the fuel. Shell; Mitsui & Company; and the Mitsubishi Corporation, both of Japan, said they would proceed with plans to develop the Lunskoye gas field and build a liquefied natural gas plant on Sakhalin Island.

title: Sorenstam vs. Men, Sorenstam vs. History
description: For two days next week, maybe four, Annika Sorenstam will dominate the telecast of a golf tournament as only Tiger Woods has. There may be no reason to watch the Colonial on USA Network and CBS except to follow her progress.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TIFFANY, New York, the retailer of luxury jewelry, increased its quarterly dividend to 5 cents from 4 cents a share, the first increase in three years.

title: Germans Edge Toward U.S. Stance on U.N. Iraq Resolution
description: BERLIN, May 16  In a sign of improving relations with the United States after the worst diplomatic chill between the two countries in half a century, Germany's top officials said they wanted to reach an agreement on the Security Council resolution on Iraq that is being pressed by Britain and the United States.

title: Streetwise Son With Heart, Played by a Young Natural
description: A year after its premiere at the Cannes International Film Festival, Ken Loach's quick, deft life-on-the-streets drama ''Sweet Sixteen'' still has a place in my head. The picture remains indelible because of Mr. Loach's bold, direct framing of the narrative and the casual dynamism of its young star, Martin Compston, making his acting debut. This slim, gawky kid takes to the camera with alarming ease and makes acting seem as deceptively simple as the title of Mr. Loach's involving new social melodrama.

title: Weekender | Bridgewater, Conn.
description: ''IT's delicious,'' said Cathleen P. Black, president of Hearst Magazines, who bought a 1790 farmhouse in Bridgewater for $1.3 million in 1997 and has spent every possible weekend there with her family since. ''I look out at the horses and the baby cows in the fields across the road, and just say 'ahhh.' You come to Bridgewater and just completely chill out and calm down.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Number of Cases in Taiwan May Be More Than Reported
description: Even as Taiwan was reporting its biggest one-day jump in probable SARS cases, health officials said today that the outbreak here was being inaccurately counted and was probably much bigger than reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIGAN, R. DAVID
description: MULLIGAN-R. David. May 16, 1952 to May 3, 2003. Survived by sisters Susan and Nancy. Beloved son of Robert and Alice. He left his family and friends a better world. We'll go on, but without the same lightness and without his unusual perspective. Happy Birthday, David.

title: On the Turf of the Hip, Phillips Sells Young Art
description: The audience was greeted with the thumping sound of techno music. In the heart of Chelsea, surrounded by a neighborhood dense with galleries, Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg held its first sale of contemporary art in its downtown space.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about bombings in Saudi Arabia misstated the theory of American investigators about the 1996 bombing of the Khobar Towers apartment block in Dhahran, which killed 19 members of the American military. (The error was repeated in an article on Wednesday.) United States officials have publicly stated that the attack was carried out by members of a pro-Iranian group known as Saudi Hezbollah. The United States government has also made those charges in federal court. The attack is not believed to have been the work of Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASTANIS, GEORGE
description: KASTANIS-George. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of George Kastanis, beloved father of John N. Kastanis, F.A.C.H.E., President and Chief Executive Officer of The Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute. We extend our sincere condolences to the Kastanis family and their many friends. Edward A. Stolzenberg, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater New York Hospital Association

title: Green Acres, Not the Place for Me
description: ONE or two Fridays each year, a group of friends and I leave work a half-hour early, pile into a rented car and drive four hours or so to the quiet Catskills town of Bovina. My friends Tom and Maria Lauricella own a small second home up there and are gracious enough to share their mountain idyll with us city-choked wretches. These weekends invariably pass too quickly, filled as they are with lazy sunsets, gently swinging hammocks, and Tom and Maria's excellent cooking. In the winter, we build a life-threatening sled run on the 37-acre property. In the summer and fall, our energies are spent on intensely competitive bouts of whiffle ball home run derby.

title: Putin Offers an Amnesty Plan Covering Most Chechen Rebels
description: President Vladimir V. Putin proposed granting amnesty today to Chechen separatists who agreed to lay down their arms by Aug. 1, but the offer would exclude any accused of murder, rape, kidnapping or other crimes.

title: U.S. Moves to Allow Trading Of Radio Spectrum Licenses
description: The government took the first steps today to permit companies to lease and trade radio spectrum licenses, a move that could result in improved service for the nation's millions of users of cellphones and other wireless devices.

title: Shopping List | Garden Tools
description: TOOLS for gardeners are like knives and pots for cooks; the better they are, the more you want to use them. For dedicated gardeners and their gardens, both deserving the best, good gear is an investment that will last a lifetime. For a variety of plants and seeds, try www.burpee.com and www.seedsof change.com. At www.eat-it.com, the site of the Virginia-based Edible Landscaping, there is an extraordinary selection of fruit and berry plants and trees.

title: Scene of Horror and Despair in Trailer
description: One woman, among the dozens of people trapped inside a tractor trailer outside this sweltering southern Texas city, screamed over and over, ''El nio!, el nio!'' El nio -- the boy -- was seven years old and had died in his father's arms.

title: Five Requests to Saudis Went Unheeded, U.S. Says
description: In the month before Monday's bombings in Riyadh, the United States asked Saudi Arabia on at least five separate occasions to deploy armed uniformed government guards around all Western targets of a possible terrorist attack, Bush administration officials said today.

title: Pataki Hints at Legal Action To Block Legislature's Budget
description: Gov. George E. Pataki cast a pall of uncertainty over the budget the Legislature enacted today, saying that many sections of it were drafted unconstitutionally, including the tax increases, and hinting that he may yet challenge those sections in court.

title: Behind a Fairy Tale Horse, Teamwork and Romance
description: He is 65 with a face as burnished as a well-worn saddle and more than 30 years of experience rising at 4 a.m. to make horses who are O.K. in the morning pretty good at the racetrack in the afternoon. She is 40 and has the regal bearing of the show rider she once was. She traces her affinity for horses to the moment before her birth, when her mother won a jumping competition while she kicked in the womb.

title: Lebanon Says Arrests Foiled Attack on the U.S. Embassy
description: The Lebanese Army, helped by Syrian intelligence, has arrested nine Islamist militants in northern Lebanon who were plotting an attack on the United States Embassy here, government and military officials said today.

title: American Dies in a Land Whose Faith Called Him
description: Sgt. Obadiah Y. Abdullah left the United States Army last June, and sent his rsum to the Vinnell Corporation, a Defense Department contractor. Within three days Mr. Abdullah, a former fire control specialist, was hired and by July he was on his way to Saudi Arabia.

title: Laurence Radway, 84, Politician
description: Laurence I. Radway, a Dartmouth College professor of government with a zeal for practical politics who walked the length of New Hampshire in his losing 1972 campaign for the United States Senate, died on May 7 in Lebanon, N.H. He was 84.

title: Has Technology Lost Its 'Special' Status?
description: Searching for the elusive recovery in technology spending has resembled walking toward a horizon that just keeps receding. Improvement lies just over the next hill, most technology executives keep saying, but the present looks pretty murky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, ANNE
description: FRIEDLANDER-Anne. Died May 11, at age 100, after a lifetime fighting for peace, social justice, and against racism. She had a major influence on the lives of her nephews, Sidney and Philip, her niece Sylvia, and their families.

title: Wise Women, Heroic, Ripe Or Villainous
description: Strong roles for women are a staple of ballet. And three dancers took advantage of that in ''La Bayadre'' and Antony Tudor's ''Offenbach in the Underworld,'' presented by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Sports of The Times; Devils Get a Sellout To Go With Their Run
description: WHEN the Devils skated onto the ice last night for Game 3 with the Ottawa Senators in the Eastern Conference finals, most of them did what most hockey players always do. They checked out the size of the crowd.

title: 34 Years Later, One Coach's Sweetest Victory
description: For 34 years, April 5 was never just another day for Kitty Fassel and her husband, Jim, the head coach of the Giants. On that day, wherever they were in the rolling stone existence of a coach's life, the Fassels would always find time to come together privately and quietly say, ''Happy Birthday'' to the son they did not raise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, JOHN
description: BOYLE-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Boyle, associated with The Times from December 1976 until retiring in September 2000.

description: WHO -- Anne Hopkins, 61, professor and former president of the University of North Florida in Jacksonville.

title: Palestinians' Chief Negotiator Resigns
description: JERUSALEM, May 16  In a sign of the turmoil inside the governing Palestinian Authority, the Palestinians' chief negotiator, Saeb Erekat, has submitted his resignation after being cut out of high-level talks between the adversaries that are planned for Saturday night.

title: DOLLAR TREE IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR GREENBACKS INC.
description: Dollar Tree Stores, a leading retailer of goods that cost about $1, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Greenbacks Inc. for about $100 million in cash. Greenbacks, which is closely held, has 96 stores in 10 states in the West and Southwest, including Arizona, Colorado and Texas. Six of the 10 states are new markets for Dollar Tree. The purchase will give Dollar Tree a presence in 47 of the 48 contiguous states, the company said. Greenbacks had sales of about $127.5 million last year, compared with Dollar Tree's sales of $2.33 billion.

title: Richard Bosman; Gaylen Hansen; Abraham Cruzvillegas
description: Richard Bosman

title: Dominican Bankers Linked to Embezzlement
description: Three top executives of the Dominican Republic's second-largest commercial bank were arrested Wednesday after authorities discovered a clandestine banking operation that resulted in the embezzling of $2.2 billion.

title: Doctors Rally for Limits on Awards in Malpractice Suits
description: Several thousand New Jersey doctors and nurses staged their second rally of the year here today to press their demand for legislation to limit jury awards in malpractice lawsuits.

title: Godfried Donkor
description: The Scene

title: Single Case, Unproven, Stirs Fear Of Chinese
description: Here on the Siberian border with China, Russia's first and only suspected case of severe acute respiratory syndrome lies in medical isolation demanding food and a good book, presumably unaware of the utter confusion trailing in his wake.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Truckers Strike Ends
description: A truckers' strike that had paralyzed the port of Pusan for a week was settled, with the government agreeing to cut drivers' taxes, pay for some of their gasoline and reduce rates on toll roads. Members of the Korea Cargo Transport Workers Union unanimously approved the agreement. The government estimated losses incurred by the strike at $450 million. Pusan is in southeastern South Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Where Music Is a Game

title: Woody Being Woody (Well, Who Else?)
description: That Woody Allen has never directed for the stage before now seems odd and unlikely, but it's so. And after seeing ''Writer's Block,'' the engaging, summerweight show made up of two new one-act comedies that Mr. Allen both wrote and directed, you may find yourself wondering how his career would have been different if his directorial vision had originated in the theater.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Regulators Seek E.D.S. Papers On Navy Deal
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a leading seller of computer services, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission requested documents about a $6.9 billion Navy contract after the company had a loss on the deal. The S.E.C. is already investigating Electronic Data's purchase and settlement of stock-option contracts and events leading to a Sept. 18 forecast that third-quarter profit would be a fifth of the company's estimate. Electronic Data disclosed the Navy-related request in a first-quarter report filed with the S.E.C. yesterday. The report does not say what is in the requested papers. The S.E.C. asked for the additional documents, Electronic Data said, after the company reported a $334 million pretax loss on its seven-year contract to build a network linking the Navy and the Marine Corps at more than 300 bases in the United States and the Caribbean.

title: Whittenburg Confident He Can Win at Fordham
description: Dereck Whittenburg was nearly a half-hour late for the news conference introducing him as Fordham's new basketball coach yesterday. But given the debacle that the team endured last season, and the program's failure to post a winning record since 1992, the university's staff and fans were happy to wait for Whittenburg's cabdriver to make it from the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, AGNES MARIE
description: GOODMAN - Agnes Marie, 85, of Bradenton, FL. Died on Wednesday, May 14, 2003. The daughter of the late Mary (Daly) Dowling and John Dowling, she was born on March 16, 1918 in Manhattan, N.Y. and retired to Bradenton, FL. in 1979 from Brooklyn, N.Y. She was the widow of the late Dr. Herman S. Goodman. She was a Registered Nurse. A family statement reads ''she was a tender, loving wife, sister, aunt and friend who traveled the world for us to see. Her grace, courage and love shall always be cherished and remembered.'' Mrs. Goodman is survived by her sister, Florence Carey of Pearl River, N.Y.; nieces, Patricia Bauscher, Eileen Montalbano, Barbara Carey, Carol-Jean Mackin; nephews Raymond J. Carey Jr, Dr. Michael Dowling and Frank Dowling and twelve grand-nephews and nieces. She is predeceased by her siblings Charles Dowling, Frances A. Dowling and Margaret Dowling. A memorial service will be held at St. Anthony's R.C. Church in Nanuet, N.Y. on May 19, at 11AM. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice Southwest Fl, 5955 Rand Blvd, Sarasota, FL. 34238.

title: Gravano's Arrest Saved Him From Murder, Officials Say
description: Two mob figures, acting on orders from the upper echelons of the Gambino crime family, were in the final stages of an elaborate plot to kill Salvatore Gravano with a bomb in Arizona in 1999 when his arrest narrowly averted his murder, federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Rare Glimpse Of Disorder In the Court
description: Transcripts released yesterday from the just-concluded Crown Heights federal trial offer a rare glimpse of bare-knuckled rancor, brinkmanship and trash-talking behind the scenes that the considerable tension in the courtroom barely hinted at.

title: My First Cigarette, and My Last
description: My father, a Russian peasant, came to this country in 1910. Like all of his pals, he smoked. It's hard for me to picture my father without a cigarette in his mouth.

title: Virus Takes a Toll on Texas Poultry Business
description: David Alders's business is up a gravel road behind his white, two-story farmhouse: six air-conditioned poultry houses, each filled with 25,000 squawking chickens -- some 150,000 chickens in all, gorging on buckets of corn feed and sipping water from plastic nipples suspended in the air.

title: Peggy Cyphers
description: The Proposition

title: Ruling Leaves Legal Standoff In 9/11 Case
description: A trial judge today threw the fate of Zacarias Moussaoui back into the hands of a federal appeals court, saying she could not accept a Justice Department compromise over classified evidence that might have allowed the trial of Mr. Moussaoui to go forward.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: KaZaA Operator Told To Disclose Investors
description: AOL Time Warner, Sony and other entertainment companies suing the operator of the KaZaA online file-sharing system will be able to learn who has invested in it, a federal judge ruled yesterday. Magistrate Judge Patrick J. Walsh in Los Angeles ordered the company, Sharman Networks Ltd., to produce a list of investors, as well as lenders that declined invitations to invest. The company also has to provide the names of all its managers and directors, the judge said. Record companies and music publishers have begun suing investors and individual users in music-swapping services in their battle against what they say is piracy that costs them billions of dollars annually in lost sales. In a suit filed last month, Vivendi Universal and the EMI Group accused Hummer Winblad Venture Partners of contributing to copyright infringement through Hummer's investment of $13 million in Napster Inc., which is now defunct. Roderick Dorman, a lawyer for Sharman, did not immediately return a call for comment.

title: Pataki Vetoes Aid Package, Urging His Proposals Instead
description: Less than an hour after the Legislature voted overwhelmingly to override his vetoes of the state budget, Gov. George E. Pataki struck again, vetoing an aid package for New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, JOACHIM
description: SPRINGER - Joachim. Be loved father, brother and friend passed away peacefully at his home May 15, 2003.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Nominee For A Suny Campus
description: Robert L. King, the chancellor of the State University of New York, has recommended Steven G. Poskanzer as president of SUNY's New Paltz campus. Mr. Poskanzer, 44, who joined SUNY in 1997, has been acting president since 2001. New Paltz's previous president, Roger W. Bowen, stepped down when Gov. George E. Pataki and some SUNY trustees strongly criticized him for defending the campus's right to include a session on sadomasochism in a conference on sex. The appointment is expected to be approved next week. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Sweden Makes Bid To Host World Cup
description: While the United States remains the favorite, Sweden made a formal bid yesterday to be host to the Women's World Cup this fall, soccer's world governing body said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGA KHAN, SADRUDDIN
description: AGA KHAN-Sadruddin. The editors and staff of the literary quarterly, ''The Paris Review,'' mourn the loss of Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, who was its publisher for 24 years after its founding in Paris in 1953. George Plimpton

title: Eye-Catching Women In an Altered Reality
description: A major fault line running through the shaky world of contemporary art separates the land of the verbal from the land of the visual. That line is spotlighted by the concurrence of two exhibitions at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea: works from the 1960's and 70's by Robert Whitman and, on the floor below, an installation by the contemporary German Conceptualist Rosemarie Trockel.

title: Big East Game Plan Focuses on Money
description: The Big East Conference's strategy to keep Miami from bolting to the Atlantic Coast Conference hinges on money more than loyalty, and on future gains more than friendship, two Big East athletic directors said today.

title: Target Posts Slow Growth as Spending Lags
description: The Target Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 1.2 percent, the smallest increase in a year and a half. The company predicted disappointing results for this quarter.

description: Directed by Claes Lilja

title: Coleman Is Again a Leader in the Playoffs
description: It was 10 years ago this month when Derrick Coleman was a young star carrying his team. That year the Nets had been devastated by injuries, leaving Coleman, then 25, to try to carry them past the far more talented and accomplished Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: 'Pokmon Heroes'
description: Directed by Kunihiro Yuyama and Jim Malone

title: Seeing Kandahar In Taliban Days
description: As always, New Yorker Video is filling its niche with interesting releases. Last month there was Jean Vigo's film ''L'Atalante'' (1934). ''May be the greatest film of all time,'' reads a critic's assessment on the front of the DVD.

title: Architect of Atrocity, The Formative Years
description: Viewers who feared the worst of ''Hitler: The Rise of Evil'' can relax. This CBS mini-series about Hitler's early years, which begins on Sunday night, does not make him sympathetic. On the contrary, the producers were so anxious not to blur their portrait of evil that they left out the banality of Hitler.

title: Second Act for Controversial Mayor
description: The political career of Carl E. Officer funeral director, minister, mayor of this city -- has had more than its share of peculiar turns.

title: Umbrellas For a Rolls
description: Sudden showers can mean frustrating moments trying to scramble out of the car and open an umbrella at the same time. But Rolls-Royce has made the process just a tad easier. Its new Phantom, due to go on sale in the United States in June, comes equipped with two custom-made umbrellas that stow in tubes inside the rear doors. Before alighting from the car, the owner (or the chauffeur) pushes a silver button. The brushed-aluminum handle of a black umbrella slides out. Opened and held by hand, it protects the emerging passenger from the elements.

title: IDT UNIT IS BUYING MAJORITY STAKE IN ANIMATION COMPANY
description: A unit of IDT, a long-distance phone company, is buying a majority stake in Film Roman, animator of ''The Simpsons'' and ''King of the Hill,'' for $900,000 in cash and a credit line of about $2.1 million. In exchange, the unit, IDT Media, will receive about 10 million shares, or a 51 percent interest in the company, Film Roman said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. IDT Media's animation-production unit, Digital Production Solutions, is trying to expand the number of programs it animates. IDT is based in Newark.

title: Where Luxury R.V.'s Go to Roost
description: ON a golf-cart tour along palm-lined avenues, Joanne Williams was explaining the amenities of the neighborhood, a gated community that she manages for its owners. ''We have seven lakes, waterfalls and four pools,'' she said. ''I have a full-time masseuse, hairdresser and spa health director who does personal training. We have local pros who come and provide golf or tennis lessons.''

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Translation, Please, Laddie

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: FLOODWATER THREATENS MARQUETTE Two dam breaks sent water surging down a river toward Marquette, the largest town in the state's Upper Peninsula, and more than 1,700 people were ordered to evacuate their homes. The deluge flooded a power plant, but no injuries were reported and no one was reported missing. Officials were trying to determine whether other dams would hold and telling evacuees they would not be able to return until Friday morning at the earliest. The trouble began when heavy rain on Wednesday washed out an earthen dam about 20 miles northeast of Marquette, which has about 20,000 people and is the home of Northern Michigan University. (AP)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Honor For Gay Church Founder
description: The Episcopal Divinity School of Cambridge will give an honorary degree to the Rev. Troy Perry, the gay founder of a predominantly homosexual church. The move has angered some members of the denomination. Episcopal bishops will decide this summer whether to recognize relationships between people of the same sex. Mr. Perry founded the predominantly homosexual church, Metropolitan Community Churches, in 1968. Bishop Steven Charleston, president of the seminary, said Mr. Perry was a ''figure of outstanding importance.'' The Rev. Dr. David L. Moyer, president of Forward in Faith, a conservative Episcopal group, said the invitation went against church doctrine. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: 2 Officials Fired by M.T.A. Say They Will Sue Agency
description: Saying they want their jobs back, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's fired security director and his deputy formally notified the agency yesterday that they were suing it for wrongful discharge.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of tax increases misstated the year the New York State Legislature last overrode a veto. It was this year, on a bill to extend the date for school districts to hold referendums on their budgets; 1982 was the date of the most recent previous override of individual budget items.

title: Spurs End Lakers' Dream Run
description: At the end of the third quarter, the sellout crowd of 18,997 rose to its feet and let out a roar that nearly shook the Staples Center. The hope was that its energy and support would reinvigorate the Los Angeles Lakers, transforming them from a wounded, overmatched group of fading champions into the indomitable force they had been for the previous three seasons.

title: New Advice on Travelers Stresses a Rational Caution
description: To counter what it called irrational behavior, the World Health Organization issued guidelines yesterday on how to handle travelers arriving from areas with cases of SARS infection, stressing that only people who have symptoms are contagious and can transmit the respiratory disease.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No More Free Nicotine Patches
description: Nearly a month after announcing the availability of free nicotine patches for any smoker interested in quitting, New York City's health commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, said yesterday that the department had run out of patches. At a City Hall budget hearing, Dr. Frieden said that 35,000 six-week patch kits had been given out, at a cost of $2.5 million in state and city funds. He said it was unlikely that further financing for the program would be available. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: A New Bronx View for Showalter
description: Buck Showalter had a pinstriped cot that he ordered from a catalog, like a giddy 10-year-old gearing up for summer sleepovers, and he stored it near the manager's office at Yankee Stadium. Showalter crawled onto the pinstripes on the nights he figured he was better off sleeping there than driving home because the next game was a mere 11 hours away.

title: Gemstar's Loss Narrows in First Quarter
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International, the publisher of TV Guide magazine, said today that its first-quarter loss narrowed to $45.4 million as acquisition-related expenses declined. Revenue fell 13 percent.

description: To the Editor:

description: For $182.5 million, Arturo Moreno bought a baseball team yesterday. Why did he want to do that in these perilous times both for the economy and baseball?

title: Saudis Are Shaken as Jihad Erupts at Their Front Door
description: The mourners came pouring in to the wealthy Khozama neighborhood by the hundreds over the last three nights, the younger men kissing the deputy governor of Riyadh on the forehead as a Bedouin mark of respect, his peers bussing him on the cheeks. ''May God extend his condolences,'' they murmur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICCARDI, JOHN
description: RICCARDI-John. On May 14, 2003. Beloved husband of Regina. Loving brother of Frank, Anna, Mollie and Mary. Cherished brother-in-law of Dolores Storch, Grace, Rose and Brandy Silece, Frances Reder and Mary Spatola. Adored uncle of many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Guidetti Funeral Home, Inc. 33 Spring Street, NYC today 2-5 and 7-9PM. A Requiem Mass celebrated Saturday 11 AM St. Patrick's Old Cathedral.

title: Coach Guilty of Sexually Abusing Six Boys
description: A Long Island soccer coach was convicted yesterday of sexually abusing six of his players, all young boys, during team trips in 2001.

title: Joss Whedon
description: As the seven-year run of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" comes to a close, creator Joss Whedon shares his thoughts about redemption, the soul and other frivolous matters.

title: Nets' Mutombo Is Prepared To Bolster the Frontcourt
description: The Nets returned to practice today after two days off and at least three days away from playing Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: WACHOVIA SAYS CARD SETTLEMENT WILL REDUCE ITS PROFITS
description: The chief executive of Wachovia said yesterday that the settlement between Visa USA, MasterCard International and retailers over the use of debit cards would cut its profit this year by $25 million to $30 million. Wachovia, the fifth-biggest bank in the nation, may also have a $60 million decline in profit in 2004 because of changes associated with the deal, the executive, G. Kennedy Thompson, said. The agreement between the bank-owned credit card associations and merchants is likely to decrease the fees banks get from debit card transactions. Wachovia earned $1 billion in the first quarter.

title: Texas Legislative Dispute Goes National
description: The Bush administration said today that the Department of Homeland Security had inadvertently become enmeshed in a partisan dispute in the Texas Statehouse this week when the department agreed to try to track down a private plane owned by a leading Democratic state legislator.

title: Air-Purifying Devices Near Nascar Approval
description: Nascar is close to approving an air-purifying system for racecars to reduce the carbon-monoxide fumes to which drivers are exposed.

title: Man Arrested In the Killing Of a Teenager In Newark
description: The Newark police arrested a 29-year-old man today in the stabbing death early Sunday morning of a 15-year-old girl who, along with four friends, had rebuffed his advances and struggled with him at a bus stop.

title: Otto Edelmann, 86, Bass-Baritone Who Appeared Often at the Met
description: Otto Edelmann, a leading Austrian bass-baritone of the postwar period particularly known for his interpretations of Wagner and Strauss roles, died on Wednesday in Vienna, where he lived. He was 86.

title: An Uprising in Albany
description: In its most extensive rebellion in over two decades, New York's usually docile State Legislature replaced Gov. George Pataki's skinflint of a state budget with its own. It was a heady moment for legislators and a humiliating defeat for Mr. Pataki. In fact there were 119 separate defeats as members in the Democratically controlled Assembly and then in the Republican-led Senate voted to override his vetoes of their $92.8 billion budget package.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted in Circuits yesterday for a picture of Dave Walker, author of what he calls the Web's most boring journal. It was by Jonathan Player for The New York Times.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Allows Muslim Women To Cover Head
description: An appeals court ruled that Muslim women could wear head scarves in photographs for internal passports that Russian citizens are required to carry. The court's ruling -- on an appeal by 10 women from Tatarstan, an autonomous, predominately Muslim republic east of Moscow -- overturned a ban on wearing head scarves first imposed by the Interior Ministry in 1997 and upheld by lower court rulings last fall and earlier this year. President Vladimir V. Putin had publicly supported a ban, but it was not immediately clear whether officials within his government would appeal the ruling to Russia's highest court, the Constitutional Court. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Ex-Top Cop Gets Iraq Post
description: Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, has agreed to become a senior policy adviser in Iraq's reorganized Interior Ministry, Pentagon officials said today.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Japanese cuisine may seem timeless, but it changes all the time. Sushi, for example, did not come along until the 19th century. More recently, chefs like Nobu Matsuhisa, of Nobu, have put a global spin on traditional Japanese dishes, opening the way for a new generation of Japanese chefs to experiment, sometimes wildly, with their native cuisine.

title: Congressman Seeks Review Of U.S. Effort To Aid Iraq
description: The chairman of the House International Relations Committee said today that he would ask the General Accounting Office to conduct a detailed review of the American-led reconstruction of Iraq, saying that a ''lack of transparency'' had made Congressional oversight difficult.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 6 about the Bush administration's plans to spend $15 billion on programs to fight AIDS -- and the possibility of conflicts with a rule barring foreign aid to groups that promote abortions -- misidentified the official who traveled to Mexico City in 1984 to announce that rule. (The error also occurred in articles on April 29 and 30.) The official was James L. Buckley, chief United States delegate at a United Nations conference; President Ronald Reagan did not attend. A reader recently reported the error.

title: U.S. Pushes for Rights Commissioner to Become U.N. Representative to Iraq
description: The Bush administration is pushing Srgio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, to be the United Nations representative in Iraq, saying such an appointment could broaden the organization's role in the faltering reconstruction effort, senior administration officials and Security Council diplomats said today.

title: June Carter Cash, a Fixture In Country Music, Dies at 73
description: June Carter Cash, a singer, songwriter and actress and the wife and collaborator of Johnny Cash, died yesterday in Nashville. She was 73.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: QUALCOMM FACES CHALLENGE ON CHIPS Texas In- struments Inc., STMicroelectronics and Nokia have agreed to design mobile telephone semiconductors that will challenge Qualcomm Inc.'s dominance in sales of the industry-standard chips it created. The companies are collaborating on chips using code-division multiple access technology and will begin sales in the third quarter, they said yesterday. Qualcomm developed the technology and gets a royalty payment on every phone using it. Texas Instruments , the world's biggest maker of chips for mobile phones, has an agreement with Qualcomm to use the technology without paying fees. Qualcomm shares fell 61 cents, or about 2 percent, to $30.23. Shares of Texas Instruments rose 18 cents, to $19.60.   (Bloomberg News)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: One Separatist Is Released, One Is Barred
description: In reciprocal signs of good will between India and Pakistan, the government of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir released Mukhtar Ahmad Sofi, a separatist who had been held for 20 days. In Pakistan, the government indefinitely banned from the Kashmir border area Maulan Masood Azhar, a leader of the Jaish-e-Muhammad, one of several Pakistani groups that has tried to force India out of the disputed area. James Brooke (NYT)

title: War, SARS and Deflation Leave Japan Economy Flat
description: Japan's economy stalled in the first three months of the year after three consecutive quarterly expansions as concerns about the Iraq war and the SARS virus limited exports and dampened some consumer spending.

title: LEUCADIA OFFERS $365 MILLION FOR REST OF WILTEL
description: Leucadia National, whose businesses include insurance, banking, mining and telecommunications, said yesterday that it had offered to buy the part of WilTel Communications that it does not already own for $365.1 million. Shareholders of WilTel, an operator of fiber-optic networks, would get 0.3565 Leucadia share for each WilTel share, Leucadia said. The offer values WilTel shares at $13.78 each, 30 percent more than their closing price Wednesday. Leucadia owns about 47 percent of WilTel, which was known as Williams Communications before it emerged from bankruptcy protection in October. Leucadia acquired its current stake for $330 million. It said earlier this week that it might sell or liquidate its banking unit.

title: National Briefing | Health And Science: Warning Sought On Teflon
description: A consumer organization, the Environmental Working Group, says normal household cooking temperatures can cause nonstick coatings like Teflon to break down into toxic gases when a coated pan is left on the stove. The group is petitioning the Consumer Safety Products Commission to put warning labels on Teflon-coated cookware and heated appliances. Currently, such warnings are sometimes included in instructions and on covering, but they are not mandatory. DuPont, which manufactures the coating polytetrafluoroethylene under the brand Teflon, has long warned consumers that the coating does break down or burn, but says it does not occur at under 500 degrees. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Restless Koreans, Stifled at Home, Head Overseas
description: Jeong Seung Keun's apartment sits on a high floor of a recently built skyscraper, affording a fantastic view of the city. Modern art hangs on the walls. Fancy exercise equipment sits tucked away in a corner.

title: Want to Smoke? Go to Hamburg
description: I never thought I'd say this, but I'm thinking of leaving New York for a city that's free and tolerant and treats me like an adult. Berlin, maybe, or Barcelona, or even London, the city I left nearly 20 years ago.

title: As Artists Move In, Can a Gritty Town Adapt?
description: SO why did David A. Ross, the former director of the Whitney Museum and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, buy a second home in the scrappy river town of Beacon, N.Y., where the Main Street is still dotted with boarded-up storefronts and a quarter of an acre is considered a generous amount of property? Isn't Sag Harbor more his speed?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Guilty Plea In Sex Abuse Case
description: A Long Island man who impersonated a police officer pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of coercion and attempted sexual abuse, the Nassau County district attorney's office said. Prosecutors said that in April 2002 the man, Jamie Greenberg, 30, of Seaford, told a couple who were in a local park that he was an undercover police officer and would arrest them unless they had sex in front of him. They also said that in December, he sexually abused a 16-year-old girl while pretending to search her for drugs. He is expected to be sentenced in June to 6 months in jail and 10 years' probation and to be required to register as a sex offender. His attorney did not return a call seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Mexico Misses Growth Forecast
description: Mexico's gross domestic product grew 2.3 percent in the first quarter of the year over the same period in 2002, the Finance Ministry said today. But on a seasonally adjusted basis, the economy contracted 0.49 percent compared with the previous quarter.

title: Federal Help for Crumbling Schools
description: The No Child Left Behind education act was touted as a way to raise standards, improve teacher training and prevent America's schools from sliding further into mediocrity. But the Bush administration undermined the effort by failing to fully finance the new law at a time when the recession-ravaged states are laying off teachers, shortening the school year and cutting education budgets.

title: SARS Scare at J.F.K. Brings Fast Response From Doctors
description: On Wednesday afternoon, the van from Kennedy International Airport's medical center dropped off a passenger at a terminal, and a young man from Pakistan, spotting the medical emblem on the shuttle, walked up and tapped on its window.

title: France Seeks Union Allies Amid Strikes Over Pension Reform
description: Trying to end a spasm of labor unrest touched off by a proposed overhaul of the nation's public-employee pension system, the French government offered talks today seeking the support of those labor unions whose views on pension reform are most like its own.

title: Bushes' Assets Put at $8.8 Million in Filing
description: President Bush reported today that he and his family own stocks, bonds, real estate and other assets worth at least $8.8 million and that they kept thousands of dollars worth of gifts including eight tickets to a Rolling Stones concert for one of the president's twin daughters, Jenna Bush.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telephone Profit
description: The largest telephone company in Europe, Deutsche Telekom, increased sales in the first quarter and returned to profit after two years. The company surprised markets with a net profit of 850 million euros ($977 million), reversing a loss of 1.8 billion euros in the first quarter of 2002, and by reducing its 2002 year-end debt of 61.1 billion euros to 56.3 billion euros ($64.7 billion). The improved earnings were largely a result of proceeds from asset sales and tax gains. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Letting Hip-Hop Convey Humanity's Struggle
description: Rennie Harris upholds the great contemporary-dance tradition of eclecticism in ''Facing Mekka,'' which his company, Rennie Harris Puremovement, presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shipbuilder Posts Profit
description: Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's biggest manufacturer of merchant ships, reported a net profit of 81.4 billion won ($68 million) in the first quarter of this year, up 4.9 percent from the first quarter of 2002. Sales fell slightly. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: UNION ALTERNATIVES TO LAYOFFS Two dozen municipal union leaders met for nearly two hours yesterday with New York City's labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, to put forward some new proposals that they hoped would persuade Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to suspend 3,000 layoffs scheduled to take effect today. Mr. Bloomberg has asked the unions to agree to $600 million in labor savings if they want to avoid the layoffs. He has rejected proposals to encourage early retirements and to stretch out the city's pension payments, arguing that little money would be saved. One official involved in the talks said the unions presented some modifications of those proposals. Talks are to resume this morning.

title: G.M. OFFERS SIX-YEAR LOANS ON MOST OF ITS '03 MODELS
description: General Motors is offering six-year financing at 1.9 percent on most 2003 models, after saying earlier this year that it would limit its use of the longer loans. The new loan program, starting yesterday and ending June 2, covers most Chevrolet, GMC, Oldsmobile, Pontiac, Saturn and Saab cars and trucks, excluding the Chevrolet Corvette, a spokeswoman, Elaine Redd, said yesterday. G.M. said as recently as February that it would offer those loans only on entry-level vehicles like the Chevrolet Cavalier.

title: William D. Witter, 73, Investment Executive
description: William D. Witter, an investment executive who founded two firms named William D. Witter Inc., died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73. The cause of death was not announced.

description: Al Leiter did not take part in the brief reunions here this afternoon. Edgardo Alfonzo played against his former team and Art Howe was back in the Bay Area, where he made his name as a manager.

title: Keepers of Bush Image Lift Stagecraft to New Heights
description: George W. Bush's ''Top Gun'' landing on the deck of the carrier Abraham Lincoln will be remembered as one of the most audacious moments of presidential theater in American history. But it was only the latest example of how the Bush administration, going far beyond the foundations in stagecraft set by the Reagan White House, is using the powers of television and technology to promote a presidency like never before.

title: As Ethics Panel Raises Its Profile, Chairman Warns of Budget Cuts
description: Unlike, say, that of the Department of Sanitation, the work of the Conflicts of Interest Board goes largely unnoticed by most New Yorkers. The board members spend much of their time advising city employees on things like what to do when they marry someone with a stock portfolio full of companies doing business with the city, or whether it is acceptable to take a gift from a contractor (as a rule, no).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Asset Sale Planned
description: The Dutch paint and pharmaceuticals concern Akzo Nobel said it would sell 500 million euros ($575 million) worth of assets, primarily in its chemical division. Two weeks into his job as Akzo's chairman, the former Dutch minister of economics, Hans Wijers, left, said he would use the asset sale to free the company of financial burdens, including debt. A prime objective is to revive the pharmaceuticals operation, Organon, which has been hurt by the introductions of generic competitors as well as regulatory setbacks related to new drugs.

description: The governor and the State Legislature battled over the budget for most of the session, with the governor accusing lawmakers of spending beyond the state's means. The Legislature rejected such claims, and in a show of bipartisan unity, overrode his vetoes on spending bills.

description: By late yesterday morning, the most dedicated local stargazers had set up their parasols and folding chairs behind the steel barricades outside the bulky glass-and-concrete Palais des Festivals in anticipation of the evening's red-carpet promenade. And by dusk, when the chauffeured Mercedes-Benzes and giant Renaults began to disgorge their cargo of directors, movie stars, money men and trophy dates, a respectable throng had gathered, necks craning, to catch some flashbulb dazzle from the opening of the 56th Cannes International Film Festival.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Studios And DVD Copier Go To Court
description: Several major movie studios and a maker of software that allows people to copy DVD's argued in court yesterday in a widely watched case dealing with copyright protection in the digital age. The studios were seeking a summary judgment from Judge Susan Illston of Federal District Court in San Francisco to dismiss a case brought against them by 321 Studios, which makes and sells DVD X Copy and DVD Copy Plus software. Judge Illston heard arguments from lawyers, then adjourned to consider the case, according to officials on both sides. She did not indicate when she might issue a ruling, they said. In a pre-emptory lawsuit filed last year, 321 asked the judge to rule that its software did not violate the 1998 Digital Millennium Copyright Act. At stake in the case, the studios argue, are potentially billions of dollars in lost future revenues if people can make perfect digital copies of movies on DVD, then put the movies in digital files stored on the Internet to be distributed free around the world.

description: We in journalism tend to write about scoundrels, but today let me instead hail a saint for our age.

title: 3 European Economies Contract, Stirring a Fear of Wider Damage
description: Europe, which has struggled for more than a year to regain its economic footing, appears on the brink of tumbling back into recession -- with Germany, Italy and the Netherlands reporting today that their economies unexpectedly contracted in the first three months of the year.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Qualcomm Faces Challenge On Chips
description: Texas Instruments Inc., STMicroelectronics and Nokia have agreed to design mobile telephone semiconductors that will challenge the dominance of Qualcomm Inc. in sales of the industry-standard chips that it created. The companies are collaborating on chips using code division multiple access technology and will begin sales in the third quarter, they said yesterday. Qualcomm developed the technology and gets a royalty payment on every phone using it. Texas Instruments, the world's biggest maker of chips for mobile phones, has an agreement with Qualcomm to use the technology without paying fees. Qualcomm shares fell 61 cents, or about 2 percent, to $30.23. Shares of Texas Instruments rose 18 cents, to $19.60.

title: Sophomore Wins 2 Races in Queens
description: Jeavon Benjamin, a sophomore at Far Rockaway, won the 200-meter dash in 25.2 seconds and the 400 in 58.0 seconds yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Queens Borough girls championships at August Martin High School.

title: France Says It Was Victim of Lies Fed by White House
description: French officials today took the highly unusual step of complaining formally that their country was the victim of a campaign of ''repeated disinformation'' they say is being fed by Bush administration officials, accusing France of having provided military and diplomatic aid to Saddam Hussein's government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MANUEL
description: GORDON-Manuel. We note with sorrow the passing of our partner, mentor and friend. Our condolences to his daughter, Bonnie, and her family. We shall miss his guidance. Walter Kaye and Staff of Merchant Factors Corp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, GWENDOLYN
description: STRAUS-Gwendolyn, died May 14, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Straus, loving mother of Moshael (Zahava), Daniel (Joyce), Adina (Jeffrey) and Bethia (Paul), dear sister of Annette Renick, and the late Samson Goldstein and the late Judah Goldstein, proud grandmother of Elizabeth, Dori, Benjamin, Joshua, Sarah, Joseph, Samuel, Julia, Eliana, Joseph, David, Sarah and Rebecca. Ardent Zionist and tireless volunteer. She will be greatly missed by all who had the good fortune to know her.

title: INSIDE
description: China Takes SARS Measures

title: With Everything but Hippos in Tutus
description: Some of us grew up on Winnie-the-Pooh, but not Peter Rabbit. Before ''The Nutcracker,'' a child's introduction to ballet often came through ''Peter and the Wolf''; American Ballet Theater kept Adolph Bolm's 1940 version, one of the best, in its repertory for years.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Seeing Kandahar in Taliban Days
description: As always, New Yorker Video is filling its niche with interesting releases. Last month there was Jean Vigo's film "L'Atalante" (1934). "May be the greatest film of all time," reads a critic's assessment on the front of the DVD.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: ACEH TALKS LIKELY The government said that talks over ending a decades-long separatist war in Aceh Province were likely to resume this weekend but that the government was still preparing for one of its biggest assaults in a generation. Separatist rebels said they would attend the talks in Japan, less than 12 hours after the government gave them a two-day reprieve to salvage a peace pact that promised to end the conflict. ( Reuters )

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOULTON, ANTHONY K.
description: MOULTON-Anthony K., 59, of Manhattan, died on May 14th, 2003 after a short illness. Survived by his wife, Arden, children, Anthony K. Moulton, Jr. and Tracey M. Moulton, brothers, Allan R. Moulton III, Ambrose K. Monell, Edmund Monell, and sister, Mary Masri. Service St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., May 19th, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Down Syndrome Soc, 666 B'way NYC.

title: Slicing and Dicing: Tired Senators Achieve Goal, to Pass a Tax Bill, Any Tax Bill
description: When the Senate began to talk last month about cutting taxes, the goals set out by Republicans were clear and high-minded: End the double taxation on dividends Republicans said they were seeking. Create jobs through business investment. Reduce the tax burden on two-income families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOECKNER, CONSTANCE HALL
description: GLOECKNER - Constance Hall, 87, longtime past resident of West Cornwall, CT, died peacefully Saturday May 3, 2003 in West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved aunt of William Hall Brinckerhoff of Palm Beach, FL and of Sidney Burr Brinckerhoff of Bellevue, WA. who survive her. Beloved daughter of the late William Edwin Hall of Greenwich, CT. and Palm Beach, President of the Boys Clubs of America, and of the late Marguerite Wood Hall. Born November 17, 1915 in New York City, Mrs. Gloeckner graduated from Miss Porter's School, Farmington, CT in 1934. She then eschewed college education to pursue a theatrical career in Europe and the United States. This was followed by a 30 year marriage to the late Michiel R. Gloeckner of West Cornwall, a noted painter of abstract art. Funeral services will be held at 1PM Thursday May 29th at United Church of Christ, Congregational, Cornwall, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent in support of Mrs. Gloeckner's life long love of animals, to The Little Guild of St. Francis, West Cornwall, CT. 06796.

title: Queens Ponders Post-Modern Life; Will Newfound Cachet Leave When the Museum Does?
description: It breezed into the neighborhood like a Hollywood film crew. Its big-name stars drew crowds of the curious, creating lucrative opportunities for the resourceful.

description: Gary Snyder Fine Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ANN
description: LEVY-Ann, 85, of Scarsdale, NY. Beloved wife & mother. Widow of Ernest, mother of John of Putnam Valley, NY. Born in Berlin. Ann was an adventurous world traveler with a keen wit and strong intellect. She was an accomplished bridge player, an athlete and an avid golfer. Funeral 12 noon Friday (today) Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY (Saw Mill Exit 17). Memorials to Cancer Society or Hadassah.

title: When Astronauts Were in Peril
description: The panel investigating the disintegration of the space shuttle Columbia turned an important corner this week, ending a honeymoon period in which it had limited itself to mostly circumspect comments about the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. In stern and challenging testimony before the Senate Commerce Committee, Harold Gehman Jr., the retired admiral who is the panel's chairman, indicated that a lot more than the shuttle fleet needs fixing. The flaws unearthed by his investigations board are embedded deep in the culture and habits of the space agency itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ETTA LOUISE
description: GOLDMAN-Etta Louise, 80, died Saturday, (May 10, 2003). A 50-year New York City resident, she was a retired designer of fine women's clothing, a supporter of animal shelters and the arts, and a Board member of the Hudson Guild. She leaves her nephews Robert Goldman, and his wife Amy, of Aurora, IL; David Goldman, and his fiance Cheryl McGrath, of Spokane, WA; and Stuart Lavine, and his wife Brenda, of Coventry, CT; her cousins Gladys Schreiber of Queens, NY, and Bud Bunim of Cranberry, NJ, four great nieces and many dear friends. Interment will take place at Sharon Memorial Park, 120 Canton Street, Sharon, MA. on Sunday, May 25 at 11:45 A.M. A memorial service will be held at the Hudson Guild, 441 West 26th St, New York City, on Sunday, June 1 at 2:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Hudson Guild.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Alternatives To Layoffs
description: Two dozen municipal union leaders met for nearly two hours yesterday with New York City's labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, to put forward some new proposals that they hoped would persuade Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to suspend 3,000 layoffs scheduled to take effect today. Mr. Bloomberg has asked the unions to agree to $600 million in labor savings if they want to avoid the layoffs. He has rejected proposals to encourage early retirements and to stretch out the city's pension payments, arguing that little money would be saved. One official involved in the talks said the unions presented some modifications of those proposals. Talks are to resume this morning. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: First Biotech Drug To Treat Asthma Clears Key Panel
description: An advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration yesterday endorsed Genentech's new asthma drug, the first biotechnology product for the disease.

title: A New Museum As Unconventional As Its Collection
description: THE opening of Dia:Beacon on Sunday changes the landscape for art in America. ''Have you seen it?'' people in art circles have been asking each other for months. Now you can.

title: Mass Graves, Pointed Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Museum, Smith Puts Its Best Forward
description: The ribbon has been cut, the galas have been held and no less than seven exhibitions are open for viewing. After a two-year shutdown for its $35 million makeover, the art museum at Smith College here is up and running again, renamed the Brown Fine Arts Center for three Smith alumnae from the Brown family of Houston, who donated $10 million.

title: 'Cinemania'
description: Directed by Angela Christlieb

title: Ending Streak, Jeter and Yanks Get on Track
description: Derek Jeter gave himself a one-clap round of applause when he arrived at second base in the third inning last night. He had driven in his first run of the season with his second double of the game.

title: A Tale of 2 Carmakers and 2 Countries
description: To the casual observer, the sprawling BMW car plant outside this quaint university town appears to be much like the main plant of the Fiat group outside Turin, Italy. At each factory, shiny new cars roll leisurely along assembly lines dominated by giant twisting robots and automated welders that spray sparks like New Year's fireworks.

title: If You Want to Lead the Fed In New York, Raise Your Hand
description: Does anyone want to be president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York? Only a month before the planned departure of the current president, William J. McDonough, several top candidates for the job have apparently pulled out of the running.

title: 2 Airlines Reach Marketing Accord
description: US Airways and Lufthansa, the German airline, said yesterday that they had reached an agreement to form a marketing partnership. The partnership, known as a code-share alliance, will allow the airlines to book passengers on each other's flights.

title: 36 Hours | Santa Catalina Island, Calif.
description: SOME people go to Santa Catalina Island, 22 miles off the coast of Southern California, to see the buffalo, imported for the filming of an obscure 1925 movie, ''The Vanishing American,'' and long ago gone wild. But the abundant native wildlife is even more of a draw. Dolphins may swim up to meet your boat and sea lions sun themselves on the rocky coast. On the island itself, just an hour's ferry ride from Long Beach, you will find a decidedly Mediterranean flavor. The view from the boat as you approach Catalina is of a busy, energetic harbor lined with small vessels. The arid rugged interior is peppered with fragrant trees and flowers. The 3,700 year-round residents in the charming port town of Avalon, the only sizable settlement on the 76-square-mile island, are proud of its shops, beaches and year-round temperate climate. Get to the ferry terminal early and jockey for a spot on the boat or you might be left behind.
