description: Directed by Aviva Slesin

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Tuesday about bombings in Saudi Arabia misstated the theory of American investigators about the 1996 bombing of the Khobar Towers apartment block in Dhahran, which killed 19 members of the American military. (The error was repeated in an article on Wednesday.) United States officials have publicly stated that the attack was carried out by members of a pro-Iranian group known as Saudi Hezbollah. The United States government has also made those charges in federal court. The attack is not believed to have been the work of Al Qaeda.

title: On a Moonlit Tank Charge Into a Gaza Powder Keg
description: Under a brilliant full moon, the Israeli Army commander took a final drag on his cigarette, then wriggled into a cramped armored personnel carrier and ordered his men on a nighttime charge into one of the Gaza Strip's most combustible neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures with two reports in the World Briefing column were interchanged in some copies yesterday. Tung Chee Hwa, chief executive of Hong Kong's Legislative Council, was shown with glasses; Alfredo Scappaticci, the Irish Republican Army veteran accused of being a British informer, wore a checked jacket.

title: Euro-Youths Enjoy a Pajama Party
description: Much of the action in ''L'Auberge Espagnole'' takes place in a communal flat in Barcelona populated by a mix-and-match assortment of attractive young Europeans. The film's digital video look, its jumpy editing and its focus on matters of household politics -- dividing up space in the refrigerator, managing sexual tension and differences of temperament -- make it resemble a season of ''The Real World Catalonia'' telescoped into two hours.

title: U.S. Agents Arrive to Join Saudi Bombing Investigation
description: As a team of American investigators landed here, United States officials said today that warnings to foreigners to leave Saudi Arabia were based on intelligence suggesting that Monday night's bombing attacks could be the first in a series of such assaults in this country and the region.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: SIX CUBAN MIGRANTS PICKED UP AT SEA The Coast Guard stopped six illegal Cuban migrants who tried to enter the Florida Keys on a small boat, plucking all six from the sea, two after they had been in the water for more than two hours, the authorities said. The six were taken aboard a Coast Guard boat off Tavernier, about 75 miles south of Miami, Petty Officer Anastasia Burns said. After receiving medical treatment, they will be questioned by the Border Patrol to decide whether to send them back to Cuba or bring them ashore. Cubans who reach American soil are generally permitted to stay, while those caught at sea are sent back. (AP)

title: House Is Undecided on Vote To Extend Ban on Assault Guns
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said today that House leaders had not decided whether to allow a vote on extending a ban on assault weapons that is scheduled to expire next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEAK, ROBERT
description: PEAK-Robert. 48. Died suddenly on May 13, 2003, of acute arrhythmia. Loving father of Charlotte, who was the center of his life. Devoted husband of Marianna Koval. Beloved son of George and Adele Peak, cherished brother of Audrey Barrow, Catherine Bendert, William Peak and Carol McIntyre. An active member of St. Boniface Catholic Church in Brooklyn, Robert was a respected and admired litigator with the law firm Reboul, MacMurray, Hewitt, and Maynard, which recently joined with Ropes and Gray. A man who gave generously and constantly of himself to his family, his friends, his community, and his church, Bob will be hugely missed. His loss will be marked with a wake today (Friday) 4pm-8pm at St. Boniface Church, 190 Duffield Street between Willoughby and Myrtle Streets in Downtown Brooklyn. A funeral service will be held at St. Boniface Church Saturday, May 17, at noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Bob's memory may be made to the Robert Peak Turkana, Kenya Fund in care of the St. Boniface Church Office, 111 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201. Bob's life was marked immeasurably by his monthlong working visit to Turkana last August 2002. The fund will support the St. Boniface community's continued relationship with Turkana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, CELINE G.
description: MARCUS-Celine G. Died on May 15, 2003 at the age of 93. Funeral on Sunday, May 18, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at W. 91 St. Proud mother of Daniel, Ann and Dorothea. Beloved sister of Marion Epstein and Helen Joffe. Loving grandmother of Stephanie, Jonathan, Alexandra, Daniel and Ruby and six greatgrandchildren. A graduate of Barnard College, Celine Marcus was executive director of Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association for 23 years, until her retirement in 1982. A visionary community leader in Yorkville, she was a founder of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter and a long time member of Community Board No. 8. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, 157 E.86 St, NYC 10028 or Lenox Hill Neighborhood Assoc, 331 E.70 St, NYC 10021.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Godard's Grand Allusions, Full of Impish Esprit
description: ''I don't know if it's a comedy or a tragedy, but in any case it's a masterpiece.'' This is the opinion of Angela (Anna Karina), the Parisian stripper whose quicksilver changes of mood animate ''A Woman Is a Woman'' (''Une Femme Est une Femme'') from 1961, Jean-Luc Godard's whimsical celebration of romance, sentiment, musical comedy, color film, the city of Paris and the abundant charms of Ms. Karina herself, who at the time was also Madame Godard.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer's Profit Falls
description: The Dutch insurance and banking concern ING said that its first-quarter profit fell 85 percent, to 167 million euros ($192 million), after it was forced to take a 735 million euro ($845 million) charge to cover paper losses on its equity investments. Just a year ago, ING had first-quarter net income of 1.14 billion euros ($1.31 billion). Declining stock markets, rising defaults on corporate bonds and lower interest rates contributed to ING's portfolio problems. Insurers like ING use investment gains to help pay policyholders. ING also reported weakness in its insurance business. Excluding the equity losses, insurance-related profit was down 13.4 percent, to 504 million euros ($579 million). Premium income fell 11.2 percent, to 12.6 billion euros ($14.5 billion), in part because of a weakening dollar. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Tyco Selects Agency To Help Repair Image
description: Tyco International in Hamilton, Bermuda, which is trying to help repair its battered image, yesterday named Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston to handle a communications project aimed at employees, with potential advertising assignments to come.

title: The Return
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 16 - There are two remarkable facts about Col. Martin Stanton. One is that he was in Iraq more than a decade ago. The second is how he got there.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Governor Says He Will Veto Budget
description: As expected, Democratic senators approved a two-year, $28 billion budget package yesterday, one day after the House of Representatives did so by a wide margin. And, also as expected, Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, promptly proclaimed his intention to veto it. The Democrats' budget would raise taxes by almost $700 million in the first year and roughly $780 million in the second year. Mr. Rowland's budget proposal places a far greater emphasis on reduced spending, and would increase taxes by about $150 million to $190 million. Democrats called their proposal realistic given the state's revenue shortfall; Mr. Rowland said the Democrats' budget would ''reverse all the good things we've done over the last eight years.'' Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Times Reporter Wins a Book Award
description: Keith Bradsher of The New York Times was awarded the New York Public Library Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism on Wednesday for his book, ''High and Mighty: S.U.V.'s -- The World's Most Dangerous Vehicles and How They Got That Way'' (Public Affairs).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 8 about the quarterly results of Electronic Data Systems misstated the company's forecast for cash flow. It called for a $100 million drop in 2003 because of a change in a Navy contract that increased the number of lower-priced workstations and delayed delivery -- not because the price was renegotiated. The company did not say negative cash flow would continue until mid-2004; E.D.S. is already generating positive cash flow.

title: U.S. Indicts 2 Men for Attack On American Ship in Yemen
description: Federal prosecutors announced the indictments of two Yemeni men today in connection with the bombing of the American destroyer Cole in 2000. But relatives of some of the 17 sailors killed in the attack said they were angered by the slow pace of the investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CYTRYN, JACK
description: CYTRYN-Jack. The Board of Directors of Friends of Israel Disabled Veterans notes with sorrow the passing of Jack Cytryn, former Board member and a great and benevolent friend. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Helen and daughters Janey and Joy. Michael Leichtling, Secretary Friends of Israel Disabled Veterans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, ALISON
description: FAY-Alison, May 12, 2003, Beloved wife of Richard. Loving mother of Lisa and Keith. Devoted daughter of Margaret MacBain and the late Gavin MacBain. Her compassion for love and life will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Tuesday, May 20, 9:30 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 Street, NY NY 10019-3984 or Trustees of Columbia University, C/O Department of Medicine, 630 West 168 St. PH8E-105, NY, NY 10032.

title: Nelson's Lawyers Give Their Count Of 'Time Served'
description: After Lemrick Nelson Jr. was convicted at his federal retrial on Tuesday of violating Yankel Rosenbaum's civil rights by stabbing him, a charge carrying a maximum 10-year sentence, his lawyers said that counting time served in previous related prison stints and good behavior, he could be out of jail in less than a year.

title: Mass Graves, Pointed Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Reintroduces Standards to Control Ozone and Smog and Encounters Criticism
description: After six years of intensive wrangling over tighter smog standards, the Environmental Protection Agency reintroduced proposals yesterday for new standards.

title: Transit Agency to Appeal Judge's Order to Roll Back Fares
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority filed papers yesterday saying that it would appeal a Manhattan judge's order to roll back transit and commuter rail fares, setting off an automatic stay of the ruling.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: ASSET SALE PLANNED The Dutch paint and pharmaceuticals concern Akzo Nobel said it would sell 500 million euros ($575 million) worth of assets, primarily in its chemical division. Two weeks into his job as Akzo's chairman, the former Dutch minister of economics, Hans Wijers, left, said he would use the asset sale to free the company of financial burdens, including debt. A prime objective is to revive the pharmaceuticals operation, Organon, which has been hurt by the introductions of generic competitors as well as regulatory setbacks related to new drugs.

title: Czech Republic Pays $355 Million to Media Concern
description: After having its last appeal dismissed in a Swedish court, the Czech Republic paid a $355 million arbitration award today to Central European Media Enterprises, a company founded by Ronald Lauder, the American cosmetics heir, for failing to protect the company when its Czech partner squeezed it out of Televize Nova, a Czech television station.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bank Robberies On The Rise
description: A persistent bank robber, thwarted from stealing from a Harlem bank yesterday by a teller who stalled for time, dashed to another bank nearby and made off with about $2,000 using the same hold-up note, the police said. The robbery of the second bank, a branch of Banco Popular on East 116th Street, was one of three bank robberies in New York City yesterday morning. At an HSBC bank in Queens, a man whom the police identified as Michael Harris, 35, of Astoria, told a teller that he had a bomb. He fled with $300 but was caught by police officers, and the bomb was discovered to be a fake. At least 181 bank robberies have been committed in the city this year, the police have said, about three times the number that occurred by April of last year. The mayor and the police commissioner have criticized some bank officials for lax security measures. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Official Puts Cost of Rebuilding World Trade Center Site at $10 Billion, but That Could Rise
description: Rebuilding the World Trade Center site will cost roughly $10 billion, with two-thirds of that paying for the office, cultural and transportation buildings envisioned in the architect Daniel Libeskind's design, a top rebuilding official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLLAGE, ARTHUR
description: KROLLAGE - Arthur. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Arthur Krollage, associated with The Times from March 1949 until retiring in June 1984.

title: Sluman Holds the Lead, But Not the Attention
description: While female golfers continued making news off the course, Jeff Sluman focused on making birdies today.

title: Bush Makes It Official: He Files Papers for '04 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  President Bush took a step today that was both totally unsurprising and quite important: he formally began his campaign for re-election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPLIN, FRANK
description: TAPLIN-Frank. The Institute for Advanced Study is profoundly grateful for the commitment of Frank E. Taplin Jr. to its mission of fostering advanced scholarship and postdoctoral education, and for his desire to be a part of the Institute community as our friend and Trustee for over thirty years. Frank's wide-ranging curiosity embraced science as well as the humanities, and he was fascinated by research advances at their very frontiers. A man who always led by example, Frank inspired support for the Institute's scholarly work and outreach programs, and provided art from his personal collection to grace our walls. An environmentalist who cared deeply for the Institute Woods and farm fields, Frank led the way to a partnership for the permanent preservation of almost 600 acres of Institute land. We were fortunate to have been counted among his friends, and deeply appreciate all that he did for the Institute, as well as his care and concern for each individual here. We will miss him greatly, and extend our deepest sympathy to Peggy and their family. Institute for Advanced Study

title: MEDI-HUT HIRES AUDITOR TO REVIEW FINANCIAL REPORTS
description: Medi-Hut, a maker of medical supplies whose headquarters were raided by federal agents in November, said yesterday that it had hired Eisner L.L.P. as its auditor to review past financial reports. Eisner will audit Medi-Hut's full-year reports for 2001 and 2002, first- and second-quarter filings for the last three years, and third-quarter results for 2002 and 2001, Medi-Hut said. The company reiterated to investors that they should not rely on those documents. Medi-Hut was delisted from Nasdaq in March. The company, based in Wall Township, N.J., fired Rosenberg Rich Baker Berman as its independent auditor. Medi-Hut delayed filing an annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission in April after the seizure of documents by the F.B.I. in November. The items were later returned.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Warden Claims Rights Violation
description: Lionel Lorquet, a deputy warden in the Department of Correction, has claimed in a lawsuit against the city that he had been a victim of retaliation for openly supporting the campaign of Mark Green for mayor in 2001, and for other political activity outside of work. The suit, filed in federal district court, also said that the department had a ''policy and practice'' of rewarding employees who supported Republican political candidates, and of punishing those who did not. Mr. Lorquet, of Queens, said he had not been promoted since 1998, while others less qualified had been. Claiming his First Amendment rights were violated, he seeks damages and a promotion to the position of warden. A department official said the lawsuit would be addressed ''through the legal process.'' Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Dame Wendy Hiller, English Film and Stage Star, Dies at 90
description: Dame Wendy Hiller, an English actress whose performances were celebrated for spirit and integrity and who became a major film personality despite only a relative handful of movie performances, died at her home west of London on Wednesday, her family said. She was 90.

title: A Svelte, 94-Foot Pet With Tummy Tucks
description: A beloved fixture of New York City is back in place, awesome as ever and even more resplendent. After an absence of more than two years, the great blue whale at the American Museum of Natural History has returned to its familiar setting, suspended over the completely renovated Hall of Ocean Life, and will go on public display tomorrow.

title: Hey Mayor: Where Are Sunny Days?
description: MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG went to Washington Square Park yesterday, one of five people getting honorary doctorates from New York University. The university holds its graduation ceremonies in the park. On the whole, the mayor found himself treated well there, something that cannot be said about every corner of the city.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: TRUCKERS STRIKE ENDS A truckers' strike that had paralyzed the port of Pusan for a week was settled, with the government agreeing to cut drivers' taxes, pay for some of their gasoline and reduce rates on toll roads. Members of the Korea Cargo Transport Workers Union unanimously approved the agreement. The government estimated losses incurred by the strike at $450 million. Pusan is in southeastern South Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Robert Stack, 84, Who Starred In Television's 'Untouchables'
description: Robert Stack, who won an Emmy and received an Oscar nomination in his 60-year career in films and television but was best remembered as the implacable, square-jawed Eliot Ness of the 1959 series ''The Untouchables,'' died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: American Troops Step Up Efforts to Curb Crime and in Iraqi Capital
description: United States military forces have embarked on their most aggressive police action yet in the Iraqi capital, seeking to arrest thousands of criminals who Saddam Hussein released, to jail looters for extended terms, and to run hundreds of night patrols to restore order.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer's Sales Fall
description: Sales at Safeway, the British supermarket chain, dropped sharply in the second half of the year, as merger speculation created an uncertain environment, the company said. Earnings per share for the year ended March 29 were 22.6 pence, versus 24.5 pence a year earlier, in part because sales growth fell from 2 percent in the first half of 2002 to 0.5 percent in the second half. Still, sales for the year over all were up 1.3 percent, to 9.5 billion ($15.4 billion) from a year ago. The company took a 20 million ($32 million) exceptional charge in the second half, for fees related to its possible merger. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Decimalization Under Attack on Wall St.
description: RARELY has a change on Wall Street been more important in making life better for retail investors than the change to decimal pricing in stocks. Now it is under attack.

title: The Devils Lose a Goal, But Brodeur Finds a Way
description: Except for the play of Martin Brodeur and the rest of the Devils, Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals would have been remembered for the goal that wasn't.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 6 about the Bush administration's plans to spend $15 billion on programs to fight AIDS -- and the possibility of conflicts with a rule barring foreign aid to groups that promote abortions -- misidentified the official who traveled to Mexico City in 1984 to announce that rule. (The error also occurred in articles on April 29 and 30.) The official was James L. Buckley, chief United States delegate at a United Nations conference; President Ronald Reagan did not attend. A reader recently reported the error.

title: VIVENDI UNIVERSAL SAYS FIRST-QUARTER REVENUE FELL 4%
description: Vivendi Universal, the media company, said yesterday that first-quarter revenue fell 4 percent, hurt by a weaker dollar and lower demand for recorded music. Revenue dropped to 6.23 billion euros ($7.15 billion) from 6.49 billion euros a year earlier, excluding assets sold in 2002, Vivendi said. Sales at Vivendi's Universal Music Group, the world's biggest record company, fell 19 percent. Vivendi, based in Paris, reiterated that it would make a profit this year, excluding exceptional items and good will. In 2002, the company posted a net loss of 23.3 billion euros, the biggest in French history, after writing down the value of assets, including the music unit.

title: Four Men Rape Deaf Woman In Brooklyn
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn woman, who is deaf and mute, was dragged to an empty apartment building in East New York on Wednesday afternoon and raped by four men, the police said yesterday.

title: STATE LEGISLATURE OVERRIDES PATAKI ON BUDGET VETOES
description: For the first time in two decades, New York's Legislature overrode a governor's vetoes of its spending plan today. The lawmakers revived a budget that increases state taxes to restore billions of dollars in spending on schools, hospitals, nursing homes and localities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROUTER, AGATHE (NEE KELIHER)
description: CROUTER-Agathe (nee Keliher). The Packer Collegiate Institute Board of Trustees, Alumni Board, faculty and staff mourn the loss of our long-time friend and esteemed alumna. A former Trustee and member of the class of 1954, Mrs. Crouter served as a tireless advocate for Packer. She made deep and lasting contributions to the school that will stand as a testament to her personal integrity and insistence upon academic excellence and moral standards. We shall miss our partner and caring friend. Cynthia Elliott Chair, Board of Trustees J. Geoffrey Pierson Head of School

title: Another Lesson for Life: Buy Lottery Tickets Alone
description: New Jersey has a new and nasty imbroglio on its hands over a multimillion-dollar lottery jackpot, replete with the same accusations of office-pool chicanery that swirled around a similar squabble a year ago.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means tickets were at the booth for last Friday night only.

title: Two-Wheel Drive Meets Four-Wheel Drive
description: JOEL BRAZY went to a bicycle show and bought a car. Michael Gerold went car shopping and walked out with a bicycle. They were captured, in different deals and separate parts of the country, by a marketing marriage that has been successful at enticing buyers. Great-looking bikes parked in auto showrooms help lure bike-loving customers, often the young, who can then be persuaded to buy cars. And if a customer came in to see the cars, a bike can be an added incentive to buy one.

title: Senate Adopts A Tax Cut Plan Of $350 Billion
description: The Senate Thursday night approved a sweeping tax cut bill that would reduce then suspend taxes on stock dividends before restoring them in 2007, adopting at least for now the central element of President Bush's tax plan.

title: Dell's Profits Increase 31% On Gains in Market Share
description: Dell Computer said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 31 percent, to $598 million, or 23 cents a share, meeting analysts' estimates and defying a prolonged slump in technology spending.

title: Joss Whedon
description: As the seven-year run of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" comes to a close, creator Joss Whedon answered readers' questions about redemption, the soul and other frivolous matters.

title: Taiwan Health Minister Quits Over His Handling of SARS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 16  Taiwan's health minister resigned today, saying he was ashamed at how quickly the SARS epidemic has grown here and that he should accept responsibility.

title: When Art Is Looted
description: To the Editor:

title: China Suspends Adoptions and Sets Edict to Fight Virus
description: Seeking new ways to show it is effectively combatting the SARS epidemic, China today temporarily suspended most foreign adoptions of Chinese babies and announced severe new penalties, including execution, for anyone knowingly spreading the disease.

title: Digging Up the Past in Iraq's Killing Fields
description: Balkis Hassun had spent an entire day looking through bags filled with rotting human remains when I met her. Her 14-year-old son, Ali, had disappeared one day in March 1991, after she had asked him to go to the river for water. Now, just as quickly as the hope had risen that she would finally discover his fate, she started confronting the reality that she would never find his body.

title: President Is Named at Infinity Broadcasting
description: The chief executive of Westwood One, the radio syndication company, will become president and chief operating officer of Infinity Broadcasting, the second-largest radio group in the nation, Infinity said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airlines Post Losses
description: Korea's two airlines both lost heavily in the first quarter. Korean Air, the nation's flagship carrier, said its results went from a net profit of 29 billion won ($24.3 million) in the first quarter of 2002 to a net loss of 180 billion won ($150.5 million) in the first quarter of this year. Asiana moved from a net profit of 23.7 billion won ($19.8 million) in the first quarter of 2002 to a net loss of 59.5 billion won ($49.8 million) in this year's first quarter. Officials at both airlines cited a rise in fuel costs and the outbreak severe acute respiratory syndrome. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Pictures with two reports in the World Briefing column were interchanged in some copies yesterday. Tung Chee Hwa, chief executive of Hong Kong's Legislative Council, was shown with glasses; Alfredo Scappaticci, the Irish Republican Army veteran accused of being a British informer, wore a checked jacket.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: STUDIOS AND DVD COPIER GO TO COURT Several major movie studios and a maker of software that allows people to copy DVD's argued in court yesterday in a widely watched case dealing with copyright protection in the digital age. The movie studios were seeking a summary judgment from Judge Susan Illston of Federal District Court in San Francisco to dismiss a case brought against them by 321 Studios, which makes and sells DVD X Copy and DVD Copy Plus software. Judge Illston heard arguments from lawyers, then adjourned to consider the case, according to officials on both sides. She did not indicate when she might issue a ruling, they said. In a pre-emptory lawsuit filed last year, 321 asked the judge to rule that its software does not violate the 1998 Digital Millennium Copyright Act. At stake in the case, the movie studios argue, are potentially billions of dollars in lost future revenues if people can make perfect, digital copies of movies on DVD, then put the movies in digital files stored on the Internet to be distributed around the world, free.

title: Richard Bosman
description: Elizabeth Harris Gallery

title: BRUNSWICK RESTATES EARNINGS TO REFLECT A RESERVE FUND
description: Brunswick, the maker of recreational products, said yesterday that it was restating first-quarter earnings because of a $25 million reserve for a possible settlement of a patent lawsuit. Net income for the quarter was restated to $3.8 million, or 4 cents a share, the company said. On April 24, Brunswick said net income was $19.8 million, or 22 cents a share. The company said its Life Fitness unit was in talks with Precor, a unit of the Amer Group, to settle a dispute over rights held by Precor relating to the design of an exercise machine known as a cross-trainer. Precor filed the lawsuit in January 2000, a Brunswick spokeswoman said.

title: Paths Of Glory
description: The central dogma of American politics right now is that George W. Bush, whatever his other failings, has been an effective leader in the fight against terrorism. But the more you know about the state of the world, the less you believe that dogma. The Iraq war, in particular, did nothing to make America safer -- in fact, it did the terrorists a favor.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Those people who say they want to make jihad against the United States or Israel, what they did is pointless. Jihad is not like this.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MARVIN, M.D.
description: STERN-Marvin, M.D. The NYU - Bellevue Psychiatric Society notes, with deepest regret, the death of one their founding members, Marvin Stern, M.D., on May 13th. Dr. Stern was Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry at the NYU School of Medicine and was associated with Bellevue Hospital for over 65 years. He was a distinguished educator and clinician who taught generations of psychiatrists, all of whom valued him as an esteemed and inspirational teacher. The members and officers of the Society extend their deepest sympathies to the bereaved family. Benjamin J. Sadock, M.D. President, NYU-Bellevue Psychiatric Society

title: Blair Says He'll Tell Nation in June About Policy on Euro
description: Sidestepping critics' demands to state its intentions on whether to adopt the euro, the British government said today that it would announce its plans next month and seemed to distance itself from news reports that Prime Minister Tony Blair had already given up the idea of a referendum on the contentious issue.

title: Tickets? Lifestyle Guru? All Set
description: WHEN Denise Rich was planning a recent trip to Aspen, she meticulously packed her essentials -- toiletries, ski gear, thermals, oh, and yoga instructor. That's right, yoga instructor. Ms. Rich, the songwriter and ex-wife of Marc Rich (the fugitive financier pardoned by Bill Clinton just before he left the presidency), takes her own personal guru when she hits the road.

description: Analyze That

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Auto Emission Tests Delayed
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection announced on Wednesday that it would delay the start of its new computerized auto emissions test until August because the system's software still had some techinical problems, and many privately owned garages requested more time to upgrade to the necessary software. The tests, originally scheduled to start on June 2, compile data from a car's computer to determine if the exhaust system is operating properly and meeting state health levels, Commissioner Bradley M. Campbell said in a statement. The tests are to start on Aug. 4.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the two first establishments cited by New York City for violations of its new ban on indoor smoking -- the Hotel Pierre and Seor Swanky's -- misstated the location of the offense cited at the Pierre. It occurred in the employee cafeteria, not in the Cafe Pierre restaurant.

title: With vastly differing needs to come up with hit shows, Fox and UPN introduce their schedules.
description: THE Fox network and UPN announced their new fall shows to advertisers yesterday, concluding a week of broadcast network presentations. But the day was about all the two networks had in common.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Man Drives Truck Into Government Building
description: A man in a truck loaded with 15 barrels of gasoline drove into the Ministry of Transport building in Taipei and detonated it, killing himself and setting off a fire that badly seared part of the building. The incident did not appear to be an act of terrorism, but the police had no immediate explanation. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALEY, JACK
description: PALEY-Jack. On May 13, 2003. Loving husband and best friend of Sylvia Schultz Paley for 65 years. Brother of Reba Windreich. Father of Anita and Howard Orlin, Kenneth and Jian Paley. Greatly admired and beloved grandfather of Jonathan and Mary Orlin, Liz Orlin and John Ifcher, and Janet Orlin. Greatgrandfather of Jonah Paley Ifcher. A graduate of NYU, a founder of District 65, Executive Officer of the Retail Wholesale and Department Store Union, an official of the AFL-CIO, trustee and founder of the District 65 Pension and Security Fund and long-time fighter for social justice. He worked to improve conditions and wages for the working person. His life made a difference.

description: Theater depends at least as much on revivals and adaptations as on new work. So do dance, classical music and jazz. Why? Because none of them are now at the center of the culture.

description: The head of European operations for Microsoft said today that money from a special fund intended to capture deals with governments and large institutions could be spread throughout Europe.

description: Directed by Baltasar Kormakur

title: Man in the News -- Nstor Carlos Kirchner; Argentina's Backwoods Leader-to-Be
description: Nstor Kirchner's friends admit that when he announced late last year that he would seek to become president of Argentina, he had no expectation of winning. As the governor of a remote and sparsely populated province in Patagonia -- ''the man nobody knows,'' in the words of one newsmagazine here -- he aimed merely to make himself known to the rest of the country and then try again in four years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Extortionist Wants A.T.M. Cards
description: An extortionist who has threatened to poison food in Czech hospitals and has left two vials of a cyanide solution in a Prague maternity ward to prove his intentions, said he wants the police to leave A.T.M. cards in 100,000 copies of a daily newspaper that is distributed free at Prague subway stations, according to local press reports. The blackmailer said he would then ask the police for a PIN that would let him use the cards to withdraw a ransom. He is demanding more than $10 million. The country's top law enforcement official, Interior Minister Stanislav Gross, had said he was ready to negotiate, but the police now say that the A.T.M. plan is unworkable. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: 'Matrix' Sets Record, but With an Asterisk
description: Despite a consensus among critics that ''The Matrix Reloaded'' does not quite measure up to the original, the film sold $42.5 million worth of tickets in its first day, enough to qualify as the biggest opening day in movie history, and is clearly on its way to eye-popping grosses for its opening weekend.

title: God and George W. Bush
description: Is President Bush a religious zealot, or does he just pander to that crowd? That, crudely put, is probably the most persistent question I hear about Mr. Bush when I travel outside the country, and it comes up all the time in the less godly American precincts (universities, Bush-hater Web sites, Hollywood, the island of Manhattan). On issues from Saddam to sodomy, the assumption is that Mr. Bush is an evangelist for a moralistic agenda that grows from his born-again Christianity. Or else (the more cynical variation), regardless of what he believes in, he has handed over the presidential portfolio to the preacher pols of the religious right in exchange for their influence as campaign ward heelers.

description: Because of a production error, the National League baseball scoreboard page yesterday carried incorrect box scores, standings and text in some copies for Thursday's games. Correct box scores and standings are online at nytimes.com/sports.

description: It was the classic rotten-egg odor of natural gas, the kind that seeps into the kitchen when the knob on a gas stove is turned halfway. Except that this smell seemed to be everywhere.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ad Agency's Profit Slips
description: Japan's largest advertising agency, Dentsu Inc., said yesterday that it earned 23 billion yen ($198 million) in the year ended March 31, a decline of 16 percent from the year before. The profit was 21 percent below the company's November forecast. The company also said sales fell 5.4 percent last year. Dentsu said it expected profits to slip another 3.9 percent this fiscal year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Suicide Bombs Kill at Least 14 In Casablanca
description: At least 14 people were killed in several explosions tonight in Casablanca, Morocco, as attackers used car bombs and detonated another device to strike Jewish, Spanish and Belgian targets, according to Morocco's state news agency.

title: Sampras Isn't Competing, But Isn't Retiring, Either
description: Pete Sampras's decision this week to withdraw from the French Open and Wimbledon may signal the end of the most remarkable tennis career in the last 30 years.

description: It is called the Tour d'Afrique and, like the Tour de France, it is a grueling, multiple-stage bicycle race.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Posts Loss
description: The insurance company Allianz reported a net loss of 520 million euros ($603 million) for the first quarter, hurt by a decline in the value of its investments and a poor performance by its banking unit. The loss was more than investors had expected. A year earlier, Allianz reported a profit of 1.9 billion euros. The company said it deducted 800 million euros from its earnings to reflect the lower value of its investments. Its banking unit, Dresdner, posted a loss of 424 million euros. In its insurance business, premium income rose nearly 10 percent, to 25.1 billion euros. Allianz said it was still optimistic about an overall profit for the year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 3 about Ella King Torrey, a former president of the San Francisco Art Institute, misstated its fiscal situation in 1995, when she took the post. While the institute had often run a deficit, sometimes amounting to half its annual budget, it had begun to reduce deficits since the mid-1980's and to address many of its structural problems. It was not in financial or physical disarray.

title: Juror Explains Mixed Verdict On Crown Hts.
description: The jury forewoman in the Crown Heights federal retrial said yesterday that the jury cleared Lemrick Nelson Jr. of causing Yankel Rosenbaum's death not because of anything that came up at trial, but because jurors knew from old news accounts that Mr. Rosenbaum's family has a negligence lawsuit against the hospital where he died.

title: Saudis Triple Bomb Inquiry; Vow Joint Antiterror Effort
description: As many as 70 additional American law enforcement and intelligence officials left for Saudi Arabia tonight after the Saudi government approved tripling the size of the team investigating the terrorist bombings on Monday in Riyadh.

title: Forstmann Set To Deal Again
description: The billionaire investor Theodore J. Forstmann, who has not bought a company in almost two years, said Thursday that he was ready to get back to making deals.

title: Do You Know Where That Cartilage Came From?
description: Human tissue transplants are being used with increasing frequency to reconstruct injured or aging body parts. In the coming year, cartilage, tendon, bone and other tissues will be used in nearly one million procedures. They will be implanted in arthritic knees and inserted between vertebrae to stabilize the spine in cases of chronic low back pain.

title: Dowdy Image Overshadows Role of Pimlico
description: Lore has it that the name, Pimlico, comes from the English settlers who inhabited the 129 acres on which the racetrack was built. They were a nostalgic bunch and yearned for the famous landmark near London that they had left behind: Olde Ben Pimlico's Tavern. Since opening its doors in 1870, Pimlico Race Course has been visited by history in odd and significant ways.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after Royal Dutch/Shell said shipments from Nigeria would be disrupted because of political unrest. In New York, crude oil for June delivery rose 40 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $29.14 a barrel

title: Officer Is Suspended After Arrest on Sex Charge
description: A New York City police officer was arrested yesterday on a charge of sexually assaulting a woman at a Washington hotel during an annual three-day national police memorial observance, the authorities said.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Stake In Gas Project
description: China's top offshore oil producer, CNOOC Ltd., said yesterday that it would pay $348 million for a 5.3 percent stake in the North West Shelf project, Australia's largest oil and gas venture, to meet growing gas demand in China. The project, led by Woodside Petroleum Ltd., beat rivals in Qatar and Indonesia last year to supply about 3.3 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas a year for 25 years to China's first L.N.G. import terminal at Guangdong, in the nation's south.

title: Sports of The Times; Overcoming Barriers With His Sports Pen
description: I WAS driving to Boston last Friday for a Nets-Celtics playoff game when I heard the news that Sam Lacy had died. Sam was 99 years old, 5 months short of his 100th birthday, so I shouldn't have been surprised. But I was. There are people who live so long, become such institutions, that you think they have eternal lives.

title: Study Finds No Sign That Testing Deters Students' Drug Use
description: Drug testing in schools does not deter student drug use any more than doing no screening at all, the first large-scale national study on the subject has found.

title: Seton Hall's Ingram Wins Heptathlon
description: Bridgette Ingram of Seton Hall won just one of the seven events but her total of 5,223 points enabled her to repeat as heptathlon champion yesterday at the Eastern College Athletic Conference women's track and field championships at Princeton's Weaver Stadium.

description: The musicians were playing, the 2,000 guests were dining, the Hindu priest was preparing the ceremony and the bride was dressed in red, her hands and feet festively painted with henna.

title: Piazza Injures Groin In Mets' Latest Defeat
description: Mike Piazza left tonight's game after straining his right groin muscle in an unusual sequence while batting in the first inning. A team spokesman characterized the injury as substantial, and Piazza was expected to be placed on the disabled list after the game, probably dissolving any hope the Mets had of contending this season and moving them closer to disbanding the few remaining healthy players on the roster.

title: The Art in Budget Cutting
description: The depth of the city's fiscal crisis, with its $3.8 billion hole, means nothing is untouchable, no cuts unthinkable. Mayor Michael Bloomberg has tried to do the right thing by protecting the fundamentals: education, health, safety and sanitation. But even these are vulnerable. Among the thousands laid off over the next few months will be hundreds of teachers' aides and dozens of fire marshals. Nearly half of the city-supported children's health clinics will close. There will be fewer police officers enforcing quality-of-life laws. Trash collections in the outer boroughs will become less frequent, just in time for the hottest days of the year.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN SAYS IT IS TALKING TO SUITOR ABOUT SALE
description: The Elder-Beerman Stores Corporation, which owns department stores in eight states, is in talks with an unidentified suitor about a possible sale of the company. The shares rose 17 percent. A possible transaction will be discussed for a limited time, and there is no assurance an agreement will be reached, Elder-Beerman said. The retailer hired RBC Capital Markets as an adviser. An Elder-Beerman spokeswoman, Gloria Siegler, declined to identify the suitor or provide further details.

description: After months of behind-the-scenes maneuvers, some large shareholders of AOL Time Warner delivered an open rebuke today to Stephen M. Case, the former chairman, and two of his close associates by withholding votes in their re-election as directors at the company's annual meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, FRED A.
description: MEYER-Fred A. On May 16, 2003 at age 80. Beloved husband of Ruth L. Meyer and the late Ruth E. Meyer. Loving father of Clifford and loving stepfather to Jonathan and David Leason and father-in-law of Alle Hall, Anna and Wendy. Adoring grandfather to Jordan, Justin, Jessica, Melanie and Morgan Leason. Dear brother to Eric and the late John. Mr. Meyer served in the 10th Mountain Division and in Counterintelligence during World War II. He retired as an investment adviser. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Sunday, May 18th 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Mt. Neboh Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Judge Refuses to Stop Increase In Bridge and Tunnel Tolls
description: Toll increases of up to 50 cents on bridges and tunnels around the city operated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority can go into effect as planned tomorrow morning, a Manhattan judge ruled yesterday.

title: All the President's Image Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: A.C.C. Proposal Omits Virginia Tech
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference voted today to invite Miami, Syracuse and Boston College, but not Virginia Tech, into its league. The vote came a day before the Big East meetings were to begin here with the aim of keeping the three colleges in the conference.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Deal On Closing Budget Gap
description: Legislators reached an agreement that would plug a $2.7 billion budget gap without expanding the state's daily lottery. State Senator Darlene Fairley, a Democrat, said proposals to run the lottery several times a day fell flat. Working in a special session, both parties made concessions to complete the $23 billion two-year budget. Democrats abandoned a plan to raise $359 million with additional taxes on liquor, candy and tobacco, while Republicans agreed to delay a $115 million business tax exemption. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Anger At Broadcast
description: Spanish officials reacted angrily to a broadcast by the Basque public television station Euskal Irrati Telebista that showed three hooded members of the violent Basque separatist group E.T.A. In a video, the three men urged viewers to vote for recently outlawed separatist candidates in municipal elections scheduled for May 25. They also denied rumors of an E.T.A. cease-fire. The state prosecutor is to ask the channel for an explanation of its decision to show the video during a news program, while the deputy prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, said: ''This is not a question of broadcasting news. It's a question of a terrorist group carrying out propaganda on a publicly owned television channel.'' Emma Daly (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: America's Apparel Industry Is Latest Victim of SARS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROBERT S. JR.
description: MILLER-Robert S. Jr. Loving husband, father, brother, and friend passed away on May 14, 2003. He leaves behind him a legacy of courage, strength, and laughter and will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Bob Miller is survived by his wife, Barbara; daughters, Kara & Daniela, and sister, Elizabeth. Anyone wishing to contribute may donate to the American Lung Association at 432 Park Ave. So. 8th Fl, NY, NY 10016.

title: U.S. Officials See Signs of a Revived Al Qaeda
description: Leaders and operatives of Al Qaeda have reorganized bases of operations in at least a half-dozen locations, including Kenya, Sudan, Pakistan and Chechnya, senior counterterrorism officials said this week.

title: A Catalyst for the Knicks and the City
description: Dave DeBusschere, the basketball great who succumbed to a heart attack in Lower Manhattan this week, helped bring a championship glow to New York City at a time when it was most desperately needed. DeBusschere was the missing link whose acquisition turned a good New York Knicks basketball team into a great one in the early 70's. After DeBusschere joined the likes of Willis Reed, Walt Frazier and Bill Bradley, the Knicks were N.B.A. champions in 1970 and again, with a slightly different cast, in 1973. These are the only championships the Knicks have ever won.

title: AngloGold Seeks to Buy Ghana Company
description: Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana said today that it was in talks with AngloGold of South Africa about being acquired in a takeover that would make AngloGold the world's biggest gold producer.

title: Ruling Supports Parents' Rights To Decide on Child's Life Support
description: In a case that some medical ethicists and legislators say clarifies a murky and contested corner of state law, a judge issued a ruling this week that says no parent should have to ask a court's permission to take a child in a persistent vegetative state off life support, except in extraordinary circumstances like a conflict of interest.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 7 about Hadhrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, spiritual leader of the Ahmadiyya Muslim Movement, misstated or misinterpreted some of its principal tenets. The obituary also misstated the date of Hadhrat Mirza Tahir's death, his relationship to the man he succeeded and the estimated number of the movement's adherents. A corrective article appears today, on Page A14.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Backs Bush on AIDS

title: M.T.A. Chairman Blocked Inquiries, Assemblyman Says
description: The chairman of the state legislative panel that oversees the Metropolitan Transportation Authority accused its former chairman yesterday of political interference in the high-level workings of that agency.

title: US AIRWAYS RESTORES 2 TRANS-ATLANTIC ROUTES
description: US Airways said yesterday that it would resume flights between its hub in Pittsburgh and Gatwick Airport in London and Frankfurt Airport. The airline said it had suspended service between Pittsburgh and the two airports during the invasion of Iraq because the government had asked US Airways to provide planes for the Civil Reserve Air Fleet. That fleet, made up of planes from commercial airlines, was used to transport soldiers and equipment to and from the Middle East. US Airways said another airline agreed to provide service to the government so that it could resume its European flights. US Airways said it was adding one daily nonstop round-trip flight to each route. It said it suspended its Pittsburgh-London service on April 1 and its Pittsburgh-Frankfurt service one month later. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Hadhrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, Muslim Spiritual Leader,74
description: Hadhrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, spiritual leader of the Ahmadiyya Muslim Movement, a missionary movement that seeks to interpret Islamic doctrine in the light of the modern age, died on April 19 in London, where he had lived since fleeing Pakistan in 1984. He was 74.

title: Tax Cut Plan: A Boon for Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: You'll Have to Hold the Line, Mom, My Agent Is Calling
description: Once upon a time, students in graduate fiction writing programs dreamed of publishing stories in obscure Midwestern literary quarterlies with readerships that could all fit into a Volkswagen. Then, with a lot of hard work and a lot of luck, someday, maybe, they might have something published in Harper's or even The New Yorker. But today these students and their increasingly preprofessional programs have much grander ambitions, aiming for a published novel or a Hollywood contract.

title: Pirro's Law License Is Suspended for 3 Years
description: The husband of District Attorney Jeanine F. Pirro of Westchester, convicted of federal tax evasion three years ago, had his law career spared this week when a court ruled that his license to practice law would be suspended rather than revoked.

title: Sports of The Times; Rivals on Track Insist They're Friends Off It
description: It was a touchy-feely moment straight out of Oprah and Dr. Phil. There were D. Wayne Lukas and Bob Baffert -- Nos. 1 and 1A in your racing program -- professing their deep affection for each other.

title: Funny Cide Should Handle Wet Track
description: With Funny Cide having completed his final pre-race gallop this morning at Belmont Park, Barclay Tagg's work is all but done. The trainer of Funny Cide, Tagg has done everything he can to prepare the New York-bred gelding for a peak effort in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. The man on the spot now is the Pimlico Race Course superintendent, John Passero. It will be his responsibility to create a fast and fair track for Funny Cide and the rest of the field. His job may not be an easy one.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Economy Slows
description: Taiwan's economy grew at its slowest pace in a year in the first quarter, and the government cut its growth forecast for the year in response to the SARS epidemic, which is disrupting consumer spending, investment and trade. The economy grew 3.2 percent from a year earlier after expanding 4.2 percent in the fourth quarter, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said in a statement. The government cut its full-year growth forecast to 2.9 percent from 3.7 percent.

title: Traversing the Underworld in Toe Shoes
description: Peter Martins's ''Guide to Strange Places,'' a premiere for the New York City Ballet that is part of Lincoln Center's two-month celebration of the music of John Adams, is a jarringly turbulent piece, channeling its energy into shifts of clashing colors, both visual and emotive.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Every meeting, from umbrellas to pants, now turns into a discussion about SARS. The apparel world has been instantaneously changed.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Thursday about the first-quarter net loss at Hynix Semiconductor in South Korea misstated the dollar equivalent. It was about $870 million, not $87 billion.

title: Suicide Bombings Are Condemned in Saudi Mosques
description: As they arrived in the torrid heat at Abu Bakr Mosque for the first Friday Prayers since this week's bombings, most worshipers seemed to expect that today's sermon would condemn the attacks as contrary to Islamic tenets. They were not disappointed, or in disagreement.

title: Enabling Poor Women
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Agency to Review Its Role in Texas Hunt
description: The Department of Homeland Security said today that it would conduct an internal investigation to see if there was misuse of federal resources when the department helped Texas law enforcement agencies in a politically inspired search for the private plane of a prominent Democratic state legislator.

title: Religion Journal; A Heated Debate Flares in Unitarian Universalism
description: Humanism has been on the wane as an intellectual and political force in America for many years, as more people question whether reason and science are adequate portals into the mystery of life. But humanists alarmed by the rise of religion in American politics and culture have at least been able to turn to certain liberal domains for comfort and confirmation.

title: Kerry Introduces Health Plan, Pointing Up Divisions Among Democratic Contenders
description: The Democratic presidential contenders agree about what they predict will be a central issue next year, rebuilding a health care system that many Americans say is in turmoil.

title: Relying on Brodeur Has Served Devils Well
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 16  After breezing through the offensively challenged Boston Bruins and Tampa Bay Lightning, losing only two games, the Devils were supposed to face more of a challenge from the Ottawa Senators in the Eastern Conference finals. After all, the Senators finished the regular season with the best record in hockey and looked impressive in dispatching the Islanders in five games and the Philadelphia Flyers in six.

title: Among Kurds, Impatience and Anger Are Growing as Resettlement Tangle Drags On
description: Old and painful fault lines are beginning to open in the messy ethnic patchwork of Iraq's north.

title: All the President's Image Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ireland Bars Athletes From Nations With SARS
description: The government of Ireland has asked athletes from countries affected by severe acute respiratory syndrome not to travel to next month's Special Olympics World Summer Games there but has also said it will reconsider its decision as more information becomes available.

title: ROOTS TO PROVIDE OUTFITS
description: Roots, the Canadian apparel maker and retailer, announced yesterday at a news conference in Manhattan that it would provide the opening and closing ceremonies outfits for United State Olympic athletes in 2004, 2006 and 2008. Richard Sandomir

title: Iraqi Detainees Claim Abuse By British and U.S. Troops
description: Muhammad al-Tamimi wants the British soldier who he says kicked him in the ribs and hit him over the head with the butt of his gun to endure what he endured -- a long detention.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Credit Card Losses
description: The Financial Supervisory Service said yesterday that the country's nine credit card companies suffered a net loss of 1.3 trillion won ($1.1 billion) in the first quarter of this year, as opposed to a net profit of 661 billion won ($549 million) in the first quarter of 2002. Hardest hit were LG Card, part of the LG Group, Korea's second-largest conglomerate, which posted a net loss of 384.5 billion won, and Kookmin Card, an affiliate of the Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest financial institution, which lost 358.2 billion won. The government in April pieced together a rescue package of 15 trillion won to keep the credit card companies afloat. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: VENEZUELA: NO DOLLARS, NO PAGEANT For the first time in decades, the country that has won more major beauty pageants in recent years than any other will not be offering a candidate for Miss Universe. The Miss Venezuela Organization said that the country's strict foreign exchange controls, imposed this year, have made it unable to obtain the dollars to send a candidate to the June 3 pageant in Panama. The organization needed $80,000 for the franchise fee to send Mariangel Ruiz, above, 23, to the pageant. The organization has the money in the local currency but is not able exchange it for dollars. In January, the government imposed strict foreign exchange controls to stop panic dollar-buying and to protect its depleting international reserves amid a general strike. The controls have prevented most private businesses from obtaining dollars. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the country music singer and songwriter June Carter Cash yesterday misidentified the father of one of her children, Rozanna Cash. He was Rip Nix, her second husband, not Carl Smith, her first. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the recording of the song ''Jackson'' in 1967 by Ms. Cash and her third husband, Johnny Cash. While it did win a Grammy, it was not a No. 1 hit; the version of the song that became a hit on the Billboard top 40 chart was recorded by Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazlewood, also in 1967.

title: Fear No Longer a Factor With Lakers and O'Neal Gone
description: For the past three years, the N.B.A. finals have been a dud, with Shaquille O'Neal pulverizing and Kobe Bryant mesmerizing their Eastern Conference opponents with extraordinary ease. The suspense was nonexistent. There was no realistic chance of the Los Angeles Lakers being beaten.

title: A Ruling Makes E-Mail Evidence More Accessible
description: UBS Warburg was ordered this week to pay for the search and recovery of e-mail messages requested by a plaintiff, giving aggrieved investors a new legal tool to support their cases against investment banks.

title: Fiat Rating Cut Possible
description: Fiat may have its credit rating cut for the third time in less than 12 months as Moody's Investors Service reviews the company for a possible downgrading after Fiat posted a sixth straight quarterly loss.

title: Big Gamble For Pataki
description: Many legislators were declaring an unmitigated victory today, a day after they moved with striking swiftness to override each of Gov. George E. Pataki's 119 vetoes of the state budget. There was talk of a lame-duck governor, a robust Legislature and a new balance of power in the State Capitol.

title: Talks in Congress Dim Hopes for Speedy Tax Cut
description: President Bush is determined to get a tax bill enacted quickly that eliminates taxes on stock dividends, even if only briefly, administration officials said today.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: 150 HELD FOR OBSCENITY At least 150 men have been arrested in the northwestern town of Peshawar in an "anti-obscenity" drive by the fundamentalist provincial government, the police said. Since winning a majority in elections last year in North West Frontier Province, the Muttahida Majlis-e-Amal, an alliance of militant Islamic parties, has vowed to impose Islamic laws more strictly. A senior police officer said those arrested in the last three days included owners of shops selling audio and video cassettes and operators of transportation services who defied a ban on playing music in buses. ( Reuters )

title: Mass Grave in Iraq May Hold Kuwaitis Missing Since 1991
description: A map provided by a former driver for Iraqi military intelligence brought Abdulaziz al-Qubaisi Abu Musab to the abandoned Iraqi military camp here this morning in search of the answer to the question that most Kuwaitis have asked -- and dreaded -- since the end of the 1991 Persian Gulf war: where are the nearly 600 missing Kuwaitis?

title: Where Hip and Haute Are Intellectual Allies
description: New literary magazines don't typically generate much attention. But a new monthly called The Believer just might have the right pedigree to attract both the hip and the highbrow. The Believer (on the Internet at www.believermag.com) was created by Heidi Julavits, whose second novel, ''The Effect of Living Backwards'' (Putnam), is being published next month; Ed Park, a senior editor at The Village Voice; and Vendela Vida, whose first novel, ''And Now You Can Go'' (Knopf), is due in August. They met in the mid-90's in Columbia University's graduate program in creative writing. But the reason their magazine is an instant contender for buzz is its affiliation with a fourth person: Dave Eggers.

title: Top Palestinian Negotiator Offers to Quit on Eve of Talks
description: In a sign of the turmoil inside the governing Palestinian Authority, the Palestinians' chief negotiator has submitted his resignation just before the highest-level talks with Israel in more than two years.

title: For Some Adoptive Parents, SARS Brings a Heart-Rending Delay
description: Rebecca Sroge met her daughter for the first time on April 2, through a color photograph sent from China.

title: Billups Hits Sixers Late And Pistons March On
description: At the start of overtime, the Detroit Pistons had received their instructions, had learned their assignments and had prepared to return to the court with the swelling sound of 20,888 fans ringing in their ears. But Chauncey Billups had something else to say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, DONALD L.
description: HECHT-Donald L. Of Wellington, Florida (formerly of Upper Saddle River, N.J.) Beloved husband of Sorie. Devoted father of Frederick and Melissa. Services at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Sunday, 12:30 PM.

title: Rangers Slow Clemens's March Toward 300th Victory
description: The air was chilly and damp, the wind gusting, as Roger Clemens kicked at the Yankee Stadium mound before his warm-ups last night. Clemens seemed oblivious to the conditions -- he was the only person on the field not wearing long sleeves -- and he struck out the first two Texas Rangers. Victory No. 299 seemed inevitable.

title: Reaction to Remarks Does Not Deter Singh
description: This has been an eventful week for Vijay Singh. His comments about Annika Sorenstam have attracted controversy. But his game has vaulted him into contention.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITE, ROWENNA L.
description: WHITE-Rowenna L. Wight May 17, 1980-Sept 2, 1998 Remembered on her 23rd Birthday for her beauty, wit, exuberance. By her Mothe

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Acquisition Questioned
description: The commerce ministry said yesterday that it would ask prosecutors to investigate Sovereign Asset Management of Monaco and its affiliate, Crest Securities, which recently became the largest shareholder in the SK Corporation, Korea's largest oil refiner. The ministry wants to determine if Sovereign should be charged with violating a regulation requiring advance notice of any plan to buy more than 10 percent of the shares in a Korean company. Crest bought 14.99 percent of SK's shares on the open market earlier this year. A commerce ministry official said that Crest should have notified the ministry of its plans. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Payment Due to WorldCom Isn't Made
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, who borrowed more than $400 million from WorldCom before the company filed for bankruptcy, missed a payment on the loan, court documents show.

title: Ducks Reach Finals, Sweeping the Wild
description: Ten years ago, the Los Angeles Kings brought a jolt of hockey excitement to Southern California when they reached the Stanley Cup finals before losing to the Montreal Canadiens. That team was led by Wayne Gretzky, a crossover artist recognizable even outside the hockey community.

title: No More Mad Dashes To Get to the Intrepid
description: A newly built pedestrian bridge over the West Side Highway at 46th Street is set to open this month, providing the only unimpeded access to the Hudson River from Midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVITT, MELVIN
description: SAVITT - Melvin. Loving companion of Robin. Devoted father of Amy & Merideth. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Kara and Max. Beloved brother of Jack. Funeral services Sunday 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: United Insists It Is Acting On Financing
description: Amid criticism within the industry that United Airlines is dawdling on a restructuring plan, officials said this week that they had begun to look for lenders to provide financing for the company's eventual emergence from bankruptcy protection next spring.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Fire Destroys Fish Hatchery
description: A fire destroyed a salmon hatchery in Embden on Thursday night, killing millions of immature salmon. The fish suffocated after the fire started in a mechanical room containing pumps that pushed water and oxygen into 100 tanks that held the salmon. The hatchery is owned by Atlantic Seafood of Maine, a subsidiary of Fjord Seafood of Norway. The state fire marshal, John C. Dean, said inspectors are working to determine the cause of the fire. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday about the nomination of Kristin Forbes to serve on the Council of Economic Advisers misspelled the surname of the member she would succeed and misidentified the president who nominated him. He is Randall S. Kroszner, not Krozner -- an appointee of President Bush, not President Clinton.

title: Putin Tells Russians of Clouds With Reform-Plan Lining
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today outlined an unusually bleak vision of a country mired in poverty, strangled by bureaucracy and facing ominous threats from inside and out. Going into election season here, he offered, as an answer, an unusually ambitious platform of economic expansion, governmental reforms and military modernization, including the development of new nuclear weapons.

title: China's Help Is Credited In Tripping Up Drug Ring
description: More than 25 Chinese citizens who prosecutors say formed a huge international drug-smuggling ring were indicted yesterday in federal court in Manhattan, the result of what officials called an unprecedented level of cooperation between American and Chinese law enforcement agencies. One American was also arrested.

title: Mutating Virus: Hatred of Jews
description: At a conference on anti-Semitism at the Center for Jewish History earlier this week one panelist told a classic Jewish joke:

title: Militant Unions May Scuttle a French Pension Proposal
description: The French government won a skirmish, if not the war, with labor unions over its plans to overhaul public employee pensions when several unions, including France's largest, said they would accept a modified proposal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINNEGAN, LAWRENCE JR.
description: FINNEGAN - Lawrence Jr. Four years in heaven and you continue to watch over and protect me. Thank you for being my guardian angel. Love Always, Jackie

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: AHOLD REVISES RESULTS Fol- lowing word that its first-quarter sales this year had fallen 11.3 percent to 17.4 billion euros ($20.16 billion), the Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said yesterday that it was reducing its revenue figures for the last two years by 22 billion euros as part of a change in accounting methods. The revision involves joint ventures in Scandinavia, Portugal and South America. Ahold had in some instances booked all of the revenue from such companies even though it owned just part of them. Now, more in keeping with accounting standards in the United States, Ahold will book only its share of the revenue. Ahold said sales in its first quarter, which ended April 20, fell in large part because of unfavorable currency trends. Excluding currency fluctuations, sales were up 4.6 percent in the quarter.

title: Unheeded Alarms in Saudi Arabia
description: Among the casualties of this week's suicide bombings in Riyadh is Saudi Arabia's expensively promoted pretense that it is responding adequately to the challenge of radical Islamic terror. Images of a different, far more disturbing reality flashed across the world on Monday night. Despite repeated warnings from Washington of imminent terrorist attacks, security precautions at foreign compounds were grossly deficient. The Saudi royal family's endlessly debated efforts to defuse the political and social grievances that terrorists exploit are not moving forward with appropriate urgency.

description: The Michigan State Police are investigating accusations of criminal misconduct involving Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick and his security detail, the state police and federal prosecutors said today.

description: It was almost as if things had gone too well for Nick Johnson. His wrist and thumb injuries from spring training had disappeared, and he was having a fabulous season. Then he fouled a ball back on Wednesday, and everything changed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: No Deal In Chip Dispute
description: The ministry of commerce said that United States and South Korean officials had failed to reach an agreement in a dispute over the United States Commerce Department's decision to impose a 57 percent punitive tariff on imports of semiconductors produced by Hynix Semiconductor of Korea. Micron Technology, based in Boise, Idaho, charged that Hynix was subsidized by rescue plans put together by government-controlled Korean banks. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHSLER, JEROME, CPA, ESQ.
description: WECHSLER-Jerome, CPA, Esq. Loving husband of Margery. Beloved father of Leslie Gwenn. Endearing parent to Joanne, Stephan, and Corki. Cherished grandfather of Benjamin, Joshua, John and Sam. He became family to his friends and a wonderful friend to his family. Founder of Jerome Wechsler, Inc., he was always generous with his kindness, time, intellect, and advice. He will always be loved and cherished in our hearts. Services at noon, Monday, May 19, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York. 914-664-6800.

title: Meant Spade, Said Heart. The Rest, Alas, Is History.
description: Accidents are not uncommon at the bridge table, although the double accident that occurred on the diagramed deal is very rare. It happened during the U.J.A.-Federation Pro-Am charity game played on Tuesday at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street in Manhattan. There was no accident, however, in the organization by Marci Miron and an able team of volunteers. It was the 40th in a successful annual series and raised more than $85,000.

title: Court Orders Honeywell To Clean Up 34-Acre Site
description: A federal district judge in Newark ordered Honeywell International to clean up a 34-acre site along Jersey City's waterfront that was created more than 100 years ago as a dumping ground for chromium, a byproduct of manufacturing that has been found to cause cancer.

title: Funny Cide Wins Preakness Stakes
description: BALTIMORE, May 17  Eight hours before post time, the lobby of a hotel here on the waterfront was aglow with women clutching hats, men gripping cold beverages, and most of them wearing a swatch of silver and maroon on their lapels. Those are the colors of the 10-member partnership called Sackatoga Stable, and its entourage of 120 people was eager for Funny Cide to move a little closer to racing history.

title: 2nd Group of Trapped People Is Found in a Truck in Texas
description: Eighteen suspected illegal immigrants were found alive today in and near a sweltering tractor-trailer in southern Texas, a few miles from where 17 people from Mexico and Central America were found dead on Wednesday after being trapped in a similar trailer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBERMAN, DR. MARK M.
description: IMBERMAN-Dr. Mark M. On May 15, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Dr. Lilly Imberman. Dear father of Ingrid Einstein and father-in-law of Dr. Kenneth Einstein. Adored grandfather of Eric, Dr. Michael, and Evan. Dr. Imberman was a physician and faculty member at the Mount Sinai Medical Center for over 60 years and founded The Mark M. Imberman Student Health Center there. Service on Sunday, May 18th 12:45pm at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: As Hancock's Profit Declined, Chief's Pay Rose to $21 Million
description: For David F. D'Alessandro, the chief executive of John Hancock Financial Services, 2002 was a very good year.

title: G-8 Ministers Express Hope For an Economic Rebound
description: DEAUVILLE, France, May 17 — Struggling to brighten the global economic mood, the finance ministers of the major industrial countries and Russia agreed today that while their economies faced multiple challenges, they were confident that a revival of growth was possible.

title: Howe Keeps His Cool on the Hot Seat
description: The timing could be better, or worse. Art Howe, manager of the Mets, returned to the Bay Area this week after spending the previous seven seasons guiding Oakland. There, Howe went to the last three playoffs, riding the gifted arms of the Athletics' three aces. Now he has the security of a long-term contract, but that comes with growing scrutiny from the New York news media, the fans and even the players in his own clubhouse.

title: Italian Court Splits Trial of Berlusconi and Co-Defendants
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy will be tried separately from several co-defendants in a raptly monitored bribery trial, a change that should delay any verdict for Mr. Berlusconi until after Italy's turn in the European Union presidency.

title: Prosecutors Withdraw Request to Revoke Bail of Ex-Broker
description: Federal prosecutors withdrew a request yesterday to revoke the bail of a former stockbroker and federal informant who cooperated on a book about the Mafia's influence on Wall Street, according to the broker's lawyer.

title: Speed Defines a Dirt Racer's Life; King of the Rural Circuit Is Slowed by the Bumps and Injuries
description: As a wild 14-year-old, Bob McCreadie stole cars and hot rodded around Watertown, N.Y., his hometown. His joy-riding adventures eventually landed him in a juvenile detention center, where for a year he read auto magazines and tinkered with engines.

title: Latest SARS Victim Is Clothing Industry
description: In the heart of Manhattan's garment district, Denise White slides on a pair of white latex gloves and starts opening the brown cardboard boxes that Federal Express has just dropped off at her company, Bernardo Fashions. The shipment -- from China -- is a week late.

description: Stuyvesant scored in 17 of the 18 events, totaled 182 points and retained the team title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Manhattan Borough boys' championships at DeWitt Clinton's field in the Bronx.

description: JERUSALEM, May 17 - Less than two hours before the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers were scheduled to meet today, an explosion rocked the West Bank city of Hebron in what appeared to be a suicide bombing.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Ahold Revises Results
description: Following word that its first-quarter sales this year had fallen 11.3 percent to 17.4 billion euros ($20.16 billion), the Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said yesterday that it was reducing its revenue figures for the last two years by 22 billion euros as part of a change in accounting methods. description: For Winifred Gourdine, 2003 at least started out as a good year.

title: City Lays Off 2,000 as Talks Grow Bitter
description: The Bloomberg administration appeared to toughen its stance toward the municipal unions yesterday, ratcheting up the harshness of its criticisms and carrying out layoffs that the unions said should have been delayed while negotiations continued.
