description: Prosecutors filed misdemeanor battery charges today against 15 suburban teenagers for their involvement this month in a drunken touch football game that degenerated into a melee, injuring several participants.

title: Human Shield Returns, This Time on a Mission
description: There are at least two remarkable facts about Col. Martin Stanton. One is that he was in Iraq more than a decade ago. The second is how he got there -- and a third, perhaps, is that he came back.

title: Wendy Hiller, Spirited Actress, Dies at 90
description: Dame Wendy Hiller, the distinguished English stage and screen actress who was George Bernard Shaw's choice to play two of his most famous heroines, Eliza Doolittle and Major Barbara, died on Wednesday at her home in Beaconsfield, England. She was 90.

title: Draft on Sanctions Gets Mixed Reaction at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 16  Security Council members were polite but cautious today in their reactions to the latest draft of a resolution circulated by the United States to lift economic sanctions on Iraq and give broad powers to the Americans and British to run the country.

title: A Reunion With Old Boon Companions
description: A songwriter's former bands, like past loves, can seem much better through the mists of nostalgia. But Elvis Costello, Joe Jackson and now John Hiatt have lately found that old sidemen are just as good the second time around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUETZ, MONA WOLCOTT
description: SCHUETZ-Mona Wolcott, 82, of Middletown, NJ died May 15, 2003. Mona graduated from Elmira College and received her Master's degree as a dietician. She devoted much of her time to volunteer work in various charitable organizations and was President of the Family and Children's Service, Long Branch. She is survived by her husband, son, daughter, four grandchildren and a sister.

title: A Relationship That's Past Its Prime
description: Eleven years, eight months and nine days after a Hasidic Jew named Yankel Rosenbaum was stabbed on the streets of Brooklyn's Crown Heights, Lemrick Nelson Jr. confessed that he did it. He was woefully late in more ways than one. In its bloody moment in 1991, the killing seemed to symbolize all that had gone wrong in the special relationship between blacks and Jews. Now that a federal jury has found Mr. Nelson guilty of violating Mr. Rosenbaum's civil rights, it only reminds us how little that relationship matters anymore. One can feel satisfaction that justice was finally done in a hate crime without believing the crime stands for something larger.

description: JERUSALEM, May 17  As Israeli and Palestinian leaders prepared for their highest-level talks in more than two years, a Palestinian suicide bomber killed himself and an Israeli couple in the West Bank city of Hebron this evening.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Small Business section on May 6 about Olga Diaz, the owner of a beauty salon near ground zero, misstated the taxability of grants received by her and other small business owners after the Sept. 11 attacks. Those from state and local government agencies have been declared taxable. title: NEXT LEVEL AGREES TO SETTLE SUIT OVER MOTOROLA BID
description: Next Level Communications Inc. agreed to settle its lawsuit seeking to block the bid from Motorola Inc. for the remaining 26 percent of Next Level after Motorola raised its offer. Motorola raised its bid to about $34 million, or $1.18 a share in March. Motorola initially offered $30 million, or $1.04 a share. Officials for Next Level, which is based in Rohnert Park, Calif., argued that the original offer was too low. Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., already owns 74 percent of Next Level, which makes video networking equipment. Given the $4 million increase in Motorola's bid, lawyers for Next Level said that the settlement offer was ''fair, reasonable and adequate,'' according to court papers.

Republicans retaliated by dressing up in chicken outfits. Underlying these antics, however, was something serious: a Republican plan to redraw the state's Congressional districts that verged on lawlessness.

Imagine that after Willis Reed hobbled onto the court to take on Wilt Chamberlain and conquer the Los Angeles Lakers in 1970, he had Shaquille O'Neal in his prime waiting for him the next day. After Kirk Gibson limped to the plate for an improbable game-winning home run against Dennis Eckersley in the 1988 World Series, tell him to get back in there against Roger Clemens to try again.

In his first novel in 10 years, McGuane zeroes in again on characters responding with comically awful behavior to a hostile but also zany universe. This time his fecklessly nihilistic hero is out to cash in on his former father-in-law's infernal will by reuniting with his estranged ex-wife and managing the family business. With copious detours and one-liners, ''a lot of what happens in this novel is funny or deftly described, no matter how irrelevant or inconsequential,'' Paul Gray wrote in these pages in 2002.

title: Big Hot Blurry Painterly Nudes!
description: WHEN the German photographer Thomas Ruff started looking at Internet pornography about four years ago, it was for research purposes only. He was thinking about making a new series of photographs exploring the genre of the nude, and as he always does when he has a new idea, he began by studying existing images. Online, he first came upon pictures by fashion photographers like Helmut Newton and Peter Lindbergh, but these slickly produced, stylishly erotic nudes left him uninspired. So he continued to point and click, and before long he found his way to some porn sites, which led him to still more porn sites.

title: U2, Bob Dylan, Peter Gabriel and . . . Daniel Lanois?
description: THE rich, mournful sounds emanating from Daniel Lanois's suite at the Inter-Continental Hotel here on a sun-drenched March afternoon belonged to a classic American stringed instrument whose timbre can, depending on the moment, call up images of the Great Plains, Hawaii's balmy shores or the outer reaches of the Milky Way. Mr. Lanois, dressed in his customary uniform of black T-shirt, black jeans and black knit skullcap, was bent over a Sho-Bud pedal steel guitar hewn from a vibrantly green chunk of maple. While his right hand plucked the strings and his left hand expertly manipulated the sliding steel bar that sounds the notes and gives the pedal steel its distinctive twang, he gazed down at the instrument with an affectionate glimmer.

title: From Images to Words and Back

Her two memoirs, ''When I Was Puerto Rican'' (1993) and ''Almost a Woman'' (1998), chronicle her childhood in Puerto Rico, and her adolescence as an immigrant in Brooklyn. Her novel, ''Amrica's Dream'' (1996), tells the story of a young Puerto Rican woman, Amrica Gonzalez, who leaves an abusive relationship and a job as a hotel maid to go to work as a housekeeper for a family in Westchester. Though Ms. Santiago does not explicitly write for young readers, her books are frequently used in schools in Puerto Rico and the United States.

title: Where to Seek for Hides
description: Shoppers flipping through the racks of swimsuits may not realize that May and June are peak months to invest in shearling coats, as prices are at their lowest for the year. Come July 4, prices revert to full retail as stores prepare for the fall. The selection of coats on sale is not just made up of last season's leftovers; many are new. Where to find them? At Saks Fifth Avenue, all shearling coats from the company's 60 stores are shipped to the flagship store in New York and sold at a 20 percent discount (212-753-4000). Searle (212-717-5200) has markdowns of 40 percent to 70 percent on discontinued designs, with new models discounted 20 percent. Through June, customers can also order custom-made shearling coats and jackets for 20 percent off at Searle, bringing the average price of custom coats -- $1,695 -- to about $1,355 -- a good reason to buy shearling while the sun shines.

title: Bored With Baghdad -- Already

David McKiernan and Maj. Gen. Buford Blount III, were pummeled by the press about why they weren't doing more to make Baghdad safer. It was 102 degrees, and in the middle of the session all the lights went out. The two generals looked like they were enjoying this encounter about as much as a root canal. title: 'God's Secretaries'
description: Few moments in English history have been more hungry for the future, its mercurial possibilities and its hope of richness, than the spring of 1603. At last the old, hesitant, querulous and increasingly unapproachable Queen Elizabeth was dying. Nowadays, her courtiers and advisers spent their lives tiptoeing around her moods and her unpredictability. Lurching from one unaddressed financial crisis to the next, selling monopolies to favourites, she had begun to lose the affection of the country she had nurtured for so long. Elizabeth, should have died years before. Most of her great men - Burleigh, Leicester, Walsingham, even the beautiful Earl of Essex, executed after a futile and chaotic rebellion in 1601 - had gone already. She had become a relict of a previous age and her wrinkled, pasteboard virginity now looked more like fruitlessness than purity. Her niggardliness had starved the fountain of patronage on which the workings of the country relied and those mechanisms, unoiled by the necessary largesse, were creaking. Her exhausted impatience made the process of government itself a labyrinth of tact and indirection.

title: 'I Now Inform You'

Now, Minister of Misinformation t-shirts are hot items on E-bay and dozens of Web sites memorialize his most famous quotations. (''There are no American infidels in Baghdad. Never!''). Chagrined that Mr. Sahaf is not included in the Pentagon's deck of cards of the most wanted members of the Iraqi regime, some sites are showcasing a special-edition card named for ''Baghdad Bob,'' as he is known to his acolytes. At www.welovetheiraqiinformationminister.com, about 100,000 visitors a day continue to check in for news and purchase large quantities of Mr. Sahaf-related paraphernalia, including a flying disk emblazoned with his image. Conn Nugent, 57, of Manhattan, one of the site's creators, said the site will continue to decry the ''massive conspiracy coverup'' on the former minister's whereabouts until he surfaces. ''We miss him,'' said Mr Nugent. ''And we're getting 30 percent of the gross.'' AMY HARMON

title: CRIME
description: Joe Pickett, the Wyoming game warden who strides in big boots over the ruggedly gorgeous landscape of C. J. Box's outdoor mysteries, figures he knows as many words for snow conditions as an Eskimo. In WINTERKILL (Putnam, $23.95), he begins his list with ''powder, packed powder, slush, wind-groomed, wind-loaded, fluff, glazed, crud, rain crust, cold smoke and corduroy.'' But there are no words weighty enough to convey this decent lawman's feelings when he witnesses the slaughter of a herd of elk during the first winter storm in the Bighorn Mountains -- and then finds the demented hunter impaled on a tree by two broadhead arrows. Pickett's thoughts fly to a notorious recluse who shoots game with a bow and arrow and hunts with a peregrine falcon and a red-tailed hawk. But a fire-breathing agent with the United States Forest Service, who is ''determined to prove there's a war on'' between the government and dissenting political rebels, is itching to pin the crime on a band of survivalists camped out in the woods. Although Pickett can be trusted to give a fair hearing to every man, woman and animal on the mountain, no matter how crazy, antisocial or smelly, this exercise in fairness is wasted on Box's unmitigated villains. You'd expect more nuance from someone who could come up with all those snow words.

title: The Graves of Iraq
description: While Saddam Hussein was in power, the families of his victims never dreamed they would ever have the opportunity to find the bodies of their loved ones. Now that he has been deposed, they are rushing to excavate the mass graves of his regime -- with shovels, backhoes and bare hands. So far, at least 10 gravesites have been publicly identified, with more turning up almost daily. The macabre scramble at these sites is destroying evidence that could be used to bring the murderers to justice, and depriving thousands of the opportunity to identify the bodies of their loved ones. This could have been avoided if it had been made clear that there would be an orderly process. This is a deep failure by American and British forces, which have neither secured the sites nor communicated any plan for excavations to the Iraqi people.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: YOU don't even have to know who Robert Evans is to love THE KID STAYS IN THE PICTURE (2002). Maybe you missed Mr. Evans's 1950's acting career (a bullfighter in ''The Sun Also Rises,'' a New York cad in ''The Best of Everything'') and his fashion-industry career (Evan-Picone, a family business). Maybe you didn't know he was head of Paramount Pictures overseeing megahits like ''Chinatown,'' ''Rosemary's Baby,'' ''Love Story'' and ''The Godfather'' or that he suffered a great downfall, accompanied by cocaine. Brett Morgen and Nanette Burstein directed this documentary, about the passing of a certain kind of Hollywood glamour, but Mr. Evans, who will be 73 next month, is the star, subject and wonderfully unreliable narrator -- Thursday at 9 p.m. and Thursday/Early Friday at 5:20 a.m. on HBO.

title: Eggheads Unite
description: As a Ph.D. candidate in the history department at New York University, I can attest to a true ambivalence among many grad students toward unionization (Daniel Duane, May 4). Of course we are happy for better pay and benefits, and most of us recognize that the corporatization of the university forced our hand. But I have colleagues who literally run the other way when aggressive union organizers approach. Grad students should recognize that a vote for unionization seems to be interpreted as a mandate for the somewhat overzealous zeal of the organizer. And although your article gives an entirely cynical definition of ''collegiality,'' there is something sad about the unequivocal end of a simpler era, regardless of who deserves the blame for ending it.

title: An Arty Party
description: Every child loves a birthday party, but not every child knows how to celebrate others' birthdays. Morris, the central figure in MORRIS THE ARTIST (Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16; ages 4 to 8), is one obstinate and self-absorbed little partygoer. Long after gifts have been opened, he clings stubbornly to the present he has brought for his playmate Benjamin. Scene by scene, the package literally expands, becoming a colossal burden that Morris finally unwraps himself. This child's self-obsession knows no bounds; Morris removes the brand-new paints and brushes (tools of his own favorite pastime) and renders an enormous portrait of guess who: Morris.

They knew that there was such a thing as the 1920's and that with the right accessories, vintage lingerie from Victoria's Secret could look just like a flapper's dress. They knew that in the 20's people drank absinthe. And that 80 or so years ago hipsters used words like ''cheaters'' for eyeglasses, ''kisser'' for mouth and ''banana oil'' for nonsense.

title: How Architecture Rediscovered The Future
description: In 1988, the Museum of Modern Art in New York showcased seven architects who had accomplished far more as thinkers than as builders. Of the group, Bernard Tschumi had obtained the grandest commission, for a large-scale Paris park, La Villette; but even though he had been working on it for five years, completion was still far off. Among the others, Tschumi regarded Frank Gehry of California, in practice for a quarter-century, as a senior colleague; yet, at that point, Gehry's best-known work was his own Santa Monica residence, notable for its use of plywood planks, corrugated steel and chain-link fencing. Rem Koolhaas was the author of a dazzling, much-read architectural manifesto, as well as the designer of a tiny house in Rotterdam and a dance theater in The Hague. Peter Eisenman was a longtime professor whose pugnaciously impractical Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, was just finished. Daniel Libeskind, Zaha Hadid and the Viennese team of Coop Himmelb(l)au were theorists and teachers, with a knack for winning competitions with exciting schemes that usually failed to find financing.

title: So Sweet, So Sensitive, So Self-Absorbed, So 70's
description: IT doesn't require the Council of Economic Advisers to recognize that the United States is having economic troubles. All it takes is turning on a pop radio station or MTV to get the strange feeling that the mid-1970's have returned: the days of post-Vietnam and post-Watergate letdown, oil crisis, unemployment and soothing soft rock to provide consolation for it all. Three decades later, sensitive, guitar-slinging nice guys are once again swarming the airwaves, blanketing the concert circuit, accounting for innumerable Internet downloads and easing untold dorm-room seductions.

title: 'Perfect Enough'
description: Ever since Carly Fiorina arrived at Hewlett-Packard in 1999-in a blaze of publicity as the first woman ever to run such a giant enterprise-critics had been predicting she would fail. In their eyes, she was too inexperienced, too slick, too different ever to succeed as the chief executive officer of the legendary Silicon Valley company. It was hard enough to guide one of the fifty largest companies in the world. She also needed to be the new face of leadership at an enterprise where everyone talked constantly about "Bill and Dave," two self-effacing billionaires who started Hewlett-Packard in a tiny garage in 1939, soldering together the first products themselves. Retirement and even death couldn't diminish the founders' impact. Some commentators talked delicately about the "tremendous pressures" that Fiorina faced. Others used the taunting language of the playground or the gutter. "Pack it in babe, you stink!" one columnist wrote, before Fiorina had finished her second year in office.

title: Tomorrowland
description: If it sometimes seems as if nothing is left from the recent boom years except the misbegotten gains of erstwhile stock analysts, consider the stockpile of great architecture. Over the past five years we have witnessed an extraordinary blossoming of built form around the world. It's a trend that started with huge attention-grabbing public works, but it did not stop there. From the elaborate and daring art museums that now seem to exist in every decent-size city, the architectural vanguard has moved in closer to the daily life of ordinary people, building schools, stores, restaurants, parks, office towers and many, many private homes that turn traditional notions of domesticity upside down. The work is marked by an unabashed embrace of the future, something that had been missing in architecture for almost a generation. New materials, new processes and new technologies are put in the service of a desire to explore the unfamiliar, to make buildings that entertain, tantalize and awe the people who use them -- and, in some cases, make them angry.

Joe was a World War II Army veteran and fierce fighter for justice in his private law practice, which spanned more than 60 years, believing that all people deserved fair representation. Bush administration officials are exasperated with Europe's belief in the precautionary principle, a better-safe-than-sorry approach to regulating everything from corn flakes to chemical plants.

title: Warning Signs At the High-Risk Pool
description: AFTER Amy Donnelly's husband lost his job last December as a toolmaker for a small manufacturing company, the couple decided not to continue their health insurance under the federal law, known as Cobra, that lets workers keep their policies for up to 18 months if they pay full premiums. The monthly cost, $850, seemed too steep, they said, and they thought they could get a better rate on their own. But Mrs. Donnelly, 40, said no one would sell a policy covering the couple and their 8-year-old son. The reason, she said she was told, was her diabetes.

title: From Every Angle, a Revolution
description: LIKE many Russians who witnessed the bloody downfall of the czar and proclamation of a Marxist state in 1917, Alexander Rodchenko believed the rhetoric of a socialist paradise to come. He also believed that artists had a role to play in the shaping of this new world, helping to build a classless society through a fusion of art and industry. From now on, art must connect with daily life.

title: 'PUBLIC PLACES,' A THEATER LIFE
description: IT was 1957 and a revolution was overtaking the London theater. The previous year, the play ''Look Back in Anger'' had shown what its author, John Osborne, and a new generation of writers, dubbed the Angry Young Men, were angry about: postwar England's middle-class values. Many actors, young and irreverent themselves -- among them Alan Bates, Albert Finney, Richard Harris and Peter O'Toole -- were eager participants. In her memoir, ''Public Places: My Life in the Theater, With Peter O'Toole and Beyond,'' the Welsh actress Sian Phillips describes the hard-drinking Irish-born actor who would become her second husband in 1959, and his own personal rebellion against conventionality. Best known perhaps for her portrayal of the evil Livia in the BBC mini-series ''I, Claudius,'' Ms. Phillips was seen on Broadway in 1999 as Marlene Dietrich in Pam Gems's play ''Marlene'' and, earlier this season, in Israel Horovitz's dark comedy ''My Old Lady'' at the Promenade Theater. In the first chapter of her book, published this month in the United States by Farrar, Straus & Giroux, she sets the scene from which the three excerpts that follow are drawn.

Her radiant, technically solid and supply phrased singing filled the house effortlessly. Amazement rippled through the theater.

title: Gimme Temporary Shelter
description: After smart bombs needlepointed down onto government buildings in Baghdad, it became quite clear that our skill at destruction has reached unrivaled heights. At the same time, our skill at reconstruction remains rudimentary at best. A post-conflict (or post-disaster) refugee -- if he receives U.N. attention -- may be given only a blue plastic sheet, about 13 feet by 16 feet, which is meant to serve as a home. An entire family may live under one of these sheets for weeks, or months.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pennington; Small Town With a Sense of Community
description: THE pace of life is relaxed in Pennington, a one-square-mile borough in Mercer County, N.J., that was settled in the 17th century. Drivers traveling south on Route 31 must obey the sudden drop in the speed limit -- from 45 miles per hour in neighboring Hopewell Township to 25 at the borough's edge -- or risk speeding tickets. Elementary-school children walk to school along streets lined with pink-blossomed cherry trees. The mayor shows up at the Cup of Joe coffee shop in downtown Pennington every morning, ready to chat.

At their Smithtown home, their daughter, Sydney, 1, plays on a plastic rocking horse bought for $2. When her brother Matthew, 3, is not teeing off with a toy golf set that cost $3, he takes a driveway spin in a Cozy Coupe car that was purchased, after haggling, for $5.

title: Not Your Usual Load of Laundry
description: NIVEA FEATURING R. KELLY -- What's great about this duo's single ''Laundromat'' (Jive) is that the verses, a half-spoken and half-sung argument between a couple, feel quickly written and unconvincingly delivered, yet you still can't stop listening to it. The chorus, a Burt Bacharach-like arrangement of voices listing items to take to the laundromat, is extremely well written and beautifully believable. Together, the elements seem like they're from completely different songs, tied together by a beat made from the sound of dripping water.

title: The State of American Singing As Heard on 'I-I-I-I-I-I-Idol'
description: THE cover of the new CD ''American Idol Season 2: All-Time Classic American Love Songs'' features grinning head shots of 11 of the television talent show's 12 finalists -- an attractive, amiable-looking group that could be a high school glee club. Don't be fooled. Competitive karaoke is not for the fainthearted; ''American Idol'' contestants do not sing songs so much as attack them. In nearly every verse of every number on ''All-Time Classic American Love Songs,'' the young singers pursue a strategy of violent Mariah Carey emulation. Their credo is clear: never hesitate to warble seven notes where one would suffice.

title: 'Dracula' Takes Dancing Lessons
description: IT opens like a scene from countless horror films: under cover of darkness, winged gargoyles emerge from the shadows in the bedroom of a forbidding manor, surrounding the sleeping lady of the house. Then things get really strange: darting to and fro, the horned beasts cavort on the bedposts and shake their demon-tailed derrires, looking more like strippers from HBO's ''G-String Divas'' than 19th-century apparitions from Bram Stoker's ''Dracula.'' As the maiden tosses and turns, the creatures suddenly become a pirouetting corps de ballet. Renfield, I don't think we're in Transylvania anymore.

title: Kama Sutra, as Aperitif
description: NOW that yoga mats have replaced lap dogs as the underarm accessory of the moment, it's fitting that buff, quasi-spiritual yoga converts have their own singles bar. On a recent Saturday at K Space, a new lounge with a Kama Sutra theme, young women in low-waist jeans sipped aphrodisiac cocktails and an astrologer read their fortunes. Vikram Chatwal, who owns the club with Mallika and Gotham Chopra, the children of the New Age guru Deepak Chopra, lounged on throw cushions next to models and the fashion photographer Sante D'Orazio.

title: Jerusalem Suicide Bomber Kills 6 and Wounds More Than a Dozen
description: JERUSALEM, Sunday, May 18  A suicide bomber attacked a city bus at the start of the Israeli work week here this morning, killing at least 6 people and wounding more than 20 just hours after Israeli and Palestinian leaders held their highest-level talks in more than two years, without achieving a breakthrough toward ending their 31-month conflict.

Orange, after all, is an affluent, conservative town where residents wrinkle their noses over such goings on.

title: Ballet When It's Beastly
description: WHEN Christopher Wheeldon, the resident choreographer of New York City Ballet, was a student at the Royal Ballet School, he wrote an essay about what it would be like to spend a night locked in the British Museum of Natural History. That storybook premise comes to life at the New York State Theater today and Thursday in his new work, ''Carnival of the Animals.'' The ballet, set in the American Museum of Natural History (which Mr. Wheeldon frequents for its ''amazing mix of the grotesque and the wonderful''), uses nearly 50 dancers and includes narration by John Lithgow, who also wrote the text. The main character, Oliver Pendleton Percy the Third, is portrayed by the School of American Ballet student P. J. Verhoest. In ''Carnival,'' Oliver falls asleep; the dancers -- all characters from his life -- transform into animals. But the 50's-flavored costumes, designed by Jon Morrell (who also created the set), never camouflage the characters; rather, each is adorned with a subtle animal accent. ''I wanted to move away from the clichd bunny ears and fluffy tails,'' Mr. Wheeldon said. ''From the beginning, it was very important that they be people first, then animals.'' GIA KOURLAS

title: Murphy Brown Meets the Girl Scouts
description: BACK when conventional wisdom said that a woman over 30 was more likely to be killed by a terrorist than get married (so long ago that the idea of being killed by a terrorist was ludicrous instead of an everyday fear) the 20-something women in my circle almost unanimously agreed that when our biological alarms sounded, we would have children, married or not. There were sperm banks. There were unwitting boyfriends. There were male friends who could pinch hit when a father figure was needed, a role model stepping up to bat. It was possible. Maybe even preferable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THIERINGER, FRED, JR.
description: THIERINGER-Fred, Jr. Died peacefully at his Shelter Island home on May 15, 2003. He was born in a two family house at 189 North 18th Street, East Orange, New Jersey, on February 1, 1906. For the first 18 years of his life he moved between East Orange and Montclair (his father owned a house in each place-the Montclair house being at 8 Hawthorne Place). He attended schools in both towns and graduated from Montclair High School in June, 1924. To supplement the family income, he worked nights while in high school and in his senior year he was night manager of the local Western Union office. His business career was spent with Appleton & Cox, Inc., New York (Marine Insurance Underwriters), where he started as a clerk in the Accounting Department on August 1, 1924, and after 47 years of service, retired as President and Chairman of the Board on February 1, 1971. By that time, the firm was an affiliate of Continental Insurance Company and was called Marine Office-Appleton Cox Corp. For a number of years after he started working in New York, he took night courses at New York University on various subjects that were were allied with his business of marine insurance, including a postgraduate course in Admiralty. Fred is survived by his wife of 57 years, Margaret, and four children: Jane Thieringer of Santa Cruz, CA, James Scott Thieringer of Long Valley, NJ, David Carl Thieringer of Pine Plains, NY, and Richard (Charlie) Lawrence Thieringer of Liberty Corner, NJ. Fred is also survived by his sister Gertrude L. Dinkel of Shelter Island. Two sisters predeceased him-Elizabeth B. Crossley and Madeline A. Thieringer. Fred enjoyed eight grandchildren as well as numerous nieces and nephews. A private family graveside service will be held at St. Mary's Cemetery, Shelter Island, NY, on Monday, May 19th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Union Chapel in the Grove, PO Box 326, Shelter Island Heights, NY 11965.

title: MSGR. FARRELL HIGH WINS SECTIONALS
description: Anthony DePalma's victory yesterday in the final event, the javelin, clinched the team title for Msgr. Farrell of Staten Island in the Catholic High School Athletic Association New York boys' sectionals at Mount St. Michael Field in the Bronx.

title: Charity in Cyberspace
description: Goodwill Industries International, the charitable organization, was founded 101 years ago by the Rev. Edgar J. Helms, a Methodist minister in Boston who wanted to provide business opportunities to the disadvantaged. He collected old clothes and discarded household goods from wealthy areas of the city, and trained and hired poor immigrants to repair and resell them. Over the decades, Goodwill has expanded into a nonprofit business with annual revenue of $1.8 billion, selling goods through 1,900 retail stores and providing other services. Its Internet auction site, shopgoodwill.com, started in 1999, was a pioneer among nonprofit groups. RICK GLADSTONE

title: Sharon Wing, Donald Gibson
description: Sharon Lee Wing, a daughter of Jeanie Carter Prall Wing and Dr. George Lee Wing of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Donald Edward Gibson, a son of Di-Anne and Thomas V. Gibson of Port Matilda, Pa. The Rev. Sidney M. Nelson, a Lutheran minister, will perform the ceremony at the Great House at Castle Hill on the Crane Estate in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Real Estate 101 In the Hamptons
description: ANYONE who buys a house in the Hamptons can expect to pay for the label. The considerable cachet attached to the tag ''South of the Highway'' (and the extra cash it commands) is well known. Likewise, locations east of the Shinnecock Canal are generally more prized than the up-Island Hamptons. But there are dozens of other distinctions affecting the prestige, and the price, of Hamptons property, some more obvious than others.

But Eisenman, who became known in the 70's for building spare, cubelike houses, has done almost no work on it himself. ''I don't necessarily need or want to live in my own environment,'' he says. At Cornell, graduate students rejected unionization by a margin of 2 to 1 last fall. Here at Yale, the union lost another election the very week that your article ran. As these results show, many graduate students -- who tend to be progressive and pro-union in their overall politics -- are skeptical of big labor's role in graduate education.

Those are the colors of the 10-member partnership called Sackatoga Stable, and its entourage of 120 people was eager for Funny Cide to move a little closer to racing history.

title: The Thinkable
description: Bill Keller (May 4) rightly warns that the danger of nuclear-weapons proliferation and use is increasing. However, he is only partly correct that ''the essential bargain that induced nonnuclear states to sign the Nonproliferation Treaty'' was the promise of nuclear-energy programs. The larger quid pro quo for their promise not to develop nuclear weapons was the commitment by the nuclear states to negotiate in good faith toward full nuclear disarmament. After 33 years, that goal is not in sight.

title: Nothing but Net
description: ONE day last fall, when the weather had cooled and summer seemed to be over, I went down to my local basketball court, on Hudson Street between Horatio and Gansevoort Streets, where I've been going for seven years. The court, which is wedged between the West Village, where I live, and the meatpacking district, is on the loose circuit of courts upon which Players, as it were, like to play. But it looked a little emptier than usual. The players there were mostly those diehards whose compulsion to play basketball is somehow suspicious.

title: Teach Me Tonight
description: Leah Hager Cohen's second novel, HEART, YOU BULLY, YOU PUNK (Viking, $23.95), describes the mysterious, unpredictable, even mutinous ways people's hearts mess with their lives. Esker, a math teacher at a Brooklyn school, volunteers to tutor one of her students, who has broken both heels in a fall, and ends up falling herself -- for the girl's father. Told from the successive points of view of teacher, student and father, ''Heart, You Bully, You Punk'' (the title comes from a poem by Marie Ponsot) exposes three very different attitudes toward love: those of a 16-year-old ''filled with a volatile, dangerous faith in her own heart, in her ability to sprout wings, defy gravity, exist in midair''; a 31-year-old who has spent years trying to cauterize an old desire that had been ''too much to bear . . . too large or misguided'' and who's not sure she's ready for a new one; and a middle-aged father who deals with the darts thrown at his own heart through a strenuous effort ''to will love.'' Propriety, in the form of the school headmistress, ends up putting a damper on the ''rising elation'' of these characters, and Esker must make a difficult decision. Packed with details of contemporary life in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan, ''Heart, You Bully, You Punk'' is a lively, thoughtful pleasure. Benjamin Swett

title: Indian Heart Surgeon Took Talents Home
description: Taken out of context, it looks like Naresh Trehan is playing a video game. He stares intently into a console at a three-dimensional image, his feet pressing on pedals, his hands maneuvering levers.

title: You Must Pay the Rent!
description: For months, when I was unemployed or underemployed, my fiance paid our rent and lent me money. I thought that we were partners and that someday I'd return the favor. Later, I found a good job and slowly started to pay back the debt. Then she left me. Must I continue to repay her, or was an unwritten contract broken when she flew off to Vegas with another man? Sure I'm bitter, but I have my ethics. W.S., New York

description: ON nights when Jackson Pollock drank too much at Jungle Pete's in Springs, his new friends and neighbors kept the peace with any offended parties, then drove the artist home, avoiding the kind of rows that accompanied his binge drinking during the 1940's in Manhattan nightspots like the Cedar Bar. Truman Capote, shunned by his old society pals, regularly showed up in the 1970's at Bobby Van's restaurant in Bridgehampton before it opened for lunch, eager for a cocktail. And John Steinbeck, living in Sag Harbor, would rendezvous with his wife, Elaine, at Baron's Cove Inn, where they would sip wine and watch the sun set over the water.

Investors who had been expecting a second round for a pair of more market-friendly candidates were disconcerted by the strength shown by Mr. Kirchner, the little-known Peronist governor from Patagonia with the populist image.

title: Giving That Gives Back
description: FOR the last 15 years I have worked as an elder care specialist, helping older adults, some alert and others at peace in their own world. Many have adult children living far away, while others have no family at all. I am often called upon to put necessary services into place and to supervise each client's care. Often I enter a client's home and find I am eyed with suspicion or presented with the conviction that all is fine and my services are unnecessary. It then becomes a challenge for me to develop a relationship with each client so that we can work together give life quality and meaning. Such relationships are not one sided because I have found that in the process of giving, much is received. Three women I profile here illustrate this, and each one left me with a lesson learned.

title: Single Occupancy Indeed

I was in Room 938 at the InterContinental Hong Kong Hotel, a hotel that has the best of many magnificent views across the harbor from Kowloon peninsula. My goal was a simple one: to spend the night in one of the city's grand luxury hotels, to see what it was like after the World Health Organization's SARS advisory on April 2 recommending that people defer all but essential travel to Hong Kong.

title: Complaining Is a Duty, Not Just a Right

The van service that Disney recommended didn't show up on time at our hotel on the day of our departure. After waiting 40 minutes, in which we made several calls to the van service's dispatcher and heard promises of imminent arrival, we saw a representative of the van service on site who was working with conference groups at the hotel. She managed to find a nearby van to take us to the airport.

Do a Google search on ''ford,'' for example, and the first batch of results includes the pages for the Ford Motor Company, the Ford Foundation, the Betty Ford Center, Harrison Ford and Gerald R. Ford -- all good guesses at what a user would be looking for, particularly considering that Google estimates its index holds more than 16 million pages including the word.

description: Until five years ago, few people other than devoted evangelical Christians had heard of VeggieTales, a small company's series of cartoon videos about talking cucumbers and tomatoes learning biblical lessons. That, however, was before the VeggieTales went to Wal-Mart.

title: The Fountains of Youth
description: A PEAK experience of my early years was running full tilt through a garden sprinkler on a hot, hot day. My brother, sister and I would perform the ritual dance of braving the first tickle of cold water, beating a quick retreat, venturing in a little farther, retreating again, and finally rushing deliriously straight through the spray. At game's end, we would crouch directly over the sprinkler head for the maximum cooling effect.

Before the South Street Seaport Museum bought and towed her here, the Royal Navy in England used her to teach young men how to sail. Long before that, this merchant vessel sailed the world, carrying grain and fertilizer between Chile and Western Europe.

Under the agreement, the workers, who are represented by the United Federation of Teachers, will receive a 3 percent raise when the contract is ratified. They will also receive a raise of up to 4 percent this fall, contingent upon certain fund-raising goals being met. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: The Way of the Yakuza Is (Watch Out!) Lethal
description: A lot of severed body parts hit the floor during the grisly course of Takashi Miike's Japanese splatter comedy ''Ichi the Killer,'' including a nose, a cheek, a tongue, several heads and a face, sliced off as if it were a mask. One hapless manis slit from top to bottom by a samurai sword, his body left to peel apart like a soggy banana from its skin. None of these effects are very convincing -- if they were this film would be revolting instead of merely repulsive -- but there are enough of them to make one wonder what has happened to that once-famous Japanese sense of understatement.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: MAN WANTED FOR QUESTIONING The police have released a photo of a man who is wanted for questioning in the killing of Romona Moore, a 21-year-old Hunter College psychology major whose naked body was found behind a boarded-up building just blocks from her home in East Flatbush on May 10. Ms. Moore disappeared on the way from a friend's house to a Burger King restaurant on her block on the evening of April 24, the police have said. The last known address of the man, Kayson Pearson, 21, was on Ralph Avenue in East Flatbush. The police declined to say why they are looking for him. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Slumping Yankees Crawl Off To Boston

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospital Network Names Leader

Continuum includes Beth Israel Medical Center, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, Long Island College Hospital and New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. Mr. Brezenoff, president of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn since 1994, has served as deputy mayor of New York City, and has done stints as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the city's Human Resources Administration and the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. He was mentioned last year as a candidate to lead the city's school system. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: The Power of Sisterhood in the Rural South

It's plot heavy, full of lionhearted female characters with broadly drawn and easily graspable personality traits, and it's focused on the morally unassailable theme of the redemptive power of love; it's a chick flick for the stage.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Fatally Shot
description: An 18-year-old man was fatally shot Saturday as he rode on the Belt Parkway in the back seat of a friend's car, the police said. The man, Francesco Santillo, and three friends had left a pool hall in Bay Ridge, just after 2 a.m., when the driver stopped at a light. Another car -- believed to be a white Lincoln with two women in the front seat and a man in the back seat -- stopped beside them, Mr. Santillo's family said they had been told. The car later pulled up next to them on the parkway, between the Bay Parkway and Cropsey Avenue exits, and the man shot Mr. Santillo the police said. Mr. Santillo died early yesterday. There was nothing to indicate that words had been exchanged between the two cars or that the people were known to each other, the police said. Mr. Santillo's family said he was studying architectural drawing. He was arrested earlier this month on charges of robbery and possession of a weapon, the Brooklyn district attorney said, but his family had said they expected the charges to be dropped. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Information-Law Noncompliance
description: Fewer than half of New York City government offices fully comply with the state's Freedom of Information Law, according to a City Council investigation released yesterday. To test the law, council investigators requested information from 83 city offices, and reported that only 44 percent complied fully with the law, and that a quarter of the agencies never responded to the requests. A spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the administration takes the law seriously, but criticized the Council for releasing the report, which was completed in March, two months late. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: How to Control a New York Legislator
description: Of the 119 gubernatorial vetoes overturned with the speed of light in both houses of New York's Legislature last Thursday, override No. 93 was a clunker. It rescued an appropriation for $200 million that, technically, fits somewhere in the state's Health and Mental Hygiene Budget. In reality, it is designed as a slush fund for the two leaders of Albany's Legislature -- Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Joseph Bruno, the Senate majority leader. Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno plan to divide this big pork pie and dole the money out for parks or senior centers or medical programs or just about anything else they want for the districts of their most-favored legislators. If leaders in most state legislatures have power, No. 93 helps New York's leaders rule like czars and converts the other 210 legislators into supplicants, begging alms for their impoverished districts.

title: Judicial Nominees and Gay Rights

The president called Senator Santorum, who had just equated homosexuality with polygamy and incest, ''an inclusive man.'' At the same time, the Bush administration has been appointing federal judges who are hostile to equal rights for gay men and lesbians. Two nominees with troubling records -- one who argues in support of laws against gay sex, another who has spoken out against ''queers'' -- are now headed to hearings in the Senate. Every senator who opposes discrimination should be prepared to ask them hard questions, and to vote against one, and possibly both.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: CISCO WILL TAKE NONCASH CHARGE IN DEAL Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 maker of equipment that directs Internet traffic, said yesterday that it would take a noncash charge of up to $500 million for its pending acquisition of the storage switch maker Andiamo Systems Inc. Cisco said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that a new regulation required it to consolidate Andiamo on its financial statement on July 27, the first day of its 2004 fiscal year. Cisco previously said it expected to consolidate Andiamo entirely upon the acquisition's close. In January, United States accounting rule-makers approved final rules that clamp down on the abuse of financing entities that allowed companies like Enron to keep large amounts of debt off their books. Cisco said its investment in Andiamo was never an off-balance-sheet vehicle. The new regulation cited by Cisco applies to variable interest entities  investments in which a company has the highest risk of expected losses or more than half its shares. Cisco said the S.E.C. rule would require it to account for Andiamo as if it had consolidated the company since Cisco's initial investment in April 2001. Cisco shares fell 69 cents, or 4.1 percent, to $15.94. ( Reuters )

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: MICROSOFT TO BUY UNIX LICENSES FROM CALDERA Microsoft will buy some rights to use the Unix computer operating system from Caldera International Inc., bolstering Caldera's legal challenge to the rival Linux software. Microsoft bought the licenses to ensure its Windows-based programs would work with Unix software, the companies said in a statement. The value of the deal was not disclosed. Caldera has said the low-cost Linux operating system contains some of its Unix code and companies that use or promote Linux might owe it royalties. Caldera, which is changing its name to SCO Group, is suing I.B.M. and has warned 1,500 other companies. Microsoft, which calls Linux the chief threat to its Windows software, is endorsing a legal challenge that may raise the price of Linux, analysts said.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: CUTS AT CHEMICAL CONCERN The Swiss chemicals group Lonza, hurt by the strong Swiss franc and high costs for raw materials, cut 300 jobs and reduced its earnings outlook 20 percent for the first half of the year. As a result of worsening market conditions in most of its business lines, Lonza said it expected its 2003 profit to fall short of the 221 million Swiss francs ($170 million) it earned last year. An official at Lonza, which employs 6,200 people in eight countries, said the job cuts would primarily affect the United States and Europe. The move is part of a broader program to improve efficiency and reduce overhead, Lonza, based in Basel, said. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Reaffirming Miranda

Yesterday, the Supreme Court agreed to take a Missouri case that could scale back the effectiveness of Miranda warnings. At issue is a two-step form of questioning, which Missouri's highest court called an ''end run'' around Miranda. The Supreme Court should hold that such interrogation violates the Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: U.S. To Develop Rural Broadband Service
description: The Department of Agriculture said yesterday that it would spend $20 million on grants to develop broadband services in 40 rural communities in 17 states. About $8 million of the grants will go to more than a dozen Native American communities in Utah, Washington, Alaska, New Mexico, Arizona, Idaho and Oregon, officials said. ''Through these grants,'' the department said, ''the communities will be able to participate and take advantage of the high-speed telecommunications tools needed to be a part of the global digital community.'' While some of the money will go toward putting computers into homes, the grants were intended for small communities that do not have high-speed computer and Internet access for their police and fire departments, hospitals, libraries and schools. ''Expanding the reach of information technology brings to the homes and businesses of America's most remote rural communities new opportunities for accessing education, health and economic resources,'' said Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman.
