Lynch Jr. Cancer Fund C/O Jeffrey A. Gelfand, M.D., Massachusetts General Hospital, 50 Staniford Street, Suite #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORIA, JOSEPH, SR.
description: DORIA-Joseph, Sr., proprietor of Grace's Marketplace, born August 22, 1934 in Coratio, Italy in the Bari region, came to this country at 13. Worked for Louis Balducci, owner of Balducci's in Greenwich Village, met Grace Balducci in 1955 and married on May 5, 1957. He leaves his wife of 46 years, Grace Balducci Doria, six children, Frank, Louis, Pina, Maria, Joseph and Dino, and leaves eight grandchildren, Rosemarie, Rosemarie, Joseph, Alessandro, Daniel, Louis, Brian and Joseph Marco. Wake, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at at Beney's Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Rd., Syosset, NY. Interment Wednesday, at St. Mary's Cemetery in Flushing.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Novell Wins $680,000 In Stolen Software Case
description: The United States District Court for Utah ordered Computer Commodity Inc. to pay Novell Inc. more than $680,000 in damages, costs and lawyers' fees for selling stolen software, Novell said yesterday. In a copyright and trademark infringement lawsuit filed in 1998, the software maker Novell charged that Computer Commodity received and distributed software that was stolen from a Novell contractor in Ireland. Novell said Computer Commodity, a closely held company based in Pompano Beach, Fla., sold 1,000 copies of the stolen software in the United States at discounts of 68 percent to 95 percent. Novell also said AU Industries of Ireland and MBC Enterprises of Salt Lake City participated in the sales. MBC Enterprises agreed in 2000 to pay about $93,000 and AU Industries agreed in 2001 to pay $30,000 to settle the copyright and trademark infringement lawsuits. Both MBC Enterprises and AU Industries were also permanently barred from dealing in Novell products. Novell shares fell 18 cents, or about 6 percent, to $2.85.

title: Court Says Council's Speaker And 5 Others May Run Again
description: Gifford Miller, the speaker of City Council, and five of his colleagues were brought back to political life yesterday when a state court ruled that they could run for re-election this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 29 about a new center on disaster preparedness at Columbia University misstated the rarity of the university's Mailman School of Public Health. There are indeed other graduate schools of public health in the region.

title: Why Do Squirrels Cross the Road?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Qaeda Cells Are Operating In Saudi Arabia, Officials Say
description: Al Qaeda has carved a deep foothold here with at least three cells of operatives plotting new attacks in the kingdom or North America, American and Saudi government officials said today.

title: An Old-Fashioned Malady
description: To the Editor:

title: Nail-Biting Is Over Early In Opener
description: There was supposed to be drama at Fenway Park tonight. The first-place Yankees played the first-place Red Sox, which was perfect symmetry. There were two teams with a fierce rivalry, 35,099 witnesses and only one group of players who would be able to stroll onto Yawkey Way still in first by the time the night was over.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Strikes
description: Public employees, including schoolteachers and hospital and utility workers, went on strike as protests continued against plans by the government to overhaul pensions in the public sector. In Paris, a crowd of about 40,000 marchers, according to police estimates, braved squalling rains to march in demonstrations protesting the changes. As many as half of all teachers in some classes boycotted lessons, the Education Ministry reported, forcing schools to close across France. Moderate labor unions last week accepted the planned changes as workable, but militant unions, including the leftist General Confederation of Labor, which are strongest among public employees, have pledged to continue the protests. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Anti-Tobacco Pact Gains Despite Firms' Lobbying
description: The 192-nation World Health Organization is expected to adopt a tobacco control treaty on Wednesday at its annual assembly here.

title: When Babies Sleep Right Side Up
description: Putting babies to sleep on their backs or sides not only reduces their chance of dying, but cuts down on fevers, sniffles and ear infections, a new study says.

title: A Councilman From Queens Loses Support From His Party
description: The Queens Democratic Party took the unusual step yesterday of not endorsing an incumbent city councilman, Allan W. Jennings Jr., in the upcoming primary election. Democratic officials said they considered his behavior to be too unorthodox and unprofessional.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: OLIN FOUNDATION MAKES GRANT The John M. Olin Foundation has donated $10 million to the Harvard Law School. It is the largest grant ever by a foundation to the school, which opened the John M. Olin Center for Law, Economics and Business in 1985. The foundation, which started in 1953 and plans to spend its money and close in a few years, supports similar programs at other universities. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Profit Posted by Nordstrom for First Quarter
description: Nordstrom Inc., the upscale department store chain, had first-quarter earnings of $27.2 million because the company did not have acquisition costs.

title: Previn and Philharmonic Blend East and West
description: Andr Previn is on the New York Philharmonic's podium at the moment, and the program he led at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening -- to be repeated tonight -- offers a precarious but rewarding balance of new and old.

title: Faith, Politics and the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, SADIE
description: SILVERSTEIN - Sadie. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a compassionate, kind, generous and long-time friend and supporter of Jewish education who, with her late husband, Rabbi Israel I. Silverstein (a former Trustee of the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary), was a Yeshiva University Guardian who memorialized their late, beloved son, Dr. Jerrold Silverstein, with a science laboratory in Yeshiva College and an endowed scholarship fund at RIETS. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her devoted daughter Lorraine (and Dr. Leonard) Dauber; and to her grandchildren: Paul Dauber, Jane (and Michael) Lewittes, and Daniel (and Dina) Dauber. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Joshua Muss, Chairman YC Board of Directors

title: Yanks Rediscover Winning Ways at Fenway
description: When David Wells wakes up on Tuesday, he will be 40 years old. Age is incidental to Wells, the way weight and tact seem to be. As long as Wells's left arm is attached, little else matters. Wells, the Yankees' irascible left-hander, won again tonight, celebrating the end of his 30's responsibly.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Minneapolis-St. Paul; A Good Place to Do Business With an Easy Airport to Boot
description: As business-travel destinations go, Minneapolis and St. Paul receive high marks from many consultants and executives. The Twin Cities' relatively compact size, wide selection of good hotels and restaurants, and (in warmer months) abundance of outdoor activities make them a pleasant place to do business.

title: U.S. Forecasts Active Season For Hurricanes
description: Six to nine hurricanes are likely to churn the Atlantic or the Caribbean this year, making 2003 the stormiest year since 1999, federal officials said yesterday. They warned coastal communities not to be lulled by the relative calm of recent seasons.

title: Telescopes of the World, Unite! A Cosmic Database Emerges
description: About a year ago a large group of astronomers began to assemble what some of them were calling ''the world's best telescope.'' Their ambitious instrument is still far from complete, but they recently took it for a test run. Within minutes, to their joy and astonishment, they had discovered three or four brown dwarfs, objects that occupy the niche between planet and star.

title: How a Regular Guy Landed on Late Night
description: Perhaps no late-night television show should be too exciting. Its viewers, after all, are presumably hoping to drift off to sleep shortly. But the producers of the ABC talk show ''Jimmy Kimmel Live'' have taken that notion too far. To judge by the documentary ''The New Face of Late Night TV,'' to be shown on the Discovery Times Channel tonight, they have hired an entire crew of completely uninteresting people to create a show meant to face off against similar offerings from NBC, which has Jay Leno, and CBS, which has Mr. Kimmel's idol, David Letterman.

title: FLEMING WINS APPROVAL TO HOLD AUCTION FOR FOOD STORES
description: The Fleming Companies said yesterday that it had won bankruptcy court permission to seek higher bids for its 31 Rainbow Foods stores, which are the subject of an $85 million offer from the closely held Roundy's Inc. Roundy's offer will become the opening bid at a June 3 auction. Fleming, which is based in Lewisville, Tex., has been trying to sell its money-losing grocery stores to cut costs and focus on its wholesale business. Fleming sought protection from creditors in April after losing a contract with its largest customer, the Kmart Corporation.

title: Medicare Credited for Closing Gap
description: Black women die of breast cancer at higher rates than white women with comparable tumors, but the gap disappears among women old enough to qualify for Medicare, according to a study released yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Cuts At Chemical Concern
description: The Swiss chemicals group Lonza, hurt by the strong Swiss franc and high costs for raw materials, cut 300 jobs and reduced its earnings outlook 20 percent for the first half of the year. As a result of worsening market conditions in most of its business lines, Lonza said it expected its 2003 profit to fall short of the 221 million Swiss francs ($170 million) it earned last year. An official at Lonza, which employs 6,200 people in eight countries, said the job cuts would primarily affect the United States and Europe. The move is part of a broader program to improve efficiency and reduce overhead, Lonza, based in Basel, said. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the writer Leonard Michaels last Tuesday omitted attribution for a two-paragraph passage describing his male-consciousness-raising novel, ''The Men's Club'' (Farrar, Straus, 1981). The passage was from the reference work ''Contemporary Novelists.''

title: Doctor Admits Fraud
description: An eye doctor pleaded guilty to a fraud scheme amounting to nearly $1 million in which he rounded up adulthome residents and subjected them to unnecessary surgery or charged for thousands of procedures that were never done.

title: Leading Drugs for Psychosis Come Under New Scrutiny
description: They were billed as near wonder drugs, much safer and more effective in treating schizophrenia than anything that had come before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEE, DICKSON
description: HEE-Dickson. The Charles B. Wang Community Health Center mourns the loss of Dickson Hee, Chairperson of The Board of Directors. Mr. Hee's commitment to improving the health and wellbeing of the Chinese-American community was unbounded; his enthusiasm and dedication towards the Health Center and its mission will be missed. The Board of Directors and all the staff express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Ethel, and children, Lauren and David.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Buy Unix Licenses From Caldera
description: Microsoft will buy some rights to use the Unix computer operating system from Caldera International Inc., bolstering Caldera's legal challenge to the rival Linux software. Microsoft bought the licenses to ensure its Windows-based programs would work with Unix software, the companies said in a statement. The value of the deal was not disclosed. Caldera has said the low-cost Linux operating system contains some of its Unix code and companies that use or promote Linux might owe it royalties. Caldera, which is changing its name to SCO Group, is suing I.B.M. and has warned 1,500 other companies. Microsoft, which calls Linux the chief threat to its Windows software, is endorsing a legal challenge that may raise the price of Linux, analysts said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: As Iraq's Artists Strive for Freedom, Gunmen Silence a Pro-Hussein Singer
description: For 30 years Daoud al-Qaysi sang the praises of Saddam Hussein, bartering his modest musical talent for a dictator's favors, and now he has paid the price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEILI, PETER G.
description: MEILI-Peter G. On May 18. Beloved husband of Luchette Meili. Loving father of Ronald. Cherished grandfather of Tara and Danielle. Loving son of Chris. Devoted brother of Phyllis Chernin and uncle of Stephen and Anthony. Funeral services private. Memorial donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital c/o Dr. Kevin Kelly.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: High Court Refuses T-Shirt Case
description: The Supreme Court yesterday refused to hear a case that could have barred students in a western New Jersey school district from wearing clothes that mentioned the word redneck. Officials in the Warren Hills School District, near the Pennsylvania border, suspended a student for three days in 2001 when he wore a T-shirt printed with ''The Top 10 Reasons You Might Be a Redneck Sports Fan,'' a list from the comedian Jeff Foxworthy. Officials said that he had violated the school's anti-harassment and intimidation policy and that the T-shirt could have inflamed racial tensions, said John Zaiter, a lawyer for the district. But the student, identified in court records as Thomas Sypniewski Jr., who has since graduated, sued the district, saying it had violated his free-speech rights. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit agreed with him, saying that the word redneck was not used to intimidate and harass other students. It issued an injunction to keep the school from barring such messages and other symbols like the Confederate flag.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: SK's Debt Swells
description: The debt of SK Global, the trading firm of the SK Group, among South Korea's largest conglomerates, totals 9.97 trillion won, ($8 billion), according to a study ordered by its creditor banks. The company's debt exceeded its asset value by $4.39 trillion won, an increase of a third since an accounting in April. Hana Bank, the lead creditor, asked others to make good on promises to provide financing for SK Global despite objections from shareholders. Disclosure of SK Global's mounting debt increases the vulnerability of the SK Corporation, the oil refiner that owns 38 percent of SK Global. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Some Fears Are Relieved as Lyme Becomes Easier to Manage and Treat
description: The ticks may not have gotten the message -- they are still out in the woods in full force, biting human flesh at every opportunity -- but many of the people in Lyme disease country and their doctors have decided that the illness is not going to alarm them so much anymore.

title: 3 New Arrests in Mass Deaths On Smugglers' Truck in Texas
description: Before boarding a packed tractor-trailer last week with the hope of traveling from a border city deeper into the United States, Mara Elena Castro had a friend wire $1,500 to smugglers for the separate transportation of her son, 3, according to court papers made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETZENDANNER, JOSEPH W.
description: GETZENDANNER - Joseph W., Jr. 89 of Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA, died on May 15, 2003. Husband of Betty Anne Forbes Getzendanner and father of the late Susan M. Getzendanner and Thomas F., Lydia Kriso and Martha Lingen. He is also survived by 12 grandchildren and a great-grandchild. Private interment services will be held at Old St. Paul's Episcopal Cemetery, Chestertown, MD. Swartz/Givnish Funeral Home, Newtown, PA 215-968-3891.

title: Future as Prologue In Two New Dramas
description: Two very different sets of people, found on separate stages here, are squinting hard at what lies ahead. While their social and economic circumstances are anything but identical, the landscape that consumes their attention is the same. As bright and mysterious as a mountain range in morning haze, it's the 20th century that sprawls before them. It promises to be treacherous territory.

title: Graduation Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: New York, Still Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: Once in a Long While, the M.T.A. Loses
description: In New York, there are some transportation truisms that rise almost to the level of natural law.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about potential suitors for New York magazine referred incorrectly to the presidency of Gerald R. Ford, whom the magazine once portrayed on the cover as Bozo the Clown. He was not elected; he took office after the resignation of Richard Nixon.

title: Nuclear Risk and Reality
description: The thinking goes like this: if terrorists attacked the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County, just north of New York, hundreds of thousands of people within a 10-mile radius would need to be evacuated. A state report on emergency planning at Indian Point, prepared by James Lee Witt, the former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, concluded that current emergency plans were inadequate and warned that they could not protect the public from a large release of radioactive material. Opponents of Indian Point immediately latched on to the report as further reason to close the plant.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Internet Operator Sentenced
description: Three years after he was arrested for running dissident information on his Web site, a man from Sichuan Province was sentenced to five years in prison this month for ''subverting state power,'' rights groups have learned. The man, Huang Qi, was arrested in June 2000 after his Web site featured condemnations of the 1989 shootings of demonstrators around Tiananmen Square. The court, in Chengdu, did not explain the lengthy delay in sentencing. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINERT, SOPHIA BLICKMAN
description: WEINERT-Sophia Blickman. Magical, creative, brilliant, loving. Perfect mother. Passionate and accomplished artist and writer. Visionary and generous sister, friend and mentor. She is survived by her daughter Shira Weinert, sisters Frances Schuster and Myrna Kresh, dearest friends Barbara Levey and Lisa Weinert, and countless admirers. Fifi, we love you and are grateful to have shared your life and gifts. Fly free and close. Services will be held at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91 St Wednesday, May 21st, 10:15AM. In lieu of flowers, an art scholarship fund will be established in Fifi's name.

title: Daring to Take Fictional Columbine to Cannes
description: ''I'm not really interested in narrative filmmaking anymore,'' the director Gus Van Sant said today. ''Those popcorn movies that do that kind of thing, it's like they're baby sitters.''

title: Deep in Universe's Software Lurk Beautiful, Mysterious Numbers
description: In Dan Brown's best-selling intellectual potboiler, ''The Da Vinci Code,'' Sophie Neveu, fetching young cryptographer for the Paris police, and Robert Langdon, suave internationally acclaimed expert on religious symbology, are running through the deserted halls of the Louvre fleeing their would-be captors when Langdon, in one of the novel's typically awkward moments, pauses to reminisce. The subject: a lecture he recently gave at Harvard on the remarkable properties of the number phi.

title: A Funeral Draws a Son Home, to Joan Collins
description: The wild garden created by the set designer Tim Hatley for Charlotte Jones's play ''Humble Boy'' is one of the delights of the theater season that is now drawing to a close. It's weird that you have to go underground to see it, to the Manhattan Theater Club's subterranean main stage at City Center, where the play opened on Sunday.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Olin Foundation Makes Grant
description: The John M. Olin Foundation has donated $10 million to the Harvard Law School. It is the largest grant ever by a foundation to the school, which opened the John M. Olin Center for Law, Economics and Business in 1985. The foundation, which started in 1953 and plans to spend its money and close in a few years, supports similar programs at other universities. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Court Stays Its Ruling On Financing Campaigns
description: A federal appeals court today suspended its own ruling striking down parts of the new campaign finance law, in a decision that will block the national political parties from once again collecting the large contributions known as soft money from unions and corporations.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Announces New Low-Cost Servers
description: Sun Microsystems yesterday announced new low-cost servers based on Intel chips as part of its strategy to compete with Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Dell. In announcing the new systems, Sun's chief executive, Scott McNealy, said the new computers, with prices starting at $2,450, were priced far less than similar offerings from its competitors. With the downturn in technology spending, companies are urging hardware companies to pack more punch into smaller, more versatile and cheaper machines. Mr. McNealy announced the new servers at a news conference in San Francisco with Larry Ellison, the chairman and chief executive of Oracle. The two companies said they had expanded their 20-year development relationship and that all of Oracle's software now runs on Sun's Solaris operating system as well as Sun's Linux systems. Mr. Ellison said more than a third of Oracle's customers use Sun computers. Sun also announced a new partnership agreement with Red Hat to distribute its enterprise Linux operating system. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: The Senators' Prospects Are Brighter
description: At the start of the playoffs, Ottawa Coach Jacques Martin said it would be unfair to expect a 19-year-old to come in and make an impact.

title: Diplomatic Bonfires
description: This is not what the White House wanted as President Bush starts pointing toward next year's election campaign. Iraq is in a state of near anarchy. The conflict between Israel and the Palestinians is escalating again, and Islamic terrorists are on the attack in the Middle East. Just at the moment when Mr. Bush would like the nation to think of him as a statesman, everything seems to be going the wrong way in one of the world's most combustible regions. Mr. Bush has himself to blame in part.

title: Taking Hip-Hop Seriously. Seriously.
description: When the book is finally written about style in the late 20th century, an era when it markedly trumped substance, historians will have to contend with a group whose contributions to visual culture have, to put it politely, generally been overlooked. The history of style in the late 20th century, in other words, is substantially the history of hip-hop, an urban music scene whose effects on the aural texture of contemporary life are more than matched by its influence on how, at a certain cultural moment, people around the world decided they wanted to be seen.

title: The Search for SARS's Past May Help Predict Its Future
description: Even though SARS is contained or waning in many countries, scientists are still racing to discover the its source. The virus that causes severe acute respiratory syndrome is a newly discovered member of the coronavirus family. Other family members cause mild infections like the common cold in humans and much more serious diseases among animals.

title: A Well-Traveled Doctor Turns Trauma Into Fiction
description: As a doctor specializing in international health, John Murray served in Burundi, Tajikistan, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Ghana and Uganda and brought back stories of disease, bravery and survival -- all of them grist, it turned out, for fiction, a debut collection of short stories called ''A Few Short Notes on Tropical Butterflies.'' Yet this is fiction that holds firmly to scientific principles and comes with a harrowing edge of reality.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Anthrax Figure Injured
description: Dr. Steven J. Hatfill, named by the F.B.I. as a ''person of interest'' in its anthrax inquiry, was involved in a traffic incident last weekend with an F.B.I. agent who, Mr. Hatfill said, was following him. Dr. Hatfill, a bioweapons scientist, said a car was ''recording his movements all day when he decided to take a picture back,'' according to the police report. He was given a ticket for ''walking to create hazard'' after leaving his car with a camera and trying to confront the other driver. The car ran over his foot as it sped off, the report said. Federal officials have searched Dr. Hatfill's apartment twice in connection with the attacks in October 2001 that killed 5 people and sickened 13 others. Dr. Hatfill has denied involvement. John Files (NYT)

title: The Rams Sign Sehorn To a One-Year Contract
description: Jason Sehorn, a Giants defensive back for the last nine years, and Mike Martz, the coach of the St. Louis Rams, have not exactly been friends. That may change because the Rams, seeking help in the secondary, signed Sehorn to a one-year contract to play free safety yesterday.

title: Doctor Admits He Did Needless Surgery on the Mentally Ill
description: An eye doctor who preyed on the severely mentally ill pleaded guilty yesterday to a nearly $1 million fraud scheme in which he routinely rounded up residents of some of New York City's most notorious adult homes and subjected them to unnecessary surgery or charged for thousands of procedures that were never done.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPAN, TESSA
description: SAPAN-Tessa. The Board of Directors, Residents and Staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn the loss of Tessa Sapan, beloved mother of our esteemed Board member Joshua Sapan. We will miss Tessa's warmth and humor. We extend our condolences to Josh and the entire Sapan family. Milton Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Daniel Reingold, Exec. VP

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Bill Would Ban Sex In Public
description: The House Criminal Justice Committee unanimously approved a bill to ban sex in public. The minimum sentence would be 10 days in jail, with maximum penalties of a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Representative Daniel R. Martiny, Republican of Metairie, introduced the bill, which concerns sex between people regardless of gender after seeing what he called a ''very graphic, very offensive'' video of public sex taken last year by the Rev. Grant Storms, a minister, at Southern Decadence, a gay and lesbian festival in New Orleans. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State Supreme Court Nominee Confirmed
description: The State Senate yesterday confirmed an appellate court judge, John E. Wallace Jr., left, as Gov. James E. McGreevey's choice to the New Jersey Supreme Court. By a vote of 34 to 1, Judge Wallace, 61, will become the second African-American to serve on the court. He will replace the first black Supreme Court justice, James H. Coleman Jr., who reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 earlier this year. During his Senate hearing on May 8, Judge Wallace declined to give his views on the death penalty and on the financing of poor public school districts.

title: Market Place; Genentech Buoyed by Results Of New Tack on Colon Cancer
description: A drug that starves tumors of oxygen and nutrients has prolonged the lives of patients with colorectal cancer in a clinical trial, providing what doctors said yesterday was the first convincing validation of a new approach to treating cancer.

title: Archive to Issue Jewish Music CD's
description: After 13 years of researching various currents of American Jewish music and recording some of the music in the United States and in Europe, the Milken Family Foundation announced yesterday that in September it would begin issuing some of the recordings and other materials it has gathered.

title: U.S. Raises Terror Alert After Wave of Attacks Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  The Bush administration raised its terror alert this afternoon, saying there was a high risk of a new terrorist attack, following warnings that such an attack might be "imminent" in Saudi Arabia and signs that one was increasingly possible in the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Falls
description: Net income of the French bank Crdit Agricole fell 5.7 percent in the first quarter because of lower earnings from the bank's corporate and investment banking divisions. Good results in retail banking and asset management failed to offset losses in the value of its equity investments. Net profit dropped to 246 million euros ($285 million) from 261 million euros ($302 million), while gross operating income fell 28.2 percent, to 288 million euros ($334 million). Crdit Agricole, among France's largest banking concerns, is looking into a 19.5 billion euro purchase of Crdit Lyonnais. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Oil Field Acquisition
description: Canada's seventh-biggest oil company, Talisman Energy, agreed to buy BP's Gyda oil and gas fields in the North Sea for about 111 million Canadian dollars ($82 million) to expand into Norway. The fields have oil and gas reserves equal to more than 40 million barrels of oil, Talisman said. The company plans to spend about 241 million Canadian dollars developing the fields, which includes drilling wells.

title: Honors
description: Three agencies won best of show honors last week at the ninth annual FCS Portfolio Awards ceremony, sponsored by the Financial Communications Society, New York. Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, won in the corporate-image category for work for the E*Trade Financial division of the E*Trade Group. Fallon Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, won in the consumer retail category for work for the Citibank division of Citigroup. Publicis Worldwide, New York, also part of Publicis, won in the business-to-business category for work for the International Securities Exchange.

title: City to Phase Out Scatter-Site Apartments for Homeless Families
description: The Bloomberg administration will begin phasing out a troubled program that temporarily houses homeless families in individual apartments scattered throughout the city, officials said yesterday.

title: Professor in the Bleachers With a Lifelong Scorecard
description: TRIUMPH AND TRAGEDY IN MUDVILLE

title: In Brazil, All May Not Be as Relaxed as It Seems
description: When Telefnica of Spain took over So Paulo's creaky, state-run telephone monopoly in 1998, it installed millions of phone lines in record time and for a fraction of the price customers once had to pay.

title: He Won't Discuss Money, but He Now Accepts Visa
description: LLOYD CONSTANTINE is not talking about money, no matter how many pestering efforts are made. An antitrust lawyer, he has just extracted $3 billion from Visa USA and MasterCard International in settling a lawsuit over their debit card policies.

title: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! It's a Horse?
description: GENUINE New York heroes have been in short supply lately, whether in government, politics, business, law enforcement, sports or -- need it be mentioned? -- journalism. So wouldn't you know that when a hero finally does come along, it's a horse.

title: E-MAIL'S BACKDOOR OPEN TO SPAMMERS
description: At first, it looked as if some students at the Flint Hills School, a prep academy in Oakton, Va., had found a lucrative alternative to an after-school job. Late last year, technicians at America Online traced a new torrent of spam, or unsolicited e-mail advertisements, to the school's computer network.

title: Soldier From Brooklyn Dies When Hit by a Bullet in Iraq
description: A 22-year-old Army specialist from Brooklyn was killed in Iraq on Sunday when another soldier's gun discharged, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUG, ELLA GALVIN
description: KRUG-Ella Galvin, 85, of Quail Ridge Country Club, Boynton Beach, Florida, passed away at home and surrounded by her children on May 17, 2003. Ella Krug was predeceased by her husband Paul L. Krug in 1997. She is survived by her three brothers, John Galvin, Thomas Galvin and Rev. William Galvin, mm; her seven children, Pamela Boalt, Karen Krug, Paul Krug, John Krug, Sueanne Miller, Jude McLean and Peter Krug as well as sixteen grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. Ella was a loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Friends may call on Thursday, May 22, 2003 from 5pm to 7pm with a 6:30pm rosary service at the Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, 745 North Federal Highway, Delray Beach, FL 33483. A funeral mass will be celebrated on Friday, May 23, 2003, 11:00 am at St. Vincent Ferrer Church Chapel, 840 George Bush Blvd., Delray Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Maryknoll Fathers, Ossining, New York 10562 or Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, W. Palm Beach, FL 33407

title: A cat food company is producing a lighthearted TV show with its customers in the starring roles.
description: IN another example of the increased intertwining of programming and advertising, a leading maker of cat food and its agency want to give ''MTV'' a new meaning with ''Meow TV,'' a television show they are creating and sponsoring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, HELEN JONES
description: CARTER-Helen Jones, on May 17, 2003, at age 95. Beloved wife of Elliott Carter, loving mother of David Carter and grandmother of Alexander Elliott Carter-Parks. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to: American Association for People with Disabilities, 1629 K St. NW, Suite 503, Wash., D.C. 20006.

title: Smooth? How About Some Chunky?
description: Around 1974 a mutant strain of jazz broke apart from the main organism. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Thyssenkrupp To Sell Assets
description: The industrial conglomerate ThyssenKrupp plans to divest more noncore businesses, the company said after its supervisory board met. By focusing on its core divisions -- steel, capital goods and services -- ThyssenKrupp hopes to increase productivity 2 to 3 percent and sales to 40 billion euros ($46.35 billion) to 46 billion euros ($53.30 billion) in the midterm. In a step to avoid economic damage resulting from legislation in the United States, ThyssenKrupp repurchased 16.9 million shares for about 406 million euros from IFIC Holding, a state-owned Iranian company, thus decreasing IFIC's stake by 3.3 percent, to less than 5 percent. ThyssenKrupp said it would hold the shares for only a short period. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: CONTINENTAL IN DEAL WITH SKYWEST FOR TEXAS FLIGHTS
description: Continental Airlines Inc. contracted with a commuter carrier, SkyWest Inc., to provide flights from Houston to smaller Texas towns in the first link between the airlines. SkyWest will offer Continental Connection service from Houston to Killeen, beginning July 1, and to Waco, starting Aug. 1, a Continental spokesman, David Messing, said. Terms were not disclosed. Continental, which is based in Houston, discontinued service to Waco after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks because of lower demand, Mr. Messing said. The service to Killeen will replace jetliner service by ExpressJet Holdings Inc., which is Continental's primary commuter partner. Skywest is based in St. George, Utah.

title: Safety or Secrecy?
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has quietly issued new security standards that nuclear power plants must meet to defend against terrorist attacks. If this was intended to help people living near the plants sleep more soundly, it was a dismal failure. The few specific improvements the commission made public were unambitious, and it kept secret its ''design basis threat'' -- the elaborate set of rules spelling out the most likely terrorism attacks that the reactors must be protected against.

The costliest defense budget since the cold war -- more than $400 billion and counting -- is being gaveled through by the Republican leadership in a breathtaking few days of glancing debate. Good ideas for reforming the military are included. But so are outdated submarines and jet fighters designed for combat against the defunct Soviet threat.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Patchogue: Girl Dies After Boating Accident
description: A 16-year-old Queens girl died yesterday from injuries she sustained in a boating accident on Sunday that also killed her father and a family friend, the police said. The girl, Jacqueline Young, was pronounced dead at 6 a.m. at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center in East Patchogue, the Suffolk County police said. Jacqueline, her brother Kevin, 9, her parents and the friend had been out in a 22-foot pleasure boat when it capsized in the Moriches Inlet, a channel off Long Island's South Shore, the authorities said. The police said Susan Young, the children's mother, told them that she and her children had been in an air pocket under the capsized boat when she told them to try to swim to shore. Susan and Kevin Young survived.

title: HONDA UNIT WILL STOP LEASING VEHICLES IN 3 STATES
description: The Honda Motor Company's finance unit said yesterday that it would stop leasing vehicles to residents of New York, Connecticut and Rhode Island in July because of laws that leave leasing companies accountable in traffic accidents. Honda's action follows similar moves by the finance units of General Motors and Ford in response to the so-called vicarious liability laws. Such laws allow a leasing company to be held responsible for accidents caused by customers operating leased vehicles. Honda's unit, the American Honda Finance Corporation, based in Torrance, Calif., is offering customers alternatives to leasing a vehicle, including a $1,500 damage waiver on excess wear and use. The New York Legislature is considering changes to the state's leasing law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGAN, SUSAN BANCROFT
description: BERGAN-Susan Bancroft, 61 of New York City and Morris, CT. Died on Sunday May 18th, 2003. Beloved wife of Philip, proud mother of David of New York City and Jeffrey of San Francisco, CA. Loving mother-in-law-to-be of David's fiance Braden Cleveland of New York City and Charleston, SC. Devoted daughter of the late Dr. George H. and Mercedes W. Bancroft of Litchfield, CT and loving sister of the late Malcolm D. Bancroft of Ibiza, Spain. Graduate of Wellesley College (1963) and The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy (1964). As a Vice President of Citibank, N.A. in the 1970's and 80's she was responsible for loan syndication in the western hemisphere and in that role she played a major role in the restructuring of Latin American debt and in the early development of a market for the trading of bank loans. In 1985 she left Citibank to become Senior Vice President of Drexel Burnham Lambert. There, in 1987, she and her colleagues created one of the first funds to be devoted to investment in emerging markets debt and equity and she served as a manager of this fund (now TCW Worldwide Opportunities Fund) from its inception. Managing Director of Trust Company of the West from 1990. Chair of the Board of Trustees of the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York from 1991 to 1994; Co-Chair of the Stanford University Parents Advisory Board from 1997 to 1999; active in alumni affairs of both Wellesley College and The Fletcher School. Also a member of various business and professional organiztions. A person of rare energy and enthusiasm, caring and generous, with boundless curiosity concerning the world and its people, a pioneering woman in international finance, a dedicated church member, a wonderful cook, and a passionate fan of New York City. A loving wife, mother and friend. A funeral service will be held on Thursday May 22nd at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York City at 11am. In lieu of flowers the family suggests that contributions be made to Wellesley College, Development Services and Donor Relations, 106 Central Street, Wellesley, MA 02481 or to the Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 E. 92 St, NY, NY 10128-1398.

description: KIRCHGAESSNER - William. Of Hartsdale, N.Y. on May 18, 2003, after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Beloved husband and best friend of Christine Pisani. Loving father of Laura and Paul. Opa to Kaleb and Kenny. Cherished son of the late Erna and Erwin Kirchgaessner. Also survived by his brother Erwin and his family, and Rozella Kirchgaessner. Graduate of the High School of Music and Art, New York City; Columbia College; Brooklyn Law School. A member of the Bar of the Supreme Court of the United States. Lawyer, Judge and Deputy Commissioner at the New York City Commission on Human Rights for 22 years. Administrative Law Judge, Social Security Administration since 1994. His proudest accomplishment was that he enjoyed a ''normal'' life, lived to its fullest, despite being blind since infancy. Willie was adored by his family and large circle of close friends. His courage, optimism, humor and intelligence enriched everyone who knew him. He celebrated life and never cursed the darkness. A prince among men, we will love him always. The company's debt exceeded its asset value by $4.39 trillion won, an increase of a third since an accounting in April. Hana Bank, the lead creditor, asked others to make good on promises to provide financing for SK Global despite objections from shareholders. description: GIALLEONARDO - Victor. Passed away on May 19, 2003 at White Plains Hospital. He was 74 years old. description: When he snatched Bartolo Coln from under the noses of wealthier teams last season, Montreal General Manager Omar Minaya was hailed for making perhaps the trade of the year. Well, he has done it again with Coln, this time in trading him away.

title: Legislature Overrides Veto of $1.79 Billion City Aid Package
description: Acting with continued unity, the State Legislature handed Gov. George E. Pataki yet another resounding defeat today, voting overwhelmingly to override his veto of the Legislature's aid package for New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, SUSAN
description: KATZ-Susan. The Jewish Museum mourns the passing of Sue Katz, a devoted and passionate advocate for art and Jewish culture. As a founder of our Children's Hanukkah Program in 1995, Sue nurtured its growth through her enthusiasm, commitment, and energy. And as one of the first members of The Museum Council, she and her husband, Jerry, have been important supporters and dear friends for a decade. We extend sincerest condolences to Jerry, their sons, and the entire family. Susan Lytle Lipton, Chairman John L. Vogelstein, President Joan Rosenbaum, Helen Goldsmith Menschel Director

description: PEET-Adelaide (Cohen). Beloved wife of the late Irving Cohen and the late Abraham Peet. Devoted mother of Joel and David Cohen. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Joanna, and Nick. Adored mother-in-law of Terry Cohen. Services Tuesday, 9:45am at ''Weinstein-GarlickKirschenbaum Chapels'' 1153 Coney Island Ave, Bklyn, N.Y.

title: Court to Decide if Constitution May Sometimes Require Taxpayer Subsidies to Religion
description: Barely a year after ruling that the Constitution does not ban the use of taxpayer money for religious school tuition, the Supreme Court today agreed to take the next step and decide whether a public subsidy for religious instruction may under some circumstances be constitutionally required.

title: Better Than 50 Percent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Toys Take Little Ears On Trips In Sound
description: The composer Tod Machover, an expert on the use of electronic resources for music education, rightly points out that preschoolers are not compelled to take drawing lessons before they start making their own pictures with crayons and cut-up paper. So why, he asks, shouldn't children get immediately involved with playing and composing music without having to go through the drudgery of practicing scales and learning their lines and spaces?

title: National Briefing: South
description: MISSISSIPPI: PRISON FOR CITY COUNCIL PRESIDENT A former president of the Laurel City Council has been sentenced to five years in prison, with two years suspended, for taking bribes. Prosecutors said the former official, Thaddeus Edmonson, 49, took $5,000 from a builder to influence his vote on a road widening. The builder let investigators videotape meetings where the money was handed over, the state attorney general's office said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIND, CHARLOTTE LAZARUS
description: WITKIND-Charlotte Lazarus, 83, ''Char'' to all who knew her, of Columbus, Ohio, May 18, 2003, at home after a long illness. Born August 20, 1919 in Columbus. Nobody lived or loved life more than Char. She was the ultimate fan, of people and sports. Her passions were many and deep. Her partnerships with her forever-loving husband Dick and her beloved New York Yankees were deepest. Char's wondrous abilities with words, songs, and most of all, people, will leave us with memories that can never be erased. From New York to California to her home base in Columbus, her immediate and extended families grieve her passing, but will always cherish her incredible spirit, intellect, openness and joyful look at the world. Active alumna of Columbus School for Girls (1937) and Wellesley College (1941). Limited partner in the ownership of the Yankees, she and Dick traveled from Columbus to Yankee Stadium as often as possible. Her cheers could be heard for miles. Well-known and respected community activist. Vice President of the New York City League of Women Voters. Worked with innumerable organizations in Columbus, furthering community relations, baseball, public radio, and other causes. Preceded in death by parents Hattie and Robert Lazarus, Sr., sister Jean Lazarus Hoffman, and first husband Dr. Warren F. Gorman. Survived by devoted husband of nearly 45 years, Richard Jules Witkind; sister Babette (Howard) Lazarus Sirak; brother Robert (Mary) Lazarus, Jr.; sons Robert (Linda) Lazarus Gorman and Donald (Lisal) Gorman; daughters Babette T. Gorman and Vivian (Jack) Witkind Davis; eight grandchildren; one great grandchild (all of Columbus); numerous nephews and nieces; cousins by the dozens; and friends by the score. Char's life will be celebrated at the residence from 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM, Friday, May 23. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may contribute in her honor to Planned Parenthood of Central Ohio or the Mid-Ohio Food Bank.

title: MCI Agrees to Pay $500 Million In Fraud Case, S.E.C.'s Largest
description: MCI, the former WorldCom, agreed today to settle accusations of fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission by paying a $500 million penalty that will ultimately be given to investors.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: STATE SUPREME COURT NOMINEE CONFIRMED The State Senate yesterday confirmed an appellate court judge, John E. Wallace Jr., left, as Gov. James E. McGreevey's choice to the New Jersey Supreme Court. By a vote of 34 to 1, Judge Wallace, 61, will become the second African-American to serve on the court. He will replace the first black Supreme Court justice, James H. Coleman Jr., who reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 earlier this year. During his Senate hearing on May 8, Judge Wallace declined to give his views on the death penalty and on the financing of poor public school districts. (NYT)

title: Veal Thom Journal; What War Wrought, Cambodia Can't Stand to See
description: In Cambodia, old soldiers just seem to limp away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARZMAN, SUE
description: SWARZMAN-Sue. May 12, 2003. Beloved sister, aunt, niece and devoted friend to many. Her successful advertising sales career included Life and Business Week magazines. She was a dedicated member of 3rd Church of Christ Scientist for 40 years. Life celebration service Thursday, May 22, at 3 PM, at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Ave at 80th St.

title: Fast Start to Money Race For 2 House Newcomers
description: Representative Ral M. Grijalva is not the kind of man who enjoys small talk with lobbyists. Yet there he was last week, standing beside a breakfast buffet here, shaking hands with strangers who had paid $1,000 apiece for the privilege of chatting with him over eggs and sausage. He looked decidedly uncomfortable, like a wallflower dragged to the dance.

title: Marching in Baghdad, Thousands of Shiites Protest Against the U.S.
description: Thousands of Shiite Muslims protested here in the capital today, demanding that the United States turn over power to an Iraqi government and withdraw its troops from the country.

title: G.E. Union Warns of Strike Over Health Care Increases
description: General Electric's largest union, which staged a two-day walkout over health benefits in January, threatened to go on strike again next month as it began negotiations yesterday for a new contract covering 14,000 workers.

title: Stewart Suit Will Proceed
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia lost a bid to dismiss a lawsuit accusing its founder, Martha Stewart, of harming investors by failing to disclose her sale of ImClone Systems shares.

title: Japan Steps Up Efforts to Counter the Faltering Economy
description: TOKYO, May 20  Japanese policy makers stepped up efforts today to counter the slowing economy and to calm investors unnerved by the first major bank bailout in four years.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Truce With Church Ends In Failure
description: A 90-day truce between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston and lawyers for people who say they were sexually abused by priests has ended without a resolution. The moratorium was intended to let both sides work exclusively on settling more than 500 legal claims against the archdiocese. The plaintiffs' lawyers say that the archdiocese did not make an offer in the hiatus and that the cases, which resume immediately, could last for years. The interim leader of the archdiocese, Bishop Richard G. Lennon, has said he is committed to settling the cases out of court. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: WELLS FARGO TO BUY PACIFIC NORTHWEST BANCORP
description: Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Pacific Northwest Bancorp of Seattle for about $623 million in stock to expand in Washington and Oregon. Wells Fargo will exchange $35 a share in common stock for each share of Pacific Northwest, which has 17.8 million shares outstanding, a Wells Fargo spokeswoman, Marilyn Taylor, said. The offer is a 23 percent premium to Pacific Northwest's closing price of $28.44 yesterday. The deal was announced after the close of regular trading. Pacific Northwest, with about $3.1 billion in assets, focuses mainly on commercial banking in Washington and Oregon.

title: A Would-Be Rockefeller Gets A Deal He Can't Back Out Of
description: Christopher Rocancourt, the French-born faux Rockefeller accused of swindling wealthy and well-connected acquaintances out of more than $1.5 million, pleaded guilty yesterday in Brooklyn to three federal fraud charges.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SERENA SOFTWARE INC., San Mateo, Calif., a maker of software designed to improve the quality and reliability of Web sites, said it would buy TeamShare Inc., Colorado Springs, a maker of Web-based software for helping employees work together, for $18 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBER, PAUL A.
description: BARBER-Paul A., 56 years, of Brooklyn Heights, NY and Sharon, CT, died May 15, 2003. Vice President of Lochnau Inc. of Middleburg, VA. Formerly with Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. Survived by wife, Claudia Seymour Barber, sons, Andrew Barber and Peter Barber, and brother, John Barber III. Family will receive at Jere Cronin, 115 Atlantic Ave., Brooklyn, NY, on May 21, 7:30-8:30 PM. Funeral service St. Ann & Holy Trinity Church, Clinton and Montague Sts., Brooklyn Heights, NY, on May 22, at 7 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Ann & Holy Trinity Church, 157 Montague St., Brooklyn, NY 11201 for Capital Campaign or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, NY NY 10087 in memory of Paul Barber, wife of Claudia Barber.

title: Corrections
description: Articles last Tuesday and Wednesday about the killing of a Hunter College student whose body was found behind a boarded-up house in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, included a misspelling of her given name provided by the police and the college. She was Romona Moore, not Ramona.

title: Straphangers Strike Back
description: When New Yorkers fork over $2 apiece to ride city buses or subways, they deserve to know all the facts about why the Metropolitan Transportation Authority needs that much money. That seems obvious, but the M.T.A.'s longstanding refusal to be open about its finances has landed it in trouble. After the state comptroller's audit of the authority raised questions, a Manhattan court ordered a rollback of the recent 50-cent increase. The rollback was put on hold when the M.T.A. said it would appeal, but whatever the outcome, the stakes for the M.T.A. are bigger than four bits. Its credibility depends on a serious response to calls for financial transparency.

description: HONG KONG, May 20 — The most unlikely winners from the dollar's slide in currency markets are some of the countries now racking up the biggest trade surpluses with the United States, especially China.

description: Mullen in Wenham, Mass., part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is laying off about 10 percent of its 554 employees, the agency said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Expands
description: Singapore's economy grew more than initially reported in the first quarter as exports made up for a drop in local demand. The economy may shrink this quarter as the SARS virus curbs tourism and retail sales, economists said. The $88 billion economy expanded at an annual 1.1 percent pace, the Trade and Industry Ministry said, revising last month's estimate of 0.7 percent. From a year earlier, growth was 1.6 percent.

title: With Trouble at the Plate, Giambi Calls In His Father
description: John Giambi stood about 15 feet behind the batting cage at Fenway Park tonight and watched every one of his son Jason's practice swings. He followed a pitch to the plate and watched Jason uncork his ailing swing. Then the process was repeated, as the elder Giambi searched for flaws. He might have been watching more intently than Rick Down, the Yankees' intense batting coach, who was leaning on the cage and also studying the scene.

description: IMG is one of those businesses personified by its founder, Mark McCormack, who died last week at age 72. You can perceive of News Corporation without Rupert Murdoch, Cablevision without Chuck Dolan or Nascar without the France family, but their departures would cause changes in the companies' images.

description: The Devils are in a much better position than the Ottawa Senators, but they still seemed to be annoyed today with the way they lost on Monday night. They killed penalties for a fifth of the game, 12 minutes 4 seconds, and that is so unlike them.

description: Federal prosecutors yesterday charged a fourth man, whom they described as a captain in the Gambino crime family, in a scheme involving pornographic Web sites that investigators say were used to bilk Web users of $230 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Pumatech Shares Soar On Intuit License News
description: Shares of Pumatech, which makes software for wireless devices, rose more than 14 percent yesterday after the company said that Intuit had bought a license for a program to permit its software to work with products from other companies. Financial terms were not disclosed. Pumatech's software permits address-book information to be shared between Intuit's Quicken financial management software and products including Microsoft's Outlook for organizing e-mail and calendars and Palm's software that links hand-held devices to personal computers, Pumatech said. Intuit is one of the the world's biggest makers of tax-preparation software. Shares of Pumatech increased 39 cents, or 14.2 percent, to $3.14. Intuit shares rose $2.07, or 5.1 percent, to $42.62. Pumatech, which bought the Starfish Software division of Motorola in March, received 72 percent of its revenue from license sales in the third quarter, which ended April 30.

title: For Piazza And Mets, The News Is Grim
description: Mike Piazza gripped two crutches in his left hand as he entered the Mets' clubhouse yesterday and walked with just a slight limp. It was a vast improvement from how he felt last Friday night in San Francisco, when he felt a pop in a groin muscle as he jerked away from a fastball while in the batter's box and ended up leaving the ballpark in a wheelchair.

title: Brooklyn College's Largest Gift
description: CHRISTOPH M. KIMMICH, president of Brooklyn College, has announced the largest gift in the college's history: $10 million from two alumni, LEONARD TOW ('50) and CLAIRE TOW ('52). The money will be used for a new performing arts center to be named for the Tows. It will allow the college to bring together its arts programs, including music, television, theater and performing arts management. Dr. Kimmich said that the total cost was likely to be $25 million or more, and that he hoped to break ground in 2005, on the college's 75th anniversary.

description: In these wobbling economic times, it was only a question of when public officials would turn toward illegal immigrants and ask how much of a burden they pose to taxpayers.

title: Provocation in Cannes From a Wily Provocateur
description: The Cannes Film Festival, a paradise of film directors and a purgatory of publicists, is also a kind of summer camp for critics. They roam the smoky halls of the Palais des Festivals and the mobbed streets outside in overlapping cliques, gossiping, complaining and, true to professional form, disagreeing. You walk out of a morning competition screening in the cavernous, velvety darkness of the Salle Lumire, the grandest of the festival's screening rooms, choked with emotion by the incomparable masterpiece you have just seen, only to hear, by the time you arrive at your mailbox in the press area of the palais, that it is the most pretentious piece of garbage ever committed to film. Or you stagger out of the most pretentious piece of garbage ever committed to film and encounter a wet-eyed colleague who proclaims it a masterpiece.

title: Lord, They Hate To See Her Go
description: One of the oddest revelations in the recent television specials documenting Michael Jackson's personal life is that he makes his children wear masks in public to hide their identities from his fans and the news media. For most celebrities there are certain events that are sacred and always shielded: having children, getting married and dying. Mr. Jackson is an extreme example of this.

description: APersonal and Global Journey Into the Human Heart

title: New York To Speed Up Adoptions
description: The state and city plan to permit the adoption of 5,000 ''legal orphans'' by the end of the year, cutting courthouse backlogs that had left those children in foster care limbo for years after their biological parents had lost the right to raise them, according to lawyers who have been consulted on the plans. More than 3,500 of those children live in the city.

title: U.S. Suggests a Qaeda Cell in Iran Directed Saudi Bombings
description: The United States has intercepted communications strongly suggesting that a small cell of leaders of Al Qaeda in Iran directed last week's terrorist attacks in Saudi Arabia, and the United States is sending a strong protest to the Tehran government, according to senior Bush administration officials.
