description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Analysts Link Iraq Labs To Germ Arms
description: United States intelligence agencies have concluded that two mysterious trailers found in Iraq were mobile units to produce germs for weapons, but they have found neither biological agents nor evidence that the equipment was used to make such arms, according to senior administration officials.

title: U.N. Begins Effort in Iraq To Mend Health Services
description: The World Health Organization has begun a program aimed at bringing basic health services in Iraq back to their prewar level, which it says will cost up to $180 million.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: DEPARTING LEADER PARDONS PLOTTERS Saying "political violence is a thing of the past," the caretaker president, Eduardo Duhalde, who leaves office on Sunday, has announced that he will pardon the leaders of two attempts to overthrow the government more than a decade ago. Both Enrique Haroldo Gorriarán Merlo, a left-wing guerrilla whose attack on a military base in 1989 killed 39 people, and Mohamed Alí Seineldin, a right-wing military officer whose rebellion a year later resulted in the deaths of 13 soldiers, received life sentences. Mr. Duhalde's decision immediately drew widespread criticism.    Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: The Dreams of Peace, in Tatters
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y.U. Appoints Business Professor
description: SHEILA WELLINGTON, a longtime advocate for women in corporations, has been named a clinical professor of management at New York University's Stern School of Business. Ms. Wellington will retire this summer after 10 years as president of Catalyst, a nonprofit research group that focuses on the role of women in business. In her tenure, Catalyst's budget grew to $8 million from $2 million and Catalyst expanded its research to include Canada, Britain and Europe. Diana B. Henriques

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bid For Malls
description: The largest owner-manager of retail centers in Australia, Westfield, bid 1.9 billion Australian dollars ($1.2 billion) for eight regional malls in five Australian states controlled by the AMP Group, a troubled financial services company. AMP, Australia's largest life insurer and second in funds management, is trying to recover from losses in Australia and Britain that have cut its market value by two-thirds in 12 months to about 7 billion Australian dollars currently. The bid, which was welcomed by AMP and by market analysts, will be reviewed by federal regulators responsible for antitrust matters. Westfield controls retail centers in Australia valued at $14 billion and malls in the United States valued at $9 billion. It is supporting the Simon Group in its $7 billion bid for Taubman. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Asian Nations Gain Indirectly From Dollar's Declining Value
description: The most unlikely winners from the dollar's slide in value are some of the countries compiling the biggest trade surpluses with the United States, especially China.

title: Civil Service Exam Bonus Is Resisted for 9/11 Siblings
description: Last year the State Legislature passed a law granting an advantage on the Civil Service examinations to the children of firefighters and police officers who died in the Sept. 11 attack. The city, eager to offer concrete help to victims' families, supported the bill, as did the fire and police unions.

title: N.Y.U. Center to Study Israel
description: New York University is using a gift of more than $3 million from the Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation to form a research center for the study of modern Israel. It will be called the Taub Center for Israel Studies and will be part of the university's Faculty of Arts and Sciences. Mr. Taub, a 1947 graduate of the School of Commerce (now the Stern School of Business) at N.Y.U., is a co-founder of Automatic Data Processing, a payroll and tax filing processor.

title: A Southern-Fried Picnic, to Go
description: NO matter where you live, Southern-fried chicken is the ultimate picnic food. It is best eaten with your hands when you are propped up on an elbow, stretched out on a blanket. With summer bearing down, I set out to find the city's best takeout birds, Southern-fried and bundled up in large quantities to take to the park, the beach or the rooftop.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit For Entertainment Concern
description: The entertainment company Granada said its profit rose 35 percent in the first half of its fiscal year, helped by strong ad sales and increased cost-cutting. Granada, which owns the ITV television networks in Britain, said that pretax profit for the six-month period ended March 31 was 65 million ($106 million), versus 48 million ($78 million) a year earlier. Granada's chairman, Charles Allen, above, said the strong showing resulted from successful shows the company produced, like ''Coronation Street,'' ''Living With Michael Jackson'' and ''I'm a Celebrity . . . Get Me Out of Here!'' News of the profit set off a rally in the company's stock, which rose 6.75 pence, to 78.5 pence a share. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Suit Accuses Macy's of Bias Against Minority Shoppers
description: Blacks and other minority shoppers at Macy's are more likely to be detained on suspicion of shoplifting than whites, according to a civil rights lawsuit filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Tutu Is Awarded Medal In Ceremony at Cathedral
description: The Most Rev. Desmond M. Tutu, archbishop emeritus of Capetown, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize and chairman of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, is best known for his political stands.

title: Cranberry Grower Is Sued For Land-Preservation Sale
description: The older brother of one of New Jersey's largest cranberry growers went to court yesterday seeking to stop the sale of nearly 10,000 acres of family farms and pristine woodlands in South Jersey to a preservationist group.

title: What Vegetarianism Is
description: To the Editor:

title: On Cuban Independence Day, Bush Is Silent on New Penalties
description: President Bush celebrated Cuban independence day today by meeting with former political prisoners and relatives of Cuban dissidents, but he disappointed many of his staunchest Cuban-American supporters by not announcing new sanctions against Havana.

title: Where Coming Attractions Are the Show
description: GENERALLY, it's not a good sign when a restaurant starts fiddling and fussing with its format, and few restaurants have done more fiddling and fussing in recent years than the Tonic, now reborn as Amuse. Every few months, it seemed, a press release would announce a new chef, a new concept and a new dawn. The place seemed to be caught in a rolling identity crisis. Was it a glorified saloon? A hip lounge? A music club? A fine-dining destination? All of the above, and so much more, according to its publicists.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Flu Cases On Cruise
description: Scores of passengers and crew members on a weeklong cruise between Seattle and Alaska came down with a stomach flu caused by a norovirus, or Norwalk-like virus, but health officials said the illnesses did not constitute an outbreak. About 55 passengers and 5 crew members reported flu-like symptoms on Norwegian Cruise Lines' Norwegian Sky, which arrived in Seattle on Saturday. Twenty other passengers reported similar symptoms after disembarking. The Norwalk virus is the most common gastrointestinal virus, with over 23 million cases reported last year, James Apa, spokesman for Seattle-King County Public Health, said.

title: Banker-Analyst Firewall Plan to Be Revisited
description: Securities regulators plan to meet tomorrow with investment bank officials in New York to discuss whether proposed regulations on the interaction between bankers and research analysts may need to be clarified.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORE, LEO
description: GORE-Leo. Five years ago today. We miss you and you're in our hearts forever. With all our love, Ronny, Lesley and Michae

title: House G.O.P. Leaders Agree To Eliminate Dividend Tax
description: House Republican leaders agreed today to go along with the White House and the Senate and eliminate the tax on stock dividends, if only briefly, and Congressional Republican leaders promised to move swiftly to complete action on the bill this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRACH, ROBERT MAX
description: BRACH-Robert Max. May 21, 1943-January 1, 2000. Eternal Love, Your Frederick

title: U.S. Chasing Fraud in Fund-Raising for 'Charity'
description: The Federal Trade Commission and charity regulators in 16 states brought lawsuits yesterday against several fund-raising organizations, charging them with fraudulently soliciting donations by misrepresenting themselves as legitimate nonprofit organizations.

title: Clashing With Pinstripes; Red Sox Fans Recoil in Yankees' Backyard
description: ''What would I recommend for a Red Sox fan living in New York?'' asked Harvey Frommer, the baseball historian, Dartmouth College professor and Yankee fan, who is currently working on an oral history about the rivalry between the two teams. ''Wear a disguise.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protest In Harlem Over Police Raid
description: Two dozen people gathered in front of the 25th Precinct station house in Harlem yesterday to protest the death of Alberta Spruill, the 57-year-old woman who died on May 16 after police officers mistakenly raided her home and set off a concussion grenade. The group walked to the precinct, on 119th Street between Lexington Avenue and Park Avenue, from the building at 310 West 143rd Street where Ms. Spruill lived. Organizers said they were not satisfied with statements by police officials that the incident was under investigation. ''We've got to start policing the police,'' said one of the organizers, Calvin B. Hunt, president of the East Harlem Community Watch program. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: From a Variety of Sources, A Sound All His Own
description: Daniel Bernard Roumain, composer and violinist Merkin Concert Hall

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGAN, SUSAN BANCROFT
description: BERGAN-Susan Bancroft, 61 of New York City and Morris, CT. Died on Sunday May 18th, 2003. Beloved wife of Philip, proud mother of David of New York City and Jeffrey of San Francisco, CA. Loving mother-in-law-to-be of David's fiance Braden Cleveland of New York City and Charleston, SC. Devoted daughter of the late Dr. George H. and Mercedes W. Bancroft of Litchfield, CT and loving sister of the late Malcolm D. Bancroft of Ibiza, Spain. Graduate of Wellesley College (1963) and The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy (1964). As a Vice President of Citibank, N.A. in the 1970's and 80's she was responsible for loan syndication in the western hemisphere and in that role she played a major role in the restructuring of Latin American debt and in the early development of a market for the trading of bank loans. In 1985 she left Citibank to become Senior Vice President of Drexel Burnham Lambert. There, in 1987, she and her colleagues created one of the first funds to be devoted to investment in emerging markets debt and equity and she served as a manager of this fund (now TCW Worldwide Opportunities Fund) from its inception. Managing Director of Trust Company of the West from 1990. Chair of the Board of Trustees of the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York from 1991 to 1994; Co-Chair of the Stanford University Parents Advisory Board from 1997 to 1999; active in alumni affairs of both Wellesley College and The Fletcher School. Also a member of various business and professional organiztions. A person of rare energy and enthusiasm, caring and generous, with boundless curiosity concerning the world and its people, a pioneering woman in international finance, a dedicated church member, a wonderful cook, and a passionate fan of New York City. A loving wife, mother and friend. A funeral service will be held on Thursday May 22nd at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York City at 11am. In lieu of flowers the family suggests that contributions be made to Wellesley College, Development Services and Donor Relations, 106 Central Street, Wellesley, MA 02481 or to the Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 E. 92 St, NY, NY 10128-1398.

title: Few Doctors At Protests On Insurance In New York
description: Doctors and their supporters held demonstrations across New York State yesterday, calling for state and federal legislation to limit lawsuit awards that they contend are driving up health care costs.

title: Liberia Seen as Icon of World's Neglect of Africa
description: At a popular restaurant here on the water's edge, the dinner menu offers a rare item: a vegetarian version of the traditional West African groundnut stew. Vegetarianism is anathema in this part of the world. But adjustments have had to be made in Sierra Leone because the world is here.

title: The Dreams of Peace, in Tatters (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ice Cream Man Lured Girls, Officials Says
description: An ice cream truck driver in New Jersey was charged yesterday with enticing 12- and 13-year-old girls into his truck with the promise of free or discounted ice cream, and then attempting to kiss or fondle them.

title: Trenton Girls Sweep Three Sprint Relays
description: The girls team of Trenton Central swept three sprint relays and Toms River North's two-man pole-vault relay set a boys' meet record in the East Coast Relays at Morristown (N.J.) High School on Monday night.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: U.S. Envoy Wants Elections
description: Richard Haass, President Bush's special envoy to Northern Ireland, meeting leaders of rival parties for two days, said there was no reason to be ''discouraged'' by the stalled peace negotiations that have kept a five-year-old government in limbo since October. ''We've had a setback, yes, but this is not a crisis,'' he said. The British prime minister, Tony Blair, postponed elections to the home-rule legislature on May 1 after the Irish Republican Army failed to provide a firm commitment that it would cease all operations. Mr. Haass said he wanted the elections as soon as possible. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Big Shopping Mall Owner Is Allowed to Block Bid
description: A federal judge in Michigan yesterday suspended her ruling that would have stripped A. Alfred Taubman's family of its right to vote any of its shares to block a takeover bid for its shopping mall empire, Taubman Centers.

title: Bush Issues Directive Describing Policy on Antimissile Defenses
description: President Bush issued a directive today describing his approach to deploying missile defenses and encouraging America's allies to join in the effort. He said his objective was to counter enemies around the world who try to use long-range missiles ''as tools of extortion and aggression.''

title: Bush Weighs Mideast Trip as Peace Plan Ebbs
description: President Bush, intervening to salvage his administration's battered Middle East peace plan, today called the new Palestinian prime minister for the first time, and administration officials said he was considering traveling to the region in the next few weeks for the first time as president.

title: Israeli Who Loves Israel Listens, Sees and Weeps
description: DEATH AS A WAY OF LIFE

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: A Stereotype
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 14 about Republicans who favor a Senate campaign by Asa Hutchinson, a senior official at the Department of Homeland Security, misstated the title of Karl Rove, who has reportedly talked to him about the possibility. Mr. Rove is President Bush's senior political adviser, not the White House political director.

title: Security Is Stepped Up At Landmarks And Borders
description: Law enforcement authorities in several large cities increased security yesterday as the Bush administration put the nation on its second-highest alert level.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: MARCONI TO MARKET METALLIC POWER FUEL CELLS The British telecommunications equipment maker Marconi said yesterday that it would market fuel cells from Metallic Power as a backup power supply for small telecommunications installations. The deal is the first significant order for a large-scale fuel cell that generates power by combining with oxygen rather than with hydrogen. The two companies did not disclose the terms of the partnership but said that thousands of telecommunication sites could use the technology. Metallic Power, a privately held company based in Carlsbad, Calif., said that its cells provide up to 5 kilowatts of backup power for 24 hours, three times the duration of lead-acid batteries, which are often backed up with auxiliary gas-fired generators. The zinc cells automatically regenerate when power from the electricity grid is restored.    Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPAN, TESSA
description: SAPAN-Tessa. The Board of Directors, Residents and Staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn the loss of Tessa Sapan, beloved mother of our esteemed Board member Joshua Sapan. We will miss Tessa's warmth and humor. We extend our condolences to Josh and the entire Sapan family. Milton Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Daniel Reingold, Exec. VP

title: Confident, Sorenstam Is Ready for Her Big Climb
description: In front of a crowded room today, with more than 400 news media members who had come to chronicle whatever she does, Annika Sorenstam did not play down the difficulty of this week's task.

title: Conseco Reports Net Loss
description: Conseco Inc., the insurance company, said yesterday that its first-quarter net loss was $19 million, less than the company predicted last week.

title: Iraqi Politicians to Issue a Protest of Occupation Rule
description: Iraq's main political groups said tonight that they were drafting a formal statement of protest to the American and British authorities over their plans to declare an occupation authority in Iraq, which would delay the rapid turnover of sovereignty to an interim Iraqi government.

title: Israeli Troops Kill 2 Palestinians in Clash in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, May 21  Israeli troops shot dead two Palestinians, including a mother of eight children, during a clash today in a West Bank village, Palestinians said. The Israeli Army also rolled back into a Palestinian town in the Gaza Strip a day after pulling out.

title: Hints of a Bid Forming for Vivendi Units
description: Edgar Bronfman Jr. is trying to put together a group to buy back many of the entertainment properties his family sold to Vivendi in a deal that turned sour, according to several executives close to the negotiations.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Economy Slows A Bit
description: Indonesian economic growth slowed less than economists had expected in the first quarter, as strong agricultural output offset weaker growth in consumer spending. The economy expanded 3.43 percent compared with the same quarter of 2002 after growing 3.82 percent in the three months before. While the government has said its new campaign against rebels in Aceh province will have little effect on its budget, some investors believe it will further discourage foreign investment. Currency traders appeared to believe otherwise yesterday, and drove the Indonesian rupiah to its highest level against the United States dollar in 21 months on expectations that government asset sales would lure funds from overseas. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: A Skirmish Over Rights To 2 Drugs Is Settled
description: The Elan Corporation said today that it had settled its legal battle with King Pharmaceuticals of Bristol, Tenn., over the sale of rights to two of Elan's drugs in the United States to King.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sanitation Union Plans Ad Campaign
description: The union representing the city's sanitation workers plans to run full-page ads in several newspapers today protesting New York City's decision to lay off 515 sanitation workers and to cut trash pickups to once a week in many neighborhoods. The ads, run by the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, say that the union has been a model of increased productivity, saving the city more than $2 billion since 1980, when it agreed to go to trucks with two workers instead of three. The ads, costing more than $70,000, say that the layoffs penalize the workers for doing more work. ''Laying off sanitation workers makes no sense,'' the ads read. ''It will mean dirty streets, storage problems, reduced income from tourism and health hazards.'' City Hall officials say they reluctantly carried out layoffs because the municipal unions would not agree to $600 million in labor savings. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Home Depot Profit Up 6%; Other Retailers Mixed
description: Home Depot, the home-improvement chain, said yesterday that first-quarter profit increased 6 percent after new products like John Deere lawn tractors bolstered revenue. Sales at older stores declined less than expected, sending the shares up.

title: Results of Costly Emphysema Operation Are Mixed, Study Finds
description: An expensive and widely promoted lung operation for severe emphysema can make many patients feel better but on average does not prolong their lives, researchers said yesterday, reporting on the first large study of the procedure.

title: U.S. Heightens Security
description: Citing attacks abroad, the government raised the nation's threat alert to its second-highest level. Page A19.

title: 'Practice' Returning, but Minus Some Stars
description: After much deliberation, ABC decided last week to bring back its long-running but recently struggling drama ''The Practice,'' and even flew the show's stars to New York to parade them in front of advertisers during its presentation of its new fall season.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Departing Leader Pardons Plotters
description: Saying ''political violence is a thing of the past,'' the caretaker president, Eduardo Duhalde, who leaves office on Sunday, has announced that he will pardon the leaders of two attempts to overthrow the government more than a decade ago. Both Enrique Haroldo Gorriarn Merlo, a left-wing guerrilla whose attack on a military base in 1989 killed 39 people, and Mohamed Al Seineldin, a right-wing military officer whose rebellion a year later resulted in the deaths of 13 soldiers, received life sentences. Mr. Duhalde's decision immediately drew widespread criticism. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yaphank: Body Found In Suffolk County
description: The police were investigating the death of a man whose body was found floating in the Great South Bay on Monday morning. A clammer discovered the body about 500 feet offshore at Amityville about 9:40 a.m., the Suffolk County Police said. They identified the victim as William Niclas, 44, of Amityville. The police said Mr. Niclas was seen around midnight on Sunday, leaving in his boat from the dock of an Amityville bar and towing a second boat that he owned. Both vessels were found beached on Elder Island yesterday. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a delayed vote on the promotion of an Army general who commanded a base where a gay soldier was beaten to death referred incorrectly in some copies to the home state of Senator Daniel K. Akaka, who urged a review of the nomination. It is Hawaii, not Alaska.

title: Out of Retirement, Into the Fire
description: THE new place on the Rue de Montalembert, a few short blocks from the Muse d'Orsay on the Left Bank, doesn't cover its tables with snowy damask, nor does it set them with Baccarat and Christofle. In fact, it doesn't have any tables.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Mad Cow Case Raises Worries in United States
description: The announcement made yesterday that a case of mad cow disease had been discovered in a dead cow in Alberta raised anxiety in the United States food industry, which buys about three-fourths of Canada's beef exports.

title: A Fiddler With Roots and Electronics
description: Ashley MacIsaac had enough personality for a stageful of performers at the Knitting Factory last Wednesday night. He was a cackling, iconoclastic raconteur, an idiosyncratic singer, a canny bandleader and, most important, a fiddler who has honed Cape Breton traditional styles to a ferocious edge. Mr. MacIsaac doesn't want to be stuck in the sphere of traditionalist music, but that's still where he's most potent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRONE, GERARD GEORGE
description: FERRONE-Gerard George. On May 18, 2003 at age 84. Beloved husband, for over 60 years, of Jeanie. Also survived by devoted children Jean and husband Chip, Joanna, Rod, Chris and wife Hilary, Chessy and husband Bill, Nick and wife Stephanie, and Willie and wife Tarra, and by twelve grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Predeceased by cherished daughter Lisa, granddaughter Jandaya, sister Marjorie, and brother Michael. Service at Saint James Church, Chatham, N.Y. 10AM on Friday, May 23rd.

title: No Breakthrough at Sharon-Abbas Meeting
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon recently offered to withdraw the Israeli Army from the centers of most Palestinian cities in the West Bank, as well as from the northern Gaza Strip, in exchange for a Palestinian commitment to crack down on terrorism in those areas, officials familiar with the proposal said today.

title: Corrections
description: The New Economy column in Business Day on Monday, about the wiki, a technology for online interaction, misspelled the name of the home city of Global Business Network, a consulting company that uses a corporate version of the software. It is Emeryville, Calif., not Emoryville.

title: MIRANT TO SELL MOST OF STAKE IN POWER PLANT TO G.E.
description: The Mirant Corporation has agreed to sell almost all of its 50 percent stake in a Virginia power plant to a General Electric unit, GE Structured Finance, for about $71 million. The plant, near Fredricksburg, Va., can generate 242 megawatts, enough power for 193,600 homes. Mirant will have a book gain of $41 million on the sale, the company said yesterday. The transaction is scheduled to close this year pending lender consent and other approvals. Mirant, based in Atlanta, is keeping a 0.5 percent interest in the power generator. GE International, through GE Power Systems, will assume the operation and maintenance agreement associated with the plant, Mirant said. Cogentrix Energy Inc., based in Charlotte, N.C., owns 50 percent of the generator.

title: Lincoln and Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: A Head Start for Backyard Cooks in a Hurry
description: Brother Jimmy's BBQ, which has three restaurants in Manhattan, knows that New Yorkers often grill in a hurry, so it has assembled packs of precooked ribs to go. Throw the ribs on a hot grill, baste them liberally with the sauce that comes with them and in minutes they are ready to serve. The tender Northern ribs, left, were by far the best of the various meats I tried on my grill.

title: Appeals Court Allows Trial In Auto Review
description: The federal appeals court in San Francisco on Monday allowed a product disparagement case against the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine to proceed to trial. Eleven dissenting judges called the decision ''the death of consumer ratings.''

title: Walk This Way
description: Call me a civil liberties prude, but I don't want John Poindexter tracking my body part contours.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Greenspan Says Fed Is on Guard Against Deflation
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said today that he remained confident that economic conditions were poised for a turnaround. But Mr. Greenspan also spent considerable time assuring a Congressional committee in Washington that the central bank stood ready to do whatever might be necessary to protect the economy from a bout of falling prices, otherwise known as deflation.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Some Best-Priced Space Isn't Even on the Market
description: The space was not officially on the market, but executives at Julien J. Studley, a tenants' broker, learned that whole floors in the Bertelsmann Building at Broadway and 45th Street might be available. In short order they negotiated a 15-year lease for 180,000 square feet for the law firm of Pillsbury Winthrop, which will move from 1 Battery Park Plaza downtown to six floors in Times Square after July 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRCHGAESSNER, WILLIAM
description: KIRCHGAESSNER - William. Of Hartsdale, N.Y. on May 18, 2003, after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Beloved husband and best friend of Christine Pisani. Loving father of Laura and Paul. Opa to Kaleb and Kenny. Cherished son of the late Erna and Erwin Kirchgaessner. Also survived by his brother Erwin and his family, and Rozella Kirchgaessner. Graduate of the High School of Music and Art, New York City; Columbia College; Brooklyn Law School. A member of the Bar of the Supreme Court of the United States. Lawyer, Judge and Deputy Commissioner at the New York City Commission on Human Rights for 22 years. Administrative Law Judge, Social Security Administration since 1994. His proudest accomplishment was that he enjoyed a ''normal'' life, lived to its fullest, despite being blind since infancy. Willie was adored by his family and large circle of close friends. His courage, optimism, humor and intelligence enriched everyone who knew him. He celebrated life and never cursed the darkness. A prince among men, we will love him always. Calling hours at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, N.Y., Tuesday, May 20th and Wednesday, May 21st from 7-9PM. Funeral service Thursday, May 22nd, 11AM at the Funeral Home.

title: Tempering Rage by Drawing Comics; A Memoir Sketches an Iranian Childhood of Repression and Rebellion
description: In the early 1990's, as an art student at Tehran University, Marjane Satrapi took an anatomical drawing course. Students were provided with a female model draped in a chador; their sketches of black, formless figures must have been instructive in cultivating an appreciation of the absurd, at least.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: SARS PUSHES UP UNEMPLOYMENT Joblessness in Hong Kong rose to 7.8 percent in the period from February through April, compared with 7.5 percent in January through March. Underemployment, in which people settle for part-time jobs even though they want full-time work, rose to 3.2 percent from 2.9 percent. The government blamed an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome that began in mid-March and has hurt airlines, hotels, restaurants, travel agencies and stores. Although only one new case was reported on Monday and four yesterday, the government predicted the unemployment rate would continue to rise in the near future and has already announced a plan to provide temporary, government-paid jobs for 21,000 workers. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Back to a World in Which Weirdness Seemed Unusual
description: What does it say that Eric Bogosian's determinedly eerie monologue ''Notes From Underground,'' which he wrote and first performed in the early 1990's, feels so tame and dated today?

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SUSPICIONS HALT RAIL SERVICE Pennsylvania Station was partly evacuated yesterday afternoon and service on Amtrak was halted for nearly three hours after the authorities received a report of a suspicious man aboard a train from Washington, said an Amtrak spokesman, Dan Stessel. When it arrived at 12:18 p.m., a police dog was taken through the train and indicated that it found something in the man's possessions. Track 10 and the level above it were evacuated, Mr. Stessel said. Service was restored just before 3 p.m., he said. Service on the Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit was also delayed. The man was questioned by the Amtrak police and then turned over to the Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services, Mr. Stessel said. He had no information on the man's identity or the circumstances that led to the report. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A review of Cirque du Soleil's latest show, ''Varekai,'' on May 1 misstated the nationality of some ''dervishlike'' dancers. They are Georgian, not Russian.

title: House Vote Supports Thinning of Trees on Federal Land
description: The House voted today to hasten the burning of underbrush and thinning of trees on federal land, supporting what would be one of the most significant changes in forest policy in 100 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIES, BLAIR HAWES
description: DAVIES-Blair Hawes, of Yorktown Heights, NY on May 17, 2003. Beloved wife of Hugh Davies, loving mother of Linda, Timothy, Daphne and Melanie. Grandmother of Sarah, Meredith, Blair, Peter, Breanna and Oriana. Great grandmother of Patrick, James, Owen and Liam.

title: Cornell Given $50 Million
description: Cornell University's Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College has received an anonymous bequest of $50 million, which it will use as a challenge grant for its $750 million capital campaign. The grant will permit donors to direct matching funds to their area of interest, and donors will receive recognition for the total matched gift, college officials said. The campaign has already raised $386 million.

title: City English Scores In Statewide Testing Show Marked Gain
description: New York City public school students posted sharp gains on the state's standardized reading and writing test this year, with striking double-digit jumps in some of the city's poorest and historically lowest-performing school districts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, ALBERT
description: PRATT-Albert. Of Key Largo, FL, and Osterville, MA, died at home of cancer on May 16, 2003. Mr. Pratt was born May 23, 1911 in West Newton, MA. He graduated from the Country Day School, Harvard College 1933, and Harvard Law School 1936. He was general partner of Paine Webber, and later president of Paine Webber Properties. Mr. Pratt served in the Navy during World War II as a Lt. Comdr., and was awarded the Navy Legion of Merit. He served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy in the Eisenhower administration and received the Distinguished Civilian Medal. He was a visiting member of the Board of Overseers of Harvard, Director of Harvard Alumni Fund, President of the Investment Bankers Association, President of the Boston Chamber of Commerce and on the Board of the Deaconess Hospital. He was a member of the Cruising Club of America, The New York Yacht Club and Key Largo Anglers Club. His first wife, Alice M. (Lee) died January 1, 1976. He is survived by his widow Fanny Gray (Little), his five children, Lally Pratt of Shelburne Falls, MA, Cornelia P. McClure of San Francisco, Nina L. Pratt of Narragansett, RI, Frederick Halfdan (Dan) Pratt of Hadley, MA, Kate P. Lapping of Ashfield, MA. He will also be remembered by his wife's children, Catherine A. Peltier of Arlington, VA, Henry Morgan of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, Polly M. Timken of Old Saybrook, CT, and Joan Morgan of Washington, DC. Memorial service Thursday, May 29, 2:00 PM at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Wianno Ave., Osterville, MA. Donations in his memory to St. Peter's Church, Osterville, MA; Mystic Seaport, Mystic CT; Medical Center at Ocean Reef, Key Largo, FL.

title: Warlords Yield to Afghan Leader, Pledging to Hand Over Funds
description: President Hamid Karzai signed an agreement with Afghanistan's most powerful regional governors today to hand over their customs revenues to the central government and to stop all military interference in political and civil affairs in their regions.

title: For One Winery, One Vineyard Per Wine
description: IT can be argued that modern American wines came into their own in the 1940's and 50's, when they began to be identified by the names of the grapes used to make them.

title: SARS Fears Shake Taiwan Medical Staffs
description: Even as SARS crops up in more hospitals here, the health care system is facing a new crisis: doctors and, particularly, nurses resigning en masse.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I want to stress the cow did not go into the food chain. I want to stress from the beginning this is one cow.''

title: Nets Make a Stand and Take Two on the Road
description: With his jaw fixed and his feet planted, Jason Kidd had no intention of going for Chauncey Billups's head fake. He positioned himself within breath's reach of Billups, the Detroit Pistons' star guard. Kidd raised his arms defiantly and dared Billups to win the game in the final 1.8 seconds.

title: Senate Votes To Lift Ban On Producing Nuclear Arms
description: The Senate agreed tonight to lift a ban on research and development of smaller nuclear weapons, rejecting Democratic arguments that any step toward such arms could spur other nations to build tactical nuclear weapons of their own.

title: McGraw-Hill Refuses Data to U.S. Regulator
description: McGraw-Hill is refusing to disclose information about natural gas trades that it used to compute price indexes, federal regulators said yesterday as they asked a judge to order the company to comply with a subpoena.

title: Peter Flint Joyce; Banker, 61
description: Peter Flint Joyce, a retired Southern California banking executive who took a special interest in golf, helping to organize the 1992 U.S. Open, among other efforts, died on May 13 at his home in Pebble Beach, Calif. He was 61.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILENTZ, PAMELA ENDACOTT
description: WILENTZ-Pamela Endacott. Sculptor, teacher, beloved wife of Eli and exceptional mother of Grace, on May 19, at age 54. During her joyous life, Pam affirmed beauty and the human spirit in her art and in her love for others. She fought wonderfully, unforgettably, for years against her illness. Family and friends grieve the loss of her incandescent force. Survived by her loving daughter, her mother, Dorothy, and her stepchildren Sean, Eileen, and Philip. There will be a reception at home on Thursday, May 22 at 4PM.

title: Censorship And Politics? Views Differ Over Exhibit
description: The controversy over oil and gas drilling in Alaska spilled over into a routine Congressional hearing today as senators from Alaska and Illinois exchanged pointed remarks about whether political influence had determined how photographs of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge were displayed at a Smithsonian museum.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: TURKEY: SUICIDE BOMB IN ANKARA A suicide bomber blew herself up in a cafe in Ankara, the capital, injuring one other person. The police said they believed that the woman's explosives had detonated by accident and linked her to a far-left group, the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front or DHKP-C, a banned Marxist group.    (AP)

title: Where Did Sitcoms Go?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hewlett posts higher earnings but does not see a near-term turnaround of the technology sector.
description: A YEAR after its merger with Compaq, Hewlett-Packard posted fiscal second-quarter earnings yesterday that beat Wall Street's estimates despite continued weakness in technology spending.

title: F.D.A. CITES VIOLATIONS AT CONMED, SURGICAL TOOLS MAKER
description: The ConMed Corporation, a maker of surgical power tools, violated federal manufacturing standards at a plant in Colorado, the Food and Drug Administration said. The regulator sent the company, based in Utica, N.Y., a letter dated May 8 saying flaws were detected during an inspection of the plant in March. ConMed did not follow procedures to assure its devices met F.D.A. regulations, the agency said. The company has revised procedures to comply with F.D.A. rules, the chief financial officer, Robert D. Shallish Jr., said. ''We think we've addressed their concerns,'' Mr. Shallish said.

title: Corrections
description: The 36 Hours column in Escapes on May 9, about Morgantown, W.Va., misstated the size of a planned performing arts center. It will have 1,500 seats, not 15,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENEROFF, LAWRENCE
description: DENEROFF-Lawrence. On May 20, 2003. You made it to the millennium & beyond-but we will miss you so. Adored husband to Mickey. Best Dad to Steven and Patti. Caring grandfather to Kelsey, Kathryn & Michael. Loving sister to Mimi. Services private.

title: A Pork Burger That Does the Salsa
description: SUZANNE GOIN has a cooking rsum that would make most aspiring chefs groan. Her career began here, at Ma Maison, when she was just 17, and rambled on to Al Forno in Providence, R.I.; Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif.; Arpge in Paris; Michela's in Boston; and back to Los Angeles at Campanile, among others.

title: Woman Says Fear Invaded Cabin of Immigrants' Truck
description: As Tyrone M. Williams drove toward a government checkpoint 100 miles north of the Mexican border last week with his tractor-trailer of human cargo, the woman in the passenger seat began to worry aloud, she has told investigators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTMAN, PHYLLIS (NEE KLINGER)
description: MITTMAN-Phyllis (nee Klinger). We mourn the loss and passing of our loving mother and grandmother on May 19, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Mittman and mother of Leslie, (Mrs. John Lehman), and Judy (Mrs. Michael Elfenbein). Cherished grandmother of Stephanie and Jeffrey Lehman, and Jason and David Elfenbein. You are in our hearts. Your memory will be with us forever. Services today at 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a donation to a charity of your choice in her memory.

title: Case of Mad Cow in Canada Prompts U.S. to Ban Its Beef
description: Mad cow disease was diagnosed in a cow in Canada today, and United States health authorities immediately placed a ban on imports of beef, cattle and animal feed from Canada.

title: Bomb Is Suspected in Explosion at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, May 21 - An explosion that appears to have been deliberately detonated rocked Yale University's law school building this afternoon, collapsing one wall of an empty classroom and destroying a nearby staircase but apparently causing no injuries, officials said.

title: For Perfect Fried Chicken This Summer, Break the Rules
description: I AM here to argue that when it comes to a Memorial Day feast, fried chicken is a legitimate alternative to grilling. If there is one food that is more easily and reliably fried than grilled, it is chicken, which often as not is incinerated when cooked over flames. And if there is one special home-cooked dish that has near universal appeal it is fried chicken, not grilled hamburger.

title: Anti-Smoking Treaty Is Adopted by 192 Nations
description: GENEVA, May 21  The world's first treaty devoted entirely to health  one designed to get people to kick the smoking habit and to reduce the estimated five million deaths a year caused by it  was adopted unanimously by the World Health Assembly today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANGIERI, EMILIO D.
description: MANGIERI-Emilio D., age 56, on Sunday at home. title: House and Senate Agree on Tax Package of $350 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 - Senate and House Republicans leaders reached agreement this evening on a tax-and-spending package that would total $350 billion over the next decade.

title: Lottery Numbers
World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: TEPID ECONOMIC GROWTH The French economy avoided a recession in the first three months of the year, as its growth slowed to a rate of 1 percent year over year from 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002. The economy grew just 0.3 percent in the first quarter from the fourth. Increased consumer spending and investment fueled the moderate growth, the national statistics office Insee reported. The data come just days after three of France's partners in the euro, Germany, Italy and the Netherlands, said that their economies unexpectedly contracted in the quarter. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: A Quick Reversal in a Profit
description: Six days after announcing that it had earned net income of $25.8 million in the first quarter, Clean Harbors Inc. said yesterday that it had actually lost $7.1 million.

title: FORD TO USE CUTS TO OFFSET COSTS OF INCENTIVES
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would hasten cost cuts this year because it could not raise prices enough on most models to offset the effect of rebates and low-interest loans. Competition on incentives ''is even more intense'' than expected, the chief operating officer, Nick Scheele, told analysts. The chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., said reducing costs was ''one lever we can continue to pull to guide our way through this.'' Ford, which had losses totaling $6.43 billion in 2001 and 2002, is accelerating expense reductions because Mr. Ford has vowed not to match discounts by General Motors. Ford has already exceeded a 2003 cost-cutting target of $500 million announced earlier this year, executives have said.

title: Will Congress Remember the Jobless?
description: While the Republican-led Congress pours its energy into creating another windfall tax cut for the affluent, the toll of unemployed keeps growing, with temporary federal benefits about to expire for some of the most hard pressed. Unless Congress acts this week, the suffering will deepen for close to four million Americans. A fast extension of unemployment benefits is far more vital than the wrestling match over what mix of cuts in capital gains and dividend taxes will allow President Bush to proclaim another economic ''growth'' victory.

title: In State Parks, Friendly Animals Take to the Range
description: Barbecue grills were once ubiquitous in state parks in the Hudson Valley. But over the years they fell prey to neglect and vandalism. Now, in time for Memorial Day, they are back, but with a difference. Five designs of animal-shape cast-iron grills by Pae White, a Los Angeles artist, have been installed in Bear Mountain State Park, south of West Point, and in Franklin D. Roosevelt State Park in Yorktown Heights. There's an owl, a turtle, a rabbit, a fox and a frog, most with hinged covers.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Onward in Boston

title: FedEx to Switch 30,000 Trucks to Hybrids
description: The FedEx Corporation announced today that it planned to replace 30,000 of its delivery trucks with energy-saving, environmentally friendly hybrid-powered vehicles.

title: PRIVATE BANKING:A SPECIAL REPORT : Targeting China's 'new wealthy'
description: HONG KONG  With the fastest growing economy in the world, mainland China is one of biggest untapped markets for private banking in Asia. Unfortunately, however, for interested institutions, there remain many obstacles to entry into the Chinese market, and much of the country's new wealth has unclear sources.

title: British Officer Praised for His Code Is Accused of Violating It
description: LONDON, May 21 — The British Army officer whose rousing prebattle address to his troops in March drew worldwide attention for its emphasis on treating enemy captives with respect is under investigation on accusations of having abused Iraqi soldiers and civilians, the Ministry of Defense said today.

title: Bush Steps Up Criticism of Europe's Ban on Genetic Foods
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 21  President Bush asserted today that Europe's refusal to allow food from genetically modified crops into their markets had discouraged Third World countries from using this technology and thus undermined efforts to end hunger in Africa.

title: San Francisco Emporium to Get New Life as Mall
description: Designed by the first San Francisco architect to be trained in Paris, the century-old Emporium store near Union Square once stood as a proud symbol of this city's sophistication, with its colonnade of 18 columns and its oval rotunda topped by a 102-foot-wide green glass-and-steel dome.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: APPLE TO OPEN 20 RETAIL STORES Apple Computer will increase the number of its retail stores 35 percent over the next year by opening 19 more in the United States and one in Tokyo, its first overseas. Apple, which opened its first shop two years ago and now has 57 stores in the United States, said last month that it would have about 70 stores open by the end of 2003. Apple's chief executive, Steve Jobs, has been looking for ways to increase revenue as demand for personal computers has been in a slump for more than two years. After Apple lost market share to rivals that used the Windows operating system, which is owned by Microsoft , the company opened the stores as a way of attracting new users to its Macintosh personal computers. The stores have generated more than $650 million in sales since May 2001, Apple said. Apple shares declined 31 cents, to $17.79.    (Bloomberg News)

title: A Yak Attack On Beef And Bison
description: AS the sun sets on the Sangre de Cristo Mountains here in north central New Mexico, the dun-colored topsoil turns as red as blood itself. Long black shadows creep down the slopes in varying shapes: low and gnarly from thorny sagebrush, tall and majestic from oak and pinyon trees, and squat, shaggy and handlebar-horned from roaming yaks.

title: The Son of a 'Jetsons' Creator Works on a Wireless Future
description: William Hanna of Hanna-Barbera fame brought the world the Jetsons, the cartoon family that whizzed through rush hour on a skyway and kept robot friends. Mr. Hanna's son David plans today to introduce a more attainable vision of the future.

title: For Playing the Flip Side, An Assist From a Fisherman
description: Resembling a gaff used by a fisherman, the Pig Tail Food Flipper is a sleek tool for turning steaks, racks of ribs and other meats on the grill. The sharp stainless steel hook goes into the meat at an angle and pierces it in only one place, so it does not leave a mark or cause large losses of juices like a fork does.

title: How Do I Love Thee, Hot Dog? Let Me Count the Ways
description: Choosing hot dogs for your summer grilling season might take some time. A count of the varieties sold in a supermarket in my neighborhood exceeded 20. And this year there are a few more to consider.

title: Doner Plans to Close Its Baltimore Office
description: An era is ending at Doner. The agency said yesterday that it would close its Baltimore office after nearly 50 years and consolidate that office's operations at its headquarters in Southfield, Mich.

title: W.H.O. Expresses Optimism China Can Control SARS
description: Although China has reported the overwhelming majority of the world's SARS cases, the number of cases is dropping rapidly in many areas of the country, the World Health Organization said yesterday as it expressed wary optimism that China could contain the respiratory disease, although it might take as long as a year.

title: Interpublic Executives To Give Up Stock Options
description: Current and former top executives of the troubled Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, under mounting fire for drawing handsome pay, bonuses and benefits as the stock price plummeted, took the unusual step yesterday of showing contrition before distraught shareholders.

title: ALLERGY DRUG BY INSPIRE PHARMACEUTICALS FAILS IN STUDY
description: Inspire Pharmaceuticals Inc. said an experimental allergy medicine failed to meet the main goal of a study. The compound, called INS37217, failed to reduce significantly symptoms like runny nose over a 28-day period, and researchers were evaluating the data to decide what to do next, Inspire said. ''We will continue to conduct secondary analyses to determine future plans for the intranasal program,'' Inspire's chief executive, Christy L. Shaffer, said. Stock in Inspire, which is based in Durham, N.C., fell $1.37, or 8.5 percent, to $14.78 a share yesterday.

description: Just as the threats of a boycott against American soft drinks because of the war in Iraq appear to have petered out, Coca-Cola and PepsiCo are caught in a whole new controversy here over the water consumed by their bottling plants in southern India.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. LISTS USE OF NEW POWER TO FIGHT TERROR
description: In the most detailed public accounting of how it had used its expanded powers to fight terrorism, the Justice Department released information today showing that federal agents had conducted hundreds of bugging and surveillance operations and visited numerous libraries and mosques using new law enforcement tools.

title: Security Council Is Close to Vote on Lifting Iraq Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 21  Final amendments to a Security Council resolution to lift the sanctions on Iraq were distributed by the United States and Britain today and are likely to win broad approval when the measure comes up for its scheduled vote on Thursday, diplomats here suggested.

title: Charities Pledge $19 Million to Jesuit Model Schools
description: Impressed by the success shown by a network of four Jesuit high schools in working with urban teenagers, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and another major charity pledged $19 million today to bolster the schools and export the model to 12 additional cities.

title: E.P.A. Chief Whitman Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 — Christie Whitman resigned today as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency after two and a half years in which she sometimes differed with the White House on environmental issues.

title: U.S. Diplomatic Outposts To Be Shut in Saudi Arabia
description: American officials said today that the United States Embassy here and two consulates in Saudi Arabia would be closed on Wednesday because of an ''imminent'' threat of more terrorist attacks inside the kingdom. Officials in Britain and Germany also said they would close their embassies temporarily.

title: Private Judge to Resolve 'Spider-Man' Case
description: The Sony Corporation won its bid to have a private judge resolve a dispute with Marvel Enterprises over licensing rights to the movie ''Spider-Man,'' which generated more than $820 million in worldwide box office sales.

title: GANNETT PLAN TO BUY BRITISH NEWSPAPERS FACES SCRUTINY
description: The Gannett Company's planned purchase of British newspapers for 60 million ($98 million) will be investigated further by antitrust authorities. The British competition minister, Melanie Johnson, asked the Competition Commission to investigate further Gannett's acquisition of 23 newspapers in the London area from the Dublin-based Independent News and Media, the British Department for Trade and Industry said. Gannett agreed in March to buy the unit.

title: Mother Charged After Odyssey With Bodies Of 3 Babies
description: A woman who once lived in Sullivan County, N.Y., was charged yesterday with murdering three of her children there, then transporting the infants' corpses around the country for a decade or more before abandoning them in an Arizona shed, the state police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIGNEY, JOHN E.
description: HAIGNEY - John E. The Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester (formerly New Rochelle Hospital) notes with great sorrow the death of John E. Haigney. Jack was a valued member of the Board of Governors for over 20 years, serving as vice chairman for several terms. He was chairman of the law committee and a member of the executive, joint conference, medical affairs and compensation committees. His willingness to devote his time and efforts to meet the hospital's needs was genuinely appreciated. He will be deeply missed by his colleagues on the board and the administrative staff. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Lawrence J. Ruisi, Chairman/ Board of Governors John R. Spicer, President and CEO

description: No swans. No tutus. Instead, the Zig Zag Ballet demonstrated that it likes to take contemporary balletic twists and turns in its program on Thursday night at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College.

title: Lurking in Depths of New Budget, Bigger Bite for Some Taxpayers
description: The budget bills that the State Legislature enacted over the governor's vetoes last week stand more than six inches tall, and include hundreds of pages of dense legal writing and numbers that are impenetrable to most people, and even hard for the lawmakers who passed them to understand.

title: Buffy Rides Off Into the Sunset
description: ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' which ended its seven-year run last night on UPN, was originally aimed at a teenage audience, then turned out to be for everybody. But it had a particular resonance if you happened to be a woman who grew up in the 1960's, when ''Bonanza'' was the most popular program on TV. ''Bonanza'' was the story of a father and three adult sons who lived on a large Nevada ranch, the Ponderosa. The father was a triple widower. The sons became engaged frequently. But their girlfriends all died, sometimes within 10 minutes of their introduction. The Ponderosa was a Death Valley for the female sex -- even the family cook was a man.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: SARS Pushes Up Unemployment
description: Joblessness in Hong Kong rose to 7.8 percent in the period from February through April, compared with 7.5 percent in January through March. Underemployment, in which people settle for part-time jobs even though they want full-time work, rose to 3.2 percent from 2.9 percent. The government blamed an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome that began in mid-March and has hurt airlines, hotels, restaurants, travel agencies and stores. Although only one new case was reported on Monday and four yesterday, the government predicted the unemployment rate would continue to rise in the near future and has already announced a plan to provide temporary, government-paid jobs for 21,000 workers. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: ALLIES TO BEGIN SEIZING WEAPONS FROM MOST IRAQIS
description: Iraqi citizens will be required to turn over automatic weapons and heavy weapons under a proclamation that allied authorities plan to issue this week, allied officials said today.

description: JUST when restaurants are doing everything to attract customers, Peter Luger Steak House in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is purposely turning them away.

title: COURT DISMISSES SUIT AGAINST BANK OF NEW YORK
description: The Bank of New York Company won dismissal of a lawsuit that accused it of defrauding three offshore trusts of $40 million they invested in Inkombank, a leading Russian bank that lost its license in 1999. The trusts claimed that Bank of New York, which was a correspondent for Inkombank, knew the Russian bank laundered money and had ties to organized crime when they tried to withdraw their money in 1996. They accused Bank of New York of hiding the wrongdoing and of persuading them not to withdraw funds. In dismissing the suit, a state appeals court said the case was undermined by a similar suit litigated in federal court from 1995 to 1999. In that case, an agent for the offshore trusts said Inkombank admitted as early as 1994 that it had no intention of paying the investors, the appeals panel said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Ex-Minister Jailed
description: A court sentenced a former finance minister, Mohieddin el-Gharib, to eight years in prison for misuse of public money. Mr. Gharib was minister from 1996 to 1999. Egypt has been cracking down on corruption in an attempt to improve the image of the ruling National Democratic Party. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Man Charged With Stalking
description: A 27-year-old Queens man who was arrested Monday at Shea Stadium was arraigned yesterday on charges that he has been stalking Mets General Manager Steve Phillips since January.

title: Suit Charges Bias at Rally for Black Bikers
description: A group of black motorcycle riders filed suit today against the city of Myrtle Beach, S.C., and various businesses, accusing them of discrimination during Black Bike Week, the biggest African-American biker rally in the country.

title: Mayoral Control Changes The Politics of the Schools
description: Two or three times a day, often more, Deputy Mayor Dennis M. Walcott scoots out the back door of City Hall and strides 43 paces to the rear entrance of the Tweed Courthouse, headquarters of the city's Department of Education.

title: Breaking the Mideast Deadlock
description: Israelis buried the victims of the latest terrorist outrage yesterday while Palestinians stayed sealed off in their towns and villages, each side seething with resentment and despair. This may seem like the least likely moment to move forward on Middle East peace. But it is precisely the time for President Bush to increase his involvement. He has been saying the right things, and he took a small but significant step yesterday when he telephoned the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, for their first conversation. He also called Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister. Far more is needed. Unless Mr. Abbas and his more moderate agenda succeed, radical Muslim forces will hijack the Palestinian national movement, and hopes for a two-state solution could disappear.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPHAN, BENJAMIN
description: RAPHAN-Benjamin . We are shocked and deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our cherished friend and colleague. Throughout his nearly four decades of service with our firm as a business and corporate attorney, Ben's calm demeanor and dispassionate approach drew us to him for advice and counsel-we trusted his judgment. As a managing partner of Tenzer Greenblatt, Blank Rome's New York predecessor, he was also a major part of what bound us together as a firm. A teasing remark, a mock frown or a kind word of encouragement made him a beloved father figure and mentor to attorneys and staff alike. Beneath his straightforward style of drafting, negotiating and counseling lay a tremendous depth of legal knowledge respected and sought out by both clients and colleagues. Our hearts go out to Myrna, Howard and Carla, Stacy and Len, and Ben's adoring grandchildren. We hope they will be comforted by the knowledge of how much he meant to so many. Blank Rome LLP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ALLAN S.
description: KAPLAN-Allan S. 68, of Greenwich, Connecticut, died May 19, 2003. Mr. Kaplan was a vice chairman of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and chairman of the Firm's Investment Banking Commitment Committee, Fairness Opinion Committee and Investment Committee. Throughout his 36 - year career at Lehman Brothers, he worked in numerous areas of the Firm, including research, investment banking, commercial paper and credit. Mr. Kaplan was graduated, magna cum laude, from Yale College in 1957 and was a member of the Governing Board of the Yale University Art Gallery and the University's Development Board. In addition, Mr. Kaplan was a vice chairman of the American Architectural Foundation and a trustee of the New York Studio School. A philanthropist who was active in fundraising, he was chairman of the Lehman Brothers UJAFederation campaign and was involved in the $1.5 billion campaign for Yale. Among his many interests, he was an avid art collector and wine enthusiast. He is survived by his devoted wife of 46 years, Alice, and by his beloved children, Seth, Isabel and Caroline, and cherished grandchildren, Jason, Abigail, Justin, Joshua and Jack, and sisters, Barbara Sebiri and Naomi Eisenberger. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street in New York City on May 21 at 11:45 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the UJA Federation of New York, or the Yale University Art Gallery.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: $1.2 Billion Tax Increase Debated
description: Legislators began debating Gov. Bob Riley's $1.2 billion tax and government accountability measures, the largest proposed tax increase in state history. Mr. Riley, a conservative Republican and former congressman, introduced a series of tax and accountability bills on Monday that would take effect if voters approve a constitutional amendment in September. If voters disapprove, Mr. Riley said, $675 million in services will have to be cut from the two state budgets that finance public education and general state services like prisons and Medicaid. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Fear of SARS, Fear of Strangers
description: Earlier this month, the University of California at Berkeley banned from its summer programs all students from mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore, out of fear that some might be infected by the SARS virus. The university's response to the epidemic illustrates how easily the fear of SARS can degenerate into a generalized antipathy toward Asians, even on college campuses.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota To Increase Output
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it would increase production capacity in France and Britain to expand its sales in Europe. Toyota, the third-biggest car maker in the world, will add an extra shift at its factories in Burnaston, England, and Valenciennes, France, beginning in the second quarter of 2004. The move will create 1,500 new jobs and expand output by 26 percent at the two plants. Japanese automakers have generally fared poorly in Europe relative to their performance in the United States and other markets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Celine Marcus, 93; Aided Needy
description: Celine G. Marcus, former executive director of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, an East Side social services organization, died on Thursday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 93.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Stockholm: A Market Merger
description: The owner of Sweden's main stock exchange, OM AB, agreed to buy the rest of HEX Oyj, owner of the Helsinki bourse, for 171 million euros ($199 million) to cut costs and help it weather falling markets. OM will pay 2.5 of its own shares for each HEX share and 5.9 euros per HEX warrant, OM's deputy chief executive, Magnus Boecker, said. OM already owns 15.6 percent of HEX. Per Larsson will step down as OM's chief executive on May 30, to be replaced on an interim basis by Mr. Boecker.

description: LYNCH-Edmund Calvert, Jr. Son of Signa Fornaris and Edmund Calvert Lynch. Born in New York City January 11, 1928; died May 19, at his summer home in Newport, RI. Attended St. Paul's School and graduated with the class of 1948 at Yale. He is survived by his loving wife of twentyfour years, Alice (Treibick), three children from a previous marriage, Edmund III, Virginia Dean and Case. In addition he is survived by three step-children, Jane Paquet, Douglas Braff and Andrew Teller, and seventeen grandchildren. Mr. Lynch's father was a founder of Merrill Lynch & Company and Mr. Lynch, himself, was a partner and officer of the firm for many years. He also served on the Executive Committee of the Chi Psi Fraternity and served on the Board of its Educational Trust. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIND, CHARLOTTE LAZARUS
description: WITKIND-Charlotte Lazarus, 83, ''Char'' to all who knew her, of Columbus, Ohio, May 18, 2003, at home after a long illness. Born August 20, 1919 in Columbus. Nobody lived or loved life more than Char. She was the ultimate fan, of people and sports. Her passions were many and deep. Her partnerships with her forever-loving husband Dick and her beloved New York Yankees were deepest. Char's wondrous abilities with words, songs, and most of all, people, will leave us with memories that can never be erased. From New York to California to her home base in Columbus, her immediate and extended families grieve her passing, but will always cherish her incredible spirit, intellect, openness and joyful look at the world. Active alumna of Columbus School for Girls (1937) and Wellesley College (1941). Limited partner in the ownership of the Yankees, she and Dick traveled from Columbus to Yankee Stadium as often as possible. Her cheers could be heard for miles. Well-known and respected community activist. Vice President of the New York City League of Women Voters. Worked with innumerable organizations in Columbus, furthering community relations, baseball, public radio, and other causes. Preceded in death by parents Hattie and Robert Lazarus, Sr., sister Jean Lazarus Hoffman, and first husband Dr. Warren F. Gorman. Survived by devoted husband of nearly 45 years, Richard Jules Witkind; sister Babette (Howard) Lazarus Sirak; brother Robert (Mary) Lazarus, Jr.; sons Robert (Linda) Lazarus Gorman and Donald (Lisal) Gorman; daughters Babette T. Gorman and Vivian (Jack) Witkind Davis; eight grandchildren; one great grandchild (all of Columbus); numerous nephews and nieces; cousins by the dozens; and friends by the score. Char's life will be celebrated at the residence from 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM, Friday, May 23. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may contribute in her honor to Planned Parenthood of Central Ohio or the Mid-Ohio Food Bank.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Philippine Company To Sell Pagers
description: Smart Communications, a unit of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company, entered an agreement yesterday with Research in Motion, becoming the third Asian telephone operator to sell the BlackBerry hand-held computer, a product of Research in Motion, which is based in Canada. The BlackBerry pagers, which include a cellular phone, organizer and Internet and e-mail capability, will be marketed to corporate clients, a company spokesman, Ramon Isberto, said. The BlackBerry pagers may help Smart attract upper-income customers as the company faces rising competition from its nearest rival, Globe Telecom. In February, Smart started selling mobile phone handsets that run with Microsoft programs, betting that the handsets could help it draw postpaid customers away from Globe Telecom. Smart, along with its sister company, the Pilipino Telephone Corporation, has 9.4 million mobile phone subscribers, representing 57 percent of the domestic market. Text messaging is popular in the Philippines. The BlackBerry, which has 550,000 users in 25 countries, was introduced earlier in Singapore, Hong Kong and Australia, he said.

title: Prepared Text of Greenspan's Remarks
description: Mr. Chairman, I appreciate the opportunity to testify before the Joint Economic Committee. As you will recall, when I appeared here last November, I emphasized the extraordinary resilience manifested by the United States economy in recent years--the cumulative result of increased flexibility over the past quarter century. Since the middle of 2000, our economy has withstood serious blows: a significant decline in equity prices, a substantial fall in capital spending, the terrorist attacks of September 11, confidence-debilitating revelations of corporate malfeasance, and wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. Any combination of these shocks would arguably have induced a severe economic contraction two or three decades ago. Yet remarkably, over the past three years, activity has expanded, on balance--an outcome offering clear evidence of a flexible, more resilient, economic system.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Marconi To Market Metallic Power Fuel Cells
description: The British telecommunications equipment maker Marconi said yesterday that it would market fuel cells from Metallic Power as a backup power supply for small telecommunications installations. The deal is the first significant order for a large-scale fuel cell that generates power by combining with oxygen rather than with hydrogen. The two companies did not disclose the terms of the partnership but said that thousands of telecommunication sites could use the technology. Metallic Power, a privately held company based in Carlsbad, Calif., said that its cells provide up to 5 kilowatts of backup power for 24 hours, three times the duration of lead-acid batteries, which are often backed up with auxiliary gas-fired generators. The zinc cells automatically regenerate when power from the electricity grid is restored. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: South Korean Official Optimistic on Bid
description: Atop official of the Olympic bid committee seeking the 2010 Winter Games for the demilitarized zone in South Korea said yesterday that he did not think the resumption of North Koreas nuclear weapons program would derail its efforts. Because we have tension due to the nuclear issue, the International Olympic Committee could think in a different way, said Jin Sun Kim, the governor of Gangwon province and the executive president of the bid committee that wants to secure the Games for Pyeongchang. By awarding the Games to Pyeongchang, the I.O.C. can help us and North Korea ease the existing tension and be a turning point in promoting peace. In a telephone interview during a trip to New York, Jin added, I think the Games can be awarded to us, and the I.O.C. can greatly contribute to solving the North Korean nuclear issue. A recent I.O.C. evaluation commission report analyzing the three candidate cities  Pyeongchang; Vancouver, British Columbia; and Salzburg, Austria  did not rank the competing bids, but appeared to give a slight edge to Vancouver. It did not mention the North Korean nuclear threat. The Olympic committee will select the winning city on July 2 during a meeting in Prague. Jin said he believed that Pyeongchangs transportation network and the compact layout of its athletic facilities gave it a technical edge over Vancouver and Salzburg. Jin said that he hoped for some type of resolution to the nuclear tensions. We dont believe it will go to extremes, like a war, he said. He added that during recent ministerial talks held between the two Koreas, the North Korean delegate announced support for a successful Pyeongchang bid. Gangwon province is divided between North and South Korea; Jin said there were no plans to stage any events in North Korea.

Tularik specializes in addressing the genetic causes of cancer. The agreement may help Amgen, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., expand in oncology and add to its lineup of therapies that treat chemotherapy patients. title: Metro Briefing: New York

The unrealized plot to kill Mr. Gravano, a former underboss of the Gambino crime family who became an important government witness and was later arrested on drug charges, was revealed last week in an indictment in Brooklyn. Mr. Garafola already faces federal racketeering charges in Manhattan, to which he has pleaded not guilty. He is married to Mr. Gravano's sister, according to the F.B.I. The new indictment says he joined in the plot to maintain his position in the Gambino family. Mr. Garafola's lawyer, Michael Rosen, said his client would also plead not guilty to the new charges.

description: A tax opponent who has been gathering signatures at the town dump here for two weeks fell short of the number needed to force a referendum on government spending, he said yesterday. The man, Michael A. Gilbertie, a member of Friends of Westport, said he had collected 1,448 signatures by Tuesday evening, 125 short of the amount needed to force a townwide vote on the proposed $128.6 million budget. His failure to collect the signatures of at least 10 percent of the town's registered voters cleared the way for the town to set the so-called mill rate for the fiscal year that starts in July. As of last evening, town officials expected the mill rate to increase 9.3 percent, meaning that taxpayers who now pay $18.30 on every $1,000 in property that they own would pay an additional $1.70 in taxes. Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT)

title: In a Dark Harbor, a Bright House
description: THE snow was knee-deep on the day Ved Mehta and the architect Edward Larrabee Barnes walked through an uncleared forest here, discussing the view of Penobscot Bay. It was December 1982, and the plutocrats who occupy the island's enormous Georgian-style mansions during the summer were gone. Finding a stretch of level ground, Mr. Barnes paced the outline for a house and said to Mr. Mehta, ''I think once you've got your house here and done the initial cutting, Ved, you'd have to live here and experiment to see which trees got in the way of your view, and which trees you fell in love with and wanted to protect and keep.''

title: Taking an Art Out of the Vase
description: In ''Perfection/Impermanence: Contemporary Ikebana,'' an exhibition that opens on Sunday at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the traditional Japanese art of flower arranging has sprung loose from the vase. Teika Itoh, the designer of Ferns VII, above, has made cones, balls and rings of urajiro, a Japanese fern that has tiny leaves. The show, which has the work of six artists, will run through July 27 at Wave Hill, 675 West 252nd Street; $4 Wednesday through Sunday; free all day Tuesday and on Saturday, 9 a.m. to noon; (718) 549-3200, or www.wavehill.org. title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Council Goes To Washington
description: The New York City Council held a rare public hearing in Washington yesterday to draw attention to the city's dire fiscal condition and to lobby for aid from the federal government. Speakers said the city's situation was in part a result of the disruption that occurred in Lower Manhattan after the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001. Many speakers complained that the federal government, now dominated by Republicans, had not done enough to help the city recover. Council Speaker Gifford Miller, a Democrat, noted that while the federal government had pledged to give the city $20 billion in recovery aid, some studies put the city's overall losses at $80 billion. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter and will add St. Francis's 22 branches in the Milwaukee area to MAF's 34 offices in Chicago and its western suburbs.
