title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: I.B.M. BEATS ORACLE IN 2002 DATABASE SALES International Business Machines, the world's biggest computer maker, unseated Oracle as the top seller of database software last year, the market researcher Gartner Inc. said yesterday. I.B.M.'s share of the $6.63 billion market for relational database programs rose to 36 percent in 2002 from 34 percent in 2001, Gartner said. Oracle's portion slipped to 34 percent from 40 percent. The Microsoft Corporation's share grew to 18 percent from 14 percent. The total market fell by 6.9 percent. In recent years, I.B.M. has focused on increasing sales of database programs by expanding partnerships with software companies like PeopleSoft Inc. , Siebel Systems Inc. and SAP, whose applications store information in databases. I.B.M. and Microsoft, the world's biggest software maker, have gained business by undercutting Oracle's prices, analysts have said.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: AID FOR ECONOMY URGED The Bank of Japan's governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said the government should take additional steps to head off a financial crisis, adding his voice to a growing chorus of policy makers calling for more pre-emptive action. Mr. Fukui said that Japan's financial system was weak and that there could be a crisis without further measures. His comments come four days after Japan's fifth-largest bank group asked the government for emergency funds. Financial regulators are now mulling whether to make it easier to force banks to take public money before their capital falls below legal minimums. Underscoring Mr. Fukui's fears, the central bank downgraded its view of the economy for the first time since November, blaming the strengthening yen and the SARS epidemic. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Op-Art
Increasing the U.N. Role in Iraq
description: Earlier this year, the United States gave up on getting approval from the United Nations Security Council to invade Iraq and acted without it. Now Washington is running Iraq and its oil fields but wants the U.N.'s seal of acceptance. The Security Council is expected to vote today to give that approval. Most Council members remain understandably unhappy with the unilateral nature of the occupation but recognize that trying to block it is futile. They realize that at this point, it is better to wring the most out of the arrangement by maximizing U.N. involvement and helping Washington see the value of outside help. The American resolution has been modified in recent days and is the better for it. Shortcomings remain, but it can serve as a framework for renewed international cooperation in Iraq.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Photronics Shares Surge On Profit News
description: Shares of Photronics Inc., a maker of quartz plates used to build computer chips, rose 13 percent after the company said it would have a profit before some costs this quarter. The stock gained $1.71, to $14.83, at the close of trading yesterday on the Nasdaq Stock Market. Photronics will become profitable in the quarter ending in July, its chief executive, Dan Del Rosario, said. The profit will exclude 3 cents a share in costs for retiring a $62.1 million note, Michael McCarthy, a spokesman, said. Analysts on average expected a 5-cent loss, according to Thomson Financial. The company, based in Brookfield, Conn., makes photomasks, or templates used to transfer chip designs onto silicon wafers. It has laid off about 10 percent of its workers and cut management salaries to help break even on quarterly sales of $87 million to $88 million. It said its second-quarter net loss was $44.1 million, or $1.37 a share, for the period ended May 4, in contrast to net income of $2.52 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 17 percent, to $85.5 million.

description: Contrary to stereotype, a new video game will encourage players to go outside and play in the sunshine. In fact, natural light is a potent weapon in the game against tiny vampires and other digital bad guys.

title: Israeli and Palestinian Envoys Meet With Bush Aides
description: Senior Israeli and Palestinian envoys held separate meetings with top aides to President Bush today, trying to forge agreement on actions to reduce tensions in the next few weeks and start talks, administration officials said tonight.

title: The Red Mellowed Out Chili Peppers
description: Looking for an easy way to ruin your band? Try this: grow up, chill out, dig in. Shed your we-use-''party''-as-a-verb reputation and rededicate yourselves to musicianship. Embrace balladry. Allow the guitarist to sing.

title: You May See a Soul Mate Across a Crowded Room
description: Sizing up fellow travelers at an industry or professional conference is always tricky business. Do you care to chat with the guy in the brown velour jacket? And what could you possibly have in common with that woman with all the facial piercings?

title: Security Cutbacks Worry Airport Officials
description: The odds of breezing through McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas could soon become worse than those of hitting the jackpot at the Bellagio, if airport officials are to be believed.

title: State Dept. and U.N. to Inspect Iraq Nuclear Site
description: The State Department said today that it was making arrangements with the International Atomic Energy Agency to conduct joint inspections of an Iraqi nuclear research center that has been ransacked by looters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYNCH, , ELIZABETH
description: LYNCH--Elizabeth, 80, on May 21, 2003. Daughter of the late Paul P. and Helen Page Faulkner. Wife of the late James Simpson Lynch. Adored sister of Barbara Norris, cherished aunt of several nieces and nephews. Funeral services, Friday, May 23, 9:30AM, Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYNCH, , EDMUND CALVERT, JR.
description: LYNCH--Edmund Calvert, Jr. Son of Signa Fornaris and Edmund Calvert Lynch. Born in New York City January 11, 1928; died May 19, at his summer home in Newport, RI. Attended St. Paul's School and graduated with the class of 1948 at Yale. He is survived by his loving wife of twentyfour years, Alice (Treibick), three children from a previous marriage, Edmund III, Virginia Dean and Case. In addition he is survived by three step-children, Jane Paquet, Douglas Braff and Andrew Teller, and seventeen grandchildren. Mr. Lynch's father was a founder of Merrill Lynch & Company and Mr. Lynch, himself, was a partner and officer of the firm for many years. He also served on the Executive Committee of the Chi Psi Fraternity and served on the Board of its Educational Trust. In recent years Mr. Lynch has devoted considerable time to financing medical research projects in the cancer field. In lieu of flowers kindly make contributions to: Edmund C. Lynch Jr. Cancer Fund C/O Jeffrey A. Gelfand, M.D., Massachusetts General Hospital, 50 Staniford Street, Suite #

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: LEADER COMPLAINS ABOUT HARD-LINERS President Mohammad Khatami said it was "very difficult" for him to continue his work after conservatives blocked two reform bills, but he stopped short of threatening to resign. "They have limited the president's authority so much that in some cases his authority is less than that of an ordinary person, and this is not acceptable at all," Mr. Khatami said. His comments came after the Guardian Council, which vets legislation and is close to Islamic hard-liners, rejected as unconstitutional a bill that would have curtailed its power to disqualify election candidates and another that would have given Mr. Khatami the right to question judicial rulings.    ( Reuters )

title: U.S. STAYS IN TOP 10
description: The Unted States men's national team, which will play Wales on Monday in San Jose, Calif., stayed among the top 10 teams in the world in the latest ranking released by FIFA yesterday in Zurich.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Prada Rehires Designer
description: The Italian fashion house Prada Holding said it rehired the German designer Jil Sander to create clothes for Jil Sander A.G., which she founded and sold to Prada. Ms. Sander stepped down from her company in January 2000 after selling it to Prada. She had clashed with Patrizio Bertelli, the chief executive of Prada, above, over strategy. Ms. Sander will be on a panel that advises Prada's board, along with Mr. Bertelli and his wife, Miuccia Prada, who oversees the creative operations at the company.

title: House Approves Increasing Defense Department's Waivers of Environmental Rules
description: The House voted today to give the Pentagon broad discretion to waive laws meant to protect rare animal and plant species if the restrictions are judged to interfere with military training and readiness. And the Senate approved a more limited exemption.

description: 'Almost Blue'

title: Torre Supports Struggling Contreras
description: Manager Joe Torre did his best to stress the positive in Jos Contreras's return to the Yankees on Tuesday. But Mel Stottlemyre saw what most Yankee fans must have seen. Contreras allowed five runs in the seventh inning and lost to the Boston Red Sox, and Stottlemyre was not pleased.

title: Sports of The Times; Lady in Red Will Make The Cut at the Colonial
description: ONE of golf's attributes is that it's known as a gentleman's game. It has etiquette and manners. Win or lose, be gracious. Walking off the 18th green, shake hands.

title: Tracing the Outlines of Cathedrals in the Air
description: Fine choreography by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins received unusually fine performances by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Snags Reported In Negotiations Seeking to Settle Asbestos Cases
description: As a senator prepares to introduce legislation to end asbestos lawsuits, unions and business groups remain far from agreement on crucial details of the bill, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Americans Ever More Scarce in Tourist-Popular Spain
description: For a tourism powerhouse like Spain, the weak dollar is just one more in a cloud of worries overshadowing the hotels and restaurants, boutiques and department stores and other businesses that rely on visitors' spending.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: GUILTY PLEA IN FOOD POISONINGS A man who worked at a grocery store outside Grand Rapids pleaded guilty to lacing about 250 pounds of ground beef with insecticide last Dec. 31, sickening 92 people. The worker, Randy J. Bertram, 39, faces up to 20 years in prison for poisoning food with the intent to cause serious bodily injury. His lawyer said Mr. Bertram thought the tampering would get a co-worker with whom he had a dispute in trouble. Daniel Mekaru, an assistant United States attorney, said the number of victims made it "far larger" than any other food tampering case. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 23 about the dwindling Parsi community in India referred incorrectly to the role of fire in their religion, Zoroastrianism. While fire is widely used in ritual, it is a divine symbol; adherents do not worship it.

title: High-Definition Memories: The Camcorder Enters the Picture
description: A HIGH-DEFINITION television picture is so bright, sharp and clear, it's causing a minor upheaval in the way TV shows and movies are filmed. Talk-show and newscast sets must be rebuilt because HDTV reveals that the existing desks are nothing more than plywood and contact paper. Composing a shot is more complicated because HDTV displays a wide, sweeping rectangle of life like a movie, not the blindered square of a conventional set. And actors must go to new extremes in skin care, because the HDTV lens reveals not only every speck and freckle, but even the caking of the makeup used to cover them up.

title: Triangles, Bees And Bigots
description: 'Marathon 2003,' Program A

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Search Ends For Time Capsule
description: Historians called off their search for a time capsule buried by President Theodore Roosevelt on a 1903 trip to Portland. The capsule was to be unearthed next week during a visit by Roosevelt's great-grandson Theodore Roosevelt IV. Relics were placed in a copper box buried at the base of what became a monument to Lewis and Clark. The Oregon Historical Society determined that the box could be under more than six feet of granite and that digging for it would be too costly and could damage the monument. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: FEDEX TO BEGIN DELIVERING PACKAGES TO AFGHANISTAN
description: The FedEx Corporation said yesterday that it would start delivering parcels to Afghanistan because business in the country has recovered since the United States removed the Taliban regime. FedEx will deliver packages in the country's capital, Kabul, with its partner Afghan Express Ltd., the company said in a statement. ''The expansion is driven by the country's recent business resurgence and improving economy,'' it said.

title: Most Marines May Return From Iraq by End of August
description: Most of the 60,000 marines still in or around Iraq are to return home by the end of August, the commandant of the Marine Corps said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JULIE, , JOEL
description: JULIE--Joel. Of Bronxville, NY. Beloved husband of Hilda. Devoted father of Canter Rica Timman and Lawrence Avram Julie. Loving brother, grandfather and father-inlaw. Services today, 1:00 PM at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hasting-on-Hudson. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUATTLEBAUM, , BOOKER
description: QUATTLEBAUM--Booker. In loving memory. Husband of Isa, father of Monifa, fatherin-law of Steven and brother of Yvonne. Devoted Professor of English at Bronx Community College. >>AD#

title: Sorenstam Remains Convinced The Course Suits Her Game
description: After all the analysis and all the debate, nobody is certain how Annika Sorenstam will fare this week. Not the men she will compete against. Not the millions who will watch on television. Not the supporters who believe she is making a bold and courageous statement. Not the detractors, who believe the PGA Tour is no place for a woman, not even the best women's golfer in the world.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NEPAL: LIVE FROM EVEREST With a record number of people trying to reach the summit of Mount Everest 50 years after it was first scaled, a team of Chinese mountaineers reached the top and broadcast the first-ever live pictures from the summit. China Central Television showed live coverage of the event from a camera carried by two climbers. CCTV pre-empted its noon newscast to show the climbers struggling up the snowy last leg of the climb, above. Strong winds and deteriorating weather have thwarted attempts by more than 100 other climbers to reach the summit.    (AP)

title: In a Battle of the Bands, Musicians Are the Judges
description: IF you are a musician, you know that it is hard to get constructive commentary from friends and family. Even if you think your song or performance is awful, you might still hear, ''That's so great,'' over and over.

title: Citigroup to Pay $775,000
description: Citigroup was ordered to pay $775,000 to two customers who contended that its Salomon Smith Barney unit sold them unsuitable investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTER, , HELEN
description: CARTER--Helen. Boosey & Hawkes mourns the passing of artist Helen Jones Carter, who also served as muse to her husband, composer Elliott Carter. Her loyalty, wit, and vitality will be missed. Boosey & Hawkes Jennifer Bilfield, President >>AD#

title: Connecticut Judges Plan to Drop Secrecy Option
description: In Connecticut, long regarded as a model of governmental propriety, the governor's telephone logs are open to public scrutiny. Every lawmaker's vote is public record. And state judges, with well-defined exceptions, conduct their courts in full public view.

description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has struck a deal with State Senator Frank Padavan, a leading critic of the chancellor's plan to reorganize New York City's local school districts into 10 divisions.

description: JAKOBSON--Lusia. On May 21, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Teodor. Survived by her sister-in-law Yoela Boichis. Graveside services Friday, 2PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. >>AD#

description: Highlights from this week's forums, including comments on the current state of Iraq and reactions to the "Buffy" series finale.

title: Panel Breaks Logjam for Bill on Employees' Genetic Histories
description: A bill that would bar employers and insurance companies from discriminating against people based on their genetic histories won the unanimous approval of a crucial Senate committee today, breaking a logjam that had held up the measure for six years.

title: A Legend Returns, His Fastball Intact
description: Curt Gowdy walked into the Fenway Park broadcast booth for the Yankees-Red Sox game tonight, not nervous, but a little concerned about calling play-by-play for the first time in more than 20 years.

description: A Michael Finley fall-away jump shot, a Dirk Nowitzki rainbow from beyond the arc. There they went again, the most potent offensive team in pro basketball, moving swiftly in the fourth quarter, inching up on a scared lot of San Antonio Spurs.

title: Rise of H.I.V. In Russia Is Quickening, Official Says
description: Russia's top government AIDS expert offered a harrowing assessment of the disease's spread today, saying that at least a half-million Russians now carry the H.I.V. virus and that the true number could range as high as 1.5 million, or more than 1 percent of the overall population, which is about 147 million.

title: All Eyes on Sorenstam as She Gets Off to a Solid Start
description: FORT WORTH, May 22  Completing one of the most-anticipated rounds in golf history, Annika Sorenstam shot a one-over par 71 today in the first round of the Colonial tournament, leaving herself with a chance to achieve her goal of making the 36-hole cut on Friday.

title: Portraits in Architecture, From a Different Point of View
description: ''Drawn Home: Fritz Vogt's Rural America,'' an exhibition at the American Folk Art Museum, contrasts precise details with distorted perspective. Vogt, a native of Germany, made architectural portraits near Albany between 1890 and 1900. The show has 26 of them, some in graphite, others in colored pencil. One, the home of Mr. and Mrs. I. Snell of Minden (below), is from 1896. The show runs through Sept. 21; the museum is at 45 West 53rd Street; (212) 265-1040. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: New Armored Vehicle on Path to Approval
description: Fresh from battlefield successes in Iraq, the Army is anticipating approval this month to deploy the Stryker, its first new armored vehicle in two decades.

title: State to Acquire Property That Teddy Roosevelt Loved
description: A swath of wilderness in the heart of the Adirondacks that once captivated Theodore Roosevelt will become state parkland, under an agreement announced today by Gov. George E. Pataki and the Open Space Institute, a conservation group.

title: The Republicans Party On
description: Against some of the best economic advice in the land, President Bush and his Republican Congressional leaders have concocted a benighted final tax-cut plan that will do far more to deepen the nation's deficits and debt than to stimulate the wallowing economy. In a rush for approval by Memorial Day, the leaders have cannibalized parts of competing packages into a tentative $318 billion grab bag that again offers the most significant relief to the upper-bracket Americans so dear to the administration. Dividend taxes will be cut, not eliminated as the president hoped, but so will capital gains taxes. The latter was a conservative chestnut rejected two years ago when the first Bush cuts were enacted in the long-ago euphoria of an actual budget surplus.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Economic Aid Plan
description: Malaysia cut its benchmark interest rate by half a point and announced a 7.3 billion ringgit ($1.92 billion) plan for loans and spending to help businesses stalled by the SARS outbreak and slowing exports. Mahathir Mohamad, the prime minister, said workers' contributions to state pensions would be cut to 9 percent from 11 percent of wages, service taxes would be waived for hotels and restaurants, and a fund for small businesses would be set up. The three-month intervention rate the central bank charges commercial banks was cut to a record 4.5 percent. ''The global environment has become uncertain and complicated and will hamper recovery,'' Mr. Mahathir told reporters. ''The package will help stimulate growth and confidence among investors and consumers.''

title: Voting by Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: More Internet Fraud Charges
description: A Queens teenager already free on bail in an Internet fraud case was arrested again yesterday and charged with defrauding AOL customers by stealing their credit card numbers. District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said the teenager, Shiva Brent Sharma, continued to run a fraud scheme out of his parents' Richmond Hill home even while awaiting trial on similar charges filed in December. In the latest case, Mr. Brown said Mr. Sharma, 18, would log onto the Internet and trick AOL customers into providing him with their credit card information. He then charged more than $30,000 worth of items, including laptop computers, digital cameras, cellphones and plasma television sets that he then auctioned off, also through the Internet, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Sharma was charged this time with first-degree identity theft, grand larceny and scheming to defraud. His lawyer, Thaddeus J. McGuire, said Mr. Sharma was innocent of the December charges but had not spoken to him about the latest charges. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Price of Crude Oil Jumps 2.2% As Inventories Show a Decline
description: Crude oil prices rose 2.2 percent yesterday after an Energy Department report showed that inventories last week were lower than a year ago.

title: After the Holocaust, Devouring Life in Gulps
description: The stage adaptation of Isaac Bashevis Singer's novel ''Meshugah'' has some good things going for it. First, Emily Mann's script does a nice job of trimming Singer's urban picaresque tale almost to the bare bones without scarring the central narrative. And second, this production, which is directed by Loretta Greco and includes a trio of astute performances, deftly reproduces the wryly astonished tone of the novel. The problem with the show, on the tiny stage at the Kirk Theater through May 31, is that it is far more literary than theatrical.

title: For the Athlete, Form and Function
description: SHOE addicts like me fantasize for years about a setup as sweet as this: last week I was forced to buy new shoes for safety reasons.

title: Other Nations Join the U.S. In Banning Canada's Beef
description: As Canadian health officials scrambled today to find out how an 8-year-old Black Angus cow became infected with mad cow disease, Mexico, Japan, Australia and several other nations joined the United States in placing a temporary ban on the import of Canadian beef and cattle.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on May 13 and 14 about the killing of a Hunter College student whose body was found behind a boarded-up house in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, included a misspelling of her given name provided by the police and the college. (A correction on Tuesday also misspelled the name in some copies.) She was Romona Moore, not Ramona.

title: U.S. Says Iraqi Assembly Could Meet in July
description: The new civilian administrator of Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, said today that a national assembly of Iraqi political leaders that could pave the way for self-rule probably would be held in mid-July, weeks later than originally scheduled by the United States.

title: Fund Trade Group Backs Decimal Trading
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (Bloomberg News)  The Investment Company Institute, the biggest trade group for mutual funds, has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it supports continuing to price stocks in penny increments.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about takeover interest in Centerpulse of Switzerland, a maker of orthopedic devices, referred incorrectly to an earlier approach by Zimmer Holdings. Zimmer did make a preliminary offer for Centerpulse in October, but did not make it public.

title: The Mark of a Real Icon: Even in Wax, She Moves
description: Round up the sociologists, ideologists and philosophers. Come to us, Darwinists, geneticists, biologists. Summon the existentialists, sensualists and mystics. Give meaning to these events that unfolded yesterday beneath the shadowy light of electric candles in this chamber of graven imagery.

title: Prewar Views of Iraq Threat Are Under Review by C.I.A.
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has begun a review to try to determine whether the American intelligence community erred in its prewar assessments of Saddam Hussein's government and Iraq's weapons programs, several officials say.

title: DEUTSCHE POST TO SELL STAKE IN DHL AIRWAYS
description: The chief executive of DHL Airways, John Dasburg, and two investors agreed to buy all shares held by Deutsche Post and another investor for $57 million in a move that may end claims that the German company controls the airline. Deutsche Post, which owns 43 percent of DHL Airways through a subsidiary, and William Robinson, an Idaho investor who owns 52 percent of DHL Airways, are selling their interests, said Ray Lutz, the airline's vice president for business development and strategic planning. The other investors acquiring stakes in DHL Airways are Richard Blum, chairman of Blum Capital Partners, and Michael Klein, a business executive and lawyer in Washington. A Department of Transportation judge will hold a prehearing conference next Tuesday as part of a proceeding to determine whether Deutsche Post controls the airline, which gets 90 percent of its business from DHL Worldwide Express, the delivery service. Federal law prohibits foreign companies or citizens from controlling United States airlines.

title: 5 Men Are Indicted In Queens Attack
description: Five young homeless men were indicted yesterday in Queens on rape and assault charges in an attack on a woman and her boyfriend near Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in December.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Appeals Court Reverses $145 Billion Tobacco Ruling

title: Polo Ralph Lauren Posts 52% Profit Increase on European Sales
description: The Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation, the maker of Ralph Lauren and Club Monaco clothes, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit surged 52 percent, led by lower costs and higher sales in Europe.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trader Revises Loss
description: SK Global, the trading firm involved in an accounting scandal that is bringing down the stock of companies in the SK Group, Korea's third-largest conglomerate, said it had a loss of 405.9 billion won ($338 million) last year rather than the loss of 296.7 billion won it previously reported. The revision deepens fears about the future of the company and its major shareholder, the SK Corporation, Korea's biggest oil refiner. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: G.M. RAISES REBATES ON SOME MODELS IN THE MIDWEST
description: The General Motors Corporation raised rebates on some models in parts of the Midwest. Discounts on the company's top-selling Chevrolet Silverado pickup will increase to $4,000 from $3,000; on the Chevrolet TrailBlazer sport utility vehicle to $4,750 from $3,000; and on the Chevrolet Avalanche pickup to $5,000 from $4,000, according to the Chevrolet Web site. A G.M. spokeswoman, Deborah Silverman, declined to comment on the changes, which took effect last night in Michigan and in parts of neighboring states. The discounts end June 2.

description: To the Editor:

title: C. A. Tripp, Author of Work On Homosexuality, Dies at 83
description: C. A. Tripp, a psychologist, therapist and sex researcher who wrote an influential book on homosexuality, died on Saturday at his home in Nyack, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Cabdriver Is Arrested on Drug Charge, but Interest in Explosives Attracts Attention of F.B.I.
description: In March, the authorities said, Sayed Abdul Malike, a cabdriver from Brooklyn, went to Miami, took a boat tour of the port, and asked enough questions about bridge design and how close the boat could get to cruise ships that the captain called the F.B.I.

title: Two Studies Indicate Atkins Diet May Help Heart
description: The 31-year-old Atkins diet -- long disparaged by the medical establishment and just as fervently advocated by its adherents -- has gained a measure of credibility with the publication of two studies that indicate that some measures of heart health improved in people who followed low-carbohydrate diets for six months or a year.

title: TECHNITROL REVISES FORECAST, CITING WEAK DEMAND
description: Technitrol Inc., a maker of electronic components, lowered its forecasts for profit this year because slowing economic growth in Europe hurt demand for the company's television parts. Profit, excluding restructuring costs and other one-time expenses, will be 60 cents to 68 cents a share in the year ending Dec. 26, down from an estimate of 63 cents to 75 cents, the company said yesterday. It said prices had declined because of competition from rivals in Asia, and that it planned to close factories and move more production to China.

title: Fitch Rating Service Is Denied Journalistic Privilege in a Suit
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Fitch Inc., the credit rating service, could not invoke a journalistic privilege to avoid turning over information and testifying in a civil case that involved securities that it considered rating.

title: Write-Offs Combine for Loss At Phone Network Operator
description: The mobile phone network operator mmO2 said today that it lost 10.2 billion ($16.7 billion) in the fiscal year ended March 31, almost all of it from write-downs on the value of licenses in Britain, Germany and Ireland and for a unit it sold in the Netherlands.

Loving grandmother of Peter, Gale and John, Jeffrey and Sari, Robert and Marci, David and Lisa, Richard and Lauren. Great-grandmother of Jamie, Adam, Ryan, Jessica, Michael, Jordan, Alison, Melissa, Jason, Justin and Rachel. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERUGGI, , ANNA MARIE
description: PERUGGI--Anna Marie. The Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy extends its sincere sympathies to Regina Peruggi, our esteemed president of the Central Park Conservancy, on the loss of her mother. Our thoughts and prayers are with her. The Board of the Women's Committee, Central Park Conservancy >>AD#

title: OAKLEY SETTLES SUITS AGAINST RIVAL MAKER OF SUNGLASSES
description: Oakley, a maker of sunglasses, said yesterday that it had settled lawsuits accusing a bigger rival, the Luxottica Group, of copying patented lens designs. Financial terms were not disclosed. In January, an appeals court upheld a ruling that blocked Luxottica from selling sunglasses with ''emerald'' green or ''ice'' blue tinted lenses. The dispute began after Luxottica bought Sunglass Hut, the biggest seller of Oakley sunglasses, in April 2001. Oakley is based in Foothill Ranch, Calif.; Luxottica is based in Milan. Other patent lawsuits filed by Oakley, including one against Fossil Inc., will continue.

title: Helen Jones Carter, 1930's Sculptor, 95,
description: Helen Jones Carter, a former sculptor and the wife of the composer Elliott Carter, died on Saturday at the couple's home in Manhattan. She was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SURY, , STANLEY
description: SURY--Stanley. The New York Times records with sorrow the passing of Stanley Sury, associated with The Times from October 1967 until retiring in December 1982. >>AD#

title: Lounging About at Lever House
description: On Saturday night, designers and editors draped themselves on the low leather loungers, below, at Lever House, on Park Avenue, for the opening party of the International Contemporary Furniture Fair. ''It's semisupine seating,'' said William T. Georgis, who recently restored the building's ground floor lobby, where the event took place. Raymond Loewy's original furniture for the space had disappeared, so Mr. Georgis came up with his own design. It has a wedge for the back and is cantilevered over a polished stainless steel base a half-inch thick.

title: Greenspan, Broadly Positive, Spells Out Deflation Worries
description: While offering a generally optimistic view of the economy, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, issued his strongest warning yet today about the dangers posed by deflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAGGARTY, , KEVIN F.
description: HAGGARTY--Kevin F. Of Larchmont NY and formerly of Greenpoint, Brooklyn at age 60 on May 20, 2003. Beloved husband to Cathy, and father to Mark, Christopher, and Lizzie, and father-in-law to Amy. As Executive Managing Director of Insignia/ ESG's Capital Advisors Group, he was one of the most well respected investment sales brokers in the commercial real estate industry. During his professional career, which spanned 25 years, his clients included some of the nation's leading institutions including Lend Lease, MetLife, and Teachers Insurance & Annuity Association among others. He was a wonderful father, an inspiration to his three children, and a devoted husband of 32 years. He was an exceptionally generous man, kind, gracious, compassionate and wise, and he warmly enriched the lives of all who knew him. His family and friends are deeply saddened by the loss and will miss him immeasurably. Viewing hours, Thursday, May 22, 7pm-9pm and Friday, May 23, 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY; funeral mass service Saturday, May 24, at 9:30am, St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont Avenue (just past Boston Post Road). In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Kevin's name to the following charities: Larchmont Friends of the Family, PO Box 746, Larchmont, NY 10538, or College Track, 1846 Bay Road, East Palo Alto, CA 94303, a non - profit organization where Kevin's son Mark is employed.

title: In an Iraqi Port, a Symbolic Step Toward Self-Government
description: UMM QASR, Iraq, May 22  The British military handed over Iraq's major port to local administrators today in a symbolic transfer of power intended to show how Iraqis were slowly beginning to take control of the key elements of their country.

title: Bush Visits Capitol Hill to Voice Support for Tax Cut Deal
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 — President Bush promised today to sign the $318 billion tax cut bill that Congressional negotiators agreed to late Wednesday, even though it offered less than half the tax relief he had wanted.

title: Lessons for Iraq Seen in Balkan Aftermath
description: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz says his recent trip to the Balkans and Eastern Europe holds lessons on postwar stabilization and the transition from dictatorship to democracy that are helping shape his views on how best to rebuild Iraq.

title: 6 Skeletons From Bronze Age Found Near Stonehenge
description: Archaeologists announced today that they had unearthed the skeletons of four adults and two children, perhaps 4,300 years old, all lying in a single grave, only three miles from Stonehenge, in a find that dates to the beginning of the Bronze Age.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: PHOTRONICS SHARES SURGE ON PROFIT NEWS Shares of Photronics Inc. , a maker of quartz plates used to build computer chips, rose 13 percent after the company said it would have a profit before some costs this quarter. The stock gained $1.71, to $14.83, at the close of trading yesterday on the Nasdaq Stock Market. Photronics will become profitable in the quarter ending in July, its chief executive, Dan Del Rosario, said. The profit will exclude 3 cents a share in costs for retiring a $62.1 million note, Michael McCarthy, a spokesman, said. Analysts on average expected a 5-cent loss, according to Thomson Financial. The company, based in Brookfield, Conn., makes photomasks, or templates used to transfer chip designs onto silicon wafers. It has laid off about 10 percent of its workers and cut management salaries to help break even on quarterly sales of $87 million to $88 million. It said its second-quarter net loss was $44.1 million, or $1.37 a share, for the period ended May 4, in contrast to net income of $2.52 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 17 percent, to $85.5 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mobster's In-Law Charged In Plot
description: The United States attorney's office has charged in a new indictment that one of the men who conspired in a plot several years ago to kill the Mafia turncoat Salvatore Gravano was his brother-in law, Edward Garafola. The unrealized plot to kill Mr. Gravano, a former underboss of the Gambino crime family who became an important government witness and was later arrested on drug charges, was revealed last week in an indictment in Brooklyn. Mr. Garafola already faces federal racketeering charges in Manhattan, to which he has pleaded not guilty. He is married to Mr. Gravano's sister, according to the F.B.I. The new indictment says he joined in the plot to maintain his position in the Gambino family. Mr. Garafola's lawyer, Michael Rosen, said his client would also plead not guilty to the new charges. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Trading War Stories In Cannes's Doldrums
description: The prevailing perception of the Cannes Film Festival is red carpet premieres, with actresses like Nicole Kidman flashing a platinum smile to the paparazzi while photographers' lights bounce off her gloriously impermeable lip gloss. The festival is the place where the Palme d'Or and other highly coveted prizes are awarded at the festival or its counterpart, Directors' Fortnight. But as much as anything Cannes is also a market -- essentially a convention, where producers show up to sell their wares to distributors from around the world.

description: Turning back an anti-tax tide that has swept Oregon in recent years, Portland-area voters approved a ballot measure that will levy the state's only county income tax, channeling new financing to schools, law enforcement and other agencies.

description: Tens of thousands of pitches have sizzled from Roger Clemens's right hand in the last two decades. Tonight one line drive screamed right at it, threatening to postpone a date with history 40 years in the making.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 11 about a disagreement among Orthodox Jews in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, over a symbolic boundary known as an eruv -- within which objects may be carried outside the home on the Sabbath despite the overall prohibition against work -- referred imprecisely to the issue. Certain rabbis and their supporters assert that the Williamsburg eruv is not legitimate and that Williamsburg's observant Jews are thus forbidden to avail themselves of it. Their opposition does not apply to every eruv or to observant Jews elsewhere.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Party Defends Itself
description: Fianna Fail, the dominant party in Parliament, has published a 14-page pamphlet defending itself against claims that it made false campaign promises last year. ''There has been a concerted campaign to convince people that they were conned by Fianna Fail on the economic situation prior to the election,' it said. ''Nothing could be further from the truth.'' The party has won the most parliamentary seats in every election since 1932, but its support has fallen. Brian Lavery (NYT)

Everyone else on the road was left to fumble with old-fashioned road maps or to print out turn-by-turn directions from Web sites like MapQuest.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Inhumane Conditions On Death Row
description: A federal judge ordered the state to remedy inhumane conditions on its death row in Parchman. Magistrate Jerry Davis said the 69 inmates on death row often endured sweltering heat, mosquitoes, squalor and a plumbing system that backs up. ''It really upholds the principle that all prisoners are entitled to humane treatment,'' Margaret Winter, of the American Civil Liberties Union's National Prison Project, said of the judge's order.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Legato To Dismiss Up To 6% Of Work Force
description: Legato Systems Inc., which makes software to manage and protect data-storage systems, will lay off up to 6 percent of its work force by June 30 as it seeks to cut costs. The company expects to have 1,480 to 1,500 workers after the cuts are made, Sandy O'Halloran, a spokeswoman, said yesterday. The company had 1,563 employees at the end of the first quarter and 1,577 at the end of 2002. The total number of jobs to be cut has not yet been determined, she said. No ''operations will be shut down and no products being are being discontinued,'' Ms. O'Halloran said. ''The job cuts are across the board, all areas in the organization will be affected.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 150 Held In Redevelopment Fight
description: The police detained more than 150 people protesting the demolition of their homes in Shanghai, protesters and a human rights group said. The police rounded up the protesters at the Shanghai train station as they prepared to travel to Beijing, where they planned to complain about the destruction of their homes and neighborhoods. The incident is the latest in a string of bitter disputes in Shanghai, where the authorities have approved the redevelopment of many downtown districts to make way for commercial development. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ACOSTA, RUA, , DR. GASTON J.
description: ACOSTA-RUA--Dr. Gaston J., passed away peacefully the morning of Monday, May 19, 2003. Born August 26, 1937, in Cardenas, Cuba, Dr. AcostaRua moved to Jacksonville, Florida in 1972 to practice medicine and raise his family. He was a well respected neurosurgeon who was involved in many humanitarian endeavors. As a fateful and active member of the Catholic Dioceses of St. Augustine, FL and a Knight of the Order of Malta, he gave much of his time and effort to those in need both in the local community and around the world. He is survived by his loving wife of 39 years, Maria Victoria, sons Gaston, Fernando and Antonio, five grandchildren, Fernando Jr, Daria Victoria, Mills Hunter, Gaston Alexander and Eleanor Somerset, brother Gustavo Acosta and many loving friends. Funeral services will be held at St. Matthew's Catholic Church, 1773 Blanding Blvd, on Friday, May 23, 2003, at 11:00am, followed by burial at Evergreen Cemetery, 4535 North Main St. The family invites friends to visit the Hardage-Giddons Funeral Home, 729 South Edgewood Ave, Jacksonville, FL, from 6-9pm, Thursday, May 22. Vigil prayer services will be held 7pm Thursday at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the AcostaRua Family Foundation Inc, 2323 Oak Street, Jacksonville, FL 32204, a charitable organization helping the needy both in the U.S. and abroad. >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Investors Reject Plan On Options
description: Intel shareholders yesterday rejected a plan that would have required the company to treat employee stock options as an expense in financial statements. About 48 percent of investors voted in favor of the proposal, Intel said at its annual stockholders' meeting. The company opposed the nonbinding plan, and some shareholders criticized Intel's resistance to expensing options, saying that they inflated profit. Intel, the world's biggest computer chip maker, has said 2002 net income would have been 38 percent less than its reported $3.12 billion had it accounted for options as an expense. An accounting rule called F.A.S. 123 allows companies to estimate the cost of options in footnotes to income statements, rather than recognizing them as a compensation cost. Intel shares rose 18 cents, to $18.84.

title: Annika Sorenstam Tees Off
description: In the contest between William Johnson, known as Hootie, and Martha Burk at the Masters last month, neither player teed up a golf ball. The issue was the right of women to play as members at Augusta National, not their ability to play. But when Annika Sorenstam tees it up at the first hole of the Colonial tournament today in Fort Worth, her competitors will all be men, and the question on everyone's mind will be ability. No one doubts Ms. Sorenstam's extraordinary performance on her home circuit, the L.P.G.A., where she won 11 times last year. But no one knows, yet, how she will do when she takes her game directly to the P.G.A. People have guessed, but so far their guesses have depended more on gauging her motivation than on gauging her game.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Aid For Economy Urged
description: The Bank of Japan's governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said the government should take additional steps to head off a financial crisis, adding his voice to a growing chorus of policy makers calling for more pre-emptive action. Mr. Fukui said that Japan's financial system was weak and that there could be a crisis without further measures. His comments come four days after Japan's fifth-largest bank group asked the government for emergency funds. Financial regulators are now mulling whether to make it easier to force banks to take public money before their capital falls below legal minimums. Underscoring Mr. Fukui's fears, the central bank downgraded its view of the economy for the first time since November, blaming the strengthening yen and the SARS epidemic. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Man Convicted Of Killing Wife
description: A Long Island man was convicted yesterday of murder for fatally shooting his wife in the head as she prepared the family's Greek Orthodox Easter dinner last year. The man, Nikolaos Kotsopoulos, of Manhasset, at first blamed an intruder for the shooting of his wife, Carol, 41, on May 4, 2002. But during the trial in Nassau County Court, prosecutors said Mr. Kotsopoulos had killed his wife after abusing her for years. A jury deliberated for less than five hours before convicting him of second-degree murder and assault for beating her before the shooting. Mr. Kotsopoulos, who is to be sentenced on June 19, faces a maximum prison sentence of 25 years to life. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lacey Township: Nuclear Plant Shutdown
description: The Oyster Creek nuclear power plant will remain closed indefinitely until investigators determine the cause of a power interruption on Tuesday morning, authorities said yesterday. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said the plant was shut down manually after a cable linking a diesel generator and a power source, known as a bus, malfunctioned. The plant lost power for half of its vital safety systems, said Neil Sheehan, a spokesman for the nuclear agency. There were no environmental or safety problems associated with the failure. The plant went online in 1969 and was closed for a week in 2001 after an equipment failure.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City and Detectives Reach Agreement
description: The city reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday with the union representing New York City's detectives that raises their pay and benefits by 11.5 percent over two and a half years. The deal, which is retroactive to 2001 and expires next February, would raise the salaries of third-grade detectives to $61,670 from $55,936 and first-grade detectives to $79,547 from $72,151, officials said. Thomas J. Scotto, the president of the union, the Detectives' Endowment Association, said he expected the union's membership to ratify the contract. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the leadership of Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey misstated the timing of the appointment of Amiri Baraka as poet laureate of the state and the governor's role in it. Mr. Baraka was appointed before, not after, he read a poem at a festival that suggested that Israelis had been forewarned about the 9/11 attacks. While Mr. McGreevey signed a proclamation in August 2002 appointing Mr. Baraka to the $10,000-a-year post, for which a state arts commmittee had recommended him, the governor did not insist on the appointment. He later called for Mr. Baraka to resign.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: Brazil's central bank kept the benchmark overnight interest rate unchanged at 26.5 percent for a third month, sacrificing economic growth to prevent inflation from accelerating. Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, the president of Brazil who is a former union leader with a strong base of support among workers, said he wanted to fight inflation to avoid eroding the salaries of the poorest Brazilians. While some indicators show inflation easing, the annual inflation rate jumped to 16.8 percent in April, a seven-year high, and twice the central bank's 8.5 percent target for 2003. Brazil also reported yesterday that its jobless rate rose to its highest level in a year, 12.4 percent, in April from 12.1 percent in March.

title: Heralding Olympiad With Arts Of Greece

Conceived and directed by Costa-Gavras, the Greek filmmaker, and presented on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, this one-time program of Greek folk and popular music, film, recitation and dance was a delight. It featured performances by four popular Greek artists and a first-rate company of musicians, a new short film by Costa-Gavras and a new Greek-theme ballet by Lar Lubovitch.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Synopsys Posts 2nd-Quarter Profit

Net income increased to $22.3 million, or 29 cents a share, from $21.4 million, or 33 cents, a year earlier, Synopsys said. Sales in the quarter, which ended May 3, rose 57 percent, to $292 million from $185.6 million, increased by the acquisition of the Avanti Corporation last year. Shares of Synopsys surged as much as 6.1 percent, to $54, in extended trading after the report. They were up by 43 cents, to $50.90, in regular trading.

description: President Hosni Mubarak and his justice and interior ministers will form a National Council for Human Rights to safeguard individual rights, the information minister, Safwat al-Sharif, said. Mr. Sharif said a proposal for the rights body would soon be submitted to Parliament. He said the president also discussed the abolition of state security courts, formed in 1980 under an emergency law. Their continuation has drawn criticism from rights groups. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: White Accepts The Blame
description: Colin White stood at his dressing-room stall late tonight and, softly and almost apologetically, continued to say he wished he could come up with some kind of an explanation for his split-second, last-minute, game-turning decision.

title: U.N. Health Agency's New Head Pledges Stronger Response to Epidemics Like SARS
description: Dr. Jong-Wook Lee was elected director general of the World Health Organization yesterday and then pledged to expand and strengthen the agency's response network to help alert the world to epidemics like severe acute respiratory syndrome.

title: Metro Matters; Needs Other Than Hunger Fill Pantries
description: THEY are everywhere and increasingly insistent: warnings of growing hunger in New York, of demand outstripping supply, of shortages at food pantries. ''Not since the Great Depression has there been a time of such hunger,'' says City Harvest in a recent fund-raising letter. Are thousands of New Yorkers hungry? Is one of every four city children not getting enough to eat, as a magazine ad featuring Whoopi Goldberg contends?

title: Ruse Obtains DNA Sample, and Arrest, for Killing
description: One night in November 1982, Kristen Sumstad, 13, was raped and strangled with a cloth cord in a pleasant neighborhood in Seattle. The investigation lingered unsolved for nearly 21 years.

title: Six Firehouses Receive Order to Close by Sunday Morning, as Lawsuit to Save Them Proceeds
description: The Bloomberg administration moved closer to shutting down six fire companies yesterday when the Fire Department told the units that they would close on Sunday morning.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Lewiston Mayor Stepping Down
description: The mayor of Lewiston, Laurier T. Raymond, who last year asked that residents from Somalia advise other Somalis not to come to the city, has announced he will not seek re-election when his term ends in December. In a letter in October, Mr. Raymond said the city was ''maxed-out financially, physically, and emotionally'' by an influx of more than 1,000 Somalis in less than two years. The statement exacerbated racial tensions in the predominately working-class city of 36,000. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Iraqi Looters Raid Sites
description: U.S. forces have aggressively reined in looters in Baghdad, but have done little to protect Iraq's numerous archaeological sites.

title: The First Round
description: Scenes from a memorable 18 holes at the Colonial.

title: Earthquake Hits Algiers
description: A powerful earthquake struck the Algerian capital region Wednesday night, killing hundreds of people and injuring thousands.

title: Minding the Media
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about growing support for a revised Security Council resolution ending sanctions on Iraq misstated the given name of the Russian foreign minister, who commented on it. He is Igor Ivanov, not Ivan.

title: Algerians Begin Burying Dead From Quake; Death Toll Rises
description: BOUMERDES, Algeria, May 23  Volunteers and rescue workers here searched through the rubble of apartment buildings for surivors of Wednesday's earthquake as thousands of male mourners crowded into El Alia cemetery near Algiers today to begin burying the dead.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: An article last June 15 described the lives and attitudes of oystermen on the Florida Gulf Coast who faced threats to their livelihood from overuse of water farther north. It carried the byline of Rick Bragg, and the dateline indicated that the reporting was done in Apalachicola.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Underground Economics Equals Money to Be Made
description: REEFER MADNESS -- Sex, Drugs, and Cheap Labor in the American Black Market

title: At City College Reunion, Strivers Bridge a 50-Year Gap
description: Critics have said that City College -- once known as ''the poor man's Harvard'' -- is not what it used to be. This year's 50th-reunion class set out to discover for itself. But how to take the measure of a college?

title: Olafur Eliasson
description: Tanya Bonakdar Gallery

title: Prejudice or Prudence on SARS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Alejandro DeTomaso, 74, Maker of Sports Cars, Dies
description: Alejandro DeTomaso, whose company produced a sports car that combined Italian flair with American horsepower, died on Wednesday in Modena, Italy. He was 74.

title: Early ad sales for the 2003-4 TV season turn into a 'runaway sellers' market.'
description: NEVER mind Ruben and Clay. Madison Avenue agencies are voting, with a record amount of client dollars, for their own American idol: broadcast network television.

title: SOROS PUMPS $1 MILLION MORE INTO INTERNET RETAILER
description: The billionaire investor George Soros invested an additional $1 million in the unprofitable Internet retailer Bluefly Inc., fulfilling a promise he made in March. Affiliates of Soros Private Equity Partners purchased preferred stock, which can be exchanged for common shares of Bluefly for no more than 76 cents each, Bluefly said. Mr. Soros now owns about 90 percent of Bluefly's common stock. The retailer, which is based in New York, sells designer clothing at a discount.

title: U.S. Seeking Guantnamo Defense Staff
description: Have a law degree? Willing to work for low pay in an exotic locale? Then Uncle Sam wants you.

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: JUDGE'S SUSPENSION RECOMMENDED The State Judiciary Commission has found that a civil district judge diverted his staff from regular duties to raise campaign money from lawyers who appeared before his division of the court and that he lied about it to the commission. The judge, C. Hunter King of Orleans Parish, fired a court reporter, Barbara C. Wallace, who complained that her regular work was getting pushed aside, the commission found. It recommended to the State Supreme Court that the judge be suspended for a year without pay and pay $693.50 in investigation costs.

title: AIRCRAFT COMPONENTS SUPPLIER TO BUY BRITISH UNIT
description: Esterline Technologies Corporation, a maker of electronic components for the Boeing Company, agreed to buy Roxboro Group's Weston aerospace-sensors unit for $88 million to expand in Britain. The unit, based in Farnborough and Enfield, England, has 450 workers. Esterline said sales at its sensors unit would rise 50 percent to about $150 million this year because of the acquisition. The unit sells temperature, pressure and motion detectors for jet engines, boats and power plants. Roxboro plans to focus on its measuring-equipment and lighting businesses. Esterline is based in Bellevue, Wash. Roxboro is based in Cambridge, England.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column on May 1 on the Ballets de Monte-Carlo benefit at the Brooklyn Academy of Music misidentified a guest. (The error was repeated in the column on May 6.) She was Veronica Hearst; Victoria Hearst is her stepdaughter.

title: British Give Port Control To the Iraqis
description: The British military handed over this major Iraqi port to local administrators today in a symbolic transfer of power intended to show that Iraqis are beginning to take control of major elements of their country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, , THEODORE
description: HIRSCH--Theodore, died on May 22, 2003 after a long illness. He was founder and president of People in Places, Inc., until his retirement in 1992. He was a playwright by avocation whose plays won several prestigious theatrical awards. Surviving are his wife Gloria Reade Hirsch, brother William Hirsch and sister-in-law Sara Hirsch. >>AD#

title: U.S.-Utah Land Accord Incites Unlikely Critics
description: Two recent agreements between Utah and the federal government, making the state the latest template for the Bush administration's public lands policy, drew a rapid and predictable response from environmental groups around the country.

title: Bar Suspends 3 Lawyers In California Over Lawsuits
description: The California State Bar has suspended three Beverly Hills lawyers who filed thousands of lawsuits against small businesses before offering out-of-court settlements.

title: Some Chinese Say Government's Response to Epidemic Has Been Too Heavy-Handed
description: As China begins to bring the SARS epidemic under control, the Communist Party is seeking to claim credit for defusing a crisis caused partly by official denial and deceit.

title: In a Muslim City in Iraq, a Christian Group Enjoys Its Lively Quarter
description: Tucked in a corner of this ancient, somber Muslim city is a neighborhood that wears skimpy clothing, eats cheeseburgers and drinks beer.

title: One Woman Tied to Spree Of Robberies In Two States
description: In her jaunty baseball cap and yellow rain slicker, the middle-aged woman with the glasses and the long blonde hair might be taken for a soccer mom. Her runabout is a red compact, maybe a Mitsubishi, and she zips from town to town, and bank to bank, like a harried suburbanite juggling too many tasks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOEN, , BETSY
description: SCHOEN--Betsy nee Schuchat, on May 21, 2003, age 85. Beloved wife of Jerry for 56 years. Survived by brothers, Theodor, Michael and David Schuchat, sisters-in-law, Molly Schuchat and Louise Harper, brother-in-law, Harold Siegell, many nieces and nephews, great-nieces and nephews, and friends. Funeral arrangements to be announced >>AD#

title: U.N. Official Gains Key Support to Be Representative in Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 23  Sergio Vieira de Mello, a long-serving United Nations executive with a reputation for diplomatic legerdemain that was capped with his success at constructing political and civic institutions out of the chaos of East Timor, is Secretary General Kofi Annan's choice as the United Nations special representative in Iraq, officials here said today.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Art, Commerce and a Heart Transplant Denied
description: In a bizarre tale of art and commerce with an unusual corporate twist, a sculpture by a celebrated modern artist has once again figured prominently in the life of a former Humana official who became a critic of managed care.

title: Paul Sietsema -- 'Empire'
description: Whitney Museum of American Art

title: Scientists Find Animal Link for SARS Virus
description: HONG KONG, May 23  A virus virtually identical to the one believed to cause SARS in humans has been found in a catlike tree-dwelling animal whose meat is a delicacy in southern China and in two other species, scientists here and at the World Health Organization said today.

title: McGehee Hitches Late Ride to Indy 500
description: Robby McGehee never made it out for the final practice for the Indianapolis 500 today because his crew was still working on the engine for his sleek black race car. This is a minor detail for him. He had no race car to drive six days ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a rise in the American Express Company's dividend misstated it. The dividend was raised by 2 cents, to 10 cents a share -- not by 10 cents, to 50 cents a share.

title: ' Minha Cara/That's My Face'
description: Directed by Thomas Allen Harris

title: Men Without Paychecks, Now Minding the Children
description: Daddy Day Care

title: On Memorial Day, Recalling Not Just the War Dead
description: ARTIE MULLER had a problem. Yes, round-the-clock medication eases the pain and numbness in both legs and arms. The hearing aids help. But shrapnel damaged nerves in his left shoulder so badly that if someone brushes against it, Mr. Muller pales and rears back. And in his line of work, which this weekend will have him speaking to at least a quarter-million bikers, an untold number will want to give him a brotherly greeting with a shoulder grip.

title: Bulletproof Vest Saves Officer; Return Fire Wounds Suspect
description: Martin Diggs walked through the streets of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, at midnight Wednesday carrying, according to the police, not one but two guns. But when Mr. Diggs, a convicted felon with a 15-year arrest record, was caught by two police officers, he begged not to be sent back to jail, a witness said.

title: 8 Cylinders, As Needed
description: When it's time to merge into a fast-moving lane of traffic, there's nothing so reassuring as the power reserve of a brawny V-8 engine. The downside is paying to fuel those eight cylinders when you have caught up to the traffic and need only the power of four to maintain the pace.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about conservative groups' opposition to the naming of Patricia Ireland, former president of the National Organization for Women, as chief executive of the Y.W.C.A. omitted a word in a comment from her in some copies, reversing its meaning. She said (with the omission denoted by uppercasing): ''We're NOT predominantly sectarian. That should keep us in good stead with the federal government.''

title: Zeya Journal; The Old Prospector: The Glitter Is in His Eye
description: We had asked only for a demonstration of the art of panning for gold, not an expedition. But that was a foolish request, and Stepan Pastukhov does not suffer fools gladly.

title: The $500,000 Phone Call
description: Last week at an Assembly hearing on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the owner of a Manhattan building explained what he had done when a huge deal with the authority had almost gone sour. He appealed to former Senator Alfonse D'Amato, now a lobbyist, for help, and Mr. D'Amato made a phone call to the person who was the M.T.A. chairman. Suddenly, things started to work out, and for that, Mr. D'Amato's firm earned $500,000.

title: Whatever His Role, Prince Takes It in Stride
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 22 - Tayshaun Prince was the last player off the court at the Detroit Pistons' shoot-around this morning. He worked on his shot until Rick Mahorn, the former Pistons enforcer and now a radio announcer, took the floor, signaling a true end to the workout.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Wine Maker To Miss Dividend
description: Australia's largest wine producer and exporter, Southcorp, will miss a dividend for the first time. After several recent profit warnings, the chairman, Brian Finn, told shareholders on Wednesday that with no recovery from a 97 percent decline in first-half profit it would be impractical to pay a final 2002-2003 dividend. Analysts expect a loss for the year of 12.8 million Australian dollars. The company, whose main brands are Penfolds, Lindemans and Rosemount, has admitted marketing errors in Britain, once its biggest buyer, as well as excessive promotional costs. Its market valuation has dropped 80 percent in 18 months and 40 percent in the last six months to 2.1 billion Australian dollars ($1.3 billion) currently.

title: A Feathered Stray, Far From Field and Stream; Can a Wild Turkey Find Success and Happiness in the Canyons of Manhattan?
description: Much about this bird is a mystery.

description: House tally for Connecticut, New Jersey and New York:

title: A Garden for All as Private Eden
description: CENTRAL PARK looks greener this spring than it has in recent memory. Is this my imagination or the result of scientifically verifiable causes, like rain? I prefer to think that nature is making a bigger effort than usual this year to celebrate a very special occasion: the 150th anniversary of Central Park's birth.

title: Johnson Leads Bench Players in Adding Some Spark
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 22 - Anthony Johnson did not hesitate, pulling up behind the 3-point line before a coach or conscience could persuade him not to unload the shot. Johnson, a backup guard for the Nets, fired up the 3-point attempt. Even before it slipped through the net, he was racing to the other end of the floor with his arms raised, pumping up the sold-out crowd at Continental Arena.

title: All About Leather: You May Not Want Corinthian After All
description: Quality GRAIN Natural patterns and blemishes on the hide. Full-grain is the most natural and least processed. Top grain is from the hide's outer layer and is often sanded.

title: There Is Enough Electricity For Summer Cooling, if . . .
description: As people in and around New York City prepare to rev up their air-conditioners, the electricity industry says there will be enough power to keep all that cool air pumping all summer. Probably. Unless something happens. Like it gets really hot.

title: Dollar Takes a Dip, and Analysts Foresee Further Declines
description: LONDON, May 23  The dollar plunged against the euro today, even in the absence of a compelling new catalyst, suggesting that a bearish view had so firmly taken hold in the market that the dollar could fall significantly further, analysts said.

title: Foot Locker Says Net Nearly Doubled on 3.7% Rise in Sales
description: Foot Locker Inc., the athletic-shoe retailer, said yesterday that fiscal first-quarter earnings almost doubled. The company also said that profit in its current quarter would meet or exceed forecasts.

title: So Far, the Mets' Youth Movement Is Paying Off
description: Mike Piazza today earns the right to veto any trade, as a player with 10 years of major league experience and the last five with one team. He marked his fifth anniversary with the Mets yesterday in the training room while outside, on a day as gloomy as the Mets' season, their youth movement continued.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: PROTON ENERGY WILL ACQUIRE NORTHERN POWER Proton Energy Systems , which makes devices that use electricity to convert water into hydrogen for fuel cells, said yesterday that it would acquire Northern Power Systems, a leading designer of small power systems for businesses and institutions that want to generate their own electricity. Proton Energy, which is based in Wallingford, Conn., went public in 2000 at $17 a share and traded as high as $28.62 that year, but the price plummeted as the projected dates for widespread fuel cell use were repeatedly pushed back. It closed yesterday at $3.24, up 38 cents, or 13 percent, on the Nasdaq. Northern Power, a privately held company based in Waitsfield, Vt., has built hundreds of energy systems for pipelines, industrial sites and commercial buildings, many of them incorporating renewable energy sources. Proton will pay $27.5 million in cash and stock for Northern and issue warrants for Northern shareholders to buy 2.5 million Proton shares when the deal closes.   Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Publicis Agency To Focus on P.& G.
description: The Publicis Groupe is forming a media planning agency in the United States to work only for Procter & Gamble, the largest Publicis client.

description: McKee Gallery

description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Shift British Troops to Baghdad Is Scuttled by London
description: A plan to shift British troops to Baghdad to help secure the capital was shelved today after officials in London objected to extending the soldiers' tour of duty in Iraq, allied officials said tonight.

title: Manchester United Pursues U.S. Goalie
description: Manchester United, one of the world's most prestigious soccer clubs, is negotiating with Major League Soccer officials to sign Tim Howard, the MetroStars' goalie.

title: M.T.A. Director, Under Fire, Agrees to Back Law on Lobbying
description: The executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that she would agree to new legislation to strengthen controls on those who lobby the authority, which last year awarded more than $5 billion in contracts.
