description: House tally for Connecticut, New Jersey and New York:

title: Sports of The Times; 'I'll Never Forget This Day In My Life'
description: IN golf, you sign a scorecard to attest to the numbers after you finish the round. But yesterday Annika Sorenstam signed what she later called ''a bunch of scorecards'' as she waited to tee off at the Colonial. Nobody had to tell her why.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Fighting Women's Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dance of Africa and Its Diaspora: An Art of Variety and Self-Discovery
description: Just what Negro or black or African-American dance is and should be has been a subject of heated, lively discussion since at least as far back as the Harlem Renaissance in the 1920's. Dancers have gone to Africa (Pearl Primus) or the Caribbean (Katherine Dunham) to redisover their roots in one way or another.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Lawmaker Detained
description: A judge has ordered the detention of Juan Pablo Letelier, an influential member of Congress from the governing Socialist Party, on suspicion that he accepted improper payments from a company with a government contract. The action against Mr. Letelier, the son of Orlando Letelier, a former foreign minister assassinated in 1976, came a day after President Ricardo Lagos acknowledged the seriousness of a spreading corruption scandal and promised a crackdown. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: ECHOSTAR TO PAY $5 MILLION TO SETTLE COMPLAINTS The EchoStar Communications Corporation has agreed to pay $5 million to settle customer complaints about its satellite TV service in 13 states, Colorado's attorney general said yesterday. Prosecutors in those states have been investigating EchoStar for reportedly violating consumer protection laws, but no lawsuits have been filed. A telephone message seeking comment from the company was not immediately returned. The settlement involves about 1,800 complaints from consumers who said they were misled on pricing and contract issues involving EchoStar's Dish Network, the attorney general, Ken Salazar, said. Some people had complained that ads failed to disclose early termination fees, Mr. Salazar said. About $3 million of the settlement will be used to compensate consumers, and the rest will be used to cover the cost of the states' 18-month investigation. The settlement will take effect without court approval in September. EchoStar shares rose $1.14, or 3.7 percent, to $32.24 on the Nasdaq.    (AP)

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDGOOD, , FREDERIC ELIOT
description: FREEDGOOD -- Frederic Eliot, September 24, 1920 to May 20, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Frances Freedgood; devoted father of Elizabeth Breyer and her husband John, and of Charles Freedgood and his wife Susan; grandfather of Julia and Jackson Breyer and of Samuel and Jacob Freedgood. >>AD#

title: Bayer's Export Policy Upheld By a European Court Adviser
description: A senior European legal official said today that the European Commission had been wrong to punish Bayer, the German drug maker, seven years ago for trying to prevent pharmaceuticals wholesalers from exporting its heart drug Adalat from one European Union country to another.

title: The Shape of Hunger
description: Meet Aberash Andreos. She's a 6-year-old girl from a remote village in southern Ethiopia. I met her at a Catholic-run clinic near the town of Awassa, where she was among the throngs of children awaiting lifesaving milk to rescue them from the famine that threatens millions of people in the Horn of Africa.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Seattle

title: Sea Kayaking
description: Sea kayaking is the recreational heir to a survival tradition used by the Inuit and Greenlander people in the Arctic at least 4,000 years ago. The requirements are basic: a boat and a paddle. Despite its name, a sea is not needed to enjoy this sport, just a body of water -- and a desire to explore. Kayakers call this gunkholing, an old mariner term for traveling from island to island in a spirit of discovery.

title: Nothing Sells a Convertible Like Summer
description: ALL winter and into the spring, a pair of 2002 Thunderbird convertibles -- one red, one black -- sat outside Wyckoff Ford, a small dealership in Wyckoff, a town in northern New Jersey. Nobody wanted them. A sedan, perhaps. An S.U.V. to take on the snow, certainly. But no convertibles. Then, suddenly, both were snapped up in the same week: the red one on April 28, the black one on May 1. A 50-ish lawyer drove off with the red one; tomorrow, Lynn White, a 61-year-old boutique owner, will pick up the black one.

title: Life as a Freak Show of Perversions
description: It takes more than spicy ingredients to make something hot. ''Mondo Drama,'' the promisingly titled new comic revue by Douglas Carter Beane, should be the perfect prologue to a season of summer camp -- of bad beach books and expensively silly movies.

title: Canada Quarantines Six More Ranches in Mad Cow Case
description: Tracing the winding trail of a single cow found to be infected with mad cow disease, Canadian agricultural officials quarantined six more cattle ranches today across two northern prairie provinces where she and her offspring had lived, in an effort to stem mounting economic damage.

title: Bush Chooses White House Adviser as Budget Director
description: President Bush chose a little-known but highly influential White House adviser, Joshua Bolten, today as the director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Rolls-Royce or Hyundai, Leather Makes the Car
description: CAN any other part of an automobile exude an aura of quality like rich, buttery-soft leather upholstery? In a convertible, it's on display to the world; in any car, it radiates comfort. Sumptuous leather interiors are longstanding hallmarks of makers like Jaguar, Bentley and Rolls-Royce . For a luxurious immersion, sink back into the soft leather folds of the seats in a Lexus LS430 sedan.

title: Game 7? Brodeur Has Been There
description: If the Devils have an advantage in the Eastern Conference finals after allowing a three-games-to-one lead over the Ottawa Senators slip away, it is that Martin Brodeur will be in goal for Game 7 here Friday night.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Posts Profit
description: A Strong performance in Zurich Financial Service's nonlife business helped offset a large write-down on its equity and currency holding, leading the insurance company to swing to a $114 million profit in the first three months of 2003 from a record-breaking loss last year. Zurich's chief executive, James J. Shiro, said the write-down resulted partly from a decline in the value of its equity investments when stock prices fell in March. That loss was offset, however, by good prices for its nonlife insurance products, Mr. Shiro said. Zurich, which also owns Farmers Insurance in the United States, raised its prices, and premiums from its nonlife products rose by 32 percent. Zurich also said it sold its Dutch operations in consumer and small business segments for an undisclosed sum. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: PRUDENTIAL SELLING TWO INSURANCE UNITS
description: Prudential Financial Inc., the leading life insurer, said it had agreed to sell its auto and homeowners' insurance businesses to Liberty Mutual Insurance Group and Palisades Safety & Insurance Association for $673 million. Palisades, of Berkeley Heights, N.J., is buying Prudential's New Jersey business for $260 million. Liberty Mutual, based in Boston, is buying the operations in 47 other states and the District of Columbia for $413 million in notes. Prudential said the two sales represented a loss of $262 million, or 48 cents a share.

title: House Passes Tax Cut Bill; Senate Action Is Set Today
description: Hours after President Bush made an unusual Capitol Hill appearance to urge them on, members of the House approved his signature domestic priority early today, passing a $350 billion package of tax cuts and state assistance intended to energize the economy.

title: A New Target in Basra: Liquor Stores and Their Owners
description: BASRA, Iraq, May 20  The discos here used to close at dawn. The bars served up everything from Scotch whiskey to Iraqi wine. Basra was a party town in the 1970's and 80's, one that drew not only locals but Kuwaitis and other foreigners eager for revelry in a region that is otherwise as dry as a bone.

title: McDonald's Chief Stresses Food Safety
description: In his first face-to-face meeting with shareholders, James R. Cantalupo, McDonald's new chief executive, tried today to play down concerns about mad cow disease in Canada and focus instead on his plan to revitalize the McDonald's brand.

title: Bush Cuts Taxes but Lets Reform Ideas Die
description: TAX cuts come and go. It is tax reform that endures.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Marijuana Penalty
description: Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. signed into law a measure that reduces the maximum penalty for medicinal marijuana use to a $100 fine. Mr. Ehrlich, a Republican, signed the measure despite opposition from the Bush administration. The law applies to those who can prove that they smoked marijuana out of medical necessity. For others, marijuana possession carries a maximum penalty of a year's imprisonment and a $1,000 fine. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Accounting Firm Agrees To $1 Million Settlement
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the nation's largest accounting firm, has agreed to pay $1 million to settle federal regulators' accusations that the firm acted improperly during a 1997 audit of a telecommunications company, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asylum Applications Decline
description: The government announced a 32 percent decrease in the number of people applying for asylum in the first three months of this year, down to 16,000 from 23,385 in the same period last year. Asylum claims reached a record total of 110,000 in 2002, prompting Prime Minister Tony Blair to pledge to cut the number with tough new rules. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day, actually May 30, will be legally observed.

title: A Lady With Eager Suitors, In a Scotland a Lot Like Italy
description: It's easy to summarize Rossini's opera ''La Donna del Lago,'' as performed by the Opera Orchestra of New York on Monday night. There was Stephanie Blythe, and then there was everybody else.

title: Iraq's Silenced Majority
description: When I was a schoolgirl in Iraq in the 1980's, April 28 was the day Baath Party officials would round up students and force us to march in rallies celebrating Saddam Hussein's birthday. This year on that date I celebrated at a very different kind of gathering: the United States-organized conference in Baghdad to determine a new government for the liberated Iraq.

title: Home Builders and Tobacco Companies Lead a Rally
description: Stocks rose yesterday on optimism that earnings growth would pick up as a survey of business economists reinforced the Federal Reserve chairman's statement that the economy might accelerate.

title: Costa Rica Intervenes at Troubled U.S.-Owned Academy
description: The Costa Rican authorities moved today to seize an American-owned behavior-modification academy for children after hearing allegations of physical and emotional abuse, officials said.

title: Anti-Semitism Endures
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Want Federal Bailout to Find Its Way to Localities
description: New York State stands to receive at least $2 billion from an aid package that Congressional leaders have put together to help states grapple with the worst fiscal crisis they have faced in decades, lawmakers announced today.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Ban On Animal Traps Remains
description: Gov. Gary Locke vetoed a bill that would have rolled back a ban on the use of ''body-gripping'' animal traps. Voters passed an initiative banning the traps in 2000, but land managers, like timber companies, have said they cannot manage pests like mountain beavers without the traps, said Bob Nichols, a policy adviser to the governor. Mr. Nichols said the governor supported a partial repeal of the ban but considered the legislation contrary to the spirit of the initiative. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Ex-Officer Pleads Not Guilty
description: A former Yugoslav Army officer, Miroslav Radic, has pleaded not guilty to charges of involvement in a 1991 massacre in the Croatian town of Vukovar. The United Nations war crimes tribunal had charged him with overseeing the execution of about 200 civilians, many of them pulled from a local hospital, during a siege of Vukovar. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about President Bush's Middle East policy misstated the name of a Democratic member of Congress from California who organized a letter commending it. The Democrat is Lois Capps, not Louis.

title: BIG HOSPITAL CHAIN REDUCES PROFIT FORECAST
description: HCA Inc., the big hospital chain, said second-quarter pretax profit would be reduced by $110 million to $130 million as the company abandons work on a new billing system. HCA had spent about $123 million on the project, which was intended to integrate accounts receivable functions in an Internet-based system, the company said. A regional system combining back-office functions like bill collection made the billing project unnecessary, the chief executive, Jack Bovender, said. HCA expects to generate annual savings of $200 million to $225 million, or 5 cents to 7 cents a share, by discontinuing the project.

title: Shopping List | Outdoor Cookers
description: NOTE to seasonal grillers: if you don't have aprons, tongs and a killer burger recipe by now, you should turn in your Memorial Day credentials. But if you're looking for the best way to grill those burgers, there are plenty of innovative cookers to consider. Decisions must be made. Gas or charcoal? Portability or stability? We're passing the torch to the following. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYNCH, , ELIZABETH
description: LYNCH--Elizabeth. The Department of Neurological Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University mourns the loss of Mrs. James Simpson Lynch. Betty over the years provided support and encouragement for the educational, research and humanistic missions of our department. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RADMAN, , JUDITH ANN KUSCH SINCLAIR
description: RADMAN--Judith Ann Kusch Sinclair, May 20, 2003. ''Ever grateful will we be for these joyous days''--for the friendship begun at Birch Wathen, for the decades of wonderful friendship that followed. Your intelligence, your easy elegance, your clear straight eye for people and politics, your warmth and wit are a part of us always. Joan Hamburg Cera Patricia Eliscu Lee Alice Katz Berglas >>AD#

title: Iraqi Looters Tearing Up Archaeological Sites
description: Mobs of treasure hunters are tearing into Iraqi archaeological sites, stealing urns, statues, vases and cuneiform tablets that often date back 3,000 years and more to Babylon and Sumer, archaeologists say.

title: Wakeboarding
description: Imagine that you are skateboarding on water while being pulled by a powerful motorboat and you're on your way to understanding wakeboarding. One of the fastest-growing water sports, wakeboarding used to be the exclusive domain of teenage boys and a few movie-star enthusiasts like Keanu Reeves. But wakeboard instructors are now getting calls from men and women of all ages.

title: Phone Companies See Their Future In Flat-Rate Plans Of Many Services
description: Fifteen years ago, Arthur C. Clarke in the science-fiction novel ''2061: Odyssey Three'' predicted a future as follows: ''With the historic abolition of long-distance charges on 31 December 2000, every telephone call became a local one, and the human race greeted the new millennium by transforming itself into one huge, gossiping family.''

title: World Briefing | The Arctic: North Pole: Waiting On Top Of The World
description: Pen Hadow, a British adventurer who completed a 64-day trek to the North Pole on Monday, faces at least several more days there with dwindling rations and no one within 500 miles, his wife said. Bad weather in the Canadian Arctic has grounded aircraft chartered to pluck him from the drifting sea ice. Mr. Hadow, 41, skied and hiked the 478 miles alone and unaided, becoming the first person to do so from North America. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, , ALLAN S.
description: KAPLAN--Allan S. The employees of Lehman Brothers deeply mourn the loss of our trusted, loyal and beloved colleague and friend for 36 years. Mr. Kaplan was a vice chairman of Lehman Brothers and also served as chairman of the Firm's Investment Banking Commitment Committee, Fairness Opinion Committee and Investment Committee. During his career at Lehman Brothers, he had many different responsibilities, including research, investment banking, commercial paper and credit, earning the highest respect from employees at all levels. Importantly, he served as a pivotal bridge among all of our businesses, as well as a bridge between the Firm's history and the present, providing us with his invaluable perspective, wisdom, experience and advice. We are forever grateful for his tremendous contributions and unwavering loyalty to the Firm. His loss is felt in every corner of the organization. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and prayers to his wife, Alice, his children and grandchildren. Richard S. Fuld Jr. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Joseph M. Gregory Chief Operating Officer Bradley H. Jack Chief Operating Officer

title: Study Says China Is Decades Behind U.S. in Military Power
description: Despite its growing economic power, China is at least two decades behind the United States in military technology and ability, according to a report released yesterday by the Council on Foreign Relations.

title: Not Quite All Annika, But Close Enough
description: Annika Sorenstam made me get up at 5:30 yesterday morning in my Boston hotel room, which did not have the USA Network, to fly home to watch her play at the Colonial from 9:58 a.m. to 2:18 p.m. No other golfer, not Tiger Woods, or Tim Conway's Dorf, could prompt me into such diligence.

title: 36 Hours | North Myrtle Beach, S.C.
description: IN summer, North Myrtle Beach swings to the beat of the shag. Perhaps best known as a reasonably priced destination for golfers -- there are more than 100 courses in the area, most open to the public -- this coastal resort town is also home to a swinglike dance craze that originated in the 1930's and still has a fervid following among people who pack the area's clubs on a nightly basis. (The shag was designated the ''state dance'' by the South Carolina General Assembly in 1984; thousands of shaggers from around the country gather in North Myrtle Beach twice a year, in late April and in September, for 10-day marathons.) North Myrtle Beach accounts for nine miles of the Grand Strand of Myrtle Beach, which stretches about 60 miles along the coast. North Myrtle Beach itself is made up of the communities of Windy Hill, Crescent Beach, Cherry Grove and Ocean Drive. Flanked by the Atlantic Ocean on the east and the Intracoastal Waterway on the west, North Myrtle Beach, with its cottages, condominium complexes and small motels, has a slightly seedy charm that is hard to resist, especially if you're itching to get out on the dance floor. CAROL WATTS

title: From Sailing To Soaring, The Sea Beckons
description: IT did not take Neil Hutchinson long to get hooked on kiteboarding. A longtime windsurfer, he went out on the water in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., four years ago to try this newer sport, which involves planting your feet on a five-foot board, attaching a waist harness to a kite and then being pulled by the kite as it whips around in the wind 100 feet in the air. (An expert kiteboarder looks like a marionette skateboarder under the control of a manic water-loving puppeteer.) It was exciting and adrenaline-packed, Mr. Hutchinson, now a professional kiteboarder, said recently. ''After two weeks of kiteboarding, 20 years of windsurfing went straight out the window.''

title: A Route of Steel and Stone
description: IMMOBILE and massive as it is, Alexander Calder's black steel sculpture ''The Arch'' seems to pirouette and gracefully bow as I motor slowly past. It stands alone in a grassy field near the entrance to the Storm King Arts Center, the 500-acre sculpture park near Mountainville, N.Y., in the Hudson Highlands foothills. Its black wing beckons visitors to enter a magic realm where enormous sculptures built from tons of inanimate, gravity-bound steel and stone appear lighter than air -- and alive.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column on May 1 on the Ballets de Monte-Carlo benefit at the Brooklyn Academy of Music misidentified a guest. (The error was repeated in the column on May 6.) She was Veronica Hearst; Victoria Hearst is her stepdaughter.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bedford: Crow Tests Positive For West Nile
description: A dead crow found in Westchester County has tested positive for West Nile virus, the state's first positive detection this year, the State Health Department said. The bird was found in Bedford on May 5. There are no indications that any humans came in contact with the bird, which appeared to be dead about one week, a spokeswoman for the Westchester County Department of Health said. The crow is among 367 birds tested by the state since January. Last year, the West Nile virus infected 85 people and led to five deaths throughout the state. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Aetna and Physician Group Settle Health Care Lawsuit

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Graphics To Cut 400 Jobs
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., whose computers are used by clients like the Walt Disney Company and the Department of Defense, will eliminate 400 jobs, or 10 percent of its staff, to stem losses. The company will have $15 million to $20 million in severance costs in the quarter ending June 27, Silicon Graphics said. The cuts will reduce expenses by about $10 million a quarter, starting in the first fiscal period, which ends Sept. 26. Silicon Graphics, whose computers are used to create special effects in movies and to search for oil, has been unprofitable in four of the last five quarters. Sales in the third quarter, which ended March 28, fell 31 percent, to $217.1 million, the company said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Frustration Continues For Pettitte And Yankees
description: Andy Pettitte has made 253 major league starts. He has been a member of the Yankees' rotation since 1995 and has never had a losing season. But for the first time in his career, Pettitte has lost four starts in a row. His minislump turned major last night.

title: Absolution For a Martyr To the Profane
description: NOT everyone who emerged reasonably intact from the 1960's learned the truth from Lenny Bruce, to borrow a Paul Simon lyric.

title: Both Houses Back More Military Spending
description: The House and Senate tonight endorsed the Bush administration's continued military buildup, approving similar $400.5 billion spending measures that add to the United States arsenal and improve pay and housing conditions for the armed forces.

title: Earnings Off 13% At Williams-Sonoma
description: Williams-Sonoma, the owner of the Pottery Barn and Williams-Sonoma stores, said today that first-quarter earnings fell 13 percent, the first decline in almost two years, because of higher catalog costs.

title: General to Retire After Role Of Leading Troops Overseas
description: Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the plain-spoken artilleryman from Texas who led American forces into wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, has decided to retire and will step down later this year, military officials said today.

title: Dosky and Tubbs
description: BAGHDAD, May 23  As American soldiers battled Iraqi paramilitary forces in Samawa in March, Bashar Dosky was poring over some unusual documents.

title: U.S. Doctor With Symptoms To Fly Home From Taiwan
description: An American doctor advising Taiwan on fighting its SARS epidemic has come down with symptoms of the disease and will be flown home by air ambulance with three of his healthy colleagues, the governments of both countries said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; A Team on a Mission Is Trouble for Detroit
description: JON BARRY has an excellent view of the Nets, not only of their play but into their collective mind as well. For Barry is a veteran guard for the Detroit Pistons, who came into the Meadowlands last night to play Game 3 of their Eastern Conference finals series, down two games to none. And Barry observes the opponent sometimes eyeball to eyeball on the court and sometimes from a few yards away, on the bench.

title: Just in Time, A Bumper Crop Of New Models
description: NOTHING excites convertible devotees and spurs sales more than a new or redesigned model, and 2003 and 2004 are good years for acts of top-down creation.

title: Agassi and Graf Won't Play Together
description: Despite Andre Agassi's victory in the Australian Open, he and his wife, Steffi Graf, will not be a mixed-doubles team at this year's French Open, Agassi's coach, Darren Cahill, said yesterday.

title: For Summer Renters, Procrastination Pays
description: IF you haven't found a summer rental yet, whether it's a cottage by the beach or a cabin in the mountains, you may be in luck. Largely because of the bleak economy and a glut of rental properties, there are a number of reasonably priced houses still available. A report on the summer rental market in the resort communities of the Hamptons, Fire Island, Cape Cod, the Berkshires, Martha's Vineyard, the Maryland and Delaware shores and Lake Michigan. Page 6.

title: Pavarotti Sets Met Farewell for a 'Good Memory'
description: He left fans fuming last May when he abruptly bowed out of two scheduled performances at the Metropolitan Opera, but Luciano Pavarotti is ready to make good. He plans to return to the Met next year for three performances of Puccini's ''Tosca.''

title: Kenya Urges U.S. and Britain to Lift East Africa Terror Alert
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 23  A senior official in Kenya urged the United States and Britain today to ease a security alert in east Africa, insisting that his country had "nipped in the bud" potential terrorist operations in Somalia and Kenya, at one point sending forces by helicopter to seize a senior Al Qaeda suspect in a raid on Mogadishu, the Somali capital.

title: Aetna Agreement With Doctors Envisions Altered Managed Care
description: Aetna, the big health insurance company, and medical leaders said yesterday that their agreement to settle a long-running lawsuit over billing and medical decisions promised a radical change in their often rancorous relationship and better treatment for patients.

title: For First Time, Conservation Groups Endorse Filtering Plant for City Water Supply
description: Three big conservation groups have endorsed, for the first time, New York City's efforts to build a $1.3 billion plant to filter part of the drinking water supply -- bolstering the city's case as it struggles to meet a court deadline by the end of this month to select a site for the project.

title: Never Too Old to Learn? How to Find Out
description: SURF schools range from overnight camps lasting up to a week to day camps. Most places, including the ones listed below, also offer private lessons. If you're in an area without a surf camp, calling local surf shops is a good way to find out where you can take lessons. SALLY McGRANE

title: BURGER KING NAMES NEW CHIEF MARKETING OFFICER
description: The Burger King Corporation named Russ Klein its chief marketing officer yesterday. An advertising and marketing veteran, Mr. Klein most recently was managing director and chief marketing officer at 7-Eleven Inc. Mr. Klein's appointment comes as Burger King overhauls its advertising and marketing efforts after being acquired from Diageo by investors led by the Texas Pacific Group.

title: Moroccans Say Al Qaeda Masterminded and Financed Casablanca Suicide Bombings
description: The five suicide bombings in Casablanca last Friday night were masterminded and financed by Al Qaeda, according to Moroccan officials speaking on the condition of anonymity.

title: Senators Sharply Criticize Iraq Rebuilding Efforts
description: Democratic senators assailed the Bush administration's postwar reconstruction effort in Iraq today, peppering Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz with complaints about the planning and execution of the strategy. Even Republicans joined in, offering pointed criticisms of the administration's performance.

title: Powell Says to the French, Yes . . . but Not All Is Forgiven
description: Sending a mixed message to the French on his first visit here since before the war in Iraq, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that France's support for lifting United Nations sanctions against Iraq was ''a step in the right direction,'' but cautioned that ''the disagreements of the past'' have not been forgotten.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: TERROR SUSPECT ARRESTED The Greek police arrested a 42-year-old graphic designer suspected of aiding the November 17 terrorist group. The authorities in Athens said the suspect, Kostas Avramidis, was charged with complicity in terrorist activities after the police found his fingerprints in a hide-out used by the group. Mr. Avramidis is the 20th suspect to be captured since last June.    Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Illinois: Suit Over Poetry Endowment
description: The Poetry Foundation of Chicago, which publishes Poetry magazine, is suing National City Bank of Indiana, saying the bank mishandled a $100 million endowment by failing to pull the money out of an ailing stock market, significantly reducing the gift. Ruth Lilly, 87, an heir to the Eli Lilly & Company pharmaceutical fortune, made the endowment in November. A spokeswoman for the bank said it had done nothing wrong and would defend itself in court. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Police Officer Kills Man in Warehouse After Raid
description: A man was shot and killed by a police officer in Chelsea yesterday in what the police described as a struggle in the hallway of a self-storage company.

title: Gun-Toting Sea Lions And Other Park Tales
description: Central Park is New York's Twilight Zone -- and not just at dusk. Noirish things happen there. A dog can be murdered by a swan. When Donna Karan's Jack Russell terrier, Petey, swam too close to a nest on the lake island three years ago, the panicked mother swan forced the dog's head underwater until he drowned. (The swan and her mate both died last month, one of old age, the other, apparently, of heartbreak.)

title: An Id Filling In for God
description: In ''Bruce Almighty,'' Jim Carrey (above) plays a hapless television newscaster in Buffalo who is given a chance to play God -- literally -- by the real thing (Morgan Freeman). The comedy opens today nationwide.

title: Women in Love, Passengers in Danger
description: A lesbian romance set in late Victorian England, ''Tipping the Velvet'' begins so gently that viewers might dismiss it as another ''Well of Loneliness,'' a dated 1928 novel by Radclyffe Hall about lesbian love and despair. But there is nothing mournful about this BBC America mini-series, which begins tonight and ends Sunday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Indictment In Brookhaven
description: The Town of Brookhaven highway superintendent was arraigned yesterday on charges including grand larceny and perjury. The superintendent, Patricia Strebel, as well as a contractor, his partner and a Patchogue village official who were also charged in the case, pleaded not guilty in County Court in Riverhead to offenses in an 80-count indictment. Prosecutors said Ms. Strebel allowed the contractor, Stephen Milvid, and his partner to steal more than $250,000 by overbilling the town, underpaying workers in violation of labor laws, and using the town landfill for free. In exchange, they said, she received about $12,000 in campaign donations, and her political allies received at least $17,000. Ms. Strebel, a Republican, was elected highway superintendent in 2001. She was previously a member of the Brookhaven Town Board. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

description: John Smoltz is a reliever now, but he is not ready for long-term commitment. This is a marriage of convenience: The Atlanta Braves needed a closer and he said yes, reluctantly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLEIWEISS, , RUTH MARION
description: BLEIWEISS -- Ruth Marion. Died peacefully May 11, 2003 on Mother's Day and her wedding anniversary. Beloved mother of Ellen and Elizabeth. She will be missed by all whose lives she touched in her 85 years. She was married to Dr. Irwin Bleiweiss for 51 years and lived in Plainview, New York and West Palm Beach, FL. She was a wife, mother, daughter, sister, aunt, friend and singer. Though her career as an entertainer was short, her glorious voice and magnificent smile will live in our hearts forever. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: OFFICERS FIRED FOR PERJURY Two New York police officers have been fired for lying while giving trial testimony about the death of Anthony Baez, who died in 1994 after another police officer used a chokehold on him, Police Department records show. Mr. Baez died during a confrontation with the police outside his Bronx home after he threw a football that struck an officer's patrol car. The two officers, Anthony Farnan and Mario Erotokritou, were found guilty of perjury in a police trial last year. The officer who used the chokehold, Francis X. Livoti, is serving a seven-and-a-half-year sentence after being found guilty in 1998 of violating Mr. Baez's civil rights. The two officers plan to appeal the firings, said their lawyer, Stuart London. The officers' firing was first reported in The Daily News yesterday. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Sketch of Man Is Circulated In Investigation of Yale Blast
description: A day after an explosion rocked the Yale University Law School, investigators circulated a sketch of a man they were seeking to question about the blast, which damaged two rooms and jangled nerves but caused no injuries.

title: Market for Chinese-American Delicacy Plummets
description: For many Chinese-Americans, no wedding banquet is complete without a serving of squab, a young pigeon that is slaughtered before it can fly. The tender meat symbolizes a lifetime of peace for the newlyweds and eating a bird represents being set free by their parents.

title: From Texas, Coming Soon to a Statehouse Near You
description: One evening in April 2000, I held a small reading of a screenplay I had just written about Texas politics called ''Sonny's Last Shot.'' It was about the quixotic attempt of a young state representative to counter the influence of lobbyists. The second act features a quorum break, much like the one that occurred last week, in which a rebellious faction of the Texas House of Representatives takes to the hills (actually, to a hideout behind the Alamo) to keep a loathsome bill from coming to a vote.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Judge Indicted In Scheme
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Brooklyn, Justice Gerald P. Garson, was indicted yesterday along with six other people in a scheme to fix divorce and custody cases in return for cigars, free meals and cash. The indictments, announced by the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, do not add anything significant to the charges levied against Justice Garson and the others when they were arrested last month. The only major figure in the scheme not to be indicted was Paul Siminovsky, the divorce lawyer who prosecutors said paid off the judge to get favorable outcomes for his clients. Mr. Hynes said that Mr. Siminovsky, who was arrested on bribery charges, had testified before a grand jury and would eventually be offered a plea deal. Justice Garson is charged with six counts of receiving a reward for official misconduct and one count each of official misconduct and receiving unlawful gratuities.

title: Kenya Lets 100 Flowers Bloom
description: Kenya is not an economy that can take a serious terrorism alert in stride. With raw memories of past attacks brought freshly back to mind and British and Israeli airlines canceling flights, the country has moved a long way from the center of many Westerners' comfort zones. And the effects can be seen plainly in industries like tourism, where the hotels are even emptier than usual in the cool, damp off-season.

title: Indonesia Says It Will Press Attacks on Separatists in Sumatra
description: The Indonesian government has vowed to push ahead with its military offensive against separatist rebels in Aceh Province, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: A President from Patagonia
description: As Argentina's once prosperous economy has crumpled in recent years, Argentines have taken to referring to their country as the world's sole ''undeveloping nation.'' The last few years have been especially devastating. Argentina's economy contracted by a staggering 11 percent last year, after the country defaulted on its public debt in December 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, , GERTRUDE
description: LEWIS--Gertrude, age 92, formerly of NYC, died in Lenox, MA, May 20, 2003. Lifelong educator, humanitarian and fighter for peace, justice, and a healthy environment, predeceased by her husband of 71 years, Murray Lewis, who died September 22, 2001. Retired in 1973, the couple lived in CA, FL and then Lenox in 1998. Survived by two sons, six grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Peace! >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAGGARTY, , KEVIN F.
description: HAGGARTY--Kevin F. Of Larchmont NY and formerly of Greenpoint, Brooklyn at age 60 on May 20, 2003. Beloved husband to Cathy, and father to Mark, Christopher, and Lizzie, and father-in-law to Amy. As Executive Managing Director of Insignia/ ESG's Capital Advisors Group, he was one of the most well respected investment sales brokers in the commercial real estate industry. During his professional career, which spanned 25 years, his clients included some of the nation's leading institutions including Lend Lease, MetLife, and Teachers Insurance & Annuity Association among others. He was a wonderful father, an inspiration to his three children, and a devoted husband of 32 years. He was an exceptionally generous man, kind, gracious, compassionate and wise, and he warmly enriched the lives of all who knew him. His family and friends are deeply saddened by the loss and will miss him immeasurably. Viewing hours, Thursday, May 22, 7pm-9pm and Friday, May 23, 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY; funeral mass service Saturday, May 24, at 9:30am, St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont Avenue (just past Boston Post Road). In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Kevin's name to the following charities: Larchmont Friends of the Family, PO Box 746, Larchmont, NY 10538, or College Track, 1846 Bay Road, East Palo Alto, CA 94303, a non - profit organization where Kevin's son Mark is employed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Terror Suspect Arrested
description: The Greek police arrested a 42-year-old graphic designer suspected of aiding the November 17 terrorist group. The authorities in Athens said the suspect, Kostas Avramidis, was charged with complicity in terrorist activities after the police found his fingerprints in a hide-out used by the group. title: Growing the Political Economy
description: After helping the Republican Party collect a cool $22 million for its House and Senate candidates at a dinner on Wednesday, President Bush is ready to turn his attention to his own re-election drive with fund-raising events in New York, Florida and Washington next month. Solicitations have gone out at $2,000 per ticket, with chrome-plated options for the big money raisers, like a $50,000 ''leadership luncheon'' with Karl Rove, the White House campaign guru. ''Make your commitment now,'' exults Gov. George Pataki in handing out ascending V.I.P. slots, with those who raise $200,000 at the top. A tenth of that garners a photo-op with the beaming president, presumably in mufti, not ''Top Gun'' costume.

title: On This Night, No One Could Keep Pace With Kidd
description: Jason Kidd had spent the night racing ahead of his own teammates as well as the Detroit Pistons. Still, perhaps the best sign of how far ahead of the pack he was tonight came in the interview room.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: The Cost Of A Virus
description: Travelers' concerns about severe acute respiratory syndrome have been more costly for Toronto's hotels than their concerns after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were, according to the Greater Toronto Hotel Association. The association's 145 members reported that their average occupancy rate fell to 46.7 percent in April from 68.1 percent a year earlier, costing them 125 million Canadian dollars ($90.8 million) in cancellations and no-shows.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas prices fell after a report showed inventories rose more than expected last week. In New York, natural gas for June delivery fell 16.3 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $6.035 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Report Finds Flaws in Inquiries On Foster Abuse in New Jersey
description: New Jersey's child welfare agency has shown a ''routine failure'' to adequately investigate allegations of abuse and neglect in foster homes and state-run institutions, leaving thousands of children under its care at risk of harm, a study has found.

title: Residential Real Estate; Market-Rate Rents Continue Downturn
description: Rents for market-rate apartments in and around New York City have continued to slip this year, according to rental brokers and landlords, but not as steeply as they had during their nose dive from a breath-catching peak two years ago.

description: On weekday mornings for the last month or so, the hip-hop radio station Hot 97 has been waking its listeners with a catchy, unusual song called ''Cameltoe.''

description: A former corporate executive tapped by Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein to train principals said yesterday that he had come close to quitting twice because of the school system's enervating bureaucracy.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: UTILITY PURCHASED Scottish and Southern Energy said it would purchase Midlands Electricity, the fourth-largest energy provider in Britain, for 610 million ($997 million). Scottish and Southern will buy Midland's bonds for 567 million ($927 million), a 15 percent discount to their face value, and will pay 43 million ($70 million) to the utility's owners, Aquila Inc., which owns 79.9 percent of the utility, and the FirstEnergy Corporation of Akron, Ohio, which owns the rest. Scottish and Southern will also take on 502 million ($821 million) in Midlands debt. Midlands serves 2.4 million customers through a 38,000-mile distribution network in Britain and has operations in Turkey and Pakistan. Scottish and Southern is expected to sell off the units outside Britain and will control nearly 20 percent of the British electricity market when the deal closes.

title: FEDERATED TO ADD MACY'S NAME TO OTHER STORES
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. will add the Macy's brand name to its regional department stores, the company said yesterday. After Aug. 1, the stores will be known as the Bon-Macy's, Lazarus-Macy's and Goldsmith's-Macy's. The Burdines stores in Florida will be called Burdines-Macy's after Feb. 1, and the division will take control of all seven Macy's stores in Florida. New regional credit cards will be usable at any of the company's stores and macys.com, the company said. Federated, which is based in Cincinnati, said the changes would coincide with $100 million in renovations for stores in Seattle, Pittsburgh, Memphis, Cincinnati and Columbus, Ohio.

title: Yankees' Williams Likely to Be Out Four to Six Weeks

A magnetic resonance imaging test on Williams, the Yankees' center fielder, revealed torn cartilage in his left knee. The team is recommending surgery, which would cause him to miss four to six weeks.

description: This is a quietly spectacular season for the American painter and printmaker Ellsworth Kelly, who will have his 80th birthday this month. There are three separate shows of Mr. Kelly's work -- self-portrait drawings, paintings and sculptures -- at the Matthew Marks gallery spaces in Chelsea. And the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston is presenting ''Ellsworth Kelly: Red Green Blue,'' an exhibition that takes as its focus the wonderful painting of that name produced in 1963. The exhibition closes in Houston on July 27 and is scheduled to open at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Aug. 2.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Urges Tax On Stocks
description: The union representing 8,000 municipal middle managers will begin a broadcast campaign tomorrow accusing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of favoring the rich and urging him to support a tax on Wall Street's stock sales. The first advertisement, sponsored by Communications Workers Local 1180, says New York's working families are overtaxed, pointing to the 8.625 percent sales tax and an 18.5 percent increase in property taxes. The second ad, titled ''Toilet Paper,'' notes that New Yorkers must pay sales taxes on basics like soap and toothpaste while stock purchases go untaxed. Urging a stock transfer tax, the ad says, ''Just a penny per share, less tax than we pay on a roll of toilet paper, would close our city's budget gap.'' Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: A Lifetime Of Memories And Magic
description: To a real New Yorker, Central Park is the country. Sure, somewhere in the back of our minds, we know that Dutchess County, Bucks County and all of the Hamptons are only two hours away. But that's an outing, or frankly, a schlep. Those of us who went away to summer camp learned that life amid the trees outside Central Park meant mosquito bites and enforced games called Color War. For most New Yorkers, even those who dream of trekking the Appalachian Trail or hitting the slopes at Vail, Central Park is our constant definition of open space, room to run and the romance of reading under a tree. Free and open to the public, Central Park is our citywide campus and our common backyard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, , HOWARD COOPER, JR.
description: JOHNSON--Howard Cooper, Jr., of Fort Myers, Florida, passed away on May 19, 2003, at the age of 94. He had a long career in public service, including serving with the Joint Chiefs of Staff during WW II and The Ford Foundation, and as a Director of the United Nations Planning Staff of the Department of State and Portfolio Manager of the World Bank. In his banking career, he worked for Morgan Stanley and Co. and as President of The World Banking Corporation of Nassau, Bahamas. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Elizabeth Hovey Johnson, and three children, Pamela Young Johnson, Richard Doane Johnson and Christina Johnson Rosenberg. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Habitat for Humanity of Lee County, 1288 North Tamiami Trail, Fort Myers, Florida 33903. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADE SURPLUS EXPANDS Japan's trade surplus hit 840 billion yen ($7.2 billion) in April, an increase of 1.6 percent from the same month a year earlier, helped by strong exports to China. Exports over all grew 4.7 percent. However, Japan's trade surplus with the United States, its single largest trading partner, fell 11.8 percent because of the sluggish economy in the United States. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Proton Energy Will Acquire Northern Power
description: Proton Energy Systems, which makes devices that use electricity to convert water into hydrogen for fuel cells, said yesterday that it would acquire Northern Power Systems, a leading designer of small power systems for businesses and institutions that want to generate their own electricity. Proton Energy, which is based in Wallingford, Conn., went public in 2000 at $17 a share and traded as high as $28.62 that year, but the price plummeted as the projected dates for widespread fuel cell use were repeatedly pushed back. It closed yesterday at $3.24, up 38 cents, or 13 percent, on the Nasdaq. Northern Power, a privately held company based in Waitsfield, Vt., has built hundreds of energy systems for pipelines, industrial sites and commercial buildings, many of them incorporating renewable energy sources. Proton will pay $27.5 million in cash and stock for Northern and issue warrants for Northern shareholders to buy 2.5 million Proton shares when the deal closes. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When a restaurant offers a flight of three wine ice creams, diners get a pretty clear idea of where its priorities lie. But how could it be otherwise with Morrells, the second venture into restaurant territory by one of the city's most famous wine merchants? Its tiny parent, Morrells Cafe, next to the company's wine store in Rockefeller Center, found a successful formula offering wine-based cuisine and a long list of wines by the glass. Michael Haimowitz, the chef, expands on the original concept in a spacious dining room with a cafe and bar up front. For the first time he has enough room to turn around.

title: Chief Agrees To Salary Cap Of $6 Million At Hollinger
description: Conrad Black, the British lord and newspaper publisher, told a roomful of restive shareholders yesterday that he would limit his annual pay to $6 million and would give up some control of the company he runs, Hollinger International.

title: An Architect Of Images
description: The reviews may have been mixed on the foreground action in ''Down With Love,'' Peyton Reed's pastiche of those early 1960's sex comedies that starred Doris Day and Rock Hudson, but the backgrounds have been earning raves. ''Every inch of every CinemaScope frame -- from the zippy title credits to the geographically absurd Manhattan sets to the modular furniture to the glass martini pitchers -- is designed to plunge you into a fairy-tale 1962,'' A. O. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times when the film opened on May 9. That look is largely the work of Andrew Laws, the production designer, who has earned his reputation on more realistic films like Joel Schumacher's ''Tigerland'' (2000) and Mr. Schumacher's more recent ''Phone Booth.''

title: Corrections

Basra was a party town in the 1970's and 80's, one that drew not only locals but Kuwaitis and other foreigners eager for revelry in a region that is otherwise as dry as a bone.

title: CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS FOUNDER INVESTS MORE
description: Mark Cuban, a billionaire who made his fortune selling an Internet company he helped found, increased his investment in the struggling cable operator Charter Communications Inc. to 6.5 percent. Mr. Cuban, who also owns the Dallas Mavericks National Basketball Association franchise, held 19 million Class A shares as of Dec. 31, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He previously held 15.6 million shares, or 5.3 percent. Charter is based in St. Louis.

title: Security Council Almost Unanimously Approves Broad Mandate for Allies in Iraq
description: The United States and Britain won an international mandate today to occupy and rebuild Iraq, as the Security Council voted to end nearly 13 years of sanctions. It was a significant diplomatic victory for the Bush administration, as France, Germany and Russia, the principal opponents of the American-led war, lined up in support of the measure.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Judge's Suspension Recommended
description: The State Judiciary Commission has found that a civil district judge diverted his staff from regular duties to raise campaign money from lawyers who appeared before his division of the court and that he lied about it to the commission. The judge, C. Hunter King of Orleans Parish, fired a court reporter, Barbara C. Wallace, who complained that her regular work was getting pushed aside, the commission found. It recommended to the State Supreme Court that the judge be suspended for a year without pay and pay $693.50 in investigation costs. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officers Fired For Perjury
description: Two New York police officers have been fired for lying while giving trial testimony about the death of Anthony Baez, who died in 1994 after another police officer used a chokehold on him, Police Department records show. Mr. Baez died during a confrontation with the police outside his Bronx home after he threw a football that struck an officer's patrol car. The two officers, Anthony Farnan and Mario Erotokritou, were found guilty of perjury in a police trial last year. The officer who used the chokehold, Francis X. Livoti, is serving a seven-and-a-half-year sentence after being found guilty in 1998 of violating Mr. Baez's civil rights. The two officers plan to appeal the firings, said their lawyer, Stuart London. The officers' firing was first reported in The Daily News yesterday. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Auto Insurance Fraud Ring Broken
description: The acting state attorney general, Peter C. Harvey, announced yesterday that 22 people had been indicted on charges that they participated in a ring that staged automobile accidents for insurance fraud. The authorities identified Eric Boyer, 33, of East Orange, as the mastermind. Mr. Boyer, along with 21 others, were charged with conspiracy, health care claims fraud and attempted theft by deception in the indictment, which was handed up May 19. More than $200,000 in insurance claims were submitted in connection with the orchestrated accidents, which occurred between October 1998 and October 1999, the authorities said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: European Panel Chooses Domain Name Registry
description: A European identity in cyberspace came a step closer yesterday when the European Commission selected Eurid, a Belgian-led consortium to act as registry for the .eu top-level domain name. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, has given the go-ahead for .eu Web and e-mail addresses, which could start appearing toward the end of this year, the commission said. Eurid, a nonprofit organization, will appoint private companies to act as registrars, which will allocate .eu addresses. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: A Wedding, 2 Dads and Security Issues
description: Originality is not usually something you expect from a remake. But in a field that includes such pointless recent updates of not-quite-classic older movies as ''Bedazzled,'' ''Sweet November'' and ''The Truth About Charlie,'' ''The In-Laws'' stands out. Not for its freshness or novelty, mind you, but for its utter, nearly systematic lack of imagination. It's as if the director, Andrew Fleming, and the screenwriters, Nat Mauldin and Ed Solomon, set out to make a movie that would be mediocre in every respect. If so, they have completely succeeded.

title: AMERISOURCE, A DRUG SELLER, TO BUY PACKAGING COMPANY
description: The AmerisourceBergen Corporation, a leading drug wholesaler, agreed to buy Anderson Packaging Inc. for about $100 million in stock, cash and debt to expand its packaging services for customers. The acquisition, which will probably be completed in 60 days, will add about 1 cent a share to profit in the 2004 fiscal year starting Oct. 1, an Amerisource spokesman, Michael Kilpatric, said. The purchase will give Amerisource additional annual sales of as much as $90 million through contracts with drug makers to create sample packages for doctors. Anderson, based in Rockford, Ill., will operate as a separate business after the acquisition, Mr. Kilpatric said.

title: Totally Ripping: Catching the Curl At Surfing Camp
description: IT'S a warm June day in Capitola, Calif., a little coastal town just south of Santa Cruz, and the beach is teeming with life: junior lifeguards in red swimsuits going through their training exercises, mothers watching their toddlers at work in the sand with shovels and pails, teenage girls stretched out on blankets trying to capture the first rays of the summer sun. Out in the ocean, tanned, teenage surfers in their Quiksilver and O'Neill wet suits wait patiently on their boards for a wave to break, and then catch the curl at the exact right moment and glide thrillingly along the water's edge as the wave rolls toward shore.

title: Andy Warhol's 'Screen Tests' Were 3-Minute Eternities
description: She holds her head steady, staring without blinking. She has full lips and long dark hair. Her jaw tightens. Maybe she's swallowing. You can't tell, since she's filmed only from the chin up. Is she slightly cross-eyed? Well, one eye seems darker, or at least bigger, than the other. Her eyes begin to water. Oh, dear. A tear rolls down, then another. What is she thinking? Or is it just that she hasn't blinked yet? Her chin is all wet. Blink, lady, blink.

title: Sailing

That said, sailing courses can certainly help you get started and also help you decide what style of sailing (and thus what kind of sailboat) most appeals to you.

title: The Seasonal Allure Of a Convertible
description: THE flower gardens are bursting and the beaches have reopened, but an equally reliable sign that summer is approaching is that car buyers are being drawn by the siren call of the convertible. Whether the dream is a Jaguar, a BMW or a Volkswagen Beetle, sellers say, buyers are showing up eager to get behind the wheel by Memorial Day weekend, anticipating the pleasure of the summer wind rifling through their hair. Page 8.

title: God's Power as an Ego Trip for an Id
description: Jim Carrey embodies the scary possibility that at heart every human being is a sugar-crazed 6-year-old hellion gleefully wreaking havoc in Mommy and Daddy's fastidiously decorated living room. All this star has to do is stand there and grin to convince you that once the layers of civilization have been peeled away, what's left is an insatiable, rampaging id. And in Mr. Carrey's rambunctiously funny new comedy, ''Bruce Almighty,'' his alter ego, Bruce Nolan, a frustrated television newscaster in Buffalo relegated to human interest stories, gets to rampage at the loftiest spiritual level.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
description: Japan's trade surplus hit 840 billion yen ($7.2 billion) in April, an increase of 1.6 percent from the same month a year earlier, helped by strong exports to China. Exports over all grew 4.7 percent. However, Japan's trade surplus with the United States, its single largest trading partner, fell 11.8 percent because of the sluggish economy in the United States. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Where Benedict Arnold Meets Henry Moore
description: AT the Storm King Art Center, 65 miles north of New York, monumental outdoor sculptures by famous artists work a curious, awe-inspiring magic against the natural backdrop of verdant hillsides. Along the way, the practical work of engineers, bridge builders and generals has left a different stamp on a landscape of river and mountains. A drive up the Hudson River to Storm King, at Mountainville, N.Y., offers plenty of both kinds of vistas. Page 10.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Wouldn't It Be Luvverly?

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS. The dollar fell on speculation that the Federal Reserve is trying to drive down interest rates to keep inflation from slowing too much. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1699, up from $1.1678 on Wednesday.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: THE COST OF A VIRUS Travelers' concerns about severe acute respiratory syndrome have been more costly for Toronto's hotels than their concerns after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were, according to the Greater Toronto Hotel Association. The association's 145 members reported that their average occupancy rate fell to 46.7 percent in April from 68.1 percent a year earlier, costing them 125 million Canadian dollars ($90.8 million) in cancellations and no-shows.

description: Friedrich Petzel Gallery

title: A Tax Cut Without End
description: True, the price tag on the tax bill the House approved this morning is officially only $320 billion over 10 years, barely two-fifths of the $726 billion President Bush proposed in February.
