description: To the Editor:

title: Saturday Afternoons: Tune In to Wagner
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: OKLAHOMA: SETTLEMENT IN BRIDGE COLLAPSE Victims of a deadly bridge collapse have settled lawsuits with the owner of the towboat that pushed barges into the bridge's pier, the vessel's owner said. The plaintiffs include the families of 14 people who died and those who survived on May 26, 2002, when vehicles plunged from the bridge into the Arkansas River. A judge's order prevents parties from discussing details of the agreements. (AP)

title: ANTIQUES
description: A Pioneer And a Rebel, Still a Secret

title: Nets Quickly Take Control Of the Pistons
description: Kenyon Martin took off from the opening tip and in the flash of four seconds he laid the ball in the basket, announcing the Nets' bold plans for tonight and beyond.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Profit Rises
description: The British telecommunications company BT Group reported a 44 percent increase in profit, to 1.83 billion ($2.99 billion), for the year ended March 31, but said its pension was underfunded by 6.3 billion. Though BT's overall pension liabilities are large, their estimated impact on earnings going forward is still lower than predictions. The company said it expected to pay 32 million more in 2004 than 2003 to close the gap, about a third of what analysts expected. The company's stock closed up about 2 percent to 188.50 pence on the London Stock Exchange. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 12 about Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, his talks in Jerusalem and the Bush administration's efforts to bring peace to the Middle East referred imprecisely to the peace plan drawn up by the United States, the United Nations, the European Union and Russia. The plan, known to diplomats as the road map, is understood by its authors and by Israel and the Palestinians to entail the eventual dismantling of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. But that understanding is not stated explicitly.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility Purchased
description: Scottish and Southern Energy said it would purchase Midlands Electricity, the fourth-largest energy provider in Britain, for 610 million ($997 million). Scottish and Southern will buy Midland's bonds for 567 million ($927 million), a 15 percent discount to their face value, and will pay 43 million ($70 million) to the utility's owners, Aquila Inc., which owns 79.9 percent of the utility, and the FirstEnergy Corporation of Akron, Ohio, which owns the rest. Scottish and Southern will also take on 502 million ($821 million) in Midlands debt. Midlands serves 2.4 million customers through a 38,000-mile distribution network in Britain and has operations in Turkey and Pakistan. Scottish and Southern is expected to sell off the units outside Britain and will control nearly 20 percent of the British electricity market when the deal closes.

title: Putin Writes to Bush, Making an Overture in an Effort to Mend the Rift Over Iraq
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, seeking to heal relations bruised by the war in Iraq, has written to President Bush seeking cooperation ''on all levels,'' a senior Russian official said today.

title: Lawmakers Want to Expand Inquiry on U.S. Efforts in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  Senior Republican and Democratic lawmakers asked today that the Congressional investigation into how federal contracts were awarded for the reconstruction of Iraq be expanded to include nearly every aspect of the American occupation of that country.

title: Cindy Sherman -- 'Centerfolds, 1981'
description: Skarstedt Fine Art

title: Israel Says Explosives Expert Was on Fishing Boat It Seized
description: Israeli naval commandos seized a small fishing boat off the country's northern coast and captured a suspected explosives expert from the Lebanese group Hezbollah who had bomb detonators and computer disks on preparing weapons, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERNER, , RHODA TANEN BAUM
description: LERNER -- Rhoda Tanen baum. The Historic House Trust of New York City notes with sadness the passing of Rhoda Tanenbaum Lerner, mother of our esteemed colleague and Board member, Susan Klein. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. The Board & Staff of the Historic House Trust of New York City >>AD#

title: Annika v. Vijay
description: The creators of SimGolf designed a three-hole golf course to see if they could level the playing field between male and female golfers.

title: Disney's Wedding Dreams
description: Disney and other hotel and resort companies are capitalizing on the boom in destination weddings.

title: The Minivans of Our Lives
description: The Japanese companies are betting that there are enough families out there who still want minivans and are willing to pay premium prices for them.

title: The Second Round
description: She failed to make the cut, but Annika Sorenstam won over many new fans during her PGA adventure.

title: Glamour Girls
description: Two Hollywood Pretty Babies put on a show!

title: Outdoor Cookers
Breaking Through to the Other Side
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: LAND SPECULATION DISCOURAGED The government is trying to control skyrocketing prices of apartments and other real estate. Finance Minister Kim Jin Pyo, blaming speculative forces, said the government would discourage loans to real estate investors and encourage them to put their money in the stock market. The program aims to halt the purchase of options on apartments at prime locations in new shopping malls and on remodeled units in apartment blocks. Investment in apartments has boomed as a result of declining interest rates and favorable terms on mortgages offered by Kookmin Bank , Korea's largest financial institution and biggest mortgage firm, and a host of competitors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Moscow a Candidate For the 2012 Games
description: Russia's Olympic Committee voted unanimously yesterday to propose Moscow as the site for the 2012 Summer Olympics, thrusting the Russian capital into competition with New York and at least five other cities.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OFFICE DEPOT INC., Delray Beach, Fla., said it had received European Union approval to buy a stationery unit from Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, Paris, for about $1 billion in cash to double European sales and regain the lead as the world's largest seller of office supplies.

title: Torricelli to Oversee Honeywell Toxic Cleanup
description: Former Senator Robert G. Torricelli, who returned to private life in New Jersey after abandoning his re-election campaign last fall, has received a court appointment to oversee an environmental cleanup project in Jersey City.

title: Poetry and Actors in a Publicist's Mix
description: You are a smart publicist for Miramax Books, and you want to promote your new poetry anthology, ''Staying Alive: Real Poems for Unreal Times.'' What to do? You turn to Alice Quinn, poetry editor of The New Yorker and executive director of the Poetry Society of America, who is always eager to advance the cause of poetry. You rent the Great Hall at Cooper Union on Wednesday night. Ms. Quinn, with considerable clout in the culture world, invites Meryl Streep, Liev Schreiber, Maria Tucci and her famous poet friends to read from the book, and voil! The press will come.

title: How Noblity of Purpose Can Square With Meanness and Lies
description: The life of Justice William O. Douglas reads like a novel. He was on the Supreme Court of the United States for over 36 years, longer than anyone else, going through four wives, seven presidents and four impeachment attempts. His image has been that of an antigovernment idealist pitted against an establishment that blanched at his much younger wives and his stand against the Vietnam War.

title: Shuttle Board Chief Calls Rescue Try 'Conceivable'
description: If NASA had known immediately that the Columbia was damaged on liftoff, it might have sent the shuttle Atlantis on a rescue mission, the chairman of the board investigating the accident said today. But he would not characterize the chance of success.

title: Blacks, Jews And Crown Heights
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators in Yale Bombing Shift Focus to Second Sketch
description: Federal agents investigating a bombing Wednesday at Yale University Law School yesterday showed students there a second sketch, this time of a man who may have been on the scene just before the explosion, the students said.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption last Saturday about the funeral of two Jordanian children killed in the bombings in Saudi Arabia on May 12 referred incorrectly to the service. It was a Greek Orthodox rite, not a Mass.

title: Albert Pratt, 91, Wall St. Figure Who Held Naval Post in 1950's
description: Albert Pratt, a retired senior partner of Paine Webber, former governor of the New York Stock Exchange and an assistant secretary of the Navy in the Eisenhower administration, died May 16 at his summer residence in Osterville, Mass. He was 91 and also had a home in Key Largo, Fla.

title: The Shadows of Ancient Cities
description: One of the most telling sentences in the catalog of ''Art of the First Cities'' -- the exhibition now on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- refers to two striding demons wearing upturned, elflike shoes and vultures draped over their shoulders. ''Sadly,'' the text says, ''both of these pieces come from the antiquities market, and therefore their point of final deposition cannot be known.'' In other words, we have the demons before us but no certain knowledge of where they were found or the age of the rubble they were found in.

title: Years of Chaos In Youth Homes In New Jersey
description: It did not take long for new residents of the Newark Transitional Shelter II -- a group home for teenage boys -- to realize that their temporary refuge had major troubles of its own.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: MISSILE PENALTIES CRITICIZED China said penalties imposed on a Chinese company accused by the United States of selling ballistic missile products to Iran were "entirely unreasonable." The penalties imposed this week are likely to cost the company, North China Industries, or Norinco, more than $200 million in exports to the United States over the next two years. The Chinese Foreign Ministry said Norinco had not helped the Iranian missile program. The company is one of China's largest, making a diverse line of products from forklifts to firearms.

title: Lifting of Iraq Sanctions Ends 13 Years of Isolation, but Immediate Relief Isn't Expected
description: The United Nations' resolution to remove trade sanctions against Iraq will officially end 13 years of international isolation for this country. But business executives and other experts said today that it would bring little immediate relief to Iraq's battered economy.

title: Burnitz Builds the Lead And Shinjo Preserves It
description: Jeromy Burnitz's grand slam and the five-run lead it produced for the Mets had long passed. The Mets' fragile bullpen had let most of it slip away, and suddenly Armando Benitez was backing up home plate, standing in foul territory watching Chipper Jones chug from second base with the potential tying run in the bottom of the ninth.

title: Qualcomm's Technology Gains in India
description: Qualcomm Inc., whose wireless technology is used by 147 million mobile phone users, expects 6 million Indian subscribers to use phones based on its code division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., technology by the end of the year.

title: Kabul Announces Push to Gain Revenue and Combat Corruption
description: Afghanistan's finance minister announced an aggressive new campaign today to overhaul customs and finance departments countrywide, and to curb corruption in an effort to draw in customs revenue and other taxes for the central treasury.

title: Police Killing of Unarmed Man Is Investigated
description: An African man who was fatally shot by a police officer after a raid at a self-storage warehouse in Chelsea on Thursday was unarmed, had no criminal record and was not part of a CD counterfeiting ring that was the target of the raid, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday.

title: Mussina Contributes to Yanks' Fall From First
description: For the first 53 days of the season, no matter who was injured or who was inept in any game, the Yankees took solace in knowing they were still in first place in the American League East. They were alone in the top spot for 51 days and shared it with the Boston Red Sox for two. How many problems could the Yankees have had if they were continuously sitting in first place deeper into the season than any Yankees team since 1949?

title: Iraq's Liquor Trade Becomes A Casualty of Postwar Chaos
description: The discos here used to close at dawn. The bars served everything from Scotch whiskey to Iraqi wine. Basra was a party town in the 1970's and 80's, one that drew not only locals but Kuwaitis and other foreigners eager for revelry in a region that was otherwise dry as a bone.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Smuggling Trial Begins
description: Eight suspected members of a Chinese gang went on trial in Rotterdam on charges of smuggling illegal immigrants from China, across Europe, on their way to Britain. The police have linked four of the suspects to one notorious operation that ended in the deaths of 58 Chinese immigrants, found suffocated in a truck in the British port of Dover three years ago. The trial involves seven men and one woman, known as Sister P, who is believed to be the ringleader of the group. Its members also face charges of mistreatment and falsification of identity papers. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Executive Pay Cuts
description: The SIA Engineer ing Company, the aircraft maintenance unit of Singapore Airlines, said its senior managers would take a pay cut, saving the company 2.3 million Singapore dollars ($1.3 million) a year, after the SARS virus led to a slump in demand for air travel. The chief executive, William Tan, will take a 27.5 percent pay cut, while 71 other senior managers will have their pay reduced by 22.5 percent from June 1. Directors will also waive half their fees, the company said.

title: SPECTOR AND ALEXANDER WIN
description: Gary Spector and Casey Alexander carded 12 birdies, seven in the morning round, and finished 10 under par at 66-68--134 to win the Wilson Cup at the Scarsdale, N.Y., Golf Club. Forty-eight teams competed in intermittent rain in the best-ball tournament. Bernie Beglane

title: Parents Fill Goody Bags While Mourning a Closing
description: Parents gathered around the table, looking over children's books, homework advice work sheets, tape measures and Barbie accessory kits. Everything was theirs for the taking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOEN, , BETSY NEE SCHUCHAT
description: SCHOEN--Betsy nee Schuchat, on May 21, 2003, age 85. Beloved wife of Jerry for 56 years. Survived by brothers, Theodor, Michael and David Schuchat, sisters-in-law, Molly Schuchat and Louise Harper, brother-in-law, Harold Siegell, many nieces and nephews, great-nieces and nephews, and friends. Funeral arrangements to be announced >>AD#

title: Who Speaks for Africa's Hungry?
description: To the Editor:

title: Owner of Private Discipline Academy in Costa Rica Is Arrested
description: The owner of an American behavior modification program in Costa Rica housing nearly 200 American youths was jailed today after accusations that students had been deprived of their civil liberties.

title: A-Plant Electrical Workers Strike, Citing Job Reductions
description: Electrical workers at the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant in central New Jersey have gone on strike, adding another woe to a troubled week for one of the nation's oldest nuclear-generating stations.

title: Canada Extends Cattle Ranch Quarantine to British Columbia
description: Inspectors extended the quarantine of cattle ranches to British Columbia today in an attempt to trace the path of feed eaten by a single cow infected with mad cow disease and to find where its remains were distributed after it was butchered.

title: WELLA HOLDER IN BRITAIN MOVES TO BLOCK P.&G. OFFER
description: A Wella shareholder in Britain is filing a motion to block the $6.9 billion offer from the Procter & Gamble Company to buy Wella, the German maker of hair-care products. Tigges, a law firm representing the shareholder, Mellon HVB Alternative Strategies U.K., is filing the motion with the Frankfurt higher regional court, it said. The firm is appealing a ruling by regulators that P.& G.'s offer did not violate Germany's takeover law. P.& G.'s bid is unfair because it treats two share classes differently, a Tigges lawyer, Guido Holler, said.

title: 8 Analysts Are Dismissed By Citigroup
description: Citigroup dismissed eight research analysts yesterday and temporarily withdrew coverage of 117 companies, signaling a fresh initiative by Sallie L. Krawcheck and her research team to reduce costs.

title: New Chance for Troubled Los Angeles School
description: In the shadow of the reinvigorated downtown skyline with its new Roman Catholic cathedral and the shortly to open Walt Disney Concert Hall, the school system's Belmont Learning Center sits half finished, surrounded by chain link and barbed wire.

title: Republicans Explain an About-Face
description: As President Bush was fighting for tax cuts earlier this year, Bruce Bartlett, an official at the Treasury Department during the administration of Mr. Bush's father, went before Democratic legislators on Capitol Hill to acknowledge an awkward bit of history.

title: A Utah Massacre And Mormon Memory
description: As families tramp all over the country this summer, visiting historic sites, there's one spot -- Mountain Meadows in southwestern Utah -- that won't be on many itineraries.

title: Only 270 Chances to Catch a Street Fair This Year
description: Finally, for some, the only good news to come out of the city's fiscal crisis: There will not be any new street fairs beyond the 270 the city has already approved for 2003.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about residential compounds in Riyadh where many Americans live misspelled the name of one who moved to Riyadh from Iowa City almost two years ago and said life was simpler. He is Dr. Michael D. Wagoner, not Wagner.

title: Algerians Claim their Dead in Town Shattered by Quake
description: An overpowering smell of disinfectant stood guard at the entrance to Boumerdes Municipal Sports Hall as Ahmed Yebka came for his 23-year-old niece, Nora Bouali, armed with a plain wooden coffin.

title: With a Brand Faltering, Prada Designer Returns
description: In 1999, Prada, the Italian maker of luxury goods, was on a buying spree, snapping up fashion-related brands including the designer houses of Jil Sander and Helmut Newton, the Church Group shoe business and a stake in Fendi. Harmoniously integrating the acquisitions afterward was not always a top priority.

title: The Mini Finds a Place in New York; A Growing Mania for a Revamped Version of the British Classic
description: Alexandre Klabin is a mild-mannered, polite young man, the kind of fellow who opens doors for strangers. But, once a day, he allows himself a measure of wickedness.

title: Dollar Plunges Against Euro, Drawing Close to Record Low
description: The dollar plunged against the euro yesterday, spurred by lingering speculation that the United States is content to see the dollar fall to help the economy.

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: SKETCH OF SERIAL KILLER SUSPECT Investigators seeking the serial killer of five women released a sketch of a possible suspect, a man who tried to rape one woman and approached two others. The women in the encounters, in June and July 2002, were not killed, and officials said no conclusive evidence linked the man to the serial killer. The police described him as a possible suspect in the killings based on his behavior and other evidence that they would not release. "We think this is a significant development," said Sheriff Michael W. Neustrom of Lafayette Parish. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Technology Concern For Sale
description: Baltimore Technologies, a struggling developer of security software that was once Ireland's foremost technology stock, is putting itself up for sale, and has appointed J. P. Morgan to seek binding offers by June 30, the chairman, Peter Morgan, said at the company's annual meeting in London. The company said that finding a strategic partner would streamline its development of products relating to digital signatures and secure electronic transactions. Since the resignation of the founder, Fran Rooney, in 2001, Baltimore has cut its work force tio 270 from 1,200 and it is using up cash at the slowest rate in three years. Cash reserves stood at 15.6 million ($25.5 million) at the end of April. Shares in Baltimore traded up 31 percent, to 35 pence (57 cents), in London. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A credit in Business Day on Thursday for a picture of airline passengers waiting in lines at McCarran International in Las Vegas, which is facing a 15 percent reduction in security screeners, misstated the photographer's given name. He is John Gurzinski, not Joe.

title: Record Sales for Lacrosse Final Four
description: Lacrosse may be a niche sport, but this weekend it will show just how healthy its following is. For the first time, the N.C.A.A. Division I final four will be played at a professional stadium. And a record number of tickets have been sold.

title: Clemens Says He Will Pitch Monday
description: Roger Clemens was a solitary Yankee in the bullpen yesterday, throwing in the rain. The persistent drizzle did not prevent Clemens from testing his bruised right hand during a scheduled session, and he emerged from the 20-minute workout predicting that he would pursue his 300th victory against the Boston Red Sox on Monday.

title: West Point Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPHAN, , BENJAMIN
description: RAPHAN -- Benjamin. We mourn the loss of Ben, our beloved friend and counselor. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Myrna and the entire family. The HIG Corporation Barry Tenzer Ira Greenblatt >>AD#

title: A Slam With a Trump Void Still Leads to Long Beach
description: One of the most coveted titles in the New York metropolitan area is the Grand National Teams, because the winners advance to the national playoffs. Four players won the final at Honors on Wednesday night, earning the right to represent New York in Long Beach, Calif., in July.

title: ATARI SELLS A MILLION COPIES OF 'MATRIX' GAME IN A WEEK
description: Atari Inc., the maker of video games, said its Enter the Matrix game sold more than a million units in its first week. Shares rose as much as 27 percent. Atari shipped four million copies of the game to retailers in North America and Europe for an average price of $38 and tied the release to the film debut of ''The Matrix Reloaded,'' Atari's chief financial officer, David Fremed, said. Infogrames, based in Lyon, France, holds a majority stake in Atari.

title: Businessman Is Guilty in School Aid Scheme
description: The owner of a Staten Island Internet services company pleaded guilty Thursday to participating in a fraudulent scheme to obtain money from a federal program that helps pay for Internet technology for schools and libraries. The defendant, John Angelides, 65, pleaded to conspiracy in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Moratorium For Abuse Cases
description: Lawyers for half the plaintiffs in sexual abuse cases against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston have agreed to nenew a moratorium on litigation for 30 days in an effort to settle the cases. A 90-day suspension ended this week. The lawyers agreed to the extension after an appeal by Bishop Richard G. Lennon. The archdiocese faces more than 500 cases. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Humanism on the Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: Love the Worker, Not the Union, A Store Says As Some Organize
description: In just 23 years, Whole Foods Market has grown from a single store in Austin, Tex., to the largest natural foods chain in the nation. It is widely praised for its folksy style and high-quality goods, offering more than 20 kinds of granola, well-stocked wine shelves, attentive service and a hearty bow to Mother Earth.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Land Speculation Discouraged
description: The government is trying to control skyrocketing prices of apartments and other real estate. Finance Minister Kim Jin Pyo, blaming speculative forces, said the government would discourage loans to real estate investors and encourage them to put their money in the stock market. The program aims to halt the purchase of options on apartments at prime locations in new shopping malls and on remodeled units in apartment blocks. Investment in apartments has boomed as a result of declining interest rates and favorable terms on mortgages offered by Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest financial institution and biggest mortgage firm, and a host of competitors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: CBS Scrubs Extra Colonial Coverage
description: CBS will not expand its weekend coverage of the Colonial because Annika Sorenstam missed the cut, the network said yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Orders A Review Of Its Policy On Discipline
description: The F.B.I. today ordered a high-level, outside review of the way it disciplines agents because the bureau said nagging criticisms had produced ''an erosion of trust'' in the current process.

title: Ex-Publishing Executive Gets Jail Term
description: Fritz Blumenberg, the former president of Burda Media, the United States unit of Hubert Burda Media, which publishes Focus magazine and the German edition of Elle, was sentenced in New York to two and a half years in prison for embezzling $2 million.

title: Eclecticism Reaches Songful Heights
description: There were plenty of worthy performances at the Kaye Playhouse on Thursday night, but the warm ovation that concluded the anniversary concert of the New York Festival of Song was clearly directed toward the organization itself.

title: SHARON GIVES PLAN FOR MIDEAST PEACE QUALIFIED SUPPORT
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said today that Israel was ''prepared to accept the steps'' in a new international peace plan, after the Bush administration said it would ''fully and seriously'' address Israel's reservations while seeking Arab-Israeli peace and a Palestinian state within three years.

title: Strain of SARS Is Found In 3 Animal Species in Asia
description: A virus virtually identical to the one thought to cause SARS in humans has been found in a tree-dwelling animal whose meat is a delicacy in southern China and in two other species, scientists here and at the World Health Organization said today.

title: Sports Authority's Earnings Fall Sharply
description: Sports Authority Inc., the biggest sporting goods chain, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit tumbled 71 percent after an accounting change and a decline in sales.

title: Boeing and Air Force Agree To $16 Billion Tanker Deal
description: The Boeing Company has agreed to lease 100 fuel-tanker planes to the Air Force for about $16 billion over six years, the Defense Department said today, ending a year and a half of price haggling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOCKWOOD, , JOSEPH T. III
description: LOCKWOOD--Joseph T. III. On May 21, 2003. Beloved husband of Jane. Loving father of Chris (Susan) and Nancy Lockwood-Petas. Cherished grandfather of Kristen, John (Ashley), Nondas and Steven. Adored great grandfather of Kobain. Also survived by his brother-in-law Donald F. Pollit and his sister-in-law Jean (Lockwood) Caton. A forty year employee of U.S. Steel International. Memorial visitation will be at the Whitting Funeral Home on Tuesday from 2-5 and 7-9PM. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday at the funeral home at 10AM. Interment is at Locust Valley Cemetery. Masonic services will be held Tuesday at 2PM. Contributions may be made to North Shore INN, P.O. Box 168 Glen Cove, New York 11542. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CONCEPCION, , RENE
description: CONCEPCION--Rene. Seven years went by without you, but your smile and your courage will always stay with those you loved. You'll be in our hearts forever. Love, Steven & Adolfo

title: Bear Gets Best of Tussle With Man
description: North Jersey man tangled with a bear yesterday afternoon and wound up in the hospital, the West Milford Police Department said.

title: Better Late Than Later, a Philharmonic Debut
description: Robert Spano's Philharmonic debut, on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, should not have been so long in coming.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Iraqi Held In Refugee Case
description: Khaleed Shnayf Daoed, 36, an Iraqi arrested in Sweden who is suspected of having helped organize a boat trip from Indonesia to Australia in which 353 asylum seekers drowned, was ordered held in custody in Stockholm at Australia's request while a formal extradition application is drawn up. Mr. Daoed is suspected of involvement in the voyage of the SIEV-X, which sank nearly two years ago after departing Indonesia, a transit point for Middle Eastern and Afghan migrants. Australia is also trying to extradite another man in the same case, Mootaz Muhammad Hasan, an Egyptian also known as Abu Quassey, who is being detained in Cairo. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: 'Horrible Frenchman' to 'Honorary Englishman'
description: NOTHING in his unlikely career, including the time he pulverized his ankle in a gruesome incident while playing ice hockey for France, prepared PY Gerbeau for the reaction of the British tabloids when he arrived here in 2000.

title: Friends Recall a Gentle, Reliable Man
description: Walking down the street in Harlem 5,000 miles from home last year, Ami Volta saw someone she knew from her hometown. It was Ousmane Zongo, newly arrived from Ouagadougou in Burkina Faso, West Africa, and Ms. Volta could not imagine anyone she would have rather run into.

title: Sports of The Times; As the 'Next Jordan,' Should James Try to Be Unlike Mike?
description: ONE day after news of LeBron James's staggering Nike deal worth a reported $90 million, America's most famous consumer advocate was wondering what the ''next Michael Jordan'' was going to give back.

title: MICROSOFT'S CHIEF PLANS TO SELL SOME OF HIS SHARES
description: Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of the Microsoft Corporation, is selling an undisclosed number of shares in the company for the first time in 12 years to diversify his assets. Mr. Ballmer's last sale, of 65,000 shares, was in May 1991, according to the Washington Service, which tracks insider share sales and purchases. Mr. Ballmer owned almost 471 million shares, or 4.4 percent, of Microsoft as of September. Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., will not disclose the number of shares Mr. Ballmer is selling until he files a disclosure with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Rachel Wayne, a spokeswoman.

title: Everything Seems to Be Playing in the Nets' Favor
description: The Nets were in a playful mood today. One by one, they lined up to fling shots from halfcourt. If someone made the shot, practice would be canceled.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about attempts to determine when a cow on a Canadian farm was exposed to mad cow disease misattributed a comment made at a briefing in Washington that reporters monitored by telephone. It was Dr. Stephen Sundlof, an acting assistant deputy administrator for a unit of the Food and Drug Administration -- not Bobby R. Acord, administrator of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service -- who said: ''The only way the disease is transmitted is through feed. My sense is that it will be almost impossible to trace back. Imagine trying to trace back the food you ate six or four years ago. How could you ever do that?''

title: He's the Sinatra of Metal, Locked in His Own Movie
description: Some performers like to combine extreme generosity with extreme arrogance; mixing the two becomes a potent form of stagecraft.

title: Bipartisan Call to Expand Inquiry Into Occupation
description: Senior Republican and Democratic lawmakers asked today that a Congressional investigation into how federal contracts were awarded for the reconstruction of Iraq be expanded to include nearly every aspect of the American occupation.

title: 'Mission Accomplished'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. May Let Kurds Keep Arms, Angering Shiites
description: The American occupation authority in Iraq, apparently preserving the prewar distinction between Kurdish-controlled northern areas and the rest of the country, will allow Kurdish fighters to keep their assault rifles and heavy weapons, but require Shiite Muslim and other militias to surrender theirs, according to a draft directive.

title: Lionel Wilson, Who Gave Voice To Tom Terrific, Is Dead at 79
description: Lionel Wilson, the voice of Tom Terrific, Mighty Manfred the Wonder Dog, Crabby Appleton and all the other characters of the ''Tom Terrific'' cartoons on the ''Captain Kangaroo'' children's television show, died on April 30 in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Out of Money, Some School Districts in Oregon End the Year Early
description: This affluent Portland suburb shut down its schools today for the summer, three weeks early, becoming the first of 84 Oregon school districts to close ahead of schedule this year for lack of money.

title: Capitalizing on Experience, Burns and Devils Move On
description: The Ottawa Senators may have had more skill, but the Devils had more will. People could sense it, even when the young, faster, less experienced Senators carried the play to the older, slower, more championship-tested Devils in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals tonight in the Corel Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTSCHULER, , ROSE (FINK)
description: ALTSCHULER--Rose (Fink) on May 22, 2003. Devoted wife of the late Louis, loving mother of Milton and Jane and Irwin and Arlene; cherished grandmother of Steven and Lee (Ellen); adored greatgrandmother of Brian, Sarah and Jacob. Dear sister of Harry Fink, Lillian Jacobson and Helen Leibowitz. Service 1PM Sunday, May 25, 2003 ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. (Near 66th Avenue). >>AD#

title: Sports of The Times; 'I Love What I Do,' and the Crowd Knows It
description: You could tell from the sounds. Or the silence.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airport Acquired
description: A Spanish engineering conglomerate, Grupo Ferrovial, acquired Belfast City Airport and the rights to run it until 2114 from the Canadian airplane maker Bombardier Inc. The sale, for 35 million ($57.2 million), came nine months after the airport was put up for sale, initially for 40 million ($65.4 million). Belfast City, which is used by three airlines for 18 destinations in Britain, handled 1.8 million passengers last year and has added capacity for 3 million. It is Ferrovial's 13th airport, adding to ones in Britain, Mexico, Chile and Australia. A Ferrovial unit is building the first privately run toll road in the Irish Republic. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about SARS misspelled part of the name of a publication that recounted a laundry worker's spreading of the disease in Taiwan. It is Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, not Morality.

title: Critic at the Mercy of His Own Kind
description: James Wood, variously described as the most brutal, the most loathed, the most respected literary critic of his time, was struggling along the street, his body ''pretzelized,'' as he puts it, from a muscle he pulled playing with his 2-year-old daughter, Livia.

title: For $38,000, Get the Cake, and Mickey, Too
description: It's not every day that a woman gets to feel like, let alone be, Cinderella. But so it was for Lucia Coates, 27, who married Paul Baker, 31, at Walt Disney World here not long ago. The quintessential princess bride (tiara included), she rode from hotel to lakeside wedding pavilion in a horse-drawn coach, complete with two footmen in gray wigs and gold lam pants.

title: Services for Journalist
description: Memorial and remembrance services for Elizabeth Neuffer, a foreign correspondent for The Boston Globe who died on May 9 in an accident in Iraq, are scheduled for May 30 in Wilton, Conn., and on June 5 in Boston.

title: About-Face on the Tobacco Pact
description: The Bush administration finally came to its senses this week and stopped trying to undermine a tobacco-control treaty that was approved by the World Health Assembly in Geneva on Wednesday. The decision ended a prolonged and ultimately futile battle to modify the treaty in ways that could have rendered it virtually useless.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile: Economy Expands
description: Chile's economy expanded at the fastest rate in the first quarter in almost two years, helped by stronger manufacturing output as demand rose at home and as Asia bought more copper, Chile's top export. The central bank said that the economy grew 3.5 percent in the first quarter, the fastest rate since the economy grew a revised 4.1 percent in the second quarter of 2001. Manufacturing rose 6 percent, compared with an average of 2.8 percent growth last year, and retailing and construction activity also rose.

title: Amid Buzz Over Pick, Pistons Try to Keep Focus on Nets
description: Before a humiliating loss to the Nets on Thursday night, the Detroit Pistons earned a victory. Because of a six-year-old trade with the Grizzlies, the Pistons acquired the second pick in next month's draft. With LeBron James a sure thing to be selected first by the Cavaliers, either Darko Milicic, a 17-year-old 7-footer from Serbia and Montenegro, or the Syracuse freshman Carmelo Anthony is the most likely player to fill the next spot.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on May 12 reported that Jay Garner, the top American civil administrator in Iraq, would leave within a week or two as part of an overhaul that also involved the replacement of other senior officials in his team. Among four officials who the article said were expected to leave soon was Tim Carney, a former ambassador who is overseeing the Ministry of Industry and Minerals.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Judge Continues Suit Against Tobacco  Industry
description: A judge refused to throw out a federal suit against the tobacco industry that asks $289 billion in damages as a result of 50 years of what the suit calls ''fraudulent'' marketing. The industry had said the Justice Department's contentions about its advertising, marketing, promotion and warnings fell in the exclusive jurisdiction of the Federal Trade Commission. Judge Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court in Washington denied the motion. The suit is scheduled for trial next year. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Sorenstam Fails to Conquer, But Wins Fans on the Way
description: The talk-show hosts set up behind the 18th green kept referring to the opening round of the Colonial golf tournament as Annika Sorenstam's first rodeo.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bond Conversion
description: A producer of canned foods, Cirio Finanziaria, which defaulted on its bonds, approved a plan to convert 1.3 billion euros ($1.5 billion) of debt into shares in a bid to avoid bankruptcy. Cirio will issue 450 million euros of new shares for the swap, which will give bondholders ownership of as much as 95 percent of the restructured company, Cirio said. Bondholders will receive shares worth 13 percent to 78 percent of their original investments.

title: Roger Pilkington, British Author, 88
description: Roger Pilkington, a prolific British author of books about sex, religion and sailing small boats along Europe's inland waterways, died in England on May 5. He was 88.

title: HUDSON TECHNOLOGIES PLANS TO TRIM STAFF BY 20 PERCENT
description: Hudson Technologies Inc., which sells refrigerants, is cutting about 20 percent of its work force and closing six service depots to reduce costs by $1.6 million a year. The cuts will begin in the third quarter, Hudson said. The company, based in Pearl River, N.Y., has 85 employees, its president, Brian Coleman, said. Service depots to be closed are in Hillburn, N.Y.; Rantoul, Ill.; Charlotte; and Seattle.

title: SARS and Adoptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Singapore Begins SARS TV Channel
description: Singaporeans who cannot get enough news about SARS can now tune into the Sars Channel, which has nothing but news and information about severe acute respiratory syndrome.

title: Lottery Numbers
Philosophers Draw On a Film Drawing On Philosophers
description: Hundreds of millions of dollars ago, in a galaxy far, far away, a hacker named Neo reached into his bookcase and pulled out a leatherbound volume with the title ''Simulacra and Simulation'' -- a collection of essays by the French postmodernist philosopher Jean Baudrillard. But when Neo opened it to the chapter ''On Nihilism,'' it turned out to be just a simulacrum of a book, hollowed out to hold computer disks.

title: MARVELL TECHNOLOGY SHARES JUMP 16% ON PROFIT REPORT
description: The shares of the Marvell Technology Group rose 16 percent after the company, a chip maker, posted strong results and provided a bullish outlook. Shares of Marvell ended at $32.10, up $4.52 on Nasdaq. Marvell, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., reported net income of $4.4 million, or 3 cents a share, for the fiscal first quarter, which ended May 3, after the markets closed on Thursday. Excluding acquisition-related expenses and other items, the company said it would have reported earnings of $24.5 million, or 19 cents a share, above the 17 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue was $168.3 million, topping the $162.6 million predicted by analysts.

title: Jury Deadlock Spares Life Of Man Guilty In 3 Murders
description: A Westchester County jury was unable to agree today on a sentence for a man who killed his girlfriend and two of her young children, in effect sparing his life in the county's first death penalty case in almost 30 years.

description: The police captain who supervised a mistaken raid last week on the apartment of a Harlem woman who died shortly afterward of a heart attack has been transferred, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday.

description: $350 Billion Tax Cut Plan Is Approved by Congress

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIGLER, , HARVEY
description: TIGLER--Harvey. The entire Tourneau organization and the Wexler family mourn the passing of the founder and past president of its in-house advertising agency Harvard Marketing. His vitality, enthusiasm and creativity made him one of the true artists in the marketing world. His animated character and his perseverance will long be remembered. We extend our thoughts and prayers with our heartfelt condolences to his loving wife Ann and family. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGMAN, , JANICE LERNER
description: SELIGMAN--Janice Lerner. Died peacefully at home on Thursday, May 22, after a long illness. She is survived by her beloved daughters Ellen and Maggie and her grandchildren Alex and David. She had for many years been an active fundraiser for The New Lincoln School. She was well-known by her friends not only as vivacious, witty and generous, but as someone who remained a strong and outspoken supporter for many social and other causes. All who knew her will miss this courageous and great lady. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name to Gay Men's Health Crisis and The Southern Poverty Law Center. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about a study's finding that drug testing in schools does not deter drug use misstated the views of a sponsor, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. While it supports research on the subject, it has not endorsed testing; it has taken no position.

title: Demanding Discounts on Drugs
description: State efforts to obtain big discounts on prescription drugs for uninsured residents got a welcome boost from the Supreme Court this week. The court lifted an injunction that had prevented Maine from implementing an innovative program that will use the state's purchasing power under Medicaid to press the drug companies for discounts on medicine sold to other citizens as well. Although the court rendered no final judgment on the issue, its reasoning in lifting the injunction gives us hope that the states will ultimately be able to use their Medicaid plans as a crowbar to pry broader discounts from the drug industry.

title: Beliefs; In the aftermath of war, what is there to be said about the pope's opposition to it?
description: For many months, Pope John Paul II made it unmistakably clear that he opposed an invasion of Iraq and supported instead a continued effort by the United Nations to counter any threat posed by Saddam Hussein.

title: Former Mayor Giuliani Marries
description: Some bridegrooms might have chosen "Lohengrin." But Rudolph W. Giuliani and his betrothed, Judith Nathan, exchanged wedding vows on the lawn of Gracie Mansion this evening to the strains of "Ave Maria," sung by Ronan Tynan, the Irish tenor.

title: New Jersey Is Running Out Of Open Land It Can Build On
description: New Jersey, far more densely populated than any other state -- more crowded than Japan or India, for that matter -- is on course for another distinction: it will be the first state, land-use experts say, to exhaust its supply of land available for development.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWEDEN: IRAQI HELD IN REFUGEE CASE Khaleed Shnayf Daoed, 36, an Iraqi arrested in Sweden who is suspected of having helped organize a boat trip from Indonesia to Australia in which 353 asylum seekers drowned, was ordered held in custody in Stockholm at Australia's request while a formal extradition application is drawn up. Mr. Daoed is suspected of involvement in the voyage of the SIEV-X, which sank nearly two years ago after departing Indonesia, a transit point for Middle Eastern and Afghan migrants. Australia is also trying to extradite another man in the same case, Mootaz Muhammad Hasan, an Egyptian also known as Abu Quassey, who is being detained in Cairo.

title: In Switch, Money Leaves Junk Bond Funds
description: High-yield bond fund managers reported their first outflows since February, losing $257.7 million in the week ended May 21, AMG Data Services said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Saturday with an article about a judge's order requiring Honeywell International to clean up a 34-acre site along Jersey City's waterfront included an outdated reference for an area south of it. Roosevelt Stadium was demolished in 1985. A residential community called Society Hill is there now.

title: In Japan, Smaller Banks Are Outperforming the Giants
description: In Japan these days, the words healthy bank may seem to be an oxymoron. But a handful of midsize regional lenders are doing what neither the debt-sodden national megabanks nor the dozens of weak local banks can seem to manage: they are making money.

title: Blacks, Jews And Crown Heights

title: U.N. Appoints Special Representative for Iraq
description: Srgio Vieira de Mello, a longtime United Nations executive who made his reputation in recent years helping repair the havoc caused by the world's nastiest regional conflicts, is Secretary General Kofi Annan's choice as the United Nations special representative in Iraq.

title: Chvez and Foes Agree to a Referendum on His Rule
description: After six months of bitter negotiations, President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela and his adversaries have agreed to sign an accord that would lead to a referendum on his rule, officials on both sides said today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES. Crude oil rose on speculation that damage to Iraq's oil infrastructure will slow the return of exports to prewar levels. In New York, crude oil for July delivery rose 31 cents, or 1.1 percent, to $29.16 a barrel.

title: Music That Needed Room and Got It
description: The Vision Festival is a kind of good-will festival in an overcompetitive town. It's an annual bonanza of jazz that split apart from the mainstream more than 40 years ago, developing its own traditions, language, innovations and clichs. Some call it free jazz, though most of it isn't free of rhythm, harmony and melody, Some call it avant-jazz, but at this point it's hardly avant-anything. A few years ago people were calling it ecstatic jazz, which got to the point, but you don't hear the phrase much anymore.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have a giddy feeling that says, 'Great, no finals!' But the adult growing inside me says this won't be great for college transcripts.''

title: Gerard M. Weisberg, Longtime State Judge And City Official, 77
description: Gerard M. Weisberg, a judge on the New York State Court of Claims from 1977 to 1995, died at his home in Manahawkin, N.J., on May 17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAULT, , LOUISE MELLOR
description: GAULT--Louise Mellor, in New York City on May 23, 2003 of complications from Myelodisplastic Syndrome (MDS), a blood marrow disorder. She had been battling other forms of cancer for many years. She was 68. Beloved wife of Stanley A. Bowker of New York City. Louise is also survived by two brothers: Robert, of West Newton, Massachusetts; and James, of Rockford, Illinois. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday May 26th 6-8PM. Services to follow at 8PM. Interment will take place on Thursday May 29th at the Allegheny Cemetery, Pittsburgh, PA. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York City Ballet. >>AD#

title: Atswhatimtalknbout Has a Bruised Foot
description: Atswhatimtalknbout, who has been pointing for the Belmont Stakes since finishing a fast-closing fourth in the Kentucky Derby, has missed two days of training with a bruised right front foot.

title: Friesen's Late Goal Gives Devils A Date With Ducks in the Finals
description: The Ottawa Senators entered Game 7 tonight hoping to duplicate the Devils' feat of rallying from a three-games-to-one deficit to win a conference final series and advance to the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Fear of a Quagmire?
description: Suddenly the d-word is on everyone's lips. Last weekend the International Monetary Fund released a rather ominous report titled ''Deflation: determinants, risks and policy options.'' The report made headlines by suggesting that Germany is likely to join Japan in the falling-price club. Alan Greenspan hastened to reassure us that the U.S. isn't at imminent risk of deflation. But alert Greenspanologists pointed out that he seemed to hedge his bets, and the fact that he even felt obliged to discuss the issue showed that he was worried.

title: Man in the News -- Srgio Vieira de Mello; In a Storm, a Calm Voice
description: About two years ago, during the long, fractious aftermath of East Timor's break from Indonesia, Srgio Vieira de Mello and various United Nations personnel and journalists were descending into Jakarta on a United Nations plane when the landing was abruptly aborted.

title: Campus life : For students, a lesson in tolerance
description: VIENNA  She's 13. She goes to an American international school. Her dad works for an American company, and then there's that American accent, but don't get the wrong idea, she says. She's "anything but" an American.

description: FINE--Marjorie Goldstein, on May 23, 2003 at home in New York City at age 86. Beloved mother of Ellen Weaver. Adored grandmother of Marc Davies. Funeral service will take place at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday, May 25th at 1:30PM. Interment to follow at Union Fields Cemetery. title: Slaughter in the Name of a Drug War
description: For the last three months, the Thai government has been engaged in a war on drugs, with the goal of ridding the country of methamphetamines. The result, however, has been 2,275 deaths -- and the sacrifice of human rights, freedom of the press and Thailand's reputation as a democratic country.

title: SARS Fears in Toronto
description: Authorities in Canada reported a cluster of possible new SARS cases in Toronto that they said could number in the 20's. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control reinstated a travel alert for the city, and health officials issued new quarantine orders.

title: For a Champion of Song, It's About Communicating
description: Nothing is more natural than a song. And nothing is more artificial than the standard art song recital. The singer stands frozen in the sheltering curve of a grand piano, enunciating syllables in five languages, all incomprehensible.

title: Partial Recall for Top Cholesterol Drug
description: About 100,000 bottles of Lipitor, the Pfizer Inc. cholesterol pills that are the world's top-selling prescription medicine, have been recalled because of suspected counterfeiting, the Food and Drug Administration said.

description: THE UNCONQUERABLE WORLD:

title: Expectations of a Jump-Start Are Countered by Wait-and-See
description: The Bush administration is promising big things for the package of $320 billion in tax cuts and $30 billion in aid to states and families that Congress passed yesterday. But independent experts disagree about how much the measure will jolt the economy.

title: Labor Group On 2004 Vote Suffers Split
description: The labor movement's efforts to develop a unified strategy to defeat President Bush in 2004 stumbled this week when the chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political committee angrily quit the board of a new labor-backed group aimed at mobilizing nonunion voters, taking the two other board members with him.

description: Instead of playing this weekend, Annika Sorenstam will be reminiscing.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Officials Report Births Of 2 Lynx
description: Wildlife officials have confirmed that two lynx kittens have been born, the first evidence of reproduction in the wild since lynx were reintroduced in the state in 1999. The program has suffered a high mortality rate. Of the 128 lynx released, 45 are confirmed dead, and 20 are missing. Biologists plan to release an additional 100 lynx next year and in 2005. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Truckmaker's Loss Triples
description: The truckmaker Isuzu Motors said it lost a record 114 billion yen ($973 million) in the year that ended March 31, almost three times what it lost the year before. Weak truck sales combined with losses on its stock portfolio and its venture with Fuji Heavy Industries were responsible. The company expects to earn 35 billion yen ($299 million) this year. General Motors owns 12 percent of Isuzu. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Hamilton's Arrest Clouds His Return
description: The Giants' Keith Hamilton talked optimistically this spring about his comeback from a torn Achilles' tendon, saying he intended to dedicate his performance in the 2003 season to the memory of his youngest sister, who was killed in a car wreck last winter.

title: Terror Scare On a Cruise Leads Police To a Voyeur
description: One hour into a credit union's office party on a Thursday evening cruise from Perth Amboy, N.J., to the Statue of Liberty, the boat's engineer made a startling find near a toilet: a fake air freshener that contained a suspicious device with wires.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: No Neglect Laws For Fetus
description: The Court of Appeals has ruled that courts cannot use child-neglect laws to protect a fetus. The case began when a county human services department asked a court to intervene in the welfare of an unborn baby on the grounds that the mother was using methamphetamines. The state district judge would not do so on the grounds that state law applied just to dependent and neglected children younger than 18, not unborn children. The Court of Appeals agreed, stating that the law protects children only after birth. The baby in the case is living with his mother. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Bush's Heaviest Hitters to Be Called Rangers
description: President Bush, who owes his personal fortune to the Texas Rangers baseball team, is hoping the name will help provide him another bonanza in political fund-raising.

title: Andretti's Last Chance For Better Luck at Indy
description: Michael Andretti was asked once again today if the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday would really be his last race. At age 40, Andretti is 14 years younger than his father, Mario, was when he retired, and it would be easy to make a last-minute U-turn.

title: With Tax Cut Bill Passed, Republicans Call for More
description: The $350 billion package of tax cuts and state assistance approved by Congress today was still being printed when Republican leaders in Congress vowed to bring up more tax cut proposals later this year and extend today's measure for years to come.

description: President Bush and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi warned North Korea today that any steps it took toward building additional nuclear weapons would be met with a stronger response from the United States and Japan.

title: Fewer Survivors and More Bodies as Algerians Search Rubble
description: DELLYS, Algeria, May 24  Muhammad Iferki sprayed a stream of lemon air freshener through the window of an old ambulance today as rescue workers loaded yet another body into it to transport to the hospital morgue.

title: Editorial Observer; The Wisdom of 'The Compleat Angler' at 350
description: Only a handful of the books first published in London in the sober year of 1653 are still read today, even by scholars. And only one of that year's first editions has gone on, over the next three and a half centuries, to be reprinted again and again and to find new readers every year.

title: Spurs Win, and the Mavericks May Lose Nowitzki
description: The boisterous American Airlines Center grew quiet tonight, with cries for a rally turning into prayers for a miracle healing as Dirk Nowitzki writhed beneath a basket. Nowitzki, the Dallas Mavericks' superstar 7-footer, sprained his left knee, buckling it while going for a rebound, with about eight minutes left in tonight's game against the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VLACHOS, , GEORGE N.
description: VLACHOS--George N. Devoted father to Nicholas, Alexander and Sophia, and loving brother to James. Courageous World War II veteran, loyal friend, and a determined individual. We will miss your counsel and love. Peter Vlachos and Family >>AD#

title: Big Trouble for the President's Magician
description: Although the world is spinning more out of control every day, the American theater has seemed reluctant to address some of the issues that are polarizing the country. Gil Kofman's ''American Magic'' tries but has little new to say.

title: JUDGE APPROVES UNITED'S DEAL WITH G.E. ON 51 PLANES
description: United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, and General Electric gained a bankruptcy court judge's approval for their agreement on restructuring leases and financing arrangements on 51 planes. The agreement is expected to save United $200 million over five years and is part of the airline's goal to reduce aircraft costs by $500 million annually. Judge Eugene Wedoff of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the agreement yesterday in Chicago. The airline, which filed for bankruptcy protection in December, has been seeking to tailor its fleet size to a lower level of air travel demand. United, which is based in Chicago, would also get $16 million more in bankruptcy financing through the arrangement with the G.E. Commercial Finance unit.

title: Nets' Bosses Mutter Amid the Cheering
description: The Nets are playing with a sense of camaraderie and purpose in the Eastern Conference finals, and are a victory from their second straight trip to the N.B.A. finals.

title: Detroit Mayor Fights Accusations of Misdeeds

title: Climb Other Mountains
description: When I reached the summit of Mount Everest on the 29th of May, 1953, I wasn't the slightest bit interested in mankind. As far as I was concerned, our objective was to reach the summit, and what mankind thought about it was more or less unimportant. It wasn't until we came down off the mountain, in fact, that we became aware that the public and the media had built up a big sort of aura of heroic effort. We didn't feel heroic at all. My climbing partner, Tenzing Norgay, in many ways was more emotional about it than I was. In those days, Tenzing, who was a Sherpa, did not speak particularly good English. My ability with Nepali was pretty limited. Even when we were on the summit, we didn't discuss things at all. I put out my hand, in sort of stuffy old Anglo-Saxon fashion, to shake his hand, but that wasn't enough for him. He threw his arms around my shoulders, and I threw my arms around his.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBLUM, , MARVIN J.
description: ROSENBLUM -- Marvin J. Died on May 7, 2003, in Chicago, IL, at the age of 60. He was the devoted husband of Gina (nee Hirsch) for 32 years. He was the loving father of Rachel and Jonathan Rosenfeld of NYC, David and Liora Rosenblum, of Riverdale, NY, Sara and Mark Ginsberg of Clifton, NJ, and Lea Rosenblum of Chicago, IL. He was also the adoring grandfather of Joseph Ginsberg and Gabriella Rosenblum. He is survived by his father William Rosenblum of Chicago, IL, and by his sisters, Myrna Epstein of Scranton, PA, Sandra Hertzberg, of Monsey, NY, and Rosalyn Fishler of Chicago, IL. Marvin received Rabbinic Ordination from the Telshe Yeshiva of Wickliffe, OH (Class of '65). He loved, learned and practiced Torah throughout his entire life. He graduated from DePaul University, Chicago, IL (Class of '68), and was a graduate of the University of Chicago Law School (Class of '71). He served as Senior Law Clerk to the late US District Court Judge, Abraham Lincoln Marovitz. Marvin was a brilliant lawyer and served as General Counsel to Matchbox Toys, Ltd. As a successful entrepreneur, he founded several companies and served as a Board Director (First Commercial Bank of Chicago, Excalibur Technologies Corp, Innapharma, Inc, The Osmotics Corp and Kahr Pharmaceuticals). He was the executive producer and guiding spirit of the remake of George Orwell's ''1984'' starring John Hurt and Richard Burton. Marvin was an avid reader and had friends around the world. His dreams and visions knew no intellectual or geographical bounds. Marvin was beloved by family, friends and associates who were charmed by his sharp wit, keen mind and gentle spirit. Honesty, loyalty and fidelity were his constant companions. Eulogies were delivered in Chicago, IL, and Queens, NY, on May 8, 2003. Marvin Rosenblum was laid to rest on May 9, 2003, in Jerusalem, Israel, on Har HaMenuchot. Shiva was held in Chicago, IL, and concluded on May 15, 2003. May his memory serve as a blessing to all who knew him. >>AD#

title: A Lot Has Changed In North Amityville
description: ''Stuck in Last Place'' [May 4] ignored the positive aspects of North Amityville. According to the 2000 Census, North Amityville is 69 percent African-American, 19 percent white and 14 percent Hispanic or Latino. The African-American population has decreased 7 percent since the 1960's, when North Amityville was put on a list of ''racial ghettoes.''

title: Pass the Butter, Please
description: Dr. Robert Atkins, the diet guru who died last month from head injuries suffered in a fall, would have enjoyed reading last week's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. It carried two independent studies that enhanced the credibility of his controversial low carbohydrate, high fat, high protein approach to weight loss. Though the Atkins diet has been reviled by the medical establishment for decades as a bit wacky and even potentially dangerous, the two new studies and a third published last month suggest that the diet actually works better than standard low-fat diets in the short term, without any detectable signs of harm. It was a startling reminder of how little the experts know, in this obesity-plagued nation, about the best way to lose weight and keep it off.

title: A Riviera Suicide, a Paris Rebirth
description: ON March 16, 1955, Nicolas de Stal jumped to his death from the terrace of his studio in Antibes on the Cte d'Azur. Only 41 at the time, the Russian-born painter was a leading, albeit controversial, member of the School of Paris. But his renown did not long survive him. In the art world's unforgiving version of natural selection, de Stal never made the list of the 20th century's most important artists.

title: 'October Men'
description: ON THE EARLY EVENING of October 1, 1978, after six months of roistering with an intensity unmatched in the long history of hyperkinetic, high-proof roistering that so enriches the annals of American baseball, the New York Yankees found themselves tied for first place. The team had won 99 of 162 games, a commendable winning percentage of .611, but so had their traditional rivals, the Boston Red Sox. Autumn had taken hold along the eastern seaboard, bringing bright clear skies and quickening winds. The regular season of '78 was history. Still, in a sense, the teams found themselves just where they had been some six months earlier on Opening Day, April 8-tied, toe to toe, and glowering. As nature is said to abhor a vacuum, baseball abhors a tie, so now the Yankees were going to have to fly to Boston and meet the Red Sox yet again in a single-game playoff on October 2. As more than one sportswriter pointed out, the entire season for the two teams was coming down to one game. The regular season had ended and it had not ended. (In an interesting theory advanced by the author W. P. Kinsella, a ball game can stretch from the first inning clear to infinity. Uniquely among team sports, baseball proceeds outside of time. There is no clock.)

description: KEEPING a low profile is not always easy, especially for someone considered one of the most powerful politicians never to have been elected to public office in New Jersey. Yet that is what George E. Norcross III has been trying to do and, until recently with more than a little success. Working mostly from his sprawling white brick-faced colonial home or his glass-and-chrome office at Commerce Bancorp here, with an occasional well-timed visit to Trenton, Mr. Norcross has spent the last several years reshaping the Legislature and influencing state spending, all the while becoming a millionaire many times over and accumulating unrivaled power.

title: Editorial Notebook; Whose Language Is It Anyway?
description: As a career language guardian, I was more than casually interested in the College Board's decision to throw out a grammar question on its PSAT after a high school teacher pointed out that the desired answer was not technically correct. The question asked if there was a grammatical error in this sentence: ''Toni Morrison's genius enables her to create novels that arise from and express the injustices African Americans have endured.'' The College Board thought the sentence was correct, but a journalism teacher in Maryland told the officials that the word ''her'' did not refer back to Toni Morrison but to ''Toni Morrison's'' -- an error in grammar.

title: COURT NOMINEE WINS
description: The Senate also confirmed an appellate judge, John E. Wallace Jr., for a seat on the state Supreme Court. The dissenter in the 34-to-1 vote, Gerald Cardinale, a Republican from Bergen County, argued against maintaining the court's ''left of center bias.'' Judge Wallace, 61, will become the second African-American on the court, succeeding the first, James H. Coleman Jr., who is retiring. At a hearing on May 8, Judge Wallace declined to give his view on the death penalty or on the financing of poor public-school districts.

title: Music Works Its (Western) Wiles in China
description: A decade ago, Chen Kaige's popular film ''Farewell My Concubine'' immersed Westerners in an exotic world known to few: Chinese opera. Mr. Chen's latest film, ''Together,'' which opens in New York on Friday at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema and the Sunshine Cinema, uses rough and rustic Chinese settings as the backdrop for a tale steeped in Western culture and values.

title: How Students Fared on the State English Exam
description: New York City's fourth and eighth graders made solid gains this year on New York State's standardized English Language Arts tests, with particularly sharp improvements among fourth graders in some of the city's poorest and historically lowest-performing districts.

title: Nets Sweep Pistons And Return to Finals
description: The Nets reached the National Basketball Association finals for the second year in a row by sweeping their series with the Detroit Pistons last night.

title: POSTINGS: At Newport in Jersey City; School Moving To Office Site
description: In an unusual alliance between a private elementary school and a commercial developer, the 15-year-old Cornerstone School in Jersey City will move this September into a floor of an office building now rising at the Lefrak Organization's Newport development.

title: Posh 'n' Becks Hear America Calling
description: THE modern celebrity throne, a black Chevrolet Suburban, pulls up outside 1411 Broadway, the address of such dependable American brands as Jones New York, Perry Ellis and Bobbie August. This is where you go if you're a buyer for Nordstrom and you want 20,000 units of a cotton interlock shirt with a lay-down collar: a 39-story caravansary of potted-plant reception areas, beige wall-to-wall and what anybody in the industry without the slightest need to romance a $10 Chinese-made shirt calls ''merch.''

title: As American as Pie and Lobster
description: LARRY BOCKIUS, a longtime member of the Pound Ridge Community Church, was seething. With his unkempt brows and blaze of white hair fairly quivering, he was hardly the picture of Christian forbearance. Somehow, scandalously, the key lime pie he'd been promised earlier in the day had disappeared.

title: Doctors Seek to Cut Malpractice Awards
description: HUNDREDS of lab-coated doctors rallied on Long Island on Tuesday to protest high liability insurance rates and call for a cap on pain-and-suffering awards in malpractice cases.

title: Using Handicapped Spots Could Become More Costly
description: Those who crave convenience will have to think two and a half times harder before they illegally park in a handicapped spot if a bill pending in the Legislature is approved. The proposal would raise the penalty for a first offense to $250, from $100. A second offense would cost just as much -- in addition to 90 days of community service.

title: By Rail, on the Trail Of Lewis and Clark
description: Beginning this month, passengers aboard the Lewis and Clark Explorer Train can follow the same route from Portland to Astoria, Ore., that the explorers took by canoe 200 years ago.

title: Wells Roughed Up as Yankees' Slide Picks Up Steam
description: David Wells can be an intimidating presence, especially when he is stretching with a green elastic band in the low-slung Yankee clubhouse, as he was during the hours before yesterday's game against the Toronto Blue Jays. At one point, Jason Giambi walked up to the bald-headed Wells and patted him on the stomach, a half-rub, half-love tap for the man entrusted with trying to break the Yankees' free fall. Wells barely noticed him.

title: Where Performance Art and Pasties Meet
description: ON a recent Wednesday night, Julie Atlas Muz took the stage at Low, a sleek little nightclub tucked under the Brooklyn Bridge. Ms. Muz, a contemporary-dance choreographer known for her outrageous conceptual burlesque numbers, eyed the audience with slyly coquettish abandon. The only thing ordinary about this striptease was her get-up: a tight black corset, garters and high heels.

title: The Rules on Bosses' Pay Seem Written With Pencil
description: OF all the big lies out there, the one that corporate executives' pay is linked to the performance of their companies takes the prize. No matter how much of the shareholders' wealth goes down the drain, the hired hands in the executive suite keep pocketing preposterous pay and insisting that it is based on results.

title: Corrections
description: Charts on April 6, May 11 and May 18 recording votes in Congress by members of the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut delegations were published in error. They showed votes for the week ended March 29. Corrected charts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion, and a current one appears today, on Page 38.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: WISH YOU WERE HERE, by Stewart O'Nan. (Grove, $14.) The secret scars of childhood, the long-held grudges from slights both real and imagined and the betrayals of love are the central themes in this large-canvas family saga, which unfolds through the perspectives of the members of three generations of the Maxwell clan during a summer vacation at their cottage in New York State. ''The action rises and ebbs with the rhythms of daily life'' and the characters are drawn ''with sympathy and subtlety,'' Ruth Franklin wrote here in 2002. The result is O'Nan's ''finest and deepest novel to date.''

title: Motor City
description: AMONG the attractions of Hunts Point, that patch of the South Bronx that juts out into the East River like a clenched asphalt fist, are a juvenile prison; ominously shuttered drinking establishments with names like Al's Mr. Wedge; informal, and illegal, late-night drag races on the weekends; and the world's largest wholesale fruit and vegetable market. Since the 1940's, the Point, as natives call it, has also been a grease monkey mecca, with almost 200 junkyards, garages and used auto parts shops packed into a couple of square miles.

title: Those Summers In Camelot . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASKARIS, , ARETI

Passed on May 23. The world knew her as the hard working hotdog lady ''Rita'' that stood on Beaver Street downtown for decades. We knew her as independence, work ethic and infinite love. You will always be with us, Mama. >>AD#

title: In Tile, Honoring The Lives Lived
description: A mural made up of 2,000 six-inch-square ceramic tiles painted by hundreds of adults and children to commemorate 9/11 will be installed on a specially built wall in Greenburgh.

title: Uh, That's What We Thought You Meant
description: JUST what, exactly, is North Korea thinking? America's attempts to dismantle the rogue regime's illegal nuclear weapons program seem endlessly stymied by diplomatic missteps and plenty of harsh talk. Now, it seems, at least some of this confusion has been caused by North Korea's own state sponsored communiqus.

title: He Has Godzilla's Ear
description: NO deer-caught-in-the-headlights stares. No sweaty palms or sudden urges to flee. The first time Roger Kahlon saw the media horde descend on him, he knew exactly what to do.

title: 'The Empty Ocean'
description: Once upon a time, gray whales fed in the cold waters off Iceland and Greenland and migrated south-perhaps to the Bay of Biscay or even to the English Channel-to breed. Morphologically, they were the same whales (now known as Eschrichtius robustus ) as the better-known California gray whales, which confine their migratory meanderings to the Pacific coast of North America, annually swimming south from the Bering Sea to Baja California and back again. No living person has seen an Atlantic gray whale, but we do have suggestive historical and conclusive paleontological evidence to confirm the existence of the creature that whale-hunters used to call "devil-fish."

title: May 18-24; NOW AND THEN
College Pays $75,000 to Settle a Sexual Harassment Case
description: Apublic liberal arts college in southeastern New Jersey has agreed to pay $75,000 to a former vice president who accused the college president, Vera King Farris, of sexual harassment, according to a settlement announced last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUPPERSTEIN, , GEORGE
description: KUPPERSTEIN--George. 86, of Spencertown, NY on May 17, 2003 in Scottsdale, AZ. Retired Offical Court Reporter. Leaving wife Lee, sons Joel, Gordon and Robert, grandchildren Russell, Rebecca and Sam. >>AD#

title: Going Price for Castles? In Tarrytown, $10.9 Million
description: Elite Hotels, a limited liability company formed by C. Dean Metropoulos, an international investor, has paid $10.9 million for the Castle at Tarrytown, a 31-room inn on 10.1 acres overlooking the Hudson River.

title: With Kidd Still Standing, His Teammates Are Exhaling
description: The game was already over, maybe had been since Kenyon Martin ran the opening tip in for a dunk. But with 6 minutes 59 seconds to play tonight, the one thing that could take the Nets' breath away happened.

title: The Sincerest Form Of Self-Flattery: An Allen Crib Sheet
description: WRITER'S BLOCK'' consists of two new Woody Allen one-acts (''Riverside Drive'' and ''Old Saybrook''), and its recent premiere at the Atlantic Theater in Chelsea marked the first time that Mr. Allen has directed his own original work for a live audience.

title: 3 Strikes, You're Out? Not Necessarily
description: AT a time when youth sports are so scheduled and hyper-competitive, it seems like a simple but unlikely concession: For the 7- and 8-year-olds in the Pelham Little League, there is no such thing as striking out. Batters can take swings until they hit the ball in fair play. And if they never hit the ball? ''They get to walk to base so they don't feel like they got out,'' said Lori Anzilotti, the president of the Pelham Little League. ''If kids' feelings are hurt, they can't succeed. A lot don't have the skill level and we don't want them to feel they have failed.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on May 11 in Summer Movies, Part 2 of this section, about horse-racing films misidentified Stanley Kubrick's first movie. It was ''Fear and Desire''; ''The Killing'' was his third.

title: Program Aims to Help Child-Care Providers
description: The Child Care Council of Westchester, in collaboration with the Women's Enterprise Development Center, the Westchester Housing Fund, the Westchester County Office for Women, and J.P. Morgan Chase Bank, is coordinating a business training and loan program for child-care providers who want to start or expand their business.
