description: To the Editor:

title: The World: New Chapter, Old Debate; Would Kennedy Have Quit Vietnam?
description: HISTORY abounds in what-ifs. If Lincoln had not been shot, the South, and the nation, might have accepted full racial equality a century earlier. If Wilson had not been felled by a stroke, the United States might have joined the League of Nations and prevented World War II. And if John F. Kennedy had not been killed in Dallas could the Vietnam War have been avoided?

title: What Children Watch
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Writing on the Wall, the Writing's on the Wall
description: ''KECH,'' ''HVROTE'' and ''JDENSI'' had better beware. These graffiti ''tags'' face the same weapon that building owners have long used against traditional scourges like floods, fires and termites: insurance.

title: GOVERNORS RESIST BUSH PLAN TO SLOW COSTS OF MEDICAID
description: After two months of intense secret negotiations, governors and Bush administration officials have been unable to agree on a plan to rein in the soaring cost of Medicaid, participants in the talks say.

title: Mississippi: The Album Postal Service: The Video Time Travel: The Beat
description: DAVID BANNER -- A great hip-hop album from Mississippi, called -- just to be clear -- ''Mississippi: The Album'' (SRC/Universal). The rapper and producer David Banner (he borrowed his name from the Incredible Hulk) collapses the history of Mississippi music, putting bluesy laments side-by-side with wild-eyed scream-alongs. ''Bush'' turns civic pride into sociopolitical criticism: ''This for Mississippi, and every place y'all treat like Mississippi.'' Nearly everything works, from the synthesizer-driven club tracks to the slow-motion love songs, but nothing tops ''Cadillac on 22's,'' an extraordinary ballad of faith and self-doubt. Accompanied by a strummed acoustic guitar, David Banner moans, ''Lord, please just tell me something . . . My music bumping/ But I feel nothing.''

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; At Home Offices, 2 Firms Project Their Own Style
description: A REAL estate company's home office is its castle -- a domain reflecting the style and philosophy of the person in charge. At least this holds true with the Gale Company of Florham Park and the Lightstone Group of Lakewood, two large companies that recently set up new home offices.

title: Vital Role
description: In the grand drama of governing post-Saddam Iraq, what role will the United Nations play? More to the semantic point, what modifier of that noun role most accurately defines -- or obfuscates or sugarcoats -- the part that the international agency will play? (Note that I have strained to substitute part for the overused figure of speech, role to play, but cannot avoid the theatrical metaphor of some character playing a part.)

title: Ideas & Trends; Sorenstam Has Got Game, in Reality and Virtually
description: ON Thursday at the Colonial Country Club, the pressure was on Annika Sorenstam; on Friday, it was on the 40 men who had failed to beat her opening-round 71.

title: An 11-16 Skid Has Yanks Looking Up to Red Sox
description: Mike Mussina said the Yankees have not done anything right. Manager Joe Torre said their dismal play is puzzling and Derek Jeter hoped that being bounced out of first place for the first time this season would motivate them. If the Yankees sounded a little depressed and a little desperate, it is because both emotions were swimming around their clubhouse on Friday night.

title: How This Cowboy Got Lost in the City
description: URBAN COWBOY,'' which closed last Sunday after 26 previews and 60 performances at the Broadhurst Theater, garnered some of the worst reviews of the Broadway musical season. Not the disaster-cult euphoria that greeted ''Dance of the Vampires,'' but something more along the lines of ''How dare they bring this tripe to New York?'' Based on the 1980 John Travolta-Debra Winger movie (and the original Esquire article by Aaron Latham), the musical's book, about a hick ranch hand finding love at a singles bar near Houston, was by Mr. Latham and Phillip Oesterman; the score consisted of country standards (some from the film), as well as newly commissioned songs in a similar vein.

title: Next Stop, the Regatta
description: IF it weren't for trains, the venerable Harvard-Yale Regatta might never have started, much less produced 137 races over the past 150 years. And although trains eventually faded from the regatta scene as they did elsewhere, a vigorous volunteer effort has now brought back a classic regatta feature.

title: Patriotism, Shopping And Poppies
description: ON D-DAY, Stephen Berberian was an 18-year-old Navy quartermaster steering a landing craft filled with troops and supplies onto Omaha Beach under heavy fire. But Mr. Berberian found making it onto that bloody beach 59 years ago much easier than landing today on the parking lots of several sprawling chain stores that line Route 10 here.

title: Dining; An Indian Sampler, Influenced by South
description: DAKSHIN in Stamford proves that success can repeat itself. The restaurant, a new sibling of Coromandel, an excellent Indian restaurant in Darien, is living up to its elder's high standards in dcor, friendly and polished service, and food.

description: INDIAN SUMMER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLUNKET, , JOHN THOMPSON
description: PLUNKET--John Thompson, 88, of Sarasota, FL, passed away May 7th in Cholula, Mexico. Devoted husband of Dolores, loving father of Lucy Silver, Robert, John Jr. and Patricia, revered grandfather of Sarah, Andrea, Rebecca, Benjamin, Orion and John III. Mr. Plunket's career spanned 50 years of Latin American business and politics. A former special agent of the FBI, he conducted intelligence work during WWII in Venezuela and Costa Rica. After the war, he served as legal counsel to Braniff Airways and later as an executive with American and Foreign Power Company. He was President of the Cuban Electric Company when it was nationalized by the Cuban government in 1960. In Mexico during the 70's and 80's, he helped develop Mexico's industrial growth and expansion. He served as President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Mexico and President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Latin America. After funeral services in Mexico, Mr. Plunket was buried in his hometown of Greenville, TX. A memorial service will take place in Sarasota. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: The Crash Course column on Page 21 of The Times Magazine today, about different viewpoints on distributing foreign aid, misstates part of a Web address for further information. It is www.worldbank.org/html/ extdr/gc/index.htm, not worlbank.

title: Alissa Vradenburg, Michael Sheresky
description: Alissa Lee Vradenburg, the daughter of Trish and George A. Vradenburg of Washington, was married yesterday to Michael James Sheresky, the son of the late Stefani Royce Sheresky and the late Kenneth B. Sheresky, both of New York. Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: When Senioritis Strikes
description: THE virus has been in existence for decades. It remains dormant for most of the year, but come spring it appears in a virulent form on high school campuses. It strikes only the senior class and the symptoms include lassitude, apathy and a fatigue that manifests itself in sleeping through the first class or two of each day.

title: Bush on Board
description: To the Editor:

title: For Nissan, a New Plant and Ambitious Goals in the U.S.
description: IT'S hard for locals to miss the new $1.43 billion Nissan plant in Canton, Miss. The plant, at 2.5 million square feet, sprawls alongside Interstate 55, about 20 miles north of Jackson, with bright red letters declaring the company name to drivers traveling by.

title: Young Love Gone Wrong
description: BRIAN MORRIS, the handsome 17-year-old star of his high school baseball team, appeared to have a shining future. He had won a sports scholarship to Concordia College. His girlfriend, Bridgette Maldonado, also 17, was considered one of the prettiest girls in Tuckahoe High School. But on May 8, Brian went to Bridgette's home, tried to strangle her and then threw himself in front of a Metro-North train speeding down the tracks.

title: Perspective; A Special Bond Between Champions
description: ''They took away my father's career. They took away his life. Today it would be the same as some administrator telling Tiger Woods his career is over. Can you imagine how Tiger Woods would have felt, and how the rest of the world would have reacted, if he had been told at the age of 22 that he could never again participate in serious competition? Jesse Owens was touted as this legend who had beaten Hitler. Yet, back home in America, he was continually reminded that he was not so special. He was still black -- just like Joe Louis.''

title: Ideas & Trends: Learning Through Science; Mad Cow Disease Is a Little Less Scarier
description: ALARMING as it was to learn last week that mad cow disease had appeared in North America, the news could have been far worse. Thanks to advances in bioscience and technology, we can now stop an epidemic like mad cow disease, and its human offshoot, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, in its tracks.

title: Truth in Pictures
description: My fianc and I are starting a landscaping business. In planning a brochure, he suggested that we consider using photographs of other people's work. He says this is an accepted practice, and that buying photos from the Internet will produce a more professional job than would our amateur photos. But when I receive a brochure I assume I am seeing work that company has done. Can you bring some clarity to this? Anonymous, Connecticut

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSSI, , ASTRID (NANA)
description: ROSSI--Astrid (Nana). Age 80, May 12, 2003. She is preceded in death by husband, Loftus. Mrs. Rossi was born May 30, 1922 in St. Thomas. Beloved mother of Storm & Michael. Grandmother of David, Lisa & Michelle. Great-grandmother of Adrian. Survived by sisters Margie and Lena. Burial Calverton National Cemetery, Tuesday 10:30AM. >>AD#

title: Clubbing the Opposition
description: What is it with golf and the sexes? This famously genteel game, with its mannerly code of etiquette, has lately become a Thurberesque skirmish ground in the long-running battle between men and women.

title: Private Sector; A Drug Company's Man in Tweed
description: UNTIL recently, Mark C. Fishman, 52, worked in a rarefied realm where clinical academic medicine meets basic scientific research. He was a professor at the Harvard Medical School, chief of cardiology at Massachusetts General Hospital and a geneticist who founded and ran the hospital's cardiovascular research center, which has a staff of 95.

title: A Five-Block Move Planned for Sears
description: Ivy Equities of Montvale, N.J., and Barrow Street Capital, a pension fund adviser in New York City, have taken over Sears' lease of a three-floor, 270,000-square-foot building on Main Street in White Plains.

title: 'May the Best Team Win'
description: Many would say that the baseball industry had much to celebrate on November 6, 2001. The most scintillating World Series in recent memory, between the Arizona Diamondbacks and the New York Yankees, was decided in the bottom of the ninth of game seven. There had been no work stoppages for six-and-a-half years, the longest stretch in thirty years. Industry revenues in 2001 were 2.57 times greater than they were in 1995. Total attendance was at an all-time high. Major League Baseball (MLB) was in the midst of rich, long-term national television contracts, with Fox through 2006 for $2.5 billion and with ESPN through 2005 for $851 million. A new group of well-educated, business-proficient, and talented owners and executives were bringing intelligent and effective management strategies to many franchises. The industry could be proud of its patriotic sentiments, rituals, and contributions following the events of September 11, 2001.

title: No Hat, No Cap? A Hair Rescue
description: For bare hair, Ren Furterer makes a Waterproof Sunscreen Nutrient Oil ($18) with a keratin protective factor of 90. The manufacturer says it protects not only against ocean and pool water but also against ultraviolet rays. Orders: (800) 522-8285.

title: The President's Mideast Vision
description: This page has said, countless times, that strong American intervention offers the only chance for a peace settlement between Israel and the Palestinians. We have often said it with faint hope that it would ever happen. Early in his presidency, George Bush stepped back, on the theory, promoted by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and Mr. Sharon's supporters in the United States, that little could be accomplished without changes in the Palestinian leadership and its attitude toward terror. There have now been such changes. Moreover, Mr. Bush is not the same president. He may go to the Middle East next month to become more directly involved. We urge him to do so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINE, , MARJORIE GOLDSTEIN
description: FINE -- Marjorie Goldstein, known as Maggie. On May 23, at 5:45am, at home, after 86 memorable years. Beloved mother of Ellen Weaver, adored grandmother of Marc Davies and great-grandmother to Marc and Lenore's children: Zachary, Owen and Sam. Cherished aunt of Susan and Stan Mirsky. Treasured great-aunt of Jennifer and Jonathan Mirsky and Karen and Amy Leavitt. Maggie was an eminent sociological researcher, a graduate of Smith College, class of 1937, with Masters in Constitutional Law from Columbia University and Human Relations from New York University. She taught at Columbia, conducted Human Relations workshops at John Jay College and was on the faculty for special programs for African women leaders under State Department grants. Maggie was an original, a cultured woman who took French conversation and writing classes well into her 80s, regularly attending diverse cultural performances and serving on the social action committee of her synagogue, Shaaray Tefila. >>AD#

title: Fifty Yen? Japanese Hip-Hop Downtown
description: IN traditional Japanese culture, it is considered vulgar to show off your talents. Perhaps that's why a younger generation of Japanese have been drawn to the flash and dash of hip-hop culture, which for 20 years has hugely influenced Japanese music, dance, visual art and fashion.

description: A report in the Pulse column on March 16 about Gayle's Miracles, a brand of low-calorie chocolate truffles, misstated their fat content. It is one gram each, not five. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Springtime Finally Arrives To Leave Doldrums Behind
description: After the first old-fashioned winter in the East in nearly a decade, spring has arrived much later this year. Fishing remains a bit spotty and thin. The principal aquatic insects that sustain trout throughout the interminable twilight of winter, and emerge from the bottom cobble of Eastern trout streams from February to May, have proved sporadic and late. These are not the only symptoms of scarcity.

title: Chic? Sexy? Is Japan Really Talking Minivans?
description: EVEN in the darkened room, her face obscured in shadows from the camera, the woman being questioned clearly seemed uncomfortable. Squirming in her seat, a sense of shame in her voice, she whispered, ''I drive an M-I-N-I-V-A-N.''

title: State Prepares for Mosquito Season
description: IN the next few weeks, the season's first new crop of mosquitoes hatches by the thousands. Because of the wet spring, entomologists said fewer mosquitoes are expected in urban areas, but more elsewhere.

title: Sure-Hand Shows With Italian Cuisine
description: THE bad news is that Caswell's, one of Montauk's few serious restaurants, is no more.

title: CRANBERRY FAMILY FEUD
description: An older brother filed suit in Atlantic County Superior Court last week to try to stop a plan by the cranberry magnate J. Garfield DeMarco to sell nearly 10,000 acres of family farmland in the Pine Barrens to a conservation group. The suit, by Mark DeMarco, 72, also accuses Garfield DeMarco, 64, of mismanaging A.R. DeMarco Enterprises, which is owned by them and a sister, Anna Lynne Papinchak. The New Jersey Conservation Foundation has an option to buy the land for $12 million. Garfield DeMarco denied any wrongful conduct and said he expected the land sale to be upheld. ''My brother started a battle,'' he said. ''If that's what he wants, that's what he has.'' Jill P. Capuzzo

title: Conceptual Art, in the Days Before E-Mail
description: RAY JOHNSON (1927-95) seemed to be into something new during the many years he was sending what is called mail art and staging his ''Nothings,'' usually a one- or two-hour display of his works on paper presented in off-beat locations that were an easy drive from his home in Locust Valley.

title: Eggheads Unite
description: Introducing my comments in his article on graduate student unionization, Daniel Duane (May 4) pauses to point out that I am overweight and need exercise. I'm sure he was not resorting to the cheap rhetorical trick of trying to undermine my credibility with irrelevant personal remarks. So, assuming that such information is indeed salient to the debate, let me add that I am balding (indeed, quite nearly bald), that I wear glasses and that my teeth are not what they were. These several defects are undoubtedly the marks of a dubious character, and I am quite ashamed of myself.

It is ostensibly about a new Hyperion CD, with Keith John playing his own organ transcription of Elgar's ''Enigma'' Variations, which is of interest on several counts, to Elgar lovers, organists and collectors of musical curiosities. But it's really about an older, parallel CD, Lionel Rogg's organ version of Bruckner's Eighth Symphony, which is flat-out great.

Bruno, a professor at Stevens Institute of Technology, and one ferry operator, New York Waterway. The company has given his laboratory research grants; it does not employ him as a consultant.

title: Pomp, Circumstance, Checkbook
description: WRITING the last fat check for a child's final semester of college should bring a sigh of relief to most parents. But the savvy billpayers among them know something that colleges do not disclose in their catalogs: Four years of private higher education can cost way more than room, board, tuition and books.

title: D.Y.F.S. SPLIT ENDORSED
description: Governor McGreevey endorsed a set of changes last week for the embattled Division of Youth and Family Services, including removing the unit that investigates charges of child abuse and neglect in its own foster homes and other institutions and transferring that duty to a new office. He also announced a new 17-member panel that will evaluate changes and suggest other ways to improve the division. Days later, a University of Maryland study cited a ''routine failure'' by the investigations unit to handle abuse and neglect cases adequately. ''No assurances can be given,'' the researchers said, that any child in New Jersey's foster care system is safe. Richard Lezin Jones

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUBY, , PAUL T.
description: LAUBY--Paul T. The trustees and staff of the United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia are deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Paul T. Lauby, who served as its general secretary from 1970 to 1989. Prior to his leadership of the United Board, Dr. Lauby spent 16 years as a missionary educator at Silliman University in the Philippines, serving on the faculty and as dean of the Divinity School, and as the university's vice president for academic affairs. The mission and work of the United Board continues to be influenced by the legacy of his vision, leadership, and commitment, and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Timothy Light, Chair Richard J. Wood, President >>AD#

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IN the springtime spiders come out, and apparently not just in the basement. Among the creature features on television this week are ''Spiders'' and ''Arachnid,'' on SciFi, and ''Eight-Legged Freaks,'' on Cinemax. But the flick that got the mix of horror and humor just right is ARACHNOPHOBIA (1990), in which an ultrapoisonous tropical spider hitches a ride to the United States in a coffin and ends up in Jeff Daniels's backyard. Humor is used in deft dribs and drabs, as well as in one large dollop in the person of John Goodman, who is over-the-top hilarious as the local exterminator. But this is no comic horror parody. The film is genuinely scary, thanks to exquisitely creepy pacing -- Wednesday at 6 p.m. on HBO.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STABER, , ALEX

title: Elevated
description: 'I like Indy,'' Tamika Catchings says, pointing over her steering wheel at the 284-foot-tall State Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument as we circle a roundabout in downtown Indianapolis. Catchings and I are driving around in her Jeep Cherokee, checking out the highlights of her adopted hometown. The tour began about an hour earlier with a visit to her tidy new three-bedroom house in a subdivision north of town, which she shares with her sister, Tauja, and which on this evening is jammed with friends who have driven up from Knoxville to see the Tennessee Lady Vols take on Notre Dame in a big N.C.A.A. women's basketball game the next day at the Conseco Fieldhouse.

This had something to do with FM radio, which was no longer underground but widespread, successful and as eager as Top 40 stations had been in their heyday to promote the next new thing, which Led Zeppelin represented; and this also had something to do with the new dashboard-mounted, 8-track tape deck, for which Led Zeppelin's music was perfectly suited for local broadcast: a) pull Camaro or Firebird into Burger King parking lot; b) turn ignition so just the battery is on; c) roll down windows, whatever the weather; d) engage cassette at full volume; e) impress friends, freak out stray grown-ups.

title: KIKI & HERB: COUP DE THTRE
description: HIGH heels swiveling and bugle beads flashing, Kiki, of the downtown performers Kiki & Herb, is in full frontal mode right now at the Cherry Lane Theater. In the most recent edition of their lounge act, which defies comparison with any other, Justin Bond (Kiki) and Kenny Mellman (Herb) are telling it like it was. Especially Mr. Bond, who wrote the book for the show, ''Kiki & Herb: Coup de Thtre,'' directed by Scott Elliott, and who channels the 60-plus, whiskey-lapping Kiki. Mr. Mellman, who did the musical arrangements, is at the piano, though he's not exactly playing backup; he's more like a backstop for Kiki, whose confessional monologues are the ties that bind this show, and its songs by Styx, Radiohead, Eminem, Gil Scott-Heron and many others, to earth. Here are three selections from the early part of the evening, when the large bow in Kiki's hair is still crisp and the bottle under Herb's piano stool is as yet unopened.

title: 'The Last Good Season'
description: The first time Billy Kleinsasser saw Walter O'Malley was in November of 1955, at Princeton, when O'Malley had come looking for a new ballpark. Billy Kleinsasser was twenty-six years old, a graduate student in architecture, and that fall he enrolled in a graduate seminar taught by the great architect, R. Buckminster Fuller. Fuller had devised the geodesic dome, the great igloo that arched across the sky without benefit of intrusive struts and beams. Domes were the subject of the semester, specifically, the feasibility of creating a dome of the grandest scale, one that would, if done correctly, fit over a baseball stadium. This dome, however, was not Buckminster Fuller's idea. It was Walter O'Malley who had suggested to him just this sort of stadium for his Dodgers, in Brooklyn. Fuller, intrigued, enlisted his students who set about building a model for O'Malley. They worked through the fall and by Thanksgiving it was ready.

title: 'The Teammates'
description: Ted was dying, and the idea for the final trip, driving down to Florida to see him one last time, was Dominic's. It was in early October 2001, and Dominic was not eager to get aboard a plane and fly to Florida so soon after the September 11 terrorist attack, and his wife, Emily, most decidedly did not like the idea of him driving there all by himself. "I just don't want you driving to Florida alone," she told him. "It's much too far." They had been having dinner at a restaurant in Marion, Massachusetts, with their friend Dick Flavin, a local television personality and humorist. Flavin's boyhood hero, a mere 55 years earlier, had been this same Dominic DiMaggio, then the centerfielder for the Red Sox. Half to herself Emily had added, "Can you imagine? An eighty-four-year-old man driving all the way to Florida by himself." It was said in a way that precluded any argument. "How about this?" Flavin suggested to Dom. "I'll go with you and share the driving." Dominic jumped at the offer and immediately signed on. That gained Emily DiMaggio's approval, something not lightly done. "I know what else, I'll call John," Dominic added, "and see if he'll come with us" John was Johnny Pesky, his and Ted's teammate for all those years, for whom trips to Florida were significantly harder to make.

title: New Washington Consensus
description: Earlier this year, the Bush administration requested $1.3 billion, or a first installment, for the ''Millennium Challenge Account,'' the president's plan to increase foreign aid to unprecedented levels. When combined with his pledges of greater international financing for the fight against AIDS and more loans for developing countries, total foreign aid would spike fully 75 percent, well above Clinton administration levels. But certain academics who have long advocated improving the effectiveness of American largess abroad say that wealthy nations must refine the rules of giving. Specifically, they call for reforming the ''Washington Consensus,'' which tethers development money to ''conditionalities'' that include market deregulation, privatization of state-owned enterprises and trade liberalization by recipient nations. Otherwise, critics say, aid will be marginally effective, at best.

title: Dying Wish
description: I almost always agree with Randy Cohen. This time, however, he's wrong (The Ethicist, May 11). He writes that a hospice should not honor the dying request of an African-American patient for an African-American caregiver on the basis of the request alone, noting further that similar requests (say, by Strom Thurmond, for a white caregiver), would be wrong. While I despise all racism, I believe context almost always matters. A dying patient is in the most vulnerable (and final) state of human existence. Cohen fails to give appropriate weight to the extreme vulnerability of the patient in balancing her interests with that of the Latino caregiver to be assigned. The caregiver can and will be assigned to many other patients. The dying patient will have only this last person to provide comfort. In this case, the dying patient wins out.

title: The Black Panthers' Beauty Moment
description: FOR certain Americans, the Black Panthers, one the most potent revolutionary groups of the late 1960's, were very over by 1970. That was the year Tom Wolfe's ''Radical Chic & Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers'' appeared. His account of media-savvy young African-Americans wearing berets and shades and hustling a scam, and of rich white types (Leonard Bernstein, Carter Burden) tripping all over themselves in support, was the Panther story people had been waiting for: a Rowan and Martin ''Laugh-In'' skit. A spoof, a circus, a farce. Mortified, the haute bourgeois Left turned off its largesse. The Panthers dropped in status from superstars to superfluous. ''Delicious,'' purred The Wall Street Journal of Mr. Wolfe's caustic little neo-conservative classic.

title: Reviewing the Intelligence on Iraq

The failure so far to find any weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, the prime justification for an immediate invasion, or definitive links between Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda has raised serious questions about the quality of American intelligence and even dark hints that the data may have been manipulated to support a pre-emptive war. These are critical issues that require thorough review not only by the C.I.A. but also by high-level oversight bodies in the administration and Congress.

title: Anger Mounts in Algeria As Quake Death Toll Rises

title: Israeli Premier Defends Approval of Plan for Palestinian State
description: JERUSALEM, May 26  In the face of withering criticism from his own right-wing party, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon staunchly defended his support for the latest Mideast peace effort today, declaring that "ruling three and a half million Palestinians cannot go on indefinitely."

title: The Braves Show Seo It's All in the Wrist
description: Jae Weong Seo, the Mets' rookie starting pitcher, reached into an equipment bag stuffed with T-shirts and gloves, searching for the evidence. One of the few overachievers on the Mets this season, he had just discovered the extent of the Mets' rivalry with the Braves.

title: Giants of Iraqi History Linger In Pieces of Plaster and Bronze
description: Saddam Hussein lies ruined, face down, in the dust of a warehouse in a northern corner of town. Pigeons shuttle through the rafters above and speckle him with droppings. Looters drop by to pilfer whatever scraps of metal still wink of profit.

title: A Magazine Goes Online, And Tells of 'Lonely Hearts'
description: One of the world's great bridge magazines has disappeared into cyberspace. Bridge Today, founded in 1988 by Matthew and Pamela Granovetter, has ceased to be a print publication. Instead of publishing it six times a year on paper, the couple will offer 12 monthly online issues of Bridge Today E-Magazine, downloadable from the Internet, for $33 a year, which was the cost of the magazine. Details are available at bridgetoday.com.

title: British Airways Considers Options After Rivals Talk
description: Senior British Airways executives are expected to meet on Tuesday to discuss business options in the wake of talks between two of its largest competitors.

title: Washington Talk; A Spectrum of Color-Coded Choices for the White House's E.P.A. Nominee
description: ''And Christie Todd Whitman, who's head of the E.P.A., has announced she's resigning next month. She's stepping down. President Bush was shocked. He didn't know he had an Environmental Protection Agency.'' -- Jay Leno, May 21.

title: Democrats Seek a Stronger Focus, and Money
description: Democrats from the West came here in mid-May to share political hopes and fears and to reassure one another that despite President Bush's popularity, their party has a future.

title: Corrections

The co-founder was Lawrence Langner, not Langer. Ms. Steinbeck was a replacement assistant stage manager, not stage manager.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Tuesday with an article about Michael Mercer, who was cleared by DNA evidence after spending 12 years in jail for a rape conviction, carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The picture, showing Mr. Mercer with a bag over his right shoulder, was by Frances Roberts for The New York Times. (In earlier editions, a picture of Mr. Mercer holding the bag in his left hand was by Michael Nagle for The Times.)

description: While there may be no atheists in foxholes, it seems there are at least some agnostics in firefighting trenches.

description: The Nets, dizzy in their own fantasy last season, raced to their first N.B.A. finals with enough time only to congratulate themselves before the Los Angeles Lakers stomped them four games later into a footnote of basketball history.

title: Workers March Through Paris to Protest Pension Reform
description: Hundreds of thousands of French workers, teachers and students took to the streets today in a demonstration intended to step up pressure on the government here amid a wave of strikes over pensions and other issues.

title: BMW, Shielded This Year, Sees '04 Currency Risk
description: BMW said over the weekend that the rise of the euro against the dollar might begin to hurt earnings next year, when the company, a leading maker of luxury cars, is no longer fully hedged against currency fluctuations.

title: All of New York's a Stage for the G.O.P. Convention
description: Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty are being considered for possible events or backdrops to festivities. There is also talk of forgoing elaborate stages in favor of something more down to earth at the convention hall, Madison Square Garden.

title: Security Is Tightened for Yale Graduation After Law School Blast
description: More than 20,000 visitors are expected for commencement ceremonies today at Yale University, where they will be greeted by bomb-sniffing dogs and other security measures days after a bomb exploded at the law school.

title: Hunt for Etiquette Among Unwired
description: About 200 top telecommunications executives and analysts met last week in Dana Point, Calif., at the Vortex Conference, so named to reflect the supposed convergence of communications technologies. In the future, organizers may want to rename it the Anarchists Conference.

description: PARIS  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED June 4, 2003

title: Sprint's New Boss Is Handcuffed By His Past Job
description: Gary D. Forsee's office, while ornately appointed, still has few personal touches. Two months after he began his job as chief executive of the troubled telecommunications company Sprint, Mr. Forsee's bookshelf is mostly empty, except for a photograph of his wife and daughters. He is still awaiting the arrival of belongings and work files from Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, , SANDRA
description: GOLDBERG -- Sandra. Of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of North Woodmere, NY, passed away on May 25, 2003, at age 67. She is survived by her loving husband Arny; children Howard and Cindy, Brian and Brenna, Michael and Jill; grandchildren Gregory, Alex, Remy, Jacob, Melissa, Alison and Lindsey; sister and brother-in-law Florence and Stuart Bednoff, sister and brother-in-law Arlene and Bob Hunter, brother and sister-in-law Larry and Petra Lambert, sister-in-law and brother-in-law Rita and Stanley Yagoda; and mother-inlaw Rose Goldberg. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, on Tuesday, May 27, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the local chapter of the American Cancer Society. >>AD#

title: Sports of The Times; Kidd's Injury Scare Reveals Fragility of Nets' Success
description: THE Nets rumbled through a regular season that was up and down but free of much drama or any nightmares. The franchise's fortunes nearly changed Saturday night when the Nets swept their second straight playoff series, this time closing out Detroit.

title: IRAQIS FRUSTRATED BY SHIFT FAVORING U.S.-BRITISH RULE
description: The sudden shift in postwar strategy in favor of an American and British occupation authority has visibly deflated the Iraqi political scene, which earlier this month was bustling with grass-roots politicking and high expectations for an all-Iraqi provisional government.

title: Sharon, Trusting Bush
description: In the midst of yesterday's stormy six-hour meeting of Israel's cabinet, assembled to reluctantly affirm or angrily reject Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's decision to accede to White House pressure to sign on to a lopsided ''road map,'' a beeper went off in the pocket of an aide.

title: Pepper LaBeija, Queen of Harlem Drag Balls, Is Dead at 53
description: The performer who used the stage name Pepper LaBeija as a glamorous queen of the Harlem drag balls immortalized in the 1991 documentary ''Paris Is Burning'' died on May 14 at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She, as she preferred to be called, was 53.

title: Some Firehouses Go Quietly, Some With Rage
description: At Engine Company 204 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the police used two vans to cart away 12 protesters who had invaded the firehouse to keep it alive. At Engine Company 212 in Williamsburg, protesters rushed in and jammed pieces of lumber to prop open the door. One man chained himself to the bumper of the fire truck, and others sat down in front of it. Eight people were arrested.

title: W.H.O. Restores Toronto to SARS List After Surge in Cases
description: TORONTO, May 26 — The World Health Organization today reinstated Toronto to its list of places where severe acute respiratory syndrome is spreading, after an announcement that there is a fresh outbreak of the disease.

title: Goalie Gives Virginia Measure of Confidence
description: Just as a World Series can be decided by one hot pitcher, the N.C.A.A. Division I men's lacrosse final Monday can be won or lost by one hot goalie. Johns Hopkins is seeded No. 1, but second-seeded Virginia has the hot goalie in Tillman Johnson.

title: Stephanopoulos Is Slow To Win Sunday Viewers
description: George Stephanopoulos last week completed his first regular season as the sole host of ABC's public affairs program ''This Week,'' and the early returns on the Sunday morning popularity contest are not particularly encouraging for the network.

title: A War Without End
description: Soon thousands of American soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines will rotate back home to their families from the surreal experience of war. Many will barely be out of their teens, most in their early 20's; but they will all be changed forever.

title: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: From PlayStation to Supercomputer for $50,000
description: As perhaps the clearest evidence yet of the computing power of sophisticated but inexpensive video-game consoles, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign has assembled a supercomputer from an army of Sony PlayStation 2's.

title: Times Only a Little Tough in Fairfield County
description: Cities around Connecticut are holding their breath as they wait nervously to find out how much the state's severe budget crunch will cost them. But here inside the gilded enclaves of Fairfield County, mayors and first selectmen are putting the finishing touches on spending plans that are only mildly different from years past. They never got much help from the state because of their affluent citizenry and super-size grand lists of taxable property, so now they are experiencing less pain than other cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITT, , SUSAN

title: Old Hickory, Hang On To Your Noggin
description: Isn't it a little weird that the United States government's campaign this month announcing the fall introduction of its new, colorful, counterfeit-resistant $20 bill -- a bill with faint peach, turquoise and gold tones -- is called ''The New Color of Money''? Wasn't ''The Color of Money'' a movie about a pool hustler named Fast Eddie Felson?

title: The Patience of Memorial Day
description: At one time -- long ago, it seems -- Memorial Day could almost slip past without notice. But not in recent years. The memorial observances we make are too fresh, drawn from too sudden a memory to have lost any of their solemnity.

title: Home Is Not So Sweet For Yankees Anymore
description: The Yankees hit a new low yesterday. From Ruth to Rizzuto, Mantle to Mattingly, Pipgras to Pepitone, it has never been this bad in the Bronx. For the first time in club history, the Yankees have lost 11 of 12 games at Yankee Stadium.

title: Wales Is Forced to Experiment
description: The roster that Wales Manager MARK HUGHES took to Spartan Stadium in San Jose, Calif., for a 2-0 friendly loss against the United States last night bore little resemblance to the Welsh team that leads Group 9 in qualifying for the 2004 European championships and is unbeaten in its last 10 games over 20 months. It could generously be called an experimental squad. After upsetting Italy, 2-1, and beating Finland and Azerbaijan twice, Wales is not scheduled to play another qualifier until an away game Aug. 20 against Serbia and Montenegro. RYAN GIGGS (Manchester United), ROBBIE SAVAGE (Birmingham City) and KIT SYMONS (Crystal Palace) begged off are on paternity leave. JOHN HARTSON (Glasgow Celtic) and CRAIG BELLAMY (Newcastle United) are injured. All five had been named to Hughess preliminary 29-man squad. The captain, GARY SPEED (Newcastle United), made the trip, but is still recovering from a hernia operation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CAPELLUTO, , VICTOR
description: CAPELLUTO--Victor. Dad, one year has passed since you left us, but not a day goes by that I don't think of you and miss you terribly. All my love, Bettina >>AD#

title: STAMBERGER WINS AMATEUR TITLE
description: Mike Stamberger, reinstated as an amateur after playing on the PGA Nike Tour, shot 70-71 and finished with a four-under 54-hole total of 212 to win the New York City Amateur Championship at LaTourette Golf Club on Staten Island.

title: 2 Sikhs on Trial in Canada in '85 Jet Blast
description: The Irish air-traffic controller, on the stand 18 years after Air India Flight 182 exploded and plunged into the North Atlantic, became teary-eyed on Tuesday as he recalled how the aircraft suddenly vanished from his radar screen.

title: A Playwright Casts Himself to Tell His Angry Story
description: Any suspicion that the playwright August Wilson is mellowing disappears a few minutes into his new one-man show here when he removes his jacket to reveal a T-shirt that proclaims, ''I am supposed to be white.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The moment has arrived to divide this tract of land between us and the Palestinians.''

title: New Economy; A Unix company hopes a Microsoft deal will strengthen its legal case against Linux.
description: JUST when it seemed like nothing was going the company's way, the SCO Group received a piece of good news last week. Microsoft announced it would license a Unix patent from SCO along with the source code. To SCO -- which recently changed its name from Caldera Systems -- this would mean the Linux software industry could see that SCO's Unix intellectual property claims were legitimate and enforceable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHAN, , JILL HARRIET

title: Silent 30 Years, A Jazzman Resurfaces; Left New York in '68, Plays Again Tonight
description: In avant-garde jazz circles in the mid-1960's, Henry Grimes was one of the most respected bassists working. Trained at Juilliard, he had already played with Anita O'Day, Charles Mingus, Thelonious Monk, Gerry Mulligan, Miles Davis, John Coltrane and Sonny Rollins when he was in his 20's.

title: Pay-to-Play Reform Effort Is Nearer to Death by Politics
description: On its surface, New Jersey's beleaguered political system appears ripe for stricter campaign finance laws.

description: Empire Maker will not start in today's Jersey Derby at Monmouth Park after all.

title: Iraq Will Control Its Oil, Iraqi Official Asserts
description: Three days after the United Nations gave the United States and Britain broad authority to govern Iraq, the interim head of the Iraqi Oil Ministry stated today in some of his strongest terms yet that Iraqis controlled the country's oil riches and would continue to do so in the future.

title: Roosevelt Hotel, Near Grand Central, Goes on the Market

title: 4 Leading Japanese Banks Report $31 Billion in Losses
description: TOKYO, May 26  Japan's four largest banks today reported a combined loss of 3.6 trillion yen, or about $31 billion, for the last fiscal year, a 28 percent increase, because of declining stock prices and stricter accounting methods that unearthed more bad loans.

title: ISRAEL APPROVES BUSH'S ROAD MAP TO NEW PALESTINE
description: The Israeli government for the first time officially accepted a Palestinian claim to eventual statehood today, as Prime Minister Ariel Sharon persuaded his right-wing government to endorse the steps of a new American-backed peace plan, known as the road map.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about the legalizing of Sunday liquor sales in some states misstated the racial makeup of Georgetown, Del., where one businessman, J. R. Patel, said he had to open his store on Sundays to stay competitive. It is about 21 percent black, not largely black.

title: Two Ways to Boost Democracy
description: The surprising speed with which New York's legislators finished their work on the budget leaves about three weeks until the end of this year's session. That opening gives Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature a chance to improve both their reputations as public servants and the way the state government works. They should act quickly to improve campaign finance laws and to make elections more competitive by establishing a nonpartisan commission to draw election district lines.

description: Hlio Castroneves, the Spider-Man of auto racing, scaled the giant fence at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway for the third straight year today. But this ascent was different. Another driver had beaten Castroneves, and invited him to join the celebration.

title: Argentina's Chief Is Sworn In and Comes Out Fighting
description: Promising to ''reconstruct our identity as a people and a nation'' after the worst economic crisis in Argentina's history, Nstor Kirchner was sworn in as president today. He immediately issued strong challenges to foreign creditors, the armed forces and the political establishment, which has opposed his unexpected rise to power.

title: 300-Victory Club Becomes Tougher to Join
description: The list includes Tommy John, Bert Blyleven, Robin Roberts, Ferguson Jenkins, Jim Kaat, Red Ruffing, Jim Palmer, Bob Feller, Jack Morris, Carl Hubbell, Bob Gibson, Juan Marichal, Herb Pennock, Whitey Ford, Jim Bunning, Catfish Hunter, Don Drysdale, Sandy Koufax and Dizzy Dean. title: John Haigney, 91, Ex-Chief of Rheingold
description: John E. Haigney, the former chief executive and president of the Rheingold Corporation, died on May 15 at Atria Manresa in Annapolis, Md. He was 91.

title: In 13 States, a United Push To Limit Fees of Lawyers
description: Lawyers in 13 states have begun a coordinated campaign to limit the fees their colleagues collect in some lawsuits. They say it is unethical for plaintiffs' lawyers to routinely pocket one-third or more of the money they win for clients, no matter how long or hard they work on a case.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pilot Rescued After Plane Crashes In Sound
description: A small aircraft headed to White Plains from Orlando, Fla., crashed into Long Island Sound yesterday after apparently running out of fuel. The pilot, who was alone in the aircraft, was rescued by the Coast Guard and emergency medical personnel and taken to a hospital in Port Jefferson. James Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said the pilot, whose name was not disclosed, had called to report that the aircraft was running low on fuel. Mr. Peters said the pilot was directed to land at the Sikorsky Memorial Airport, near Bridgeport, Conn. But the plane crashed into the water about eight miles from Bridgeport. Emergency medical officials in Port Jefferson said the pilot of the five-passenger Cessna was in good condition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ERWIN, , ROBERT DEAN

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: BNP Selling Stake In Bank
description: BNP Paribas, France's largest bank, will sell its stake in Crdit Lyonnais to a rival, Crdit Agricole, as part of the 16 billion euro ($19 billion) offer that closed yesterday. ''BNP Paribas has decided to tender all the Crdit Lyonnais shares it owns to the public cash offer filed by the Crdit Agricole group,'' a spokeswoman, Michele Sicard, said. The bank expects a profit of ''slightly less than 100 million euros,'' on the holding, she said. At the end of last year, BNP Paribas and Crdit Agricole, France's No. 2 bank, were vying for control of Crdit Lyonnais. BNP spent about 3 billion euros to build up a 16.3 percent stake. Crdit Agricole responded by raising its stake to 17.8 percent, and in December agreed to a friendly takeover with Crdit Lyonnais.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Party Lagging In Rome Race
description: Results in the first local elections since Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi came to power nearly two years ago were mixed, with initial tallies showing his conservative government losing the race for president of the Province of Rome to the center-left opposition. But officials said government parties made up ground elsewhere. About 12 million Italians across the country were eligible to vote yesterday and Sunday for candidates in 12 provinces and 508 cities. Some political analysts framed the elections as a report card for Mr. Berlusconi, whose recent political and legal difficulties have included testifying at his own corruption trial. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOK, , MURIEL MULLER
description: COOK -- Muriel Muller. A Stamford resident, died Tuesday, May 20 at the Hospice Residence in Stamford. She was 83. She died of natural causes, according to her family. Born December 29, 1919 in Woodhaven, N.Y., she was the daughter of the late Adam Charles and Margaret Dircks Muller. Mrs. Cook graduated from Katherine Gibbs College. She worked for General American Investors, Inc., a closed end investment company traded on the New York Stock Exchange for twenty-two years. She retired as the Assistant Corporate Secretary and Treasurer of the Company in 1989. Mrs. Cook was a world traveler, visiting more than forty-six countries with her husband, daughter and friends. She was a avid gardener and enjoyed playing golf. Before moving to Stamford in November, 2002, she was a resident of New Hyde Park, N.Y. for fifty-four years. She was predeceased by her husband Godfrey V. (Buddy) Cook, Jr. She is survived by her only daughter, Patricia M. (Tricia) Cook of Stamford, a brother Martin H. Burial will follow in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, N.Y. description: Iraqi officials here say that they asked American military leaders as early as a month ago to help protect major archaeological sites from looters, but that for the most part, their pleas were ignored and artwork and relics from ancient Babylon are still being stolen from many locations.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Global Air Traffic Plunged in April

title: The Pentagon Shuffle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIRKSER, , ANN
description: FIRKSER--Ann. Devoted wife of the late Ben Firkser. Loving stepmother of Diane Belfer, Gladys Kanner and the late Janet Charlse Leeds. She died peacefully. Private graveside services. >>AD#

title: Sports of The Times; Forget Parties, The Yankees Need to Win
description: THROW away the fireworks, the rolled-up red carpet, the 300 doves, whatever extravagant festivities the Yankees had planned for Roger Clemens yesterday.

title: Immigrant Boon
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Students Rebel At a Harsh Academy
description: In a torrent of rage, teenagers at the troubled Academy at Dundee Ranch in Costa Rica rose up over the weekend and overthrew their masters, walking off the ranch that was set up 19 months ago as a behavior modification program for troubled youths. Most of the children are going home, many to an uncertain future.

title: Editorial Observer; For Partisan Gain, Republicans Decide Rules Were Meant to Be Broken
description: There was a lot not to like about the new Congressional district lines Republicans tried to push through in Texas this month, the ones that made Democratic legislators flee to Oklahoma to prevent a vote. Democratic Austin was sliced into four parts and parceled out to nearby Republican districts. A community on the Mexican border and one 300 miles away were painstakingly joined together and declared to be a single Congressional district. But the real problem was that Republicans were redrawing lines that had just been adopted in 2001, defying the rule that redistricting occurs only once a decade, after the census.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Led Zeppelin: Passion to Bloat
description: When it comes to the giants of classic rock, the catalogs of most have been exhausted. The last thing a Jimi Hendrix listener needs is another live recording of his Isle of Wight or Monterey performances. And Cream, a band that existed for only about two years, has been packaged into dozens of different studio, live and greatest-hits albums. The notable exception to this has been the Led Zeppelin discography. For a group known as one of the most formidable (and biggest money-making) arena-rock acts of the 70's, Led Zeppelin has oddly never put out a decent live album. The closest approximation was the soundtrack to ''The Song Remains the Same'' film, which always felt more obligatory than revelatory, largely because the band's power is dimmed by sheer end-of-tour exhaustion.

title: Central Bank Expected to Cut Interest Rate In Euro Zone
description: It has become a consuming question for economists and corporate executives across Europe, discussed and disputed with the fervor of a theological debate: When will the European Central Bank cut interest rates?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Korea: Talks On Commercial Ties
description: Negotiators for the two Koreas have agreed on a new timetable for commercial ties, with implications for South Korea's goal of becoming an economic hub for Northeast Asia. In talks in Pyongyang, negotiators set June 6 as the date for linking a newly built rail line across the demilitarized zone. The line will connect South Korea to the North Korean city of Kaesong, several miles north of the truce village of Panmunjom, and eventually to China and Russia. Negotiators also agreed on beginning construction next month on an industrial complex at Kaesong, estimated to cost more than $20 billion. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Boom Times in the City's Housing Courts
description: Since its inception 30 years ago, New York City's housing court has sometimes resembled a chaotic netherworld worthy of Dickens. There some of the city's poorest tenants, or the most litigious, quarrel eternally with their landlords in courtrooms so wretched that even judges have described them as black holes of Calcutta.

title: Mayor's Handling of Harlem Death Is Praised
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's handling of the aftermath of a police raid in Harlem that left an innocent 57-year-old woman dead drew effusive praise yesterday from one of the city's most prominent black leaders.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the declining number of SARS cases in China referred incorrectly to Tianjin, which still had more than 100. It is a city, not a province.

title: U.S. REPORT FAULTS EFFORTS TO TRACK WATER POLLUTION
description: The computer system used by the Environmental Protection Agency to track and control water pollution is obsolete, full of faulty data and does not take into account thousands of significant pollution sources, according to a new government report.

title: Witnesses in Killing by Police Want to Talk Only to an 'Objective Prosecutor,' Sharpton Says
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that he had spoken to people who were present in a Chelsea warehouse at the time of the fatal police shooting of Ousmane Zongo last week, but Mr. Sharpton said the witnesses wanted to speak only to an ''objective prosecutor.''

title: Red Sox Stay a Step Ahead Of History
description: The Boston Red Sox have an ignominious 103-year history, filled with shocking finishes, miserable collapses, endless misfortune and perpetual heartache. The Red Sox are the proud team that usually ends up playing out the same depressing script that has haunted them for decades. History lessons are not happy ones for the Red Sox because history has hexed them.

title: Canada's Problem -- and America's
description: The discovery of a case of mad cow disease in Canada underlines the need for American officials to exercise much greater vigilance to prevent the emergence of this fatal brain-wasting disease in the United States. Live cattle, beef products and animal feed move relatively freely between the United States and Canada; last year the United States imported one billion pounds of beef from Canada. Unfortunately, the federal government's defenses are full of gaps.

title: Federer Is a Day 1 Casualty, but Agassi Breezes
description: The dimensions of the court do not change in a Grand Slam tournament, but it must have felt that way to Roger Federer at times today.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: BOYFRIEND CHARGED WITH ASSAULT A 31-year-old Manhattan man was charged with assault early yesterday for pushing his girlfriend out the window of the fourth-floor apartment they shared near Union Square Park, the authorities said. The woman, Sheila Cordell, 32, was declared brain dead yesterday about 12:45 p.m. as a result of the injuries she received in the episode early Sunday at 9 East 17th Street and was being kept alive on a respirator at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital, the police said. The charges against her boyfriend, Edgar Ortega, are expected to be upgraded to manslaughter when she is taken off the respirator, the police said.    William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: With SARS, Antivirus Arms Race Heats Up
description: Viruses and bacteria are often lumped together as germs. But when it comes to drugs to treat the illnesses they cause, the microbes are worlds apart.

title: Baghdad Family Mourns Lost Son, Victim of Lawlessness
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq  On the afternoon of May 6, a stranger came to the home of Abdul al-Sattar Yusef. He asked Mr. Yusef to go to the hospital with him where, he said, Mr. Yusef's son, Ahmed al-Sattar, was being treated for a slight shoulder injury.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Supermarket Sales Fall
description: Argentina's supermarket sales volume fell in April from a year earlier, the Buenos Aires-based National Statistics Institute reported. The sales brought in 1.3 billion pesos ($460 million) in April, compared with 1.1 million pesos in April 2002 as inflation pushed prices higher.

title: U.S. Youths Rebel at Harsh School in Costa Rica and Many Head for Home
description: A torrent of teenage rage, hard and fast as the tropical rain on this Pacific coast, washed away the Academy at Dundee Ranch this weekend.

title: Despite Need for H.I.V. Vaccines, Fear Mutes Call for Volunteers
description: Several years ago, Mark Moreau was thumbing through HX, a New York City magazine geared toward gay men, and the wording of an advertisement caught his eye.

title: Q & A
description: Arsenic in the Garden

title: An Instinct For Decisive Moments; A Show and a Foundation Honor Cartier-Bresson
description: Henri Cartier-Bresson has always shunned the limelight, preferring his remarkable photographic record of the mid-20th century to speak for him. He has never liked giving interviews, agreeing at most to ''a conversation.'' He long resisted being photographed, believing it stripped him of the anonymity essential to his work. In the mid-1970's he even abandoned photography as a profession to devote himself to his first love, drawing.

title: Scott, Planning Ahead, Sees Spurs-Nets Finals
description: For a moment, Byron Scott tried his best to remain politically correct, to point out that the Dallas Mavericks were not done in the Western Conference finals. But about a moment was all it took for Scott to admit that his mind was already racing with thoughts of Tim Duncan and the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Toronto Again Listed as City With Spreading SARS Cases
description: The World Health Organization restored Toronto today to its list of places where severe acute respiratory syndrome is spreading, after the announcement of a fresh outbreak of the disease here.

title: Canada Moves to Ease Marijuana Possession Law
description: TORONTO, May 27  The Canadian government introduced legislation today to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana but set stricter penalties for those apprehended for trafficking the drug.

title: Vodafone Is Close to Japan Telecom Deal
description: Vodafone Group of Britain is in the final stages of a deal to sell the land-line division of Japan Telecom Holdings to Ripplewood Holdings, an American investment fund.

title: DNA of Blacks To Be Gathered To Fight Illness
description: Saying black people are in danger of being left behind at the newest frontier of medical research, Howard University plans to create the nation's largest repository of DNA from African-Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOVER, , BETTY ALPERT
description: KOVER--Betty Alpert. 85, of the Bronx, died Sunday, May 25th. She will be missed by Elly and Terry, Andy and Susan, and her three loving grandchildren, Molly, Hillary and David. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, May 27th, 2003, 10:45AM, at Plaza Funeral Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: Gold Hill Journal; Dragging a Town Forward to the Past
description: When Darius Hedrick set out to restore this faded 19th-century mining village about a decade ago, he did not get a lot of encouragement.

title: Rumsfeld Suggests Iraq Might Have Destroyed Illicit Arms
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld suggested publicly for the first time today that Iraq might have destroyed its suspected chemical and biological weapons before the start of the Iraq war.

title: Weather Worries, Not Fear, Mark Yale Commencement
description: Just five days ago, a bomb rocked Yale Law School. But as rain poured down during the university's commencement today, graduates and their families were more worried about being poked by umbrellas than about being attacked.

title: European Nations to Buy Airbus Planes in $24 Billion Deal
description: PARIS, May 27 — Launching one of Europe's most ambitious military projects after decades of delay, seven European countries agreed today to acquire 180 transport planes from Airbus in a deal worth the equivalent of $24 billion.

title: Katmandu Journal; Young and Old, and Speedy, They Are All Doing Everest
description: It's getting a little crowded at the top of the world.

title: A Journey to Bridge Math and the Cosmos
description: Dr. Arlie O. Petters grew up in a quiet corner of Belize, far from the intellectual centers of mathematics and physics and unaware of many of his career possibilities.

title: Death Throes of a Crippler
description: On Oct. 26, 1977, in Somalia, a young man came down with a rash. It was smallpox. But the fellow, who survived, was remarkable, for he had the planet's last case of naturally occurring smallpox. Eleven years after smallpox became the first disease to be wiped off the face of the earth, health ministers from around the world voted to make polio the second. That goal is very close. But the campaign is short of money. Another $275 million is needed to finish the job by 2005 -- a sum that would be repaid manyfold if polio vanished.

title: Sloan Wilson, of 'Man in the Gray Flannel Suit,' Dies at 83
description: Sloan Wilson, the novelist who put ''The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit'' into the American lexicon in 1955, died on Sunday in Virginia. He was 83 and lived in Colonial Beach, Va.

title: Canada Introduces Measure Adjusting Penalties for Marijuana
description: TORONTO, May 27  The Canadian government introduced legislation today to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana but set stricter penalties for trafficking the drug.

title: Nowitzki Needs Time to Heal That the Mavs Don't Have
description: The Dallas Mavericks put an optimistic spin on their playoff predicament today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAPNICK, , DR. SIMON
description: WAPNICK--Dr. Simon. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member, Dr. Simon Wapnick, beloved husband of Isabelle; father of Laura & Richard Leeds, Jan & Scott Zeitlin, and Jonathan; grandfather of Chloe, Jordan, Michael and Joshua; brother of Alec. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President >>AD#

title: Kariya Leads Ducks Out of the Wilderness
description: Why didn't Paul Kariya just fly away from the Anaheim Mighty Ducks? A franchise born as a cute curiosity had become an acute monstrosity. Its home rink -- the half-empty Pond -- was an N.H.L. backwater, far from the sport's mainstream. The team was a mismanaged mess, for sale with no bidders.

description: SARS: Advance and Retreat

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Four Japanese Banks Lost Nearly $31 Billion Last Year

title: Making the Children Healthy and American
description: For more than 20 years, thousands of poor children who tested positive for tuberculosis but were not yet ill were sent to children-only institutions. There, they were fed lots of milk and beef and forced to sleep outdoors even in frigidly cold winters.

title: Group Says Iran Has 2 Undisclosed Nuclear Laboratories
description: An Iranian opposition group said today that it had evidence of two previously undisclosed uranium enrichment facilities west of Tehran -- information that, if proven, might add to the Bush administration's argument that Iran is violating its commitment not to produce nuclear weapons.

title: At a Traumatic Moment, Morocco's King Is Mute
description: Though a direct descendant of the Prophet Muhammad, Mohammed VI is applauded by those around him as a thoroughly modern monarch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANKIN, GOLDEN, , LYN
description: HANKIN-GOLDEN--Lyn. August 2nd, 1957--May 20th, 2003 of complications from anorexia. Daughter of Kathleen and the late Leonard Hankin. Beloved sister of Kim and devoted aunt of Lindsey and Kendall Barrett. A bright and funny person devoted to her family, now finally at peace. >>AD#

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Dalai Lama's Envoys Arrive For Talks
description: For the second time in nine months, two senior representatives of the exiled Dalai Lama have arrived in Beijing for quiet consultations. A visit in September by the envoys, Lodi Gyari and Kelsang Gyaltsen, was the first formal contact between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama in a decade. Tibetan advocates abroad expressed hope that the visit this week could lead to a serious dialogue about autonomy for Tibet, but China continues to accuse the Dalai Lama of trying to split the nation. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Actors Light Up. Do I Have to Breathe It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Training Teachers' Helpers
description: Classroom aides have become a hot topic in New York City since the teachers' union sued Mayor Michael Bloomberg to halt his plan to lay off more than 800 of them for budgetary reasons. The union contended that the aides were crucial to the educational process. But an article this week by The Times's Abby Goodnough showed that the classroom aide initiative was often no more than a jobs program for untrained, often unmotivated workers who lack proper supervision and have few specific duties. While some aides have become beloved and valuable assistants to the teachers, others perform clerical work or actually sit idle.

title: New Commander in Charge of U.S. Forces in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 27  A new commander took charge of the American-led forces in Afghanistan today, promising a continued international commitment to bring peace and prosperity to the nation, but warning that "the job will not be easy."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's appearance at a meeting of ministers from the major industrial countries and Russia misstated an action taken by NATO last week. It agreed to help Poland conduct peacekeeping operations in Iraq. The vote was not on admitting Poland; that occurred in 1999.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column on May 17 about the relationship between two prominent horse racing trainers, Bob Baffert and D. Wayne Lukas, misstated the year Baffert won the Del Mar Futurity stakes race with Silver Charm. It was 1996, not 1997.

title: Comparing Octets, Looking for the Classic
description: Listening to the octet Louis Spohr wrote in 1814, one ponders what makes something ''classic.'' Spohr was, in his day, a celebrated composer and violinist, hailed as an heir to Haydn and Mozart. Last Tuesday, he was accounted the little-known composer in a pairing with Schubert in the last of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's three-part examination of the early Romantic period, each of which contrasted the famous with the (largely) forgotten.

description: WINSOR--Kathleen, author of ''Forever Amber'' published in 1944 and several other novels, died at her home in Manhattan on May 26th, 2003. Ms. Winsor was the widow of Washington lawyer, Paul A. Porter, who died in 1975. No services are planned. >>AD#

title: Biotech Food And the Hungry
description: To the Editor:

title: Top prize reflects clash of French vs. foreign sensibilities : Climax of the Cannes critics wars
description: CANNES:  The Cannes festival, so venerable, so vain, wears ambition on its sleeve love me, love my films. This year, there were few films to love, and, instead, another kind of drama took over at the Palais: friction between old friends and allies. The French and their foreign guests had a war of nerves and clashing sensibilities. The Palme d'Or awarded by Patrice Chereau and his jury to Gus Van Sant for "Elephant," which also won him the best director prize, simply fanned the flames.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSTEN, , BEVYA (NEE BEVERLY ROSEN)
description: ROSTEN--Bevya (nee Beverly Rosen). Daughter of the late Herschel and Ida Rosen, died on May 24, after a long and valiant struggle. Survived by her sister Miriam Rosen. Deeply mourned by all who knew and loved her. Services Tuesday, May 27, at 11 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: AHOLD FRAUD GROWS Months after uncovering accounting fraud at an American subsidiary, the Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said yesterday it found an additional $29 million in accounting errors in other American operations. It will miss a June 30 deadline to finish auditing its books for 2002. Royal Ahold has been struggling to achieve accurate accounts since its announcement in February that U.S. Foodservice had overstated profits. An internal inquiry put the overstatements at $880 million from 2000 to 2002. The company said yesterday that other inquiries had since found the extra $29 million in irregularities, mainly at its Tops markets subsidiary in the United States. The company pledged to have the remaining investigations finished within two weeks, adding that its banks have now agreed to a new deadline of Aug. 15 for the 2002 books.   (AP)

title: High Court Sides With State Workers in Family Care Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  The Supreme Court departed from its recent path on a vital constitutional question today, ruling that Congress had the power to remedy some discrimination against state workers.

title: Bush Honors Newest Graves In Arlington
description: President Bush observed the nation's first Memorial Day since the battle for Baghdad with a remembrance this morning at Arlington National Cemetery, where soldiers who died in Iraq lay in freshly dug graves.

title: Miscellany
description: Conferon, Twinsburg, Ohio, a meeting planning unit of the Riverside Company, acquired ExpoExchange, Frederick, Md., a convention and trade show information management company, from Veronis Suhler Stevenson, which is based in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Turning 40: Even Bands Get Older
description: In rock 'n' roll, there are few things less exciting than a happy ending. Just look at Fleetwood Mac, the Anglo-American conglomerate that will celebrate its 40th birthday in a few years. Members have come and gone, and so have romances, feuds, battles with addiction, even -- most dangerous of all -- solo albums. Compared with the group's long career, a presidential term is merely a passing fad: Fleetwood Mac was there in 1993, to play Bill Clinton into office, and the group was there eight years later, to play him out.

title: AWOL Soldier Was Killed During Robbery, Police Say
description: A 19-year-old man who the police said had been absent without leave from the Army for several months was fatally shot Sunday night during a robbery at a bodega in Harlem, the authorities said.

title: British Investors Bristle at American-Size Pay Packages
description: Shareholders in Britain are wielding new voting rights to register their objections to hefty executive pay packages. And their next target may be an American, William F. Aldinger III, the former chief executive of Household International, who sold the company to the British bank HSBC Group in November for $14.2 billion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Charged With Selling Drugs
description: A New York police officer was arrested and charged with selling drugs at a bar in Brooklyn, police officials said. It was not clear when or where the arrest took place, but the officer, Thomas Coyle, was suspended on Sunday. Officer Coyle joined the Police Department in July 1986, an official said. Officers of the department's Internal Affairs Division began investigating him when they learned that he was moonlighting as a bartender at Cousins Sports Bar on Flatlands Avenue in Brooklyn, the police said. Department regulations prohibit officers from taking jobs at businesses regulated by the State Liquor Authority. Undercover officers twice bought cocaine from Officer Coyle, the police said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Inquiry Into Death of Girl, 7, in Bronx Apartment
description: The police are investigating the death late Sunday of a 7-year-old girl, whose mother told the authorities that she woke up to find the girl unconscious on the bathroom floor of their Bronx apartment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENFIELD, , LOIS F.
description: ROSENFIELD--Lois F. Age 78 of Glencoe, IL, film and theater producer, co-produced the movie, ''Bang the Drum Slowly'' and the plays, ''Barnum'' and ''Singin' in the Rain,'' (New York and London) as well as other productions; wife for 54 years of Maurice, mother of Andrew (Betsy Bergman) and James; grandmother of Zak, Alex, Lannie and Jake; loving and caring friend of many in Chicago, New York and Palm Springs. Memorial services Thursday, 2:30 PM at Am Shalom, 840 Vernon Avenue, Glencoe, IL 60022. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Lambs Farm, 14245 Rockland Road, Libertyville, IL 60045. Info: The Goldman Funeral Group, 847-478-1600. >>AD#

title: Linking Guns and Gun Violence
description: People with guns in their homes are almost twice as likely to be killed by guns as people who do not keep them at home, researchers reported yesterday in The Annals of Emergency Medicine.

title: AOL Founder Is Said to Be Open to a Spinoff
description: Stephen M. Case, mastermind of America Online's record-breaking acquisition of Time Warner, has begun to talk favorably of undoing the deal by spinning off AOL, according to two senior company officials who have spoken with him.

title: Stating The Obvious
description: ''The lunatics are now in charge of the asylum.'' So wrote the normally staid Financial Times, traditionally the voice of solid British business opinion, when surveying last week's tax bill. Indeed, the legislation is doubly absurd: the gimmicks used to make an $800-billion-plus tax cut carry an official price tag of only $320 billion are a joke, yet the cost without the gimmicks is so large that the nation can't possibly afford it while keeping its other promises.

title: 200 in Herd Found Free Of Mad Cow
description: Nearly 200 cows belonging to the same Alberta herd as the one infected with mad cow disease were found to be free of the disease after they were slaughtered and tested over the weekend.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Some circuitous tax changes for those who sell stock short.
description: THERE is an unwelcome surprise for short-term stock traders in the new tax law: They may have to pay full income-tax rates on some dividends they receive.

title: 2 Councilmen Hope to Block Charter Plan
description: Two city councilmen plan to introduce a bill this week that would prevent Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg from using his personal fortune on an advertising campaign asking New Yorkers to abolish party labels and party primaries in city elections.

title: With No Surprise, Chief Leaves Tenet Healthcare
description: In response to intense pressure from investors, Jeffrey C. Barbakow stepped down yesterday as chief executive of Tenet Healthcare , the troubled hospital chain.

title: A Liszt World Premiere Is Presented in Cincinnati
description: Music history protects its sleeping beauties: pieces living briefly, laid to rest by their contemporaries and slumbering ever since. We dig them up with occasional profit and at our own risk.

title: Reported Asian SARS Cases Continue to Fall
description: HONG KONG, May 27  Fewer than two dozen new cases of SARS were reported in Asia today as the disease appeared to recede further in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUADAGNINO, , CARMINE A.
description: GUADAGNINO--Carmine A. On May 23, 2003 at age 51. Beloved husband of Valerie Merone Guadagnino. Loving father of Matthew. Cherished son of Martha and the late Domenic. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 West 71st Street, Wednesday 10AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Browning School, 52 East 62nd Street, NY NY 10021. >>AD#
