description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They told us you have the right to speak, you have the right to speak to your parents, you have the right to leave if you feel you've been mistreated. Kids heard that and they started running for the door. There was elation, cheering and clapping and chaos. People were crying.''

title: SARS Scare Casts Pall on Las Vegas of Siberia
description: Nobody would ever mistake the Las Vegas Casino ''Welcom's You!'' cries a crawl of red lights above the door -- for a Las Vegas casino.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about SARS misstated the name of the Michigan border city where American customs officials temporarily blocked garbage trucks headed from Toronto to a landfill. It is Port Huron, not Fort Huron.

title: Proud Baymen, Scraping Bottom; Lobstermen Are Dredging Clams, and Earning Less
description: Paul Ritter used to be a lobsterman, until the lobsters in the bays around New York Harbor disappeared. Then he equipped his boat for gill netting, making his own nets as his dad had taught him. But overfishing out in the ocean ended that, too.

title: On This Memorial Day, Memories Are Still Raw
description: The hat, an American flag pattern with two fingers jutting up in a peace sign like stubby antennas, is a bit ridiculous, but the message from the man beneath it is serious.

title: A Green Developer, in More Ways Than One
description: NED SULLIVAN, the president of the environmental group Scenic Hudson, is an earnest, intense man who looks most at home in the country, in running sneakers. That's where he was on a recent morning, in a field, getting a tour from an ecologist about expanding a park in the shadow of Storm King Mountain in Orange County, picking a tick off his pants leg.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Defense Department confirmed the death of the following American in Iraq:

title: Pounds Lost on Atkins Diet May Quickly Return
description: The Atkins diet gained a modicum of respectability this month when scientists reported that two clinical trials found the high-fat, high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet did not cause disastrous increases in serum cholesterol and even reduced one or two cardiac risk factors.

title: Amid a Shifting of Colors, An Intersecting of Forms
description: Jelon Vieira has bravely set himself the task of blending traditional and concert dance forms. Everyone is doing it these days. But in Mr. Vieira's new ''Misso,'' presented by his DanceBrazil company on Friday night at the Joyce Theater, the jaggedly percussive capoeira, the Afro-Brazilian martial kickboxing form, is merged with flowing modern dance. Somehow it worked.

title: The Mideast Thicket
description: The phrase ''arc of crisis'' was coined by President Jimmy Carter's national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, after a revolution in Iran and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. It described the religious fervor, instability and strategic and economic importance of the world from South Asia to the Mediterranean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEMPNER, , MONA (NEE SALZMAN)
description: KLEMPNER -- Mona (nee Salzman), of Forest Hills, NY, on May 25, 2003, in her 80th year. Beloved wife of Henry. Loving mother of Leon and his wife Laurie. She also leaves three adored granddaughters, Amy, Lisa and Jodi. Born in Poland, Holocaust survivor, she will be missed by all of her family and friends and will live in our hearts forever. >>AD#

title: The Hog That Saves the Grunts
description: The Air Force is planning to give the A-10 Warthog an ignominious homecoming from the Persian Gulf.

title: Renovation Project Will Close Islamic Galleries at the Met
description: The Islamic galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which hold one of the most comprehensive displays of Islamic material in the world, will close on Monday for four years for expansion and renovation.

title: Rain Battles Tradition, and Mostly Wins
description: Robert Fleming usually arrives at the Orchard Beach picnic area at 7 a.m. on Memorial Day to ensure that he and his family get the grill they have always used, the one next to a big stone poking up out of the grass. He need not have risen so early yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in House & Home on May 8 about the inconsistent and sometimes misleading numbering of floors in New York high-rises misspelled the given name of a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Buildings, who commented on regulations. She is Ilyse Fink, not Elise.

title: 'Leaves of Grass,' Anyone? A Reading Room Returns to Bryant Park
description: In 1935, during the depths of the Depression, the Bryant Park Open-Air Reading Room was established in the backyard of the New York Public Library to engage the minds of the jobless thousands.

title: But Harvey! What Would Mr. Turnblad Say?
description: DICK LATESSA, the Broadway actor who's been around for more than 40 years, was upstairs at Sardi's the other day, in happy tears. Earlier this month he received his first Tony nomination for his role as Wilbur Turnblad in ''Hairspray.'' On Thursday afternoon, among a theatrical crowd, Mr. Latessa's caricature was unveiled at Sardi's.

title: Yet Again, The Lovers Outwit The Elders
description: Whatever the weather outside, sunshine is guaranteed to fill the Metropolitan Opera House when American Ballet Theater performs Frederick Ashton's very funny, very poetic and enchanting masterpiece ''La Fille Mal Garde'' this week.

title: Old Soldiers And Voices Fading Away
description: ON the first Memorial Day after the latest war, remembrances took various forms.

title: U.S. Replaces China As Host of Soccer's Women's World Cup
description: The United States was named yesterday as the substitute host of the 2003 Women's World Cup this fall after the tournament was moved from China because of the SARS epidemic.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about efforts to identify a tick-borne disease in Montana misstated the genus of the bacterium that causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, another tick-related illness common to the region. It is Rickettsia, not Borrelia.

title: Northern Japan Hit by Quake; 78 Are Injured
description: A powerful earthquake struck northern Japan today, injuring at least 78 people, starting fires and damaging buildings throughout the region.

title: Soul of Old Is Breaking Out All Over
description: Documenting the history of soul music once seemed relegated to public-television pledge drives and the odd Sinbad special on HBO. Now it has bubbled into full-time cultural anthropology.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Bus Service To Pakistan To Resume
description: Indian officials announced that they would resume cross-border bus service with Pakistan and release 70 Pakistani fishermen and 60 civilians in Indian custody, the Press Trust of India reported. The move came three weeks after the Indian prime minister began a peace initiative that included a planned re-establishment of air links between the countries, which nearly went to war over the disputed territory of Kashmir last spring. Despite the diplomatic activity, violence continued in Kashmir, the Press Trust reported. Indian officials reported that Islamic militants killed a family of five and that, in a separate clash, five militants and one Indian soldier were killed. David Rohde (NYT)

title: U.S. Says Bank Credits Will Finance Sale of Goods to Iraq
description: The head of the occupation authority in Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, said today that the Central Bank of Iraq and a group of private banks would begin providing ''substantial'' trade credits for exports to Iraq within weeks.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: BERLUSCONI PARTY LAGGING IN ROME RACE Results in the first local elections since Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi came to power nearly two years ago were mixed, with initial tallies showing his conservative government losing the race for president of the Province of Rome to the center-left opposition. But officials said government parties made up ground elsewhere. About 12 million Italians across the country were eligible to vote yesterday and Sunday for candidates in 12 provinces and 508 cities. Some political analysts framed the elections as a report card for Mr. Berlusconi, whose recent political and legal difficulties have included testifying at his own corruption trial.    Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Sharon Defends Peace Plan Against Critics in Likud
description: In the face of scathing criticism from his own right-wing party, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today staunchly defended his support for the latest Middle East peace effort. ''Ruling three and a half million Palestinians cannot go on indefinitely,'' he declared.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of the soot-covered deck of the cruise ship Norway yesterday with an article about an explosion on board carried an incorrect credit in some copies. It was by Getty Images, not Reuters.

title: Middle School Malaise
description: The New York State education commissioner, Richard Mills, was scoffed at when he announced in the mid-1990's that New York was raising graduation and achievement standards and would require the same performance from poor inner-city schools as from their affluent suburban counterparts. Rising test scores in poor elementary schools suggest that this can be done. But schools across the spectrum are having trouble in extending these gains into middle school, which has come to be seen as the Bermuda Triangle of education, not just in New York but across the country.

title: Right School for 4-Year-Old? Find an Adviser
description: Amanda Uhry, founder of Manhattan Private School Advisors, ushers her client into an unmarked conference room in an Upper East Side high rise. Ms. Uhry has a real office 13 floors above, but the parents who spend upward of $1,000 for her guidance would rather not bump into anyone they know in the elevator.

It is Helmut Lang, not Helmut Newton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CROUTER, , AGATHE KELIHER
description: CROUTER--Agathe Keliher, of Chestnut Hill, PA, died on May 13, 2003 at Keystone House. Retired school head. She had been diagnosed with bone cancer last December. The daughter of the late Francis T. and Agathe S. Keliher, Mrs. Crouter grew up in Brooklyn, NY, and attended The Packer Collegiate Institute. A graduate of Smith College, Class of 1956, she also earned a Master's degree in English from Columbia University. Mrs. Crouter spent her entire professional career in education for girls, teaching first at The Winsor School in Boston and then at The Spence School in New York City, where she became supervisor of the upper school. In 1970 she moved to Philadelphia to become headmistress of The Springside School. There she met her husband, Henry E. Crouter, now a retired investment advisor. In 1980 Mrs. Crouter returned to Manhattan where she was headmistress of The Hewitt School until her retirement in 1990. Mrs. Crouter was active in a number of professional organizations. A past president of the Headmistresses of the East, she had also served as a board member of The Agnes Irwin School, Packer and The Fox Chase Cancer Center. In retirement she very much enjoyed world travel, her friends, her vegetable garden and fly fishing. At the time of her death, Mrs. Crouter belonged to The Acorn Club in Philadelphia and The Cosmopolitan Club in New York City. Mrs. Crouter is survived by her husband, three step-children, six step-grandchildren and a brother. A memorial service will be held in Philadelphia at The Springside School on Thursday, June 12, at eleven a.m. A second memorial service will be held in New York City on Wednesday, June 18, at 4 p.m. at The Hewitt School, 45 East 75th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Packer, Springside, Hewitt or the educational institution of your choice. >>AD#

title: DRUG COMPANY BOARD SAYS TAKEOVER OFFER IS TOO LOW
description: Salix Pharmaceuticals, the drug maker that is the subject of a hostile takeover bid from Axcan Pharma, said yesterday that its board had decided that Axcan's latest offer was too low and should be rejected by shareholders. Axcan's bid of $10.50 a share does not reflect the value of Salix's Colazal medicine for inflammation of the colon or its two medicines under development, Salix said. Axcan, which makes treatments for gastrointestinal diseases, has been trying to buy Salix for four years. Its latest offer, a 20 percent increase from an earlier bid of $8.75 a share, expires on June 27. Axcan is based in Mont-Saint-Hilaire, Quebec. Salix is based in Raleigh, N.C.

title: OXIGENE ANNOUNCES CANCER DRUG TESTS, AND SHARES JUMP
description: Oxigene, a biotechnology company, said yesterday that it would collaborate with a British research organization to test one of Oxigene's most advanced cancer treatments, setting off a 55 percent gain in its share price. Oxigene, which has no products on the market, will work with Cancer Research UK to test a product that blocks the flow of blood to tumors, said Dai Chaplin, Oxigene's chief scientific officer. The treatment shuts down a tumor's blood supply and then kills the cancer cells, he said. The company expects to begin human testing in early 2004, the chief executive, Frederick W. Driscoll, said. Oxigene, based in Watertown, Mass., rose $1.55, to $4.35 a share.

title: Japan Bank Regulator Weighs Departure
description: Heizo Takenaka, Japan's top financial regulator and the point man for banking reform in the cabinet of Junichiro Koizumi, the prime minister, is preparing to return to academia as early as September in the expectation that he may be forced out of the government.

title: Deal Is Seen For NextWave Spectrum Sale
description: NextWave Telecom is nearing an agreement to sell nearly a fifth of its radio spectrum licenses to one of the nation's largest wireless carriers, Cingular Wireless, in a deal that would allow NextWave to start paying off some of its billions of dollars of debt, executives involved in the transaction said yesterday.

title: Guatemalan Twins Improving After Return to U.S., Doctors Say
description: Two young Guatemalan girls born joined at the head who were surgically separated last summer here have shown constant improvement since returning on Thursday after concerns developed about their health, doctors here said today.

title: Luciano Berio Is Dead at 77; Composer of Mind and Heart
description: Luciano Berio, an Italian composer whose many compositions, ranging from chamber music to large-scale orchestral works and from operas to songs, combined innovative imagination and analytical depth with a richly sensuous feeling for sound and form, died yesterday in Rome. He was 77.

title: Splendor on the Bowery
description: IN a city with no shortage of grand dining rooms, Capitale takes the cake. Formerly the Bowery Savings Bank, it is almost preposterously opulent, a gilt-encrusted temple with 45-foot-high coffered ceilings, Corinthian columns the size of sequoias and enough marble to rebuild the Parthenon. The superhuman scale turns diners into tiny figures straight out of a Bruce McCall illustration, the kind in which New Yorkers from a vanished golden age sit impassively as patrons arrive by chauffeured blimp and waiters speed to the tables on roller skates.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 and a correction in this space on Saturday about a study that found that drug testing in schools does not deter drug use referred incompletely to the views of a sponsor, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. While Dwayne Proctor, a senior communications officer of the foundation, initially told The Times that testing was ''an appropriate tool for identifying kids in need of treatment,'' the organization has since disavowed that view and says it has taken no position.

title: Comptroller Accuses Mayor Of Manhattan Bias in Budget
description: The unofficial nonaggression pact between the city's comptroller and the mayor was shattered yesterday when Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. accused Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of favoring Manhattan over the other boroughs.

title: Issues of Purity and Pollution Leave Farmed Salmon Looking Less Rosy
description: THE images of salmon farming that the industry promotes seem pristine and natural, of fish frisking in icy cold clean waters, of wise management saving an endangered species while providing shoppers with the fish they love.

title: Saudis Arrest at Least 8 Men Believed Tied to Bombings
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 28  A series of police raids around the holy city of Medina have led to the capture of up to eight suspected militants wanted in the bombing attacks against residential compounds in the Saudi capital, including the possible mastermind and perhaps two of the clerics who backed the attacks with religious sanction.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday about a 20 percent reduction in the work force of Hudson Technologies Inc., which sells refrigerants, referred incorrectly to the future of service depots in Hillburn, N.Y.; Rantoul, Ill.; Charlotte; and Seattle. They are to remain open.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swiss Carrier Posts Loss
description: The Swiss national carrier, Swiss International Air Lines, said it lost 200 million Swiss francs ($155 million) during the first quarter of the year and will cut costs in an effort to stay aloft. The airline, created from the remnants of the bankrupt Swissair, blamed the travel slump caused by the SARS epidemic and a general malaise in the economy. Revenue was 1.04 billion Swiss francs ($808 million). Costs rose to 1.27 billion francs ($987 million), partly because of the increase in fuel prices during the war in Iraq. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Teachers Seek To Retire
description: More New York City teachers are planning to retire this year than last year, their union said yesterday. About 6,200 of New York City's 80,000 teachers, or 8 percent, have taken preliminary steps toward retiring at the end of the school year, said Randi Weingarten, the union president. She said the teachers had requested ''retirement consultations'' with the union, the United Federation of Teachers. Last year at this time, only 5,000 teachers had requested such consultations, she said. About 5,000 teachers actually retired last year, but the number included many who had been ready to leave for several years but waited until a salary increase took effect in June. Ms. Weingarten, who testified before the City Council's Education Committee yesterday, said many veteran teachers were considering retirement because they were nervous about the new citywide curriculum and other changes that Chancellor Joel I. Klein plans to introduce in the fall. David Chai, a spokesman for Mr. Klein, declined to speculate whether the chancellor's policies were prompting teachers to leave. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: SARS Forces Beijing to Fight An Old but Unsanitary Habit
description: As Mr. Liu sped along the path at Bei Hai Park here, the rumbling in his throat became louder and more intense. A restaurant cleaner, Mr. Liu had a dollop of phlegm to dispose of, and was rushing around the lake to go out the park's west gate.

title: AUTO AIR BAG MANUFACTURER TO CUT 3,500 JOBS BY 2005
description: Breed Technologies, a maker of automotive air bags, will cut 3,500 jobs by the end of 2004 in a bid to restore profitability after being bought last month by Carlyle Group, the private equity firm. Carlyle said the reductions would help Breed, which has yearly sales of $1 billion, reduce annual costs by $200 million. Breed lost $50 million last year, said Peter McElroy, head of marketing and public affairs for the Carlyle unit that holds Breed. The company has about 13,200 workers. Carlyle plans to move Breed's headquarters to the Detroit area from Lakeland, Fla., and rename the company.

Among his many accomplishments, Dr. Ostashevsky studied chromosome structure and the effects of radiation on the cell's hereditary material (DNA). description: The Canadian government introduced legislation today to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana but set stricter penalties for trafficking the drug.

description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld suggested publicly for the first time yesterday that Iraq might have destroyed chemical and biological weapons before the war there, a possibility that senior American officers in Iraq have raised in recent weeks.

title: G.I.'s Condemned to Slave Labor in the Holocaust
description: The Holocaust, with its genocidal mechanisms long hidden from other nations, is now reasonably understood in physical terms. Historians have read the records of who, when, how and how many. What might never be fully understood is the irrational aspect. Why did inhumanity flourish, earn such wide berth, spread like a contagion?

description: It was a day for goodbye at the French Open. But Andy Roddick was not supposed to be part of it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: 100 New Jobs Set For Upstate
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that a company that recycles scrap rubber tires would create 100 new jobs in upstate New York. The company, Recovery Technologies Group Inc., is the largest tire-recycling firm in North America, the governor said. It will establish plants in Albany, Rotterdam and Romulus, in Seneca County, where an existing storage site will also be expanded. The company recycles more than 40 million tires a year at 17 plants in North America. It is estimated that six million tires will be recycled in New York when the three plants are running by next fall, officials said.

title: 4 Flavors, No Waiting
description: I CAME across a nice-looking pineapple last week and thought about dinner. Pineapple is used occasionally in savory dishes, of course, but rarely well -- a horrifying image of pineapple pizza comes to mind. But some savory pineapple dishes are not only legitimate but also delicious, and this light colorful sauce, which you can serve with fish, chicken or beef, is one of them. All three versions drew raves from my guests. I preferred it with swordfish.

title: Supreme Court Ruling Increases Federal Power
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  In a surprising break with its march toward states' rights, the Supreme Court ruled today that states can be sued for violating their employees' federally guaranteed right to take time off for family emergencies.

title: If Giants Modernize Stadium, They Also Want to Control It
description: The Giants will meet today with officials of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority in hopes of advancing an agreement on modernizing Giants Stadium to make it eligible to be the site of the 2008 Super Bowl.

description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: SAP TO FORM PARTNERSHIP WITH MYSQL The open-source software model received another endorsement yesterday when SAP, the big German software company, said it would form a technical partnership with MySQL, which makes an increasingly popular open-source database program. The goal of the agreement is to enable SAP's software, which automates an array of corporate operations including benefits and procurement, to run on the MySQL database. SAP software already runs on the databases made by Oracle , I.B.M. and Microsoft . MySQL distributes its database free according to open-source practices, but also offers it under a commercial license for corporate customers that prefer it. MySQL collects revenues from both licensing and maintenance fees. As part of the agreement, SAP will hand over its own fledgling open-source database project, which had only a few thousand users, to MySQL, which is used on about four million computers. "This is part of the commoditization of database software," said Marten Mickos, chief executive of MySQL. "SAP has acknowledged that trend and it wants to make sure it has a commodity database that works with SAP products." Steve Lohr (NYT)

description: Bungling a daily parking routine he had carried out for decades, a Queens man ran over his wife in their driveway yesterday, killing her.

description: There is no evidence that American forces were fired on from the Palestine Hotel in Baghdad before they shelled the building, killing two of nearly 100 journalists staying there, a journalist advocacy group said today.

title: In Williamsburg, Feeling for Engine 212 Runs Deep
description: As firefighters gather their belongings and officers pack up files for storage, a determined band of protesters in Brooklyn has been keeping watch on their firehouse, trying somehow to stave off its closing by making sure the fire truck stays inside.

title: Straight Talk From Ariel Sharon
description: Important changes have been occurring in Israel in recent days. On Sunday, the Israeli government, for the first time, gave its support to a Palestinian state when it accepted the so-called road map for Middle East peace. On Monday, an equally significant moment occurred when Ariel Sharon, the prime minister and the father of Jewish expansion in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, told his party faithful that Israeli rule over Palestinians must be brought to an end.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Press Points Ahead of Key Meetings
description: JERUSALEM, May 28  With Middle East diplomacy gathering momentum, the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers are planning to hold a crucial meeting on Thursday, with both sides saying it is time to move forward on an international peace plan.

title: Putin's Sure Hand Abroad Belies Problems at Home
description: When President Vladimir V. Putin meets President Bush in St. Petersburg on Saturday, more than a few questions will be asked about how Russia's steely leader opposed a hyperpower over the war in Iraq and came away unscathed.

title: Fasten Your Seat Belts, Organic Free-Range Chickens
description: A different kind of airline food will soon be coming down the aisles of Song, the new low-price Delta carrier that in April inaugurated flights between New York and Florida. Michel Nischan, who was the chef at Heartbeat in the W hotel, is developing a menu for passengers on the all-coach airline that will include organic ingredients, some from small farms. The menu is being introduced gradually and most of it will be offered starting June 15. Food on Song is not included in the ticket price. The bill of fare will be mostly wraps and salads priced from $6 to $10. ''Selling the food is the only way we can offer the quality we want to offer,'' Stacy Geagan, a spokeswoman for Delta, said. The decision to sell this type of food was based on market research that identified Song's ideal core customers as 35- to 55-year-old mothers with full-time jobs who do yoga. The airline tested the selections on some regular Delta flights. For those not interested in Stonyfield Farm yogurt, a free-range chicken wrap, a Caesar salad made with organic lettuce or Newman's Own organic cookies, items like Pizzeria Uno sandwiches, Pringles and Snickers will be available. ''We want people to know they don't have to stop at McDonald's before getting on the plane,'' Ms. Geagan said.

title: Passion For Peace
description: For years I believed that when it came to Middle East peacemaking, America couldn't want peace more than the parties themselves. I no longer believe that. In fact, I now believe just the opposite. For there to be any progress, America must want peace more than the parties themselves -- in Israel and the West Bank, and in Iraq. And the question I have going forward is whether that will be the case with President Bush.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Term Limit Appeal Sought
description: Lawyers for three politicians said yesterday that they had filed papers with the Court of Appeals seeking to appeal a lower-court decision on New York City's term limit law. If the appeal succeeds, the decision would bar the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, left, and five other council members from running for re-election this year. On May 19, the lower court, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, overturned a trial court's decision that had rejected changes by the City Council to the term limits law. At issue is whether the Council had the authority to extend the time that some of its members could remain in office. The lawyers, Randy M. Mastro and Ravi Batra, said the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, would decide whether to consider the case after Monday. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Shareholder Rules Eased
description: China's stock regulator named UBS AG and Nomura Holdings as the first overseas investors to be allowed to buy yuan shares, marking a new stage in opening its capital market to international funds. Under a qualified foreign institutional investor program, overseas fund managers with at least $10 billion in assets and at least $50 million to spend will be allowed to buy Shanghai- and Shenzhen-listed Class A shares, which up to now have been reserved for domestic investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDNER, , RICHARD A., M.D.
description: GARDNER--Richard A., M.D. A child and adult psychiatrist and psychoanalyst practicing in Cresskill, N.J. died Sunday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 72. He had been a clinical professor of psychiatry and faculty member in the division of child psychology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons since 1963. Dr. Gardner authored more that 40 books and 300 articles on psychiatric issues related to children and families. In 1970, he wrote the highly acclaimed book for children, ''The Boys and Girls Book About Divorce''. He created the first psychotherapeutic board game, ''The Talking, Feeling and Doing Game'' in 1973, and later the ''mutual storytelling technique''. In the last 20 years, he devoted himself to high conflict child-custody disputes, serving as court evaluator in more that 400 cases. His most recent work was on evaluating and treating families affected by a disorder he identified as the parental alienation syndrome. Dr. Gardner was born April 28, 1931 and attended the Bronx High School of Science, Columbia College and SUNY School of Medicine. He lectured extensively in the U.S. and abroad. He is survived by his mother, Amelia Gardner, three children, Andrew Gardner, Nancy Gardner Rubin and Julie Gardner Mandelcorn and their spouses, by eight grandchildren and by his partner, Natalie Weiss. Funeral service 11:30AM today, Wien & Wien, 402 Park St, Hackensack, N.J. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J. Shiva May 28th and 29th at Dr. Lee Gardner's and May 30th at Natalie Weiss'. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to American Tinnitus Association, Unit 20, POB 4900, Portland, OR. 97208 or Chai Lifeline, 151 W. 30 St, N.Y., N.Y. 10001. For information call Donna LaTourett, 201-567-8989. >>AD#

title: Kidd Walks Gingerly, Tiptoeing by Free-Agency Issue
description: In the Nets' locker room, Kenyon Martin spied a purple bruise covering Jason Kidd's sprained right ankle and told him it was pretty. But Martin did have some sympathy for Kidd as they began preparations today for the N.B.A. finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DI MONTEZEMOLO, , ALESSANDRO
description: di MONTEZEMOLO--Alessandro, 1918-2003--In Loving Memory. On behalf of the Board of Directors, the staff and volunteers of the American-Italian Cancer Foundation, we extend our deepest sympathy to the family and friends of Alessandro di Montezemolo, beloved husband, friend and mentor. He will be dearly missed. Contributions in his honor may be sent to the American-Italian Cancer Foundation, 112 E. 71 St., #

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Grants
description: Residents of Lower Manhattan have until Saturday to apply for up to $14,500 in grants through a federal program meant to increase the residential population of downtown and help the area recover from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is administering the $306 million program, which offers grants to residents of three zones in Lower Manhattan. Most of the grants require two years' residency. Details are available at the development corporation's Web site, www.renewnyc.com, or by calling (866) 736-3969. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Sleeping Pills Handed Out At School
description: A middle school student took her grandmother's sleeping pills to school yesterday and distributed them to her friends, identifying them as candy, the police said. The student, whom the police did not identify, visited her grandmother a month ago and took a bottle of sleeping pills, said a spokeswoman for the city's Board of Education, Margie Feinberg. At 1:30 p.m, eight 11- and 12-year-old girls at Public School 192 in the east Bronx were taken by ambulance to Jacobi Medical Center for treatment. All were treated and released with no major injuries, said a hospital spokesman. Only two children wound up ingesting the pills, Ms. Feinberg said, but all eight girls were taken to the hospital as a precaution. She added that Betty A. Rosa, the superintendent of Community School District 8, planned to meet with the girl and her mother to discuss the incident. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Creditors Move to Push Key Seoul Company Out of Business
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 28  The creditors of SK Global, the trading company at the center of a scandal that threatens to tear apart the SK Group, South Korea's third largest conglomerate, took the first decisive step today toward putting the company out of business.

title: Hormone Use Found to Raise Dementia Risk
description: Hormone therapy doubled the risk of Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia in women who began the treatment at age 65 or older, a large study has found.

title: The SARS Spectrum
description: To the Editor:

title: The Month of May Has Been Difficult for the Boss
description: George Steinbrenner is 72 years old, but he cannot sleep at night because of the sloppy way his beloved Yankees have played in the last month. He tosses and he sees Jason Giambi slapping a lame groundout and brooding. He turns and he sees Jeff Weaver and Andy Pettitte looking tense as they pitch poorly. He wakes up and he sees a listless team, a team he is now vowing to change.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Ice Cream Deal
description: Nestl expects to get regulatory approval of its $2.4 billion takeover bid of Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream, Nestl's chief executive told investors during a conference call. ''I am confident that we will get the final green light,'' the executive, Peter Brabeck-Letmathe, said. The Federal Trade Commission in the United States held up the deal in March. The commission is concerned that if the sale is completed, Nestl, which would then own the Hagen-Dazs, Starbucks and Godiva brands, would eliminate competition in the premium ice cream market, leading to higher prices. Its only competitor would be Unilever, maker of the Ben & Jerry's label. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Gunmen Kill 2 U.S. Soldiers In a Firefight in Central Iraq
description: In a second day of deadly guerrilla attacks on American convoys in Iraq, unidentified gunmen fired machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades at a column of military vehicles near the Euphrates River Bridge here today, killing two American soldiers, military officials said.

title: Its Reputation and Its Odor Precede It
description: AT a cheese dairy called La Laiterie de la Cte, in the village of Brochon in Burgundy, last fall, I was struck by a display in a refrigerator case of little chvres on sticks, each one a single bite, like a cheese lollipop, but covered with a furry down of gray mold.

title: Commercial Time Is Selling Quickly For Cable, Too
description: The robust demand for commercial time on the broadcast television networks before the start of the 2003-4 season, as evidenced last week, is carrying over to their cable counterparts as both look to set records for revenue in the ''upfront'' market.

title: A Serene Tea Break With Korean Lemonade
description: The iced tea list at Franchia, the invitingly cool and serene Korean cafe and tea room that opened last month at 12 Park Avenue (34th Street), includes a number of decidedly tealess fruit-based drinks. One made with citron, which shades in the glass from pale to gold, is like lemonade, but modestly sweetened and with a refreshing hint of bitterness from the citron peel. Franchia serves it for $5 a glass or $3 to go.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With No Surprise, Chief Is Out at Tenet Healthcare
description: In response to intense pressure from investors, Jeffrey C. Barbakow stepped down yesterday as chief executive of Tenet Healthcare, the troubled hospital chain.

title: Bus Driver Is Sentenced to Prison For Accident That Killed Five
description: A bus driver who dozed off at the wheel after near-sleepless nights of gambling and killed five passengers on a church fund-raising mission must serve at least three years and four months in prison, a term a prosecutor called too brief.

title: Thank You
description: Thank you for your submission. Thank you for your submission.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: PRESIDENT OF XO COMMUNICATIONS RESIGNS The president and chief operating officer of XO Communications, Nate Davis, has resigned and will be succeeded by the chief executive, Carl J. Grivner. Mr. Davis, who joined XO in January 2000, helped it expand the services it offers to businesses and reduce its operating expenses, the company said yesterday in a statement. He is leaving to pursue other business interests, the statement said. His departure comes five months after Daniel F. Akerson resigned as chairman and chief executive of the closely held company, which sells business telephone and Internet services. Mr. Grivner, who was most recently chief operating officer at Global Crossing Ltd., became XO's chief executive on May 15. XO emerged from bankruptcy in January. It shed $4.6 billion in debt and sold control to the financier Carl C. Icahn, who retains an 80 percent stake in the business. An XO spokeswoman, Kara Palamaras, did not answer a voice mail message seeking comment.

title: Revenue Up At Vodafone; Still, It Loses $16 Billion
description: The Vodafone Group, the world's largest wireless operator, reported today that operating results for the year exceeded expectations, as revenue rose 14 percent.

description: SILVERBERG--Julian E. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne. Devoted father of Elizabeth Gelb and Lucy Smith, father-in-law of Larry Gelb and Sheldon Smith. Loving grandfather of Adam, Amanda, Emily, David and Julia. Services ''GuttermanMusicant,'' Hackensack, New Jersey, on Wednesday, at 10:30 AM, 1-800-378-1892. >>AD#

title: Flavors of Spain, Wholesale to Retail
description: Despaa Brand Foods, a sausage maker and wholesaler of Spanish imports in Jackson Heights, Queens, has renovated its storefront and opened for retail customers. ''People kept coming by and asking us to sell our products,'' said Angelica Intriago, who owns the shop with her husband, Marco Intriago. The shelves are crammed with Spanish cheeses, rices, olive oils, vinegars, anchovies, piquillo peppers, spices, squid ink, dozens of kinds of olives, their own chorizo and morcilla (blood sausage) and other products, all at reasonable prices. Aged manchego is $8.50 a pound. An 8-ounce jar of piquillo peppers is $4.50. Imported serrano ham is $11 a pound and marcona almonds, raw or fried, are $6.50 a pound. Worth trying are the unusual naturally sweet Montegrato Pedro Ximenez sherry vinegars, $12 for 750 milliliters of the 16-year-old variety. The shop also sells paella pans. It is at 86-17 Northern Boulevard, and has food tastings on Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.

title: When Good Friends Make Bad Diplomacy
description: It is fitting that President Vladimir Putin of Russia is welcoming President Bush to his hometown of St. Petersburg. An imperial backdrop makes sense for two men creating empires of the 21st century. When Peter the Great built his city 300 years ago, he had two somewhat contradictory purposes in mind. He wanted to showcase Russia's world-power status, but he also wanted to create a ''window to Europe.'' (Europe's hand would poke through, pulling Russia into a more modern era.) The question is which of the two St. Petersburgs Mr. Bush will focus on: the gold-encrusted imperial capital, or the portal to the West and its values of human rights and liberal democracy.

title: Devils Cruise With Incentive and Brodeur on Their Side
description: As if the Devils needed any more incentive in the Stanley Cup finals, all they had to do this morning was look at the news article that was posted on the chalkboard in their dressing room.

title: Snappy, Crackling, Popping Chips of Rice
description: Lundberg Family Farms, a California rice company, has introduced rice chips that have more in common with tortilla chips than with air-puffed spongy-textured rice snacks. Made from pressed brown rice, the chips are crisp with an alluring nutty flavor that comes through best in the plain sea-salt variety. Other flavors are sesame and seaweed, the oddly named ''Santa Fe barbecue'' and pico de gallo, made with black beans. A six-ounce bag of the chips is around $2.50 at Whole Foods markets.

title: World Briefing | The North Pole: Stranded Adventurer Rescued
description: Eight days after Pen Hadow apparently became the first person to trek alone and unaided from North America to the North Pole, he was plucked from the drifting ice by a small plane flying out of northernmost Canada. Mr. Hadow, 41 and a Briton, was headed back to a base camp at Eureka Weather Station on Ellesmere Island, off Canada's coast. From there, he was expected to return to Britain. He had spent a week tucked in a tent waiting for clouds to lift, living on chocolate chips and other remnants of the supplies he had dragged behind him in the 64-day, 478-mile journey. His wife said he was healthy but hungry and in need of a shower. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Global Network Speeds Plunder of Iraqi Antiquities
description: The meeting took place as planned, in a battered van on the side of the highway. Closing the curtains on the windows facing the road, Khalil quickly got down to business.

title: Warm and Weird Toasts to Russia's Crown Jewel; St. Petersburg Celebrates 300 Years With Everything From Pornography to Preservation
description: Pushkin wrote verse that immortalized this city, the imperial capital of Russia, as a ''window into Europe.'' Sergei V. Pryanishnikov makes pornography that depicts it as a palatial peep show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Charges In Woman's Death
description: Assault charges against a man accused of pushing his girlfriend out of a fourth-floor window were raised yesterday to two counts of manslaughter after the woman was declared dead. The man, Edgar Ortega, 31, was arraigned yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court after the woman, Sheila Cordell, 32, was removed from a respirator. Mr. Ortega is accused of pushing her out the window of the apartment they shared near Union Square Park on Sunday. Mr. Ortega's lawyer contended that detectives had coerced statements of guilt from his client.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LONDON, , WILLIAM

title: The Mass Is Still the Mass, Even in Tantalizing Variety
description: Once upon a time art replaced religion as a unifying force in the spiritual life of Western society. Fairy tale or no, this point was symbolically demonstrated by the Eos Orchestra's program, ''Mass en Masse,'' on Thursday night. Jonathan Sheffer, Eos's founder and conductor, showed the Catholic Mass as concert music rather than as religious ritual, presenting three Mass settings back to back in the churchlike, nondenominational auditorium of the Ethical Culture Society.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 and a correction in this space on Saturday about a study that found that drug testing in schools does not deter drug use referred incompletely to the views of a sponsor, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. While Dwayne Proctor, a senior communications officer of the foundation, initially told The Times that testing was "an appropriate tool for identifying kids in need of treatment," the organization has since disavowed that view and says it has taken no position.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Tree Trade Ruling
description: Siding with Canada, a World Trade Organization panel said that stumpage, or tree-cutting, programs in forests owned by Canadian provinces did not constitute an unfair subsidy to lumber exporters, the Canadian government said. The United States cited the programs last year when it imposed a 19 percent countervailing duty on softwood lumber imports from Canada. Two other W.T.O. panels are examining Canada's complaints against an 8 percent antidumping duty on lumber, and against the extent of injury to American producers, as set by the International Trade Commission. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: The Schools in Basra Expel 'Papa Saddam'
description: What Naheda Muhammad Nage did to the textbook she uses to teach social studies here was just as dramatic as the toppling of Saddam Hussein statues or the looting of Saddam Hussein palaces that took place after the American-led invasion of Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENWALD, , HERBERT
description: GREENWALD--Herbert, on May 27, in his 98th year. Beloved father of Rose (Morton) Landowne, husband of the late Helen N. Greenwald, grandfather of Dena (Jay), Lea, Shifra and Aryeh, greatgrandfather of Micha, Keren and Gilad. title: Police Questioning Allowed To the Point of Coercion
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that police questioning in the absence of Miranda warnings, even questioning that is overbearing to the point of coercion, does not violate the constitutional protection against compelled self-incrimination, as long as no incriminating statements are introduced at the suspect's trial.

title: Gucci Plans to Return $1.6 Billion to Its Shareholders
description: PARIS, May 28  Gucci Group said today that it would return 1.34 billion euros, or about $1.6 billion, to its shareholders in a move that is expected to reduce the amount that Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, Gucci's biggest shareholder, will have to pay next year to buy the shares of the Italian fashion house it does not already own.

title: A Russia Resurgent
description: Last month Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain traveled to Moscow to discuss postwar Iraq with President Vladimir Putin of Russia. Although the war was effectively over, Mr. Putin remained skeptical of its aims. ''Where is Saddam?'' Mr. Putin asked at a press conference after the meeting. Where, he continued, were the weapons of mass destruction, ''if they really existed?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTLIEB, , MARTIN
description: GOTTLIEB--Martin. The Officers and Directors of Green Bus lines, Triboro Coach, Jamaica Buses and Command Bus Company sadly note the passing of Martin Gottlieb, a man who rose from bus driver to executive and later a respected member of the Board of Directors. Hard working, industrious and capable, but above all a good friend. His able guidance will be missed. Our condolences to his wife Eileen, his children Stacey Stone, Karen and Steven Bodnar, and his grandchildren Alex and Joshua Stone and Andrew Bodnar. Jerry Cooper, Chairman Board of Directors >>AD#

title: Airbus in $24 Billion Deal for Military Jets
description: Seven European countries agreed today to acquire 180 military transport planes from Airbus in a deal valued at $24 billion.

title: Newark Groups Unite to Work At Preventing Child Abuse
description: Church and community leaders and relatives of Faheem Williams, the 7-year-old boy whose body was found in a locked basement here in January, said today that they were forming a coalition to help prevent child abuse.

title: Hollandaise Made Easier
description: The traditional recipe for rich hollandaise sauce -- useful for glorifying asparagus or to blanket eggs Benedict at brunch -- calls for clarified butter. But Jean-Georges Vongerichten does not bother melting his butter before making the sauce. ''When chefs start in my kitchen they think we're doing it wrong,'' he said. ''When you clarify the butter you throw out the part that has all the flavor and also some moisture. Hollandaise made with whole butter is tastier and lighter.'' For a generous cup of sauce, start with four egg yolks beaten with two tablespoons of water in a metal bowl over boiling water. Beat in half a pound of soft unsalted butter bit by bit. Finally, whisk in a little lemon juice, salt and pepper, and keep the sauce warm.

title: Upholding Family Leave
description: The Supreme Court's decision yesterday holding that state employees can sue for damages under the Family and Medical Leave Act struck an important blow for women's rights and humane employment practices. It may also signal that the court is beginning to moderate its destructive use of the doctrine it calls ''federalism'' to invalidate or limit laws passed by Congress.

title: Sunshine in the Kitchen And Summer on the Tongue
description: FRUIT is so wonderful in its natural state that you really need a good reason to cook it. When fruit is less than perfect, for instance, it may require culinary improvement to be made palatable. When fruit is perfect, however, this round of recipes can amplify its essential fruitiness to sensational levels.

title: Reds Easy to Drink, Easy on the Budget
description: SAMPLING a bunch of easygoing, uncomplicated wines that are easy on the wallet, too, can be a pleasure. The hard part is selecting a few of them for special mention, as there are hundreds, if not thousands, of inexpensive yet worthy wines out there. Just as hard is learning not to ask too much from them.

title: Delta Gets Some Stiff Competition on a Key Route
description: Delta Air Lines is scrambling to cope with competition that has spread as quickly here as a California wildfire: two low-cost airlines are challenging it for passengers between this city and Atlanta, on what until now was the country's biggest nonstop route with no rivalry.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: REVIEW OF BANK RULES Singapore's de facto central bank has issued new regulations that would force the country's banks to unwind cross-shareholdings with their affiliates. In a consultation paper outlining rules to take effect in July 2004, the monetary authority said it would limit to 2 percent the shareholdings of any bank's affiliate in its parent bank. The authority said such cross-shareholdings muddy the ability of investors to determine who controls affiliates and weaken a bank's ability to evaluate its investment in them. Following the announcement, the Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation and an affiliated beverage maker, Fraser & Neave, announced plans to unwind their own cross-shareholdings, with the bank swapping Fraser & Neave's stake in the bank with part of its stake in Fraser & Neave and some cash. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: For Asylum Seeker, Self-Torment Becomes Means of Protest
description: LONDON, May 28 — The torture was as commonplace as it was brutal, Adas Amini told the British authorities when he arrived here from Iran seeking asylum two years ago. Among other things, he said, the soles of his feet were beaten; he was strung up so that his body was horribly contorted, and he was forced to play victim in prolonged mock executions.

title: Contreras to Make First Start; Clemens Given an Extra Day
description: Each Yankee starter for this weekend's series in Detroit will carry very different subplots to the mound. On Friday, Jos Contreras will try to impress the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, in his first major league start. On Saturday, Jeff Weaver will be pitching, perhaps futilely, to save his spot in the rotation. And on Sunday, Roger Clemens will have a second chance to win his 300th game.

title: L.I. Town Runs Into Trouble Courting Fame and Fortune With Two Summer Rock Concerts
description: Ever since its economic linchpin, a Grumman aircraft plant, closed more than a decade ago, the town of Riverhead has been caught in a bind. It is too far from Manhattan to be a home to white-collar commuters. But for tourists who head to Long Island's East End for the summer, it is little more than a pit stop, albeit one with an outlet mall, on the way to the North Fork or the Hamptons.

title: Cooking Risotto With an Inexpensive and Decent Red Wine
description: ON a certain level, it is understandable to feel as if you should be able to eat just about anything you want with an inexpensive bottle of red wine. You want to have fried catfish with it? Go ahead. A doughnut? It's all yours.

title: The Changes Unwelcome, A Model Teacher Moves On
description: ''MS. MacLEISH! Ms. MacLeish!'' The door to Room 7 was still locked, but the kindergartners could not wait for the school day to begin. They were jumping up and down in the hallway, trying to peek through the high window and get Ms. MacLeish to let them in early.

title: Greening of Lower Manhattan With $25 Million Grant to City
description: A carousel is planned for the Battery Park Bosque. A new park will spring from rutted asphalt at a bustling corner along Canal Street. Synthetic turf or natural grass will spread over concrete in several playgrounds.

title: Steinbrenner Speaks, and Yankees Perk Up
description: The fans outside Yankee Stadium sounded desperate when Andy Pettitte reported for work yesterday. ''They weren't booing me or anything,'' Pettitte said. ''They were yelling, 'Stop the bleeding!' I told them, 'I hear you.'''

title: 24 Groups Press State Leaders To Replenish the Superfund
description: With less than a month left in the legislative session, environmentalists and others sought today to pressure Albany's political leaders to address the cleanup of the state's most polluted industrial sites.

title: PIPELINE COMPANY INCREASES ITS GOAL FOR CUTTING DEBT
description: The El Paso Corporation, a natural gas pipeline company, intends to reduce debt in the next two years by $10 billion, a third more than announced two weeks ago, to get its credit rating back to investment grade. El Paso, based in Houston, cited the target yesterday in a letter urging shareholders to support its board nominations in a proxy fight. The company, which has about $25 billion in debt, is shedding at least $3.4 billion in assets this year to raise cash, and it is reducing capital spending. The chief executive, Ronald L. Kuehn Jr., has been trying to cut costs ahead of a June 17 vote on proposals by two shareholders, Selim Zilkha and Oscar Wyatt. Mr. Zilkha wants to replace El Paso's 12-member board with a 9-member slate, including himself; among other motivations, he has cited the 84 percent drop in the company's stock last year.

title: Picasso in Paris: A Suspect, Never a Citizen
description: After his death in 1973, France honored Pablo Picasso with the museum that carries his name in Paris. Yet during his first four decades as a French resident, the Spanish-born Picasso was viewed with suspicion by the French police and intelligence services. When he sought French nationality in 1940, he was turned down on the ground that he was an anarchist with Communist tendencies.

title: Palestinians Delay Summit Talks With Israelis for a Day
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders today postponed a summit meeting for at least a day, while Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, came under renewed criticism from Israeli politicians and officials for referring to Israel's ''occupation'' of the West Bank and Gaza, a term the Israeli government has long avoided.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Common Ground
description: President Vladimir V. Putin and his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, who is making his first trip abroad as Chinese leader, pledged to deepen the ties between their countries but did not announce any new diplomatic or economic initiatives, as some political experts had predicted they might. After meeting in Moscow, the two leaders issued a joint statement urging that the United Nations take ''the central role'' in forging a political settlement in Iraq, and reiterating their desire for North Korea to abandon its pursuit of nuclear weapons. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Kurds Mobilize to Elect One of Their Own in City of Kirkuk
description: KIRKUK, Iraq, May 28  A Kurd was elected today to head the local interim government, a significant political victory for the Kurds that tipped the ethnic balance in this oil-rich northern city that was dominated for years by Arabs from the Baathist-led regime.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: East Hartford: Bomb Incident
description: Part of downtown was evacuated yesterday after a device resembling a hand grenade was found outside a coffee shop. A patron of Whole Donut on Main Street noticed the device on top of a newspaper vending machine. Streets were closed and the busy commercial district was evacuated beginning at 10:24 a.m. The Hartford police bomb squad removed the device, Detective Winston Brooks said. He declined to confirm that it was a grenade.

title: U.S. Still Critical of Iran Despite Al Qaeda Arrests
description: The Bush administration said today that it had received word that Iran had recently arrested some Al Qaeda members operating in its territory, but that the actions had failed to ease American concerns about Iranian support for terrorist activities.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP To Form Partnership With MySQL
description: The open-source software model received another endorsement yesterday when SAP, the big German software company, said it would form a technical partnership with MySQL, which makes an increasingly popular open-source database program. The goal of the agreement is to enable SAP's software, which automates an array of corporate operations including benefits and procurement, to run on the MySQL database. SAP software already runs on the databases made by Oracle, I.B.M. and Microsoft. MySQL distributes its database free according to open-source practices, but also offers it under a commercial license for corporate customers that prefer it. MySQL collects revenues from both licensing and maintenance fees. As part of the agreement, SAP will hand over its own fledgling open-source database project, which had only a few thousand users, to MySQL, which is used on about four million computers. ''This is part of the commoditization of database software,'' said Marten Mickos, chief executive of MySQL. ''SAP has acknowledged that trend and it wants to make sure it has a commodity database that works with SAP products.'' Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: American And New Zealander Held
description: An American citizen and a New Zealand citizen, both Chinese-born, have been detained for promoting a new, illegal dissident group, the government said. The two, Benjamin Lan of San Francisco and Sung Gang of New Zealand, recently entered China to promote the group, China Federation Foundation, which aims to overthrow the Communist government and promote democracy, according to a statement by a group leader in California. No formal charges have been announced. A spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry said, ''They received support from the heads of some hostile organizations and came to China to carry out violent terrorist activities.'' She did not give further details about when the men were arrested or what the charges against them would be. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Flavors of Spain, Wholesale to Retail
description: Despana Brand Foods, a sausage maker and wholesaler of Spanish imports in Jackson Heights, Queens, has renovated its storefront and opened for retail customers. "People kept coming by and asking us to sell our products," said Angelica Intriago, who owns the shop with her husband, Marco Intriago. The shelves are crammed with Spanish cheeses, rices, olive oils, vinegars, anchovies, piquillo peppers, spices, squid ink, dozens of kinds of olives, their own chorizo and morcilla (blood sausage) and other products, all at reasonable prices. Aged manchego is $8.50 a pound. An 8-ounce jar of piquillo peppers is $4.50. Imported serrano ham is $11 a pound and marcona almonds, raw or fried, are $6.50 a pound. Worth trying are the unusual naturally sweet Montegrato Pedro Ximenez sherry vinegars, $12 for 750 milliliters of the 16-year-old variety. The shop also sells paella pans. It is at 86-17 Northern Boulevard, and has food tastings on Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.

Loving brother of David and Gerry Kule, Gene and Arlene Kule; brother-inlaw to Seymour and Blossom Prager; special uncle and adored friend of Mike and Edith Steingart. Served with the 8th Air Force in WWII, flew 19 missions over Germany. On the 19th mission was shot down, parachuted out, and captured by the Germans. Was in a prison camp until General Patton's Third Army liberated them. Awarded the Purple Heart, Air Medal with two OLC's, POW Medal and New York State Distinguished Service Cross. Funeral services Thursday, 11:30 AM, Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Ave./Rt. 527, Manalapan, NJ. >>AD#

title: Excerpts From Court's Ruling on Personal Leave
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court ruling yesterday that states can be sued for violating their employees' right to time off for family emergencies. The vote in Nevada Department of Human Resources v. Hibbs was 6 to 3. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion; Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote a dissent. The full text is available online at nytimes.com/washington.

title: JUSTICES, 6-3, RULE WORKERS CAN SUE STATES OVER LEAVE
description: In a surprising break with its march toward states' rights, the Supreme Court ruled today that states can be sued for violating their employees' federally guaranteed right to take time off for family emergencies.

title: Pressure Increases For Tighter Limits On Injury Lawsuits
description: Arguing that legal costs and big jury awards are overwhelming them, insurance companies and other businesses have stepped up efforts in the states to restrict medical malpractice lawsuits and other kinds of personal injury suits.

description: THE green objects resting on top of vibrant, bias-cut rectangles of raw king salmon belly at Craft are not a garnish. Nor are they pieces of basil branch or sprigs of strange new hybrid parsley. They're sea beans. And, for something so small they're remarkable.

title: BOEING TO ADD BROADBAND SERVICE TO LUFTHANSA
description: Lufthansa, the biggest German airline, said yesterday that it had reached a deal with the Boeing Company to have broadband Internet service installed on its entire long-haul fleet, the first airline to make such a move. Starting next year, Boeing will outfit Lufthansa's 80 long-haul planes with what Boeing calls its Connexion system. Lufthansa and Boeing began offering Internet service in January on some flights between Frankfurt and Washington. Lufthansa said it had not set prices for passengers yet. Lufthansa declined to say how much it would pay Boeing to outfit the planes. Boeing will install Connexion on Lufthansa's Boeing 747-400's and Airbus A330's and A340's. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T To Sell Services From Former Division
description: AT&T will start selling a package of services that includes mobile calling from AT&T Wireless Services, a company it spun off in 2001. Terms were not disclosed. The service package will be tested in some markets in the next few months and be offered nationwide by year's end, a spokesman, Gary Morgenstern, said. AT&T also sells Internet access and local calling to some of its 43 million residential customers. AT&T wants to sell partners' products to win and keep customers, after abandoning a plan to sell phone, wireless and cable service from under the same roof in 2000. Local carriers like Verizon Communications have added long distance to their offerings, and analysts say subscribers with multiple calling services on one bill are less likely to switch carriers. Shares of AT&T fell 34 cents, to $18.91.

description: College commencement signifies the end of a journey, often long and arduous. But for some graduating seniors, the trip involves extra twists and turns. Here are the stories of graduates with their own special reasons to celebrate.

They were made by Gerald Dupree LaBeija, a member of the House of LaBeija troupe, not by Pepper LaBeija.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Phoenix Financial Chief Steps Down
description: Phoenix Technologies Ltd., whose software is used to boot up personal computers, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, John M. Greeley, had resigned to become a consultant. Phoenix has hired an unidentified executive-search company to find a new finance chief, the company said in a statement. Mr. Greeley had been chief financial officer since May 2000. The company makes basic input/output systems, or BIOS, software that provides instructions to computers once they are turned on. Phoenix shares rose 18 cents, to $4.50.

title: EUROPEAN PANEL TO MAKE ANTITRUST RULING ON G.E. DEAL
description: The European Commission will take charge of the antitrust assessment of General Electric's acquisition of a unit of Agfa-Gevaert at the request of seven European countries. Germany, Austria, Greece, Ireland, Spain, Portugal and Italy asked the commission to rule on the 400 million euro deal ($475 million). It involves businesses that are too small to set off an automatic review. General Electric agreed in January to buy the Agfa unit, which makes ultrasonic systems to test materials. The commission suspended the normal four-week ruling deadline so it can get information from G.E., a spokesman said.

title: Kathleen Winsor, 83; Wrote 'Forever Amber'
description: Kathleen Winsor, whose 1944 novel ''Forever Amber,'' detailing the sexual adventures of a young woman in Restoration England, became a model for romantic best sellers to follow, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MORE TEACHERS SEEK TO RETIRE More New York City teachers are planning to retire this year than last year, their union said yesterday. About 6,200 of New York City's 80,000 teachers, or 8 percent, have taken preliminary steps toward retiring at the end of the school year, said Randi Weingarten, the union president. She said the teachers had requested "retirement consultations" with the union, the United Federation of Teachers. Last year at this time, only 5,000 teachers had requested such consultations, she said. About 5,000 teachers actually retired last year, but the number included many who had been ready to leave for several years but waited until a salary increase took effect in June. Ms. Weingarten, who testified before the City Council's Education Committee yesterday, said many veteran teachers were considering retirement because they were nervous about the new citywide curriculum and other changes that Chancellor Joel I. Klein plans to introduce in the fall. David Chai, a spokesman for Mr. Klein, declined to speculate whether the chancellor's policies were prompting teachers to leave.

The song is ''All My Loving,'' not ''All My Love''; it did not open the concert (''Hello Goodbye'' did).

It is the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System, not Pollution Discharge.

description: COCHLEAR implants that restore some hearing to the profoundly deaf have improved steadily over the past two decades. Although they are called implants, however, these systems still lie mainly outside the ear.

title: Colombian Drug Figure Is Convicted in U.S. Court
description: A longtime Colombian narcotics trafficker who the government said had joined with associates to bring as much as 30 tons of cocaine a month into the United States during the late 1990's was convicted by a federal jury here today of two counts of drug conspiracy.

description: The toughest diagnosis that Matthew Hajzl made last month was on his credit card statement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Becomes Lender
description: The budget airline Ryanair will offer personal loans with G.E. Capital Woodchester to Irish and British customers for amounts between 2,000 and 20,000 euros ($2,363 and $23,630), typically at an annual rate of 10.9 percent, the company said. Ryanair entered the Irish personal-finance market, which is dominated by a handful of large Irish banks, earlier this year with an MBNA affiliate credit card. G.E. Capital Woodchester is a G.E. Capital subsidiary. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Play It Again, On Purpose Or by Accident
description: The term ''da capo'' tells musicians to go back and play something again. For the Da Capo Chamber Players, this principle of repetition extended even to accidents on Tuesday night. The A string on Jane Chung's violin slipped badly from its pitch not once but twice during Mario Davidovsky's ''Quartetto'' at the ensemble's Merkin Hall recital, each time requiring stopping completely and starting over.

title: Bush Visit Will Lift Poland to Status of Special Friend
description: President Bush is scheduled to stop in Poland later this week to spend a few hours on Friday and Saturday in the southern city of Krakow, and the point of his visit is obvious: to thank this country for supporting American policy in Iraq when other, bigger members of the Atlantic alliance campaigned vociferously against it.

title: An Advocate for Children, a Keeper of the Faith
description: IT is hard for some to believe in the resurrection of the body. But the resurrection of the spirit colors more lives than one might suspect. For Kevin M. Ryan, Gov. James E. McGreevey's chief advocate for child welfare, that resurrection had its beginnings when he was a student at Catholic University of America in Washington, and he and his future wife, Clare, worked in the priests' dining hall.

title: Enlisting the Young As White-Hat Hackers
description: ON a Wednesday evening, in an office suite appointed with Pentium II's and little else, 10 teenagers were doing Andrew Robinson's bidding. Fortified by pizza and soda, they studied a computer system's weaknesses, looking for ways to break in and steal information. Mr. Robinson urged them on, like a modern-day Fagin goading his band of pickpockets.

title: Financial Data Sought in Case Involving Bomb in Officer's Car
description: Amonth after a prison inmate was charged with paying an accomplice to plant a bomb in a police officer's sport utility vehicle in Brooklyn Heights, prosecutors say they are seeking to subpoena the inmate's financial records to see whether he paid others to commit crimes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: H.I.V. Drug Cleared
description: Regulators gave the Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche approval to market Fuzeon, an H.I.V. drug, in the European Union. Fuzeon, developed by Trimeris, a biopharmaceutical company in Durham, N.C., blocks the virus's access to healthy immune cells. Fuzeon, which must be injected twice a day, is active against H.I.V. strains that have become resistant to current therapies. The drug has been approved in the United States and Switzerland. With European approval, Fuzeon is expected to bring peak sales of 1 billion Swiss francs ($777 million) a year for Roche. In February, Roche took the unusual step of announcing in advance the drug's price of 52 euros ($61) a day to warn health care providers, insurance companies and governments that will pay for the medicine. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Economy Slows
description: Malaysia's economy grew at its slowest pace in a year in the first quarter. Gross domestic product expanded 4 percent from a year earlier, in line with analysts' expectations and slowing from a revised 5.4 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent To Sell $1.3 Billion In Convertible Debt
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell about $1.3 billion of convertible senior bonds to gain more financial flexibility. The company, based in Murray Hill, N.J., also said it had obtained $595 million of new senior credit facilities secured by assets. Lucent, which has twice sold more than $1 billion of the stock-bond hybrids in the past, said it expected to use net proceeds from the sale of 20-year and 22-year convertible debt to retire debt, and for general corporate purposes. The sale reflects growing investor optimism regarding companies that have struggled in the three-year stock bear market. Lucent shares have fallen 97 percent from their December 1999 peak of $84.19. The shares fell 9 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $2.28 yesterday on the Nasdaq Stock Market. They fell another 4 cents, to $2.24, in after-hours trading. May has been the second-busiest month for United States convertible issuance, Thomson First Call said. Thirty-seven companies, the second-most ever, have sold $10.3 billion of convertibles in May, Thomson said.

title: Next for Albany: Rents and the Environment
description: For the first time since their bruising budget battle ended with a resounding defeat for Gov. George E. Pataki, the State Legislature's two leaders met with the governor today to set priorities for the rest of the legislative session.

title: TV Stations to Put Antennas On New Ground Zero Tower
description: The 1,776-foot Freedom Tower planned at the World Trade Center site is meant to send a signal of resilience to the world. Now it will also be designed to send signals of another kind to households from the New Jersey Shore to the end of Long Island to Fairfield County, Conn.

title: Saudis Arrest 8 in Deadly Riyadh Bombing
description: A series of police raids around the holy city of Medina on Tuesday and today led to the capture of eight suspected militants wanted in connection with the bombing attacks on residential compounds in the Saudi capital.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Carmaker Tempers Outlook
description: The European carmaker PSA Peugeot Citron said it might not meet its 2003 goal of increasing profit as much as 6.5 percent because of the decline in the European car market and the appreciation of the euro. The French automaker will not give any new profit target until July 24, when it releases first-half earnings, its chief executive, Jean-Martin Folz, said at Peugeot's annual shareholders' meeting in Paris. ''The economic decline and foreign-exchange movement are a big challenge for us,'' Mr. Folz said. ''Meeting our targets will be very difficult this year.''

title: Quarantine Hits Toronto School In SARS Fight
description: Health authorities today quarantined as many as 2,000 students, teachers and staff members of a large parochial school on the outskirts of Toronto that was closed after an 11th-grade student attended classes for two days last week while showing symptoms of SARS.

title: Ex-Chief of ImClone Systems To Be Sentenced on June 10
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems who pleaded guilty to securities fraud, perjury and other charges last year, will be sentenced at a hearing June 10, the federal judge in his case said yesterday.

title: ONEX TO BUY CONTROLLING STAKE IN MAGELLAN HEALTH
description: The Onex Corporation will pay as much as $200 million to take a controlling interest in Magellan Health Services Inc., the bankrupt manager of mental-health plans. Onex, a holding company that owns electronics, auto parts and other businesses, will pay stock and cash to buy about 45 percent of Magellan when the company emerges from bankruptcy in the next few months, the companies said. Magellan, the largest manager of mental-health plans in the United States, said it expected that to happen by the end of September. It filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in March with almost $1.5 billion in debt. The company lost business when the insurer Aetna Inc. shrank its membership to focus on more profitable health plans. Onex is based in Toronto, and Magellan is based in Columbia, Md.

title: Cold War Long Over, Bush Administration Examines Steps to a Revamped Arsenal
description: Backed by Congressional sentiment favoring a new approach to nuclear weapons, the Bush administration is taking steps that could lead to revamping the nation's cold-war-era atomic arsenal to meet what officials describe as more imminent modern threats.

title: Microsoft to Pay $750 Million to AOL in Settlement
description: SEATTLE -- Microsoft Corp. will pay AOL Time Warner $750 million and let the media company license its browser software for seven years in a settlement to resolve an antitrust lawsuit against the software giant, the companies announced Thursday.

title: Comptroller Opposes Mayor On Nonpartisan Elections
description: Taking aim at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for a second straight day, William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller, lashed out last night at the mayor's plan to establish nonpartisan city elections. He called the idea flawed and said the commission studying the matter was an unnecessary expense.

title: Dear Customer, G.M. Says, We've Improved
description: General Motors is ready to try the redemption card.

description: Kurds celebrated a major political victory today after electing a Kurd to head the local interim government in this oil-producing northern city, which for years had been dominated by Arabs from the Baath Party of Saddam Hussein.

title: Corrections
