title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, , HELEN W.
description: MEYER--Helen W. passed away peacefully in her sleep in San Francisco on May 25, 2003 several weeks after a severe stroke at age 92. Helen was born April 16, 1911, the youngest of six children of immigrant parents, Fanny & Frank Wallerstein. After completing studies to become a teacher for educationally handicapped children, she taught in NYC elementary schools for a number of years. In the early 1940's she married Dr. William C. Meyer and they moved to Pomona, CA where they lived for many years with Helen continuing her work as a special education teacher. After retirement she and ''Bill'' moved to Santa Barbara where they enjoyed sailing, tennis, a rich cultural life in music and theater and the congenial company of many friends and relatives. Although they had no children of their own, they became the favorite uncle and aunt to their nieces and nephews and played important roles in each of their lives. ''Bill'' died in 1983. Helen continued to live in Santa Barbara until 1998 when she relocated to Coventry Park Retirement Center in San Francisco to be near her close relatives. She is survived by many loving nieces and nephews and their children. For information contact Sinai Memorial Chapel, SF. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, , GERALDINE SWIMM
description: KING--Geraldine Swimm of Springfield, formerly of Short Hills, NJ on Monday May 26, 2003. Wife of the late John James Van Nostrand King. Mother of Robert C. King and Martha King Rickenback. Grandmother of Victoria King Kerman, Robert C. King, Jr, John Frazier Baker and Elizabeth Baker Clippinger. Funeral service private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Springfield Volunteer First Aid Squad, PO Box 247, Springfield, New Jersey 07081. >>AD#

title: Times Reporter Steps Down Amid Criticism
description: Rick Bragg, a Pulitzer Prize-winning national correspondent for The New York Times, resigned yesterday, five days after the newspaper published an editors' note that said he had relied heavily on the reporting of a freelance journalist for an article about the oystermen of the Florida Gulf Coast.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: Call For U.N. Tribunal
description: More than 90 American religious leaders and organizations have issued a statement urging creation of an international tribunal under United Nations auspices to try Indonesian military and police officials accused of human rights violations in East Timor. Indonesia has set up its own human rights court, but the religious leaders called that court, which so far has acquitted 12 of 17 defendants, a ''sham.'' East Timor won its independence from Indonesia in 1999 after 24 years that included periods of ethnic and religious violence and rights abuses. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Mixed News on Brazil Economy Is Good News for President
description: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 29 — Brazil's economy shrank 0.1 percent in the first quarter compared with the last three months of 2002, but grew by 2 percent compared with the same period last year, providing the left-leaning government of President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva with some good economic news.

title: Turn On the Grill for Music, Hot Dogs and Ballgames
description: Cal Spas, in Pomona, Calif., has introduced the barbecue equivalent of a Hummer: a $27,000 grill and entertainment center with five burners, three miniature television screens, a weather-resistant stereo system and a DVD player. Four retractable awnings complete the look. Who will buy? ''Athletes, movie stars and anybody who has the means to make other neighbors jealous,'' said Rob Santos, the company's national sales and service coordinator. The Gourmet 3000 Sports Bar and Grill requires an extension cord and natural gas or propane (it doesn't accept charcoal). For information, www.calspas.com or (800) 225-7727. ELAINE LOUIE

description: Thanks to an infusion of federal and private money, some $2.4 billion in spending is in the works for new and revamped museums, theaters and other projects in and around the nation's capital.

description: The University of Miami's president, Donna Shalala, received authorization this morning from the executive committee of the university's board of trustees to negotiate the Hurricanes' joining the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: Hong Kong Names a Panel to Plan for SARS
description: Hong Kong's leader named a panel of international experts today to draft contingency plans for another SARS outbreak next winter, but said no specific official would be investigated in the government's handling of the disease here this spring.

title: Microsoft and AOL Time Warner Settle Antitrust Suit
description: Microsoft agreed to pay AOL Time Warner $750 million in a legal settlement yesterday that ends one of the most bitter rivalries in modern corporate history and commits the two companies to a sweeping program of business cooperation.

title: Updating Media Constraints
description: Six decades ago, when television was so new the nation had yet to discover ''I Love Lucy,'' the government wisely decided to create a federal regulatory system to make sure that one -- or two or three -- media barons could not get a stranglehold on the flow of information in the United States. Back then, viewers desperately fiddled with their sets' rabbit ears in hopes of getting access to more than one station. Now we sit and click our way through a couple of hundred options. Everything has changed except the importance of preserving a competitive media marketplace, open to multiple owners and programmers.

title: Retail Sales Pace Picks Up, Hinting of Broader Rebound
description: The first signs of a postwar pickup in consumer spending are emerging, reducing the chances that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates when it meets next month.

title: U.S., in Assessment, Terms Trailers Germ Laboratories
description: The Bush administration yesterday made public its assessment of two mysterious trailers found in Iraq, calling them mobile units to produce deadly germs and the strongest evidence yet that Saddam Hussein had been hiding a program to prepare for biological warfare.

title: Wallpaper Seems to Be Sewn Onto the Wall
description: Petra Blaisse and Rem Koolhaas turned the collaboration of draper and designer into something combustibly seductive. For example, her hand-knitted oversize knot of gray polyester trails around (on a mechanized track) the SoHo Prada store he designed. Now, Ms. Blaisse is turning her hand to vinyl wallpaper ($14.95 a yard), with ''Touch,'' an eight-piece collection for Wolf-Gordon. The patterns are based on digital images of her favorite materials, including cross-stitched threads (below) and knits (shown with Ms. Blaisse, bottom) enlarged 300 percent and color-tinted. Information, www.Wolf-Gordon.com. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: Cutting Grass Without Ruffling The Neighbors
description: There are few things as lovely as a freshly manicured lawn -- and few things as annoying as listening to it being mowed. A cordless electric mower, the Neuton, makes about half the noise of a conventional mower, the manufacturer says, and at 48 pounds it can be easily maneuvered. Especially helpful for those with small yards, the Neuton comes with a rechargeable battery and mows for about an hour before running out of juice. It stores easily, too, folding to fit a two-by-three-foot space. Attachments, sold separately, include an edger and a bagger to hold clippings. The Neuton is $399 from Country Home Products, (800) 929-8401, or www.neutonmowers.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Speaking in the Gulf state of Veracruz, President Vicente Fox said Pemex planned to spend $30 billion in the next 15 years to develop the Chicontepec Reserve, with estimated reserves of 18 billion barrels. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRANNON, , CHARLES L.
description: GRANNON -- Charles L. Charles (''Chuck'') Lee Grannon a former partner of Goldman, Sachs & Co., New York, NY, and resident of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ died March 7, 2003 at age 87. Grannon spent his entire career at Goldman Sachs & Co., joining the firm in 1945, he became a partner in 1959, and a limited partner in 1982. In 1972 he was Chairman of the Corporate Finance Committee of the SIA, a Financial Industry oversight group. Grannon served twice in the Navy, first during World War II from May 1942 until October 1945. During that time he served on Admiral Nimitz's staff in the South Pacific. He was called back in 1951 for the Korean War and served in Washington, DC. He became a Lieutenant Commander in 1951 and was discharged in 1952. He served as a director of Federal - Mogul Corporation from 1968 until 1986. He was also a life trustee of DePauw University in Greencastle, IN, and a lifetime honorary director and past Vice Chairman of the University of Iowa Foundation. Recently, the Valley Hospital Foundation of Ridgewood, NJ elected Grannon, a past president, as an Honorary Life Trustee. He has also served on the boards of several other charitable organizations including: President of the Center for Group Counseling in Boca Raton, FL; Trustee at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, NJ; President of the philanthropic Shamrock Society of Boca Raton, FL. He has also been active with the YMCA of Ridgewood, NJ as a Trustee for over twenty years. Through the generosity of Charles and Alice Fay, endowed scholarship programs in business have been established at both DePauw University and the University of Iowa. He was born on December 2, 1915 in Lafayette, IN, the son of Charles D. Grannon and Verena Ruth Benedict Grannon. He received a B.S. from Purdue University, Lafayette, IN in 1939. In 1941 he received an M.A. in Economics from the University of Iowa and married Alice Fay Conard. They were married until her death in December 1995. In 1988, both Charles and Alice Fay were honored by the University of Iowa with a joint Distinguished Alumni Service Award. He graduated from Jefferson High School, Lafayette, IN in 1934. He is survived by his four sons; Michael L. (Lee) of New Canaan, CT; Craig C. (Linda) of Burr Ridge IL; Charles P. (Sandi) of Bloomington, IN; Mark W. (Gai) of New York City, and two grandchildren, Emily and Christopher. A memorial service will be held Saturday, May 31st at 9:30am at C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 East Ridgewood Ave at Maple Avenue in Ridgewood, NJ. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LATTES, , RAFFAELE
description: LATTES--Raffaele. The faculty, staff and students of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons are saddened by the passing of Raffaele Lattes, M.D. Prof. Emeritus of Pathology. Dr. Lattes was born in Turin, Italy in 1910 and received his M.D. degree there in 1933. Following the enactment of racial laws in Italy he came to the U.S. in 1940 and joined the Columbia Faculty in 1943. He received a Doctor of Medical Science degree from Columbia in 1946. Dr. Lattes served as Prof. of Surgery and then as Prof. of Surgical Pathology at Columbia and continued to serve for many years after his formal retirement in 1978 before returning to Italy in 1998. Dr. Lattes was one of the foremost experts in surgical pathology of his generation and the mentor for many of todays leaders in the field. His work on the pathology of soft tissue tumors contributed immensely to our scientific knowledge and treatment of human cancers. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. The family requests that memorials be contributed to the Conrad G. Lattes Scholarship Fund at Columbia University. Kathleen O'Toole, M.D., Director, Surgical Pathology Michael L. Shelanski, M.D. Ph.D., Chairman, Department of Pathology Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D., Exec Vice President & Dean, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Shareholder Suit Dismissed
description: Rambus Inc. said yesterday that a federal judge in northern California had dismissed a lawsuit filed by shareholders who accused the company of using fraud to secure patents for high-speed memory chips. Rambus, which designs computer chips used by customers including Sony and Intel, said in a statement that the shareholders suing the company requested that the lawsuit be dismissed after a federal appeals court ruled in Rambus's favor. Rambus shares rose $1.11, or 6.8 percent, to $17.55 in Nasdaq Stock Market trading yesterday. A federal appeals court in Washington on April 4 refused to reconsider its ruling that Rambus did not commit fraud while pursuing patents for high-speed chips. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit had previously determined that Rambus fulfilled its legal obligations under patent disclosure rules established in the early 1990's. Nonetheless, Rambus is on trial on related charges in Washington before a Federal Trade Commission administrative law judge. The F.T.C. has accused Rambus of maneuvering to collect billions of dollars in royalties by deceiving competitors into adopting its secretly patented computer-chip technology as an industry standard.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, taking note of the criminal investigation of a Brooklyn judge and other scandals, called on political party bosses yesterday to loosen their hold on the selection of Civil Court judges and Supreme Court justices in favor of independent panels.

title: New Tour Pays Homage to Poetry and Cheesecake
description: It does not sail gaily by the Gowanus Canal. It eschews the scenery of the auto body shops on Fourth Avenue. It turns away before reaching the storied Navy Yard, Coney Island or the Ebbets Field housing development.

title: When Passing Up a Slam Produces a Better Score
description: To say that the result of a deal is unique in the history of the game might seem rash, but this department would be willing to make a small wager about the one shown in the diagram. There is, of course, no way to prove the point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUGER, , DANIEL, M.D.
description: LUGER--Daniel, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and longtime friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his entire family. William G. Stein, M.D.-Pres. Barry D. Stimmel, M.D.-V.P. Elliot J. Rayfield, M.D.-Secy. Betty J. Mintz, M.D.-Treas. >>AD#

title: In Vienna, 'Matrix' Meets 'Sound Of Music'
description: SHORTLY after Jrgen Bauer and Beatrix Roidinger moved into their house, two police officers on their midnight rounds walked onto the property, mistaking it for a construction site. They walked all the way into the master bedroom before realizing their error. ''Who are you?'' one of them asked the startled residents. ''We live here,'' Mr. Bauer replied from beneath the bedcovers.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lacey Township: Nuclear Plant Back In Service
description: A nuclear power plant shut down because of equipment failure in a nonnuclear part of the plant has returned to service, while, in an unrelated dispute, its work force is out on strike and has been replaced with nonunion workers. The plant, the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, resumed operation Tuesday and returned to full power yesterday, a spokesman for the plant said. An emergency generator, which powers alarms, sensors and security cameras, failed May 20. On May 22, more than 200 plant workers, members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 1289, walked out after a contract dispute. When the plant reopened, their positions were temporarily filled with nonunion workers, the spokesman said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand/Australia: New Zealand: Exchange To Sell Shares
description: The operator of New Zealand's stock exchange, NZSE Ltd., plans to sell shares next month and become the world's 11th exchange to go public. NZSE, based in Wellington, plans to raise 15 million New Zealand dollars ($8.7 million) in an initial public offer and by selling more stock to the 330 brokers that own the company. (Bloomberg News)

title: OFFICE DEPOT SAYS PROFIT MAY FALL SHORT OF FORECASTS
description: Office Depot Inc. said second-quarter profit might be lower than analysts' forecasts because of price discounting and reduced demand for costlier items like furniture. The company expects profit excluding some costs of 16 cents to 18 cents a share, compared with the 18 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Net income will fall to 14 cents to 16 cents a share from 18 cents a year earlier, the company said. Office Depot's profit will fall for a second consecutive quarter as it tries to increase sales with price cuts. Sales at stores open at least a year will decline 4 percent during the period, the 13th consecutive quarterly drop. Gross profit margins at North American stores will narrow by 2 percentage points, the company said. Shares of Office Depot fell 50 cents, or 4 percent, to $13.20 a share.

title: Absence of a Backhand Spells Defeat for a Russian in Paris
description: PARIS, May 29  During the course of her second-round match today at the French Open, Evgenia Koulikovskaya did not make a single backhand error. So why was such accuracy and consistency not rewarded with a better result than a 6-3, 6-2 defeat at the hands of Magdalena Maleeva?

title: Lost Season for Vaughn, Lost Night for the Mets
description: The season is most likely over for Mo Vaughn. This afternoon, in a two-hour meeting with Mets officials, Vaughn and his agent, Jeff Moorad, provided the club with medical reports on the severity of Vaughn's arthritic left knee.

title: A Suffolk Lawmaker Admits Taking Bribes, and Resigns
description: A Suffolk County legislator pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he took more than $10,000 in bribes and made personal use of more than $10,000 in campaign funds.

title: In This Playground, A Wheelchair Is Not a Handicap
description: A combination play structure and stage at Merry Place, a public park in Havertown, Pa., has ramps, above, for children who are wheelchair-bound, a wall with found objects that rattle and bang, and a separate storytelling area, top. The $30,000 project, designed and built by architecture students at the University of Pennsylvania, was sponsored by the Foundation for Art, Architecture, Research and Making, which is in Philadelphia and which showcases unconventional uses of architecture while giving students hands-on experience. ''This is the first place in the country where kids in wheelchairs can climb up into the air and look down on the world,'' said Tim McDonald, an executive director of the foundation. MARC KRISTAL

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Nuclear Treaty Clears Last Hurdle
description: The upper house of Parliament approved the treaty in which Russia and the United States pledged to reduce their arsenals of strategic nuclear weapons by two-thirds -- to fewer than 2,200 each -- over the next decade. Two weeks after the lower house approved it, the Federation Council voted overwhelmingly -- 140 to 5, with two abstentions -- to adopt the treaty, signed by President Vladimir V. Putin and President Bush last May. Russia's foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, told the Interfax news agency that the vote would allow the two leaders to formally adopt the treaty when they meet in St. Petersburg this weekend. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Water Tap Often Shut to South Africa Poor
description: The afternoon's end brings a rural rush hour of women walking down the dirt road that winds through this village. Many of them barefoot and dressed in rags, the mothers and grandmothers come pushing wheelbarrows or carrying big buckets to fetch water for their families.

title: Software Company's Battle Over Unix Produces Profit
description: A recent campaign of litigation and warnings by a Utah software marketer against companies that use Linux has helped make the company profitable for the first time ever, it said yesterday.

title: An Anchor on the Dashboard For Gadgets That Travel
description: Finding a dashboard holder for your cellphone, palmtop computer or pocket navigational system can be complicated if your device or your car is not among the most popular models.

title: A Better Class Of Competition
description: A week before spring training ended, Jeremy Bonderman got the news that had seemed highly unlikely a few months earlier. He had made the Detroit Tigers' roster and would pitch the second game of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIMET, , MELVIN
description: ZIMET--Melvin, 90, of New York City and Hanover, NH, died on May 27, 2003. Beloved husband of Janet Ginandes and the late Joan Zimet. Loving father of John Zimet, his wife Kristen and Paul Zimet, his wife Ellen, stepfather to Peter and Carol Ginandes and grandfather of Anya, Isaac, Zachary, Nicholas, Deborah and Mark and great grandfather to Joshua and Capeley. Until his retirement in 1983, he was a faculty member of Manhattan College Graduate Business School serving as Chairman of the Management Department and as Director of the School of Business Research Institute. During the Second World War, he was a Field Representative of Wright Aeronautical. He and his first wife moved to Kendal, Hanover, NH in 1991. A memorial service will be held at Kendal, Hanover, NH on June 21. >>AD#

title: Details Set for Meeting With Bush in Mideast
description: President Bush will hold a three-way meeting in Jordan next week with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and Mahmoud Abbas, the new Palestinian prime minister, White House officials said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Fan in Charge, if Only for a Day
description: WHEN Roger Farina landed his Army Chinook helicopter in Iraq during the recent conflict, he stepped out wearing the orange jacket of the Islanders, the team of his childhood.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MAINE: TOUGH PENALTIES FOR 2 FISH FARMS A federal judge in Portland imposed strong penalities on two salmon farms in the state, which had been operating without permits required under the Clean Water Act. The judge, Gene Carter, ordered Atlantic Salmon of Maine and Stolt Sea Farm not to stock fish until permits had been issued. Judge Carter ruled that after the fish now in the cages are harvested that the farms be fallow for two years before production can start again to allow the sea floor to recover from pollution created by the fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLICOTT, , JOSEPH REMINGTON
description: ELLICOTT--Joseph Remington on May 25, 2003. Dear husband of Marie and devoted father of Diane, Judy and Jill and devoted grand-dad of Greg, Geoff, Amy, Ben and Joe. Joe will rest at Moritz Funeral Home, 348 Closter Dock Road, Closter, New Jersey on Friday, May 30 from 14 PM. Service following immediately after at Alpine Methodist Church, 1 Old Dock Road, Alpine, NJ. A private burial at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. >>AD#

title: 76ers Can Talk to Van Gundy
description: The Knicks granted the Philadelphia 76ers permission yesterday to interview Jeff Van Gundy about their head coaching position. Van Gundy has already spoken to Cleveland and Houston about jobs, and he turned down an opportunity to be interviewed by New Orleans.

title: Media Deregulation Foes Make Murdoch Their Lightning Rod
description: Opponents of media deregulation are running advertisements depicting the media mogul Rupert Murdoch as the scowling face of industry consolidation, including commercials being shown today on his company's Fox News Channel in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A question-and-answer interview in Science Times on May 20 with Dr. Lee Clarke, an expert in disaster studies, referred incorrectly to his standing in the field. Though he is a leading researcher, he was not a founder of the field; researchers have studied people's responses to disasters for more than 50 years.

title: New Take On Turkey
description: The Kennedy clan had a motto that fits the relationship now being worked out between Turkey and the U.S.: ''Forgive but don't forget.''

title: She Doesn't Need Her Vocal Chords to Sing
description: The show is just a saucy piece of silliness, and it gets off to an adolescent start (the Bride of Frankenstein with singing breasts), but there's a lot of talent onstage in ''Boobs! The Musical,'' subtitled ''The World According to Ruth Wallis.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HIGH RIVER LP, the investment company controlled by Carl C. Icahn, extended its $100-per-unit cash offer for Hallwood Realty Partners LP, Dallas, owner of 5.1 million square feet of office and industrial properties, to June 12.

title: Steady Rationale at Court Despite Apparent Bend
description: At first glance, the Supreme Court appeared to have been overcome on Tuesday by a belated case of judicial modesty.

title: Who Knew? A Shangri-La Within Driving Distance
description: Shorter vacations are again in vogue as a weak-kneed economy persuades more Americans to stick close to home. But coming up with a destination that is both nearby and unexplored can be tricky.

title: Apple Finds a Route For Online Music Sales
description: Apple Computer seems to have the future of online music in its hands for the moment. Its new service, iTunes Music Store, has been the first real success story in the long effort to sell music over the Internet. In just its first month of operation the service, by the company's estimate, has sold three million songs online, at 99 cents each. This is an impressive figure considering the limited access that music fans now have to the service. Less than 1 percent of the country's home computers are Macintoshes that are compatible with the iTunes Music Store, and only a fraction of those have a broadband connection to the Internet.

title: VAXGEN SHARES LEAP AS U.S. BACKS ANTHRAX VACCINE TEST
description: Shares of VaxGen Inc., which is developing AIDS and smallpox vaccines, surged 68 percent after the company said it had won federal regulatory approval to begin testing a product to protect against anthrax. VaxGen and rival biotechnology companies in the United States have increased research on anthrax treatments after anonymous mailings of the bacteria that cause the disease killed five people in 2001. Testing of VaxGen's product on about 100 volunteers will begin in June, a company spokesman, Lance Ignon, said yesterday. Stock in VaxGen, based in Brisbane, Calif., gained $2.28, to $5.62 a share.

title: Inspections Were Lacking, Shuttle Panel Member Says
description: Confidential interviews with shuttle workers at NASA and its contractors, ''from line technicians all the way through management,'' found no one who believed that preflight safety inspections were adequate, a member of the independent board investigating the loss of the Columbia said here today.

title: From Hot Rods to Racehorses, It's All in the Bonding
description: GALLOP RACER 2003: A NEW BREED

title: In Insurance Cost, Woes for Doctors and Women
description: Shannon Minor went to the drugstore last year to buy a home pregnancy test, picked up the local newspaper and read some bad news: her obstetrician, Barbara Pringle, was planning to stop delivering babies.

title: Shareholder Sues John Hancock Over Executive Pay Levels
description: A shareholder of John Hancock Financial Services filed a civil suit in federal court yesterday over the compensation of the company's chief executive and other senior executives, seeking the return to John Hancock of much of the $42.3 million they received.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Garden Q.&A. column on April 3 about ornamental sweet potato vines referred imprecisely to one of their growth habits. While they can indeed form large, edible tubers, that seldom occurs in the small containers in which they are usually grown. Two readers notified The Times on April 4 about the error; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: A Daughter's Idyll, a Mother's Chore
description: ONE thing E.B. White and my two older daughters have in common is their love of Maine. Perhaps this is because all three of them spent considerable portions of their childhoods there, Mr. White in a lakeside cottage with his family and my daughters at a girls' sleepaway camp.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Financial Data Sought In Bomb Case
description: A month after a prison inmate was charged with paying an accomplice to plant a bomb in a police officer's sport utility vehicle in Brooklyn Heights, prosecutors say they are seeking to subpoena the inmate's financial records to see whether he paid others to commit crimes. The inmate, Stephen Alster, 66, was charged last month with paying a jailhouse acquaintance to plant five crude bombs and two guns in the officer's vehicle on March 31. He was not seeking to harm the officer with the bombs, which had no triggers, the police and prosecutors have said. Instead, prosecutors say, Mr. Alster was trying to make it appear that he was wrongly convicted last year for setting off a pipe bomb in the officer's Brooklyn Heights home in 2001. Robert A. Solomon, a lawyer who handles Mr. Alster's finances and is representing him in a civil lawsuit, has hired his own lawyer to fight the subpoena, saying that turning over Mr. Alster's records would violate lawyer-client privilege. A hearing on the matter has been set for next month, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENLER, , JONATHAN

title: Diffley Captures Met P.G.A. Title
description: Mike Diffley shot a second consecutive 68 and finished with a four-under-par 136 to beat Rick Hartmann by a shot and win the Tommy Hilfiger Met P.G.A. Head Pro championship at the Garden City Country Club on Long Island.

title: Teach Your Children, Virtually
description: MADELINE NELSON of Steubenville, Ohio, has been in the third grade since last fall but has met her teacher only a few times. She has plenty of schoolwork to do, including book reports and her favorite, art projects.

title: Sharon and Abbas to Meet, With Quite Different Agendas
description: With Middle East diplomacy gathering momentum, the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers are planning to have a crucial meeting on Thursday, with both sides saying it is time to move forward on an international peace plan. But the antagonists have set very different priorities.

title: New Palestinian Leader Hopeful Hamas Will End Attacks on Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  Just hours before a crucial meeting with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, said today that he expected to reach a cease-fire with the militant Islamic group Hamas in the coming week.

title: A New Jersey Fire Department Is Cited for Several Violations
description: The New Jersey Labor Department has cited the Gloucester City Fire Department for several violations of state law related to the burning and subsequent collapse of an apartment house in which three firefighters and three young sisters died last July 4.

title: State Oversight Urged as Way To Save Buffalo
description: After years of teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, Buffalo is faced with having to turn over its financial operations to a state board that would oversee nearly all major city spending.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Loses Munich Contract To Linux
description: Microsoft, the world's biggest software maker, is losing a contract to supply its Windows operating system for 14,000 Munich government computers because the city is switching to Linux. The conversion to Linux, a freely distributed, open-source program, will begin in 2004, the city said yesterday in an e-mailed statement. The city did not announce what company would be hired to make the change. Open-source programs let developers see the underlying code, make changes and pass along the result to others. The city's decision ''doesn't just ensure more provider independence for its I.T. infrastructure, but also sets a signal for more competition in the software market,'' said Christian Ude, the mayor of Munich, in the e-mailed statement. The switch by Munich, Germany's third-largest city, after Berlin and Hamburg, may help determine software purchases of other regional governments. Germany's Interior Ministry has framework agreements with Microsoft and I.B.M., which sells computers with Linux.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on May 15 with an article about a site in Venosa, Italy, where archaelogists are unearthing evidence of ancient Jewish communities, was published in error. It showed a painting of a seven-branched candelabrum that was found at the site many years ago, not a recently discovered carved stone candelabrum.

title: Willard G. Rouse III, 60, Dies; Shaped Philadelphia Skyline
description: Willard Goldsmith Rouse III, a scion of a family of builders who built his own niche with Liberty Property Trust of Malvern, Pa., a real estate business that includes some of the most visible peaks of the Philadelphia skyline, died on Tuesday at his home in Phoenixville, Pa. He was 60.

title: Shadows Are Gone for Two Veterans
description: Survivors of an ignominious era, Kerry Kittles and Lucious Harris could tell their teammates stories, if anyone wanted to listen.

title: For Sherpas, a Steep Climb
description: The world outside the Himalaya Mountains ''discovered'' Mount Everest in the 19th century. Since then, foreigners have sought to conquer, market and control it. Though Sherpas and their Tibetan kin had known Everest -- or Chomolungma -- for centuries, not one of them wanted to climb it until my grandfather, Tenzing Norgay, came along. He made it to the summit, with Sir Edmund Hillary, 50 years ago today -- and life for Sherpas has never been the same.

title: Environmental Groups Gain As Companies Vote on Issues
description: Almost a quarter of the shareholders of the Southern Company, one of the nation's largest utilities, voted at the annual meeting today to require the company to analyze and report on the potential financial risks associated with its emissions of the pollutants that cause global warming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEAUCLERK, , DR. WILLIAM T.
description: BEAUCLERK--Dr. William T., of New York City and East Hampton, passed away peacefully after a valiant battle with pancreatic cancer on May 28, 2003 surrounded by his loving family. Beloved husband of Melanie Puffpaff. Loving brother of Fran O'Connor. Brother-in-law of Jack O'Connor. Cherished uncle of Karen and Jerry Pace, Tracey Weir, Robert and Kim Weir. Loving greatuncle of Kevin and Jimmy Pace. Adored brother-in-law of Marilyn Weir. Son-in-law of Martin Puffpaff. Dr. Beauclerk received his B.A. from Queens College and his Master's Degree and Ph.D. in Philosophy and Psychology from N.Y.U. Recently retired professor of Brooklyn College and clinical psychologist in private practice in New York City. A gentle soul, always a mentor and teacher, his legacy will be the memory of his goodness, passionate love of life, and pursuit of knowledge. He leaves behind the richness of many memories he gave to others. Friends may call Friday evening 5-7PM at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street followed by funeral service at 7PM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Humane Society, 306 E. 59th St., New York, NY 10022. >>AD#

title: M.T.A. Projects Threatened By Federal Money Changes
description: New York could lose $300 million a year in federal transportation money, an amount that could threaten subway maintenance and expansion projects like the proposed Second Avenue Station, according to a report by researchers at New York University.

title: Gucci to Pay Shareholders To Ease Its Sale to Pinault
description: The Gucci Group said today that it would lavish 1.34 billion euros, or $1.58 billion, on its shareholders in a move that is expected to reduce the amount that its biggest shareholder will have to pay next year to buy the Gucci shares it does not already own.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Coach Plans To Sue School District
description: A high school baseball coach who was suspended after leading a spring break trip to Florida during which 15 players visited a strip club filed papers yesterday in State Supreme Court saying he intended to sue the Massapequa school district. The coach, Robert Dell, said he should not have been punished for the actions of the students, who visited the club during their free time. Mr. Dell also filed a defamation lawsuit yesterday against two parents, whom he blamed for a letter that alerted school officials to the visit. The letter noted Mr. Dell's supervisory role. Mr. Dell charged that the parents named in the suit had defamed him because they thought he was not letting their sons play enough. The parents and a school district official did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: In Sherpa Country, They Love 'Sir Ed'
description: Fifty years ago, Edmund Hillary went up Everest an amiable New Zealand beekeeper and came down a 20th-century icon. But looking back this week, Sir Edmund said here that he was equally proud of what he did with the rest of his life: helping the Sherpa people of the Himalayas.

title: But change would have had minor effect : Expatriates weather threat to tax exclusion
description: PARIS:  Americans working abroad breathed a collective sigh of relief last week as Congress jettisoned an item in the tax reduction bill that would have repealed the $80,000 expatriate earned-income exclusion. The provision, section 911 of the Internal Revenue Service code, allows U.S. taxpayers who are foreign residents to exclude up to $80,000 of money earned from services performed abroad from their gross income, and calculate their U.S. taxes only on the rest.

description: AS Judge Lewis A. Kaplan took his seat in Courtroom 12D in United States District Court in Manhattan, the plaintiff's lawyer sheepishly raised a question. He needed help connecting a laptop that contained a PowerPoint presentation that a witness would use during questioning. A court clerk sprang into action, and minutes later the cover page of the witness's presentation appeared on the courtroom's monitors.

description: The best moment of Andre Agassi's long career came at Roland Garros in 1999, when he finally won here. He has a less sentimental relationship with the Suzanne Lenglen Court.

description: An article in Science Times on May 27 about volunteers for H.I.V. vaccine trials misstated the affiliation of Elmerlene Robertson, a recruiter for them. She is with the University of Illinois at Chicago, not the University of Chicago.

title: Money Gone, U.S. Suspends Designations Of Habitats
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service says it will temporarily stop designating tracts of land as critical habitats under the Endangered Species Act within a matter of weeks because the program has depleted its money for this fiscal year.

title: Somnolent Encounters of the Seductive Kind
description: ''Molly's Dream'' is an oddity in the work of Maria Irene Fornes, the Cuban-born playwright known for lyrical dramas. The play is neither lyrical nor dramatic. Rather, it is a surreal comedy with music, a romantic fantasy set in a seedy barroom, and it has the tentative feel of an experiment.

title: Versions of Old Yacht Deck Chairs Now Lie at Anchor in Gardens
description: THE inspiration for many garden lounge chairs are the steamer chairs that lined the decks of great old ocean vessels and yachts. Usually made of teak or mahogany, the steamer lounge and Australian veranda chair with extensions to support the legs were designs that most influenced the new outdoor furniture collection of Robert Martin, a Brooklyn designer.

title: SCHOLASTIC CORP. BLAMES SLOWING SALES FOR 400 LAYOFFS
description: The Scholastic Corporation, the publisher in the United States of the best-selling Harry Potter books, said it laid off about 400 employees, or 4 percent of its staff, because of slowing sales of educational and consumer books. The company, based in New York, said it would take an after-tax charge of $7 million, or 17 cents a share, in the current quarter, which ends Saturday. Mostly administrative and management jobs were cut, the company said. Pressure on school budgets has cut into sales, Ray Marchuk, Scholastic's vice president for finance and investor relations, said. The company's book club business has been weak for most of the last year, Mr. Marchuk said, and Scholastic has reported losses in two of its last three quarters.

title: ALLIES TO RETAIN LARGER IRAQ FORCE AS STRIFE PERSISTS
description: Faced with armed resistance that has killed four American soldiers this week, allied military commanders now plan to keep a larger force in Iraq than had been anticipated and to send war-hardened units to trouble spots outside Baghdad, senior American officials said today.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Air Academy Punishment
description: Air Force Secretary James G. Roche said there could still be punishment for Air Force Academy officials in the aftermath of a sexual assault scandal. Earlier this year, 57 women came forward with accusations of rape and sexual assault or harassment over several years and complaints that their claims were often dismissed or they were punished. Mr. Roche made his comments at a news conference before graduation ceremonies at the academy, in Colorado Springs, but did not mention the scandal in his commencement speech. Four officials were removed in March and new guidelines were put in place dealing with sexual assault cases. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Happy to Get Their Hands on Someone Else's Leftovers
description: Colorful classic kitchen bowls, oval fish platters, doughnut-shaped teapots and leaf plates were collecting dust in storage at the Hall China Company's factory in East Liverpool, Ohio. This overstock, all of it of fairly recent vintage, was not the stuff of collectors' dreams, and it would have flooded Hall's factory outlet in town. So a deal was made with Julie Gaines and Dave Lenovitz, above right, owners of Fishs Eddy, a small chain of stores that sell American-made dishware in the Flatiron district, the Upper West Side, Staten Island and East Hampton, N.Y.

title: 400 Years Later, Play Goes Hip-Hop; London Theater Changes Its Form To a Club Outing
description: Rodgers and Hart have gone hip-hop here, as a new generation of ''The Boys From Syracuse'' is bounding onstage in soulful song and dance as ''Da Boyz'' from East London.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: NEW AMBASSADOR TO INDIA Pakistan announced Aziz Ahmad Khan as its new ambassador to India and said that New Delhi had accepted the appointment, filling a post left vacant for more than a year amid heightened tensions between the two countries. Mr. Khan, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, will take over the ambassadorship after consultations with President Pervez Musharraf and other top officials, the ministry said in a statement. On May 9, India named Shiv Shankar Menon, a career diplomat, as its next ambassador to Pakistan, but he has not yet arrived. (AP)

title: FOSTER WHEELER AND BECHTEL TO BUILD PLANT IN CHINA
description: Foster Wheeler Ltd., a power-plant and refinery builder, the Bechtel Group and a Chinese engineering company won a contract to build a $4.3 billion petrochemicals plant in China's Guangdong Province. Specific allotments of funds under the contract were not disclosed. Closely held Bechtel, the world's largest construction company, and the others in the group, which is called BSF, will build the plant for CNOOC Ltd., a unit of the China National Offshore Oil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group's Shell Petrochemicals Company, a spokesman, Richard Tauberman said. The group, which includes Sinopec Engineering Inc., a unit of the China Petrochemical Corporation, won the design award for the plant in March 2001. The plant is scheduled to begin operations by the end of 2005.

title: 4 Men Jailed in China Accused of 'Subverting State Power'
description: BEIJING, May 29  Four young friends who met on university campuses to discuss their progressive politics and posted occasional essays on the Internet were sentenced here to long prison terms on Wednesday, accused of "subverting state power."

title: Two Americans Break 1849 Record

description: WARM weather instantly inspires a brilliant idea: lolling around for hours in the hammock. A glider on a porch or a swing hanging from a friendly tree also provide the quintessential way to spend a summer afternoon.

Steinbrenner, the Yankees' impetuous principal owner, huffed and puffed in a two-day tirade in the wake of his team's recent slide.

title: Palestinian Doctor Seized in Raid Denies Israeli Charges
description: JERUSALEM, May 29  A prominent Palestinian psychologist, detained after Israeli troops flattened his family compound and killed three of his militant brothers, pleaded innocent today to charges of weapons possession and incitement, relatives said.

title: A Weaving of Myth and Movement, With the Audience Helping
description: DanceAfrica has gradually become as much performance art as dance. The annual festival, now in its 26th year, has proved its point. The African continent has been scoured for new indigenous troupes. American companies have successfully blended traditional African and home-grown concert and popular dance forms. Though there was a full complement of imaginative, vividly costumed dance at the Saturday matinee at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the ancillary ingredients have become at least as important.

title: Honesty About Amtrak
description: This summer, Americans can travel by train without having to fear, as they did last year, that Amtrak may be out of business by Labor Day. Much beyond that, Amtrak's future becomes rather murky. America's approach to passenger rail remains woefully haphazard and shortsighted.

title: NATIONAL EQUIPMENT SAYS IT MAY FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: National Equipment Services Inc., one of the largest construction equipment rental companies in the nation, said it might file for bankruptcy after it defaulted on bank loans and was blocked from paying interest owed on $275 million in bonds. Wachovia Bank NA and other lenders, owed more than $495 million, exercised their right to block interest payments due as early as tomorrow on two series of senior subordinated notes, National Equipment said in a regulatory filing. Failure to pay within 30 days would be a default, giving noteholders the right to demand immediate payment of their principal, the company said. ''In light of the company's current condition, the company may seek protection from its creditors under Chapter 11,'' National Equipment, based in Evanston, Ill., said in the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: La-Z-Boy Talks of Possible Plant Closings
description: La-Z-Boy, the home furniture maker, said yesterday that it might close plants and extend vacation shutdowns after its quarterly sales fell amid declining demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SURY, , STANLEY J.

He was born and raised in Port Chester, NY and graduated from Port Chester High School in 1940. He was a veteran of World War II, serving in the United States Army in Panama. He was a longtime member of the Washington Engine & Hose Co. #

title: Harvard Dominates Opening Heats
description: Harvard more than confirmed its favored status to capture the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship regatta at Pennasuken, N.J. Not only did Harvards undefeated varsity boat win its qualifying heat, but so did five other Crimson entries.

title: If You Behave Yourself, I'll Print You a Toy
description: VIEWED through the fantastic lens of science fiction, three-dimensional printers seem as amazing as the transporters in ''Star Trek.'' In goes a digital idea of a thing and out comes the thing itself.

title: French Proposal for U.N. Force to Halt Congo Strife Gets Support
description: Mindful of continuing bloodshed that has killed or maimed hundreds of civilians in northeastern Congo, members of the United Nations Security Council rallied today around a French proposal to send a multinational force to the city of Bunia to prevent further massacres.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: H.I.V. DRUG CLEARED Regulators gave the Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche approval to market Fuzeon, an H.I.V. drug, in the European Union. Fuzeon, developed by Trimeris , a biopharmaceutical company in Durham, N.C., blocks the virus's access to healthy immune cells. Fuzeon, which must be injected twice a day, is active against H.I.V. strains that have become resistant to current therapies. The drug has been approved in the United States and Switzerland. With European approval, Fuzeon is expected to bring peak sales of 1 billion Swiss francs ($777 million) a year for Roche. In February, Roche took the unusual step of announcing in advance the drug's price of 52 euros ($61) a day to warn health care providers, insurance companies and governments that will pay for the medicine. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Copter Rescues 6 From Cliff
description: Rescuers plucked six hikers listed as missing since Tuesday off a steep cliff face in Gifford Pinchot National Forest in southern Washington. The hikers were in ''remarkably good'' health after a Coast Guard helicopter airlifted the group to an airport near Portland, Ore., said Patrick Brennan, an officer at the Coast Guard air station in Astoria, Ore. They are Timothy Hensley, 25, Alicia Hensley, 25, Russell Maddy, 23, Jaime Maddy, 24, and Jennifer Skoog, also in her 20's, all of Vancouver; and Matthew Margolis, 29, of Portland. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Judge Rules On Firehouse
description: A judge said yesterday that the city's closing of a firehouse in Queens was flawed, but he stopped short of ordering it reopened. The judge, James G. Starkey of State Supreme Court, ruled that the Bloomberg administration had failed to give proper notice to a Manhattan community board that it planned to close an engine company in Queens that serves as a backup for Roosevelt Island. Responding to a lawsuit brought by state and city officials, Justice Starkey reserved judgment on whether the firehouse, the home of Engine Company 261, should be reopened and when the clock would begin running on the required 45 days' notice. The firehouse was one of six closed on Sunday. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Funny Cide Looks Fit In Effortless Workout
description: With only nine days to go until the Belmont Stakes and with two races in the Triple Crown series complete, it is no longer so much about proving who has the best horse, but who can deliver a healthy and fit animal to the starting gate for the race on June 7. For that reason, it was a good morning for the Barclay Tagg stable and Funny Cide yesterday and a dismal one for a horse thought to be one of his main competitors.

title: Tax Law Omits $400 Child Credit for Millions
description: A last-minute revision by House and Senate leaders in the tax bill that President Bush signed today will prevent millions of minimum-wage families from receiving the increased child credit that is in the measure, say Congressional officials and outside groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PESKIN, , MARILYN
description: PESKIN -- Marilyn, died peacefully on May 27, 2003 at the age of 71. Beloved wife of Ira Peskin for 50 years. Cherished mother of Jill Saunders and Jeffrey Peskin, the daughter of the late May and Dave Schlissal and sister to Jerry Schlissal. Also survived by her two grandchildren, Michael and David Saunders, who lovingly called her ''Mama,'' and will miss her greatly. Mama was a woman of grace, elegance and charm. To know Mama is to love Mama. A special goodbye from her son-in-law, Jeff Saunders, who wishes she were here to see his flowers. Goodbye, Mama Marilyn, we all love you. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Selling Units
description: The British home-improvement retailer GUS will take some of its South African business public next year as part of a continuing strategy of selling noncore assets. GUS owns the Lewis Stores and Best Electric chains in South Africa. The company expects to raise as much as 250 million ($409.6 million). Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: NELKIN -- Dorothy. The trustees, faculty, staff, alumni and students of New York University School of Law are saddened by the loss of Professor Dorothy Nelkin. Professor Nelkin served NYU since 1988, both in the law school and in the Dept of Sociology. On behalf of the many law students she taught, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Dorothy's husband, Mark Nelkin, daughter, Lisa Nelkin, granddaughter, Erica Peckens, and her entire family. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Lester Pollack, Chairman, NYU School of Law Foundation Richard Revesz, Dean, NYU School of Law >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Troubled By Police Questioning
description: A federal judge who recently eased limits on police surveillance of political groups said yesterday that he was troubled by recent police questioning of antiwar demonstrators. The demonstrators were arrested and questioned about their past political activities, and their answers were recorded in a computer database. Lawyers for the group that opposed the easing of limits on police surveillance say the practice shows that the Police Department is flouting court-ordered guidelines. They asked the judge, Charles S. Haight Jr. of Federal District Court, to create a mechanism so the department could be held in contempt of court. A lawyer for the city said no action was necessary because the practice, which the police say has ended, served a legitimate law enforcement purpose. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Arrests In Lawyer's Killing
description: The British police arrested a man and a woman in connection with the killing of a well-known Roman Catholic lawyer in Belfast 13 years ago. There have been allegations that the British authorities colluded with the Protestant paramilitaries who shot the lawyer, Pat Finucane, a prominent legal defender of members of the Irish Republican Army. The male suspect, who has been brought to Northern Ireland for questioning, is thought to be Ken Barrett, a member of the paramilitary group responsible for the killing, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, the Press Association of the United Kingdom reported. Mr. Barrett said last year that the Northern Ireland police had ordered the killing. Brian Lavery (NYT)

If you need to sleep with a computer, this is what you want.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Complaint In Kidnapping Case
description: Members of a Manhattan realty group filed a complaint in civil court yesterday against the TriBeCa man accused of locking his bound and gagged business partner into an apartment crawlspace. In the complaint, members of Plot Realty LLC claim that the man, Lawrence Omansky, who is free on $100,000 bail after being charged with kidnapping last month, is an inept manager who refuses to give up his responsibilities. The members asked the court to remove him from the position of general manager. Benjamin Brafman, a lawyer representing Mr. Omansky in the criminal case, refused to comment on the new complaint, as he had not yet seen the court papers. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: McGraw Is a Believer In a Full Recovery
description: A malignant brain tumor, removed after six hours of surgery, has left Tug McGraw with a large scar across his forehead and a bald head. He admits he is still weary and he did not pretend today that his ordeal was an easy one while speaking haltingly as he relived the last few months. But cancer has done nothing to change the upbeat attitude that was one of his traits during his 19-year major league pitching career with the Mets and the Phillies.

title: Criticism Takes Toll on South Korean Leader
description: Barely three months into his five-year term, President Roh Moo Hyun is fighting for his political life.

title: Number of SARS Cases Falls Sharply in China
description: BEIJING, May 30  China has nearly tamed the SARS epidemic, with new cases dwindling and no evidence of the wildfire spread in the hinterlands that experts had feared, a senior health official said today.

World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Economic Slowdown
description: Philippine economic growth slowed to 4.5 percent in the first quarter compared with the same three months of 2002, falling from 5.8 percent growth in the fourth quarter, according to government statistics. Compared with the fourth quarter, the economy contracted 0.5 percent, but officials said they anticipated domestic spending to revive quarterly growth in the current three months, helping the country avert a technical recession of two consecutive quarterly contractions. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Qwest's Finances Improve, But Investigations Widen
description: Qwest Communications International reported progress yesterday on several financial fronts, but the encouraging news was tempered by its warning that federal regulators looking into past accounting irregularities had widened their investigation.

title: Illegal Immigrants File Suit Against Vigilante Patrols
description: Hostility along the border with Mexico between American ranchers, illegal immigrants traveling across their property and armed volunteer groups determined to keep them out found its way into a Texas court today.

title: Spurs Surge, Not Sputter, Into Finals Date With Nets
description: The San Antonio Spurs were becoming renowned and not for being the team that Tim Duncan plays for. Although they were only a victory away from returning to the N.B.A. finals for the second time in five years, the Spurs were gaining recognition as a team that fizzles when it is holding a big lead.

title: A Misspent Youth? Tell That to My Victims
description: MY obsession with spades began in 1986 during my sophomore year at Brooklyn Technical High School. Unlike the smaller, nerdier, comic-collecting clique that counted me as a member, playing spades at Tech made me part of a large community -- every third student seemed to carry a deck. We played before class, at lunch and (if we could get away with it) whenever we had a substitute teacher.

title: Red Sox Trade Hillenbrand
description: The Boston Red Sox, in dire need of a starting pitcher and a closer, acquired Byung Hyun Kim yesterday from Arizona for Shea Hillenbrand, the kind of run producer the Diamondbacks desperately need.

title: Britain to Grant Iranian Dissident Refugee Status
description: An Iranian poet and political dissident, who sewed up his lips, eyelids and ears to protest what he says are injustices in the way Britain treats asylum seekers, is to be granted refugee status and allowed to remain in Britain, the government said today.

title: Ex-Wife Is Accused of Marketing Photos She Stole
description: The former wife of O. Winston Link, a photographer famed for dreamy pictures of trains, spent five years in prison for stealing 1,400 of his prints. The photos were never found, and throughout her trial and even after her release a year and a half ago, she never uttered a public word about their whereabouts.

description: Todd Shell of the New Jersey Dragons was named the Arena League coach of the year yesterday in a vote by the league's 16 head coaches.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Police Seek Man In Three Rapes
description: The police are looking for a man linked by DNA to the rapes of three teenagers in the past 14 months. The man is in his early 20's, is 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighs about 140 pounds. He is wanted in the rape of a 13-year-old in an alley near Harrod Avenue on April 11, 2002. He is also a suspect in the July 21, 2002, rape at knifepoint of a 17-year-old near Soundview Avenue. On Jan. 5, 2003, the police say, the same man dragged a 19-year-old woman into an alley near Morrison Avenue and raped her. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: 50 Years Later, a Lone Man Stands at Top of the World
description: Fifty years after the first ascent of Everest, a lone Russian stood on the summit today, his solitude bearing testimony to the enduring challenge of climbing to the highest point in the world.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Immunity Plan
description: Parliamentary supporters of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi presented legislation to give him legal immunity in his current corruption trial. The plan would protect officials in the country's top five posts from facing trial while they hold office. The bill is expected to pass, despite opposition criticism that it is devised to enable Mr. Berlusconi to evade justice. Mr. Berlusconi has repeatedly said that the charges, which center on his media empire, are politically motivated. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Brazil Economy Shows Growth From Year Ago
description: Brazil's economy contracted 0.1 percent in the first quarter of 2003 from the last three months of 2002, but it grew 2 percent from the comparable quarter a year earlier, the government reported today.

title: A Young Man Radicalized by His Months in Jail
description: Before he spent seven months in an Israeli jail, one of thousands of Palestinians detained on suspicion of militant activities, there was little about Fuad Qawasmeh that suggested to family and friends that he might one day become a suicide bomber.

title: Mock-Up Wing Is Torn by Foam In Shuttle Test
description: A piece of insulating foam shot at a mocked-up shuttle wing opened a long slit in its leading edge, which may help to explain what caused the loss of the space shuttle Columbia, investigators said today.

title: US AIRWAYS TO RESUME HOURLY SHUTTLES IN EAST
description: US Airways plans to restore hourly weekday shuttle service along the East Coast beginning Monday. The move, announced Wednesday, comes after Delta Air Lines said earlier this week that it would restore its own hourly shuttle flights. Both airlines, which compete on shuttle flights between New York and Washington and New York and Boston, cut several flights in April because of what they called sluggish passenger traffic. US Airways also said yesterday that it would start selling food on July 1 on domestic flights longer than 700 miles. Several airlines, including America West, United and Northwest Airlines, have been experimenting with selling food aboard flights. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Oil Giants Line Up at Iraqi Pump
description: Several of the world's biggest petroleum companies have approached the Iraqi Oil Ministry hoping to buy the first oil exports after the lifting of United Nations sanctions, Iraqi officials said today.

title: Top Pentagon Official Admonishes Indonesian Military
description: SINGAPORE, May 30  Paul D. Wolfowitz, the United States deputy secretary of defense, warned the Indonesian Army today that its war against separatist rebels in the northern province of Aceh could not be won militarily.

title: Reality Elides With Drama
description: In a documentary that is part of the DVD of "The Pianist," released this week by Universal, the director Roman Polanski says that Wladyslaw Szpilman's memoir of survival in the Warsaw ghetto was the perfect source for a film because it was written shortly after the actual events and was extremely accurate. Books written 20 or 30 years later, Mr. Polanski says, don't have the same degree of recollection or detail. (The most famous eyewitness account written at the time, which survived the ghetto although its author did not, was that of Emanuel Ringelblum.)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Talks On Joining U.S. Missile Defense
description: The Canadian government announced that it would open talks with the Bush administration on possibly participation in a North American missile defense system. A final decision on whether to coordinate with the United States military on such a system would require further consideration by the cabinet. The issue has become a controversial debating point for the three Liberal Party candidates to succeed the departing prime minister, Jean Chrtien, next year. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Four Chinese Given Long Prison Terms for Discussing Politics
description: Four friends who met on university campuses to discuss politics and who posted occasional essays on the Internet were sentenced here to long prison terms on Wednesday, convicted of ''subverting state power.''

title: Weekender | Millbrook, N.Y.
description: WHEN Harvard dismissed Timothy Leary, the psychology professor turned psychedelic drug guru, in 1963, he dropped out, at the invitation of a wealthy benefactor, to Millbrook. This polished enclave of vast estates and hundred-acre horse farms set in the lush hills of the eastern Hudson River Valley became the unlikely home of Leary's Castalia Institute, where he conducted controversial experiments with LSD. (It is also where he was arrested by G. Gordon Liddy, then with the Dutchess County Sheriff's Department, in one of several brushes with the law.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORLOFF, , NEIL
description: ORLOFF--Neil, a leading environmental lawyer and noted documentary photographer, passed away on April 26, 2003, at the age of 59. His simultaneous careers as lawyer and artist captured the combination of powerful intellect and artistic imagination that defined a rich and productive life. He began his career in government, then moved to Cornell University where he was a professor and director of the Center for Environmental Research and finally switched to private practice in Los Angeles and Salt Lake City. While practicing law, he developed an independent career as an honored documentary photographer. His work led to positions as an artist in residence at the MacDowell Colony and the Yaddo Center, an unusual tribute for someone who was a full time artist only in spirit and talent. His photographic study of the homeless in Salt Lake City--''Under the Fifth Street Underpass'' -- was awarded a Utah Governor's Award in the Humanities in 2000, and was published by Art Access Gallery. Mr. Orloff is survived by his wife, Gudrun Mirin. >>AD#

title: J.C. PENNEY CREDIT RATINGS FALL BELOW INVESTMENT GRADE
description: Credit ratings on J. C. Penney were reduced yesterday by Standard & Poor's, putting the debt below investment grade. The ratings agency said a turnaround would take longer than forecast. The ratings, which cover $5.4 billion of debt, were dropped one level, to BB+ from BBB-. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., has about $5.2 billion in debt, while its Eckerd drugstore chain has about $200 million in receivables not counted on the company's balance sheet. A sluggish economy will make it harder to improve sales and profit this year after a disappointing first quarter, Standard & Poor's said.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Video Game Company Files For Bankruptcy
description: The 3DO Company's struggle to stay viable has ended with a filing for bankruptcy protection. The company said this week that it would sell the entire company or its assets. Its titles include High Heat Major League Baseball and Army Men. The company said on May 13 that it would evaluate its strategic options because of adverse economic conditions that cut revenue and access to capital. In the nine months ended Dec. 31, revenue declined to $20 million from $38.4 million a year earlier, but the operating loss narrowed to $8.3 million, from $42.3 million a year ago. The company at the time projected fiscal 2003 revenue of $80 million, with that figure inching up to $90 million the next fiscal year. Last July, the auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers said the combination of recurring losses from operations and a net capital deficiency raised ''substantial doubt'' about 3DO's ability to continue as a going concern. Trip Hawkins, the founder and chief executive, lent 3DO $3 million to meet short-term capital needs in October. Earlier this month, the company issued 1.8 million shares and a warrant to buy 441,176 shares to Mr. Hawkins in return for canceling the $3 million of debt he held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DI MONTEZEMOLO, , ALESSANDRO
description: di MONTEZEMOLO--Alessandro, of Southampton, N.Y., and Rome, Italy, died on Tuesday, May 27. He was 84. Mr. di Montezemolo joined the Italian cavalry as a young man and remained a life-long equestrian. He rose to the rank of Major and was wounded in the North Africa Campaign. In 1950 he joined the staff of Dwight D. Eisenhower, then the commander of NATO forces in Europe. Mr. di Montezemolo went on to have a distinguished business career in Europe and the United States. He was a representative of the Italian insurance conglomerate Generali Group, and spent 10 years with the risk and insurance subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan Companies, where he headed the firm's international expansion, particularly in Europe. He retired as chairman of Marsh & McLennan Incorporated and as a director of Marsh & McLennan Companies in 1983. At the time of his death, Mr. di Montezemolo was a director of Salomon Smith Barney, a member of the advisory board of John Hopkins-SAIS Bologna Center, a member of the advisory board of the Museum of Women in the Arts, a member of the board of trustees of the Umberto Veronesi Foundation for the Advancement of Science, and chairman emeritus of the American Italian Cancer foundation. Mr. di Montezemolo is survived by Catherine Murray di Montezemolo, his wife of 45 years. Funeral services and interment will be held at a later date in Tuscany. Contributions in Mr. di Montezemolo's honor may be sent to: The American-Italian Cancer Foundation, 112 E. 71st St., NY, NY, 10021.

Loving father of John Zimet, his wife Kristen and Paul Zimet, his wife Ellen, stepfather to Peter and Carol Ginandes and grandfather of Anya, Isaac, Zachary, Nicholas, Deborah and Mark and great grandfather to Joshua and Capeley. Until his retirement in 1983, he was a faculty member of Manhattan College Graduate Business School serving as Chairman of the Management Department and as Director of the School of Business Research Institute. During the Second World War, he was a Field Representative of Wright Aeronautical. He and his first wife moved to Kendal, Hanover, NH in 1991. A memorial service will be held at Kendal, Hanover, NH on June 21. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: ECONOMIC SLOWDOWN Philippine economic growth slowed to 4.5 percent in the first quarter compared with the same three months of 2002, falling from 5.8 percent growth in the fourth quarter, according to government statistics. Compared with the fourth quarter, the economy contracted 0.5 percent, but officials said they anticipated domestic spending to revive quarterly growth in the current three months, helping the country avert a technical recession of two consecutive quarterly contractions. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 30  Nearly two months after American tanks rolled into Baghdad, the Bush administration is learning a simple if unwelcome lesson: it will take more troops to police and secure Iraq than it did to destroy the Saddam Hussein regime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAULT, , MARK WILLIAM
description: GAULT -- Mark William. Passed away May 24th, 2003, at age 45. Beloved husband of Susie. Devoted father to Harry and Jack. He is survived by his parents, Phyllis and Jim, and by his brothers, Philip and Hugh. He was Worldwide Executive Vice President and Regional Director of McCann-Erickson North America, a position he assumed in January 2001. Previously he served as NY-based Director of Worldwide Accounts of McCann - Erickson World wide. Earlier, he was Chairman of McCann-Erickson Japan, the largest western agency in Japan and one of the largest agencies within the McCann-Erickson Worldwide network, and served as the agency's Asia Pacific Area Director as well. Previously he had been based in London, where he first joined the company, as head of the H.K. McCann/London agency and as a Director of Worldwide Accounts. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 3, at 3 PM, at Park Avenue Christian Church, at 1010 Park Avenue at 85th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made ''In memory of Mark Gault'' payable to the Collegiate School. Its address is 260 West 78th Street, New York, NY 10024, Attn: Development Office. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, , MURRAY
description: SHAPIRO--Murray, 85, Brooklyn, died on Wednesday, May 28, 2003, at his home. He was the husband of 57 years of Beatrice Shapiro. At 15, he graduated from Boys High School. He attended N.Y.U. and Brooklyn College, where he was a member of the soccer team. Mr. Shapiro was a decorated army veteran of WWII, and was a member of the D.A.V. He was a New York/New Jersey 3 cushion billiards champion, a nationally ranked handball player in the 1930's, and was an entertaining opera singer. Besides his wife, he leaves his daughter, Judy Kallet of South Windsor, CT; his son, Steven Shapiro of Queens and five grandchildren. Burial was held in Connecticut. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a lawsuit by six California firefighters seeking to disband the chaplain's corps in their department misstated its name. It is the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, not Prevention.

title: Are You With Us? Are We Against You?
description: When President Bush speaks tomorrow in Krakow, Poland, he should give the whole of Europe this message: we, the United States, want a strong, coherent European Union. By the time he leaves the Group of 8 meeting in vian, France, next Monday, European leaders should have responded with this message: we, the dynamically expanding European Union, want to define our new identity through a partnership with the United States, not through opposition to it.

title: Court Papers Suggest Scale Of Drug's Use
description: Documents released yesterday in the case of a drug company whistle-blower shed light on how extensively doctors were involved in promoting unapproved uses of a Warner-Lambert drug, Neurontin.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FULTON, , ROBERT EDISON
description: FULTON -- Robert Edison, was one of the most interesting men I have every known. He was a philosopher, musician, poet, director, cinematographer, aerial cinematographer, filmmaker, and most of all, an incredible man. Bob was highly skilled in all these areas. He won many awards including an Emmy for his work. He was a devout Buddhist. Bob was extremely humble and never talked about himself or his accomplishments, but only about the love of his work. Bob did everything in such a unique way that his friends and family referred to his lifestyle as Fultonian, as if hehad developed an entirely different culture and way-of-life. To tell one story about Bob was never enough; people always wanted to hear more and know more about this fascinating man. To watch Bob fly a plane was like watching a virtuoso playing an instrument. He taught me many things both in the sky and on the ground. His lessons of ''point of intended touchdown'' is something I will never forget. A wonder with words, Fulton never used profanity; he thought it was an abuse of the English language and demonstrated a lack of a proper vocabulary. I miss my generous mentor and good friend, Bob Fulton, who is in my thoughts every day. Taz Saunders

title: After N.F.L. Drafts Him, Henson Starts Hitting
description: When the Houston Texans used a sixth-round draft pick on Drew Henson, a former University of Michigan quarterback, last month in the hopes of eventually trading him, it said as much or more about his struggling baseball career as it did about his future in the National Football League.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: PRISON FOR FOSTER MOTHER The foster mother of a 6-year-old girl whose disappearance rocked the state child welfare agency was sentenced to three years in prison on charges that included accepting welfare payments for the girl long after she vanished. The foster mother, Geralyn Graham, 57, told the authorities that the girl had been taken from their home by a social worker 15 months earlier. The girl, Rilya Wilson was reported missing in April 2002, when the Department of Children and Families realized its workers had skipped more than a year of required monthly visits to her foster home. The girl remains missing. (AP)

title: Sunny Fun and Games, but Shadows Too
description: Hubbard Street Dance Chicago filled the stage with high spirits when it opened a two-week season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. Here were good-looking, well-trained dancers in stimulating works of several kinds.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: J. D. EDWARDS POSTS 2ND-QUARTER LOSS The business software maker J. D. Edwards & Company posted a loss for the second quarter yesterday versus a profit a year earlier, as revenues dropped in the weak economy. The company said that it recorded growth in the number of customers, but that its transactions were smaller. For the quarter ended April 30, it posted a net loss of $393,000, compared with a profit of $3.5 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. The Denver-based company said that on a pro forma basis, excluding unusual costs, it earned a profit of $1.1 million, or 1 cent a share, compared with a profit of $7.6 million, or 6 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Total revenue declined to $203.5 million from $223.6 million the year before, the company said. License revenues fell to $43.6 million from $54.1 million a year earlier, while service revenues declined to $160 million from $169.5 million. ( Reuters )

title: Once Again, It Takes a Thief to Catch a Thief
description: One of the sillier but more engaging conventions of the contemporary caper film is to imagine that a dream team of crooked techno-wizards, each a quirky genius who takes pride in his craft, can mesh like a perfectly functioning machine and accomplish miraculous feats of larceny. The standard movie heist is a race against time that involves at least two spectacular chases and that is often capped with a tricky surprise ending. True to tradition, the crew of ''The Italian Job,'' facing punishing deadlines, carries off its high-tech games of take-the-money-and-run with a cool, professional bravado.
