title: Reality Elides With Drama
description: In a documentary that is part of the DVD of ''The Pianist,'' released this week by Universal, the director Roman Polanski says that Wladyslaw Szpilman's memoir of survival in the Warsaw ghetto was the perfect source for a film because it was written shortly after the actual events and was extremely accurate. Books written 20 or 30 years later, Mr. Polanski says, don't have the same degree of recollection or detail. (The most famous eyewitness account written at the time, which survived the ghetto although its author did not, was that of Emanuel Ringelblum.)

title: SHARON AND ABBAS WEIGH CONCESSIONS FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: The Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers met here for a second time Thursday night to explore their disagreements over how to pursue a new international peace plan, inching toward concessions and polishing their images as peacemakers before a summit meeting next week in Jordan with President Bush.

title: Rules Proposed to Prevent Cronyism in Stock Offerings
description: An advisory committee of business and academic leaders submitted a report to securities regulators yesterday that recommended 20 new guidelines for ensuring fairness in the market for initial public offerings.

title: The Vineyard Reawakens to a Sound of Hammers
description: ALL over Martha's Vineyard, shadbushes were blooming, peepers were peeping, the goldfinches had yellowed up nicely, and year-round humans who care for the nests of their migratory cousins were in a state of near frenzy. Spring came late this year; it snowed in April, and ferry traffic was off by nearly 7 percent through the first week of May. But suddenly, Memorial Day was only a week away, and the Vineyard was scrambling to get that relaxed island aesthetic up and running for another summer.

title: Initial Offering Is Planned By Citadel Broadcasting
description: Citadel Broadcasting, the biggest acquisition made by the buyout firm Forstmann Little & Company, said in a filing yesterday that it planned to raise $306 million in an initial public offering.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; A Father's Face Unveiled, A Son's Life Shattered
description: If you suddenly discovered that everything you thought you knew about your family was a lie, how much of a psychological foundation would you have left? That's the excruciating question facing Giovanni Orzan (Sergio Rubini), the central character of Piergiorgio Gay's film ''The Power of the Past,'' after a ghost of yesterday pays him an unwelcome visit.

description: In the end, there were two spellers and a gold cup that seemed to twinkle at them from the end of the stage.

title: Mavericks' Finley Is Shining on Bigger Stage
description: DALLAS, May 29 - Michael Finley was there during the drought, when the playoffs were as far away from Dallas as his hometown of Chicago, when Coach Don Nelson was viewed as an antique who had lost touch with the modern-day player, when it took nearly three seasons rather than one for the Mavericks to win 60 games.

title: A mascot is told the cold truth: He is too snuggly for the times.
description: WITH a blissful demeanor, squeaky voice and high-pitch giggle, Snuggle, the longtime spokescreature for the Snuggle brand of fabric softener, used to behave like a Care Bear. Now cuddly Snuggle is getting an image update, becoming a devil-may-care bear, complete with sunglasses  la Tom Cruise, dates with models and knowing winks to the audience.

title: A Vrit Veteran Reflects on Life Behind the Camera
description: THE climb to Charlotte Zwerin's top-floor atelier on the leafy end of Morton Street is so steep that Ms. Zwerin, a 71-year-old documentarian whose partnership with Albert and David Maysles yielded such monuments to cinema vrit as ''Gimme Shelter'' and ''Salesman,'' occasionally resorts to a mechanical chairlift to scale the penultimate flight. But only when her dicey back flares up, or if she's having what she terms a bad oxygen day.

title: Job Description: Life of the Party; The Proper Motivator Ensures That the Bar Mitzvah Celebration Boogies
description: Lorne Hughes grew up in the Virgin Islands and now lives in Los Angeles, but he regularly spends his weekends dancing with 13-year-olds in braces and formal wear at bar mitzvahs from Great Neck to TriBeCa.

title: Battle on Child Tax Credit Intensifies in the Capital
description: The White House today defended the decision of Congressional negotiators to deny millions of minimum-wage families the increased child tax credit, saying the new tax law was intended to help people who pay taxes, not those who are too poor to pay.

title: Modern China's Clashing Values, Mirrored in a Prodigy's Career
description: Music, mostly of the Western classical variety and much of it floridly romantic, pours through Chen Kaige's film ''Together'' and helps infuse its story of a teenage violin prodigy and his devoted father with a feverish emotionalism. The newest movie by the Chinese filmmaker best known for ''Farewell My Concubine'' is not afraid to push buttons with its heady potpourri of Bruch, Richard Strauss, Liszt and Massenet, all pointing toward a climactic performance of the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto in D.

title: Panel Is Facing Strong Lobbying Over Design Of 9/11 Tribute
description: An intense lobbying effort is under way, both in public and behind the scenes, to influence the jury that will choose the design for a memorial at the World Trade Center site.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: WOMAN DIES BREAKING UP FIGHT A woman with asthma who rushed to break up a schoolyard brawl between her daughter and several middle-school students collapsed and died, school and police officials said yesterday. On Wednesday, the woman, Mary McGuire, 50, was waiting outside her home in Morrisania for her 12-year-old daughter to come home from school. She saw her daughter and other students fighting in the yard of an elementary school, said her husband, Larry Beard. The medical examiner had not yet determined the cause of death yesterday, but Ms. McGuire's family said she had asthma.

title: Cage-Rattling For Reform Of Drug Laws
description: A FILM called ''While You Were Sleeping'' was on television yesterday, and for a moment the temptation to tune in was strong. Figured it might be required viewing for a New York columnist. With a title like that, it had to be a documentary about Albany, right?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Newspaper Halted For 3 Months
description: The government suspended the country's oldest and largest independent daily, The Belarusian Business Newspaper, and its editors called the action a politically motivated vendetta against one of the few papers critical of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. The Information Ministry announced the three-month suspension after halting the press run on Wednesday, citing violations of media laws. Irina Khalip, the paper's deputy editor, said in a telephone interview that the editors had received three warnings on Monday, one for ''insulting the honor and dignity of the president'' by printing poll results and two for reporting on criminal cases now moving through the court system. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Sinatra, Gangsta Rap And 'Mack the Knife'
description: Michael Bubl, a 27-year-old Canadian singer in the Sinatra mold. makes sure his audiences know he's not wandering around in a nostalgic time warp, pretending that rock and hip-hop never happened. Mr. Bubl, who is appearing through Sunday at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village) with an eight-member swing band, spices his act with a fragment of gangsta rap that he delivers with a hard rat-a-tat edge and a humorously defiant attitude. Along with time-honored standards like ''The Way You Look Tonight,'' '''You'll Never Know'' and ''All of Me,'' his program includes hits by George Michael (''Kissing a Fool''), Van Morrison (''Moondance'') and Queen (''Crazy Little Thing Called Love'').

description: INVESTORS today are being offered two investments with virtually identical after-tax yields of 1.5 percent: stocks and bonds. That fact says a lot about both investor attitudes and tax policy.

description: Thorough defensive coverage is the preferred approach in this low-scoring era of the National Hockey League, but this was an extreme example. description: Several private groups, including the City Bar Association, filed legal papers yesterday in defense of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to reorganize the city's local school districts, which has been challenged in a lawsuit by state legislators.

title: 36 Hours | Kansas City, Mo.
description: PEOPLE will be relentlessly nice to you in Kansas City, the epitome of Midwestern friendliness. But don't be fooled. Polite doesn't equal bland. Behind the charming parks, neighborhoods and 160 public fountains of this sprawling metropolitan area of 1.8 million people lie a rich, boisterous history and an energetic present. Kansas City, on the Missouri River, was the jump-off to the Old West, the start of the Santa Fe, Mormon and Oregon Trails. Pro-slavery Missouri bushwhackers and antislavery Kansas jayhawkers skirmished there during the Civil War. The political machine of Tom Pendergast won notoriety for corruption but also produced Harry S. Truman. It's a great jazz town, where Charlie Parker, Lester Young and Count Basie all got their start. Drink in the history, shop at the bustling City Market, drop by a jazz club like Jardine's or the Phoenix. Sample a glistening platter of ribs or pulled pork and join the unending local arguments over which combination of smoky sweet or smolderingly spicy makes barbecue best. KATHLEEN LEIGHTON

title: Angry Blair Denies Iraqi Weapon Reports Were Inflated
description: LONDON, May 30  Responding to growing concerns about the accuracy of the information he relied on to make the case for the Iraqi war, Prime Minister Tony Blair angrily denied today that his government had exaggerated intelligence reports showing that Saddam Hussein was harboring weapons of mass destruction.

title: The rich have fled, wrapped in luxury : Asia's wealthy buy protection from SARS
description: HONG KONG:  As scientists scrutinize the behavior of the SARS virus, even a casual observer can see that the deadly respiratory disease affects the rich and famous differently than it affects others.

title: The Tax Bill's Final Indignity
description: The tax bill that President Bush triumphantly signed into law on Wednesday is not just unfair, dishonest and economically unsound. It is also cruel to low-income families. In a last-minute revision, Senate and House negotiators dropped a provision that would have extended child tax credits to millions of these families. The stated reason was that the total cost of the bill had to be kept to an agreed-upon limit of $350 billion. This excuse is typical of the shifty argumentation that has accompanied this legislation from the start.

title: Deportation Behind Closed Doors
description: The Supreme Court decided this week not to weigh in on the important issue of whether deportation hearings for immigrants suspected of ties to terrorism could be held in secret. The decision may reflect the fact that the government is reconsidering its use of closed deportation hearings. But whether by its own choice or by court order, the government should stop conducting these sensitive proceedings in secret.

title: Modernist in the Making: Noguchi's Many Voices
description: His reputation today may be that of a card-carrying modernist, but Isamu Noguchi (1904-1988) started out as a sculptor of the classical school. The figure was the first discipline to be mastered by this extraordinarily versatile Japanese-American artist, whose early training was traditionally academic. He became skilled in conjuring the human face and body, and they remained central to his work, although it evolved from literalism to metaphor as he went on to figure-based abstraction.

title: Van Gundy Won't Coach 76ers
description: Jeff Van Gundy took himself out of the running for the Philadelphia 76ers' head coaching position yesterday. Van Gundy told Billy King, the 76ers' president, that the situation was not right for him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: SK Rescue Urged
description: Son Kil Seung, chairman of the SK Group, the country's third-largest conglomerate, urged SK companies to provide funds needed to rescue SK Global, the group's scandal-ridden trading firm. SK asked creditors to reconsider their decision to ask a court to place SK Global in receivership, a step on the way to liquidation of the company. SK Corporation, Korea's biggest oil refiner, suspended shipment of petroleum products to SK Global, responsible for distribution to gasoline stations, but promised to resume delivery today after SK Global's creditors paid SK Global bills totaling 30 billion won ($25 million). Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SETON, , FENMORE R.

title: Corrections
description: The Day Trip column in Escapes last Friday, about a driving trip to Storm King Art Center north of New York City, misstated its hours. They are Wednesday to Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; through Aug. 30 the grounds remain open until 8 p.m. on Saturdays. The center is closed on Mondays and Tuesdays.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Free-Speech Lawsuit Settled
description: A Correction Department employee who claimed that he had been demoted after criticizing probable budget cuts in his department has settled a federal lawsuit against the city. Last June, the employee, Dane Martin, assistant deputy warden at the department, was quoted in Newsday as saying that if jail staffing were reduced, employees' safety would be endangered. Mr. Martin was later demoted to captain. He charged that his right to freedom of speech had been violated. Under the settlement, Mr. Martin will be reinstated to his position and awarded $60,000 in back pay and damages. Mario Frangiose, senior counsel for the Labor & Employment Law Division, the city's legal department, said the city did not admit wrongdoing. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: An Emperor Who Escaped Notoriety
description: ''We've had Hadrian, Nero, Marcus Aurelius and Augustus, but I can't recall an Antoninus Pius,'' said Richard M. Keresey, the antiquities specialist at Sotheby's in New York. He was referring to a marble portrait head of the Roman emperor Antoninus Pius (A.D. 86-161), which is in Sotheby's sale of antiquities on June 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NELKIN, , DOROTHY
description: NELKIN--Dorothy, 69, The New York University Faculty of Arts and Science mourns the passing of our beloved colleague, Dorothy Nelkin, University Professor and Professor of Sociology and Law. Nelkin was a groundbreaking researcher who examined the interplay among science, technology and society, and she was the author of numerous important books. A member of our faculty since 1988, she was a brilliant scholar and teacher and one of the most admired and respected faculty members at NYU. She will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathies go to her husband of 50 years, Mark Nelkin, her daughter Lisa Nelkin and granddaughter Erica Peckens. Richard Foley, Dean, NYU Faculty of Arts and Science >>AD#

title: Executive Joins Cable TV Ad Group
description: After an extended search for a new top executive, the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau in New York named Sean B. Cunningham yesterday president and chief executive, effective in mid-June.

title: Another Fair Lady Looking for Culture
description: A pretty and spirited young woman with the wrong accent finds herself in an upper-class English household where money is riding on a haughty, irascible individual's ability to teach her to speak and act like a lady.

title: Another Milestone of Cloning Is Reached as a Mule Is Born in Idaho
description: Scientists said yesterday that they had cloned a mule for the first time, raising the prospect that it will soon be possible to produce genetic carbon copies of related animals, including champion racehorses.

title: Early-Morning House Fire Takes Life of Brooklyn Man
description: A 66-year-old man was killed yesterday in an early-morning fire that erupted in a Brooklyn house he shared with his brothers and extended family, the authorities said.

title: MICROSOFT TO PAY AOL $750 MILLION; END TO 'LONG WAR'
description: Microsoft agreed to pay AOL Time Warner $750 million in a legal settlement yesterday that ends one of the most bitter rivalries in modern corporate history and commits the two companies to a sweeping program of business cooperation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Protests Over Delayed Election
description: Largely Roman Catholic political parties staged demonstrations across the country and in Northern Ireland to protest the postponement of elections to the power-sharing Northern Ireland Assembly. The protests came on the day the voting was to have taken place before it was delayed until fall by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain this month because the Irish Republican Army had failed to commit to ceasing all paramilitary activity. The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, reiterated his opposition to Mr. Blair's decision, saying the elections should take place as soon as possible. Brian Lavery (NYT)

King and Martha King Rickenback. Grandmother of Victoria King Kerman, Robert C. King, Jr, John Frazier Baker and Elizabeth Baker Clippinger. Also survived by ten greatgrandchildren. Funeral service private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Springfield Volunteer First Aid Squad, PO Box 247, Springfield, NJ 07081. >>AD#

title: Terror Threat Level Lowered to Yellow Outside New York
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 — The Bush administration lowered the nation's color-coded threat level one notch today but urged Americans to remain vigilant.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Columnist Is Robbed
description: A New York Post columnist was robbed early yesterday morning as he left Langan's, a bar on West 47th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. The columnist, Steve Dunleavy, said he was ''extremely drunk'' around 2 a.m. when two men brushed against him, stealing his wallet. Christopher Nalls, 33, of Brooklyn, and Carnell Malone, 43, of Manhattan, were arrested soon after a witness reported the theft to the police. They were charged with robbery and criminal possession of stolen property, the police said. ''I'm not sure if I was the victim of a crime,'' Mr. Dunleavy said. ''I was the victim of the gang that couldn't shoot straight.'' Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: A Rival to Gap That Operates Like Dell
description: This is the town that invented retailing's secret sauce.

title: Aetna Settlement With Doctors Wins Approval of Federal Judge
description: A federal judge in Miami gave Aetna preliminary approval yesterday for a $170 million plan to settle assertions by 700,000 doctors that the company unfairly cut reimbursements.

title: Group Says Scrushy Won't Be an Adviser
description: Investors led by the lawyer for Richard M. Scrushy, the HealthSouth Corporation's fired chief executive, have decided not to use Mr. Scrushy as an adviser in their bid for the company.

title: Leaseholder Sees Limited Role For Libeskind at Trade Center
description: Larry A. Silverstein, the leaseholder of the World Trade Center site, said yesterday that Studio Daniel Libeskind would inspire but not actually design the office buildings he is planning there, including Freedom Tower, the 1,776-foot skyscraper that is expected to be the first to rise.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Rachel Kempson, a British actress and matriarch of the Redgrave acting clan, misstated the name of a character she played in Shakespeare's ''Coriolanus'' in 1932. It was Virgilia, not Virginia.

title: Jets' Evans May Be Barred After Drug Test
description: Jets defensive tackle Josh Evans has tested positive for marijuana use, according to three people familiar with the results of a test administered by the National Football League. Evans adamantly denied any violation yesterday and has appealed the results of the test.

title: Angry Blair Denies Iraqi Weapon Reports Were Inflated
description: LONDON, May 30  Responding to growing concerns about the accuracy of the information he relied on to make the case for the Iraqi war, Prime Minister Tony Blair angrily denied today that his government had exaggerated intelligence reports showing that Saddam Hussein was harboring weapons of mass destruction.

title: Pentagon Expanding Search for Weapons of Mass Destruction
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 — The Pentagon announced today a "significant expansion" of the hunt for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

description: The Defense Department confirmed the death of the following American in Iraq:

title: Chinese Injustice
description: Seok Jae Hyun, a freelance South Korean photographer, was sentenced late last week by a Chinese court to two years in prison on charges of trying to smuggle a group of North Korean refugees out of China last January. Mr. Seok, who has done freelance work for The New York Times, was one of five people imprisoned under a law that bars ''trafficking in persons.'' This is a grave injustice, which Chinese authorities should promptly reverse. Mr. Seok had gone to China in his professional capacity and apparently for only one reason: to record the daring efforts of a group of North Korean refugees to escape their oppressive regime by leaving China aboard two fishing boats and seeking asylum in either Japan or South Korea.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Beef  La Gamma Ray
description: Local school districts will have the option to serve irradiated ground beef as part of the national school lunch program by 2004, the Agriculture Department said. Irradiation sterilizes food by using low levels of gamma rays or electrons to kill bacteria and parasites, like E. coli and salmonella. In 1999, the government approved the sale of irradiated meat to the public. The World Health Organization and the American Medical Association have said irradiated meat is safe. Some consumer groups contend that the process may lead to cancer and birth defects.

title: Vast Sea, Tiny Fish, Big Crisis
description: Among the finned creatures who wriggle and dart through Disney/Pixar's sparkling aquatic fable, ''Finding Nemo,'' the most comically inspired is a great white shark named Bruce (the voice of Barry Humphries), who glides through the ocean flanked by two menacing sidekicks, Anchor (Eric Bana), a hammerhead, and Chum (Bruce Spence), a mako. An ominous hulk, with eyes like gleaming bullets and a savage jack-o'-lantern grin, Bruce has adopted a 12-step program to curb his insatiable appetite for other fish. ''Fish are friends, not food,'' goes the mantra he repeats in an unctuously imperious drawl whenever he's tempted to gobble up a passing morsel.

title: Lawyers Accuse U.S. of Deceiving Colombians in Extradition
description: Defense lawyers say that United States authorities misled Colombia to win the extradition of several Colombians who were being sought in the 1999 fatal shooting of a retired New York police detective, court documents show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, , ROGER H., D.D.S.
description: MILLER--Roger H., D.D.S., age 79, died May 28, 2003. Beloved husband of Donna. Loving stepfather of Andrea Wasser, Michael and Stacey Wasser, and Lauren Moreno. Cherished grandfather of Giselle Moreno. Memorial service will be held. For information, call 516-671-3213. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Helped by higher prices for energy exports and by lower imports, Canada's current account surplus widened to 6.1 billion Canadian dollars ($4.4 billion) in the first quarter, from 5.4 billion Canadian dollars ($3.9 billion) in the previous three months and $4.4 billion Canadian dollars ($3.2 billion) a year earlier, Statistics Canada reported. On the financial account, foreigners invested heavily in bonds denominated in Canadian dollars, in contrast to the previous three years when the most popular Canadian bonds were in United States dollars. Bernard Simon (NYT)

description: The shot heard round the world would probably be inaudible today, drowned out by the roar of airplanes at nearby Hanscom Field.

description: Tax cuts have returned as a central issue in presidential politics. But this time Democratic candidates are aggressively challenging tax reductions with a directness not seen since the 1980's.

title: FORMER DISNEY EXECUTIVE IS NAMED CHIEF OF WET SEAL
description: Wet Seal, a retailer of clothing for teenagers, named the former worldwide president of Disney Stores, Peter D. Whitford, as chief executive yesterday. The appointment is effective June 30. Mr. Whitford succeeds Irving Teitelbaum, who has served as interim chief since February, when the company fired Kathy Bronstein. Mr. Teitelbaum is the company's chairman. Wet Seal has had losses in the last three quarters. Mr. Whitford resigned from Disney last week after it said it might sell its stores because of falling sales and profit. Wet Seal has 622 stores under the Wet Seal, Arden B. and Zutopia names.

title: When Holding a Party Is a Crime
description: During Prohibition, the government required that industrial alcohol be poisoned, typically with methanol, to keep it from being converted into cocktails. If bootleggers did not completely remove the adulterant, it could cause blindness, paralysis and death. Thus a measure aimed at discouraging alcohol consumption made it more hazardous for those who continued to drink.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MILLSTEIN, , JAMES
description: MILLSTEIN--James. 10/26/ 22--5/30/02. My darling big brother Jim, gone one year, oh how I miss you. Always, always thinking of you. Your kid sister, Annie >>AD#

title: Rolls-Royce or Hyundai, Leather Makes the Car
description: CAN any other part of an automobile exude an aura of quality like rich, buttery-soft leather upholstery? In a convertible, it's on display to the world; in any car, it radiates comfort. Sumptuous leather interiors are longstanding hallmarks of makers like Jaguar, Bentley and Rolls-Royce. For a luxurious immersion, sink back into the soft leather folds of the seats in a Lexus LS430 sedan.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Aretha Franklin Arson Investigation
description: The state attorney general's office will conduct an independent investigation into a suspicious fire that gutted a home owned by the singer Aretha Franklin in October because four local agencies could not agree on who, if anyone, should be charged in the case. Arson is suspected, but there have been no arrests. Ms. Franklin and her son, Edward, have been subpoenaed. Local prosecutors have said Ms. Franklin is not a suspect. The $1.5 million home was in Bloomfield Township, north of Detroit. Ms. Franklin was in Texas at the time of the fire.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Italian composer Luciano Berio on Wednesday listed his survivors incompletely and omitted the names of his children and the surname of a former wife, his second. He is survived by two daughters and three sons (not two) and by four grandchildren and one great-grandchild (not two grandchildren). His daughters are Cristina and Marina Berio, and his sons are Stefano, Dani and Yoni Berio. His second wife, who also survives, was Susan Oyama.

title: Echo of '78: Steinbrenner in an Ad
description: In 1978, George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin starred in a commercial selling Miller Lite in which they engaged in the campaign's long-running ''tastes great/less filling'' debate. In that summer of Yankee discord and malcontents, Steinbrenner ''fired'' Martin in the commercial. ''Oh, not again!'' Martin replied.

title: PEP BOYS NAMES 20-YEAR BOARD MEMBER AS ITS CHAIRMAN
description: Pep Boys -- Manny, Moe & Jack, an auto parts and services chain, named Bernard J. Korman as its chairman yesterday, succeeding Mitchell G. Leibovitz, who has retired. Mr. Korman, 71, has been a board member since 1983. He is also chairman of the Philadelphia Health Care Trust, a charitable foundation. Mr. Leibovitz, 57, stepped down as chairman and chief executive after more than 20 years with the company. Last month, Pep Boys, based in Philadelphia, named Lawrence N. Stevenson, a former chief of a Canadian bookstore chain, Chapters, as chief executive.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Engineer Posts Loss
description: The British engineering company Invensys reported a 1.4 billion ($2.3 billion) loss for the year, reflecting falling revenues and write-downs from sales of assets. Sales from continuing operations dropped 8 percent for the 12 months ended March 31 to 4.3 billion ($7.1 billion). The company took 1.3 billion ($2.1 billion) in one-time write-downs. Invensys also has a 931 million ($1.5 billion) pension liability. The results were disappointing, the company's chief executive, Rick Haythornthwaite, said in a statement. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Briefly Noted
description: MOROCCO: KING SPEAKS ON ATTACKS In his first public address since suicide bombers killed 31 people in Casablanca on May 16, King Mohammed VI said the country's security had been brought under control. "Immediate measures I ordered have enabled (us) to bring the situation under control and restore peoples' confidence," the king said in a live televised speech. The king described the perpetrators of the attacks as "lowly scoundrels" and "traitors" and said the authorities had done what they could to prevent attacks, referring to a bill aimed at introducing the concept of terrorism to Moroccan criminal law. ( Reuters )

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Peril For Banks
description: China's new banking regulator said time was running out for lenders to reduce bad loans, improve management and raise capital, prompting him to consider bailing out the banking industry for the second time in six years. The China Banking Regulatory Commission estimates 24.1 percent of loans at China's four biggest state-owned lenders were nonperforming at the end of the first quarter, the commission's chairman, Liu Mingkang, said. ''The high ratio of bad loans has added some risks to the financial system and time is running out for us to fix the problem,'' Mr. Liu said in Beijing.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Refugees From Somalia
description: Springfield expects to receive about 185 Bantu refugees from Somalia in the next 24 months, the director of a local religious group said. Robert Marmor, director of Jewish Family Services of Western Massachusetts, said the community would receive $300,000 a year to help the resettlement efforts. Three refugees have arrived, and the city is expecting 54 by the end of September. Last fall the mayor of Lewiston, Me., wrote an open letter requesting that local Somali leaders ask other Somalis not to come to the city. More than 1,000 Somalis have moved to Lewiston, a city of 36,000, in two years. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Sandman Sims, 86, Tap Dancer and Fixture at the Apollo
description: Sandman Sims, the celebrated tap dancer and Apollo Theater legend, died on May 20 in the Bronx. He was 86, although he long maintained that his age was ''a matter of opinion.''

Clement III, Headmaster >>AD#

title: A Wet, Nonalcoholic Addiction
description: It's 8:28 a.m., the precise moment when four lanes merge into three to accommodate the heavily attended water exercise class at the 92nd Street Y. Grudgingly, the lap swimmers begin to collect in the narrow slice of pool left to them: my friend Suzanne, a fitness instructor, immediately recognizable by her wide looping turns; Laura, who stops every few minutes for a briefing on the late-breaking gossip from the locker room; the middle-aged man with the wildly hooking stroke and don't-tailgate-me kick, who for no apparent reason has been dubbed the dentist; the admirably focused Jan in hand paddles and flippers, who streaks past all contenders between consultations with the lifeguard about the finer points of the butterfly. And me, Lycra bathing cap worn almost past usefulness, Lycra bathing suit worn almost past decorum, determined (after 25 years it seems high time) to knock out a mile in less than 38 minutes.

title: Mets Pitcher David Cone Retires
description: John Franco was driving his son, J. J., to Toys R Us in Staten Island this morning, a quick errand before driving to Shea Stadium and sitting in the bullpen, when he heard the news on the radio. David Cone, Franco's good friend and hopefully his teammate in a few hours, would soon announce his retirement at Shea Stadium.

description: ZAMBELLI--Alfred F., B.A., M.A. (Yale), World War II veteran, Fulbright Scholar, longtime New Yorker and well-known antiquarian book dealer, died peacefully on May 24, 2003, age 89. He is survived by his daughter, Pia, his son-in-law, Lorne Silcoff and grandchildren, Michael and Jonathan. >>AD#

description: Capt. Andrew Watson of Carson City, Nev., removed his helmet and mopped the sweat off his head this afternoon as he stood at the gate of his dusty encampment and puzzled over what had prompted the rioting, grenade throwing and arson on Wednesday in this little desert town that falls within his ''A.O.,'' or area of operations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 1 Dead, 2 Hurt In Shooting
description: Three men were shot, one fatally, after a dispute with an attacker in Inwood on Wednesday, the police said yesterday. The police found the three victims at 7:45 p.m. on the corner of Dyckman Street and Joe DiMaggio Highway. There have been no arrests. Robert Garcia, 29, was shot in the head and died several hours later at Columbia-Presbyterian Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital. Nolan Muoz, 20, was shot in the leg and was in stable condition yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Julian Silva, 32, was shot in the face and was in stable condition at Columbia-Presbyterian. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRUGMAN, , PAULA ALEXANDER
description: KRUGMAN--Paula Alexander, died May 28, 2003, suddenly, after a 20 year battle with cancer. Loving wife of Edward (Woody) and mother of Aaron. Devoted sister of Herbert Alexander, aunt of Jay David Alexander, Miriam Alexander Cogan, Ben-Zion Alexander, Daniel Alexander, Paul Culley, Luke Culley and Alex Culley. Great aunt of Adi, Omer, Rachel, and Roi. Beloved daughter-in-law of Herbert and Dorothy Krugman and sister-in-law of Laura Krugman Culley and Rachel Leah Alexander and the late Joyce (Rachel) Alexander. Cousin and friend of most of the known universe. Services Sunday, June 1, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment in the Kriegman Family Association Park at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Shiva will be observed Sunday through Thursday at the family residence. Donations may be made to the American Folk Art Museum or the Sisterhood of the Village Temple.

title: HOMETOWN AMERICA IS BUYING CHATEAU FOR $1 BILLION
description: Hometown America said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, Chateau Communities, the largest owner of prefabricated-housing developments, for $1 billion, topping an earlier offer from the financier Sam Zell. Hometown America, backed by Washington State's pension fund, will pay $29.25 a share for Chateau, a 16 percent premium to the closing price on Wednesday. Hometown America, which is based in Chicago and is closely held, will assume $1.2 billion of Chateau's debt and preferred stock. Chateau is based in Greenwood Village, Colo. The offer comes about a month after Washington State's pension fund approved a $750 million investment with Hometown America to buy ''distressed assets.'' Mr. Zell's company, Manufactured Home Communities, had offered to buy most of Chateau for $26 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Woman Dies Breaking Up Fight
description: A woman with asthma who rushed to break up a schoolyard brawl between her daughter and several middle-school students collapsed and died, school and police officials said yesterday. On Wednesday, the woman, Mary McGuire, 50, was waiting outside her home in Morrisania for her 12-year-old daughter to come home from school. She saw her daughter and other students fighting in the yard of an elementary school, said her husband, Larry Beard. The medical examiner had not yet determined the cause of death yesterday, but Ms. McGuire's family said she had asthma. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: British Soldier Accused of Mistreating Iraqi Prisoner
description: LONDON, May 30  A British soldier was arrested today after he left a roll of film at a photo store in Staffordshire that appeared to show an Iraqi prisoner being tortured, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: JANITORS REACH SETTLEMENT The union representing janitors in several Hartford-area commercial buildings has reached a tentative contract settlement, averting a strike. The Service Employees International Union, Local 32BJ, said yesterday that downtown workers' hourly rate would increase from $10.00 to $10.75 in 2005. Suburban cleaners' hourly wage would go from $8.50 to $9.50. The union's old contract expires Saturday. Local 32BJ represents approximately 2,000 janitors. Union members will vote on the tentative agreement on June 2. (AP)

title: Ilya Prigogine, 86, Nobelist For Study of Complexity, Dies
description: Dr. Ilya Prigogine, who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1977 for insights into how life could arise in apparent defiance of the classical laws of physics, died on Wednesday in Brussels. He was 86.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The restaurant at the Carlyle has simplified and beautified. It has also decided to rename itself Dumonet, in an effort to throw the spotlight on its chef, Jean-Louis Dumonet. The result is a more attractive restaurant with a more appealing menu. A lot of the floral froufrou has disappeared from the dining room, which is luxurious but chaste, with chocolate walls and caf-au-lait woodwork. The beloved Redout botanical prints remain in place.

Venus Williams struggled with her timing and her nerves today in a 6-3, 4-6, 6-2 victory over 110th-ranked Evie Dominikovic of Australia.

title: Trove of Stolen Photos Is Found After Arrest of Creator's Ex-Wife
description: Westchester County investigators yesterday found a huge cache of photographic prints by O. Winston Link, a master portraitist of steam trains in small-town America, after arresting his ex-wife on a charge of trying to sell some of his stolen works.

title: After Holiday Passes Peacefully, Officials Lower Terror Alert to 'Elevated' From 'High'
description: The Bush administration lowered the nation's color-coded terrorist threat level today to yellow, or elevated risk, because of what officials described as intelligence reports suggesting that the threat of domestic terrorist attacks had dropped since Memorial Day.

title: ARREST IN PEARL CASE
description: Pakistani officials reported the arrest of an Islamic militant believed to have helped plan and carry out the kidnapping and murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl and other terrorist attacks across the country, Pakistani news media reported.

title: CNA FINANCIAL SAYS ARBITRATION LOSS WILL AFFECT PROFITS
description: The CNA Financial Corporation, the Chicago-based insurer controlled by the Loews Corporation, said it lost an arbitration decision related to a 1995 fire claim and as a result its second-quarter profit would be reduced by $49 million. ''We are disappointed and surprised by the arbitration decision,'' Stephen W. Lilienthal, the chief executive, said in a statement. The decision was rendered against an insurance pool that included CNA, the company said.

title: Federal Persecution
description: Ed Rosenthal, a medical marijuana advocate, is to be sentenced next week on marijuana cultivation charges. His conviction, by a California jury that was made to believe he was a common drug trafficker, was a miscarriage of justice. A federal judge may now be on the verge of compounding the wrong by sentencing Mr. Rosenthal to prison.

title: Psychiatrists Rebuke China For Blocking Inspection Visit
description: In an unusual public rebuke, the World Psychiatric Association has called on China to fulfill its promise to let international experts examine charges that psychiatry has been misused in China as a political tool.

title: Blair Denies Britain Distorted Reports on Iraqi Weapons
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair angrily denied today charges that in making the case for the war in Iraq his government had exaggerated intelligence reports showing that Saddam Hussein possessed weapons of mass destruction.

title: Yet Another Smokers' Refuge Succumbs
description: Smokers grow accustomed to fleeting pleasures. One of the choicest was visiting the Oak Bar at the Plaza, which managed to avoid the city's smoking ban that took effect on April 1. But now that too is gone.

title: Sports of The Times; Sorenstam Rewarded With 10-Under-Par 62
description: IT'S one of golf's articles of faith. If you play longer, tougher courses, you'll score better on shorter, easier courses.

title: A Piece of Hudson Riverfront Is Reclaimed for the People
description: On a pier poking 860 feet into the Hudson River and once used for such grinding work as shucking oysters and hauling freight, 25 young honey locust trees were quivering in a soft breeze yesterday and a thick cushion of grass stretched the length of one and a half football fields.

title: Spurious George
description: Statehouse reporters almost anywhere like to boast that the capital they cover is, hands down, the most craven, the most corrupt, the most inept. New York, which has a colorful history of official malfeasance and an almost comically pointless Legislature, is no exception. Betsy Kolbert, the astute Albany veteran who covers politics for The New Yorker, undoubtedly spoke for many of her colleagues when she wrote recently, with perverse but unmistakable pride, that ''New York has always been something of a pioneer in the field of fiscal mismanagement.''

title: Europe Awaits, With Bated Breath
description: President Bush arrived tonight in a Europe simultaneously hopeful that the trans-Atlantic rift can be healed and skeptical about the American administration's willingness to rebuild the European-American partnership.

title: In Monaco, glamour in the fast lane
description: MONACO:  Take a fabulous and unique diamond. Add a royal family, a black-tie ball, fashion models and movie stars, Ferraris, Jaguars and spacious yachts. Throw in an exclusive three-night party with star disk jockeys, dancers and circus acts.

title: Elusive Bombing Fugitive Divides a Town
description: ANDREWS, N.C., July 23 There is a part of this town that is rooting for Eric Robert Rudolph to elude the camouflaged G-men and their droopy-eared bloodhounds, and not just because the six-month search for Mr. Rudolph, the accused abortion clinic bomber, has been good for business.

title: HOCKEY: Stanley Cup Analysis; The Ducks Are Now in Danger of Losing Their Dignity
description: Here is the hope, not only for supporters of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks, but also for fans of the National Hockey League in general. Perhaps it is just wishful thinking.

title: REPORT BY POLICE OUTLINES MISTAKES IN ILL-FATED RAID
description: A tangle of mistakes by the police, including communications failures, poor supervision, ignorance about some procedures and a failure to follow others, led to the death of a 57-year-old Harlem woman in a botched drug raid, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: Detention Is a Tool Used in New Jersey For Foster Youths
description: Month after month, dozens of teenage foster children in New Jersey remain locked up in the state's array of secure juvenile detention centers -- often, child welfare officials admit, because there is simply a lack of more appropriate places to put them, and often while officials skirt state laws meant to limit how long children can be held in such places.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: AIR TALKS DEADLINE EXTENDED An Ontario court extended until midnight tonight a deadline for Air Canada to reach a cost-cutting deal with its 3,100 pilots. The airline, which is based in Montreal and has been under court protection since April 1, has so far obtained concessions worth 766 million Canadian dollars ($560 million) a year from eight unions and management, but has said it must have an agreement with the pilots. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Marking Three Centuries of Brilliance and Bondage in St. Petersburg
description: As President Bush and other world leaders descend on St. Petersburg this weekend to help President Vladimir Putin celebrate the city's tricentennial (and to help his re-election campaign), their canned speeches are certain to contain lots of references to a ''window into Europe.'' That, according to Alexander Pushkin, was what Peter the Great had in mind when he decreed a new capital in the swampy delta of the Neva and gave it a Dutch name, ''Sankt-Piterburkh'' (it was Russified to Petrograd only in World War I).

title: Florida 'Scarlet Letter' Law Is Repealed by Gov. Bush
description: Gov. Jeb Bush signed a bill today repealing the state's ''Scarlet Letter'' law that required single women planning to put their infants up for adoption to first publish their sexual histories in a newspaper if they did not know the identity of the father.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Schering-Plough Warns That It Faces Indictment

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Conditions For A Merger Eased
description: Zimmer Holdings Inc., a maker of orthopedic devices, said it was dropping two of the conditions it had set for acquiring Centerpulse, Europe's largest orthopedics company. The conditions relate to product-liability litigation against Centerpulse and possible corporate income tax liability connected to Centerpulse's 2001 spinoff from Sulzer, Zimmer said. Zimmer, which was spun off from the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, made an unsolicited offer for Centerpulse last week to create the world's biggest maker of implants used for reconstructive surgery. Zimmer is based in Warsaw, Ind., and Centerpulse is based in Switzerland.

title: Security Council Votes to Dispatch Peacekeepers to the Congo
description: The Security Council today unanimously approved the dispatch of a French-led international force of 1,400 troops to the Congo's northeastern province of Ituri, where, the United Nations estimates, at least 415 civilians have been killed in the last two weeks and 60,000 have been killed since 1999.

title: Tracing the Maltese Falcon-like Journey of a Stolen Diamond Ring
description: When F.B.I. agents learned in 1997 that a stolen five-carat diamond ring was being offered for sale, it looked like a run-of-the-mill case of jewelry theft.

title: A New Backwoods Threat: Feeble-Minded Flesh Eaters
description: I had car trouble in West Virginia once. The experience (some nice people in a trailer let us use their telephone to call Hertz) was not as eventful as that of the attractive young characters in Rob Schmidt's ''Wrong Turn,'' but it was also a lot less tedious.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a shelter in Barre, Vt., for male and female victims of sexual abuse misidentified the street where it is located. It is Cottage Street, not Carriage.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NEPAL: PRIME MINISTER QUITS AMID PROTESTS Prime Minister Lokendra Bahadur Chand, a staunch royalist, resigned after eight months in office as thousands across Nepal protested peacefully against his unpopular rule. The resignation came after months of street protests and pressure from political parties demanding that King Gyanendra dismiss him and appoint a government with their nominees, or revive the Parliament disbanded last year. Earlier this week, the police beat protesters, including ousted lawmakers, when thousands tried to march on Parliament. Analysts said the resignation could be the beginning of a conciliatory process between the king, a constitutional monarch, and mainstream political parties. ( Reuters )

title: A Day for Old Hands
description: Shea Stadium magically shrank last night, but only when the Atlanta Braves were batting.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Militia Figure Pleads Guilty
description: A man accused of leading a paramilitary group pleaded guilty to federal firearms charges. Under a plea deal, the man, David Burgert, 39, admitted possessing a machine gun and a firearm while a felon. At sentencing on Sept. 10, he faces a maximum of 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000 and supervised release for three years for each charge. Prosecutors said Mr. Burgert agreed to cooperate with the authorities. The agreement said prosecutors could recommend a lighter sentence if he gave them ''substantial assistance'' in prosecuting others. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: With an Aching Hip, Cone Calls It a Career
description: John Franco was driving his son, J. J., to Toys ''R'' Us on Staten Island yesterday morning, a quick errand before reporting to the Shea Stadium bullpen, where a phone ring would be meaningful for him for the first time in 20 months. Then he heard the news on the radio. David Cone, Franco's good friend, was about to retire.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   VERGNES, , JEANNINE (NEE GEFFNER)
description: VERGNES--Jeannine (nee Geffner). Dearest Jeannine, I seem to be lost for words other than I miss you and kiss you. Happy birthday. Davi

title: Benefits
description: With next Sunday's issue, the Benefits column will temporarily cease publication. It will resume at the end of summer.

description: Following is the text President Bush's radio address today as released by the White House.

description: In percent

title: Protection on the Cheap
description: President Bush's budgets have generally shortchanged environmental programs. His proposed budget for all discretionary (nonfarm) environmental protection programs for fiscal 2004 is down $1.6 billion, or 5 percent, from actual spending in 2002. These numbers do not really register, however, until you suddenly wake up to the fact that for want of a few million strategically placed dollars, programs essential to the government's ability to carry out important environmental laws have been compromised. There have been two distressing examples of this in the last week alone.

title: Photos Raise Allegations Of Torture
description: A British soldier was arrested today after he left a roll of film at a photo store that appeared to show an Iraqi prisoner being tortured, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: Just an Ordinary Guy Finds Unordinary Love
description: The Showtime movie ''Soldier's Girl'' is -- like ''Boys Don't Cry,'' ''The Matthew Shepard Story'' and ''The Laramie Project'' -- based on a true and terrible story. In 1999 Barry Winchell, a decent, ordinary guy from Missouri nominated for Soldier of the Month in a crack Army infantry unit, fell in love with Calpernia Addams, a glamorous and warm-hearted transgendered nightclub performer. And he paid a grisly price for that love.

title: Indictment Seen By Drug Maker Over Marketing
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it could soon be indicted in a federal investigation into its prescription drug marketing practices, and face charges that employees destroyed documents related to the case.

title: Jets' Evans Keeps Quiet As He Waits For Ruling
description: Jets defensive tackle Josh Evans continued to practice today while awaiting word on his appeal of a positive drug test for marijuana. The team and Evans, who adamantly denied on Thursday that he had used marijuana, declined comment on the situation today in accordance with advice from the National Football League.

title: Relief for Rug Cutters
description: Relief for Rug Cutters

title: Palestinian Doctor, Held by Israelis, Pleads Not Guilty
description: A prominent Palestinian psychologist who was detained after Israeli troops razed his family home and killed three of his brothers who were Hamas militants has pleaded not guilty to charges of weapons possession and incitement, his family said.

title: Support Groups for Mentally Ill Sue M.T.A. Over Half-Fare Cards
description: Three advocacy groups for the mentally ill have filed a class-action lawsuit against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, saying its application process for half-fare MetroCards is too difficult and invasive for about 37,000 mentally ill riders who are eligible for the discount.

title: For Senate Parliamentarian, Great Power but a Sensitive Constituency
description: The dark-haired, mustached man who sits in the swivel chair on the dais in the Senate chamber just below the presiding officer typically attracts little notice. In keeping with Senate tradition, he takes copious notes in red and blue pencil, whispering his wisdom to those who lead the proceedings. Others never hear his voice.

title: Historians Trace an Unholy Alliance; Religion as the Root Of Nationalist Feeling
description: When Shiite Muslims in Iraq took to the streets to protest the presence of American troops as well as Saddam Hussein, was the world witnessing the birth of nationalism? When President Bush used the term crusade to describe the war on terrorism, was he inadvertently revealing religious roots in American patriotism? In short, is religious sentiment, long considered the prime enemy of nationalism, actually one of its founding elements?

title: Pay Debated at British Bank's Meeting
description: Sir John Bond's message to British investors today was unapologetic: Executives are paid more in America. Get used to it.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Lottery Bill Passes
description: The Legislature passed a bill on Thursday to create a lottery to finance education programs. The office of Gov. Phil Bredeson, a Democrat, said he would sign it, probably next week. Tennesseans voted in a referendum in November to remove the constitutional ban on a lottery. Tickets could be on sale by January. The state had been one of three that lacked legalized gambling. The others are Utah and Hawaii. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Martha Scott, Original Emily in 'Our Town,' Dies at 88
description: Martha Scott, who created the role of the sweet, ethereal Emily in the original Broadway production of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' and was nominated for an Oscar for repeating it in the film version, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 88.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in Weekend last Friday with an opera review of ''La Donna del Lago'' by Rossini referred incorrectly to the work on which it was based, ''The Lady of the Lake'' by Sir Walter Scott. It is a poem, not a novel.

title: Ex-Informant Is Sent to Jail
description: A former stockbroker and federal informant who cooperated on a book about the Mafia's influence on Wall Street was jailed yesterday after he refused to comply with an agreement to be relocated to help ensure his safety.

title: U.S. Civilians Not Told of Raid on Palestinians
description: United States military officials ordered a raid on the Palestinian diplomatic mission in Baghdad this week without first informing senior American civilians in Iraq, an administration official in Washington said today.

title: New Book Includes Passages From Others
description: A new book chronicling the creation of the atom bomb, written by a historian who teaches at the United States Naval Academy, includes more than 30 uncredited passages that are identical, or nearly identical, to those found in their own books by four other authors, including two by Richard Rhodes.

title: Rikers Island Inmate Is Stabbed to Death
description: A 35-year-old inmate at a Rikers Island jail was stabbed to death about 5 p.m. yesterday, and investigators were questioning two other inmates in his cellblock, said Thomas Antenen, a spokesman for the City Department of Correction.

title: Sports of The Times; Swampland Providing Urban Thrill
description: THIS is an open thank-you note to the Nets, bless their acrobatic hearts. They are one of the most enjoyable teams to watch since the Celtics and the Lakers were moving the ball around the court in the mid-80's.

title: What Rift? Top Aides Deny State Dept.-Pentagon Chasm
description: American presidencies have often been riven by feuds between hard-liners at the Pentagon and diplomats at the State Department. Yet the chasm between the two under President Bush is often so wide that to outsiders it can appear they are conducting two entirely different foreign policies.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Bank Buys Insurance Unit
description: The Bank One Corporation agreed to buy most of the United States life insurance unit of Zurich Financial Services for about $500 million to become the nation's second-biggest bank insurance underwriter behind Citigroup Inc. The purchase would be the largest for Bank One's chief executive, Jamie Dimon, a former Citigroup president, since he took over the leadership of Bank One in 2000. He has said that he wants to move into insurance underwriting to add to the mutual funds and credit cards that are being sold through Bank One's 1,798 branches in 14 states. Bank One is based in Chicago and Zurich Financial is based in Zurich.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Awaiting placement in detentions is one of the dirty little secrets of the system. It's an issue across the country, an example of kids being blamed for a bunch of stuff adults should be fixing.''

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: End To Desegregation Order
description: A federal judge has said he will approve a settlement to free the Fulton County public schools from a 1970 desegregation order. The judge, Robert L. Vining of District Court in Atlanta, ruled on Thursday that the county district, which excludes Atlanta, no longer has the discrimination that prompted the class-action suit. Under the accord, a voluntary busing program will be phased out, and the county will try to increase enrollment in advance placement and language courses, said the plaintiffs' lawyer, Chinh Le of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Serena Williams Wastes No Time in Victory
description: It has been a week of long, side-to-slide marathons at the French Open. If you were not playing three hours or more on the sun-baked clay, you were not going with the flow. But today, the mood changed.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Chrysler Group said today that its marketing chief, James C. Schroer, was resigning, effective immediately.

title: Pataki Asks Board to Reconsider Rejection of Jobless Benefits for a Same-Sex Partner
description: When Jeanne Newland's companion landed a prestigious computer job in Virginia, Ms. Newland did not hesitate to quit her own job in Rochester and make the move south.

title: A Country on the Verge
description: President Bush and President Vladimir Putin of Russia will have much to discuss when they sit down in St. Petersburg today: Iraq, terrorism, nuclear arsenals, NATO expansion. It is vital, however, that they also address Russia's mounting health crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIRINSKY, , RUTH (SPECTOR)
description: ZIRINSKY--Ruth (Spector), 71, on May 29, 2003 after an eight year battle with lymphoma. Beloved wife of George Spector and the late Ralph E. Zirinsky. Devoted mother of Robert, Linda and Jill, and mother-in-law of the late Kathryn, David and Mark. Cherished grandmother of Ralph, Elissa, Harry, Benjamin, Zachary, Julia, Emily and Kate. Dear sister of Sara. Services Sunday June 1st, 11:30AM, BoulevardRiverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Receiving from 10AM. We request no flowers or baskets. Please honor Ruth's memory with a memorial contribution to the Janet Cuttner M.D. Research Fund, Mount Sinai Medical School, 1735 York Avenue, Suite P2, NYC 10128. >>AD#

title: Court Rejects Request to Stop Rock Concerts in Riverhead
description: The courts will not stop two rock concerts planned for Riverhead, N.Y., but the events' promoters still need to arrange for adequate police protection before the shows can receive the necessary permit from Suffolk County officials.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES Japan's unemployment rate stood unchanged at a near-record 5.4 percent in April, highlighting the problems that have ailed its anemic economy for nearly two years, the government said. The number of jobless totaled 3.85 million people, up 100,000 from the same month a year ago, the Labor Force Statistics Office said yesterday. Jobs fell in farming, construction, manufacturing, retailing and restaurants. Japan has been fighting its worst slowdown in half a century. The labor problem began to take a turn for the worse in the summer of 2001, edging up to 5 percent levels for the first time since the government began keeping those statistics in 1953. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSER, , GLENN M.
description: KOSER--Glenn M., 35, of New York City, passed away May 29, 2003 from Leukemia. Graduate USAF Academy, Captain in Gulf War and market analyst. Beloved husband of Kimberly, cherished son of Emely and John, caring brother of Brian, irreplaceable friend to many. Funeral services today, 11:00AM, St. Joseph's of Yorkville, 404 East 87 St. Donations to Leukemia-Lymphoma Society. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary of the Brazilian musician and producer Almir Chediak reversed two identities. The composer Caetano Veloso was at the left and Mr. Chediak in the center. (The composer Djavan was at the right.)

title: Liberty Is Back To Tackle New Season
description: The Liberty has reached the W.N.B.A. finals in four of the league's six seasons, but has never won a title. Last season, the team lost in the finals to the Los Angeles Sparks, two games to none.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Stitches Out
description: An Iranian asylum-seeker who sewed up his eyes, mouth and ears and refused to eat or drink to object to his treatment by the British immigration authorities ended his protest, more than a week after it began and a day after the Home Office said it would no longer continue opposing his asylum application. The asylum seeker, Abas Amini, 33, a dissident and poet, spent six years in Iranian jails and was repeatedly tortured before coming to Britain in 2001. Mr. Amini, who lives in Nottingham and who drank a small amount of water after his stitches were removed by a nurse, told reporters that he would work on behalf of other asylum seekers. ''I want to stay alive to continue the struggle,'' he said. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Judge Orders Ephedra Maker To Pay Back $12.5 Million
description: The makers of the ephedra supplement that was implicated in the death of a Baltimore Orioles pitcher must return $12.5 million in profits on sales of the substance in California, a judge ruled yesterday in a false-advertising suit in San Diego.

title: Japanese Government Plans To Control Bank After Bailout
description: Japan plans to take control of Resona Holdings, which was given a $16.5 billion government bailout, to ensure that the money is used to revive the company, the top financial regulator said yesterday.

title: vian Offers Its Magic By Tubful
description: Pierre Lewandoski lay still as vian mineral water, heated to 95 degrees, bubbled and swirled, gently massaging his middle-aged body.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUMINS, , ALFRED
description: KUMINS -- Alfred. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our dear, longtime member. Funeral Sunday, 9:45 AM, Gutterman's Rockville Centre. May the bereaved family find solace and consolation amongst all mourners in Israel. Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi Joel M. Greenberg, President >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOISI, , LUKE
description: BOISI--Luke, of Locust Valley, on May 28, 2003, in his twenty-first year. Beloved son of Geoffrey and Rene Boisi, loving brother of Zachary, Peter and John, cherished grandson of James O. and Edith M. Boisi, and Norine G. and the late Anthony J. Isacco. Luke will be truly missed by many aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. This creative spirit of God will always be remembered for his individuality and his caring nature. Visiting at the Beney Funeral Home Inc, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY, Saturday and Sunday from 24 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:30am, at St. Dominic R.C. Church, Oyster Bay, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to MENTOR/National Mentoring Partnership, 1600 Duke Street, Suite 300, Alexandria, VA 22314. >>AD#

title: S.&P. Index Is Up for the Sixth Week in the Last Seven
description: Shares rose yesterday, as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed the week higher for the sixth time in seven weeks, after surveys on Midwest manufacturing and consumer confidence increased optimism that the economy is reviving.

title: Stopping the Genocide in Congo
description: In 1995, a contingent of 400 lightly armed Dutch peacekeepers stood by while Serbs massacred some 7,000 Muslim men and boys in Srebrenica, Bosnia. The United Nations, which had promised security, betrayed Srebrenica by failing to send enough men and crippling them with restrictive rules of engagement. The U.N.'s failure shocked the world's conscience at the time. Today, the same thing is happening in eastern Congo.

title: Bomb Kills 2 Spanish Police Officers; Basque Group Suspected
description: A bomb planted under a police car killed two officers and seriously wounded a third. The Spanish government blamed the violent Basque separatist group E.T.A. for the attack.

title: Driver Shoots Officer, Then Is Killed by Troopers' Fire
description: A New Jersey state trooper shot and killed a man who had been stopped for questioning at a rural Warren County intersection early today, after the man opened fire and seriously injured a police officer from Washington Township.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: RHODE ISLAND: MAKERS OF LEAD PAINT FACE NEW TRIAL A judge ruled on Thursday that the state may retry its suit against seven former makers of lead paint, giving Rhode Island another chance to convince a jury that the industry created a public health threat. Rhode Island was the first state to try to hold the industry responsible by saying the paint created a public nuisance, an effort that resulted in a mistrial last fall. Judge Michael A. Silverstein of Superior Court will schedule a new trial.   (AP)

title: Memorial Jury to Decide How to List 9/11 Rescuers
description: A top rebuilding official said yesterday that the guidelines for the World Trade Center memorial were flexible enough to allow the professional affiliations of firefighters and other rescue workers to be listed on it with their names, if the memorial jury chose a design that did so.

title: Woman Hit by Stool Says She Does Not Blame Students
description: The pregnant woman knocked down by a stool thrown from a sixth-floor window of a Manhattan high school said yesterday that she did not want anything bad to happen to the two students charged in the case, because she was confident that they were just horsing around.

title: Labor Turns to a Pivotal Organizing Drive
description: If the labor movement is to have a future, if it is not to shrink to insignificance, it must unionize workers like Cristina Gomez.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Faster Growth
description: Canada's economic growth accelerated to a 2.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, led by consumers buying food and clothing and businesses stockpiling inventories. The pace of expansion ebbed as the quarter wore on, and the economy had no growth in March. That left gross domestic product, the sum of all goods and services produced, at an annualized 1.09 trillion Canadian dollars ($797 billion), according to Statistics Canada. Consumer spending, which accounts for 56 percent of G.D.P., rose 3.5 percent, but consumer demand abroad was softer, forcing companies to stockpile unsold goods, a development that could lead to slower production.

description: WorldCom said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a Canadian ranch once owned by its former chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers, for $68.5 million.

description: KRAKOW, Poland, May 31 - President Bush affirmed today his commitment to the half-century relationship between Europe and the United States, but he made clear that he expected traditional allies that opposed him in the war on Iraq, like Germany and France, to conform to an American vision of a shared future.

description: Shareholders of Home Depot Inc., the world's largest home-improvement chain, overwhelmingly re-elected Kenneth G. Langone as lead director yesterday. The vote came amid criticism that Mr. Langone, an investment banker who helped found the retailer, was not independent.

title: Geoffrey Bawa, 83, Architect Who Blended Asian Styles
description: Geoffrey Bawa, a Sri Lankan architect whose striking blend of traditional Asian forms and contemporary international styles produced houses and public buildings in harmony with their Asian landscapes, died on Tuesday at his home in the capital, Colombo. He was 83.

title: Variable Annuities Inquiry Is Looking at Prudential
description: NASD, a securities industry regulator, and the New York State Insurance Department are investigating the sale of variable annuities by Prudential Financial Services, one of the nation's largest insurance companies.

title: St. Petersburg Is Given Some Major Primping For Its Birthday Bash
description: Its manhole covers sealed, rain-dispersing air force circling aloft, unsightly shacks summarily torched, quadrilingual phrase books issued to police and cellular phone encryption disabled, Russia's baroque czarist capital is girded this weekend to wrap President Bush and nearly 45 other world leaders in an extravagant bear hug to celebrate its 300th birthday.

title: Contreras Finally Puts On Show Worthy of His Billing
description: Smooth and powerful. Those were the words Roger Clemens, closing in on his 300th victory, used to describe a pitcher who had one major league victory. Jos Contreras is smooth and he is powerful. He is also poised and patient, waiting for a chance to be a significant contributor for the Yankees. And he was looking to crawl within 297 victories of Clemens tonight.

title: Editor Is Leaving Meredith to Finish a Book
description: Myrna Blyth, who was the editor in chief of Ladies' Home Journal for 21 years, announced yesterday that she would retire from the Meredith Corporation, the publisher of the magazine, at the end of June.

title: Clemens Has New Setting For 300
description: Take two. Roger Clemens will try to write a different pitching scene on Sunday against the Detroit Tigers in his second attempt to snare his 300th victory. The scene, whenever Clemens achieves it, will be a milestone. It will also be a relief for Clemens, who hopes to avoid a take three, a take four, or worse, to accomplish it.

Powell today fiercely defended the intelligence used by the Bush administration to justify war against Iraq, saying he spent several late nights poring over the Central Intelligence Agency's reports because he knew the credibility of the country and the president were at stake.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES AGREES TO BUY 2 MALLS
description: General Growth Properties Inc., an owner of shopping malls, agreed to acquire two malls in Missouri and New Mexico and buy out a partner in a joint venture for about $626 million. The company, based in Chicago, will purchase the Saint Louis Galleria in St. Louis and Coronado Center in Albuquerque. It will also buy the 49 percent it does not already own of a venture that controls seven malls in the United States from Ivanhoe Cambridge of Montreal, the chief executive, John Bucksbaum, said. The acquisitions, which will close by early July, will add $73 million in operating income for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2004, General Growth said.

title: A.C.C. Delegation Ends Visit to Miami
description: What began as a flirtation between a powerful conference and one of the nation's most dynamic athletic programs gained momentum yesterday as officials from the Atlantic Coast Conference completed a visit to Miami and both sides signaled that the university could leave the Big East Conference within two weeks.

description: Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul D. Wolfowitz warned the Indonesian Army today that its war against separatist rebels in the northern province of Aceh could not be won militarily.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Dining section on Wednesday about pollution problems that affect salmon farming misstated Agriculture Department data on the relative levels of Omega-3, the healthful fatty acids, in farmed and wild salmon. Farmed salmon has about the same levels as wild Atlantic salmon -- not less -- and more than wild Coho salmon.

description: Sam Segond, a Rutgers sophomore, won the men's discus title and three Iona runners qualified for the N.C.A.A. championships in the 5,000-meter run yesterday at the East Regional championships at George Mason in Fairfax, Va.

title: 2 Reports Give Hints of Strengthening Economy
description: United States consumer confidence rose this month to the highest point in a year, and manufacturing in the Chicago area expanded, signs the economy may be strengthening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERLING, , ADA
description: STERLING--Ada. Died May 29, 2003, age 91, at home in Manhattan. NYC Teacher. Beloved mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister, and aunt. >>AD#

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Nobel Money To Benefit Staff Children
description: The General Assembly has agreed to a plan by Kofi Annan, the secretary general, to use the $947,000 that came with the 2001 Nobel Peace Prize to start a fund for the education of children of United Nations civilian staff members killed in the line of duty. The organization was co-winner of the prize along with Mr. Annan, who proposed that the money be pooled for the fund. The deputy secretary general, Louise Frechette, said: ''Here at headquarters, we do not have to worry about a perilous working environment -- stepping on a land mine or being ambushed on a lonely road where no laws prevail. Some of our colleagues do.'' Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: IRAN DISPUTES U.S. ON ACTIONS IN IRAQ
description: Iran's foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, said today that American accusations of Iranian meddling in Iraq were an attempt to cover Washington's failure to establish order there, and he suggested that the chaos in Iraq would end only after Iraqis were able to choose their own government.

title: Going Into Finals, Harvard Dominates
description: Harvard continued to lead the qualifying for today's finals of the 101st Intercollegiate Rowing Association national championships in Pennsauken, N.J. Harvard won its varsity semifinal heat yesterday, topping a six-boat field that included Cal, the four-time defending I.R.A. champion; and Wisconsin, the only crew to defeat the Crimson last year.

title: Religion Journal; A Slice of America: Judaism Among Non-Jews
description: David Haase observes more Jewish customs than most American Jews: he attends a Conservative synagogue, keeps kosher, sends his children to Jewish day school and fasts on Yom Kippur.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KLEIN, , BARRY
description: KLEIN--Barry. On your birthday & every day, miss you & love you. Not a day goes by. Love & Kisses, Sherry >>AD#

title: How the G.O.P. Created Affirmative Action
description: The Supreme Court will soon decide a pair of cases brought against the University of Michigan by two disappointed white applicants who object to the use of race as a factor in admissions. Although it may seem that every aspect of the cases has been thoroughly debated in the press, there has been little discussion of one vital element: the original source of constitutional doctrine on which affirmative action is based.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the opening of an outdoor reading room behind the New York Public Library in Manhattan misidentified the trees at the site, near the statue of the industrialist William Earle Dodge. They are London planes, not maples.

title: Asia's rich buy SARS 'immunity'
description: HONG KONG:  As scientists scrutinize the behavior of the SARS virus, even a casual observer can see that the deadly respiratory disease affects the rich and famous differently than it affects others.

title: Constitutionally, A Risky Business
description: In the last 35 years, more than 100 countries have tried to accomplish what Iraq is trying to do: create a democratic constitution.

title: Morocco's Choice: Openness Or Terror
description: When suicide bombers shattered the calm of the night here on May 16, they did more than take 43 lives -- they also endangered Morocco's future as a democracy. Morocco had long been considered a haven of tolerance and peace, and any troubles we had we attributed to foreign agitators. We can't pretend that is the case any more. This time, all the attackers were Moroccans. All grew up in poverty; none had been outside the country. Instead, the ideology of radical Islam came here and found ready recruits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEOLY, , JOAN ELLEN FLAX
description: GEOLY--Joan Ellen Flax passed away May 30th after a long illness. Beloved mother of James and Kathryn, mother - in - law of Adam, grandmother of Alex, Tom, Andrew, Cayla, Benjamin and Jack. Sister of Robert, sister in law of Marjorie, aunt of Melissa and Sean and dear friend of Daniel. Services Sunday, June 1, 1:30PM at ''Riverside - Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR) Great Neck, NY. Joan was a light in every life she touched and will be remembered forever. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOLZER, , HERB
description: HOLZER--Herb. They say that time heals all wounds, so please let time fly. We miss you. Love always, Dottie, Scott & Joan >>AD#
