description: AMERICA AS SECOND CREATION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANKIN, GOLDEN, , LYN
description: HANKIN-GOLDEN--Lyn. August 2nd, 1957--May 20th, 2003 of complications from anorexia. Daughter of Kathleen and the late Leonard Hankin. Beloved sister of Kim Hankin Barrett and devoted aunt of Lindsey and Kendall Barrett. A bright and funny person devoted to her family, now finally at peace. >>AD#

title: Marathon Is Set to Name Its First Title Sponsor
description: The 34-year-old New York City Marathon has gone the route of college football bowl games and signed a title corporate sponsor.

title: Henson Starts to Hit After N.F.L. Draft
description: When the Houston Texans used a sixth-round draft pick last month on Drew Henson, a former University of Michigan quarterback, in the hopes of eventually trading him, it said as much or more about his struggling baseball career as it did about his future in the National Football League.

title: INVITROGEN NAMES LEADER OF G.E. UNIT AS ITS CHIEF
description: The Invitrogen Corporation, a maker of chemical kits used for analyzing and cloning genes, named Gregory T. Lucier as president and chief executive. Mr. Lucier is a former president and chief executive of the General Electric Company's GE Medical Systems information-technology business unit, Invitrogen said. He replaces Lyle Turner, founder of the 16-year-old company, who retired Jan. 1. Invitrogen is based in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: MONTANA: MILITIA FIGURE PLEADS GUILTY A man accused of leading a paramilitary group pleaded guilty to federal firearms charges. Under a plea deal, the man, David Burgert, 39, admitted possessing a machine gun and a firearm while a felon. At sentencing on Sept. 10, he faces a maximum of 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000 and supervised release for three years for each charge. Prosecutors said Mr. Burgert agreed to cooperate with the authorities. The agreement said prosecutors could recommend a lighter sentence if he gave them "substantial assistance" in prosecuting others.    Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: A Return to the Familiar, With Its Constant Change
description: Guest conductors have been leading the New York Philharmonic for the last few weeks, but Lorin Maazel has reclaimed the podium. His first task was part public relations, part music-making: he maintained Kurt Masur's tradition of offering a free Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in this case an all-Tchaikovsky program.

title: Doctor Saves an African Boy, and Vice Versa; Brought to New York for Care, an Orphan Transforms His Benefactor's Life
description: ''I want to go where you are from.''

title: Frugal Japanese Dig Into Savings
description: In more prosperous times just a few years ago, Kiwako Kaiyama and Kiyoko Kitamura looked to a future of kicking back on their husbands' salaries. Instead, to make ends meet, the 40-something housewives have had to cut their spending, take part-time jobs and -- shockingly, for Japan -- dip into their savings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EDELMAN, , HILDA W.
description: EDELMAN--Hilda W. Reunited with Daddy for eternity. With us always, Diana, Robert, Nancy, Alex >>AD#

title: Malone Returns To Knicks
description: Brendan Malone rejoined the Knicks as an assistant coach yesterday, joining his son Mike on Coach Don Chaney's staff.

title: Court Upholds Man's Firing In Flag Case
description: An employee may be fired for displaying the Confederate battle flag at work, the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Richard E. Cheney, a former public relations executive who switched occupations in Manhattan, referred incorrectly in one instance to his adopted area of study. It is psychoanalysis, not psychiatry.

title: New York Fishing Contest Draws 22 Boats to Harbor
description: Although many landlubbers think of New York Harbor as a sterile place, those who regularly venture on the water know it teems with fish, including the queen of the waters, the striped bass. Yesterday, New York's premier fishing competition, the Manhattan Cup, attracted 22 boats to the harbor.

title: INSIDE
description: Powell Backs Iraq Reports

title: Gigure Tells Mighty Ducks To Play With Emotion
description: Jean-Sbastien Gigure said today that he was usually not very vocal in his team's dressing room. ''I try to lead on the ice by working hard and doing my job,'' Gigure, the Anaheim Mighty Ducks goaltender, said.

title: Janet Collins, 86; Ballerina Was First Black Artist at Met Opera
description: Janet Collins, prima ballerina of the Metropolitan Opera House in the early 1950's and one of a very few black women to become prominent in American classical ballet, died on Wednesday in Fort Worth. She was 86 and lived there.

title: National Briefing: South
description: TENNESSEE: LOTTERY BILL PASSES The Legislature passed a bill on Thursday to create a lottery to finance education programs. The office of Gov. Phil Bredeson, a Democrat, said he would sign it, probably next week. Tennesseans voted in a referendum in November to remove the constitutional ban on a lottery. Tickets could be on sale by January. The state had been one of three that lacked legalized gambling. The others are Utah and Hawaii.    Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Olympics Park Blast Kills One, Injures 111
description: ATLANTA, July 27 - A pipe bomb spiked with nails and screws shattered the Summer Olympic Games today, transforming an international celebration of sport and fellowship into a symbol of the dark side of modern life.

title: A Romeo And Juliet Wreathed In Sorrow
description: The intimate duet was at the heart of Kenneth MacMillan's ballets, and this is true even in his ''Romeo and Juliet,'' the full-evening theatrical spectacle that returned in blazing glory to American Ballet Theater on Thursday night. Julio Bocca and Alessandra Ferri led the first of the season's 11 performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Closed South Dakota Gold Mine Is Selected for Underground Lab
description: A panel of mining engineers and geologists has unanimously selected a closed gold mine in South Dakota as the preferred site for a proposed underground laboratory, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Pastor Reaches Out With Suicide Line
description: FOR the Rev. Yukio Saito, reflecting on the suicide hot line he opened in Japan 30 years ago inevitably raises mixed feelings.

title: U.S. National Team Selects Three From the MetroStars
description: Sixteen players from Major League Soccer, including three from the MetroStars, were among the 23 selected today by the United States coach, Bruce Arena, for two international tournaments.

title: China Says SARS in Retreat; Canada Has Another Death
description: China has nearly tamed the SARS epidemic, with the number of new cases dwindling and no evidence that the disease has spread to the hinterlands as some experts had feared would happen, a senior Chinese health official said today.

title: Philippine Camps Are Training Al Qaeda's Allies, Officials Say
description: The southern Philippines has become the training center for Al Qaeda's Southeast Asia affiliate, Jemaah Islamiyah, drawing recruits from a number of countries, according to Western and Philippine officials.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Charges In Lawyer's Killing
description: The police charged a former top Protestant paramilitary with murder in the 1989 shooting death of Pat Finucane, a Roman Catholic lawyer whose killing is alleged to have been ordered by British security forces. The defendant, Ken Barrett, 40, denied the charge and issued a statement saying that he was a government scapegoat. An investigation by Britain's metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, concluded last month that the British authorities colluded with Protestant guerrillas to kill Roman Catholics during the province's sectarian conflict. Mr. Barrett was arrested in England on Wednesday, where he had told BBC television that the police ordered Mr. Finucane's killing. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: This Time, Nets Feel Ready For Final Step
description: After two days of rest, four days of scrimmages and countless hours speculating on the identity of their opponent in the N.B.A. finals, the Nets could officially focus today on their ultimate matchup of the season.

title: Corrections
description: The Revisions column in Weekend on May 16, about creating vital theater when staging revivals, misidentified the Wagner opera presented last season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a reduced form by the Eos Orchestra. It was ''Das Rheingold,'' not ''Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Tours Resume
description: Hyundai Asan, in charge of tours from South Korea to the resort area of Mount Kumkang in North Korea, said it would resume tours in early June. North Korea suspended the tours in April because of severe acute respiratory syndrome. Hyundai Asan said North Korea's Asia-Pacific Peace Committee approved resumption of the tours after the company promised ''strict examinations'' of all those joining the trip. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Monsanto Struggles Even as It Dominates
description: Monsanto should be thriving.

description: One of the world's most experienced groups headed the Women's Trials in Orlando, Fla., this week and will represent the United States in world championship play in Monte Carlo in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRUGMAN, , PAULA ALEXANDER
description: KRUGMAN--Paula Alexander, died May 28, 2003, suddenly, after a 20 year battle with cancer. Loving wife of Edward (Woody) and mother of Aaron. Devoted sister of Herbert Alexander, aunt of Jay David Alexander, Miriam Alexander Cogan, Ben-Zion Alexander, Daniel Alexander, Paul Culley, Luke Culley and Alex Culley. Great aunt of Adi, Omer, Rachel, and Roi. Beloved daughter-in-law of Herbert and Dorothy Krugman and sister-in-law of Laura Krugman Culley and Rachel Leah Alexander and the late Joyce (Rachel) Alexander. Cousin and friend of most of the known universe. Services Sunday, June 1, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment in the Kriegman Family Association Park at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Shiva will be observed Sunday through Thursday at the family residence. Donations may be made to the American Folk Art Museum or the Sisterhood of the Village Temple. >>AD#

title: With Wireless, English City Reaches Across Digital Divide
description: Three years ago, Shirley Hughes lived a life of dreary routine, collecting welfare checks, bringing up two children as a single mother, passing her evenings in front of the television.

title: Governors Cite Progress on a Medicaid Plan
description: A bipartisan team of governors appeared to make progress this week toward agreement on a comprehensive plan to revamp Medicaid. But powerful Democrats in Congress immediately urged Democratic governors to reject the deal, saying it would hurt poor people.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: White Worker Wins Bias Suit
description: A federal jury has awarded a white former social worker $85,000 in her racial discrimination suit against the state. The former social worker, Bertha Earnest of Okolona, said her regional director, who is black, discharged her after 15 years of work. Her position was filled with a black applicant, as were all further vacancies in her office in Chickasaw County, said her lawyer, James Waide of Tupelo. The state attorney general's office will appeal to reduce the damages, said Hunt Cole, the chief of civil litigation. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES, Lancaster, Pa., the nation's largest maker of vinyl flooring, said it had won court permission to seek creditors' support for its bankruptcy recovery plan, which would create a $1.8 billion trust fund to resolve its asbestos litigation.

title: Despite Casino Tax Issue, Warm Greetings for McGreevey
description: Out on the Boardwalk and inside Bally's casino, Gov. James E. McGreevey received a warm welcome today during his brief stop here for a political convention. Over the airwaves, however, the governor was met by a far harsher greeting -- a series of radio advertisements denouncing him and his plan to raise taxes on casinos.

title: Peter Lasko, 79, Ex-Director Of the Courtauld Art Institute
description: Peter Lasko, director of the Courtauld Institute of Art in London from 1974 to 1985, died on May 19. He was 79 and lived in Norwich, England.

title: Famed Psychiatric Clinic Abandons Prairie Home
description: In its best years, it was a pearl on the prairie, a place where bold ideas sprouted like cornstalks under the Midwestern sun, a name that meant the best that American psychiatry had to offer.

title: Bush in Europe
description: President Bush arrived in a Europe hopeful that the trans-Atlantic rift could be healed but skeptical about the administration's willingness to rebuild the European-American partnership.

title: A Budget Without Blinders
description: There may be a surprise awaiting New Yorkers when lawmakers finish closing a $3.8 billion budget gap: the city's finances may actually come into balance this time. While that had been the hoped-for outcome last year, the City Council and Mayor Michael Bloomberg served up a delusional plan that fell well short of addressing the fiscal crisis. Within weeks, the mayor had to issue a budget modification, and the first of the serious cutbacks began.

title: Powell Says U.S. Will Send Mediation Team to Mideast
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States would send an American ''coordination group'' to the Middle East to mediate between the Israelis and Palestinians on a new international peace plan after President Bush meets with leaders in the region next week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 20 about the source of the SARS virus misstated the typical timing of influenza outbreaks. Most occur in the winter in both the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. They do not occur in the summer in the Southern Hemisphere.

title: AOL Emerges With the Edge In the Truce With Microsoft
description: AOL Time Warner and Microsoft presented the agreement they announced Thursday as a new era of cooperation between two longtime rivals. But on closer inspection, the terms of the deal largely require Microsoft to cooperate with AOL while inviting AOL to reciprocate at its pleasure.

title: Report Said to Be Critical of Detentions Is Expected on Monday
description: A government report due to be released next week is expected to criticize the tactics and strategies the Justice Department used in detaining foreigners after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, officials said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Dragons Happy To Be on the Road
description: For the Arena League's New York Dragons, there is no place like the road.

title: Treffinger Pleads Guilty To Corruption
description: James W. Treffinger, the former Essex County executive, pleaded guilty today to several of the corruption charges that cut short his political career last year, when he was the leading Republican candidate for the United States Senate.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column yesterday about the government suspension of a newspaper in Belarus carried an erroneous signature. The writer was Steven Lee Myers.

title: In Connecticut, Pressure Is On to Close the 2004 Budget Gap
description: With only three weekdays left in this year's legislative session, Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, and the Democrats who control Connecticut's legislature remain about $350 million apart on a plan to close a $1 billion projected budget shortfall in fiscal 2004.

title: Suspect in '96 Olympic Bombing and 3 Other Attacks Is Caught
description: In a quiet end to one of the most intense manhunts in the nation's history, Eric Robert Rudolph, the fugitive charged with the fatal bombing at the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta and in bomb attacks at two abortion clinics and a gay nightclub, was arrested early today as he lurked behind a shopping center in a remote mountain town in western North Carolina.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Credit Card Consolidation
description: Kookmin Bank, the country's largest financial institution, said it would absorb the Kookmin Credit Card Company, an affiliate, merging the card company's operations into a separate credit card unit that is already a part of the bank. The decision, under consideration since last year, became final after the card company posted a loss of 360 billion won ($300 million) in the first quarter of this year. Kookmin Credit Card's 1,400 workers, fearful of job losses, went on strike, but investors approved. Share prices of the bank went up 9.3 percent on the Korea Stock Exchange while those of the card company were up 4 percent.

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the World Briefing column yesterday about the government suspension of a newspaper in Belarus carried an erroneous signature. The writer was Steven Lee Myers.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: STITCHES OUT An Iranian asylum-seeker who sewed up his eyes, mouth and ears and refused to eat or drink to object to his treatment by the British immigration authorities ended his protest, more than a week after it began and a day after the Home Office said it would no longer continue opposing his asylum application. The asylum seeker, Abas Amini, 33, a dissident and poet, spent six years in Iranian jails and was repeatedly tortured before coming to Britain in 2001. Mr. Amini, who lives in Nottingham and who drank a small amount of water after his stitches were removed by a nurse, told reporters that he would work on behalf of other asylum seekers. "I want to stay alive to continue the struggle," he said. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: The Lesson of Smalls, a Little Club With a Big Heart
description: In the common model for a jazz club in New York, the emphasis is on established musicians who have a new album, weeklong runs of a single band, a healthy bar business. (Something has to make up for those nights when four people show up.)

description: SPECTOR--Ruth. Please see notice listed today under ''Zirinsky.''

title: Along the River
description: The old Louisiana Territory is something that neither Jefferson nor his modern successors imagined. Vast as ever, but with a shrinking population, subdued yet wild, it is a region of contradictions.

title: Bush Visits Nazi Death Camps
description: President Bush and First Lady Laura Bush toured the Nazi death camps of Auschwitz and Birkenau on Saturday during a vist to Poland.

title: Ripple Effects of Trade Talks
description: Leaders of the world's richest nations will try this week to revive globalization.

title: Altering the Landscape
description: After a decade of construction, China closes the sluice gates of the Three Gorges Dam, forever altering the landscape of its historic heartland.
